title: Worlds Most Expensive Mint Julep Cup
description: If you watched the Kentucky Derby post position draw Wednesday on ESPN2, perhaps you caught a glimpse of the internationally famous sports artist LeRoy Neiman  how could you miss his mustache?  scribbling away in the crowd.

title: Jagrs Last Stand?
description: Aside from the injury to Sean Avery and the steep odds against a comeback from a 3-0 series deficit to the Penguins, the biggest issue hovering over the Rangers in Thursday nights Game 4 is whether or not it is Jaromir Jagrs last stand in New York.

title: Auction Seasons Highs and Lows
description: Carol Vogel picks the best and worst of the season.

title: Winding Up as a Season Winds Down
description: O.K., the first all-English Champions League final is less than three weeks away. It will be played in Moscows Luzhniki Stadium on May 21. (Note that the stadiums artificial turf, which was used for last years Euro 2008 qualifier between Russia and England, has been covered with the real thing for the match.) But there are some other loose ends around the globe, some that do not necessarily show the game at its best.

title: The End of the Gate, Not the End of the World
description: The fact that Big Brown will break from Post 20 doesnt change my perception of his chances in the Derby. Richard Dutrow Jr. is putting his colt out there for all to see. No excuses now; he cant get pinched between horses coming out of the gate, and chances are quite good that he wont get touched at all with the speedy Gayego, who breaks just inside, figuring to go quickly forward rather than sideways.

title: Into the Amazon
description: In the Amazon jungle in Ecuador, Nicholas D. Kristof encounters an unusual pair of activists who are fighting to preserve the rainforest.

title: Regents Park building getting luxury residential makeover
description: >Cornwall Terrace

title: Your Comments on Thursdays Amazon Column
description: My Thursday column (accompanied by this video) is the second part from the Ecuadorian Amazon, about the work of a remarkable American businessman and a former Amazonian hunter in promoting education in the region, as a way to raise living standards and preserve the rain forest. You can find more about their work  everything from their eco-lodge to their chocolate company  at the Yachana website.

title: More Workplace Lessons From the Canine Set
description: A few weeks ago, when I blogged about working alongside my new puppy, Sinatra, I asked readers to tell me about their experiences of working with dogs. (Please excuse my unintentional discrimination; I should have been more inclusive of the array of furry, and probably nonfurry, workplace companions out there.) I received many photos of pets engaged in adorable (or just lazy) antics around the office. But the most productive pet I heard about was Bella, the boxer, who is listed as director of goodwill at the public relations firm, Galvin Communications, in Portland, Ore.

title: Justice Dept. Will Share Interrogation Opinions
description: WASHINGTON  In a partial concession to Congressional pressure, the Bush administration agreed on Wednesday to show the Senate and House Intelligence Committees secret Justice Department legal opinions justifying harsh interrogation techniques that critics call torture.

title: Lacerated Spleen Sidelines Avery
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The news that Rangers forward Sean Avery had sustained a lacerated spleen and was hospitalized rippled through the Rangers practice Wednesday morning, another hurdle thrown in front of a team facing elimination in its playoff series against Pittsburgh.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,046 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Wednesday:

title: CURRENTS | A Chance to Shop Till You Help
description: Design on a Dime, the annual sale to benefit Housing Works thrift shops, which raise money for poor New Yorkers with H.I.V. or AIDS, begins next Thursday evening. All furnishings will be sold at 60 to 80 percent off retail, and vignettes will be created by 30 designers, including Jamie Drake, Thom Filicia and James Huniford. An opening-night cocktail party ($200 a ticket) will be an early opportunity to shop and to take part in a silent auction of photographs. Admission to the rest of the sale, on May 9 and 10, is free. At the Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street, housingworksauctions.com or (212) 645-8111.

title: The B.C.S. Takes a Pass, Again
description: For a system originally designed to produce a definitive winner, the Bowl Championship Series can't win.

title: Arizona Adds Digit to License Plates to Keep Up With Growth
description: As people have rushed to Arizona in the past decade like water to a drain, the state has faced problems familiar to bigger states  crowded schools, urban sprawl and jammed freeways.

title: Open-Toed Fetishes (and More)
description: ON the subway ride to Christian Louboutin, so far up the Upper East Side as to be in what I call Canada, I was getting my mind blown by Guy Debords Society of the Spectacle:

title: Step Right Up, Kids (and Thank the Dance Gods Youre Not Elephants)
description: With Jerome Robbinss death in 1998, roles in his ballets and shows began to be taken by performers who had never met him. Ten years later, weve already entered the era when his ballets are danced by those born after his lifetime. Enter the School of American Ballet.

title: Reprise: The Fifth Avenue Ballad of Pale Male and Lola
description: April is the cruelest month.

title: Door Keeper on 79th St. Keeps Stories of Queens
description: Daytime and evening shifts are busy ones for an Upper East Side doorman  hailing cabs, helping with luggage  but how does the late-night doorman pass the wee hours, once quiet descends upon the lobby?

title: A Beach Where Discretion Is More Than Just Advised
description: LONG BEACH TOWNSHIP, N.J.  The New Jersey surfer defies stereotype. He may work as a carpenter or as an eye surgeon. Could be in his 20s or late 50s. Hes able to rip the swell in water temperatures of 50 degrees for up to six hours, then hop on a one-speed bicycle with a board and steer one-handed. Or no-handed, while doing that signature thumb-and-pinky sign.

title: Pellicano on Pellicano: He Was No Mastermind
description: LOS ANGELES  Defiant and colorful to the end, the accused Hollywood wiretapper Anthony Pellicano told jurors in his racketeering trial Wednesday that he was no criminal mastermind but a diligent private eye and a lone ranger who deliberately kept his accomplices in the dark.

title: IPod Quandary: Fix or Replace?
description: Q. Is it possible to get a cracked iPod screen repaired for significantly less than what it would cost to just buy a new iPod? Are there other repair options besides Apple?

title: F.B.I. Questions Clemens Associate
description: The owner of a weight-loss center told a Houston television station that he was questioned on Monday by federal authorities investigating Roger Clemens for perjury.

title: No. 20 Post? Derby Favorites Handlers Say Sure
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  The confidence the connections to Big Brown have in their colt knows no bounds. Faced with making a choice from five remaining post positions, Big Browns trainer, Rick Dutrow, and the co-owner Mike Iavarone, chose what most would consider the worst slot of all: the one farthest outside, No. 20.

title: Returning to the Past and Finding the Bogeyman Is Still There
description: When Augusten Burroughs wrote Running With Scissors, he regaled readers with hilarious tales of the domestic craziness he endured while growing up. Now in another family memoir Mr. Burroughs makes a crazy move of his own. A Wolf at the Table is a portrait of the authors apparently maniacal and Augusten-hating father. Determinedly unfunny, awkwardly histrionic and sometimes anything but credible, it repudiates everything that put Mr. Burroughs on the map.

title: Gambling Back at WOR
description: John R. Gambling, who left WOR radio in New York in 2000, will return to the station with a morning show beginning at 5:30 on Monday, The Associated Press reported. His grandfather John B. Gambling began morning broadcasts on WOR shortly after the station went on the air in 1922, and his father, John A. Gambling, hosted the morning program until 1985, when John R. succeeded him before moving to WABC. WOR said the current morning hosts, Joe Bartlett and Donna Hanover, would remain at the station. Mr. Bartlett, as news director, will deliver the news on weekday mornings; and Ms. Hanover will serve as a film critic and substitute host. ... Randi Rhodes will now host the Randi Rhodes Show, to be broadcast weekdays, beginning on Monday, from 3 to 6 p.m. on XM 167. Ms. Rhodes ended her employment with Air America radio network last month after she was suspended when a video of her making disparaging remarks about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton surfaced on YouTube. In other radio news the Internet blogger and television personality Perez Hilton will deliver celebrity gossip when he joins Miss Jones in the Morning next week on the hip-hop radio station Hot 97 (WQHT-FM in New York), AllHipHop.com reported. The one-minute segments will be heard at 8.

title: Starbucks Reports 28% Drop in Profit and Trims Store Openings
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Facing an increasingly stingy consumer, Starbucks is tightening its belt.

title: Canada: Grocers Profit Climbs 15%
description: The Loblaw Companies, Canadas largest supermarket chain, reported an increase in first-quarter profit and said it planned to accelerate price and cost cuts to compete with Wal-Mart Stores. Net income climbed 15 percent, to 62 million Canadian dollars ($61.2 million), or 23 cents a share, from 54 million Canadian dollars, or 20 cents a share, a year earlier, when it recorded costs for cutting jobs. Sales rose 2.8 percent, to 6.53 billion Canadian dollars. The executive chairman, Galen G. Weston, said price cuts would continue this year as Loblaw tries to blunt Wal-Marts expansion into fresh foods across Canada.

title: Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island
Opening a Window on a Forgotten Work and Feeling That Fresh Air Rush In
description: Certain revolutions speak in small voices yet describe profound and sudden change. LHistoire du Soldat, Stravinskys traveling music-theater show, was one of them, saying  in few words and not that many notes  what music in 1918 no longer was and at the same time offering an alternative for what music might become.

title: Its Not Easy to Stick to Principles Devised for Farmers 141 Years Ago
description: STANFORD, N.Y.

title: Loss and Furor Take Toll on Obama, Poll Finds
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obamas aura of inevitability in the battle for the Democratic presidential nomination has diminished after his loss in the Pennsylvania primary and amid the furor over his former pastor, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: The F.D.A. and Heparin
description: To the Editor:

title: Trials and Triumphs on the Road to Justice
description: Its a safe bet that Thurgood is the only play on Broadway at which the announcement of a famous legal verdict is greeted by a burst of heartfelt applause.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Front Page

title: Man Threatens to Shoot Student
description: A distraught man held a pellet pistol to the head of a student on City Colleges campus in Harlem and threatened to shoot her and himself on Wednesday before the police persuaded him to drop the gun, the authorities said.

title: New York City
description: The season of house tours, garden tours and show houses is here, with oak doors and picket-fence gates swinging open for visitors.

title: How Will It Play in Apex?
description: You have to give Bill Clinton credit. Sure we think hes self-involved. But on Wednesday the former president of the United States was campaigning for his wife in North Carolina, making appearances at Apex, Sanford, Lillington, Dunn, Hope Mills, Lumberton and Whiteville. Following a 7:45 a.m. event in Apex, he was scheduled to discuss Solutions for America on the lawn in front of McSwain Extension Education and Agriculture Center.

title: Fed Cuts Rate but Hints About a Pause
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve, mixing concern about the feeble economy with worries about rising inflation, reduced short-term interest rates Wednesday for the seventh time since September, while signaling a pause in any additional rate cuts for now.

title: Federal Contracting Chief Is Forced Out
description: WASHINGTON  Lurita A. Doan has been forced out as head of the General Services Administration, the federal agency that oversees billions of dollars in contracts and manages thousands of government-owned buildings.

title: Closing Arguments in Suit on Veterans Mental Care
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The issue of whether veterans with mental health problems are neglected or whether their sheer numbers are overwhelming the system divided closing arguments on Wednesday in a class-action lawsuit in federal court here.

title: Boot Up for the Big Easy
description: The bipartisan group of bigwigs who choose the sites for presidential debates made the wrong choice when they rejected New Orleans bid. Now Google and YouTube are hoping to hold a forum, with questions zapped in over the Internet, and the sparring candidates seated proudly in New Orleans.

title: Reshaping Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloomberg Back on Radio
description: Listeners who had grown wistful for the cozy banter, consumer-friendly news announcements and occasional gaffes and malapropisms of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on his Friday call-in radio program with John Gambling have reason to celebrate. They will be able to tune in again starting next week, the mayor said Wednesday, though they will have to get up earlier to catch it.

title: Carey Holds at No. 1
description: Mariah Careys new E=MC2 (Island Def Jam), lost 61 percent of its sales in its second week out, but its still the No. 1 album in the country. It moved 182,000 copes, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bringing its two-week total to 645,000. Leona Lewiss Spirit (Syco/J) holds at No. 2 with 96,000, and the next three spot holders on the Billboard chart are new. The New Zealand musical-comedy duo Flight of the Conchords is No. 3 with its self-titled album on Sub Pop, which sold 52,000; Ashlee Simpsons third record, Bittersweet World (Geffen), is fourth with 47,000; and the alternative hip-hop duo Atmosphere had the best sales week of its more than decade-long career, reaching No. 5 with 36,000 sales of When Life Gives You Lemons ... (Rhymesayers). Down the chart, the country singer Phil Vassar bowed at No. 10 with 27,000 sales of Prayer of a Common Man (Universal South).

title: Law Professor Accuses Students of Defamation
description: For some law students, brass-knuckled litigation starts before they even finish school.

title: Whale Protection Caught in Agency Rivalry, Files Show
description: A federal plan to protect endangered whales along the East Coast has been caught in interagency warfare and held in limbo by the White House, according to documents made public on Wednesday by a Democratic congressman and an environmental group.

title: Is This the Worlds Cheapest Dress?
description: IF rock purists were unsettled last month by the opening of a designer boutique on the site of what once was CBGB, the hard-core Bowery nightclub, imagine how they will feel reading the next sentence: The old Tower Records space a few blocks away on Broadway, for two decades the spot for adolescent reveries of dance, pop and punk, has been leased by Steve & Barrys, a clothing chain where everything costs less than $10.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. I want to paint a room red. How can I make sure it will feel livable?

title: Features of Smartphone Without Smartphone Costs
description: If you are looking for many of the features of a smartphone but without the smartphone price, you might consider the Motorola Moto Z9. In addition to its phone functions, it makes digital photos, shoots video, has G.P.S. navigation, plays music and can have access to the Internet.

title: Six Votes, Then and Now
description: When the Senate passed the Civil Rights Act of 1964, only six Republicans voted with obstructionist Southern Democrats against the historic measure, which outlawed discrimination across a broad swath of American life.

title: Idol Judge Admits Rehearsal Guided Her
description: LOS ANGELES  Paula Abdul acknowledged on Wednesday what some American Idol viewers have long suspected: The shows judges sometimes see portions of the dress rehearsal for the show and use that to help formulate their comments on the evenings live performance.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about World Wrestling Entertainments comeback efforts misidentified the employer of Chris McCumber, who commented on the companys cable show W.W.E. Raw, and a correction in this space on Wednesday misstated his title. He works for USA Network, not World Wrestling Entertainment, and he is executive vice president  not senior vice president  for marketing, digital and brand strategy.

title: G.M. Invests in Second Ethanol Process
description: WASHINGTON  The General Motors Corporation announced on Thursday that it was hedging its bets on how best to make ethanol from non-grain sources, and making an investment in a second company with technology that might do that job cost-effectively.

title: CURRENTS | An Encore, Even Without Nine High Cs
description: Opera, Saul Steinbergs 1950s fabric, has just been reproduced by F. Schumacher & Company, the textiles manufacturer. Steinberg, best known for his New Yorker cartoons, was an opera buff who designed numerous stage sets, and this charming fabric was a favorite of both devotees of his cartoons and opera lovers. The new 68.5-inch-wide cotton fabric has a slightly larger printed pattern than the original version and is available with two background colors, aqua or natural, above. It is $94 a yard to the trade. Information and showroom locations: (800) 523-1200 or fschumacher.com.

title: Footnote
description: The 12-day Cannes Film Festival will open on May 14 with Blindness. Directed by the Brazilian Fernando Meirelles (City of God, The Constant Gardener), the film stars Julianne Moore as the only sighted person in a town where everyone else is mysteriously struck blind.

title: For Europes Middle-Class, Stagnant Wages Stunt Lifestyle
description: LES ULIS, France  When their local bakery in this town south of Paris raised the price of a baguette for the third time in six months, Anne-Laure Renard and Guy Talpot bought a bread maker. When gasoline became their biggest single expense, they sold one of their two cars.

title: CURRENTS | What Could Be Happier Than a Pig in Ceramic?
description: What do a foldable cutting board, plates resembling conversation bubbles and a soy sauce dispenser with a duck bill have in common? All are part of Destination: Japan, a new collection at the MoMA Design Stores that highlights the quirkier side of Japanese design. Many items are intended to elicit a laugh, like the silicone lid with a pig face ($18): put it over a pot while cooking, and steam comes out the snout. But they are also highly functional: the bottle opener in the shape of a pincer ($18) is Nambu cast iron; the spoon-fork ($12) is perfect for eating ramen noodles (and was originally designed for the popular Sugakiya restaurant chain). Available starting Thursday at momastore.org and, next week, in the stores, 81 Spring Street (Crosby Street), (646) 613-1367, and 44 West 53rd Street, (212) 767-1050.

title: CURRENTS | Not the Poster to Nail Up Over a Crack in the Plaster
description: Some 600 rare posters will be put on the block Sunday by Poster Auctions International. Jack Rennert, the companys president and the author of several books on poster art, predicted that some of the highest bidding will be inspired by an 1895 poster of Sarah Bernhardt, right, by Alphonse Mucha. He expects it to bring $25,000 to $30,000.

title: The Ore of Youth, Under Refinement
description: To see young dancers perform at the start of their careers is to see dance in a poignantly pure or raw state. They have not developed star personas or the practiced look of longtime corps dancers. The world is theirs, or so they hope. And the 123 Festival, which opened on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, offers a chance to see gifted youngsters on the brink of careers. All three participating companies  Taylor 2, Ailey II and ABT II  performed together on opening night but will have their own individual programs through May 11.

title: Live Bacteria to Keep the Cold Away
description: Athletes are often stricken by colds, due in part to the stress of hard training. But a recent study published in the British Journal of Sports Medicine suggests that high doses of probiotics, the "good bacteria" found in yogurt and some supplements, may protect against these annoying infections.

title: Microsoft Chief Set to Narrow Pursuit of Yahoo
description: Steven A. Ballmer, Microsofts chief executive, told employees on Thursday that the company would announce in very short order which of three paths it would choose in its three-month-old pursuit of Yahoo.

title: For Exxon Mobil, $10.9 Billion Profit Disappoints
description: Exxon Mobil, the worlds largest publicly traded oil company, said Thursday that its first-quarter net income rose 17 percent, boosted by surging oil prices.

title: An Oldies Marathon Runs a Few Extra Miles
description: NEW ORLEANS  Men whooped and hollered, rasped and preached. Women sassed, strutted, hurled accusations and wailed away tears. Guitars twanged and cackled, horns laughed, and drums pounded backbeats and chattered with funk. Tuesday was the first of two nights of the seventh annual Ponderosa Stomp, a party on its way to becoming an institution. The Ponderosa Stomp is an oldies marathon as dreamed up by record collectors: the kind of music fans who prize soul veterans rare B-sides and limited-edition garage-rock singles, the wilder the better.

title: A Rescued Goat Gets a Chance for a Normal Life
description: WOODSTOCK, N.Y.  They are both amputees: She lost part of her right leg to bone cancer at the age of 10, and he lost part of his left leg four months ago because of an injury he most likely suffered at a Brooklyn slaughterhouse.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 30, 2008

title: It Was a Dark Afternoon for the Daydreaming Mets
description: There was a man standing in shallow left field when a ball that had zipped down the third-base line toward the corner was retrieved and tossed back into the infield. This man was slim, and he was wearing a No. 7 jersey. That is the corporeal evidence that Jos Reyes was playing shortstop for the Mets against Pittsburgh during the second inning of their game Wednesday.

title: A Classroom Path to Entrepreneurship
description: The college campus, it turns out, can be an ideal incubator for hatching small businesses.

title: Prominent Green Group to Help Buyout Firm
description: Is private equity going green?

title: Starbucks Earnings Sink 21%
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Starbucks, faced with a sharp drop-off in customers, reported on Wednesday that earnings declined 21 percent during the second quarter.

title: Former D.N.C. Chairman Backs Obama
description: Joe Andrew, a superdelegate who was the Democratic National Committee chairman under President Bill Clinton, announced Thursday that he had switched his allegiance from Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton to Senator Barack Obama in the race for the presidential nomination.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about a genetic drug doping study in Sweden misspelled the surname of one of the researchers. He is Dr. Anders Rane, not Rhane.

title: Cycling Success Measured in Frequent-Flier Miles
description: EARLY last year, Dr. Jason Newland, a 34-year-old pediatric infectious disease physician from Stilwell, Kan., decided he would upgrade his Cannondale road bike to something more aerodynamically suited for triathlons, where riders must fight the wind on their own, without the pack shielding them. But instead of ambling into a local sports shop, Mr. Newland flew nearly 1,400 miles from Kansas City, Mo., to Waitsfield, Vt., where he bought a custom titanium and carbon Serotta Legend Ti from a specialty-fit studio called Fit Werx. The price: about $7,000, not including travel.

title: More Mothers Breast-Feed, in First Months at Least
description: About 77 percent of new mothers breast-feed their infants at least briefly, the highest rate seen in the United States in more than a decade, according to a government survey released on Wednesday.

title: Yossi Harel, Who, Defying British, Brought Jews to Palestine, Is Dead at 90
description: Yossi Harel, who renamed the rickety ship he commanded Exodus 1947 and sailed it to legend as a symbol of the righteousness of the mission by Jews to settle Palestine in the face of British opposition, died Saturday at his home in Tel Aviv. He was 90.

title: No Change Imminent for B.C.S. Format
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla.  After years of research and discussion, major college footballs top executives gathered here to finally have a formal discussion about changing the sports controversial and polarizing postseason format.

title: James Day, Public Television Host, Dies at 89
description: James Day, a former president of Channel 13 in New York, an early executive of public television station KQED in San Francisco and an on-air interviewer for many years, died last Thursday in Manhattan. He was 89 and lived in Manhattan.

title: New York, True to Mayors Promise, Slashes City Parking Permits
description: The Police Department gave up about 20,000 of the citys coveted parking placards. The Fire Department lost more than 2,000. The mayors office gave up 163.

title: Today in Business
description: THE ECONOMY STAGNATES ...Consumer spending advanced by only 1 percent in the first quarter, as Americans cut back on a wide variety of discretionary purchases.

title: Status: Looking for Work on Facebook
description: AS anyone who has ever received a virtual Jagerbomb or fought off intergalactic cyber chickens knows, social-networking sites are designed to be entertaining. If there wasnt so much fun to be had, there wouldnt be so many articles warning that what you post on your profile  i.e., photos of you in a beer helmet and a tequila bandolier  could one day cost you a job.

title: Fund Set for Minneapolis Bridge Collapse Victims
description: Minnesota legislators announced on Friday that they had reached an agreement on a $38 million plan to compensate victims of the highway bridge that collapsed last August in Minneapolis, killing 13 people and injuring 145.

title: Hoosier Time
description: With just days to go before the Indiana and North Carolina primaries, the Op-Ed page asked writers from each state to report on the race. Here are their first dispatches.

title: Sharing Your iPod Tunes Without Those Tangled Earbuds
description: Since the iPod has no built-in speaker, sharing a song or video with a friend can often mean becomong tangled up in swapped headphones. If snarled earbud cords are cutting into your communal listening pleasure, theres the iFrogz Audiowrapz silicone case for the third-generation iPod Nano. It has a set of speakers right on the front.

title: In a New Climate Model, Short-Term Cooling in a Warmer World
description: After decades of research that sought, and found, evidence of a human influence on the earths climate, climatologists are beginning to shift to a new and similarly daunting enterprise: creating decade-long forecasts for climate, just as meteorologists routinely generate weeklong forecasts for weather.

title: A Run on Rice in Asian Communities
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Along Stockton Street, the bustling heart of Chinatown, there is no lack of eye-popping products and equally eye-popping prices paid for them. Dried toad goes for $42 a ounce, deer tail about $350 apiece, and abalone $428 a pound, a Mothers Day special.

title: Pizza and Pop Lift Fox
description: Pizza night on Hells Kitchen and the start of Neil Diamond week on American Idol lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Tuesday. Nielsen estimated that 24.4 million viewers tuned in to watch the five remaining Idol contestants square off at 8 p.m. After Idol, Foxs Hells Kitchen delivered 12.3 million viewers, the largest audience ever in the series three-year history. The cooking competition led the 9 p.m. time slot among adults 18 to 49, but trailed ABCs Dancing With the Stars in total viewers in the hour (16.7 million). Despite its edge at 9, ABC ranked third over all, struggling early in the night with two episodes of According to Jim, each averaging around 4 million viewers. CBS won second place, thanks to NCIS at 8 (14.6 million) and Shark at 9 (10.3 million). NBC was fourth for the night, despite leading the 10 p.m. hour with Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (12.1 million), which easily outpaced both ABCs Womens Murder Club on ABC (8.1 million) and a rerun of CSI on CBS (7.6 million).

title: The Pentagons Message, and Ours: 5 Analysts Reply
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Forces Out G.S.A. Chief
description: WASHINGTON  Lurita A. Doan has been forced out as head of the General Services Administration, the federal agency that oversees billions of dollars in contracts and manages thousands of government-owned buildings.

title: Pakistani Parties Weigh Reinstating Judges
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Leaders of Pakistans governing coalition are holding crucial talks in Dubai over whether to restore the high court judges ousted by President Pervez Musharraf in November, an issue that had badly strained relations between the coalition partners and even threatens to break them apart.

title: Hard Times, but Your Lips Look Great
description: LAST month, Betsy Stein made a beeline for Bloomingdales to buy a shirt, but the Nanette Lepore top she found was $280. Ms. Stein, 33, a business manager for a classical music composer in Manhattan, told herself that in the current economic climate, she shouldnt charge it.

title: France: Drug Maker Posts a Decline
description: Sanofi-Aventis, the French drug maker, said first-quarter profit fell 12 percent, hurt by generic competition to the Ambien sleeping pill and by the decline of the dollar. Net income dropped to 1.86 billion euros ($2.9 billion), or 1.41 euros a share, from 2.12 billion euros, or 1.57 euros a share, a year earlier. Revenue fell 3.3 percent, to 6.94 billion euros. Sales of Ambien, which lost patent protection a year ago, fell 65 percent, countering higher revenue from the Lantus diabetes medicine and the Lovenox anticlotting drug.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Schedule information on Friday with a film review of Standard Operating Procedure, using information from a publicist, misstated the date the film opens in Los Angeles. It is this Friday; it did not open last Friday. (That is when it opened in New York.)

title: Attacks in Pakistan Rising, State Department Reports
description: WASHINGTON  Terrorist attacks against noncombatants more than doubled in Pakistan from 2006 to 2007, reflecting the growing violence in the countrys turbulent tribal areas and new bombings against Pakistani government officials and security services, according to a report released Wednesday by the State Department.

title: After Break With Ex-Pastor, Obama Tries to Move On
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Senator Barack Obama sought on Wednesday to set aside the controversy over his former pastor, the Rev. Jeremiah Wright Jr., and steer the conversation in the Democratic presidential campaign back to the economy.

title: New Jersey
description: The season of house tours, garden tours and show houses is here, with oak doors and picket-fence gates swinging open for visitors.

title: Venerable Classical-Music Magazine Plans to Add Online Sales to Its Reviews
description: Gramophone  the leading classical music magazine in the world, 85 years old and based in London  plans to allow readers to buy CDs and downloads from its Web site. This means that it may profit from recordings on which it is passing critical judgment.

title: Afghans See Link to Qaeda in Plot to Shoot Karzai
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The attempt to kill President Hamid Karzai on Sunday was the work of militants who had infiltrated Afghanistans security forces and had ties to groups linked to Al Qaeda in Pakistans tribal areas, the Afghan intelligence chief said Wednesday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A theater review on Monday about The Country Girl, at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, misidentified the singer in one of the recordings played between scenes. The singer is Perry Como  not Bing Crosby, who starred in a film version of the play.

title: Free Madonna Show? Only for Die-Hard Fans
description: The first ones lined up at 10 a.m. Monday. They brought Madonna memorabilia and warm clothes. Some had candy earrings in tribute to their heroines new album, Hard Candy (Warner Brothers), which went on sale Tuesday. They were outside the Roseland Ballroom on West 52nd Street in Manhattan, and the lucky ones would get free tickets to Madonnas promotional show there. For this event Roseland had a capacity of 2,200, which by Madonnas standards is as intimate as a basement club. At 6 a.m. on Wednesday 750 fans received wristbands entitling them to free tickets that night. But by noon a hundred or so still had not left; they just had to be the first to walk inside. I told my bosses I was going to take four days off, said Juan Romani, 34, of Pawcatuck, Conn., who was near the front of the line. When I told them what I was doing, they thought I was crazy. But its Madonna.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on April 22 about the rising financial risks facing farmers misstated the length of time that certain futures contracts have been available on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat and corn futures contracts were first listed in 1877 and soybean futures in 1936; the futures contracts were not introduced in 1959 .

title: The Heisman Trophy Moves Into Its New Home
description: The 80-pound statue was lugged a short distance Wednesday from a safe at its temporary home on Battery Place to its permanent dwelling. The original, nearly 73-year-old Heisman Trophy, tarnished by time and reverent rubbing, was then hoisted upon a wooden pedestal by two of its past winners  Pete Dawkins and Mike Rozier  at the $93 million Sports Museum of America, which will open next week in Lower Manhattan.

title: Los Angeles Police Expect Calm at Immigration Rally
description: LOS ANGELES  A day before thousands are expected to converge here as part of the annual May Day pro-immigration rallies nationwide, police officials said Wednesday that new technology, training for officers and better communication would prevent a repeat of the melee that concluded demonstrations in Los Angeles last year.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Sports of The Times column on Tuesday, about a football scheduling dispute between Rutgers and Notre Dame, referred incorrectly to Air Force and Navy, which joined Rutgers and some private universities among the football leaders in a recent N.C.A.A. academic report. They are public institutions, not private.

title: Iraq Team to Discuss Militias With Iran
description: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi prime minister is sending several senior Shiite leaders to Tehran to discuss their concerns that Iran is arming and financing militias in Iraq, senior Iraqi and American officials said Wednesday.

title: Fewer Latino Immigrants Sending Money Home
description: In a sign that the economic downturn is hitting hard among Latino immigrants, more than three million of them stopped sending money to families in their home countries during the last two years, the Inter-American Development Bank said on Wednesday.

title: Cablevision Set to Raise the Stakes in Newsday Bidding
description: Cablevision is preparing a $650 million offer for Newsday, $70 million more than bids by Rupert Murdoch and Mortimer B. Zuckerman, while the owners of The New York Observer have dropped out of the bidding, people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

title: Fewer Latino Immigrants Send Money Home
description: More than three million Latin American immigrants in the United States, responding to the economic downturn and new uncertainties about their future, have stopped sending money home to their families in the last two years, according to a survey released on Wednesday by the Inter-American Development Bank in Washington.

title: Operation Went Great, and Woods Expects Quick Recovery
description: After a two-week checkup on his surgically repaired left knee, Tiger Woods said Wednesday that his doctors believed the arthroscopic surgery was successful and he should be able to return to competition within the four-to-six-week timetable that was set immediately after the April 15 operation.

title: The Yanks Add Hughes to the Disabled List
description: By Wednesday, it was obvious to the Yankees that Phil Hughes needed something to change. He is 0-4 with a 9.00 earned run average, a discouraging showing for the youngest pitcher in the majors.

title: Race Is No Longer Off the Beaten Track
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  When Smarty Jones showed up at Oaklawn Park in Hot Springs, Ark., to prepare for the 2004 Kentucky Derby, some people might have wondered what he was doing there. Hot Springs was known for its mineral baths, for its barbecue joints, for being the former home of Bill Clinton, and also as the place where 3-year-olds started on the road to obscurity.

title: British Bank Offers an Optimistic Outlook
description: LONDON  The British central bank suggested Thursday that the credit crisis was easing, saying markets have taken an unnecessarily pessimistic view about losses that will ultimately be felt by banks and the wider economy.

title: What Would You Drive, if the Taxpayers Paid?
description: Representative Anthony D. Weiner, Democrat of Brooklyn and Queens, drives a 2008 Chevrolet Impala, leased for $219 a month. Representative Michael R. McNulty, a Democrat from the Albany area, gets around in a 2007 Mercury Mariner hybrid, a sport utility vehicle, for $816 a month.

title: Slower Consumer Spending Hits Home Depot
description: Home Depot, the nations largest home improvement chain, said Thursday in a statement that it was dropping plans to open 50 stores and would close 15 poorly performing locations, becoming the latest retail victim of the slowdown in consumer spending.

title: Microsofts Board Meets on Yahoo Bid
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Microsofts directors met Wednesday to discuss how to proceed with the companys attempted takeover of Yahoo, according to a person briefed on the discussions.

title: Palestinians Agree to Plan for Truce With Israel
description: Palestinian groups agreed in Cairo to an Egyptian proposal for a truce with Israel, the official Egyptian news agency MENA reported. The truce would apply first to Gaza and later to the West Bank, the agency said. Hamas, the Islamic group that controls Gaza, has already agreed to the proposal. Its rival, Fatah, has given its support. Egypt is expected to seek Israels response next week. Israeli officials are wary, saying that Hamas will use any truce period to build up its strength. But they also say Israel will have no reason to act in Gaza if the groups cease their fire.

title: Turnaround Under Way, G.M. Is Still Bleeding Cash
description: DETROIT  Three years into its turnaround plan, General Motors has greatly improved its primary business  selling cars  yet money keeps flowing out of the company by the billions.

title: Quintet of Calming Strings and a Rumbling Clarinet
description: Too much time and ink have been spent talking about how challenging, rigorous and difficult Elliott Carters music is, and not nearly enough on how lively, vigorous and even funny it can be. The playful qualities outnumbered potential hazards on Tuesday night in the Peter Jay Sharp Theater at the Juilliard School, when the Juilliard String Quartet and the clarinetist Charles Neidich offered the premiere of Mr. Carters Clarinet Quintet.

title: Even Less Help in Hard Times
description: The troubled economy could soon create a major fiscal crisis for the state-run Medicaid and childrens health programs that would only be exacerbated by the Bush administrations efforts to cut these programs back. Congress must provide temporary aid to the most beleaguered states and find a permanent way to protect Medicaid and childrens health programs from wrenching cuts every time a recession hits.

title: Despite Some Bumps, Snedeker Enjoys Ride
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Brandt Snedeker stands out in a crowd with no apparent effort. He has a shock of blond curls that spills out from beneath his visor, and a whimsical smile that constantly tugs at the corners of his mouth. He moves with a brisk pace that is somehow unhurried, with an upright bearing free of posturing.

title: Brooklyn Councilmans Funds for a Group He Founded Were Blocked
description: The first chance he had to spend the discretionary funds that City Council members control, Mathieu Eugene directed $45,000 last year to a nonprofit Brooklyn group that was close to his heart: a youth sports and mentoring program he had founded and headed until his election.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about criticism of West Virginia University for awarding the daughter of the states governor a masters degree she did not earn misattributed quotations suggesting that the universitys president accept responsibility for errors in judgment and inform the governors daughter of the panels recommendation and of the decision that her degree was inappropriately granted. The quotations were from a statement by the universitys board of governors, not from a report by an independent panel investigating the incident.

title: Firing Puts New Coach in Crowded Marketplace
description: Avery Johnson was fired by the Dallas Mavericks on Wednesday, and Mike DAntoni clung loosely to his job in Phoenix  their fates underscoring that success is no guarantee of security for N.B.A. head coaches.

title: Can We Be as Smart as Bats?
description: IN THE AMAZON JUNGLE, Ecuador

title: Belarus Expels 10 U.S. Diplomats
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department reacted angrily on Thursday to the expulsion of 10 American diplomats by Belarus, a former Soviet Republic widely regarded as having one of the worlds most repressive governments.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Solemnity of the Ascension, also known as Ascension Thursday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Senate Says McCain Is Qualified
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Wednesday delivered its judgment on a constitutional question involving one of its own and formally declared that Senator John McCain is eligible to be president  at least from a citizenship perspective.

description: Following is the full text of the statement released Wednesday by the Federal Reserve:

title: Gordon Bradley, Who Nurtured U.S. Soccer, Dies at 74
description: Gordon Bradley, a native of England who was a pioneering figure in American soccer and the first to sign with the New York Cosmos, as a player and as a coach, died Tuesday in Manassas, Va. He was 74.

title: For a Day, the Giants Are Washingtons Favorite Team
description: WASHINGTON  The Giants had one more play to run to complete their championship season. When the band outside the White House started New York, New York, players and coaches filed out of a door in two lines, then down opposite curving stairways, pageantlike, toward the South Lawn, where President Bush awaited.

title: U.S. Sues Alabama Mayor in Bond Deals
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  An Alabama investment banker gave more than $156,000 to Mayor Larry P. Langford in undisclosed payments while Mr. Langford was arranging millions of dollars in fees for the bankers firm, the Securities and Exchange Commission said in a lawsuit on Wednesday.

title: H.P. Unveils New Memory Technology
description: A team of Hewlett-Packard scientists reported Wednesday in the science journal Nature that they have designed a simple circuit element they believe will enable tiny powerful computers that could imitate biological functions.

title: How to Amplify Those Fading Bars
description: WHATS the hottest amenity in high-rise apartments these days? Five bars on your cellphone.

title: TV Dramas Feel Brunt of Strike Fallout
description: The writers strike is over, but the damage apparently is not.

title: Adopting Meters, Washington Ends Taxi Zone System
description: WASHINGTON  Over the objections of cabdrivers, the District of Columbia is set on Thursday to scrap its seven-decade-old method of calculating taxi fares. Conventional time-and-distance meters will replace a system based on geographic zones.

title: In Inner Mongolia, Pushing Architectures Outer Limits
description: Ordos, China

title: Home and Garden Calendar
description: Images, New York City

title: Sickened by the Office (Really)
description: FOR Patty Mulcahy, it began with itchy eyes. They started to water two years ago when renovation began on the Midtown office building where she was working as an assistant at a television network. By the fifth day, after 30,000 square feet of new carpeting had been glued in place, the redness and swelling became unbearable. She ended up in the emergency room.

title: Pittsburghs Dynastic Duo
description: Is this the next great dynasty? That is the only logical reaction after seeing the brilliance of Sidney Crosby, 20, and Evgeni Malkin, 21, in the same uniform or, good grief, on the same power-play unit.

title: A Strained Wright-Obama Bond Finally Snaps
description: Late Monday night, in the Carolina Inn in Chapel Hill, N.C., Barack Obamas long, slow fuse burned to an end. Earlier that day he had thumbed through his BlackBerry, reading accounts of the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr.s latest explosive comments on race and America. But his remarks to the press this day had amounted to a shrug of frustration.

title: Of Affirmed and Other Homestretch Heroes
description: Saturday's Kentucky Derby launches this year's Triple Crown series, with a reputedly weak field and no credible candidate to sweep all three races. That leaves us to fall back on memory, to 30 years ago, when Affirmed became the last horse to accomplish racing's greatest feat. He did it in breathtaking fashion, outdueling his great rival Alydar by the thinnest of margins in all three races. None of the victories was more exciting than the final leg at the Belmont Stakes, a race that, as Steve Cady reported for The Times, was "the kind of close-combat struggle that demonstrated why humans have been so fascinated by thoroughbred race horses for centuries."

title: Tip of the Week: Searching for Text in Firefox
description: Want an even faster way than pressing Control-F to search for text on a Web page in the Firefox browser? Just tap the forward-slash key (the same key as the question mark) to open the Quick Find box at the bottom of the browser window, then type in your search terms.

description: Solebury, Pa.

description: Optimism is in the air again at the Whitney Museum of American Art, which has just released a preliminary design by the Italian architect Renzo Piano for its proposed satellite museum downtown.

title: With Two Aces Against a Slam, What to Lead?
description: Look at the West hand in the diagram and at the auction. What would you lead against six hearts?

title: Three Young Performers, Showing Their Skills
description: The estimable Young Concert Artists series has been providing talented young musicians with the chance to perform on notable stages since 1961, when it was founded by the energetic Susan Wadsworth. The association has a gilded track record, having promoted artists like Jean-Yves Thibaudet, Emanuel Ax, Richard Goode and Dawn Upshaw. Many more recent discoveries have also proved worthy.

title: Politics and the Economy Occupy Ad Agencies
description: DANA POINT, Calif.

title: Yanks Finish April Under .500 and Under Siege From Injuries
description: There are 25 players on a major league roster, and at this rate, the Yankees will be all out by Memorial Day. They have placed a prominent player on the disabled list in each of the last three days, ending a difficult month with a thud.

title: Council Approves Rezoning of 125th Street, Over Loud Protests of Some Spectators
description: The boos and cries of sellout and liar came so loudly and persistently that the entire audience was removed. But in the end, the City Council overwhelmingly approved a plan on Wednesday to rezone 125th Street in Harlem.

title: Reading Program Is Called Ineffective
description: President Bushs $1 billion a year initiative to teach reading to low-income children has not helped improve their reading comprehension, according to a Department of Education report released on Thursday.

title: As Euro Nears 10, Cracks Emerge in Fiscal Union
description: FRANKFURT  The euro turns 10 next January, a milestone that will be marked with celebratory speeches, inch-thick scholarly papers and a commemorative 2-euro coin, designed by a Greek sculptor. It was chosen from five candidates in an online poll of European residents.

title: Delays in $4 Billion Brooklyn Development Are Challenged in Tenants Lawsuit
description: The ever-lengthening timeline for completing the $4 billion Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn is not just bad news for those who hoped to see the projects basketball arena, office towers and apartment blocks completed quickly.

title: Pennsylvania, Delaware and Maryland
description: The season of house tours, garden tours and show houses is here, with oak doors and picket-fence gates swinging open for visitors.

title: McCain Health Plan Could Mean Higher Tax
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa.  Though Senator John McCain has promised to not raise taxes, his campaign acknowledged Wednesday that the health plan he outlined this week would have the effect of increasing tax payments for some workers, primarily those with high incomes and expensive health plans.

title: Corzine Aide Resigns After Testifying in the Corruption Trial of a Hudson County Mayor
description: A top aide to Gov. Jon S. Corzine who had testified he passed a questionable payment from a bar owner to a mayor in Hudson County resigned on Wednesday, the governors office said.

title: First Tibetan Death in Unrest Reported by China
description: BEIJING  A gun battle in a rural area of northwest China this week left a police officer and a Tibetan dead, according to state-run news media.

title: Germany: Catch the Next Iceberg Out of Town
description: Knut, the Berlin Zoo polar bear cub abandoned by his mother, was a sensation a year ago, a ball of white fluff who seduced the world. Now, as he has grown into a 350-pound adolescent, too big and strong to play with his handler, newspapers have taken issue with everything from Knuts weight to his sexuality, with one newspaper asking if the bear is gay. But the most enduring question is the one posed from the beginning: how would being hand-raised by humans affect him? With Knut, its clear that he has imprinted on humans, and when neither his keeper nor visitors are there, he cries out, said Thomas Pietsch, a biologist. Peter H. Arras, a zoologist, put it more succinctly: Hes a psychopath addicted to human attention. That attention has fallen off significantly. On a recent afternoon, the fading star lay with his head on his paws, his fur stained from rolling around in sand and dirt. Is that Knut? a group of teenagers asked. Told that it was, they looked disappointed. Oh, one said, and barely a minute later, they were gone.

title: While Clinton Focuses, Obama Is Distracted
description: LAFAYETTE, Ind.  Pumped up and focused, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is putting in 16-hour days in Indiana this week as if she  and not her embattled rival, Senator Barack Obama  needs a campaign-changing moment in Tuesdays primary here.

title: Producers Group Pessimistic on Labor Talks With Actors
description: LOS ANGELES  A bargaining group for Hollywoods largest movie and television companies on Wednesday told its members, in effect, not to expect a breakthrough in stalled talks with the Screen Actors Guild before their scheduled end on Friday.

title: States Limit Costly Sites for Cancer Radiation
description: Seeking to rein in medical costs, a commission in Michigan on Wednesday moved to prevent hospitals in the state from each spending $100 million or more to provide a new form of radiation treatment for cancer.

title: Canadians Investigate Death of Ducks at Oil-Sands Project
description: OTTAWA  Canadian federal and provincial government officials were conducting an investigation Wednesday into Syncrude Canada, a large oil-sands project operator, after hundreds of migrating ducks that landed in a company tailings pond died.

title: Dressing Up, Win, Place or Show
description: THERE are no rules here, Cathy Miller said from her home in Lexington, Ky., where on Tuesday she was wrapping up a two-week trunk show of designer clothes for the wealthy owners of horse farms in anticipation of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday in Louisville.

title: Protecting Alaska
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A music review on Tuesday about a concert by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, which included three works by the composer Joan Tower, misstated the name of the town where she lives and was recuperating from an injury instead of taking part in a preconcert conversation. It is Red Hook, N.Y., not Red Bank.

title: Wright Remains a Concern for Some Democrats
description: Senator Barack Obama picked up several endorsements by Democratic superdelegates on Wednesday in his presidential campaign, as some party leaders tried to assess the damage done to his candidacy by the controversy over his former pastor, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr.

title: A Student of Kicking Passes a Test and Lands in the N.F.L.
description: Like a lot of football kickers, Benjamin Datos journey to the sport began on a soccer field.

title: Hey, Kids, Free Comics!
description: Saturday is Free Comic Book Day, the annual industry promotion that allows visitors at participating stores to pick up a variety of comic books at no cost. The titles run from Jughead and All-Star Superman to X-Men and Sonic the Hedgehog. Dark Horse Comics is offering Hellboy/B.P.R.D., which looks into the nightmares of the title hero as well as the background of the Bureau for Paranormal Research and Defense. Virgin Comics, in collaboration with the Sci Fi Channel, is giving away The Stranded, about aliens secretly embedded with human families. It is being developed into a pilot for the network. Information is available at freecomicbookday.com, which gives a store locater, a list of free titles and a schedule of appearances by creators. In other comic book news, the Flash, who died in 1985, is alive again. He was resurrected on Wednesday in DC Universe No. 0, a 50-cent comic, which is a primer for Final Crisis  the latest big story line that will affect Superman, Wonder Woman, Batman and other DC heroes.

title: An Ambulatory Arbor
description: Q. I want a flowering arbor for a mid-October wedding on the southern coast of Maine, but cant erect a permanent structure. Could I grow Sweet Autumn clematis in large pots next to a lightweight arbor at home and then move everything? Or would you recommend some other flowering focus?

title: China Says Abusive Child Labor Ring Is Exposed
description: SHANGHAI  China said Wednesday that it had broken up a child labor ring that forced children from poor, inland areas to work in booming coastal cities, acknowledging that severe labor abuses extended into the heart of its export economy.

title: The Gas-Guzzler Gambit
description: Senators John McCain and Hillary Rodham Clinton have hit on a new way to pander to American voters: a temporary suspension of the federal gasoline tax between Memorial Day and Labor Day. The proposal may draw applause and votes from Americans feeling the pain of nearly $4-a-gallon gasoline. But it is an expensive and environmentally unsound policy that would do nothing to help American drivers.

title: Immigrants Challenge U.S. System of Detention
description: Immigrants who spent time in detention while fighting deportation filed a federal suit on Wednesday against Michael Chertoff, secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, demanding that the agency issue legally enforceable regulations for its detention centers.

title: TV Images to Dazzle the Jaded
description: Modern tech life teems with longstanding quandaries, questions that never seem to go away. Mac or Windows? Turn off the computer every night or let it sleep? Plasma or L.C.D.?

description: The season of house tours, garden tours and show houses is here, with oak doors and picket-fence gates swinging open for visitors.

title: Texas Reports Added Signs of Abuse at Sects Ranch
description: At least 41 children seized from a polygamist ranch in West Texas in April have had broken bones, and some young boys may have been sexually abused, Texas officials said Wednesday.

description: With just days to go before the Indiana and North Carolina primaries, the Op-Ed page asked writers from each state to report on the race. Here are their first dispatches.

description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Appeals Court Rejects Citys Suit to Curb Guns
description: A federal appeals court threw out New York Citys longstanding lawsuit against the gun industry on Wednesday, ruling that a relatively new federal law protects gun makers against such suits.

title: Yale Students' New Art
description: Aliza Shvarts, the Yale University student whose senior art project created a frenzy last month has submitted a different work to the senior thesis exhibition, The Yale Daily News reported. Ms. Shvartss original work supposedly included documentation of repeated artificial inseminations and induced miscarriages. The university has said that it found no evidence to back up Ms. Shvartss story. It also would not allow her to show that work in a campus art exhibition unless she admitted that it was a fiction, which she did not do.

title: French Premier to Seek Common Fiscal Policy in U.S.
description: PARIS  The French prime minister, Franois Fillon, is using his May 1 holiday to travel to Washington, where he will try to decipher American economic policy and build a common approach to meet growing concerns in both countries about market instability and the weak dollar.

title: A Mailbox Full of Paper Clips
description: Q. Since I got my PC repaired, all of my e-mail messages show a paper-clip icon, indicating an attachment  even when there isnt one. Is there any way I can fix this, so that only messages with actual attachments will show the paper clip?

title: For Madonna Fans, the Wait Is Worth It
description: Halfway through her 32-minute set on Wednesday night at the Roseland Ballroom in Manhattan, Madonna offered a message of sympathy.

title: Agency Floats a Proposal to Help With Home Loans
description: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration and Congress reacted coolly to a new $50 billion proposal by the head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to permit the Treasury Department to lend directly to as many as a million homeowners to help ease the housing crisis.

title: H.P. Reports Big Advance in Memory Chip Design
description: Hewlett-Packard scientists reported Wednesday in the science journal Nature that they have designed a simple circuit element that they believe will make it possible to build tiny powerful computers that could imitate biological functions.

title: Consumer Spending Stagnates as Prices Rise
description: Consumer spending barely budged in March, the fourth lackluster month as Americans grappled with higher food and energy prices amid an economic downturn.

title: NATO Accuses Russia of Stirring Tensions in Rebel Georgia Areas
description: BRUSSELS  NATO escalated its protests on Wednesday over Russian policy toward Georgias breakaway Abkhazia region, accusing Moscow of stirring tensions by announcing plans to increase the number of Russian soldiers there.

title: Rise in Minorities Is Led by Children, Census Finds
description: Since 2000, members of racial and ethnic minorities have become a majority of youngsters under 15 in two of the nations fastest-growing states, Florida and Nevada, with Georgia, Maryland and New York poised to follow, according to census data released on Wednesday.

title: Romes Mayor Plans to Raze Meier Museum
description: In his first news conference as Romes newly elected mayor, Gianni Alemanno announced on Wednesday that he would tear down a museum designed by Richard Meier. Built to showcase a first century B.C. altar that honored the military triumphs of the Roman emperor Augustus, the Ara Pacis Museum opened in 2006 to considerable criticism. (The New York Timess architecture critic, Nicolai Ouroussoff, called the building a flop and a major disappointment.) Mr. Alemanno said that getting rid of the large structure was not a top priority, but that his administration would review all the recent architectural projects in Rome. Built mostly in glass and travertine, the museum was the first important civic building completed in central Rome since Mussolinis time. Mr. Alemanno had promised to dismantle the imposing structure if elected.

title: Zimbabwe: Army Accused of Terror Campaign
description: Human Rights Watch accused the army of providing supporters of ZANU-PF, the governing party, with arms and trucks for a campaign of violence against the opposition Movement for Democratic Change. The groups researchers said witnesses and others had told them that party agents had set up camp at an army barracks in Manicaland Province and were mounting raids on the homes of the opposition riding in army trucks and armed with guns supplied by the army. A spokesman for the Movement for Democratic Change said that 20 of its members had been killed by pro-government militias since the election on March 29. The authorities have yet to announce who won the presidential election. Independent monitors say it was won by the opposition. The opposition and civic groups have charged that the military has taken a leading role in seeking to ensure that ZANU-PF remain in power and have described events since the election as a slow-motion military coup. Western diplomats have openly questioned whether President Robert Mugabe, in power for 28 years, is still in charge.

title: CURRENTS | Richard Neutras Home Seeks a Down Payment on Its Future
description: Richard Neutras residence in the Silver Lake area of Los Angeles was given to California State Polytechnic University, Pomona, by the Neutra family in 1990. But recently the university, which is financially pressed, announced that unless private financing is found to sustain the house, it may have to be sold.

title: A Confrontation on Costas Now Worthy of a Blog
description: If the sports blogosphere needed someone to symbolize the mainstream medias fear and suspicion of its influence, it found him in Buzz Bissinger on Tuesday night on a live, 90-minute edition of Costas Now on HBO. Bissinger, the author of Friday Night Lights and other bestsellers, stepped forward fulminating during a 16-minute discussion with Will Leitch of Deadspin.com and Braylon Edwards of the Cleveland Browns.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Apr. 25 through Apr. 29 with 1,065 adults throughout the United States.

title: Custom Fitting Just a Flight Away
description: Paying $2,000 to $20,000 for custom-fit bikes is no longer enough for dedicated amateur cyclists. As The Times reports today, these enthusiasts are traveling hundreds or thousands of miles to find a specialty-fit shop. "Now, to fully appreciate the magnificence of their new toys, those athletes must also be able to tell of flight miles logged and far-off bicycle gurus consulted," The Times says. "Feeding the fire is the fact that high-end bike shops like Fit Werx and Wheat Ridge are courting buyers, not just with travel discounts and refunds but with more personal touches like dinner reservations."

title: Time Warner Refocusing With Move to Spin Off Cable
description: In another era at Time Warner, before a star-crossed Internet merger, the hard-held belief of Gerald M. Levin, then the chief executive, was that content is and will remain king, but distribution is the power behind the throne.

title: Joba Rules?
description: The Yankees struggles have continued the debate about whether Joba Chamberlain should start now, or if the team should keep him in the bullpen and minimize his innings. How should the Yankees handle Chamberlain, and are major league teams in general being overprotective of their young pitchers?

title: For Eyes That Have Seen It All, Theres a Way to Prove It
description: How often have you found yourself saying, If your eyes had only seen what Ive seen? Slip on a pair of $100 sunglasses from ThinkGeek.com, and youll never have to utter those words again.

description: BANGKOK  The prime minister of Thailand, Samak Sundaravej, said Wednesday that his government would try to create a cartel of rice-producing countries in partnership with Vietnam, Cambodia, Myanmar and Laos.

description: BAGHDAD  Dhia Jabbar hides his oud in a sack when he walks down the street in his Baghdad neighborhood.

description: For those times when you cant take yourself out to the ballgame, there is the Liveboard by Vroop.

title: What Does Your Car Say About You?
description: The use of a car  gas and insurance included  is one of the benefits of being a member of the House of Representatives. In a front-page story, Ray Rivera notes that 42 representatives from New York and New Jersey, at least a dozen lease cars on taxpayer money, and their choices run the gamut.Representative Anthony D. Weiner, Democrat of Brooklyn and Queens, drives a 2008 Chevrolet Impala, leased for $219 a month. Representative Michael R. McNulty, a Democrat from the Albany area, gets around in a 2007 Mercury Mariner hybrid, a sport -utility vehicle, for $816 a month. Jim Saxton, a Republican of New Jersey, leases a 2004 Chevy TrailBlazer at $310 a month. Gregory W. Meeks, a Queens Democrat, leases a 2007 Lexus LS 460 at $998 a month. And Charles B. Rangel, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, leases a 2004 Cadillac DeVille for $777.54 a month. The car is 17 feet long with a 300-horsepower engine and seats five comfortably. Its one of the bigger Cadillacs, Mr. Rangel, of Harlem, said cheerfully this week. Ive got a desk in it. Its like an airplane. (See related graphic.)There are few restrictions on what kind of car the members can choose, and there is no limit on how much they can spend. But the benefit can be politically sensitive, given the growing concerns about automobile emissions and an economy that has left many people struggling to pay for the rapidly rising cost of gas, which was averaging $3.63 a gallon nationwide this week.

title: Milton Gendel: The Fine Print
description: Milton Gendel, born in New York City in 1918, has his first photographic exhibit in the United States, at Verdura on Fifth Avenue. There are, perhaps, several reasons for this delayed happening. Gendel is primarily a writer; living in Rome since 1950, he has been a correspondent for Art News and a consulting editor for Art in America, as well as the editor of the Illustrated History of Italy. Photography is essentially a pastime, in spite of producing many, many albums and a dozen or so exhibits in Europe. Gendels friendships span the worlds of artists, writers, and aristocrats, and they are the subjects of his candid, unaffected photographs, taken over the last half century.

Homenick, the chatty chief clerk of the jury division for New York County, mentioned this after pointing out that the New York State Supreme Court in Lower Manhattan celebrated its 80th anniversary last year. He then noted that last year was also the 50th anniversary of the classic movie about jury deliberations starring Henry Fonda, Twelve Angry Men.

title: Jazzfest: More from The Stomp

One remarkable set was by the gospel pianist and singer Davell Crawfordcelebrated in New Orleans for his untrammeled virtuositybacking up his grandfather, James (Sugar Boy) Crawford, who had a career singing secular music decades ago. Not now: James Crawford was singing gospel. He was giving thanks for his recovery from a police beating years ago that fractured his skull and initially left him paralyzed and blind, in long lines that rose from humility to joyful affirmation. All around his steadfast melodies, Davell Crawford was a tsunami of improvisation: surging ostinatos and florid filigree, tremolo chords and keyboard-spanning glissandos, excess as exaltation.

He had been taught as a boy by his grandfather, who lived to age 117, how to make, then play, the kora, a 21-string instrument fashioned from a giant gourd wrapped in cowhide, with a wooden neck and handles. He has recorded several CDs, teaches kora to a diverse range of young people, and plays concerts across the country.

And theres a corollary question that often goes along with it: Will financial success necessarily come to those who follow their passions? Ive covered this before, but I just discovered an excellent post on Chris Guillebeaus blog, The Art of Non-Conformity, in which several of my favorite bloggers chime in on this subject. title: Goya in Madrid, to Remember a Spanish Uprising
description: If you are in Madrid this weekend you will certainly become familiar with a defining event in Spanish history, that  if you live outside of Spain  youve probably overlooked before: the 1808 popular Spanish uprising against Napoleon Bonapartes occupying forces. On May 2 that year, the people of Madrid rebelled against the French, sparking fighting in which hundreds of people were killed. The next day, in a harsh backlash against the revolt, the French forces executed hundreds of suspected Spanish rebels.

title: Jazzfest: A Treasure Hunt
description: For some loyal patrons, Jazzfest can present something like a pioneer land-grab. They show up, the earlier the better, and stake their claims. Sometimes the effort involves chairs, a banner and a pole. Sometimes its just a blanket on the ground. Whatever the case, these are the festivalgoers who figure out their plan and stick to it, venturing out for provisions only as the need arises.

On Wednesday, the Red Bulls traveled north to Canada for a match against Toronto F.C. (3-2-1, 10 points), which had won three straight games after starting its second season in Major League Soccer with consecutive losses.

title: Jazzfest: Things Are Gonna Get Brighter
description: The trumpeter Kermit Ruffins is one epitome of the New Orleans musician: skillful, versatile and no less serious just because hes happy to entertain. At Jazzfest, taking a cue from Louis Armstrong, he sang What a Wonderful World. He also played one piece on a modern-jazz vamp, another on a bright Caribbean beat. He even did some rapping, interspersing the 5 Stairsteps hit O-o-h Child, with a rhymed interlude, a chronicle that spanned growing up in the Lower Ninth Ward, the neighborhood still devastated by Katrina, and New Orleans situation now: Clean up this mess. But that songs chorus is Things are gonna get brighter  a wish easily granted in an optimistic song.

title: Silvermans Vision of Broadcasts Future
description: TVWeek: In 15 years, broadcast television will only be useful for high-profile live events like the Super Bowl, awards shows and programs like American Idol, Ben Silverman, co-chairman of NBC Entertainment, said during a keynote interview at the TelevisionWeek Upfront Summit in New York. Other shows will have to live on multiple platforms to survive.

description: At one point this season, the Madison Square Garden fans were busy chanting for the team to re-sign forward Sean Avery. But now, with Avery out for the season with a lacerated spleen and the Rangers playoff lives seemingly resting on the shoulders of captain Jaromir Jagr and goalie Henrik Lundqvist, the free agent the Garden fans are showering with attention is Jagr.

Zimbabwe: Officials Begin Verifying Election Results
description: A month after Zimbabwes disputed election, representatives of the presidential candidates finally met to begin verifying an outcome that has yet to be announced. Ministers in the government of President Robert Mugabe, left, have maintained for weeks that a runoff will be necessary with his chief rival, Morgan Tsvangirai. The verification process, which allows candidates to challenge what they think are erroneous or fraudulent tallies, could take days or longer.

title: A Photographer of Pets and Perps
description: The Favor, a dreary, interminable drama written and directed by Eva Aridjis, is exactly one-third of a good movie. That third is Frank Woods beautifully modulated and modest central performance as Lawrence, a lonely bachelor with a beloved pooch and a washed-out life. Overwhelming it, however, are a limp story line and Ryan Donowhos callow portrayal of Johnny, the orphaned teenager whom Lawrence inadvisedly fosters.

description: SANTA BARBARA is a fabled, verdant oasis, renowned for its opulence. Could this magnet to the rich and famous also be a bargain hunters paradise?

title: Germany: Mayhem on May Day
description: Left-wing protesters erected barricades in the streets of Hamburg and burned police cars as part of a demonstration against a march by neo-Nazis that the counter-demonstrators said was intended as a provocation on May Day. In the confusion of smoke and smashed windshields, the counter-demonstrators attacked the police, stormed a cafe and set fires, a police spokesman said. The police said they had arrested 56 people and detained 227 others. They estimated that 1,500 people had participated in the right-wing march and 6,600 in the left-wing response.

The case is the most significant brought by Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo in his investigation of the home health care industry.

But theyll agree that globalization is the chief process driving our age. Our lives are being transformed by the increasing movement of goods, people and capital across borders.

title: Spidey at the Library
description: The Library of Congress is now home to the original artwork, above, by Steve Ditko for Marvel Comics Amazing Fantasy No. 15, the comic book that introduced Spider-Man in 1962. The library announced on Wednesday that the comic book was the gift of someone who asked to remain anonymous. Sara W. Duke, curator of popular and applied graphic art in the prints and photographs division of the library, said, Looking at the drawings inspires a new appreciation for the artists skill and design choices and also deepens our understanding of how a superhero created to attract a teenage audience became a cultural icon with mass appeal. The black-and-white drawings conclude with the lines: With great power there must also come great responsibility ... and so a legend is born and a new name is added to the roster of those who make the world of fantasy the most exciting realm of all.

Beyond the Porsches and the Jaguars, a Homey Feeling
description: ALONG skinny two-lane country roads, behind well-maintained stone walls, padlocked gates and trees that loom like sentries, the part-time residents of Bedford, harried hedge fund managers and entrepreneurs from Manhattan among them  can kick off their shiny wingtips and shut out the hubbub of modern life.

description: National Geographic won three National Magazine Awards on Thursday night, more than it had ever captured in a single year, including a prestigious award for general excellence the second year in a row.

description: HALFWAY through her 32-minute set on Wednesday night at the Roseland Ballroom in Manhattan  a promotional show for her new album, Hard Candy, that was attended by 2,200 lucky, screamy fans  Madonna offered a message of sympathy. All you people I saw sleeping in the street last night, she announced, holding a jet-black electric guitar, this song is for you.
