title: Spinsterhood Is Powerful (Until a Catch Shows Up)
description: This year, in an effort to forge an image that seemed a little more with it, the producers of Masterpiece Theater installed the actress Gillian Anderson as host and shed the stodgiest half of the title, making it simply Masterpiece. There is certainly a hint of sexiness in this linguistic divorce. The word masterpiece on its own sounds racier. It connotes something bought rather than merely endured, and it shares the same syllabic beat as MasterCard, with all the potential to capitalize subliminally on its advertising. One month of Showtime: $16. Nine hundred and six hours of Bleak House: Priceless.

title: Exit Is in With Viewers
description: Fox claimed victory in the ratings on Wednesday night, with Nielsen estimating that 22.1 million viewers tuned in at 9 oclock to watch Brooke White, below, eliminated from American Idol, leaving four contestants. CBS ranked second for the night as "Criminal Minds" at 9 p.m. (12.9 million) and "CSI:NY" at 10 (11.4 million) were the only other shows to crack double-digit audience figures over all. CBSs prime-time edition of The Price is Right" with Drew Carey, formerly on Fridays, attracted 7.3 million viewers in its new 8 p.m. Wednesday slot, outpacing Foxs comedies in the hour, Til Death (5.5 million) and Back to You (7 million). NBC ranked third for the night, broadcasting a two-hour Deal or No Deal at 8 (8 million) followed by Law & Order at 10 (9.6 million). ABC was fourth, earning its largest audience of the night at 10 for Boston Legal (7.3 million).

title: House Panel Approves Bill to Assist Borrowers
description: WASHINGTON  The House Financial Services Committee pushed forward on Thursday with an aggressive effort to help troubled homeowners, approving legislation that would make up to $300 billion in federally insured loans available to refinance the mortgages of borrowers in danger of foreclosure.

title: Myanmar: Sanctions on 3 Companies
description: The United States broadened financial sanctions against Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, to include three prominent state-owned companies. The United States already restricts most trade with Myanmar but says these sanctions would prevent even indirect dealings with the companies  Myanmar Gem, Myanmar Timber and Myanmar Pearl  on international markets.

title: Going Through Intersection of Fate
description: Rod Thorn called from New Jersey. Pat Riley left a voice message from Miami. One by one, the guys checked in, telling Byron Scott how happy they were for him, how much he deserved the N.B.A. coach of the year award and the taste of Western Conference playoff success after New Orleanss five-game brush-off of Avery Johnson and Dallas.

title: Koreans Recall an Era of Propaganda Battles
description: CHONGSON, South Korea  In early April, when North Korea called President Lee Myung-bak of South Korea an impostor, a traitor and an American running dog, the verbal barbs sounded all too familiar to Jin Yong-seon. He has a museum filled with them.

title: London Is Counting the Votes in Its Tight Mayoral Contest
description: LONDON  Mayor Ken Livingstone campaigned hard across London on Thursday as voters went to the polls to decide whether to let him stay in office for another four years. Meanwhile, seats on 159 local councils across England and Wales were up for grabs in elections widely seen as a referendum on the popularity of Prime Minister Gordon Browns floundering Labor government.

title: Agency Seeks New Credit Card Rules
description: The federal agency that oversees savings associations is proposing new rules that would prohibit several practices of the credit card industry that consumer groups have long called unfair and deceptive.

title: Confronting the Perils of Puberty Squared
description: How must the world appear to someone who has been treated as an exotic clinical specimen from birth? The moody, surreal XXY explores the world of Alex (Ins Efron), an intersex teenager  born with both male and female sex organs  navigating the treacherous emotional and hormonal rapids of uncertain gender.

title: Shame in Calais
description: For Americans, what is happening each night in the French channel port of Calais is poignantly and shamefully familiar. As Caroline Brothers reported in The Times recently, clusters of poor people wait for darkness and a high-risk chance to crawl inside or beneath a truck to cross to a country that needs and welcomes their labor but refuses to legally recognize their presence.

title: What Lurks Beneath the Ruffles
description: Hedonism becomes a gravitational force in Ben Danielss compelling turn as an 18th-century libertine in Les Liaisons Dangereuses, which opened Thursday night in an eye-filling, very imbalanced revival at the American Airlines Theater. Making a sensational Broadway debut in Rufus Norriss production, which also stars an uncomfortably cast Laura Linney, this London actor seems at all times pulled, pummeled and shaped by the prospect of physical pleasure.

title: Out-Of-Towners Make Mark on Broadway
description: Broadway theater contributed $5.1 billion to the economy of New York City in the 2006-7 season, according to the Broadway League, a trade association for the theater industry. The total included the spending by visitors, the costs to produce and run shows and the expenses incurred to maintain and renovate theaters. Out-of-towners bought the bulk of the 12.3 million tickets. Of all the tickets 65 percent went to tourists, and 18 percent to surburbanites. Of the 10.3 million tickets sold to out-of-towners, 4.69 million went to 3.16 million people who said they came to New York expressly for Broadway. These visitors contributed $2.23 billion to the citys economy, the report said.

title: At TriBeCa Film Festival, Winners Dot the Map
description: Films from Sweden, Turkey, the Netherlands, Britain, the United States and Spain captured the top awards Thursday in juried competitions at the Tribeca Film Festival. Let the Right One In, directed by Tomas Alfredson of Sweden and cited for its exploration of loneliness and alienation through masterly re-examination of the vampire myth, won the $25,000 Founders Award for Best Narrative Feature. It stars Kare Hedebrant, above. Huseyin Karabey, who directed the Turkish-Dutch-British production My Marlon and Brando,  cited for its skillful blending of documentary style with a classic love story, won the $25,000 prize for Best New Narrative Filmmaker. Directed by Gini Reticker of the United States, Pray the Devil Back to Hell, about peace-seeking Liberian women, won $25,000 as Best Documentary Feature. The $25,000 Best New Documentary Filmmaker prize went to Carlos Carcas of Spain for Old Man Bebo, cited for showing that if you truly have art in your body and soul, it will find its way out into the world. The winners were chosen from 12 narrative and 12 documentary features from 18 countries.

title: Crowds Smaller at Immigrant Rallies
description: Thousands of supporters of immigrant rights gathered in more than a dozen cities on Thursday afternoon. But the crowds seemed smaller than at comparable events in past years, with the turnout apparently depressed by fear of arrest.

description: LUMBERTON, N.C.  The Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., under fire for statements that have embarrassed Senator Barack Obamas campaign, has found staunch support in the pulpits of black churches around North Carolina. The people in the pews, however, are far less accepting.

title: Pakistan: Doctor Released After 2 Years
description: A Pakistani-American doctor has been released after being held by the authorities for more than two years, the local news media reported. Dr. Safdar Sarki, an advocate for greater autonomy for Sindh Province, was taken to a hospital in Quetta after the provincial government of Baluchistan withdrew weapons charges against him. Dr. Sarki, who lives in Texas, was arrested during a visit to Karachi in February 2006. The police in Baluchistan did not announce his arrest or any charges until last October. Pakistans Supreme Court identified him as one of the people held in a secret detention system.

title: Wiggle Room for Summer Rentals
description: THE faintest glimmer of an economic slowdown is on the horizon this summer in some of the most popular vacation spots within a two-hour drive of New York. Rental agents from the Jersey Shore to the Hamptons to the Hudson Valley report that prices for summer rentals have remained about the same as last year but that many people are booking late, hoping for bargains to materialize.

title: Special House Elections Could Reflect on Obama
description: WASHINGTON  Most Americans have never heard of Don Cazayoux or Travis Childers, two Southern politicians with names that could have been lifted from a John Grisham novel. But the electoral fate of those two gentlemen could be of some consequence in the ongoing presidential race.

title: Trump International Residences & Golf Club and the Villas at Miraval
description: Trump International Residences & Golf Club

title: Four Decades of Music That Redefined Free
description: First of all, No. 1, theres original music, only.

title: Bloomberg Proposes Lean Budget
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, warning that the boom in real estate and on Wall Street has come to an end, unveiled a $59.1 billion budget Thursday that would virtually halt the growth in city spending for the first time since the economic downturn following 9/11.

title: Primal Instincts Hooked to an Art Against Artifice
description: Philip Guston, the Abstract Expressionist who late in life became a painter of dark, comic images, was a great as-if artist. He wanted, he said, to paint things as if one had never seen them before, as if one had come from another planet. He aspired to paint as a cave man would.

title: Saxophone With Subtext
description: Through their sound, some jazz players connote more than what is on the surface. They have a subtext. When Frank Wess plays tenor saxophone his sound can have a delicate, almost courtly veneer. But theres another player underneath that sound with an almost opposite disposition, brawny and bullish.

title: New Policy on Security Clearances
description: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said service members would no longer have to disclose treatment for combat-related mental-health problems when they applied for security clearances. The change is intended to remove the stigma that some members of the military fear when they seek mental-health counseling, Mr. Gates said, and is meant to encourage those suffering from problems like post-traumatic stress disorder to seek help. Part of the issue of removing the stigma is making it clear that you can be tough and seek help for dealing with these problems, Mr. Gates said. After all, youre tough and you go into the hospital when you receive a physical wound. The policy will allow members of the military seeking or renewing a security clearance to avoid disclosing treatment for a mental-health problem related to deployment in a combat zone, according to a memorandum issued by the Defense Department.

title: Rivalry Played Out on Canvas and Page
description: Art is long, art criticism is often very, very brief, its Internet afterlife notwithstanding. Its viability relies on a mixture of prose style, sound-bite concepts, timing and its ability to clarify visual experience. Naming a major art movement can also help embed a critic in a periods cultural achievement or its mythology.

title: E.P.A. Proposes New Limits on Lead in the Air, the First Revision in 30 Years
description: WASHINGTON  For the first time in 30 years, the Environmental Protection Agency has proposed a new limit for lead concentrations in the air.

title: Beijing Air Terminal Goes All Out for the Games
description: BEIJING  Beijing airports new Terminal 3  twice the size of the Pentagon  is the largest building in the world.

title: Foundations Set Record for Giving in 07
description: Giving by foundations set a record last year, hitting almost $43 billion, compared with $39 billion in 2006, according to estimates by the Foundation Center.

title: Heavy Suit, Light Touches
description: The world at the moment does not suffer from a shortage of superheroes. And yet in some ways the glut of anti-evil crusaders with cool costumes and troubled souls takes the pressure off of Iron Man, which clanks into theaters today ahead of Hellboy, Batman and the Incredible Hulk. This summer those guys are all in sequels or redos, so Iron Man (a Marvel property not to be confused with the Man of Steel, who belongs to DC and whos taking a break this year) has the advantage of novelty in addition to a seasonal head start.

title: Recalling the Standard-Setter of Symphonic Ballet
description: As New York City Ballets ballet master in chief, Peter Martins, reminded the audience at the New York State Theater, Wednesday was the 25th anniversary of George Balanchines death. In these years Balanchine has become a growth industry, even more central to the art of ballet than during his lifetime.

title: Marilyn Monroe Returns Home to Her Husband, Charlie Chaplin
description: Its with some reluctance that I describe Mister Lonely, the new film by Harmony Korine, as dreamlike. Dreams are often vague, chaotic and dull, and other peoples dreams are notoriously uninteresting. Mister Lonely is enigmatic, its moods and meanings sometimes elusive in the way that dreams can be, but nearly every frame is an image of arresting clarity and beauty. And even when it strays beyond the border of sense, you cant help accepting its logic and its truth, much as you do when your unconscious spools pictures in your sleep.

title: Amid the Baroque and the Bluster, Love Blossoms
description: WASHINGTON  You dont usually think of Plcido Domingo as a singer with a passion for Baroque opera, but having left his mark on virtually everything else in the repertory, he is giving it a look. In November he sang Oreste in Glucks Iphignie en Tauride at the Met. Now he has taken up Bajazet, the central tenor role in Handels Tamerlano. After a run at the Teatro Real in Madrid this season, he sang his first American Bajazet on Wednesday evening in a new Washington National Opera production of Tamerlano at the Kennedy Center.

title: Joness Teammates Appeal
description: Marion Joness former relay teammates have appealed a decision by the International Olympic Committee to strip them of their gold medals with the Court of Arbitration for Sport in Lausanne, Switzerland, their lawyer, Mark Levinstein, said. The International Olympic Committee ruled in April that the teammates who won gold in the 4x400 meter and bronze in the 4x100 meter for the United States at the 2000 Sydney Games were disqualified because Jones admitted to using performance-enhancing drugs during that period.

title: South Africa: 9 Killed in Mine Accident
description: Eight miners and an elevator operator died when an elevator in a mine about 31 miles west of Johannesburg plunged almost 200 feet to the bottom of the shaft. Andrew Davidson, a spokesman for the mine owner, Gold Fields, said the rope bearing the elevator broke. Government regulators and the company are investigating the accident. Five other mine workers died at Gold Fields mines in two rock falls on Tuesday. Weve had a very bad week, Mr. Davidson said.

title: Loads of Grim Laughs Among the Garbage Cans
description: Me to play, the first words spoken by the blind and immobile, the irascible and imperious Hamm in Samuel Becketts Endgame, can be either threatening or misleading.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about legal maneuvering before the trial of the track coach Trevor Graham stemming from a doping investigation failed to give the context in some editions for comments by the Olympic sprinter Maurice Greene, who has been accused of cheating by a drug adviser expected to be a main prosecution witness.

title: Determining Who Rides the Lifeboat
description: I ask you, what am I? Im one of the undeserving poor. Thats what I am. Think of what that means to a man. It means that hes up agen middle class morality all the time ... I dont need less than a deserving man; I need more. I dont eat less hearty than him, and I drink a lot more.

title: Measles in U.S. at Highest Level Since 2001
description: Measles outbreaks in at least seven states are expected to produce more cases in 2008 than in any other recent year, federal health officials said Thursday, warning that measles is highly contagious and can cause severe illness and even death.

title: In Battle With Malkin, Lundqvist Holds Ground
description: For the first time in the series, Pittsburgh center Evgeni Malkin was out of options. He had launched his approach toward the Rangers goal on a penalty shot by charging hard to his right, but as he cut back toward goaltender Henrik Lundqvist, Malkin curiously slowed down.

title: Microsoft and Yahoo Are Said to Step Up Talks
description: After a months-long standoff, Microsoft and Yahoo are now engaged in active merger talks, people involved in the discussions said Friday.

title: Officers Son, 18, Stabbed to Death
description: A teenaged son of a New York City police officer was stabbed to death on Thursday night at the entrance of an apartment building in Brooklyn, according to the police and relatives.

title: A Driver, a Truck or a Train?
description: NO question about it, its great to have a second home. The rest, the relaxation  but, yikes, the transportation! Whether you fly, take a boat or a train to your vacation haven, once you arrive, youll probably need a car. So how do you get it there?

title: The Miley Cyrus Message, in the Eyes of Schoolgirls
description: On sunny weekdays just before 1 oclock, the corner of 61st Street and Amsterdam is a study in transition, as clusters of 15-year-old girls  giggling, calling out to the girls ahead of them, some half-running  head back from lunch to afternoon classes at the Beacon School, an alternative public high school with an emphasis on the arts and technology.

title: Paddling, Wining and Dining on the Other Eastern Shore
description: NORTH, out of Virginia Beach, it was just water and sky, sea gulls and salt air.

title: Qaeda Leader Reported Killed in Somalia
description: WASHINGTON  An American missile strike in Somalia apparently killed a militant long identified as one of Al Qaedas top operatives in East Africa on Thursday, but while Bush administration officials claimed success they also acknowledged facing an uphill battle to score lasting blows in their final months against the terrorist group around the world.

title: An Architects Eye Reflected in Silver
description: AN ARCHITECTS EYE

title: Oakland Teach-In Looks at Budget Cuts and the War
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Third period at Paul Robeson High School in East Oakland was pretty much what you might expect on a sunny Thursday afternoon at the end of the term: distracted students, talk of graduation and nearly silent response to teachers questions.

title: David Rockefellers $100 Million Gift to Harvard
description: To the Editor:

title: Struck by Love in a Moody Underworld
description: As Tears Go By convulses to the rhythms of mah-jongg parlor brawls, back-alley beat downs and semiautomatic flares in the neon nights, but its the rapt little interludes that arrest attention: an aspirin tablet dissolving in a bottle of water, a woman lingering in the fluorescent shadows of a ferry terminal, a mysterious cut away from lovers in bed to a pair of street lamps curving over an empty country road, a modest tracking shot along a row of drinking glasses set upon a Formica tabletop.

title: Notes From the War on Terror
description: For more than a year, President Bush has refused to honor legitimate requests from the Democratic majority in Congress for legal documents that he used to justify ordering the abuse, humiliation and torture of prisoners. This week, the Justice Department finally agreed to show some papers to members of the House and Senate.

title: The Lurita Doan Story
description: It has been 11 months since investigators found that Lurita Doan, chief of the General Services Administration, violated the Hatch Acts ban on politicking on the job, asking her staff how they could help our candidates. This week, the White House finally got around to ousting Ms. Doan from the governments principal agency for awarding rich contracts in goods and services.

title: Cubans Urged to Work Toward Change
description: HAVANA  The leader of Cubas labor union told tens of thousands of workers gathered in Havanas Revolution Plaza on Thursday morning that they must get to work to build a better country.

title: Gaza: Militant Tied to 2006 Raid Dies
description: A Hamas militant was killed in an Israeli airstrike in southern Gaza, the Israeli military and Hamas said. The military said the man, Nafiz Mansur, 40, had been involved in many attacks, including the capture of an Israeli soldier, Cpl. Gilad Shalit, in a raid in 2006. Fighters in Gaza also launched more than 30 rockets and mortar shells at Israel, causing some damage, the military said.

title: Uma Thurman Tells of Odd Card Left by Pursuer
description: In a harrowing account, the actress Uma Thurman described for a Manhattan jury on Thursday the cards and e-mail messages sent to her by an obsessive fan who sneaked onto the set of a movie she was filming in New York City in 2005.

title: The Biological Clock, Ticking for Men Too
description: Dr. Harry Fisch is director of the Male Reproductive Center and a professor of clinical urology at Columbia University Medical Center's New York-Presbyterian Hospital, and the author of The Male Biological Clock.

title: Those Who Live Longer
description: To the Editor:

title: Swinging Suburbia and the Sensual City
description: A waggish conceptual venture, Viva is a startlingly pitch-perfect reproduction of the kind of gauzy sex movies from the 1960s and early 1970s that preceded the hard-core revolution. Written and directed by Anna Biller, who also stars as the title character  a doll of a 1972 housewife first known as Barbi  the film unwinds as a series of adventures that take Barbi from swinging suburbia and backyard bacchanalias into the city and depravity. Despite the parallels with Sades Justine and the occasional lurid flourish, the depravity never becomes remotely depraved because Ms. Biller, despite her commitment to verisimilitude, maintains an ironic detachment throughout  because shes a Brechtian or a bad actress, or perhaps both.

title: Charles Tilly, 78, Writer and a Social Scientist, Is Dead
description: Charles Tilly, a social scientist who combined historical interpretation and quantitative analysis in a voluminous outpouring of work to forge often novel intellectual interpretations  as when he compared nation states to protection rackets  died on Tuesday in the Bronx. He was 78.

title: 54 More Women Accuse Bloomberg Firm of Bias
description: At least 54 more women are accusing Bloomberg L.P., the financial-services and media company founded by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, of discriminating against pregnant employees, a lawyer for the federal government said on Thursday.

title: Big Retailers Scaling Back Expansion Plans and Shutting Stores
description: After a decade of breakneck expansion, big retail chains are slamming on the brakes  hard.

title: Diversity of Talent and Spirit
description: A welcome entry in the constituency-cinema canon, Hollywood Chinese surveys a centurys worth of Chinese-American actors and filmmakers, visionaries and dragon ladies, kung fu excellence and Fu Manchu insult, Oscar winners and clich mongers. Assembled by the filmmaker Arthur Dong, it opens at the turn of the last century, when nickelodeon titles like Beheading of the Chinese Prisoner (1900) exploited stereotypes of the violent, inscrutable East, and closes by congratulating Justin Lin for directing The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006).

title: Family Feud Over Brooch
description: The older sister of the jeweler Ralph O. Esmerian is claiming that the 19th-century diamond brooch, above left, recently bought by the Louvre for $10.7 million wasnt his to sell, Bloomberg News reported. The sister, Jacqueline Esmerian King, and her four adult children said in a motion filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan that the brooch and other jewelry belong to a family trust and/or were purchased with money improperly diverted from the trust. The brooch was created by Franois Kramer for the Empress Eugnie, wife of Napoleon III. Mr. Esmerian filed for bankruptcy on April 15 on behalf of the retailer he owns, Fred Leighton Inc. He did not return calls for comment.

title: Buzzie Bavasi, a Dodgers Innovator, Dies at 93
description: Buzzie Bavasi, the general manager of the Dodgers during their glory years in Brooklyn and their first decade in Los Angeles, and a baseball executive for nearly a half-century, died Thursday in San Diego, where he lived. He was 93.

title: The Gas Tax: Out for Summer?
description: To the Editor:

title: With Backs to Wall, Rangers Fight Back
description: At the biggest moment of his season, Jaromir Jagr was facedown on the ice. He had just scored what would be a season-saving goal in the win-or-go-home game against Pittsburgh on Thursday night, and an opponents shoulder nearly knocked him cold.

title: In the First Round, Mickelson Makes a Stretch Run
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  A national advertising campaign once played off Phil Mickelsons impulsive shot selections by posing the question, What will Phil do next?

title: Unlikely Allies Campaign for a Gas-Tax Holiday
description: DES MOINES  Senators John McCain and Hillary Rodham Clinton found themselves taking a lonely stand on the campaign trail Thursday, defending the proposed gasoline-tax holiday while critics from both parties lined up against it.

title: Lonely Boys First Blood and First Pal
description: The spiritual godfather, as it were, of the comic British charmer Son of Rambow is Sylvester Stallone at his fiercest and certainly his gruntiest. Slathered in sweat and wearing a rag that circles his head like a tourniquet, Mr. Stallone is instantly recognizable as the Reagan-era avenger who first materialized in the instantaneous 1982 camp classic First Blood. He rises from the screen like a phoenix from the ashes, even if for the two boys at the center of Son of Rambow, who savor his every ponderous, violent move, hes more of a muscle-bound Tinkerbell ushering them into a new world.

title: 50-Shot Case May Affect Kellys Chances in a Mayoral Race
description: The not guilty verdict in the Sean Bell shooting last week was welcome news to three New York City police detectives charged in the case; one even wept as a judge in Queens read the ruling. But Justice Arthur J. Coopermans verdict also created some new challenges in the life of their boss, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly.

title: Fossella Is Charged With Drunken Driving
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Vito J. Fossella of New York was arrested early Thursday morning in a Washington suburb and charged with driving while intoxicated, the police said.

title: An Initiative on Reading Is Rated Ineffective
description: President Bushs $1 billion a year initiative to teach reading to low-income children has not helped improve their reading comprehension, according to a Department of Education report released on Thursday.

title: My Best Friends Big Fat (Shouldnt Happen) Scottish Wedding
description: The romantic comedy Made of Honor adds tart satirical flavors to a cotton-candy formula without sabotaging the sugar rush. Directed by Paul Weiland (City Slickers II), it begins on a nasty note when Tom (Patrick Dempsey), the putative Mr. Right in this taming-of-the-rogue fable, is introduced as a college boy wearing a hideous Bill Clinton mask and drunkenly bellowing for his Monica at a Halloween bacchanal.

title: The Mayors Responsible Budget
description: Hard economic times are the real test of a mayors budgetary skills, and New Yorkers appear to be in luck. With the economy on the skids and Wall Street revenue weak, Mayor Michael Bloomberg unveiled a budget on Thursday that should keep the city on a healthy fiscal course  if everyone shows proper discipline.

title: Sun Microsytems Reports Loss in Quarter
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Sun Microsystems, the maker of server computers, swung to a loss in the third quarter as economic challenges overshadowed its gains in overseas markets.

title: A Taste of the Vast A.A.C.M. Legacy
description: The Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians has issued a staggering amount of music in its four decades of existence. Here is a sampling: a dozen vital works, drawn from both the recent and more distant pasts. Most are still in print; all are available through online retailers like amazon.com, though in a few cases you might have to settle for a used copy or a digital-only release.

title: Congress Passes Bill to Bar Bias Based on Genes
description: A bill that would prohibit discrimination by health insurers and employers based on the information that people carry in their genes won final approval in Congress on Thursday by an overwhelming vote.

title: Exxon Posts Its 2nd-Best Quarter, but Its Not Enough for Wall St.
description: Exxon Mobil reported the second-best quarterly profit in its history on Thursday  and investors could barely hide their disappointment.

description: Its been a rough few months for David M. Rubenstein, co-founder and managing director of the Carlyle Group.

title: Theater Listings
description: STRETCH (A FANTASIA) It was a most implausible explanation. Rose Mary Woods, President Richard M. Nixons secretary, made the cover of Time magazine in 1973 after claiming that she had inadvertently pressed the wrong button on a tape recorder and then simultaneously kept her foot on a pedal control for the device while making an impossibly long stretch across her desk to answer a telephone. This gymnastic accident, she said, caused her to erase part of a tape famous for having an 18 -minute gap: a crucial conversation between her boss and his chief of staff, H. R. Haldeman. In the June 20, 1972, conversation, the men were thought to have discussed the Watergate break-in, which occurred three days earlier, so theirs was a chat that the special counsel was eager to hear.

title: Sun Microsystems Posts Loss and Plans to Reduce Jobs
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Sun Microsystems just took a big step backward.

title: The Pulpit Wouldnt Be So Bully Without Them
description: The man behind the presidents speeches was called his thinking machine and his writing machine, and not least of all his lying machine. That criticism might have come yesterday  or almost any time in the last 175 years, because the president was Andrew Jackson, whose aide Amos Kendall sometimes polished his words. Jacksons name-calling political opponent couldnt have guessed how much our awareness and suspicion of people putting words in presidents mouths would grow.

title: Sampling a Lifetime of Eclectic Collecting
description: Gustav Rau may not be a familiar name to the general public, but to old-timers in the auction world, it summons up the image of an eccentric collector who for nearly 40 years could be found in the London sales rooms of Sothebys and Christies. Often looking scruffy in hiking boots and rolled-up khaki pants, Mr. Rau trusted only his instinct and his eye, rather than the advice of professionals. He was a frequent bidder for  and buyer of  a wide range of art, including Rembrandts and Monets.

title: Microsoft Outlines Its Yahoo Strategies
description: Steven A. Ballmer, Microsofts chief executive, told employees on Thursday that the company would announce in short order which of three paths it would choose in its pursuit of Yahoo.

title: State Officials Predict a Deep Recession
description: ALBANY  State budget officials said on Thursday that New Yorks economy was slipping into a recession that could last through early next year and prove worse than the recession looming before the country as a whole.

title: Agency Pays $12 Million to Settle Accounting Case
description: THE Interpublic Group of Companies, the large advertising concern, agreed on Thursday to pay a $12 million fine to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into its accounting practices.

title: Do the Rich Pay Taxes? Italy Tells All
description: ROME  Many Italians attitude toward taxes runs something like this: Why should I pay if no one else does? Evasion is so common that landlords often demand two leases: one private with the actual amount expected, the other far lower and submitted to the authorities. Both, bafflingly, are vetted by lawyers.

title: In a Chokehold, on the Mat and in Life
description: In Redbelt, David Mamet has taken a sturdy B-movie conceit  a good man versus the bad world, plus blood  tricked it out with his rhythms, his corrosive words and misanthropy, and come up with a satisfying, unexpectedly involving B-movie that owes as much to old Hollywood as to Greek tragedy. That may sound like a perilous combination, but the films visual moderation, contained scale and ambition keep it well tethered. Its a fight film, purely if not simply, which of course also means its about the struggle to live.

title: Louisiana Democrat Holds His Party at Bay for a Chance at Victory
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  A Democrat stands a serious chance of taking a seat in the House of Representatives from Republicans in a special election here on Saturday. But to achieve that chance of victory in this Republican fortress, the candidate has labored to dissociate himself from the Democratic Partys national leaders.

title: Massachusetts Museums That Speak to Children
description: THE Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art in North Adams is a cavernous temple of modern art, with exceptionally big and provocative works in a variety of media. The Norman Rockwell Museum in Stockbridge, Mass., by contrast, serves up a whole different aesthetic, one filled with soda fountains, family dinners and sweetly nostalgic takes on small-town life.

title: Lessons From Big Leagues Guide a Bassmaster Rookie
description: APPLING, Ga.  Bass were busting up the water 60 yards away, feeding on bait fish. A fisherman trolled toward the melee to throw his bait and see if they were tournament-ready bass. After he flipped his bait, there was no movement, and no bass.

title: Selected Studies: Male Infertility
description: Government agencies, universities, doctors and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: For a 4th Month, Shoppers Curtail the Desire to Spend
description: Consumer spending barely budged in March, the fourth month in a row that Americans eschewed the shopping mall, seeking to conserve cash in an economic downturn.

title: Voting Rights Are Too Important to Leave to the States
description: It would be hard for Florida to surpass its disastrous performance in the 2000 election, but give the Sunshine State credit for trying. Its latest assault on democracy: a law threatening volunteer groups with crippling fines if they make small mistakes in registering voters. The law seems clearly aimed at keeping new voters  especially minorities and the poor  off the rolls. And it is working. The League of Women Voters, which has registered Florida voters since 1939, has called off its registration drive this year.

title: Amazon Sues Over State Law on Collection of Sales Tax
description: Amazon.com has filed a lawsuit challenging New York States new law forcing online retailers to collect sales tax on shipments to state residents.

description: BEIJING  They came. They expressed patriotic fervor. Then they shopped.

description: INDIANAPOLIS  In the cafes, gift stores and the gourmet dog biscuit shop in this citys neighborhood of Broad Ripple Village, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr.s name draws all sorts of responses  sighs, rolling eyes, laughter, grim silence.

title: U.S. Shed Fewer Jobs Than Expected in April
description: The American economy shed 20,000 jobs in April, the Labor Department said on Friday in a report that many economists took as powerful evidence that the United States is ensnared in a recession.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on Wednesday about a news conference at which Senator Barack Obama renounced ties to his former pastor referred incorrectly in some copies to Mr. Obamas relationship with his father. The assertion that Mr. Obama had never known his Kenyan father should have been that he had barely known him.

title: Young Rays Give Yanks a Model to Envy
description: BALTIMORE  The Tampa Bay Rays edited their team name, they changed some players, they say they adjusted their attitude and now they are trying to alter a losing culture that has been their birthmark. That final chore, the challenge of transforming helplessness to hopefulness, will not be accomplished in weeks.

title: Hughes Out With Fracture in His Rib
description: The injury to the Yankees right-hander Phil Hughes is worse than first thought. Hughes has a stress fracture in a rib on his right side, just under his pitching arm, and he will miss at least four weeks and probably more.

title: Book Asserts Black Reporter Didnt Kill White Officer in 81
description: PHILADELPHIA  A book published on Thursday asserts that a black radio journalist convicted of murdering a white Philadelphia police officer more than 26 years ago is not guilty of the crime and that it was actually committed by another man who is now deceased.

title: Double Bombings in an Iraqi Town Kill 35
description: BAGHDAD  Two thunderous blasts set off by suicide bombers ripped through a crowded shopping street in the town of Balad Ruz in Diyala Province on Thursday, killing at least 35 people and wounding at least 62 others, many of them seriously.

title: Crowds Are Smaller at Protests by Immigrants
description: LOS ANGELES  Thousands of immigrants and their supporters marched in several cities on Thursday to demand civil rights at a time when crackdowns against illegal immigrants are rising.

title: Reforming Our Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Dark Memories Abound
description: For a tale spiked with so much torment, Fugitive Pieces feels remarkably soothing. In images rose-tinted and golden-toned, this dreamy adaptation of Ann Michaelss acclaimed novel transforms a wrenching Holocaust-survival drama into the cinematic equivalent of warm milk and honey.

title: As Handicapping Gets Less Common, It Also Gets Harder
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  In 14 years as a public horse-racing handicapper, Steve Klein has picked thousands of winners. But one stands well above the rest.

title: Holtz Leads Hall of Fame Inductees
description: Lou Holtz, the only coach to lead six programs to bowl games, was named to the National Football Foundation and College Hall of Fame. Holtz coached 36 seasons (1969-2004) at William and Mary, North Carolina State, Arkansas, Minnesota, Notre Dame and South Carolina. The only other coach selected was John Cooper, who spent 24 seasons (1977-2000) at Tulsa, Arizona State and Ohio State.

title: Pakistan Talks End on Positive Note
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Leaders of Pakistans governing coalition concluded talks in Dubai on Thursday over how to restore the high court judges ousted by President Pervez Musharraf without saying whether they had reached an agreement. But they promised good news and fears of a breakup of their month-long coalition subsided, the local news media reported.

title: The Melting Pot on a High Boil in Flushing
description: IT was slow going on the thronged sidewalks of downtown Flushing, Queens, one recent spring afternoon, in the heart of its huge and bustling Asian community. Along Main and Union Streets many of the signs and the conversations are in Chinese, Korean or Vietnamese. A street vendor blasted Chinese pop music. At a sidewalk counter you can buy Peking duck to go. I passed under the wide window of a tea shop where high school kids sat people-watching and text-messaging as they sipped bubble tea, the sweet Chinese tea with pearls of tapioca in it. At a Chinese grocery tiny grandmas elbowed me aside, the better to haggle with the grocers over vegetables and fruit.

title: Hendrix Company Disputes Sex Video
description: Experience Hendrix, the Seattle-based company that manages the music and merchandise of the legendary guitarist Jimi Hendrix, said in a statement that we strongly dispute the claimed authenticity of a newly released sex video purporting to feature him. Posted on its Web site (experiencehendrix.com) on Wednesday night, the statement called the film  being released by Vivid Entertainment, a Los Angeles company that is one of the biggest players in the porn-film business  a callous attempt to trade on the image and reputation of a deceased artist who is unable to defend himself against such an outrageous and baseless assertion. The video by Vivid, which said it conducted extensive research to prove the films veracity, shows the face of a man who resembles Hendrix, but it does not incorporate any of his music. On Thursday Steven Hirsch, Vivids co-chairman, stood by the films authenticity and said, Anyone who believes it is not Jimi Hendrix in this video should come forward and prove it, rather than rely on their emotions to make baseless claims. He said that since the films release his company has been approached by unidentified people who may want to step forward to verify that the man in the film is Hendrix, adding that if they do, we will release their opinions in due course.

title: At Kodak, Some Old Things Are New Again
description: ROCHESTER  Steven J. Sasson, an electrical engineer who invented the first digital camera at Eastman Kodak in the 1970s, remembers well managements dismay at his feat.

title: As Gas Costs Soar, Buyers Flock to Small Cars
description: DETROIT  Soaring gas prices have turned the steady migration by Americans to smaller cars into a stampede.

title: A Bad Day for Hughes and Kennedy
description: It was the seventh inning of Detroits 8-4 victory over the struggling, injury-weakened Yankees on Thursday night at Yankee Stadium. Fans began to flee from the chilly rain following a two-run home run by the Tigers Miguel Cabrera.

title: The Spinning Wheel of Justice
description: Im back in court today. The process of actually selecting a jury is pretty arcane. Every once in a while in Room 452 at State Supreme Court in Manhattan, a clerk put the names of the entire pool in a wheel and spins it around, then chooses 40 randomly. I was among the ones called late Thursday morning, my second day of jury duty.We marched downstairs. The judge went over some of the basics of the case: the names of the defendant and plaintiffs, the witnesses to be called in case any of us knew any of them. Eight of the 40 raised their hands to claim some sort of conflict. After meeting one by one with the lawyers and the judge in the judges chambers, all eight were dismissed while the rest of us wondered why.

description: After growing consumer complaints about hidden fees and other tricks of the credit card trade, the rules proposed by the Federal Reserve on Friday to deal with unfair or deceptive practices are a modest step forward. But the final versions of these rules will probably not go into effect until next year, and the nations bankers are already mounting a strong opposition to any changes in the rough ways they are allowed to do business.

title: Tuning In on Thursday
description: CBS delivered more viewers on Thursday, but ABC fared better among adults 18 to 49, with Greys Anatomy, with Ellen Pompeo and Patrick Dempsey and Lost putting it on top in that demographic in the 9 and 10 p.m. hours, Nielsen estimated. In total viewers, the ABC shows trailed their competitors on CBS, drawing 15.1 million and 11.1 million viewers, compared with 17.8 million for CSI at 9 and 12.9 million for Without a Trace at 10. CBS also let in the 8 oclock hour with Survivor (12.5 million), which easily outperformed ABCs Ugly Betty (7.9 million) and NBCs comedies in that hour, My Name is Earl (6.8 million) and Scrubs (5.9 million). NBC and Fox shared third and fourth place. Fox had more viewers; NBC more of the 18-to-49 set, thanks to The Office at 9 and ER at 10. NBCs 30 Rock continued to struggle at 9:30 (5.4 million).

title: Judge Says Reggie Bush Must Testify

Bush, a running back for the New Orleans Saints, is being sued by Lloyd Lake, who says he lent Bush and his family nearly $300,000 in a business deal that fell apart. Bush has denied the charges. The judge, Joan B. Lewis, set the trial for March 13, 2009.

description: Gov. David A. Paterson said on Friday that he decided in March to admit publicly to an extramarital affair because he feared that a rogue unit of the New York State Police would disclose the information to embarrass him.

title: Lincoln Center Summer
description: Midsummer Night Swing and Lincoln Center Out of Doors, those hardy perennials of summer in Manhattan, have announced their schedules. The 20th season of Midsummer Night Swing, featuring the first appearance of Nellie McKay & the Aristocrats Swing Band and a range of ensembles offering music including hot jazz and funk, tango, salsa, electro, Cuban son, samba and rumba, will run from July 8 to 26. The attractions of Lincoln Center Out of Doors comprise flamenco, gypsy guitar, the 25th annual Roots of American Music Festival, Wordless Music (a program of minimalist works), rock versions of opera arias and the New York premiere of Still Black, Still Proud: An African Tribute to James Brown. That festival begins on Aug. 7 and runs through Aug. 24.

title: Corrections: For The Record

An 18-story hotel where rooms will start at $375 a night is to be called Thompson LES, not the Allen Hotel. The article also misstated the name for retail space at Avalon Bowery Place. It is Extra Place, not Exit Place.

title: A Tribute to Robbins and His Artistic Partners, Past and Present

At Tuesdays gala the mezzo-soprano Susan Graham sang Somewhere during West Side Story Suite: crossover at its best (and far more idiomatic than Leonard Bernsteins own infelicitous recording with Kiri Te Kanawa and Jos Carreras).

title: Papers Filed for Judicial Hearing on City Council Spending
description: Relying on an antiquated provision of the New York City Charter, a civil rights lawyer filed papers in State Supreme Court on Friday requesting a judicial hearing on City Council spending practices that have recently come under intense scrutiny. The hearing, known as a summary inquiry, would not determine guilt or innocence, but would merely lay out the facts surrounding the case for public review.

title: Injured Posada Hopes to Come Back Within 6 Weeks
description: Jorge Posadas first experience with the disabled list has been miserable  Not good at all, he said  and he does not want to be there very long. So Posada, the Yankees catcher, has decided to spend the next several weeks resting and strengthening his damaged right shoulder in hopes of a comeback within six weeks.

description: PARIS  The worlds major powers agreed in London on Friday to offer Iran modest new incentives to coax it to freeze important nuclear activities.

title: Philipp von Boeselager, Who Attempted an Assassination of Hitler, Dies at 90
description: Philipp Freiherr von Boeselager, believed to be the last surviving member of the inner circle of German Army officers who attempted to assassinate Adolf Hitler with a briefcase bomb on July 20, 1944, died on Thursday. He was 90 and lived in Altenahr, in the Rhineland-Palatinate.

title: New Recordings of Legendary Pianist
description: This Tuesday privately made recordings of the American pianist William Kapells last concerts will finally be available. Sony/BMG is releasing this two-disc set, right, which has works by Chopin, Rachmaninoff, Bach, Mozart, Mussorgsky, Debussy and Prokofiev. Kapell was one of the great pianists of the mid-20th century when he died at 31 in a plane crash in 1953 while on his way home from a concert tour in Australia. A music lover in Melbourne had recorded radio broadcasts of several of his concerts on acetate discs, some of which made their way in 2004 through an intermediary to Kapells widow, Anna Lou Kapell-Dehavenon. Several of the works had never been recorded for commercial release by Kapell, and others represent new interpretations. That last playing is a step beyond anything that weve had before, Ms. Kapell-Dehavenon said. Can you imagine how it feels? Its really extraordinary.

title: For a Dancer in the Moment, the Past and Future Converge
description: I MARCHED into the dining room of the Greens at Cannondale, an assisted-living community in Wilton, Conn., decked out in the finery of an 18th-century Colonial gentleman. It was an unseasonably warm spring afternoon, and a rather incongruous situation. I was perspiring inside my black tricorn hat and my matching green breeches, waistcoat and frock coat. But my nerves calmed when the four-piece band played the opening notes of a dance number called Fantocini.

title: About Mr. B.: A Compact Guide to a Masters Works
description: When people find that their dancegoing is getting to be a habit, they often ask, How can I find out more about this? The answers are endless and usually too complicated to be of much practical help. But now at last we can say, If you like Balanchine, you must read Nancy Goldners Balanchine Variations. Slim enough to fit into a jacket pocket, it surveys 22 of Balanchines most popular ballets; its good-humored, enthusiastic and undictatorial; it gives you numerous things to look out for in any performance; and it abounds with insights.

description: Viacom, the media company controlled by Sumner M. Redstone, said on Friday that its first-quarter profit rose 33 percent on sales of the video game Rock Band and higher ratings at its cable channels.

title: Fading Sounds of an Elegant Manhattan

As you ascend the green carpeted stairs to the lobby, her music invites you into a world of elegance where the spirit of Cole Porter, a longtime resident of the Waldorf, still hovers.

title: Ailey Fledglings Show How Far They Can Fly
description: Is it quibbling to say that the Ailey II dancers look way too professional to be members of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theaters junior troupe? Or to be participating in an event, the Joyce Theaters 1 2 3 Festival, that showcases dancers at the start of their careers? Or that the emotional and physical intensity of the four works they performed on Wednesday night was almost too much? (Quite a few fans in New York City must have been hoarse the next day, to judge by the hoots and hollers that greeted each piece.)

description: As Christine Baranski, Mark Rylance, Bradley Whitford and the other cast members of the 1960s farce Boeing-Boeing face a house full of first-nighters on Sunday, one concern may be whether the play will be upstaged by the theaters new ceilings, new seats, new carpets and  not inconsequentially  new restrooms.

On the eve of his return to the Kentucky Derby, Matz, the trainer of Barbaro, watched as one of the current stars of his stable, Chelokee, apparently sustained a condylar fracture of the cannon bone in his right front leg during the running of the Alysheba Stakes at Churchill Downs on Friday.

Just days before the North Carolina primary, the Democratic presidential contest in this state is suddenly alive with a fresh air of competition, as Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton seeks to capitalize on a controversy that polls suggest has whittled away some of Senator Barack Obamas support among white voters.

When Wagner entered, the pitching coach Rick Peterson gently closed the door from the outside. It was safe to say that Randolph and Wagner were not going to play catch.

Also joining the cast are Randy Graff as Meg Hardy, and Ana Gasteyer as Gloria. The Paris production of The Lion King (Le Roi Lion) won three Molire Awards, Frances version of the Tonys, on Monday night in Paris, Variety reported. Honors went to the show for best musical, costumes (by Julie Taymor, who also directed the production) and lights (by Donald Holder). John Malkovich was also honored for his direction of the French production of Good Canary, written by Zach Helm, the American screenwriter of Stranger Than Fiction. ... How Theater Failed America, Mike Daiseys monologue, will move from a sold-out run at Joes Pub to a six-week engagement at the Barrow Street Theater. Last month the three policemen tried for Mr. Bells death were acquitted of all charges by a New York judge. title: Hong Kong Embraces Olympic Torch
description: HONG KONG  Thousands of mainland Chinese and Hong Kong residents cheered the Olympic torch through the streets of Hong Kong on Friday during the largely peaceful first leg of its three-month trip through China.

title: Creating Sounds for a Nonsensical World
description: During an interview segment in the concert devoted to Frederic Rzewski at Zankel Hall on Thursday evening in Carnegie Halls Making Music series, the moderator, Ara Guzelimian, asked Mr. Rzewski about his reputation as a political composer. Mr. Rzewskis Attica (1972) and War Songs (2008) had just been performed, and ahead were Natural Things (2007), a work commemorating the Haymarket massacre of striking workers in 1886, and Winnsboro Cotton Mill Blues (1980), a thundering arrangement of a 1930s protest song.

title: Rough Tough Times, but Still No Recession
description: MARYLAND HEIGHTS, Mo.  President Bush has no shortage of words to describe the ailing economy.

title: Derby May Have a Sprint at Start and the Finish
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  When the starting gates open Saturday for the 134th running of the Kentucky Derby, five front-running horses, all stuck in outside posts, will angle sideways and race one another to the rail. Big Brown, the morning-line favorite in the No. 20 post, must run the farthest and fastest of all if he is to gain the all-important position on the rail.

title: Virus Kills 22 Children in Eastern China
description: BEIJING  A fast-spreading viral outbreak in China has killed 22 children, sickened nearly 3,600 others and caused panic among parents in an impoverished corner of Anhui Province, government health officials said Friday.

title: Paterson Nominates Executive Director for Port Authority
description: Gov. David A. Paterson announced on Friday that he had nominated Christopher O. Ward, a former executive with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, to be the authoritys executive director. Mr. Ward, 53, would succeed Anthony E. Shorris, who was appointed to the job last year by Gov. Eliot Spitzer.

title: Convention Preparations Prompt Suit by A.C.L.U.
description: DENVER  Groups planning parades or protests at the Democratic National Convention filed a lawsuit here on Friday charging that the Secret Service and the City of Denver are threatening free speech  not because of tight security rules, but by the very lack of them.

title: Gold Medalist Listed as Banned-Drug User
description: A government witness list filed Friday publicly identified Antonio Pettigrew, winner of a gold medal in the 4x400-meter relay at the 2000 Olympics, as a user of banned performance-enhancing drugs.

title: A Sweet-Toothed Queens New Royal Edict: Let Them Eat Cake, on Toe Shoes
description: Ballet companies of America, take note: it is possible to create new story ballets and not just retool the existing war horses. And it can be done without byzantine sets, two-intermission marathons or huge casts.

title: Thurman Fan, Affable on Stand, Admits He Was Possibly Foolish
description: The man accused of stalking Uma Thurman testified on Friday that he thought he had played a flirtatious cat and mouse game with her, but that he had never meant to scare her.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article on Page 3 of the Travel section this weekend about lighthouses on Croatian islands that take guests gives an outdated name for the home country of some visitors to one lighthouse. It is the Czech Republic, not Czechoslovakia.

description: Since January, the Clintons have pummeled Barack Obama with racially tinged comments and questions about his character.

description: Shortly before Toby Goldfisher Kaplowitz married two years ago, she went to a kallah teacher  a woman who prepares Orthodox Jewish brides to be intimate with their husbands.

title: Lottery Numbers
Republicans Crossing Over to Vote in Democratic Contests
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Until now, Shirley Morgan had always been the kind of voter the Republican Party thought it could count on. She comes from a family of staunch Republicans, has a son in the military and has supported Republican presidential candidates ever since she cast her first ballot, for Richard M. Nixon in 1972.

title: Parmalat Settles U.S. Shareholder Suit
description: The Italian dairy company Parmalat, which collapsed in December 2003 in the countrys largest bankruptcy, agreed to settle a shareholder lawsuit in the United States by paying investors stock with a market value of almost 24 million euros ($37 million). The removal of the class action as an issue in return for a nominal payment removes a cloud that has been hanging over the stock, said Richard Holloway, an outside spokesman for Parmalat. The settlement is subject to court approval.

title: What a Difference a Year Makes
description: It was a year ago Tuesday that Roger Clemens interrupted a Sunday afternoon game in the Bronx between the Yankees and the Seattle Mariners to announce that he was coming back in pinstripes. A lot has happened since then for Clemens, little of it good.

title: A Last Vanishing Act for Robert Vesco, Fugitive
description: HAVANA  Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier who spent most of his life eluding American justice, might even have managed to die on the sly.

title: Sometimes a Little Psychology Helps Bring a Contract Home
description: How would you compare the bridge-playing abilities of humans and computer programs?

title: Rangers Find Way to Impede the Penguins Advance
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  As the end of Game 4 between the Rangers and the Penguins devolved into something between a scuffle and a brawl, the Rangers had, at the very least, thrown the first piece of drama into the Penguins playoff march.

title: Parsing McCain on the Democrats Health Plans
description: Senator John McCain has been repeatedly suggesting that his Democratic rivals are proposing a single-payer, or even a nationalized health care system along the lines of those in countries like Canada and Britain.

title: Derby Side Bet: U.P.S. vs. KFC
description: There is a lot riding on the Kentucky Derby for two charities in Louisville. Two corporations have bet on different horses, and if either of those wins, the charity chosen by the victorious bettor will be $10,000 richer.

title: The Anguish of War, Expressed in Movement
description: Nora Chipaumires Chimurenga (struggle, cry, revolution) demands close attention, even though she doesnt always make it easy. But its no easy thing Ms. Chipaumire is trying to do in translating her youth during Zimbabwes second war of liberation into a 60-minute dance-theater work.

title: As Gasoline Prices Soar, Politicians Fall Back on Familiar Solutions
description: WASHINGTON  When President Bush called on Congress this week to address soaring gasoline prices by allowing drilling for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge and by expanding nuclear power, Democrats on Capitol Hill quickly pummeled him as falling back on tired ideas.

title: Listen to Your Statement
description: PEOPLE loathe keeping track of expenses, and I am no exception. Few chores manage to combine anxiety and tedium in such high doses.

title: Police Question Olmert in Possible New Criminal Inquiry
description: JERUSALEM  The prime minister of Israel, Ehud Olmert, was questioned by police investigators on Friday in connection with what appeared to be a new criminal inquiry.

title: Arab and Israeli Peace, at Least for Children
description: Bridge Over the Wadi begins with the small and familiar to examine the big and complex. The first scene in this documentary, scheduled to have its television premiere in this country Sunday night on the PBS World channel, shows two sleepy-eyed little boys and their morning routine.

title: Tom Cruise on Oprah, Without Gymnastics
description: This is so normal! Oprah Winfrey exclaimed as Tom Cruise took her through the vast, pristine, wood-paneled kitchen in his mountaintop estate in Telluride, Colo. Ms. Winfrey sounded relieved, almost as if she were half expecting to find space helmets and a teleporting station wedged next to the stove.

title: Britain: 2 Convicted of Trying to Extort a Royal
description: A judge sentenced two men to five years in prison after they were convicted of demanding nearly $100,000 from a member of the royal family in exchange for audio and video tapes featuring accusations that the royal, who is married, participated in a sex act with a male employee at a party. A court order in Britain has prevented publication of the identity of the extortion target. Scotland Yards counterterrorism squad arrested the suspects, Ian Strachan, 31, and Sean McGuigan, 41, in a sting operation. The court was told that the royal, known in court as Witness A, contacted the police after a man claiming to have the tapes contacted one of his assistants and demanded that the royal contact him if he knows whats good for him.

title: A Swallow in the Hand
description: A couple of times in the past few weeks, Ive stopped by a local swamp where the peepers live. Its hard to believe that the high-pitched chorus of such small frogs could amount to a roar, but it does. It rises into the night sky and swallows the listener. My internal compass seems to go awry in the midst of such an outcry. In the darkness, there is no horizon except a silence somewhere on the far edge of that cacophony. To the extent that any one peeper has a sense of identity, it must dissolve completely in that night song, because I certainly feel myself dissolving when I hear it.

title: Israels Tactics Thwart Attacks, With Trade-Off
description: NETANYA, Israel  Suicide bombings in Israel have dropped off so significantly that the nations security officials now dare to speak openly of success. But the very steps they are taking to thwart bombers appear to collide head-on with the governments agenda of achieving peace with the Palestinians.

title: U.S. Seeks New Curbs on Credit-Card Practices
description: WASHINGTON  Federal bank regulators on Friday proposed a new set of rules to make it more difficult for credit card companies to raise rates arbitrarily, conceal high penalty fees or engage in other practices that consumer groups say are abusive.

title: Tibetan Envoys Head to China for Informal Talks
description: NEW DELHI  A week after the Chinese government offered to meet with representatives of the Dalai Lama, the Tibetan government in exile in India announced Friday that two envoys were on their way to an undisclosed location in China for informal discussions. But in a signal of low expectations, the announcement predicted that the visit would be brief.

title: Bids for Botox? Auctions Go Deep to Aid Schools
description: The auctioneer came on with a bold pitch, trying to get the bidders to open their wallets as wide as possible.

title: William Frankel, Who Edited Jewish Chronicle, Dies at 91
description: LONDON  William Frankel, who reinvigorated the venerable London-based newspaper The Jewish Chronicle as its editor for two decades, broadening its coverage of world affairs to include the Vietnam War and the American civil rights movement, died on April 18 in Washington, where he had a home. He was 91.

title: Its Newer Homes That Stand Empty as Vacancies Rise
description: THERE are a record number of vacant homes in America, the government reported this week, and the vacancies are concentrated in the newest part of Americas housing stock.

description: Phone rings.

title: Jason Shinder, 52, Poet and Founder of Arts Program, Dies
description: Jason Shinder, a poet, anthologist and teacher who founded the Y.M.C.A. National Writers Voice program, one of the countrys largest networks of literary-arts centers, died on April 25 at his home in Manhattan. He was 52 and also lived in Provincetown, Mass.

title: Kennedys Near Future Could Be in the Minors
description: The Yankees have not lost faith in the promise of Ian Kennedy, but they are reluctant to devote more regular starts to him now. Kennedy has not won a game in five starts, and Manager Joe Girardi acknowledged he could be sent to the minor leagues because the Yankees do not need a fifth starter until May 10.

title: Composers Work to Play Where Words Stirred Ire
description: In his life, the composer Karlheinz Stockhausen often stirred strong feelings with his avant-garde works. After 9/11, he stirred outrage by calling the attack on the World Trade Center the greatest work of art that is possible in the whole cosmos. Now one of his pieces is being performed near the very scene of that event.

title: Chevron Profit Rises Even as Production Falls
description: Chevron said first-quarter profit rose 9.5 percent, beating Wall Street estimates. Net income climbed to $5.17 billion, or $2.48 a share, from $4.72 billion, or $2.18, a year earlier, the company said. Petroleum output dropped 1.7 percent, however, to the equivalent of 2.6 million barrels of crude a day. Chevrons chief executive, David J. OReilly, plans to spend more than $400 million a week this year in the companys costliest push ever to find new reserves, tap discoveries and expand refineries.

title: Plans for a Cross-Border Peace Park in the Mideast
description: This month faculty members and students from the Yale School of Architecture will join counterparts from Jordan, the Palestinian territories and Israel to design the first cross-border peace park in the Middle East, Yale announced. On May 12 the design teams will begin a visit to the proposed park site, south of the Sea of Galilee at the confluence of the Yarmouk and Jordan Rivers. The park area includes the Three Bridges site, where a Roman bridge, an Ottoman railway bridge and a British Mandate road bridge still span the Jordan. No person, train or vehicle has crossed the river at this site since the 1948 Arab-Israeli war. The goal of the event is to develop ideas on how to recreate a wetland from the dry lake bed into a bird sanctuary, convert the old power station into a visitors center, the old workers homes into eco-lodges and renovate the bridges so they can be used again, said Munqeth Mehyar, the Jordanian director of Friends of the Earth Middle East, a Jordanian, Israeli and Palestinian organization that developed the idea for the park, which has the support of the local Jordanian and Israeli authorities.

title: A Divorce Is Sought by Governor of Nevada
description: LAS VEGAS  Gov. Jim Gibbons of Nevada, whose marital problems have been a titillating sideshow to the states more serious budget problems, filed for divorce on Friday, starting a legal battle to force his wife of 24 years to vacate the governors mansion.

title: Footnote
description: The Mystic Seaport maritime museum in Connecticut has announced the retirement of Douglas H. Teeson, its president and director since 2001.

title: Spinning Iraq
description: President Bush will never live down Mission Accomplished  and should not. When the White Houses spinners spun that claim five years ago (remember the aircraft carrier?), it seemed cocky and premature. As Mr. Bush continues his $526 billion war-without-end in Iraq, it seems stunningly deceitful.

title: New Jerseys Timid Legislature
description: Gov. Jon Corzine of New Jersey has thrown in the towel in his four-month effort to persuade the State Legislature to reduce his states colossal debt by sharply raising turnpike and parkway tolls. The Legislature, which does not share his sense of urgency, gave him no choice. Despite its merits, the plan had little support from Republicans or the Democrats, who control both legislative houses.

title: Alou Sparks the Mets to a Welcome Victory
description: PHOENIX  As a few teammates lounged on plush leather couches, one eye on the movie "Old School" on the clubhouse television, Moises Alou, all 41 years of him, came bounding around a corner. This is his time of year  Kentucky Derby time  and Alou, a horse racing aficionado, wanted everyone, even those who could not tell a gelding from a filly, to share his passion.

Hurricane Katrina broke that streak, but on Sunday the Nevilles plan to play their first hometown concert after the storm.

He has dropped by clubs before previous New Orleans gigs, so the rumor was plausible. And it reached enough people to pack the club, and then some, with people talking about Stevie.

description: Every great city is swathed in memories. New Orleans openly clings to them: its peculiar habits, celebrations, foods, rituals and syncopations. The Jazz and Heritage Festival is one of the few big popular music festivals that promises not the newest, hippest or most popular acts, but the heritage thats part of its name. And Ive been running into a retrospective impulse in many sets Ive heard.

description: CBS delivered more viewers on Thursday, but ABC fared better among adults 18 to 49, with Greys Anatomy, with Ellen Pompeo and Patrick Dempsey, and Lost putting it on top in that demographic in the 9 and 10 p.m. hours, Nielsen estimated.

title: Jazzfest: Coming Back for More
description: In a conversation with Quint Davis, the producer and director of Jazzfest, he mentioned a startling statistic. One of the festivals marketing surveys found that people who visit Jazzfest for the first time return as regulars for the next five years. Thats serious recidivism.

description: Leaders of the Screen Actors Guild and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers said on Friday that they would extend their current round of contract talks through Tuesday, The New York Times reports.

During the summer, he calls races as the track announcer at Suffolk Downs in Boston. He looks back on Dancers Image and the 1968 Kentucky Derby.

title: Slow in suburbia
description: Theres a new report out from the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation on broadband. It confirms the fact that the United States is lagging in broadband adoption, both in overall penetration and in other aspects including speed and price. Part, but only part, of this may be due to bad policy  basically, the United States failed to enforce effective competition.

title: Gas Tax Cut Is No Holiday
description: Senators John McCain and Hillary Clinton both propose to suspend the 18.4-cents-per-gallon federal excise tax on gasoline between Memorial Day and Labor Day this year. For a moment, forget about whether encouraging fossil fuel burning makes sense during a time of global warming, whether we should raid the highway trust fund when bridges are collapsing for lack of maintenance, or the disconnect between the proposal to cut gasoline taxes and all three candidates endorsement of cap-and-trade pollution limits that would raise gasoline prices.

title: Gas Tax Holiday: Why It Makes Sense
description: To hear critics tell it, proposals from John McCain and Hillary Clinton to declare a federal tax holiday on gasoline and diesel fuel during the summer driving season will, simultaneously, bring no relief to consumers while bringing doomsday to government. A gas tax holiday is not a fantastic idea, but it doesnt deserve such controversy either.

title: Love Story at the Track Is Still Aglow
description: After Leo and Sadie Buse married in 1971, they were looking for an activity to bring their families together. Leo, who had five children from a previous marriage and loved horses, had the idea of going to Keeneland Race Course in Lexington, Ky., an easy drive from their home in Cincinnati, for the spring meet. Sadie, who had three children, was hesitant.

title: The Morning Skate: The Sharks Swim with Madonna
description: A couple of days ago, the Morning Skate took a stroll down memory lane to look at the two playoff teams who rallied from 0-3 to win a series.

title: Yes Way, Jose
description: The equation for Mets success is as simple as this: Jose Reyes hits = Mets win. Doesnt take Einstein to figure that out, but we all saw during last nights 7-2 victory against the Diamondbacks how scary this team looks when Reyes is wreaking havoc at the top of the order. Four hits, including two triples, three runs, a stolen base. Reyes has had nine multihit games this season. Care to guess how many of them the Mets have won? Ill make it easy for you: eight. Thats a pretty good ratio.

title: Jazzfest: Going Crazy With John Boutt
description: John Boutt is one of those New Orleans entertainers who can seem like a force just barely contained. Hes a jazz singer and a soul singer, though sometimes not in that order, and a wickedly effective communicator. He works hard to connect with his audiences, and more often than not he succeeds mightily. Yesterday he had the jazz tent packed, and going crazy.

title: Jazzfest: Ellis Marsalis Brings the Monk
description: Out in the world, Ellis Marsalis is best known as a jazz patriarch: father to Wynton and Branford, and to the less-heralded Delfeayo and Jason. Here in New Orleans, he has always been known chiefly as a first-call pianist conversant in the full scope of the jazz tradition, and capable of great things on the bandstand.

title: Tiviakov, Lahno Are European Champions
description: Going into the last round of the European individual championships, eight players were tied for first, but only Sergei Tiviakov of the Netherlands won, so he is the 2008 European champion. In the womens section, Kateryna Lahno of the Ukraine, the leader before the last round, drew her final game against Anna Ushenina of the Ukraine while her rivals also only drew, allowing Lahno to hold on and claim the womens title.

description: Eight Belles ran a terrific race to finish second to Big Brown. She beat the third horse, Denis of Cork, handily. She encountered traffic trouble but nothing got in her way. Galloping out she went down quickly. It was over. Two fractured ankles, likely one fractured and the other followed with a shift in weight. Speculation. But the reality is, we lost a terrific horse doing what we wanted her to do, run in the biggest race of the year.

title: It Takes Two, Baby
description: I love people. I could not even begin to count how many times my dear friends have tortured me  lovingly, of course  about my unlimited affection for any and every stranger who comes my way. I have made myself late to many a movie or dinner engagement by getting into impromptu conversations with the valet, the police officer, the mailman, the crossing guard, the paperboy, the street vendor, the truck driver. They could be 4 years old, 98 years old, it doesnt matter. I have gotten lost in conversations with them. I cant help it. I just love people.

title: Your Comments on my Guantanamo Column
description: My Sunday column is about the remaining 270 prisoners at Guantanamo, which is a national disgrace. One reason is simply the injustice of keeping innocent people in abusive conditions  a far harsher regime than that faced by convicted murderers in the United States. The inmates at Guantanamo havent had visits or phone calls with family members for more than six years of confinement, and the authorities constantly play games with them. For example, one of those I mention in the column is al-Ghizzawi, a Libyan who is suffering from extreme health problems. The authorities boasted of giving him glasses. But, according to his lawyer, the glasses are distance glasses, when he is in confined to a tiny cell. What he desperately wants is reading glasses.

title: Horse Lovers View From Inside the Industry
description: If human athletes were euthanized on television every time one broke a leg or a neck in an accident, the National Football League, Nascar and Olympic skiing would be out of business.

title: Jazzfest: Drum Battles and a Tribute to Max Roach
description: Theres ample precedent for the festival-enabled drum battle: at the early Newport Jazz Festivals, for instance, where Buddy Rich duked it out with Philly Joe Jones and others. Here at the jazz tent Saturday afternoon, a tribute to Max Roach featured three drumsets onstage, manned by Jason Marsalis, Herlin Riley and Shannon Powell. But the exchange had more to do with camaraderie than competition.

title: Jazzfest: Ludacris Goes Green
description: The Ludacris guest spot with the Roots on Saturday afternoon was short but sweet, and pointed: he stalked onstage for a quick jaunt of Stand Up, and then preached for a moment about green activism. Then he was off.
