title: Commissioner Takes His Cuts
description: Bud Selig has been the commissioner of Major League Baseball since 1992. A former owner of the Milwaukee Brewers, Selig, 73, has presided over the game during a period of tremendous growth. But he may ultimately be remembered for his handling of baseballs so-called steroids era. This year, team owners extended his contract by three years, through 2012. MIKE ABRAMS

title: Born Again
description: In the summer of 1976, as Chairman Mao lay on his deathbed in Beijing, the pigs at the Ximen Village Production Brigade Apricot Garden Pig Farm in Gaomi County, Shandong Province, also began to die. The first batch of five were found with their skin dotted with purple splotches the size of bronze coins, their eyes open, as if theyd died with unresolved grievances. The commune vet declared they had succumbed to what we call the Red Death and ordered them to be cremated and buried immediately. But it had been raining for weeks and the ground was too waterlogged. Dousing the carcasses with kerosene and trying to set them alight simply filled the farm with vile-smelling smoke. Soon 800 more pigs were infected. A fresh team of vets arrived by motorboat with more sophisticated medicines, but their ministrations were of little help. Dead pigs were piled up throughout the farm, their bloated forms expanding and exploding in the heat.

title: Terrifying, Not Unlike Your Real Life
description: ASIDE from some of the more banal horrors of reality programming, Medium has nothing to rival it as the most frightful hour on television. The series, which stars Patricia Arquette as an earnest telepath (Allison Dubois) who lends her powers of premonition to Phoenix law enforcement, has been a quiet success on NBC for four seasons, receiving some of its highest ratings in recent months as the show has delved further into the human capacity for selfishness and intimate depravities.

title: The Coming of Age of Copenhagens Nordic Cuisine
description: THE waiter wore the kind of mad grin normally seen on movie villains as they unleash mayhem on an unsuspecting city. A silvery industrial canister dangled from his hand. It looked like something for transporting dangerous radioactive isotopes. More alarming, it was emitting thick clouds of cold white smoke through the lid.

title: What Not to Wear to a Cocktail Party
description: HERES one way to introduce a new cocktail: hire a stripper to take a bath in a giant replica of it.

title: Enterprise Going Green in Atlanta
description: Visitors to Atlanta who are sensitive to carbon emissions might want to check out Enterprise Rent-A-Cars four new Green Branches. The branches  in the Buckhead, Emory, Downtown and Dunwoody areas  have reconfigured their fleets to feature 30 percent hybrids and 30 percent fuel-efficient cars (those that get at least 28 miles per gallon). Hybrids rent for the same price as a premium car (about $45 a day), and fuel-efficient cars rent for about $35.

title: Correction
description: A review on April 20 about Elizabeth Strouts Olive Kitteridge, using information provided by the publisher, carried an incorrect picture credit. The author photograph was by Andrea Sperling, not Jerry Bauer.

title: Yes, Manhattans Over There. What of It?
description: AS small-town upbringings go, Robert Holdens is a classic. He grew up in a small house on 74th Street, across the street from the house where his mother was born in 1924. His siblings came to view their neighborhood as a place to leave. For Mr. Holden, it was a place to stay, and in 1978 he bought a house around the corner, within sight of his boyhood home. He and his wife, Amy, reared three children in the house, and when his father died in 1993, his mother moved in upstairs.

title: Prepping Robots to Perform Surgery
description: WHAT do you call a surgeon who operates without scalpels, stitching tools or a powerful headlamp to light the patients insides? A better doctor, according to a growing number of surgeons who prefer to hand over much of the blood-and-guts portion of their work to medical robots controlled from computer consoles.

title: A $31 Million Wallflower, Languishing Amid Luxury
description: TROPHY houses have a strange way of sitting empty long after the giga-bucks have passed across the table. So it is with the magnificent Ziegler house, at 2 East 63rd Street, bought by a billionaire entrepreneur in 2005 but still dark and silent.

title: Radio Nowhere
description: To the Editor:

title: Four to Watch
description: James Franco: 'Pineapple Express'

title: Betty Tong and Suhail Mithani
description: Dr. Betty C. Tong, a daughter of Ai-Chuan Tong and Yung L. Tong of Atlanta, was married there on Saturday evening to Dr. Suhail K. Mithani, the son of Dr. Kamrudin Mithani of Havre de Grace, Md., and the late Yasmin Sani Mithani. The Rev. Antone Melton-Meaux, a Baptist minister, officiated at the Atlanta Botanical Garden.

title: 36 Hours in Athens, Greece
description: FOR years, Athens was little more than a one-night stand on the way to the Greek isles. Concretized and crowded, it lived off its archaeological sites and dirty-dancing-on-tables night life. But now a visit has become more than just a quickie for the sake of the Parthenon. Athens is reinventing itself as a city where antiquity meets edginess. Museums and galleries abound, and new ones are in the works. Late this year, the New Acropolis Museum, designed by the New York-based architect Bernard Tschumi, is scheduled to open at the foot of the ancient citadel. Not a bad warm-up for Mykonos.

title: Deborah Adler, Brian Sutherland
description: Deborah Adler and Brian Sutherland are to be married on Sunday evening at the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts in Manhattan. Cantor Steven S. Sher will officiate. Judge Susan M. Breall of the Superior Court of California in San Francisco is to take part in the ceremony.

title: Brearley Rauch, Ali Khan
description: Mary Brearley Rauch and Ali Alexander Khan were married on Saturday in Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Wesley D. Avram performed the ceremony at Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church.

title: Cold-Comfort Farming
description: My parents are organic farmers, but springtime makes my mother sad and anxious. In the winter, the duties are reasonable: the barn cats need Kibble, and the eggs have to be collected. But the first sprouts are needy and will only increase their demands as the season wears on. Farming asks everything of you eventually. But first it gives you plenty of time to fall in love.

title: Funky Town
description: HIT THE ROOF: Previous spread: Table grill by eva solo, $320. go to unica home.com. Melamine spatula by Zak Designs, $5. AT Broadway panhandler. Bocca sofa by studio 65 from heller, $975. At Heller, 149 fifth avenue. Summer dots Beach Towel by lacoste home, $40. At macys herald square. tatu coffee table by stephen burks for artecnica, $550. At matter, 227 fifth avenue, brooklyn. butterfly appetizer plate (with image by andy warhol), $2. go to cb2.com. Miss rio ottoman by karin wittmann Wilsmann for gueto Ecodesign, $350. GO to dwr.com. market editor: Andreas Kokkino.

title: Frenchwoman Wins Attention at an Event Dominated by Men
description: At the European Championships, which ended on Friday, there were two sections. In one, 159 competitors vied to be the womens champion. In the other, 336 men and 1 woman, Marie Sebag of France, battled for the overall title.

title: Back to the City, for More Than Just Sex
description: LAST year, around St. Patricks Day, as auspicious a time as any for a writer with Irish blood to start telling a story, Michael Patrick King left his house in the Hollywood Hills and drove to a motel in Palm Desert, Calif., where he spent 16 days thinking about four women whose approach to love, friendship and money defined the manners and folkways of affluent single life at the turn of the new century.

title: Not on Our Blog You Wont
description: AT 12:04 P.M. on April 25, a skirmish broke out on Jezebel.com.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Metro

title: Colleges and Universities Represented by Student Submissions
description: List of colleges and universities represented by student submissions to the Modern Love College Essay Contest:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions last Sunday about the perks and powers enjoyed by the majority party in the New York Senate referred incorrectly to the rules regarding constituent newsletters distributed by Senate Democrats, who are in the minority. The Democrats are allowed to use one color in addition to black and white; they are not limited to black and white alone. (Republicans are allowed to use multiple colors.)

title: A Georgia Community With an African Feel Fights a Wave of Change
description: SAPELO ISLAND, Ga.  When Wevonneda Minis first came to this marshy barrier island where her ancestors had been rice-cultivating slaves, she learned of the dream her great-great-grandfather, Liberty Handy, had the night before he died. In the dream, people told her, a black cat scratched him.

title: Understanding the Temporary Insanity of Adolescence
description: MAMARONECK

title: Bigger Condos, North of Littler Italy
description: IN the last 80 years, Little Italy in Lower Manhattan has lost more than 90 percent of its Italian-American population, according to community leaders, and shrunk by two-thirds.

title: Palestinians Seek Support on Borders
description: JERUSALEM  Seeking a more active American role in talks with Israel, the Palestinians say they hope that Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice will take a stand on the borders of a future Palestinian state and define them as corresponding with the 1967 lines, a senior Palestinian official said Saturday.

title: A Pianist Who Balances Acclaim and Assists
description: THE 59-year-old pianist Mitsuko Uchida  born near Tokyo, trained in Vienna and long resident in London  is, in more ways than one, a musicians musician. Her performances and Philips recordings of Classical and Romantic standards  especially works by Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert  have consistently fed a reputation for elegant and profound musicianship.

title: Charming Classic Rock Fans With Something New
description: White Plains

title: Inside the List
description: WEB OF FEAR: Harlan Cobens Hold Tight, a thriller for the Google era, is new at No. 1 on the fiction list.

title: Riding the Waves of Peru
description: IT was high tide on a scorching Tuesday, and the choppy beaches around Lima, Peru, were crawling with surfers. There were teenagers in ratty flip-flops carrying short boards patched with duct tape, and bronzed women in wet suits paddling out into the shimmering blue waves. There was even a businessman in his 30s, who climbed out of a black-tinted S.U.V. in nothing but shorts, as a muscular chauffeur handed him a freshly waxed board, a bottle of water and a dab of sunscreen.

title: As You Exit J.F.K., a Chilling Memory Below
description: FROM inside the AirTrain terminal in Jamaica, Queens, against the hum of trains and climate control, the residential swath of neighborhood just to the south looks peaceful, even idyllic. Sidewalks are clean and straight, the rooftops form tidy rows, and especially as winter fades, the backyards look inviting.

title: Outsider in South Africa (Wisconsin, Too)
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A Salute to Softball Players

title: Heard Is Chasing Lost Time After Hard Time
description: ATLANTA  Bennie Heard is on all fours, butt raised, at the foot of a steep hill suitable for sleigh riding. It is another quirky regimen for Heard, boxings Ripped Van Winkle, this one in a midtown park sprinkled with lunchtime sunbathers and bicyclists, homeless snoozers and smitten couples strolling hand in hand.

title: On the Verge of Victory With Newfound Serenity
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Playing with the calm assurance of a veteran and the fiery passion of a rookie, 22-year-old Anthony Kim served notice at the Wachovia Championship on Saturday that his game had matured and so had he. Two strokes behind when the third round began, Kim turned the $6.4-million tournament upside down, fashioning a bogey-free round of six-under-par 66 that propelled him into a four-stroke lead over Jason Bohn, the second-round leader, and Heath Slocum.

title: A Fiery Theology Under Fire
description: Black liberation theology was a radical movement born of a competitive time.

title: Up Front
description: Jonathan Spence has been a familiar figure on the Yale campus since the university granted his doctoral degree in 1965. He began teaching there the following year and still offers one of the most popular undergraduate courses, on the history of modern China.

title: Chinas Unfair Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: Piece(s) Of Cake
description: When a skinny woman with a big appetite and a hefty man on a diet are seated among the guests at your table, the S-XL Cake pan saves them from asking for a slice just a little bit bigger/smaller. Designed by Ding3000 and produced by Konstantin Slawinski (both based in Germany), the flexible silicone mold features built-in portions of varying sizes. S-XLs one setback: limited small

title: Correction: Trippy Rock, Relaxed Jazz and Other Delights
description: A review of Michael Doucet last Sunday in the Playlist column misstated the name of his new album. It is From Now On, not Solo Gombo.

title: Judith Nelson, Thomas Mitz
description: Judith Gael Nelson and Thomas Wayne Mitz are to be married on Sunday in New York. Joan Cleveland, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, will officiate.

title: Empty Nest Egg
description: The future of Americans pensions has not become a serious campaign issue so far this election season. Its hard to get retirement issues to the front of the line when the nation faces soaring health care costs, global warming, $100-a-barrel oil, a likely recession and collapsing housing prices. There is also the little matter of the worst credit crisis since the 1930s.

title: Study, but Have Fun, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Reuse, Recycle, Reheat
description: Matthijs Vogels was frustrated by the amount of food people throw away after meals. So, for part of his masters thesis at the Design Academy Eindhoven in the Netherlands, the 27-year-old designer put his frustrations to work: he created a zero-waste restaurant installation. The temporary, small-scale project espoused the cradle to cradle philosophy, which embraces ecologically intelligent design as a means of turning waste into new products. I did several crazy experiments, Vogels says, and not everything worked out. But he did succeed in creating a series of bowls and plates called Waste-Ware that were hand-pressed out of left-over coffee grounds and herbs. Each biodegradable set doubles as a container; the coffee version is perfect for storing chocolates. To purchase, go to studiohergebruik.nl. S. KIRK WALSH

title: I Take This Cyberpal to Be My Bridesmaid
description: WHEN the time came to pare down her guest list to 50 people, Brigitte Aleman had firm instructions.

title: On Gossamer Wings
description: In 1882, Mabel Loomis Todd sent Emily Dickinson a little picture shed painted of a woodland plant called Indian pipe. Dickinson thanked Todd with a poem, eight lines about a hummingbird, that would one day be among her best known, A Route of Evanescence. That summer, Todd had begun to fall in love with Dickinsons brother, Austin (adulterously  both parties were already married), but not before she received a visit from another admirer, the artist Martin Johnson Heade, known for his paintings of hummingbirds. Henry Ward Beecher, the Brooklyn preacher who had been sued for adultery by his best friend a decade earlier, had bought one of Heades landscapes in 1859; among the many other things that Beecher collected were stuffed hummingbirds. Beechers sister, the novelist Harriet Beecher Stowe, once rescued and tamed an injured hummingbird, teaching it to drink sugar syrup from a silver spoon.

title: Bedtime Stories | Lee Friedlander
description: With the opening of the Thompson LES hotel next month, Lee Friedlander will bring new meaning to the term artist in residence. Over each of the 141 beds in this downtown Manhattan hotel, a wall-mounted light box will illuminate black-and-white photographs from Friedlanders apple and olive tree series, seven variants in all (including the one above). Our approach was to integrate the work in an architectural context rather than treat it as an applied afterthought, says the hotels interior designer, Jim Walrod. The photographer is in good company: the lobby features a giant color-field painting by Peter Halley, and at the bottom of the outdoor pool, Andy Warhol gazes up from a Gerard Malanga filmstrip that has been acid-etched into the tiles. So, while a handful of locals might bemoan the continuing gentrification of the Lower East Side, few can complain about the hotels artistic pedigree. BILL POWERS

title: For Sale: Art and Optimism
description: YOU cant help but wonder just how many of the smartly dressed people sitting night after night at Sothebys, Christies and Phillips de Pury over the next two weeks will be serious bidders and how many will be voyeurs hoping to witness an implosion of the multibillion dollar art market.

title: An Invitation to Childs Play: Big Blocks and Wheelbarrows
description: It is the playground of the future, already in beta mode in New York City and coming soon to empty lots, day care centers and even suburban backyards across the country.

title: The Case for a Newer Deal
description: PART of the New Deal was a new financial deal. The shameful shenanigans leading up to the 1929 stock market crash and the frightening wave of bank failures during the Depression led directly to the creation of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: A Bordeaux, Blended Well
description: Year after year, Lamothe de Haux, a minor chteau, produces enticing Bordeaux blanc blends. The succulent 2007 shows why they have become a cult white in New York.

title: Exotic Destinations for Mothers Day
description: One hundred years ago, a church in West Virginia dedicated a service to motherhood for the first time. Mothers Day is now an annual event, and resorts in exotic destinations are honoring the holiday (May 11 this year) with special packages.

title: Brenda Haendler, William Plishker
description: Brenda Elizabeth Haendler and William Lester Plishker were married on Saturday evening at Grace Church in Washington. The Rev. John M. Graham, an Episcopal priest and the churchs rector, performed the ceremony, with R. Alan Plishker, a minister of the Reformed Church in America and an uncle of the bridegroom, taking part.

title: Despite Alert, Flawed Wiring Still Kills G.I.s
description: WASHINGTON  In October 2004, the United States Army issued an urgent bulletin to commanders across Iraq, warning them of a deadly new threat to American soldiers. Because of flawed electrical work by contractors, the bulletin stated, soldiers at American bases in Iraq had received severe electrical shocks, and some had even been electrocuted.

title: Corrections: Where Many Ended Their Search for Paradise
description: An article on April 13 about the Marquesas in the South Pacific misidentified one of the countries that make up the so-called Polynesian Triangle and the Polynesian island that is the farthest from Tahiti. In addition to Hawaii and Easter Island, the triangle includes New Zealand, not Tahiti. And Easter Island, not the Marquesas, is the farthest from Tahiti.

title: Melissa Torres, Peter Toomey
description: Melissa Ann Torres, a daughter of Janette S. Laurita of Whitestone, Queens, and Gilberto L. Torres of Brooklyn, was married Saturday to Peter Hugh Toomey, the son of Lauretta A. Toomey and Peter T. Toomey Jr. of Milford, Conn. The Rev. Bill Sangiovanni performed the ceremony at St. Augustine Catholic Church in Philadelphia.

title: Jane Ringer, James Gregoire
description: Jane Kathryn Ringer and James Albert Gregoire were married on Saturday at St. Peters Episcopal Church in Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Christopher Thomforde, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony.

title: The Wrong Friends
description: It is remarkable how many people are willing to help illegal gun sellers. Congress all too often takes the side of the gun lobby over victims of gun violence. Last week, in a particularly wrongheaded ruling, a federal appeals court threw out New York Citys longstanding lawsuit intended to rein in illegal gun sellers.

title: Sadaharu Oh Still Feels and Thinks the Game
description: MIYAZAKI, Japan  After a 22-year playing career in which he became Nippon Professional Baseballs home run king, Sadaharu Oh is in his 44th season in uniform, now as manager of the Fukuoka SoftBank Hawks.

title: Indiana Jones and the Savior of a Lost Art
description: THIS is a recreational activity for me is surely among the last things youd expect to hear from the director of a huge, costly, dauntingly complex summer action movie as it nears completion, with its release date just a few weeks away.

title: Dj Vu Dining
description: HELLO, your name is familiar  and so is your food.

title: The Wheels on the Bus Go Here and There
description: SOME 200 times a day, the M96 bus wheezes westward. As its name suggests, its route is mostly a straight shot across 96th Street. But around Broadway, the bus takes on acrobatic airs: it lunges up the avenue, turns laboriously onto 97th Street while dickering with Broadway traffic, pushes a block westward, and then executes two more lefts, finally swinging east onto 96th Street at West End Avenue.

title: They Keep the Light on for Visitors in Croatia
description: ISLANDS  some 1,200 of them  dot the Adriatic coast of Croatia like a long line of bread crumbs, ranging from two-acre specks to 35-mile-long spines of rock and scrub. Beautiful and remote, the labyrinth stretches for several hundred miles, from the northern coastal town of Rijeka past the walled city of Dubrovnik.

title: Live at the Garden
description: How did an English garden center become a social hub and foodie destination? At Petersham Nurseries near Richmond, Surrey, a 15-minute train ride from central London, city folks longing for a country home  or perhaps a glimpse of Stella McCartney  roam the grounds while posh suburbanites from nearby Kew shop for garden supplies and make impromptu play dates around the communal table in a teahouse. The setting is quintessential shabby chic, with rambling greenhouses filled year-round with lush plants, garden antiques and design objects both exotic and familiar. In the main greenhouse, rickety tables hidden among plants form the setting for the chef Skye Gyngells lunch-only cafe, with an inspired menu featuring local and seasonal ingredients. (Reservations are mandatory.) A nearby toolshed has been converted into the teahouse, an inviting space for a cup of coffee, tea cakes or a bowl of soup served with Poilne bread and farmhouse butter  the best way to battle the perpetually damp London air. Church Lane, off Petersham Road, Petersham, Surrey; 011-44-20-8940-5230; petershamnurseries.com. PIM TECHAMUANVIVIT

title: Forging Ahead With Sewers in Suffolk
description: AFTER obtaining the fire marshals approval in January for a 157-seat restaurant in Southaven, Jim McGuckin learned not long before he opened three months ago that Suffolk County health officials had cut his seating capacity by more than half.

title: Bend Me, Misshape Me
description: Last summer in a quiet suburb of Vail, Colo., Kent Logan showed off his private gallery to a group of visitors. Around the building were paintings by Andy Warhol and sculpture by Jeff Koons, along with flat files filled with hundreds of precious drawings and works on paper. Mr. Logan said he owned about 1,000 works of art and then politely announced that he had promised much of it to museums.

title: A Rare Shop-and-Stroll Area
description: IN much of So Paulo, window-shopping is simply not practical: the concrete city is too vast for sidewalk strolling. Instead, residents who can afford higher-end merchandise drive to centers of consumption known in Brazil as shoppings; in the United States, they are called malls.

title: Of Locks, Beauty and Driveways
description: The Security of a Lock, the Invincibility of Youth

title: Turkish Schools Offer Pakistan a Gentler Vision of Islam
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Praying in Pakistan has not been easy for Mesut Kacmaz, a Muslim teacher from Turkey.

title: The Lost Dog
description: TUESDAY

title: In Bleak Days for Builders, Lessons in Saving Your Life
description: MANUEL ARRANGO, a construction mechanic, works high above the pavement, toiling over masonry, brickwork, and waterproofing. On Monday night, at a training session for scaffold workers held in a church in Westchester Square in the northeast Bronx, Mr. Arrango also did a turn  literally  as a fashion model.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Empire Zone column in some editions on Monday, about a bill that would give the New York State Board of Elections the ability to overrule decisions by New York Citys Campaign Finance Board, misstated the surname of a spokesman for the city board. He is Eric Friedman, not Feldman.

title: Fillys Death Casts Shadow Over Big Browns Derby Victory
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Both came here chasing history and hinting at greatness. Big Brown was unbeaten and trying to become the first horse in 93 years to win the Kentucky Derby after three lifetime races. Eight Belles, a filly, had ticked off four victories, emboldening her owner to run her against the boys in Americas greatest horse race.

title: Peter Howard, 80, Dies; Put Music on Broadway
description: Peter Howard, who arranged the dance music, composed the incidental music or conducted the orchestra for many of Broadways biggest hits of the last half-century, and who sometimes did all three of those underappreciated jobs, died on April 18 in Englewood, N.J. He was 80 and had lived in recent years at the Lillian Booth Actors Home in Englewood.

title: Triumph, and Then Tears, at the Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  After running the race of her life, the filly Eight Belles finished second behind Big Brown in the Kentucky Derby on Saturday, then collapsed after the finish line and had to be euthanized.

title: His Fathers Siren, Still Singing
description: BEFORE Vladimir Nabokov, the author of Lolita, Pale Fire, Speak, Memory and other masterworks, died in Lausanne, Switzerland, in July 1977, he had been hard at work on another novel. The previous December, he told The New York Times that the not quite finished manuscript was called The Original of Laura, that it had already been completed in my mind and that during a recent hospital stay, in my diurnal delirium, he had kept reading it aloud to a small dream audience in a walled garden. Shortly afterward, Nabokovs editor at McGraw-Hill revealed that the author was about to do the actual writing, in pencil on 3-by-5-inch index cards (Nabokov never worked with a typewriter). Then, in words parroted by the editor, Nabokov would deal himself a novel.

title: Here Comes Everyboy, Again
description: ON June 6 a new Adam Sandler comedy  its pseudomysterious, catchphrase-ready title is You Dont Mess With the Zohan  will open across the country. This is hardly a surprising piece of news, since a new Adam Sandler comedy comes around just about every spring or summer. Last year was I Now Pronounce You Chuck and Larry, before that was Click, and so on, for as far back as most of Mr. Sandlers audience can remember.

title: Misspeaking Too Soon
description: As Wordwatchers Watch

title: Dana Weisberg, Steven Zeller
description: Dana Meredith Weisberg, a daughter of Helaine R. Weisberg and Allan L. Weisberg of Warren, N.J., was married on Saturday evening to Steven Lee Zeller, the son of Dana Zeller-Alexis and Mark Zeller of Middlefield, Mass. Rabbi Ammiel Hirsch officiated at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios, a film production complex in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: Dropout Prevention
description: To the Editor:

title: Shell Get It for You: Retail
description: HER name may have the ring of heavenly virtue, but Faith Hope Consolos stock in trade is earthly luxury. Ms. Consolo is the chairwoman for retail real estate at Prudential Douglas Elliman, and the citys highest-profile practitioner of the art of matching stores with storefronts.

title: Low Expectations Made for a Good Week
description: The stock market rose last week on news that generally wasnt very good but was still better than expected.

title: Breathing Light Into Ballet
description: IT was another evening at the ballet three weeks ago when the Kirov presented an evening of works by William Forsythe. As the audience members settled into their seats and looked at their programs before the first piece, a dancer appeared on the stage. His presence and his cryptic, telegraphic gestures seemed to indicate the start of Mr. Forsythes Steptext, but as the house lights remained on, the audience only gradually quieted its chatter, a little unsure about exactly what was happening.

title: A Love Story at the Track Is Still Aglow
description: After Leo and Sadie Buse married in 1971, they were looking for an activity to bring their families together. Leo, who had five children from a previous marriage and loved horses, had the idea of going to Keeneland Race Course in Lexington, Ky., an easy drive from their home in Cincinnati, for the spring meet. Sadie, who had three children, was hesitant.

title: Julianne Fisher, Robert Breitbeil Jr.
description: Julianne Kate Fisher and Robert George Breitbeil Jr. were married on Saturday at St. Charles Borromeo Catholic Church in Arlington, Va. The Rev. Clement M. Aapengnuo, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Vog
description: Vog closed in over Oahu last weekend, a thick haze that flattened the landscape and drained it of color. Sky and ocean bled to gray. The mighty, mossy-green Koolau mountains blurred, then vanished. A warm tropical morning in Honolulu had the ashy pallor of winter in upstate New York.

title: All Over the Dial, and Under One Roof
description: WHEN Clear Channel Radio started consolidating its five New York-area music stations, its online operation and its traffic-information network under one roof, it was a little like creating a multicultural blended family. The company wanted to put the corporate family first but to allow siblings as stylistically diverse as the adult contemporary 106.7 LiteFM and the hip-hop Power 105.1 FM to maintain their artistic identities.

title: Adrienne Lee, Zealous Wiley III
description: Adrienne Yvonne Lee and Zealous Darrell Wiley III are to be married on Sunday at the Biltmore in Atlanta. The Rev. Joseph Barta, a member of the Society of Christs Priesthood, will officiate.

title: A Revival in a Run-Down Part of Town
description: WEST HARTFORD

title: Paperback Row
description: SUPREME DISCOMFORT: The Divided Soul of Clarence Thomas, by Kevin Merida and Michael A. Fletcher. (Broadway, $15.95.) Thomas, the most controversial figure on the Supreme Court, is a man of contradictions. A beneficiary of affirmative action, he opposes it; the author of sometimes unfeeling legal opinions, he is compassionate in his personal relations. Merida and Fletcher, journalists at The Washington Post, conducted hundreds of interviews with Thomass friends, relatives and colleagues; they focus most successfully on his upbringing and early experience. The problem of color is a mantle Thomas yearns to shed, even as he clings to it, they write.

title: The Trouble With Harry
description: Harry Rent, the hero of Mark Sarvass first novel, is a Prufrock in his mid-40s. His arms and legs are thin, as is his courage, and the author writes most persuasively in a handful of early passages dramatizing Harrys zoned-out self-consciousness, his crippling awkwardness and his anxiety about what to do with his hands while standing by his wifes casket.

title: Cheating Hearts
description: Im not sure if its irony or good luck that landed Isabel Fonsecas swirling examination of midlife crises on my desk just as the Eliot Spitzer mess broke (infidelity being a  duh  major wind force), but the coincidence sure made reading this clever, well-observed novel that much more compelling. What happens when the spouse youve leaned on and trusted for decades turns out to have a secret life? And what do you do with this potentially explosive information if the story is breaking not under the klieg lights of The New York Times, but rather in the relative privacy of a cybercafe on a tropical island in the Indian Ocean?

title: Baghdad Must Pay Its Way
description: THE success of the coalitions counterinsurgency strategy has opened new, and under-reported, opportunities for Iraqs economy. Per capita income is more than four times 2003 levels. Inflation is coming down. Polls show that Iraqi businessmen are overwhelmingly optimistic about the countrys future and new enterprises are being opened every day. title: Entitled to What?
description: Virtually unnoticed during the primary season, the baby boom generation turned 62 this year and began to draw Social Security benefits. This heralded a milestone in Americas aging, and depending on which of the candidates you ask, it spells a budgetary straitjacket or possibly a looming social crisis. Over the next generation, the population of seniors will practically double, to 72 million. With more people retiring and a smaller share of people working, the strains on Social Security and especially Medicare will become evident. Over the very long term, the two programs combined are projected to consume virtually the entire federal budget. A portion of Medicare (the part that pays hospital bills) faces insolvency much sooner than that  in 2019. The entitlement problem is here and now, says Eugene Steuerle, a senior fellow of the Urban Institute. It is so big and overwhelming, none of the candidates feel they can tackle it.

The Belgian fashion designer Ann Demeulemeester recently opened a store in Seoul, South Korea, whose inner stairway and outer walls are covered in mossy Pachysandra terminalis. Broadway East, an edgy organic restaurant on the border of New Yorks Chinatown, has a garden wall in its dining room  the perfect backdrop for eating shojin salad. And a 30-foot-high wall of Dryopteris dilatata and Polystichum polyblepharum (ferns) provided a foil for the floral frocks in Stella McCartneys spring show. title: A Haiku to Synthetics

After working with Shiro Kuramata and Issey Miyake, Yoshioka became strongly influenced by structure, transparency and the use of synthetics. His origami-like Honey-Pop chair from 2001, made for the Italian company Driade, is composed of 120 sheets of glassine paper that are compressed, cut and then spread open. His 2006 limited-edition Pane chair is made of polyester fibers baked like Italian bread. This month, the Museum of Modern Art Design Store is presenting Destination: Japan, a retail exhibition that includes home accessories. Slit Bag (above), a woven vinyl bag that has the illusion of depth even when flat, was originally designed by Yoshioka for the cover of a monograph of his work, which was published by Phaidon. MoMA decided it would be the perfect tote for the design-obsessed shopper  and, at $33, a bargain. MELISSA FELDMAN

title: Cuisines in Bloom
description: Sooner or later the weather will turn warm and sunny, making it easier to enjoy the full New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. For now, consider a visit to the gardens current exhibition, Darwins Garden: An Evolutionary Adventure, which explores Charles Darwins research with the world of plants outside his window. Outside the garden is a diverse selection of restaurants.

title: Lisa Stenson and Antonio Desamours
description: WHEN Lisa Stenson, 43, and Antonio Desamours, 41, met two years ago at a Valentines Day event at a church in Atlanta, his first words to her were not, My name is Antonio, or Hello, how are you? or even You have beautiful eyes.

title: When to Drop Charges
description: I work as a consultant out of my home, doing a variety of research, writing and editing tasks for five or six clients at a time. Much of what I do for one client also helps me with others, since the topics are in the same domain. If I spend a day researching something for Client A and can use the same information for Client B, may I charge both of them the consulting fee? NANCY V. YINGER, OAKTON, VA.

title: New Jersey Man Is Held in Boys Death
description: The male companion of a Linden, N.J., woman has been arrested and charged with the murder of her 2-year-old son, the authorities said on Saturday.

title: Kissing the Cook
description: You cant get better publicity for a book than Banned in Boston. But as product endorsements go, Banned in China sends a more mixed message, even if it still wins points for piquancy. Seeing this legend on the dust jacket of Yan Liankes faux-naif novel, Serve the People!  the first of his books to be translated into English  you have to wonder what Chinese officials are banning books for these days. Publishing overly frank air pollution charts? Leaking hints on Olympic gymnasts floor routines? Indulging in too much of the wrong kind of self-criticism? Too much lead in the ink or too much lead in the pencil  that is, excessive lewdness?

title: Now Viewing | John Lautner
description: John Lautner apprenticed with Frank Lloyd Wright, designed Bob Hopes Palm Springs mansion and unwittingly spawned Googie, the futuristic style of Left Coast architecture based on a coffee shop of the same name. For more than 55 years, the architect created dwellings so site-specific they seemed to spring from the Los Angeles hills (the Sheats/Goldstein house) or touch down from a distant galaxy (the Marbrisa house, seen at right, or the Chemosphere house). His glass-and-poured-concrete masterpieces have co-starred in films, TV shows and even a video game. This summer, Lautners cult status gets an institutional imprimatur with the opening of the exhibition Between Earth and Heaven: The Architecture of John Lautner at the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles, from July 13 to Oct. 12. (The accompanying catalog, from Rizzoli, is available for $60.) Meanwhile, make like Vincent Gallo and Kelly Lynch and buy a Lautner original at architectureforsale.com. The 1949 Schaffer residence in Glendale, Calif., is on the market for just under $2 million. SARAH VERDONE

title: Taking the Temperature of Brownstone Brooklyn
description: A DIZZYING variety of sources feed weather information to the federal government: ships at sea, sensors on planes, instruments on balloons  and the whirligig on the roof of Bradley Feldmans brownstone in Park Slope.

title: Can the South Stand Strong?
description: THE surge and the new American counterinsurgency strategy have improved the situation remarkably in the northern half of Iraq. This progress could serve as the eventual basis for sustainable stability across Iraq. However, as countless people  starting with Gen. David Petraeus, the top United States commander in Iraq  have rightly noted, that progress is fragile.

title: Coveting Thy Neighbors Condo
description: BOTOX. The iPod. Arugula. Each in its own way ushered in an era of heightened expectations  for brow lines, personal music players and salad courses, respectively.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: Elizabeth Martin, Christopher Coakley
description: Elizabeth Lauren Martin, a daughter of Virginia B. Martin and Dick Martin of Summit, N.J., was married on Saturday to Christopher Augustin Coakley, a son of Joan H. Coakley and Gerald M. Coakley of Westwood, Mass. Msgr. Charles V. Antonicelli, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Josephs on Capitol Hill in Washington.

title: Salvadorans, Building Their Own Cultural Bridge
description: BRENTWOOD

title: In Ballot on a Public Pool, a Village Divided
description: ROWAYTON

title: Ohio Celebrates a Game of Foot Ball
description: On May 3, 1890, a group of Ohio State students rose early, boarded their horse-drawn wagons and made the 20-mile trip along the Olentangy River from Columbus to Delaware, the home of Ohio Wesleyan University, to play what that days Delaware Gazette described as the first game of Rugby foot ball.

title: Cycles Reach for Pebble Beach Cachet
description: ONE day in 1906, in Springfield, Mass., Oscar Hedstrom presented a gift to Harmon Elliott, the 16-year-old son of his friend (and fellow inventor) Sterling Elliott. The gift was a shiny black Indian motorcycle produced by the Hendee Manufacturing Company, which Hedstrom had co-founded.

title: The Preachers New Pulpit
description: THE biggest news in the presidential campaign over the past 10 days was the unapologetic re-emergence of the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., whose incendiary statements threatened serious harm to his former parishioner Barack Obama.

title: Songwriting Sisters and the Universe of What They Like
description: SINCE first gaining attention four years ago with So Jealous, the 27-year-old twins Tegan and Sara have been known for playing driving rock with straightforward lyrics. The Con (Vapor/Sire), the fifth studio album from these singer-songwriters, was no exception when it was released last year. On Tuesday they released a follow-up called Live Session EP: Tegan and Sara, available on iTunes, with four songs from The Con. Theyve amassed three nominations for Junos (Canadas equivalent of the Grammys) and are on tour through December, with stops at Bonnaroo and the recent Coachella festival along the way, as well as select dates with Cyndi Lauper and others on the True Colors tour. Off the road the sisters live in separate cities: Tegan Quin in Vancouver and Sara Quin in Montreal. On a recent afternoon in Portland, Ore., before heading out to an impromptu street hockey game, they spoke to Winter Miller by phone about what theyre listening to.

title: Two Dead in Newark After Fistfight Escalates to Gunfight
description: A teenager and a man fatally shot each other on a Newark street on Saturday, a few blocks from Mayor Cory A. Bookers house, the police said.

title: Remember the Refugees
description: RECOMMENDATIONS for how to ensure the best outcome in Iraq are politically easy  and thus plentiful. Our moral responsibility as a nation, however, requires that we prepare for the worst even as we work and hope for the best.

title: Is There a Real Woman in This Multiplex?
description: IRON MAN, Batman, Big Angry Green Man  to judge from the new popcorn season it seems as if Hollywood has realized that the best way to deal with its female troubles is to not have any, women, that is.

title: Buyers Guide to a Soft Market
description: THESE days, every source, be it a county housing group or a consumer-oriented real estate Web site, is offering its own specialized kind of help to any buyer interested in taking advantage of the softened housing market.

title: Yearning to Breathe Free
description: In the tradition of Mommie Dearest, which recounted a terrorized daughters childhood and escape from the brutal Joan Crawford, Who Do You Think You Are? is the moving story of Alyse Myerss struggle with a cruel if far less glamorous mother, and of the authors fight to break free.

title: Dharma Bum
description: In this memoir of a musical prodigys avatar as a Buddhist monk, Nikolai Grozni, the author of three novels published in his native Bulgaria, dwells on the overriding, blissfully benumbing feeling of resignation to the moment that keeps him in the Indian town of Dharamsala.

title: A Bit More Room on Delta
description: Delta (www.delta.com) has come up with a new look and feel for its international coach seating. Called Cozy Suite, the seating is staggered, allowing for increased arm and knee space. It also has a contoured shoulder area and a tip-up seat base for a more comfortable passage between aisle and window positions. The design, pending regulatory agency approval, is scheduled to be used on Delta 767ER and 777 international aircraft beginning in 2010.

title: Letters: Prague is Middle Europe
description: To the Editor: The Check In/ Check Out column (April 13) about Prague twice referred to Prague as being in Eastern Europe. The countries of the old Austrian Empire  the former Czechoslovakia, along with Hungary, Poland and Austria itself  make up Central Europe. They use a Western alphabet; if Catholic, they are Roman rather than Orthodox; and they looked west for cultural leadership instead of east to Moscow.

title: Correction: Securing the Homeland
description: A brief item on April 13 about developments in homeland security gave a misleading figure for the number of Americans who subscribe to a mobile phone service. The number of subscribers was recently estimated by M:Metrics, a research firm, at about 226 million, not more than 255 million. The higher figure is used by the International Association for the Wireless Telecommunications Industry to estimate the number of subscriptions. A subscriber can have more than one subscription.

title: Ritzy Organic
description: The Hotel Ritz in Paris has cleaned up its act. From locally sourced wild game (watch out for buckshot in the duck!) and line-caught

title: The New Collectibles
description: PHOTOS

title: Earmarks in Form, if Not Process, Are an Issue for McCain
description: The campaign trail has recently taken Senator John McCain  the scourge of earmarked, pork-barrel spending in Congress  across the Alabama River on the Gees Bend ferry, to one of his old Navy posts at Cecil Field in Jacksonville, Fla., and to the Lehigh Valley Hospital in Allentown, Pa., where he marveled at the new technology.

title: Believe It or Not
description: To the Editor:

title: Young Man, Old Man
description: The Mayors Tongue begins when two guys who work for a moving company in New York form an unlikely friendship. Alvaro is from the Cibao Valley in the Dominican Republic, uneducated, living in Washington Heights with his wife and children, keeping a filthy studio in Inwood where he sleeps with mistresses and whores. Eugene is from an Italian-American family, well born, college educated, estranged from his father. Alvaro speaks only Cibaeo, virtually incomprehensible to natives of the other Spanish-speaking countries in the Caribbean; Eugene speaks English and Italian. The friends are unable to communicate, and yet they converse feelingly, or at least they think they do. Alvaro is writing a novel that he asks Eugene to translate, and Eugene believes that he is able to capture the essence of the story, even without knowing the language.

title: The New Staples
description: Smoke Apple- or cherry-wood chunks are $3 a pound at the Woodman, Brooklyn; (718) 554-3251; thewoodman.com. Apple- or cherry-wood chips are $4 for 2 pounds at amazon.com.

title: Blocking the Transmission of Violence
description: LAST SUMMER, MARTIN TORRES WAS WORKING AS A COOK IN AUSTIN, Tex., when, on the morning of Aug. 23, he received a call from a relative. His 17-year-old nephew, Emilio, had been murdered. According to the police, Emilio was walking down a street on Chicagos South Side when someone shot him in the chest, possibly the culmination of an ongoing dispute. Like many killings, Emilios received just a few sentences in the local newspapers. Torres, who was especially close to his nephew, got on the first Greyhound bus to Chicago. He was grieving and plotting retribution. I thought, Man, Im going to take care of business, he told me recently. Thats how I live. I was going hunting. This is my own blood, my nephew.

title: Pen and Sickle
description: On March 2, Russians went to the polls and dutifully voted for Dmitri Medvedev, the presidential candidate handpicked by Vladimir Putin, just as theyd once voted for the handpicked Putin. Three days later, it was reported that the F.S.B., itself a handpicked successor to the K.G.B., was holding a contest to find the best artistic portrayal of its work. And the next day, the American publisher Alfred A. Knopf released Solomon Volkovs Magical Chorus, a history of 20th-century Russian culture.

title: Proposed Train Station Is No Sure Thing
description: Stamford

title: Attractive Candidate, Great Debate
description: So here I am, subjecting myself to yet another night of Clinton-versus-Obama coverage on CNN, when my mind drifts away from matters of war, health care and the economy. Who can concentrate on the loss of American jobs when Joba Chamberlains job remains up in the air? Talk about a hot-button kitchen-table issue!

title: Some (Real) Letters From Buzzie
description: Every so often, a letter  not an e-mail message, a real letter with a postmarked stamp on the envelope  would arrive from Buzzie Bavasi, who often chastised himself in it as this old goat.

title: Soccer Stars Misadventure Leaves His Fans Smirking
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  In a city famed for sexual tolerance, the men who shine on the soccer field are held to a different, more macho standard.

title: Call of the Wild
description: Lu Xun, Chinas most revered modern writer, was a student of medicine in 1906 when he saw a lantern slide of Japanese soldiers decapitating a Chinese prisoner. It was a particularly low moment in Chinas national self-esteem, and what appalled Lu Xun most was the passivity of the Chinese spectators. The people, he later wrote, of a weak, backward country, even though they may enjoy sturdy health, can only serve as the senseless material of and audience for public executions. Convinced that art could goad his compatriots toward spiritual transformation, he presented them in his first story, The Diary of a Madman, as hypocritical cannibals. His later work abounded in such pitiless depictions, inaugurating a modern Chinese literature marked by what the critic C. T. Hsia called an obsessive concern with China as a nation afflicted with a spiritual disease and therefore unable to strengthen itself or change its set ways of inhumanity.

title: Editors Choice
description: FANON, by John Edgar Wideman. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.) Widemans novel  raw and astringent, yet with a high literary polish  explores the life of the psychiatrist and revolutionary Frantz Fanon, who treated victims of French torture in Algeria.

title: Samantha Rosenberg, Jonathan Darche
description: Samantha Meredith Rosenberg and Jonathan Abraham Darche, both assistant district attorneys in Kew Gardens, Queens, were married on Saturday in Westhampton Beach, N.Y. Justice Arthur J. Cooperman of State Supreme Court in Queens officiated at the Westhampton Bath and Tennis Hotel and Marina.

title: So Young, So Strong, So Fast and Oh So Very Sad
description: Anyone who watched the Kentucky Derby on Saturday had to feel saddened and amazed  saddened, of course, by the death of the filly Eight Belles and amazed by the power of the winner, Big Brown. As a longtime very ambivalent fan of horse racing and a lover of thoroughbreds, I cant help seeing what happened as a kind of paradigm of Thoroughbredness, if you want to call it that.

title: When Spring Cleaning Includes a Power Plant
description: THE gigantic old power plant at 500 Kent Avenue, next to the Brooklyn Navy Yard in South Williamsburg, has stood on the waterfront since 1905, generating power for the trains and streetcars of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company.

title: Upstate, Where It Was First Made, Unwavering Devotion to Jell-O
description: Le ROY, N.Y.  Jell-O is as American as, well, Jell-O, a staple at generations of potluck dinners and fodder for students in cafeteria food fights. For some immigrants at Ellis Island, where it was served, it was their first taste of their new home. Carolyn Wyman, author of Jell-O: A Biography, sees it as nothing less than a metaphor for the national character.

title: Jagr Has Even Higher Hopes for the Rangers
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  His Rangers teammates fell neatly in line after Saturdays practice, expressing the conventional wisdom about never looking past the next game. With the one-game-at-a-time clich seemingly written in professional athletes DNA, Jaromir Jagr was willing to take on all the demons at once.

title: Mixing Metaphors
description: The old adage that beauty plainly in sight is the most difficult to see came home to me one Sunday morning in Williamsburg. I had wandered into the restaurant Moto, where, front and center on the brunch menu, was the Black Velvet, that oddball combination of stout and Champagne. Friends of discriminating palate had long raved about it, usually as a morning-after recuperative, but I couldnt get around my purists snobbery: stout is heavenly and Champagne marvelous, but the thought of mixing them made me wince  until that morning. The creamy, dark grab of the brew was given a tart goose by the bubbly, the two of them buffing each others rougher edges to make something entirely, wonderfully other.

title: How to Clear a Road to Redemption
description: IT is Day 79 in the hostage crisis otherwise known as the auction-rate securities market. Some $300 billion worth of investors funds  advertised as being easy as pie to cash in  are still locked up. And the brokerage firms that got investors into this mess are doing little to help.

title: A New Jet Will Try to Outrun His Height
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  No matter how many touchdowns he scores, no matter how many yards he picks up and no matter how fast he runs, Danny Woodhead cannot escape one statistic. Woodhead, the running back who signed with the Jets last week as an undrafted free agent, is 5 feet 7 inches.

title: In-Store: One of a Kind
description: 1. Youd have to search far and wide to find another shop like Few and Far, Priscilla Carluccios new concept emporium in Londons Knightsbridge area. (Go to fewandfar.net.) Carluccio, the sister and sometime collaborator of Sir Terence Conran, scans the world for eclectic objects for the home and wardrobe that range from classic to cutting-edge. In addition to unique, inspiring goods, I wanted to return to traditional shopkeeping, where service matters more than spreadsheets. I want to surprise, delight and really look after my customers.

title: Right the Wrong
description: WITH eight months left in office, President Bush has the power to shape his successors inheritance in Iraq. And the over-arching imperative right now, as articulated by Gen. David Petraeus and others, is to build on the reduction in violence that the surge has achieved by encouraging political reconciliation among the various factions in Iraq.

title: This Buds for You
description: Barack Obama is going to get down if it kills him.

title: A Songs Forgotten History, Complete With Cracker Jack
description: They call it baseballs greatest hit.

title: Fighting to Save the Planet, at School
description: CHAPPAQUA

title: The Whinnyings Welcome, but Wariness Greets a Stable
description: THE closing of the Claremont Riding Academy in April of last year did not bode well for the future of horseback riding in Central Park. But a lesser-known effect has been the strain on the parks department, which for years kept horses at the stables, on West 89th Street near Amsterdam Avenue. Since the closing, the department has had to haul horses in a trailer from a stable at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: A Prison of Shame, and Its Ours
description: My Times colleague Barry Bearak was imprisoned by the brutal regime in Zimbabwe last month. Barry was not beaten, but he was infected with scabies while in a bug-infested jail. He was finally brought before a court after four nights in jail and then released.

title: A Northeast Movement to Cut Emissions
description: AT a conference at Yale University last month, officials from New Jersey, New York and Connecticut were among leaders from 18 states who signed a declaration urging the federal government to take action on climate change.

title: A Strange City Called Home
description: IN the opening moments of Grand Theft Auto IV, the latest chapter of the cinematically styled video game franchise, two men are standing at the side of a boat, watching a familiar sight drift into view. Through their eyes, we see a digitized, 21st-century retelling of a scene that greeted numerous generations of new arrivals to an unknown country: the eastern end of a long, narrow island, with a towering metal spire emerging from its belly, and a diminutive green statue beckoning from a tiny point off the islands southern tip.

title: Microsoft Withdraws Bid for Yahoo
description: Microsoft said Saturday that it was abandoning its blockbuster bid to acquire Yahoo after it raised its offer by $5 billion but Yahoo rejected it as still too low.

title: The All-White Elephant in the Room
description: BORED by those endless replays of the Rev. Jeremiah Wright? If so, go directly to YouTube, search for John Hagee Roman Church Hitler, and be recharged by a fresh jolt of clerical jive.

title: Nothing Sacred: Young Hotshot Artist Tries to Make It Big
description: Ah, youth. Imagine being an art student in Paris in the 1880s  a flight of fancy made easier by a small but absolutely fascinating exhibition at the Princeton University Art Museum. Invoking the Comic Muse: Toulouse-Lautrecs Parody of The Sacred Grove looks at the role of caricature and pastiche in Henri Toulouse-Lautrecs early art.

title: Intellectual Property
description: For Glenn OBrien and Gina Nanni, weekend life in the Hamptons had become too stressful. So the couple sold their Bridgehampton, N.Y., farmhouse in 2003 and set their sights on the more laid-back Litchfield County, in Connecticut. A vintage Modernist stone-and-glass structure caught their attention online. But when they drove up from the city to look at it, what they found was a scene straight out of Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House  the before scene. It looked great on the outside, says Nanni, a partner in the New York public relations firm Company Agenda, but the inside was a horrible disappointment.

title: Film Crew Rights
description: Film Crew Rights

title: Alone Home
description: Part treehouse, part oversize closet, the lollipop studios for one, known as Single Hauz, was dreamed up by Pawel Kobrynski, Wojciech Krawczuk and Marcin Sakson, a trio of Polish architects. Each elevated prefab is 6 feet by 20 feet; sliding French doors open into the main living area, with a kitchenette and enough room for a bed and a single chair; and a tiny bathroom is shoehorned into a windowless nook. It can be erected on almost any terrain, even on a lake. The Single Hauz is a kind of architectural-social manifesto about single people, Kobrynski says. But it can also provide a refuge even for the happily married, because every one of us sometimes needs a place where we can be alone. The Single Hauz has not yet found a manufacturer; for more information, go to frontarchitects.pl. MARK ELLWOOD

title: Giants Zito Offers Help and Is Looking for Hope
description: PHILADELPHIA  Staff Sgt. Christopher Hill was fighting in Iraq when a rocket attack broke his back in June 2004. A few weeks ago, Hill and about 20 other injured Marines were treated to three days of spring training in Arizona by an organization founded by Barry Zito, a pitcher for the San Francisco Giants.

title: Trying to Put a Name to the Face of Evil
description: HITLER is alive in Burma reads the words scrawled on a cardboard sign, held aloft by a sweet-faced Ellen Page, the Juno star, in a 90-second human-rights public awareness message that began showing on video-sharing Web sites last week.

title: Correction: The Spirit of 68
description: An article last Sunday about the impact of the political upheavals of 1968 on world cinema gave an incorrect courtesy title for the filmmaker Rosa von Praunheim on second reference. He is Mr. von Praunheim, not Ms. The article also misidentified the season during which the Soviet Union sent its forces into Prague that year. It was in the summer  on Aug. 21  not fall.

title: Kristina Napolitano, Christopher Bauer
description: Kristina Maria Napolitano, a daughter of Maria C. Napolitano and Dr. Raffaele A. Napolitano of North Caldwell, N.J., was married on Saturday to Christopher Charles Bauer, a son of Jean D. Bauer and Eugene Bauer of Washingtonville, N.Y. Bishop Nicholas DiMarzio of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn performed the ceremony in Manhattan at St. Patricks Cathedral.

title: Dont Know Much About History
description: Never mind his Pulitzer, the best-selling books, the writing jobs at The Wall Street Journal and The New Yorker: Tony Horwitz is a dope. Really, hell tell you so himself, and often does, though not in so many words, in his funny and lively new travelogue, A Voyage Long and Strange. Horwitz is probably best known as the author of Confederates in the Attic, an exploration of how the American Civil War and its cultural backwash still move otherwise semi-normal Americans to do crazy things, like sleep outdoors in 19th-century-style long johns while pretending to be Abner Doubleday. In that book as in this one, Horwitz assumes the pose of a baby-boomer Everyman, overschooled but undereducated. He is chagrined at the basic historical facts he was once taught but can no longer remember or, worse, never knew to begin with. Like so many of us, he is the incarnation of Father Guido Sarduccis Five Minute University, where degrees are awarded for reciting the two or three things the average liberal-arts graduate remembers from four years of college.

title: New Recall at Queens Food Company
description: A Queens food company is recalling about 286,000 pounds of fresh and frozen beef, pork and poultry products that may be contaminated with listeria, a type of bacteria, a federal agency said on Saturday.

title: When a Landlord Sells the Property
description: Q We rent a house in Westchester County, which the landlord has decided to sell. If we have a signed lease through August 2009, can it be terminated before that date by the new owner?

title: Correction: Claudia Drummond and Raymond Acciardo Sr.
description: A report on April 20 about the marriage of Claudia Drummond and Raymond Acciardo Sr. misidentified the residence of Anthony James Acciardo, the bridegrooms late father. It was Fall River, Mass., not Barrington, R.I.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Page 3 of the Travel section this weekend about lighthouses on Croatian islands that take guests gives an outdated name for the home country of some visitors to one lighthouse. It is the Czech Republic, not Czechoslovakia.

title: Mandatory AP Exams Stir Student and Parent Outcry
description: STUDENTS enrolled in Advanced Placement classes at two schools in the Northern Valley Regional High School District in Bergen County are now required to take the AP exams this month  or receive a failing grade in the courses under a new school policy being questioned by some parents and students.

title: Whats an Investor to Do if a Star Firm Stumbles?
description: IT has been a rough stretch for those who have invested with Bruce S. Sherman, the co-founder of Private Capital Management.

title: A Lender Gets Caught in the Currents
description: WALKING across his sun-drenched office overlooking Fifth Avenue and the New York Public Library, Jeffrey M. Peek points to a picture on his desk. It is a perfect family portrait, filled with smiling, happy faces on a mountain summit. Perfect, except for one detail: theres a problem with the guy in the far left corner.

title: This Jokes for You
description: Brawndo

title: On the Ground, Counting Deer
description: MILLBURN

title: When Law Prevents Righting a Wrong
description: STAPLES HUGHES, a North Carolina lawyer, was on the witness stand and about to disclose a secret he believed would free an innocent man from prison. But the judge told Mr. Hughes to stop.

title: New Album, New Fears, Same Old Attitude
description: AHMIR Thompson was sitting in the back of a town car inching through Midtown when he received a vexing call from management, not entirely unlike the one that opens Rising Down (Def Jam), the new album by the Roots. One month before its release there were problems with a hidden track, and Mr. Thompson, better known as ?uestlove, the Roots drummer and bandleader, made no attempt to hide his frustration, raising his voice in protest.

title: If the Fish Liver Cant Kill, Is It Really a Delicacy?
description: SHIMONOSEKI, Japan  Poison has been as integral to fugu, the funny-looking, potentially deadly puffer fish prized by Japanese gourmands, as the savor of its pricey meat. So consider fugu, but poison-free.

title: Who Do You Think You Are?
description: Prologue

title: Chow, Darling
description: When the 25-year-old fashion designer Christopher Kane first considered giving a dinner party for a few of his friends, he knew, without question, that it was not going to be at home. Kane spends most of his time working with his older sister, Tammy  who is also his accomplice, business partner and fit model  in a spacious but grungy East London loft that is best suited for sandwich deliveries. My studio is so messy, said Kane, rolling his eyes. I have magazines and piles of stuff everywhere because I often start working on projects and dont finish them. We would have had to eat on the floor.

title: Stray Thoughts
description: Michelle de KretSers new novel is filled with aphorisms. The past is not what is over but what we wish to have done with. Reality is an effect produced by the accrual of detail. Euphemisms are symptomatic of shame. To which Id add, aphorisms enlighten  except when they dont.

title: INSTANT DECORATOR: Gala Force Entertaining
description: For the Manhattan event planner David Monn, organizing a dinner party on the beach usually involves a tent, sofas and a dance floor. When entertaining in his own Sag Harbor, N.Y., backyard, however, things get a little less complicated. For me, its the opposite of a large production, says the man whos orchestrated everything from the Mets Costume Institute gala to the Plaza Hotels coming Grand Reopening Celebration and other intimate soirees. In either case, he first creates what he calls imaginary architecture, using torches, hurricane lanterns on pillars or lights strung in trees to make guests feel safe. Next he chooses one color element. Constancy is where we derive our power image, he notes. Can Monn purchase power among the offerings of CB2, Crate and Barrels cheap-and-cheerful offshoot? No problem. He quickly struck upon his color: Live chartreuse green  or Olivine, in CB2-speak  which works outdoors as a continuation of what the eyes are already seeing. In fact, he liked the textures and ease offered by CB2 so much, guests at one of the three beach weddings hes organizing this summer should keep a (green) eye out. CHRISTINE MUHLKE

title: Want to Be My Boyfriend? Please Define
description: Its a Complicated Subject

title: Works by the Masters in a Celebration of Drawing
description: What a pity it would be if the many big touring exhibitions at Yale managed to deflect attention from Master Drawings, a new, quieter show at the Yale University Art Gallery. The European old master drawings shown here are from the 15th to 19th centuries. They are part of the permanent collection, but together form an exhibition no less compelling than the imported works.

title: Turning Japanese
description: In 2003, after a celebrated and controversial career as the manager of the Mets, you left Major League Baseball and moved to a suburb of Tokyo to manage the Chiba Lotte Marines. These days you speak Japanese and ride your bicycle to work, as we learn in the new ESPN documentary, The Zen of Bobby V. What do you think of the film? I think I was a lucky guy to have three special young guys sharing my life for seven months.

title: Lindsay Norris, Ryan Lally
description: Lindsay Sara Norris, a daughter of Fredi and Ronald Norris of Rockville Centre, N.Y., was married on Saturday evening to Ryan Joseph Lally, a son of Irene and Brian Lally of Hanover, N.H. Cantor Robert Abelson officiated at the New York Yacht Club at Harbour Court in Newport, R.I.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: FILM

title: Stephanie Johnson, Jamie Hanford
description: Stephanie Chadwick Johnson and M. James Hanford were married on Saturday evening at St. Stanislaus Church in Altos de Chavn, Dominican Republic. The Rev. Victor Garca, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated, with the Rev. Christopher McGarvey, a nondenominational minister, taking part.

title: Trying to Lighten That Carbon Footprint
description: IN February, on a chilly, clear Sunday morning, Sir Richard Branson, president of Virgin Atlantic, along with the co-sponsors Boeing and GE Aviation, lured more than 200 journalists to a hangar at Heathrow Airport near London to witness what they said was airline history. Over flutes of Champagne and plates of mini-bagels filled with salmon, everyones eyes were fixed on a 747 as it took off on the worlds first biofuel demonstration flight.

title: Miss Shanghai
description: Midway through Wang Anyis extraordinary novel The Song of Everlasting Sorrow, its heroine, Wang Qiyao, is on her way to a pawn shop when she runs into Mr. Cheng, a friend she hasnt seen in 12 years. A portrait photographer, Mr. Cheng had taken Wang Qiyaos photo in the late 1940s; the picture appeared in a magazine, and she went on to win third place in the Miss Shanghai beauty contest, the pinnacle of her career. By the time they meet again, it is 1960. Tragedy and ill-starred romance have ruined Wang Qiyaos reputation; she is pregnant with the child of a lover whose identity she refuses to reveal. Food shortages have pushed China to the brink of famine, so Mr. Cheng, taking pity on her, invites Wang Qiyao to share his modest lunch of rice and salt pork. At his apartment, after her eyes had adjusted to the darkness, she saw that the little world inside had barely changed; it was as if the little room had been encased in a time capsule. ... Wang Qiyao failed to understand that it is precisely this myriad of unchanging little worlds that serves as a counterfoil to the tumultuous changes taking place in the outside world.

title: Jazzfest: Tubas Outnumber Rappers

In fact, tubas outnumber rappers decisively at Jazzfest; hip-hop generally has a token presence here. That said, the Roots sounded right at home during their explosive set on Saturday, charging through tunes with practiced abandon. And when Ludacris sauntered out to join them, for a brief but potent moment  rapping his 2003 hit Stand Up  the vibe was strong.

title: Jazzfest: A Closer Look at the Costumes
description: When a Mardi Gras Indian parade goes by at Jazzfest, hourly in the early afternoon, the first impression is the sheer joyous ostentation of those outsize feathers and the propulsion of the beat. Its usually worth taking a longer, closer look. The Indians sew their own costumes anew each year, and the feathers may be the easy part. The costumes also include large panels, called patches, made of painstaking, intricate beadwork  a confluence of African and Native American traditions. So much fine handwork wouldnt be wasted on mere decoration; the patches often involve symbols and stories. Many show battles between cowboys and Indians, complete with dead cowboys. But there are more contemporary ones as well.

title: Judgment Sought for Umpire Art
description: A Norman Rockwell painting depicting three umpires looking skyward as raindrops begin to fall has sent the Curtis Publishing Company in search of a favorable call from the United States District Court in Manhattan, The Associated Press reported. The company has filed suit against ESPN, seeking to bar it from rebroadcasting its television series The Bronx Is Burning, about the 1977 New York Yankees, until it withdraws its use of the painting, Bottom of the Sixth. In an e-mail message Curtis notified lawyers that ESPN did not have a license to use the painting and was committing willful copyright infringement, the lawsuit said. Court documents said that the painting was shown full screen in the second episode, Team in Turmoil, and that the series had since been sold in DVD and VHS format. Lawyers for ESPN did not immediately return calls seeking comment. The painting, one of more than 300 created by Rockwell for The Saturday Evening Post, first appeared in the April 23, 1949, issue and was donated to the National Baseball Hall of Fame & Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y.

title: Where's Schiller?
description: Question: If Ulysses S. Grant is buried in Grants Tomb, who is buried in Friedrich Schillers tomb? Answer: Not Friedrich Schiller. Two years of DNA research has determined that none of the remains billed as those of the poet and playwright were actually his, The Associated Press reported, citing MDR television. In 1826, 21 years after Schiller died in Weimar, Germany, and was buried in a common grave in Jacobs Cemetery, it was decided that he needed a new resting place, Frstengruft Cemetery. The mayor, Carl Leberecht Schwabe, a Schiller fan, decided that of the 23 skulls exhumed from the common grave, the biggest must have been Schillers. A skeleton believed to be a match was put together with the skull, and everything was buried anew in 1827, to be joined in 1832 by Schillers friend Goethe, who was interred alongside him, above. About 60,000 people visit the site annually. Researchers later unearthed two other skulls said to be Schillers. But none of them were supported by DNA from the remains of two Schiller sisters and two sons. Hellmut Seemann, president of the Foundation of Weimar Classics, which oversees the Schiller archives and exhibitions, said he believed the remains were probably still in the Jacobs Cemetery.

title: Tokyo Police Guard Film
description: Tight security was imposed in Tokyo on Saturday when a Chinese directors documentary about a Japanese shrine to its war dead opened amid threats from nationalists outraged at its content, Agence France-Presse reported. Police patrolled the entrance to the theater and were posted in screening rooms after reports of plans to disrupt the sold-out showings. But Yutaka Okada, president of Argo Pictures, distributor of the documentary, Yasukuni, said, We have been able to screen the film safely and smoothly. The film, directed by Li Ying, was to have had its premiere last month but was withdrawn after noisy protests. The documentary, recipient of a grant from the Japanese government, examines the controversy surrounding the Yasukuni Shrine, a Shinto shrine in Tokyo that honors 2.5 million war dead, including convicted war criminals from World War II. Critics said it fed anti-Japanese sentiment by, for example, superimposing images of Emperor Hirohito on atrocities by Japanese troops. The film will be shown eight times a day for a week.

title: Unusual Concert for Saudi Arabia
description: In a groundbreaking concert in Saudi Arabia, a German-based quartet played European classical music in a public setting for a mixed-gender audience, right, The Associated Press reported. Public concerts are virtually unheard of in this strict Muslim kingdom, and the sexes are segregated even in lines at fast-food outlets. The concert  with the Artis Piano Quartet performing works by Mozart, Brahms and Paul Juon  took place in a 500-seat government-run cultural center in Riyadh on Friday night and touched off speculation that Saudi Arabia was seeking greater openness. The concert is a sign that things are changing rapidly here, said the German ambassador, Jrgen Krieghoff, whose embassy sponsored the concert as part of the inaugural German Cultural Weeks in Saudi Arabia. Evidently the government has decided that a minimum of openness in our new world economy and in our information-based world is necessary for us and also for good understanding among cultures. The quartets Japanese pianist, Hiroko Atsumi, said there had been some discussion about whether she should perform in an abaya, the enveloping black cloak women must wear in public. She wore a long green top and black trousers.

title: Jazzfest: The Last Word
description: Something odd happens over a full weekend of Jazzfest. Between performances and parades, and the geography of where stages are situated, its virtually impossible not to run into a brass band, Mardi Gras Indians or both. I assume thats by design; those traditions infuse all sorts of other New Orleans music and they are the main heritage in Jazz and Heritage. To see so many groups maintaining their street-level music after Katrina is heartening, and their tunes are incorrigibly upbeat. Yet after a few days the novelty wears off: oh, yeah, here come more Indians. And then Jazzfest is over and Im headed back to New York, where Indian gangs dont vow to set your flag on fire over a tambourine beat and theres not a brass-band gig somewhere every night of the week. Theres not even one a month. Like other things that make New Orleans so utterly singular, whats commonplace within that one city should never be taken for granted.

Such insights, and the wonderful allusions to 19th-century writers provided by Steve, do enhance my enjoyment of the book. But as slight as it is, this book seems inexhaustible, always welcoming further exploration. Robinson is a hospitable writer, even if her work demands an attentiveness that is increasingly hard to come by, not only for the iPod kids but for older adults who are often too harried and distracted to sit and read. Turning off the television can help, but its not enough. C.S. Lewis discouraged even the reading of periodicals, as he felt that they had a bad effect on our capacity to pay attention, to take the long view.

title: Housewives Delivers for ABC

ABC led the night in that demographic during every hour of prime time, starting with the 400th episode of Americas Funniest Home Videos at 7 (7.3 million) and Extreme Makeover: Home Edition at 8 (11.5 million). In total viewers, however, those two shows trailed their time slot competitors on CBS, 60 Minutes at 7 (10.5 million) and Cold Case at 8 (11.6 million). CBS ranked second for the night in total viewers, falling behind from 9 to 11 with two hours of Dexter (6.4 million).
