title: This Ones on Trent Reznor
description: In an unusual nod to the popularity of free music online, the rock act Nine Inch Nails is offering its new studio album, The Slip, through its Web site, nin.com, for nothing. In a post on the site, the bands leader, Trent Reznor, said, Thank you for your continued and loyal support over the years  this ones on me. The album, which became available for download early Monday morning, seems to be the first time a superstar act has distributed an entire album free, without an option for fans to pay. Two months ago the band issued the instrumental album Ghosts I-IV, allowing fans to obtain a portion of it free or the entire recording for $5. Before that the British rock act Radiohead offered its 2007 album, In Rainbows, online with a tip-jar-style setup in which buyers could name their price, including nothing. The Slip could serve as a test of how the easy availability of free music online affects later CD sales and other money-making opportunities. The Slip will not be sold on CD or vinyl until at least July. But the free digital version could stoke interest for Nine Inch Nails recently announced concert tour. Not everyone seems convinced that such giveaways will be more than a promotional gimmick. But Jim Guerinot, the talent manager who represents Nine Inch Nails  which is now without a record contract and controls its own recordings  said: Free exists whether you want to acknowledge it or not. Lets acknowledge that, use it and do something with it.

Were big believers in the big spectacle, said Jay Marciano, the president of Madison Square Garden Entertainment, a division of Cablevision that owns and operates Radio City Music Hall, the Beacon Theater, Madison Square Garden and the WaMu Theater at Madison Square Garden. The touring show will incorporate elements of the 75th edition of the spectacular, which opened last year at the 6,000-seat Radio City Musical Hall. The touring show will involve 30 trucks and 16 buses, a huge screen and a cast of 56, including, of course, Rockettes. The show will open with an engagement on Nov. 8 and 9 in the Brown County Arena in Green Bay, Wis.; there are plans to play more than 60 markets in the next three years before repeating the cycle. If were successful in the U.S., well start to think about it in the context of international opportunities, Mr. Marciano said. (Tickets for the 2008 Radio City Christmas Spectacular at Radio City Music Hall went on sale last week. The show will run from Nov. 7 through Dec. 30.)

title: China: Virus Death Toll Climbs
description: The death toll from the spread of an intestinal virus rose to 26, and all of the dead were children younger than 6, according to Xinhua, the official Chinese news agency. The virus, known as hand, foot and mouth disease, has also infected nearly 12,000 others, more than triple the number reported Friday, the news agency said. Health officials have recorded cases far beyond the central province of Anhui, where the outbreak began, with infections as far south as Guangzhou and as far north as Beijing. The virus is not usually fatal, and health officials are at a loss to explain why so many children have died. The outbreak began in early April, but was not reported by health officials until last week, provoking accusations of a cover-up. On Monday, the government in Anhui Province punished 10 health officials for inadequate medical care or for mishandling the outbreak.

The official results, released Friday, showed that Mr. Tsvangirai had received more votes than President Robert Mugabe, but did not win by an outright majority. The runoff is supposed to be held within three weeks, but Mr. Mugabe can postpone the date by decree, buying more time for the repression of opposition supporters in areas that used to be his partys unquestioned strongholds, political analysts said. The opposition says the governing party, ZANU-PF, stole its presidential victory and has pursued a campaign of terror against its workers.

title: The Beauty of Clarified Butter
description: Recipe writers sometimes tell you to add oil to butter when sauting to keep the butter from burning. I never quite understood how the addition of oil would prevent the milk solids in the butter (which are what burn at low temperatures) from blackening and tasting nasty; it certainly never worked for me, and I abandoned the practice years ago. I finally looked this up in Harold McGees On Food and Cooking and, well, it doesnt work: whatever is going to burn at about 250 degrees will still burn at about 250 degrees. McGee also tells us that clarified butter - butter without the milk solids or water, hence more or less pure fat - doesnt burn until a good 400 degrees, a far more useful temperature for frying.

Take, for example, two recent reports, one on organic produce and the other on a slightly less mainstream ingredient, yak cheese.

title: Come for the Clothes, Stay for the Sweets
description: You might choose pants in a size 4 instead of a size 2 once you see the new Tisserie cafe on the Thompson Street side of the DKNY store in SoHo. Ronald and Morris Harrar, who own a pastry shop in Caracas, Venezuela, opened Tisserie in Union Square two years ago. This cafe, an offshoot, offers croissants and other morning temptations ($2 to $2.50), starting at 7:30 a.m., before the store opens. Later there are quiches ($5.99), brownies ($2.50), tiny fruit tarts ($1.50), above, Argentine alfajores cookies filled with dulce de leche (6 for $8), sandwiches ($8 to $12) and salads. A custard layered pudding topped with dulce de leche ($5.50) might mean size 6: 420 West Broadway (Spring Street), (646) 613-1100.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: A profile on April 29 about Francisco J. Ayala, a professor who speaks often in defense of the theory of evolution, misstated the location of McGill University, where he gave a recent talk. It is Montreal, not Toronto.

title: A Thoroughly Modern Oscar and Algernon
description: Deep in the third act of the Pearl Theater Companys entertaining production of The Importance of Being Earnest, I realized how much the sitcom Frasier owes to Oscar Wilde. Jack Worthing, this plays proper, endearingly puffed-up gentleman, is echoed in Frasier; Jacks more foppish, droll brother (as it turns out), Algernon Moncrieff, is Niles. And their swift, sardonic repartee in Wildes masterpiece ripples through the ages, surfacing  with conscious influence or not  in the most surprising places.

title: Some Signs of an Upturn for the Dollar
description: WASHINGTON  After six years of stumbling against the euro, the dollar may be showing signs of getting back on its feet.

title: UBS Announces $10.9 Billion Loss, Job Cuts, and Tax Probe
description: LONDON  The Swiss banking giant UBS, the European bank hit hardest by the tight credit market, said Tuesday that it had sold $15 billion of subprime mortgage debt and would cut 5,500 jobs as part of its cleanup, news that some investors saw as an indication that the bank was dealing with its problems.

title: Executions Resume, as Do Questions of Fairness
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  The release of the third death row inmate in six months in North Carolina last week is raising fresh questions about whether states are supplying capital-murder defendants with adequate counsel, even as an execution on Tuesday night in Georgia ended a seven-month national suspension.

title: In Battle of Aquariums, Big Gets Bigger
description: ATLANTA  Apparently eight million gallons of water and 80,000 animals were not enough for the Georgia Aquarium, which already claims to be the worlds largest. It did not have dolphins.

title: House Panel Backs a Subpoena for Cheneys Chief of Staff
description: WASHINGTON  A House panel investigating the Bush administrations approval for harsh interrogation methods voted Tuesday to issue a subpoena to David S. Addington, chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney and a primary proponent of the methods, which some legal experts have condemned as illegal torture.

title: Clinton Vows to Continue Her Run
description: INDIANAPOLIS  With a sizable share of votes yet to be counted and the outcome in the balance, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton claimed victory Tuesday night in the Indiana primary and vowed to push on to the remaining contests on the nearly finished Democratic presidential nominating calendar.

title: Clinton Takes Indiana by Slim Margin; Obama Wins North Carolina Decisively
description: Senator Barack Obama won a commanding victory in the North Carolina primary on Tuesday, while Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton very narrowly won Indiana, an outcome that injected a boost of momentum to Mr. Obamas candidacy as the Democratic nominating contest entered its final month.

title: Japan Fights Crowds of Crows
description: KAGOSHIMA, Japan  Fanning out in small teams, the men in gray jumpsuits scour the streets and rooftops with binoculars, seeking to guard this city from a growing menace. They look for telltale signs: a torn garbage bag, a pile of twigs atop an electric pole or one of the black, winged culprits themselves.

title: Europe Delays Decision on Growing of Modified Crops
description: The European Union authorities delayed decisions on Wednesday on whether to allow European farmers to grow types of genetically modified crops, heightening tensions with agro-science companies and risking further friction with trading partners like the United States.

title: World Wrestling Entertainments Earnings Rise 29%
description: World Wrestling Entertainment, the producer of the television show Friday Night SmackDown, said first-quarter profit rose 29 percent on increases in films and live events.

title: Companies Improve Scores in Climate-Change Ranking
description: This just in from Climate Counts, the nonprofit group that scores consumer products companies on their green track records: consumer companies are getting greener, but they are still a pretty carbon-intensive lot.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: A picture caption with an article on Sunday about electrocutions of American soldiers in Iraq because of flawed wiring misstated, on second reference, the surname of a victim shown with his mother, Cheryl Harris. He was Staff Sgt. Ryan D. Maseth, not Sergeant Harris.

title: State Watch for 2 Percent of Doctors
description: ALBANY  More than 2 percent of all doctors practicing in New York last year landed on the state medical boards watch list because of problems including substance abuse, mental health concerns or their professional conduct.

title: A Challenge Getting Relief to Myanmars Remote Areas
description: BANGKOK  International aid agencies began distributing food in Myanmars commercial capital and main city, Yangon, on Tuesday but there was uncertainty that the assistance would reach people stranded without shelter in the remoter reaches of the countrys vast Irrawaddy Delta.

title: Monet and Rodin Set Price Records at Christies
description: Fears that the Christies sale of Impressionist and modern art would usher in a market meltdown were assuaged early Tuesday evening when everything from a Monet landscape to a monumental sculpture by Rodin brought record prices.

title: Iran: What Does Exporting the Revolution Mean?
description: A former president has come under attack by Tehrans leading conservative newspaper for comments that appeared to suggest that Iran was supporting insurgents in other countries. On Monday, the newspaper, Kayhan, accused Mohammad Khatami, the former president, of making remarks that were against Irans national interests. Mr. Khatami said in a speech on Friday that when the founder of the 1979 revolution, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, talked about exporting the revolution, he meant making Iran a role model for other countries, not supporting sabotage operations in other countries.

title: After Fossellas D.W.I. Arrest, District Is Puzzled and Torn
description: He has become the talk of his own Congressional district, and not always in the most flattering of tones. Across Staten Island on Tuesday, voters were wondering what Representative Vito J. Fossella was thinking when, the police say, he drove into a Washington suburb while severely intoxicated early one morning last week.

title: Wines Pleasures: Are They All in Your Head?
description: THE mind of the wine consumer is a woolly place, packed with odd and arcane information fascinating to few. Like the pants pocket of a 7-year-old boy, its full of bits of string, bottle caps and shiny rocks collected while making the daily rounds of wine shops, restaurants, periodicals and the wine-soaked back alleys of the Internet. Its harmless stuff, really, except to those within earshot when a wine lover finds it necessary to elaborate on the nose, legs and body of a new infatuation.

title: Guatemala: Hiatus in Foreign Adoptions Is Ordered
description: Guatemala has ordered a one-month hiatus in foreign adoptions, to investigate potential fraud. A law that took effect in January created a government adoption authority to replace an adoption system handled by private lawyers. The suspension affects 2,300 adoptions that began earlier. The attorney general, Baudilio Portillo, said the cases, most of them involving American parents, will be individually reviewed, according to the British Broadcasting Corporation.

title: California Awards $271 Million for Stem Cell Research
description: LOS ANGELES  California has awarded $271 million in grants to build 12 new stem cell research centers in the state, even as one of the political rationales for the building program might soon disappear.

title: Fire Dept. to Send Units First, Save the Questions for Later
description: A pilot program for Fire Department dispatchers in Queens was so successful in improving response times that it will be extended across the city next month, the department said on Tuesday.

title: Patents Need Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: Young Artists Find a Private Space, Only Without the Privacy
description: One room is a cramped cubby that measures, in all, perhaps 25 square feet, just enough for a full-size mattress and whatever can be stashed beneath. The first-floor rooms, in the basement, are musty and windowless, like caves. The second-floor rooms have plywood walls but no doors, only cut-out windows that overlook a kitchen cluttered with day-old dishes, a chore wheel and the odd paintbrush.

title: Fillys Death Brings Issues to Fore, but Where Is the Accountability?
description: For the last several days, the death of Eight Belles at the Kentucky Derby has become the talk of the nation. The fillys demise was especially sobering for casual fans, whose only contact with horse racing is through one of the Triple Crown races.

title: At the Airport, Training for Heightened Diplomacy
description: At Fordham University, students can take courses in personal branding and sales management.

title: Telescoping 4,000 Years of Talmud and Tradition
description: It is easy to see why someone might approach The Jewish People: A Story of Survival with a certain reservation. The documentary, to be shown on Wednesday on WLIW and on other PBS stations in June, condenses four millenniums of atrocity into 60 minutes, allotting the pogroms the amount of time it takes to dust a coffee table.

title: The Foreclosure Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Serras Monumental Vision, Vertical Edition
description: PARIS  France is making a fuss this week over Richard Serra, the 68-year-old American bantamweight who fashions elegant, gargantuan art out of steel.

title: South Africa: Cabinet Appointment Requested
description: The governing African National Congress has asked South Africas president, Thabo Mbeki, to appoint the partys deputy president, Kgalema Motlanthe, to serve in Parliament and in Mr. Mbekis cabinet. Mr. Motlanthe is an ally of the partys president, Jacob G. Zuma, a keen rival of Mr. Mbekis. Mr. Motlanthe has often been mentioned as a possible heir to Mr. Zuma, whose trial on corruption charges is scheduled to begin in August. The partys secretary general, Gwede Mantashe, made the partys request for Mr. Motlanthes appointment public at a news conference.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article on April 25 about new federal measures that offer a path to legal status for illegal immigrants whose close relatives died in the Sept. 11 attacks misstated the position of a Republican congressman, Dan Lungren of California, on a proposed House bill that would grant the immigrants permanent resident visas. He supported it when it went before the House Judiciary Committee but said he wanted to know how many immigrants would be affected before supporting it in a final vote on the floor. He did not oppose the bill.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article on Friday about the early success of the Tampa Bay Rays this season misstated the year that Troy Percival, a pitcher, won a World Series title with the Angels. It was 2002, not 2004.

title: Cisco Sales Top Lowered Forecast, and Profit Declines
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Cisco Systems to Wall Street: Its not so bad.

title: Urban Farmers Crops Go From Vacant Lot to Market
description: IN the shadows of the elevated tracks toward the end of the No. 3 line in East New York, Brooklyn, with an April chill still in the air, Denniston and Marlene Wilks gently pulled clusters of slender green shoots from the earth, revealing a blush of tiny red shallots at the base.

title: Lost Opportunities Plague Mets
description: LOS ANGELES  It was a game the Dodgers appeared to be willing to concede to the Mets. Shortstop Rafael Furcal, their offensive catalyst, sat out with back stiffness on Tuesday night and many of the rest of the Dodgers seemed to have checked out mentally.

title: Lost and Found in New York Taxicabs
description: MIDTOWN, FEBRUARY 2007 A woman from Dallas left a suitcase in Osman Chowdhurys taxi, which she took from the Hilton Hotel to East 35th Street between Second and Third Avenues. She gave Mr. Chowdhury a 30-cent tip on a $10.70 fare  and a $100 reward when he returned the suitcase, which had been left in the trunk and which held, in addition to clothing, 31 diamond rings and a laptop computer.

title: Officials Memory an Issue When Time Stands Still
description: The officials huddled on the court, armed with nothing but their memories of a few fleeting seconds of action. They were trying to determine the length of time it took to run a play, which is nearly impossible to determine without a clock.

title: Attempted Killings Incite Violence in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Scattered violence struck areas of Baghdad as well as parts of central and northern Iraq on Tuesday, as a trickle of families began to leave Sadr City to escape bombings, and Iraqi security forces raided a hospital suspected of treating militia forces.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with a report in some editions on Saturday about the N.B.A. playoffs misidentified the player shown dunking for Atlanta. He was Al Horford, not his teammate Josh Smith.

title: Butter-Braised Asparagus and Oyster Mushrooms With Peas and Tarragon
description: Time: 20 minutes

title: Thom Yorke and Company, Kicking Off a Tour With a Lush Miasma
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  Radiohead played the first concert of its North American tour here at the Cruzan Amphitheater on Monday night, and nobody onstage was tan. Weve just spent the last three days in Miami Beach, said Thom Yorke, the bands lead singer, looking incredulous. Whats going on there? Some kind of reconstruction. For once I was proud to be white, pale and English.

title: Medical Drama Pays Off for Fox
description: Fox claimed a share of first place in the ratings on Monday, largely because of its medical drama, House, starring Hugh Laurie, above with Jennifer Morrison. Despite a modest audience of 13.3 million viewers reported by Nielsen, House, at 9 p.m., delivered the nights top ratings among adults 18 to 49. That was enough to lift Fox into a tie with CBS for first in that demographic even though Foxs Bones earned relatively mediocre results at 8 p.m. (8.1 million). CBS was solid during both hours with its regular comedy lineup and led the 10 p.m. time slot by a wide margin with CSI: Miami (13.9 million). ABC finished third among the 18-to-49 set, but outperformed Fox and CBS in total viewers, as Dancing With the Stars averaged 17.9 million total viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m. ABCs Bachelor (7 million), however, remained mired in third place at 10 behind CSI: Miami and NBCs Medium (9.5 million). NBC finished fourth overall, broadcasting Deal or No Deal from 8 to 10 (8.4 million).

title: The Death Penalty Returns
description: Roughly 15 death row prisoners are scheduled to be put to death between now and October, according to the Death Penalty Information Center. This flood of executions is the result of the Supreme Courts ruling that upheld the constitutionality of a troubling form of lethal injection. The next few months, as states put their machinery of death into overdrive, are an ideal time for the nation to rethink its commitment to capital punishment.

title: Burger With a Side of Spies
description: Monterey, Calif.

title: White House Vows to Veto Housing Measure
description: WASHINGTON  On the eve of a House floor debate on a plan to help homeowners in danger of foreclosure, the Bush administration said on Tuesday that it opposed the measure and that White House advisers would urge the president to veto it.

title: Protg in Russia Is Sworn In
description: MOSCOW  Dmitri A. Medvedev, a soft-spoken lawyer and Kremlin insider who had never held elected office before, was sworn in as Russias president at noon Wednesday inside the Grand Kremlin Palace.

title: Jagr Will Take Some Time to Decide Future
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Jaromir Jagr walked into his future on Tuesday and sounded a little more encouraging about returning to New York.

title: Bush Advisers Oppose Housing Measure, and Vow a Veto
description: WASHINGTON  On the eve of a House floor debate on a plan to help homeowners in danger of foreclosure, the Bush administration said on Tuesday that it opposed the measure and that White House advisers would urge the president to veto it.

title: Wishing Happy Birthday to a Place Where Art Is Made
description: The Joyce Theater, now a Chelsea institution, gave itself a 25th-birthday party on Monday night: a couple of choreographic appetizers, followed by dinner and dancing of the social sort. Mercifully, the speeches were short.

title: 3 Taiwan Officials Quit in Diplomatic Furor
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  The foreign minister of Taiwan and two other top officials resigned on Tuesday over a botched attempt to win diplomatic recognition from Papua New Guinea, a scandal that has stirred public outrage against the departing government just two weeks before it is to step down.

title: Focus Turns to Long Island Philanthropist as Israeli Prime Minister Is Investigated
description: A Long Island philanthropist and fund-raiser for Israeli charities is at the center of a growing storm surrounding Israels prime minister, Ehud Olmert, that has riveted and agitated Israel despite a veil of secrecy over the continuing investigation.

title: Clintons Options Seem to Dwindle
description: In this case, a split was not a draw.

title: Irvine Robbins, Ice Cream Entrepreneur and a Maestro of 31 Flavors, Dies at 90
description: Irvine Robbins, who with his brother-in-law, Burton Baskin, started the Baskin-Robbins chain of ice cream stores  together concocting quirky flavor combinations with names like Daiquiri Ice, Pink Bubblegum and Here Comes the Fudge  died on Monday near his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 90.

title: Removing the Crust for a Savory Custard
description: I SUPPOSE crustless quiche is a contradiction in terms, like seared ceviche. But if, like me, you sometimes crave what amounts to savory pie filling without the hassle of making an actual crust, this is the way to go. (The other option is to buy a crust and fill it, but if you can find a good pre-made crust youre a better shopper than I am.)

title: A New Governor, Yes, but an Old Port Authority
description: For all the drama of the coup descort that brought down Eliot Spitzer and delivered David A. Paterson into the governors office, any shifts of power in the state since then have been as noiseless as a fog.

title: Simmering Anti-Semitism Mars a Vibrant Hungary
description: BUDAPEST  Ostensibly, a rock concert sparked it, reminding us that culture is not the exclusive province of liberals, certainly not here in Europe. A young woman (who knows whether she was just intending to make trouble) walked into a ticket office in the traditionally Jewish 13th District in this Hungarian capital several weeks ago and asked about Hungarica, an obscure extremist far-right band.

title: Kennedy Makes Most of His Trip to Minors
description: By the time he met with reporters a few minutes after the Yankees 5-3 loss to Cleveland on Tuesday night, Joe Girardi had already heard the happier news from Moosic, Pa. Ian Kennedy, the rookie starter the Yankees demoted to Class AAA on Sunday, had thrown seven and a third shutout innings, allowing just one hit.

title: Gas Prices Expected to Peak in June
description: Oil jumped to another record on Tuesday, and the government said it expected gasoline prices to peak at a national average of $3.73 a gallon in June, just as the summer driving season kicks off.

title: Alvin Colt, Broadway Costume Designer, Dies at 91
description: Alvin Colt, a Tony Award-winning costume designer who draped actors in everything from gamblers pinstripes for Guys and Dolls to flowing robes for classic Shakespearean productions to vacuum cleaner hoses and Coca-Cola cans for recent spoofs of Broadway musicals, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 91.

title: Butterflies Arent Free
description: INDIANAPOLIS

title: Turqua Grill and The JakeWalk
description: NEW PLACES

title: F.B.I. Raids Office of Special Counsel
description: WASHINGTON  F.B.I. agents on Tuesday raided and temporarily shut down the offices of a small federal watchdog agency that is charged with protecting the rights of government whistle-blowers but has been accused of retaliating against whistle-blowers in its own ranks.

title: New Mexico Compounds Enraptured Believers
description: There is much to make the jaw drop in Inside a Cult, a timely documentary about the Strong City sect in New Mexico being shown on Wednesday on the National Geographic Channel. But by its end you may feel that the most stunning thing is that this film exists at all. Why would these people have let a documentarian get so close to their exceedingly eccentric world?

title: Construction Worker Is Killed in Fall From a Scaffold
description: A construction worker fell about 30 feet to his death from a scaffold on the Triborough Bridge in Queens on Tuesday afternoon, officials said.

title: Yeltsin: A Life
description: At twelve noon, Friday, December 31, 1999, Moscow time, on the cusp of the new year, the new century, and the new millennium, a surprise announcement from the presidents office was televised across Russia from the Baltic Sea, where the sun had crept above the horizon, to the Bering Strait, where it had just dipped below. Boris Yeltsin, attired in a charcoal-gray suit and silver tie, with a tinseled holiday tree in the background, had videotaped it that morning. He was retiring seven months before the expiration of his mandate, he said hoarsely, and was handing over power to the prime minister and now acting president, Vladimir Putin, pending confirmation by the electorate. As the terse clip rolled, the presidential suite, paraphernalia, and nuclear briefcase were already in Putins hands and Yeltsin was clinking glasses at a leave-taking luncheon.

title: The Police Bow Out in New York
description: The Police said on Tuesday that it would play its final concert this summer in New York. A statement posted on the Web site of the frontman, Sting  (sting.com), said, We kicked off our very first American tour at CBGBs in 1978 and this summer, 30 years later, our journey will come full circle as we play our final show here in New York City. The concert will be a fund-raiser to benefit arts programming for Thirteen/WNET and WLIW New York. Tickets will be available nationally online through those stations. The date and site of the performance are to be announced. At a news conference in Times Square with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, Sting, joined by the guitarist Andy Summers and the drummer Stewart Copeland, said the band, which split up in 1984 and reunited for a 30th anniversary world tour last year, was also pledging $1 million to the Mayors Fund to Advance New York City in support of MillionTreesNYC. The donation, matched by the city, will provide $2 million to help implement the reforestation component of MillionTreesNYC, which plans to plant 10,000 trees and reforest 2,000 acres of parkland across the five boroughs. Reforestation improves air and water quality, reduces greenhouse gases and lowers energy costs.

title: I.O.C. Rules Will Limit Protests by Athletes
description: Athletes who compete in the Beijing Olympics will not be allowed to wave flags, make gestures or alter their external appearance to make a political statement, according to guidelines issued in April by the International Olympic Committee.

title: At the Philharmonic, Musings About Muti
description: The announced union of Riccardo Muti and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra left 100 jilted suitors at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday.

title: An Improvised Asparagus Dish Is a Happy Accident
description: WHEN it came to cooking asparagus, I thought my skill set was complete.

title: The Risks of Brand-Building in the Winners Circle
description: MINUTES before he was to appear live on NBC on Saturday as the presenting sponsor of the Kentucky Derby, David C. Novak, the chief executive of Yum Brands, says he was in the dark.

title: New Rules, Different Chamberlain
description: Last season, it was the Joba Rules, the wordplay that referred to the Yankees careful use of Joba Chamberlain and his utter dominance of the opposition. This season, the term does not quite apply.

title: Revenue Rises 16 Percent at News Corporation
description: The News Corporation, the global media conglomerate controlled by Rupert Murdoch, reported a 16 percent gain in revenue in the third quarter on Thursday, mainly from growth in the companys television and cable networks businesses.

title: Amid Partisan Standoff, Bush Submits 3 Nominees to Election Commission
description: President Bush on Tuesday submitted three new nominees to the Federal Election Commission, a move that could help end a political impasse that has left the agency paralyzed in the midst of a heated presidential campaign.

title: An Auction of New Chinese Art Leaves Disjointed Noses in Its Wake
description: SHANGHAI  Sothebys auction house called it the most important collection of contemporary Chinese art to ever come to market  some 200 works by some of Chinas hottest names.

title: A Culinary Schools Changes Are Met With Unrest
description: ON the campus of the Culinary Institute of America, the New York culinary school whose alumni include many of the biggest names in cooking, the mood is as tense as a Gordon Ramsay kitchen.

title: Tapping Into a Clean Alternative
description: Though it will occupy a square foot of counter space and stands 16 inches tall, the new Cuisinart countertop water filtration unit can process 80 gallons of water before the filter needs replacing.

title: A $500 Million Week for Grand Theft Auto
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Grand Theft Auto IV, the latest iteration of the hit video game franchise, racked up first-week sales of $500 million, Take-Two Interactive, the games publisher, plans to announce on Wednesday. The report exceeded the sales expectations of analysts.

title: New Musical for Harry Connick Jr.
description: Harry Connick Jr., in the role of a Long Island playboy, will return to Broadway in March as the star of Nice Work if You Can Get It, a new musical comedy with songs by George and Ira Gershwin. Joe DiPietro, whose credits include I Love You, Youre Perfect, Now Change and All Shook Up, will provide the book. Kathleen Marshall, who directed Mr. Connick in the 2006 revival of The Pajama Game and won a Tony Award for her choreography, will direct and choreograph the new show, at a theater to be announced.

title: Obama Wins North Carolina Decisively; Clinton Takes Indiana by Slim Margin
description: Senator Barack Obama won a commanding victory in the North Carolina primary on Tuesday and lost narrowly to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in Indiana, an outcome that injected a boost of momentum to Mr. Obamas candidacy as the Democratic nominating contest entered its final month.

title: F.B.I. Raids Office of Special Counsel
description: WASHINGTON  The office of the official responsible for protecting federal workers from political interference was raided by F.B.I. agents on Tuesday as part of an investigation into whether he himself mixed politics with official business.

title: Film Says Franco Rigged Eurovision Contest
description: The Spanish dictator Francisco Franco rigged the vote in the 1968 Eurovision Song Contest, cheating the British entertainer Cliff Richard, below, of victory, according to a documentary to be televised on Thursday in Spain, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Richards song Congratulations was the favorite in the competition, held that year in London, but it was beaten by a single point by La La La, sung by a Spanish contestant, Massiel. The film contends that Franco (thats his statue below, in Santander, Spain), bought votes by dispatching music and television executives to other countries in Europe to purchase the rights to series that were never broadcast and to sign obscure acts. Jos Mara Iigo, a Spanish public television journalist, told the documentary that the Franco regime had a great need to win recognition, even if it was only in one area. In 1968 the winner of the Eurovision contest was determined by a jury from each participating country. The winner is now chosen by votes cast by telephone and text message from television viewers. Informed of the content of the documentary, Mr. Richard told The Guardian of London, Ive lived with this No. 2 thing for so many years, it would be wonderful if someone official from the contest turned around and said, Cliff, you won that darn thing after all.

title: Dancing Around Town
description: The Joyce Theaters celebration of its 25th anniversary will continue with a free festival of 25 outdoor performances spread throughout New Yorks five boroughs over five days, from July 16 to 20. A presentation with the City Parks Foundation, the festival, Dance Out!, features three international works: Dans le Jardin, an improvised piece created and performed by the Dutch choreographer Michael Schumacher and set to live music by the cellist Alex Waterman; Compagnie Beau Gestes Transports Exceptionnels, a duet by Dominique Boivin for a man and an excavator, accompanied by the voice of Maria Callas; and Contigo, a solo by the Portuguese choreographer Rui Horta for the acrobat and the Chinese-pole master Joo P. Pereira Dos Santos. Dance Out! opens with all three works being performed at the East River Park on July 16 at 7 p.m. From there it spreads to locations including the parachute jump at Coney Island, the Socrates Sculpture Park in Queens and the South Beach boardwalk in Staten Island. Information: Joyce.org or cityparksfoundation.org.

title: Truffles? Call It Fudge With Class
description: Truffles, the chocolate kind, usually have creamy ganache centers. But John Kelly Chocolates in Los Angeles has made the truffle homy by using old-fashioned fudge instead of ganache. An old-fashioned chocolate-loving mom might appreciate them on Sunday.

title: In England, at Home in a Railroad Station
description: LENWADE, England

title: After 60 Years, Arabs in Israel Are Outsiders
description: JERUSALEM  As Israel toasts its 60th anniversary in the coming weeks, rejoicing in Jewish national rebirth and democratic values, the Arabs who make up 20 percent of its citizens will not be celebrating. Better off and better integrated than ever in their history, freer than a vast majority of other Arabs, Israels 1.3 million Arab citizens are still far less well off than Israeli Jews and feel increasingly unwanted.

title: After Making an Early Call, CBS Keeps a Lonely Stand
description: At 8:09 p.m. on Tuesday, Katie Couric broke into the procedural crime drama NCIS to tell her viewers: A split decision tonight in the latest primary showdown: Hillary Clinton needed to win Indiana; CBS News estimates she did. Meanwhile, were projecting Barack Obama the winner in North Carolina.

title: Write-Down at Wachovia Nearly Doubles Its Loss
description: Wachovia reported on Tuesday that its previously reported first-quarter loss nearly doubled to $708 million because of a write-down tied to life insurance policies.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: The Books of The Times review on Thursday, about A Wolf at the Table, referred incorrectly to another book by Augusten Burroughs, Sellevision. It is a satirical novel about a television home-shopping network; it is not about Mr. Burroughss experiences in the advertising business.

title: Gingrich Warns G.O.P. Swift Change Is Needed
description: WASHINGTON  Newt Gingrich, the man who engineered the Republican takeover of the House in 1994, warned his fellow Republicans on Tuesday that they faced disastrous losses in November without a quick change in political course.

title: The Cost of Smarts
description: Research on animal intelligence always makes me wonder just how smart humans are. Consider the fruit-fly experiments described in Carl Zimmers piece in the Science Times on Tuesday. Fruit flies who were taught to be smarter than the average fruit fly tended to live shorter lives. This suggests that dimmer bulbs burn longer, that there is an advantage in not being too terrifically bright.

title: Garnett Comes Up as Big One for Celtics
description: BOSTON  LeBron James sank behind a wall of bodies, barely visible or audible from even a few feet away, his usual regal presence muted by the crowd and the din that surrounded him.

title: Aid to Education
description: To the Editor:

title: 8 Men Are Accused of Abducting, Torturing and Robbing Dozens of Drug Dealers
description: A gang of robbers used fake police lights, sirens and badges  and real handcuffs and guns  to pull over and rob more than 100 drug dealers of cash and cocaine in New York and elsewhere up and down the East Coast, federal prosecutors charged in an indictment unsealed on Tuesday.

title: Trainer Recalls One That Got Away
description: Pat Reynolds watched the Kentucky Derby on Saturday and did not know if he should laugh, cry, cheer, feel sorry for himself or just enjoy the spectacular performance of a horse he knows intimately. For Reynolds, Big Browns first trainer, it was a bittersweet time.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Ross, Head to Head

title: Thurmans Pursuer Is Found Guilty
description: Jack Jordan, a University of Chicago graduate turned drifter who lived in his car, was found guilty on Tuesday of stalking the actress Uma Thurman, the star of edgy, violent movies like Kill Bill and Pulp Fiction.

title: The Making of Yeltsin, His Boldness and Flaws
description: In the introduction to his biography of Boris N. Yeltsin, Timothy J. Colton lists more than 100 of the similes and analogies that have been applied over the years to Yeltsin, among them martyr and jester, Lincoln and Nixon, Alexander the Great and Ivan the Terrible, Hamlet and Hercules, bear, bulldog and boa constrictor. The wry list is an early signal that Mr. Colton knows he is treading into a subject that has inspired rival mythologies.

title: Fannie Mae Wins Cheers Despite Loss
description: Fannie Mae, the nations largest buyer of home loans, gave investors little reason to cheer Tuesday, announcing a $2.2 billion quarterly loss and a dividend cut, and warning of steeper losses ahead.

title: Bright Lights and Big Money in Indias New Cricket League
description: NAVI MUMBAI, India  With an infusion of bling, Bollywood and go-go boots, a new cricket league is trying to spin off Indias colonial inheritance into a money-making symbol of a brash, emerging nation.

title: China-India Rivalry Possible in African Telecom Deal
description: NEW DELHI  A battle for the MTN Group, a leading South African telecommunications company, could come down to a clash between the worlds largest and fastest-growing emerging markets.

title: British Contractor Told to Strengthen Ethical Standards
description: LONDON  BAE Systems, the British military contractor accused of paying bribes to win contracts, must improve its ethical standards or risk more damage to its reputation, a panel reviewing its business ethics concluded on Tuesday.

title: Changes at New Orleans Schools Bring Gains in Test Scores
description: NEW ORLEANS  A broad education overhaul under way here has produced improvement in test scores, results released Tuesday showed, though many students are still struggling.

title: European Commission Sues to Force Italy to Take Out the Garbage
description: After years of warnings, and a spell of hot weather that did nothing to improve the stink of tons of uncollected trash around Naples, the European Commission filed suit against Italy on Tuesday, charging that it had failed to meet its obligation to collect and dispose of its rubbish.

title: Benefits
description: Stepping Up to the Plate

title: Quarrel Erupts Between Bears Elder Statesmen
description: After 59 years, Alan C. Greenberg is still trading away at Bear Stearns, the troubled Wall Street bank that is about to disappear. Ask about his retirement plans, and he lets out a belly-jiggling laugh.

title: The Pursuer of Thurman Is Convicted
description: A jury in Manhattan decided Tuesday that Jack Jordan had tried too hard to meet Uma Thurman and sent her one too many love letters.

title: Actors Guild and Producers End Talks
description: LOS ANGELES  Representatives of the Screen Actors Guild and Hollywoods production companies ended their contract talks after three fruitless weeks.

title: Jane Jacobs Honorees Are Chosen
description: Jane Jacobs Medals and $100,000 each will be awarded to Peggy Shepard and Alexie Torres-Fleming by the Rockefeller Foundation in a ceremony on Sept. 8 at the Morgan Library & Museum. The Jane Jacobs Medal was created last year by the foundation to honor Ms. Jacobs, the urban design author and activist who died at 89 in 2006. Ms. Shepard, 61, is the executive director and a founder of West Harlem Environmental Action, a leader in publicizing and combating the practice of situating environmentally harmful facilities in working-class neighborhoods with minority residents. Ms. Torres-Fleming, 43, is the founder of Youth Ministries for Peace and Justice in the South Bronx and a founder of the Southern Bronx River Watershed Alliance, a coalition of local groups campaigning to replace the Sheridan Expressway with affordable housing and green spaces.

title: Its About the White House
description: Like many Americans, we have been intrigued and often exasperated by the long-running Democratic primary and the ever smaller-bore spats between Senators Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama. So we are thankful to Senator John McCain for reminding us Tuesday what this years presidential race really is about.

title: 75 Students Arrested in Drug Raid
description: SAN DIEGO  Seventy-five students at San Diego State University have been arrested on drug and weapons charges in an undercover operation that grew out of a students death from a cocaine overdose last year, law enforcement authorities said on Tuesday.

title: What You Get for ... $3 Million
description: Honolulu

title: Cabdriver Thanked for Returning a Stradivarius
description: NEWARK  The violinist stood on a makeshift stage between two lampposts crowned with a patina of bird droppings, under a weathered vinyl canopy hastily erected outside Newark Liberty International Airport in the taxicab holding area. The audience watched him in awe, about 50 drivers in three rows, their yellow cabs a few feet behind, some lined up neatly, others askew.

title: Paying for Doctors Classes
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeing Inflation Only in the Prices That Go Up
description: Next week, the Bureau of Labor Statistics will release its monthly report on inflation, and it sure is going to sound strange. Wall Street is expecting the bureau to announce that the Consumer Price Index rose just three-tenths of a percentage point in April. Over the last year, the index has risen only about 4 percent.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on April 26 about the acquittal of three New York City police detectives in the shooting death of Sean Bell misstated the date of his death in some copies. It was Nov. 25, 2006, not Nov. 26.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article on Friday about the quarterly earnings for Sun Microsystems misstated the given name of the companys chief financial officer. He is Michael Lehman, not Mark.

title: In Europe, New Scrutiny of Ethical Standards
description: PARIS  A series of bribery investigations at leading European companies has helped to accelerate compliance with global anticorruption standards as managers recognize the risk to their brands and reputations, legal analysts and international regulators say.

title: A City Committed to Recycling Is Ready for More
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Mayor Gavin Newsom is competitive about many things, garbage included. When the city found out a few weeks ago that it was keeping 70 percent of its disposable waste out of local landfills, he embraced the statistic the way other mayors embrace winning sports teams, improved test scores or declining crime rates.

title: Lazard Profit Off 71% on Problems in Corporate Holdings
description: Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, said Tuesday that its first-quarter profit plunged 71 percent, hurt largely by a $28.5 million write-down in its holdings of corporate debt and losses in its corporate equity portfolio.

title: Crustless Quiche
description: Time: 30 to 40 minutes

title: Lottery Numbers
UBS Banker Detained in Tax Inquiry
description: A top-ranking UBS executive was briefly detained by federal authorities in the United States in connection with a widening investigation into the Swiss banks work with questionable tax transactions, the bank said Wednesday.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article in some editions on April 15 about a plan by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to install solar panels at its facilities misidentified the entity from which it buys electricity. It is the New York Power Authority, not Consolidated Edison.

title: A Technology Consortium Plans a Wireless Network
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A whos who of technology and telecommunications companies plans to announce on Wednesday that it intends to build the first of a new generation of nationwide wireless data networks, according to several people briefed on the deal.

title: No Signs of a Slowdown in Traffic at Disneys Parks
description: LOS ANGELES  Mickey Mouse, so far at least, is not a discretionary expense.

title: Evacuation Ordered as Chilean Volcano Begins to Spew Ash
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  The Chaitn volcano in southern Chile blasted ash and what appeared to be lava a dozen miles into the air on Tuesday, leading the government to order the immediate and complete evacuation of everyone living within a 30-mile radius of it.

title: A Win for Clemenss Lawyer
description: A federal judge Tuesday ruled that Roger Clemenss lead lawyer, Rusty Hardin, could continue to represent Clemens in a defamation lawsuit he filed against his former personal trainer Brian McNamee.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article on April 24 about Augusten Burroughs, who has published a new memoir, A Wolf at the Table, referred incompletely to the settlement of a lawsuit over another book by Mr. Burroughs, Running With Scissors, that was filed by the children of a psychiatrist he lived with as a teenager. In addition to changes in some language on the acknowledgments page, there was a financial settlement of an undisclosed amount, and Mr. Burroughs and his publisher, St. Martins Press, agreed to call the work a book instead of a memoir in the authors note.

title: Quinn Plans More Changes in Councils Budget Process
description: Speaker Christine C. Quinn plans to announce more changes to the City Councils budget process, possibly as early as Wednesday, amid growing controversy over how council members spend the millions in discretionary money they control.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: Suburban Office Market Uneasy but Holding Up
description: To gauge the direction of the commercial real estate market these days, John P. Hannigan, a co-owner of Choyce Peterson, a brokerage firm in Westchester and Fairfield Counties that specializes in representing tenants, relies on his own economic weather vane.

title: The Democratic Recession
description: There are two important recessions going on in the world today. One has gotten enormous attention. Its the economic recession in America. But it will eventually pass, and the world will not be much worse for the wear. The other has gotten no attention. Its called the democratic recession, and if it isnt reversed, it will change the world for a long time.

title: Footnotes
description: Betrayed was honored as outstanding play and The Adding Machine as outstanding musical when the 23rd annual Lucille Lortel Awards for outstanding achievement Off Broadway were presented on Monday by the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers at the Union Square Theater. Among other honorees were Theodore Mann, given the Edith Oliver Award for Sustained Excellence; and Primary Stages, for Outstanding Body of Work. ...Garth Drabinsky and Myron Gottlieb, the founders of Livent, the Broadway theater company that produced Ragtime and Showboat, pleaded not guilty to large-scale accounting fraud as their trial began on Monday in Ontario Superior Court in Toronto, The Associated Press reported. ... The Babyshambles frontman Pete Doherty was released from Wormwood Scrubs prison in west London yesterday after serving 29 days of a 14-week sentenced for breaking probation imposed for drug and driving offenses, the BBC reported. ... The police in Angola arrested Bruno Carvalho, the man accused of jumping onstage and snatching a neck chain off the rapper 50 Cent during a concert last week in Luanda, AllHipHop.com reported. Mr. Carvalho was turned in by his parents.

title: Injured Racehorses You Didnt See
description: Will the death of the Kentucky Derby runner-up spur any real, meaningful change within the thoroughbred racing industry? Does it take a nationally televised catastrophe to bring about significant, long-term betterment to racehorse safety?

title: Guantnamo, Defended
description: To the Editor:

title: The Killing of Innocents Faces a Dry-Eyed Dissection
description: In Battle for Haditha, the British filmmaker Nick Broomfield revisits a wretched chapter of the war in Iraq. On Nov. 19, 2005, marines stationed in Haditha, a Euphrates River valley city northwest of Baghdad, killed 24 Iraqi civilians, including at least 10 women and children, from toddler age up, who were in their homes. The reasons for the killings remain in dispute, though not this evidence: most victims died from close-range gunfire and at least five were shot in the head. After various investigations, murder charges against four marines were dropped; one still faces reduced charges.

title: Disaster in Myanmar
description: By all accounts, Cyclone Nargis has devastated Myanmar  a 12-foot wall of water sweeping away entire villages, leaving the coastal plain under water, thousands dead, missing or homeless and much of the capital city of Yangon without electricity or water. It is the sort of disaster that brings the world together in a desire to help, and the reaction of governments, the United Nations and international humanitarian organizations has been swift and noble. There is no time to waste.

title: Technology Group Plans Wireless Network
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A whos who of technology and telecommunications companies announced Wednesday that it intended to build the first of a new generation of nationwide wireless data networks.

description: To the Editor:

description: Front Page

title: McCain Assures Conservatives of His Stance on Judges
description: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C.  Senator John McCain reached out to conservatives on Tuesday by vowing to appoint judges he characterized as strictly faithful to the Constitution and who did not engage in what Mr. McCain condemned as the common and systemic abuse of our federal courts.

title: Give the Lower East Side Some Respect
description: To the Editor:

title: Tight Credit Worries for a Hotel and Mall Operator
description: David Lichtenstein was new to the hotel business when he made one of the last big highly leveraged real estate deals before the credit squeeze, acquiring Extended Stay Hotels, a chain of 687 no-frills hotels, last June for $8.1 billion.

title: Further Travails of Scarlett and Rhett
description: Pummeled by the critics, the London production of Gone With the Wind will have its running time trimmed by 15 minutes to three and a quarter hours, the lead producer told The Independent, adding that he was committed to continuing the run of the $9.5 million show that bills itself as a play with music. Aldo Scrofani, the lead producer, said: Even the people who love the show have said its a bit long. It is long  and its going to be cut. Once that is accomplished, he said, the story itself will be more highlighted. He denied that Trevor Nunn, the director, was forced to shrink the show, and denied rumors that management had planned to post a closing notice at the New London Theater over the weekend. Weve never posted a closure notice, nor discussed it, he said, adding that Gone With the Wind, starring Jill Paice as Scarlett OHara and Darius Danesh as Rhett Butler, would continue through the traditionally slack months of May and June.

title: Failings of One Brooklyn High School May Threaten a Neighbors Success
description: Set just a few subway stops apart in blue-collar Brooklyn, drawing from a similar pool of new immigrants and American-born blacks, two high schools spent the past decade careering toward opposite destinies. The question now is whether the failure of one will destroy the success of the other.

title: John Jay Iselin, Public TV Innovator, Dies at 74
description: John Jay Iselin, who led WNET, also known as Channel 13, the nations largest public television station, through a period of innovative programming, great popularity and wide influence, died early Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 74 and lived in Manhattan.

title: To Dine at Momofuku Ko, First You Need Nimble Fingers
description: WHAT youre about to read may prod you to try for a reservation at Momofuku Ko, so its incumbent on me to say this right off the bat:

title: Congress Weighs Veterans Adjustment Aid
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii, badly wounded in World War II, reflects on the help he received in readjusting to civilian life after intense combat in Europe and finds todays government support for returning troops impersonal and inadequate.

title: Stocks Take a Fall Late in the Day
description: A late Wednesday afternoon tumble sent the stock markets to their worst session in nearly a month, as a swirl of unsettling financial and economic news unnerved investors who had enjoyed several weeks of relative calm after the winters tumult.

title: After Promise of Reform, Ohio Democrats Face Test
description: CINCINNATI  Eighteen months after scandals helped Democrats in Ohio break a Republican monopoly on top state offices, a Democratic official has found himself enmeshed in one of his own.

title: Flood of Attack Ads on Final Day
description: In these closing hours of the North Carolina and Indiana primaries, voters in the two states have been witness to a cacophony of attack ads the likes of which had not yet been seen in this protracted and already hard-hitting Democratic race.

title: Aid for Myanmar Mobilizes, Mixed With Criticism
description: BANGKOK  A powerful cyclone that destroyed a vast swath of coastal Myanmar and left many thousands of people dead prompted the countrys military leaders to allow some foreign aid groups to deliver relief supplies on Tuesday. But the ruling junta came under increasing pressure to further open its doors  and even relax its tight political grip  to grapple with the growing disaster.

title: Greek Islands, Overwhelmed by Refugees, Seek Help
description: ATHENS  A rash of refugees from Africa, southern Asia and the Middle East has been crossing the Aegean Sea and besieging a cluster of craggy Greek islands.

title: Randolph Preaches Patience While Rotation Tests His
description: LOS ANGELES  It is not even mid-May, and the Mets, despite their faults and foibles, are a mere game and a half out of first place. But the lack of reliable depth in the rotation is starting to cause some anxiety.

title: Washington: Mystery Men Identified
description: Two men whose behavior on a ferry last July prompted the F.B.I. to release their photographs in an effort to determine who they were have been identified, and it appears that they were in the area for legitimate reasons, the bureau said. The men were photographed by a ferry worker after they entered restricted areas and asked detailed questions about the boats structure, the bureau said. Robbie Burroughs, an F.B.I. spokeswoman, said the men were software consultants from Europe who were in Seattle for a conference. After learning of the search for them, they eventually went to a United States embassy and showed proof of their identity and their reason for traveling to Seattle. The F.B.I. has not released their names or nationalities. The men had dark hair and olive skin, and the release of the photographs prompted accusations that the F.B.I. was profiling passengers.

title: An Afternoon at the (New Sports) Museum
description: It is a near certainty that no museum has ever celebrated its creation by enlisting 30 renowned painters, musicians or scientists to wave foam fingers at a lunchtime crowd while cheerleaders tumbled in a park next door. But that was the endearing if goofy sight at the end of a news conference Tuesday when Carl Lewis, Billie Jean King, Walt Frazier, Martina Navratilova, Eli Manning and others waggled those red appendages on a stage in Lower Manhattan to herald Wednesdays opening of the Sports Museum of America.

title: Colombia: U.S. Accuses Russian of Arms Smuggling
description: Viktor Bout, a Russian businessman described by the United States as one of the worlds most prolific arms traffickers, has been accused in New York of conspiring to smuggle missiles and rocket launchers to rebels in Colombia, the Justice Department said. His indictment on federal terrorism charges was unsealed on Tuesday. Mr. Bout, above, was arrested in Bangkok in March following an international sting operation in which undercover investigators posed as rebels from the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia seeking to purchase millions of dollars in arms, according to the Justice Department, which says the weapons would have been used to kill Americans in Colombia. Mr. Bout, 41, is opposing extradition.

title: Smaller Programs Are Among Hardest Hit in N.C.A.A. Academic Report
description: When Dick Tomey took over as coach of the San Jose State football team three years ago, he bluntly assessed the lack of programs available to help his players schoolwork.

title: King-Mellencamp Musical Postponed
description: The Stephen King-John Mellencamp musical planned for next season in Atlanta in preparation for a Broadway run has run into an obstacle, The Associated Press reported. Having announced in February an April 2009 opening, the Alliance Theater in Atlanta notified subscribers that the show, Ghost Brothers of Darkland County, described as a sultry Southern Gothic mystery with a blues-tinged, guitar-driven score, had been delayed because members of the creative team realized the script would not be ready by spring 2009. The plot deals with a legend that grows from the deaths in 1957 of two brothers and a young girl. The Alliance said it hoped to produce the show in its 2009-10 season.

title: Results From an Indiana County Kept Democrats Waiting
description: Early this morning, all eyes were on Lake County in far northwest Indiana, which is, in essence, a suburb of Chicago, Senator Barack Obamas hometown. Results from the county, one of the states most populous with 494,000 people, were dribbling in late into the night. Results there tightened margin between Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Obama, raising the specter of a possible recount in the state.

title: A Lesson Before Writing, Courtesy of Idi Amins Ghost
description: The premise of Steve & Idi may be enough to make you laugh. Steve, a playwright who has been dropped by his agent and dumped by his boyfriend, becomes despondent enough to swallow a handful of pills. Instead of dying, he is visited by the ghost (or dream) of Idi Amin.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An obituary on Friday about Charles Tilly, a prolific theorist of social science, misstated his relationship to three survivors  Kit Tilly, Laura Tilly and Sarah Tilly. They are his daughters, not his sisters. Because of an editing error, the name of his former wife and sometime collaborator was rendered incompletely. She is Louise Audino Tilly, not Louise Audino.

title: Rings Welcomes You
description: We start Rings, the Times Olympics blog, in an appropriately friendly way: with . Thats fuwa, which means friendlies, the Mandarin term for dolls, stuffed animals, etc. The five fuwa above are the official mascots of the 2008 Beijing Olympics, and you will no doubt be seeing a lot of them between now and the closing ceremonies on Aug. 24.

title: The Nominees Emerge, Hobbled
description: Here are two things we learned tonight. First, Barack Obama is going to almost certainly be the Democratic nominee. Hes withstood seven weeks of bad news and he still exceeded expectations.

title: Hillary Clinton in Indiana
description: Hillary Clinton comments on the results from the May 6 primaries. (Video: NBC)

title: Analyzing the Results
description: John Harwood, of The Times and CNBC, analyzes the results of the May 6 primaries and looks ahead to what's next.

title: An Official-Looking Co-op Document
description: Q. I have heard that a number of co-ops have received a notice from a "Corporate Records Compliance Office" in Albany, stating that under New York law, corporations must hold annual meetings of shareholders to elect directors and conduct other business.

title: Taxing the Gas in Them Thar Hills
description: Q. I read in a recent article in The New York Times ("There's Gas in Those Hills," April 8, 2008) that landowners in Pennsylvania (and potentially upstate New York) are being paid large sums of money as "sign-on bonuses" to lease the rights to explore and drill for gas under their property. The article also says that if gas is found, the landowner gets a monthly "royalty" check, which in one case cited amounted to $20,000.

title: Producers Suspend Talks with Actors Guild
description: Hollywood producers on Tuesday temporarily broke off contract talks with the Screen Actors Guild, calling its demands regarding DVD sales and online content unreasonable,' the Associated Press reports.

title: Israel's Arabs
description: As Israel prepares to celebrate its 60th anniversary, the Arabs who make up 20 percent of its citizens will not be celebrating. Far less well off and integrated than Israeli Jews, they are feeling increasingly unwanted.

title: Victory Speeches in Two States
description: Barack Obama won in North Carolina, while Hillary Rodham Clinton pledged to keep going full throttle for the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: What In Gods Name Is That? Part 2: Hong Kong Roast Meat Shops
description: While larger restaurants often have a bewildering array of dishes, small traditional shops usually have only one or two specialties. A roast meat place will have just that on rice, so dont expect dim sum, tofu, wine, dessert or anything else. Similarly, dont go to a dumpling, soup and noodle shop (to be covered in my next installment) and ask for roast meat.At the roast meat shop, your basic choices are:char siu   honey-roasted BBQ pork which you can identify by its red-tinted skinsiu yuk  roast pork with a thick, brown-tinted crackling skin, which you can identify by the fact that its usually displayed as a large, curved slab of meatsee yeow gai  soy sauce chicken, which (rather obviously) is the color of something that has been boiled in soy saucebak cheet gai or yeow gai  like soy sauce chicken, but with plain or bright yellow skinSome of the more upscale places may also have:siu ngap  roast ducksiu ngoh  roast gooseI mean upscale in a relative sense. A rice box with roast meat will go for U.S. $3-5, or H.K. $25-40. Dont expect much in terms of presentation or service.Poultry will usually be served with minced raw ginger and scallion. Pork will usually be drizzled with soy-infused drippings. Siu yuk may come with a dab of mustard. A limp stalk of gai lan (Chinese brocolli) will probably be thrown in.

title: Tropicana Bondholders Ask for Trustee Control
description: Some creditors of Tropicana Entertainment, which has filed for bankruptcy, asked for it to be placed under a court-appointed trustees control, saying the companys chief executive, William Yung, had come close to destroying the casino operators prospects, according to court filings.

title: Glaxo Raise $9 Billion in Bond Sale
description: GlaxoSmithKline, the drugmaker with a U.S. headquarters in Philadelphia, has raised $9 billion in the largest U.S. corporate-bond sale in six years.

title: Spot Runner Said to Snag Another $51 Million
description: Spot Runner, an Internet-based advertising network that puts local business pitches on TV and radio, expects to announce Wednesday that it has landed another $51 million from investors including British media company Daily Mail and General Trust, Spanish media group Grupo Televisa, institutional investor Legg Mason Capital Management, and the luxury conglomerate Groupe Arnault/LVMH, CNet News.com reported.

title: Wilfried Romoli and the Paris Opera Ballet
description: A look at Mr. Romolis final performance with the Paris Opera Ballet.

title: ArvinMeritor to Spin Off Car Parts Unit
description: ArvinMeritor said on Tuesday it plans to spin off its automotive parts business from its larger trucking group in a move it hopes will improve the focus of each unit, sending its shares up 6 percent.

title: Former Bear Broker Is Sentenced for Insider Trading
description: A former broker at Bear Stearns was sentenced on Tuesday to three years of probation and a year of home confinement and fined $300,000 for his part in an insider trading case.

title: JPMorgan Hires Former Goldman Banker for Asia Post
description: JPMorgan Chase said on Wednesday it had hired former Goldman Sachs  banker Oral Dawe as managing director and chief executive of its Asia Pacific Commodities group.

title: Fannie Mae Wins Cheers Despite Loss
description: Fannie Mae, the nations largest buyer of home loans, gave investors little reason to cheer Tuesday, announcing a $2.2 billion quarterly loss and a dividend cut, and warning of steeper losses ahead.

title: Countrywide Admits Errors at Senate Hearing
description: The mortgage lender Countrywide Financial, which is accused of inflating certain borrowers fees, acknowledged on Tuesday that it had made errors and pledged to take steps to improve its operations.

title: Write-Down at Wachovia Nearly Doubles Its Loss
description: Wachovia reported on Tuesday that its previously reported first-quarter loss nearly doubled to $708 million because of a write-down tied to life insurance policies.

title: Hedge Funds Said to Reject Retailers Settlement Offer
description: With a shareholder showdown just days away, Charming Shoppes said Monday that dissident investors, seeking to oust the chief executive officer and two other members from the board, had rejected its offer to settle a proxy fight.

title: Will WPPs Sorrell Take TNS Bid Hostile?
description: British advertising impresario Martin Sorrell may soon go hostile in his latest takeover tussle, according to The Deal.com.

title: Silver Lake Closes $1.1 Billion Sumeru Fund
description: Silver Lake, a technology-focused private equity firm, said Tuesday that its first middle-market fund, Silver Lake Sumeru, would close with $1.1 billion, significantly higher than the original $750 million target the firm had set.

title: Cablevisions Newsday Bid Would Face Few Regulatory Hurdles
description: If Cablevision Systems manages to wrest the Tribune Companys Long Island, N.Y., newspaper Newsday away from other interested bidders, the transaction would raise the ire of consumer groups, but regulators in Washington wont have much to say, The Deal.com reported.

title: Andreessen to Join Facebooks Board?
description: Veteran Silicon Valley entrepreneur Marc Andreessen has been asked to join the board of Facebook, according to All Things Digital.

title: Investors Expect to Pour $200 Billion into Hedge Funds This Year
description: Hedge fund investors expect to put $200 billion into such funds in the next year, in spite of an overwhelmingly bearish view on the economy.

title: Legg Mason Posts First Loss in Its History
description: Legg Mason posted on Tuesday a wider-than-expected quarterly loss  the U.S. money managers first loss ever  as it took a big charge related to a bail-out of money market funds exposed to risky securities and suffered outflows from its poorly performing funds.

title: As Video Game Succeeds, How Much for Take-Two?
description: Grand Theft Auto IV, the latest iteration of the hit video game franchise, racked up first-week sales of $500 million, Take-Two Interactive, the games publisher, plans to announce on Wednesday. The report exceeded the sales expectations of analysts.

title: Deal Chatter Swirls Around LinkedIn
description: Fresh rumors are popping up about LinkedIn, the online social network that has, at various times in the past year, been thought to be preparing an initial public offering or drawing interest from potential acquirers.

title: A Feud in the Bear Stearns Family
description: After 59 years, Alan C. Greenberg is still trading away at Bear Stearns, the troubled Wall Street bank that is about to disappear. Asked about his retirement plans, and he apparently let out a belly-jiggling laugh.

title: HK Energy Partners Pulls I.P.O.
description: HK Energy Partners, formed by Petrohawk Energy to acquire, develop and exploit oil and natural-gas properties, has canceled its plans for an initial public offering, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing Tuesday.

title: Tight Credit Worries for a Hotel and Mall Operator
description: David Lichtenstein was new to the hotel business when he made one of the last big highly leveraged real estate deals before the credit squeeze, acquiring Extended Stay Hotels, a chain of 687 no-frills hotels, last June for $8.1 billion.

title: UBS Faces Tax Probe, Amid Other Woes
description: When Swiss banking giant UBS, the European bank hit hardest by the tight credit market, said Tuesday that it had sold $15 billion of subprime mortgage debt and would cut 5,500 jobs as part of its cleanup, some investors saw as an indication that the bank was dealing with its problems.

title: Talleyrand and the gas tax holiday
description: Im on record as saying that Hillary Clintons advocacy of a gas-tax holiday, while it wasnt good policy, didnt rise to the level of a crime.

title: Buyout Firms to Trim Burger King Stake
description: TPG Capital, Bain Capital Partners and Goldman Sachs plan to sell 15 million shares of Burger King, reducing their combined stake in the fast-food chain from 43 percent to 32 percent.

title: Citigroup Forms Alternative-Asset Group
description: Citigroup has formed a new unit within its investment bank that will bring together groups servicing private equity and infrastructure funds, according to an internal memorandum sent to employees on Tuesday.

title: The Creator of Mr. Peabody, Sherman and the Wayback Machine
description: Ted Key, the cartoonist who created the impertinent maid Hazel in the 1940s  later played by Shirley Booth in the 1960s sitcom  died last weekend at 95. But did you know he also created Mr. Peabody and Sherman  the time-traveling professor (who also happened to be a dog) and his little boy sidekick? They were regulars on Rocky and His Friends, starring Rocky the squirrel and Bullwinkle J. Moose. Heres a clip in which professor and boy go back to help Marconi invent the radio:

title: Party Could Be Over
description: Aired Tuesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: The Democrats had two important primaries today in North Carolina and Indiana. And the party could be over for Hillary Clinton. She might have won Indiana, but she lost North Carolina, which is bigger. Theyre saying now the only way that Obama could possibly lose would be for him to marry Bill Clinton.

title: Big Names Hook Up for Wireless Venture
description: A whos who of technology and telecommunications companies announced Wednesday that it intends to build the first of a new generation of nationwide wireless data networks.

title: Against the grain
description: From the annals of unusual political action (via Felix Salmon):

title: GLGs Profits Rise Despite Market Turmoil
description: GLG Partners, the publicly traded British hedge fund, said on Wednesday that it earned $33.8 million for the first quarter, a 142 percent jump over last year even as the firms industry continues to struggle with the choppy markets.

title: La Vie Bohme, in East Williamsburg

Perhaps 300 people  mostly young, white, and hip  live in each building, from one to eight people to each loft. Few were born before the mid-1980s. Rents can range from $375 for one person to roughly $800 for a space. To spend a few days at the McKibbin lofts is to experience what it is to be young, hungry for acceptance, and willing to put up with just about anything in order to gain a foothold in the citys competitive, and thriving, underground art and music scenes, Ms. Buckley writes. This could have been Greenwich Village 60 years ago, or SoHo 30 years ago, or the East Village in the 1990s.

title: Made in Africa
description: Children in a sunflower field in Lira, Uganda. The sunflower plant is used as a natural way to control pests on the cotton farms instead of using pesticides. The pests are attracted to and eat the sunflowers instead of the cotton plants nearby. (Photo: Nicole Mackinlay Hahn)Africa may be the second largest continent, but in the fashion world, it can be pretty darned difficult to find on the map. Most American dont know where Tunisia is, exclaims Leslie Hoffman, the executive director of the environmental organization Earth Pledge. The could soon change. Reap What You Sew, a new interactive video installation at Barneys New York by the artist and filmmaker Nicole Mackinlay Hahn aims to connect items like Christian Louboutin pumps and Phillip B. beauty products (not to mention consumers) to their place in the African supply chain. No mean feat according to Julie Gilhart, Barneys Fashion Director. We asked all of the buyers where their products were made, and a lot of them didnt even know, she says. Hahn spent several years traveling all over Africa, documenting people at work and at play. Some 200 clips  from the enlightening (factory workers dying fabric) to the entertaining (a group of men practicing their dance moves set to multiple versions of Totos Africa)  are on view on the ninth floor at Barneys through the end of May. Hahn predicts that the RFID technology she used to make her art piece (the same used to create E-Z Pass) will soon be the norm in the retail world, ushering in a new age of accountability for producers and consumers alike. And she has a point: If you could click on an image of the sweatshop where your sneakers were constructed by 11-year-olds, would you still buy them?
