description: A Spare Times listing on Friday about events at the Wave Hill garden and cultural center in the Bronx misstated the days on which two-for-one admissions with vouchers, being offered this month, are available. They are Wednesdays through Fridays, not Wednesdays through Sundays. The listing also included an outdated Web address for in- formation. The new one is nycvisit.com/culturespot.

title: Correction
description: The column by David Brooks on Tuesday included a widely reported but incorrectly transcribed phrase attributed to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. In discussing the economy during a speech, Mrs. Clinton mentioned Wall Street money brokers. She did not use the phrase money grubbers.

title: Youve Seen the YouTube Video; Now Try the Documentary
description: There is a moment of foreshadowing at the end of Battle at Kruger, the eight-minute African safari video that has drawn more than 30 million views on YouTube.

title: Political Foe of Musharraf Is Released in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A provincial leader who was one of the most prominent politicians jailed by President Pervez Musharraf was freed Friday by the newly elected government, fulfilling one of its major promises to release political detainees.

title: Design Change Sought for King Memorial
description: The United States Commission of Fine Arts has asked the creators of a sculpture of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. for the Washington Mall to change it. In a letter, the commission said that renderings of the sculpture made Dr. King appear stiff and confrontational, evoking Socialist Realist statues of political figures recently toppled in other countries. The lead sculptor, Lei Yixin, above with a model of the work, is from China and has made busts of Mao Zedong. Critics had opposed giving him the commission, saying that an African-American sculptor should have been chosen. Supporters said choosing an artist without regard to race or color was in line with Dr. Kings philosophy. The commission, whose approval is necessary for the project to proceed, recommended that the sculpture portray Dr. King as a more sympathetic figure.

title: From a Bright Past to a Cloudy Future
description: When Vito J. Fossella Jr., the soon-to-be boy congressman, stood beside the young girls of a cheerleading squad at the Excelsior Grand catering hall in 1997, it seemed a particularly vivid version of Staten Island pageantry. Mr. Fossella  32 and with Al Pacino looks  was on his way to becoming the sole Republican in New York Citys Congressional delegation at a spirited party billed as an evening of pasta and politics.

title: Spam Moves to Cellphones and Gets More Invasive
description: If you thought spam on your computer was a bother, brace yourself: spammers want to find you on your cellphone.

title: On a Windy Day, the Elders Stand Their Ground
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  There was something for everybody Friday at the T.P.C. Sawgrass, where the hot summer winds came early and stayed late, and a few PGA Tour pros were last seen limping into the fitness trailer for chiropractic care.

title: As Stimulus Rebates Go Out, Stores Want the Whole Check
description: As the government sends out roughly $100 billion in economic stimulus checks to about 130 million American homes, retailers are trying to persuade consumers to spend their windfall at a time of high anxiety about the economy.

title: Charles R. Ellis, President of John Wiley & Sons, Dies at 72
description: Charles R. Ellis, an executive who led the venerable family-owned publishing house John Wiley & Sons back to fiscal health in the 1990s after a period of misdirected expansion, died on May 4 in Paris. He was 72 and had homes in Paris and Manhattan.

title: Fears Ease, So Its Time to Be Fearful
description: NOW that public opinion is solidifying around the idea that the Federal Reserve has made its last rate cut for a while, stocks may be poised atop a slope of complacency.

title: Lottery Numbers
One Duo Celebrates the Songs of Another
description: What a pleasure to hear a songwriter whisper his own well-known lyrics as if the familiar words were a stream of consciousness spontaneously emanating from a meditative state. That is how Alan Bergman sang The Windmills of Your Mind on Thursday at Feinsteins at Loews Regency in a show celebrating his 50-year collaboration with his wife, Marilyn (who was in the audience). The performance made you realize that quiet understatement often draws you into song lyrics more than florid declamation.

title: For First Time, More Superdelegates Favor Obama
description: The trump card Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton held in her faltering bid for president  her support among the superdelegates who can control the fate of the Democratic nomination  began slipping from her grasp on Friday as Senator Barack Obama moved into the lead on this front, with uncommitted delegates declaring their allegiance to him as others deserted her.

title: An Eternal Battle, Waged With Vigor
description: Its easy to forget that ballet can be cool. But many of Twyla Tharps strongest forays into this art form are effortlessly so: the dancers may be drenched, but the choreography never breaks a sweat.

title: Circuit City Opens Its Books to Blockbuster
description: Circuit City, the electronics chain, said Friday that it would allow the video rental company Blockbuster to examine its books, a shift from its initial, highly skeptical stance toward Blockbusters unsolicited takeover bid.

title: Death Comes Ashore
description: THE word cyclone was coined in Calcutta (now called Kolkata) in the 1840s by an eccentric Englishman named Henry Piddington. Inspired by the great British meteorologist William Reid, Piddington became one of the earliest storm-chasers, besotted with a phenomenon that he once likened to a beautiful meteorite. His elegant coinage was originally intended as a generic name for all revolving weather events, but is now applied mainly to the storms of the Indian Ocean region like Cyclone Nargis, which struck Burma with devastating effect last week.

title: Mothers Day Scandal
description: By now we voters are well-versed in how to respond when, say, your law-and-order governor turns out to be a primo patron of the Emperors Club V.I.P. Escort Service. But the bar moves ever upward, and this week, New Yorkers are trying to figure out the proper reaction to news that a veteran local congressman, Vito Fossella, is the proud paterfamilias of both a household in Staten Island (wife, three children) and a love nest with mistress and child in Virginia.

title: Microsoft Appeals $1.4 Billion Fine by Europe
description: Microsoft asked Europes second-highest court to overturn or reduce a record fine of 899 million euros ($1.4 billion) from the European Union. The appeal was filed at the European Court of First Instance in Luxembourg, a Microsoft spokesman, Jesse Verstraete, said in an e-mailed statement. The European Commission, the E.U.s antitrust authority, fined the company on Feb. 27 for failing to comply with a 2004 antitrust order. Under that decision, in which Microsoft was fined 497 million euros, the E.U. ordered the software maker to provide data to rivals to allow servers to connect to the Windows platform.

title: New Shows at HBO
description: HBO has lined up another big Hollywood name for a new project. Alexander Payne, the director and Oscar-winning co-writer of Sideways, will direct and serve as an executive producer of Hung, a new dark comedy series about a former basketball coach with a large penis. The series, being created by Dmitry Lipkin, the creator of The Riches for FX, and his wife, Colette Burson, was the first project signed by Sue Naegle, who took over as president of HBOs entertainment division last month. HBO has several other new series in various stages of development, including True Blood, a vampire drama scheduled to begin in the fall; One Percent, a drama about a motorcycle gang; Last of the Ninth, a drama set in the New York Police Department in the 1970s; and Davids Situation, a comedy by Bob Odenkirk and David Cross in which Mr. Cross portrays himself living with two roommates, one liberal and one conservative.

title: Indiana Jones Is Battling the Long Knives of the Internet
description: LOS ANGELES  Now comes the part where Indiana Jones dangles over the snake pit of public opinion.

title: Columbus Orchestra May Suspend Activities
description: Is it curtains for Columbus? The Columbus Symphony Orchestra, a high-quality regional ensemble in Ohios capital, has canceled its outdoor summer concerts and says it will probably call a halt to making music indefinitely.

title: Times Publisher and His Wife Separate
description: Arthur Sulzberger Jr., chairman of The New York Times Company, and his wife, Gail Gregg, have decided to separate, they said in a statement issued Friday.

title: The Chief of Barneys Is Expected to Resign
description: Howard Socol, the chief executive of Barneys New York, who restored the companys stature after it fell into bankruptcy in the 1990s, has told colleagues he intends to resign, according to people knowledgeable about the situation.

title: Man Is Found Shot to Death in an Elevator
description: A 29-year-old man was found shot to death inside a building in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, on Friday, the police said.

title: Mr. Hus Peaceable Visit to Tokyo
description: President Hu Jintaos visit to Japan this week was the first by a Chinese leader in a decade. It was a lot friendlier than the previous one  when President Jiang Zemin publicly chastised his hosts for not showing sufficient contrition over Japans brutal occupation of China in 1930s and 1940s. Unlike some of his recent predecessors, Japans prime minister, Yasuo Fukuda, has made an effort not to infuriate the Chinese. Notably, he has refused to pander to Japanese nationalists by visiting Tokyos tainted Yasukuni war shrine.

title: Judge Drops General From Trial of Detainee
description: In a new blow to the Bush administrations troubled military commission system, a military judge has disqualified a Pentagon general who has been centrally involved in overseeing Guantnamo war crimes tribunals from any role in the first case headed for trial.

title: Blogging Against Barbie
description: MOST of Eco Childs Play, a blog for environmentally conscious parents, is concerned with tips and advice about products like nontoxic pacifiers and childrens clothing made from bamboo (ecochildsplay.com).

title: Kenya: World Food Program Worker Is Killed
description: Unidentified gunmen shot and killed a logistics officer working for the United Nations World Food Program in northwestern Kenya. The officer, identified as Silence Chirara by The Associated Press, was ambushed late Wednesday by men brandishing assault rifles, United Nations officials said Friday. The killing may have been connected to the reduction of aid efforts in the area, which used to be a hub for relief supplies to Sudan. A driver hauling food for the World Food Program was fatally shot Wednesday in Somalia.

title: Another Game Goes to the Big Screen
description: The video game BioShock is set to become a film. Take-Two Interactive Software said on Friday that Gore Verbinski (Pirates of the Caribbean) would make a movie version of its popular game about an underwater utopia gone disastrously wrong, Reuters reported. The film will be released by Universal Pictures, and the screenwriter John Logan (Gladiator, Sweeney Todd) is in talks to write the script, the company said. Take-Two did not disclose the financial terms of the deal or say when the film would be released. BioShock has sold more than two million copies, and Take-Two is working on a sequel.

title: Close Your Eyes and Smell the Brine
description: In Moby Dick Rehearsed, the Orson Welles adaptation of the Melville novel, the audience is implored early on to be prepared for a mental workout, there being no chance of getting a credible whale, ship or sea into the theater. Think, when we speak of whaleboats, whales and oceans, that you see them, an actor asks, for tis your thoughts that now must deck our stage.

title: Roaring Twenties Speakeasies With Tubs Full of Ginger Ale Fizz
description: Though it is set in an era of speakeasies and bathtub gin, the 1920s musical No, No, Nanette makes only fleeting reference to cocktails. Bootleg hooch is clearly not the signature drink of the happy flappers in this show. Nor is tea, though the possibilities of its being served for two are sung about rhapsodically.

title: Gambling Is Never Enough
description: Like a gambling addict certain that his luck will turn on the next roll of the dice, New York State is betting that vastly expanding gambling at the Aqueduct in Queens is part of the answer to the budget deficit. The states overly generous revenue projection is based on the hope that bidders will pay $250 million for development rights from the state-owned racetrack, and with it, the right to add 4,500 video slot machines that would provide the state a worry-free revenue stream.

title: Kerkorian Moves to Buy a Bigger Stake in Ford
description: DETROIT  The billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian started a cash tender offer on Friday to bolster his stake in the Ford Motor Company to 5.6 percent but stopped short of revealing his long-term plans as a major shareholder in the carmaker.

title: CBS Rules Thursday
description: For the third consecutive week the Thursday night lineup on CBS had more viewers at every time slot than any of its network competitors, according to Nielson estimates. CBS drew 12.7 million viewers for Survivor: Micronesia at 8 p.m. and continued to dominate with CSI at 9 (17.8 million) and Without a Trace at 10 (14.6 million). Despite CBSs advantage in total viewers, ABC edged ahead for the night among adults 18 to 49, thanks to Greys Anatomy at 9 (with 15.6 million total viewers) and Lost at 10 (11.3 million total), which did well in that demographic. Fox and NBC were third and fourth over all, with NBC faring better among the 18-to-49 set. While NBC garnered small audiences for the season finales of Scrubs at 8:30 (5.4 million) and 30 Rock at 9:30 (5.6 million), its ratings perked up at 9 for The Office (7.2 million) and at 10 with ER (7.6 million).

title: A Look at War, That Zero-Sum Game
description: Luis Lara Malvacas, a choreographer, dancer and visual artist, has clearly spent a lot of time thinking about the set for his new dance, Reason Without Meaning. His installation even spills into the audience at the Kitchen, where the back of every other chair is covered with a slice of bubble wrap. A black piece of cardboard with a message reading X caution is placed on the same seats, along with an object wrapped in more bubble packing to resemble a candied apple. Or, judging by the events that follow, a grenade.

title: St. Vincents Pleads Poverty to Evade Landmark Law
description: In the contentious world of New York landmark preservation, it is not always hard to be a hardship case.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on April 27 about Newarks difficulty in helping ex-convicts get jobs gave an outdated and erroneous name for a New York agency that is conducting a three-year study of employment and recidivism among ex-convicts in four cities. It is MDRC, formerly known as the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation (not Development).

title: Hezbollah Seizes Swath of Beirut From U.S.-Backed Lebanon Government
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Heavily armed Hezbollah fighters seized control of much of western Beirut on Friday, patrolling the deserted streets in a raw show of force that underscored the militias refusal to back down in its escalating confrontation with the American-backed government.

title: Touring Season
description: Hitting the road in the coming months: Coldplay, My Morning Jacket and Tina Turner. Coldplays tour begins June 29 in Philadelphia after a free show at Madison Square Garden on June 23 and runs through Aug. 4 in Chicago before returning for a second leg in October. My Morning Jacket opens its tour on June 20 with a show at Radio City Music Hall and continues on the road through Oct. 10 in Chicago. Ms. Turner, above, will start a tour on Oct. 1 in Kansas City and continue through Dec. 8 in Montreal; she will play the Prudential Center in Newark on Nov. 26 and the Nassau Coliseum on Dec. 3.

title: Bush and House G.O.P. Team Up to Present Show of Strength
description: WASHINGTON  It was just like the old days. President Bush and House Republican leaders strode purposefully out of the White House to the waiting microphones, where the president celebrated their mutual views on housing, energy, war spending and terrorist surveillance bills taking shape in Congress.

title: If Your Appliances Are Avocado, They Probably Arent Green
description: I DONT know about you, but Im a little tired of the whole green thing. Not the idea that Americans need to sharply cut their energy use (the words carbon footprint will not pass my lips). And not the idea that there are some relatively painless actions we can all take that will help  although I know real change will not be made without real sacrifice.

title: Short of Cash, Fremont May Not Complete a Deal
description: Fremont General, once a major subprime lender, may go bankrupt and wipe out shareholders because it will not have enough time or cash to complete the sale of its retail banking business. Fremont, based in Brea, Calif., is behind on required filings and does not know when it will be able to provide data needed to finish the sale to CapitalSource, according to a company statement and filing. After agreeing to sell mortgage servicing rights to a Goldman Sachs unit yesterday, Fremont said it had contracted to divest substantially all the banks remaining assets. There can be no assurance that there will be any monies left for Fremonts shareholders, the company said.

title: West Side Railyards Project Gets New Push From Mayor
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Friday that he would push to revive a $1 billion deal to develop the railyards on the Far West Side of Manhattan as he met with the developer whose negotiations with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had collapsed.

title: Marrying at Rikers Island: Few Frills, Many Rules
description: The long walk to the Rose M. Singer chapel on Rikers Island starts after the wedding party passes through metal detectors. When the bride and groom reach the altar, the chapel doors are locked behind them.

title: New Signs of Zimbabwe Attacks as Mbeki Arrives
description: JOHANNESBURG  President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa held talks in Zimbabwe on Friday with the countrys longtime leader, Robert Mugabe, as fresh evidence emerged that forces sponsored by Mr. Mugabes government were accelerating their attacks on the political opposition.

title: Bloomberg Teaches Londons New Mayor Old Tricks
description: LONDON  They are a study in contrasts, Mayor Mike and Mayor Boris.

title: Igawa Does Little to Help Himself or the Yankees
description: A three-run rally by the Yankees in the ninth inning made Friday nights final score look respectable: a 6-5 victory for the Tigers, their fourth triumph in four tries over the Yankees this season.

title: Illegal Farm Workers Get Health Care in Shadows
description: MADERA, Calif.  The curandera is weary from work. Three, four, five times a day, the immigrant farm workers knock on her apartment door, begging her to cure their ailments.

title: For Duke, Extra Year of Players Eligibility Makes a Difference
description: When Chris Kennedy sat down last spring to write an appeal to the N.C.A.A. for 33 members of the Duke lacrosse team to be granted an extra season, he had no expectations.

title: Japan: Marine Sentenced in Sexual Misconduct Case
description: A United States marine was sentenced to two years in prison and given a dishonorable discharge for sexual misconduct with a Japanese woman in October in Hiroshima, military officials said Friday. He was cleared of rape and kidnapping charges. The marine, Lance Cpl. Larry A. Dean, 20, was the first serviceman to face court-martial among four accused of rape by a 19-year-old Japanese woman. Japanese authorities investigated the case, but decided not to bring their own charges against the marines.

title: Rapper Pleads Guilty
description: Less than a month after being released from prison, the rapper Foxy Brown pleaded guilty in a Brooklyn court on Thursday to using her BlackBerry phone to menace a woman, Reuters reported. Foxy Brown, 29, whose real name is Inga Marchand, avoided a felony assault charge, which carries a maximum sentence of seven years in prison, by pleading guilty to menacing, a misdemeanor. She was accused of bruising an eye and chipping a tooth of her longtime neighbor, Arlene Raymond, when she struck the woman with the phone last July. On Thursday, Justice John P. Walsh of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn sentenced the rapper to time already served and ordered her to submit an apology. I apologize for the incident that occurred on July 31, 2007, in that I attempted to scare Arlene Raymond and place her in harms way, Foxy Brown said in a handwritten note.

title: Con Ed Seeks Another Rate Increase and Draws Fire
description: Just a few weeks after sending out bills that reflected a $425 million rise in electricity rates, Con Edison is asking for an even bigger increase next year.

title: Seeds of Destruction
description: The Clintons have never understood how to exit the stage gracefully.

title: Light Touch in Inventing Chinese Scents
description: Western perfume makers have been selling their scents in China for roughly a decade. But in a few months, Parfums Benetton will introduce two of the first perfumes that have been created especially for Chinese tastes.

title: Farnsworths Appeal Is Heard and Listened To
description: DETROIT  The bullpen dominated much of the discussion Friday when the Yankees opened a three-game series with the Detroit Tigers at Comerica Park. The topics included the suspension of Kyle Farnsworth, the antics of Joba Chamberlain, the optioning of Chris Britton to Class AAA and the loss of Sean Henn on waivers to San Diego.

title: From Places Unexpected, Support for the Press
description: WASHINGTON  An unusual cast of conservatives has added momentum to a bill that would protect the confidentiality of reporters sources, even as the Bush administration has lobbied vigorously against the idea.

title: Slam Bidding Decides Fate of Cavendish Teams
description: The Cavendish Invitational Pairs, the planets biggest cash tournament of the year, ends on Sunday in Henderson, Nev., on the outskirts of Las Vegas. Play can be watched at bridgebase.com.

title: A Warm Welcome for an Injured Vendor of Hot Coffee
description: Despite the driving rain, the customers lined up at the coffee wagon in front of State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Friday morning, not so much to get their cup of joe as to see the man they call Joe. They quickly shouted their greetings:

title: Stolen Laptop Helps Turn Tables on Suspects
description: WHITE PLAINS  The thieves were voracious, filching flat-screen televisions and computer games, purloining iPods and DVDs, even making off with a box of liquor and a set of car rims in a burglary two weeks ago at an apartment three young people shared here. Luckily, they also took two laptop computers.

title: Israel Readying for a Post-Olmert Era
description: JERUSALEM  The overwhelming view in Israel on Friday, just hours after Prime Minister Ehud Olmert declared his innocence in a bribery investigation involving a Long Island businessman, was that the post-Olmert political era had already begun.

title: Myanmar Proceeds With Vote, Outcome Certain
description: This article was reported and written by a correspondent of The New York Times. Reporting was contributed by Seth Mydans in Bangkok.

title: Russia Parades Its Military in an Echo of Soviet Days
description: MOSCOW  Nuclear missile launchers and columns of tanks rolled through Red Square on Friday in a display of martial hardware not seen since the Soviet Unions waning days.

title: Home-Grown, Everyday Sadism
description: If Ellen Page ever worried that her roles in Juno and Smart People would too securely set her image as a feisty know-it-all, she chose well to appear in An American Crime, a film that manages to wrench all the placid innocence from her bones. The movie, which appeared at the Sundance Film Festival last year and which makes its debut on Showtime on Saturday, calls for none of her verbal wood chopping. Indeed, it demands a listless opposite, turning Ms. Pages body into a cadaver long before her character becomes one, speaking to us softly, phlegmatically and from the grave. Ms. Page is all dreamy, spectral passivity; she mesmerizes. But so much is done to her that it is hard to know what she is actually doing.

title: Ranch to Be Searched for Manson Victims
description: LOS ANGELES  For those who spend a great deal of time mulling the intricacies and unanswered questions of real-life crimes, a remote area in Death Valley has always been fertile ground.

title: With European Flavor, Galaxy Tries for M.L.S. Success
description: CARSON, Calif.  The name Ruud Gullit still carries great currency in Europe, where Gullit, a two-time world player of the year from the Netherlands, was as distinctive for his flopping dreadlocks and his iconoclastic personality as for what he could do with a soccer ball at his feet.

title: Stared At in China
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Tuesday about the immigration detention system misstated the level of the charge against those who enter the country without authorization. It is a misdemeanor, not an administrative violation.

title: Taking Advantage of Previously Issued Credit Lines
description: IT appears to be a conundrum. Banks tell the Federal Reserve that they are tightening loan standards across the board, and that demand for loans is down from consumers as well as businesses. But the amount of money they are lending has been rising at an unusually fast pace.

title: Museum Plan for Chicagos Treasured Lakefront Stirs a Fight
description: CHICAGO  A proposal to build a childrens museum in a downtown park here has set off a fierce debate over Chicagos cherished lakefront.

title: E-Mail Shows Racial Jokes by Secret Service Supervisors
description: WASHINGTON  Secret Service supervisors shared crude sexual jokes and engaged in racially derogatory banter about blacks, and passed around an anecdote about a possible assassination of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, according to internal e-mail disclosed in a federal court filing on Friday by lawyers for black Secret Service agents.

title: Edwards Endorses Obama, or Does He?
description: Rewind that tape again.

title: In Flooded Delta, a Want as Pervasive as Death
description: BOGALE, Myanmar  The water has not receded fully, and few aid trucks have made it here. Only one helicopter, from the Myanmar military, was spotted all Friday, dropping off packages of instant noodles around a devastated delta that needs much more. Win Kyi, a mother looking for a lost son, was crying, her body shaking and her arms outstretched for food, money, water  anything.

title: Ledger Portrait Wins a Prize
description: A portrait of Heath Ledger that was painted weeks before his death has won an art award in Australia, The Associated Press reported. The painting, by the British-born Australian artist Vincent Fantauzzo, shows three bare-chested images of the actor, one staring out from the canvas as the others whisper in his ears. On Thursday the painting, Heath, won the Peoples Choice award in the annual national portrait competition at the Art Gallery of New South Wales in Sydney. Mr. Ledger, who plays the Joker in the new Batman movie, The Dark Knight, died in New York in January of an accidental overdose of prescription drugs. He was 28.

title: Castro Back With Mets; Wise Is Soon to Follow
description: Sitting on a clubhouse couch, Matt Wise greeted a visitor Friday afternoon with a happy-to-be-here smile and by saying: Hi, Im Matt Wise. Nice to meet you. No introductions were necessary, but forgive Wise for feeling the need to get reacquainted.

title: Housing Bailout Bill Seems to Be on Shaky Ground
description: WASHINGTON  Even as the housing foreclosure crisis deepens, legislation to rescue homeowners and their lenders appears to be in significant political jeopardy.

title: Enemies Face to Face, Exchanging Tales of Loss
description: The Fever Chart, a well-made trilogy by Naomi Wallace exploring that cauldron that is the Middle East, has absorbing characters and sharp, evocative dialogue. Just as important, though, is what it doesnt have: strap-on bombs or heartfelt hugs.

title: Most Popular Business News Articles on NYTimes.com
description: Following are the most popular business news articles on nytimes.com from May 2 through May 9:

title: An Identity Crisis? Hirshhorn Embraces It
description: WASHINGTON  Um, interesting painting, but could you please tell me where all the airplanes are?

title: Caught in a Swirl of Drug Violence, Mexico Vows to Fight Back
description: MEXICO CITY  President Felipe Caldern and dozens of federal agents attended the funeral of the chief of the federal police on Friday morning, a day after his assassination, even as investigators focused on the possibility that someone inside the police force had tipped off the killers to his location.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about airline safety records abroad misstated the timing of the crash of a DC-9 on takeoff from Goma, Congo. The crash was on April 15, not last week.

title: At Daimler, Sales Follow the Worlds Oil Riches
description: Daimler AG, the maker of Mercedes-Benz automobiles, will deal with slowing auto sales in the United States in part by shifting sales to Russia, China and the Middle East, says Dieter Zetsche, Daimlers chief executive. And the company, based in Stuttgart, Germany, expects to be the first to introduce a car with a lithium ion battery, the technology that is seen as crucial to creating all-electric vehicles, he says.

title: How to Be Smarter
description: WHILE your I.Q. is basically determined at birth, Wired says, still, there are lots of ways to get smarter  to max out your so-called functional intelligence at work and elsewhere.

title: Arizona and Utah Officials Reach Out to Polygamists
description: ST. GEORGE, Utah  Polygamy is probably here to stay. But child abuse in the polygamist world must be eradicated at all costs.

title: Safety Set to Blaze Path With Familiar Number
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Kenny Phillips said he figured all the telephone calls he had made to the Giants paid off when he spotted the blue practice jersey hanging in his locker Friday morning at Giants Stadium, and the No. 21 was on it.

title: Racial Inequity and Drug Arrests
description: The United States prison system keeps marking shameful milestones. In late February, the Pew Center on the States released a report showing that more than 1 in 100 American adults are presently behind bars  an astonishingly high rate of incarceration notably skewed along racial lines. One in nine black men aged 20 to 34 are serving time, as are 1 in 36 adult Hispanic men.

title: The Track That Defied the Writing on the Wall
description: DARLINGTON, S.C.  Harold King maneuvered the car onto the track at Darlington Raceway, Nascars original superspeedway. He punched the gas and steered the car high around the banked corner.

title: 40 Years Later, an Uprising in Paris Is Still a Puzzle
description: Even without retrieving that bundle of yellowing French newspapers from the top shelf in a closet, it is easy to remember the night of May 10, 1968, in Paris. It is far less easy, 40 years later, to discern what it was all about. Adolescent hormones, the death of Communism, the death of capitalism or, as Andre Malraux suggested at the time, the death of God?

title: Child Labor Rings Reach Chinas Distant Villages
description: LIANGSHAN, China  The mud and brick schoolhouses in the lush mountain villages of this remote part of southwestern China are dark and barebones in the best of times. These days, they also lack students.

title: Gas Prices Send Surge of Riders to Mass Transit
description: DENVER  With the price of gas approaching $4 a gallon, more commuters are abandoning their cars and taking the train or bus instead.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: METRO

title: One Man, Alone Onstage, Displays a Disquieting Family Album
description: The multiple layers of Far ...  a personal, poetic and extraordinary hourlong work of multimedia dance theater by Rachid Ouramdane  express aspects of what might be called shared post-invasion, post-traumatic stress syndrome. Political, sociological and psychological, Far ... is an engrossing work of art, devoid of any explicit agenda, frequently ambiguous and often touching on the ineffable: a one-man show about the collective unconscious.

title: China: Officials Fight Opposition to Chengdu Plant
description: Government officials are stepping up a campaign to quiet dissent over construction of a petrochemical plant on the outskirts of Chengdu, a provincial capital in western China. Last Sunday, hundreds of residents marched through downtown Chengdu to express concern about the plants environmental impact. This week, several blogs protesting the plants construction were blocked. Ran Yunfei, a blogger and journalist, said government officials visited his office to discuss the merits of the project. A state-controlled newspaper, Chengdu Business News, published articles laying out its benefits.

title: Myanmar Seizes U.N. Food for Cyclone Victims and Blocks Foreign Experts
description: BANGKOK  The military leaders of Myanmar seized a shipment of United Nations food aid on Friday intended for victims of a devastating cyclone, declaring that they would accept donations of food and medicine but not the foreign aid workers international groups say are in equally short supply there.

title: On McCain, Obama and a Hamas Link
description: In the clearest indication yet of how he intends to confront Senator Barack Obama on foreign policy issues in the general election, Senator John McCain on Friday again portrayed the Democratic contender as being the favorite of Hamas, the militant Palestinian group, and implied that he would also be friendly with Iran, a Hamas ally.

title: DAntoni Takes His Time Pondering His Future
description: Mike DAntonis teams are all about speed and spontaneity. His career planning strategy appears to be much more methodical.

title: Obama Pulls Ahead of Clinton in Superdelegates
description: Senator Barack Obama surged ahead of his rival, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, in the count of superdelegates on Friday, the first time since the outset of the race that Mrs. Clinton has lost the lead in one of her few remaining trump cards.

title: Keeping Furniture Ransom Off Your Moving Bill
description: LEAH MOORE and her husband, Colby Nichols, assumed they would be in their new Chicago home in time for dinner. Why would they think otherwise? All their belongings were in boxes, they had little furniture and they were moving only a few miles away.

title: 25 Years to Life for Lawyer Guilty in Tycoons Murder
description: A Manhattan lawyer convicted of orchestrating the 1990 murder of a real estate tycoon involved in a bitter split from his estranged wife was sentenced on Friday to 25 years to life in prison.

title: George Cressman Dies at 88; Led Weather Service
description: George Cressman, a pioneer in the use of computers to predict the weather and a former director of the National Weather Service, died on April 19 in Rockville, Md. He was 88 and lived in North Bethesda, Md.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Page 6 of the Travel section this weekend about music camps for adults misspells the given name of one rock musician who has appeared at a rock n roll fantasy camp and misspells the surname of another. They are Neal Schon, not Neil, and Roger Daltrey, not Daltry.

title: Thank Goodness, Dublin Keeps Its Guinness Plant
description: DUBLIN  The owner of Guinness stout, ending widespread media speculation in Ireland that it would shut the 250-year-old St. Jamess Gate brewery, said Friday that it was committed to continuing operations at the central Dublin site because of its iconic status.

title: Elaine Dundy, Author of The Dud Avocado, Is Dead at 86
description: Elaine Dundy, the author of the best-selling novel The Dud Avocado, whose title came from the theater critic Kenneth Tynan, her husband at the time, died on May 1 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 86.

title: Questions of Freedom, Set in Black and White
description: In his furious satire The Unconquered, the British playwright Torben Betts shakes the daylights out of the smarmy idea of freedom, commonly given lip service today in far-flung spots like Iraq, Britain and the United States. Rather like an angry dog with a series of rats in its jaws, Mr. Betts sets himself the task of killing off popular beliefs in the benevolence of Big Brother government, religion, marriage and, of course, capitalism and bourgeois consumerism.

title: Snapshots of a Frenetic Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: With More Videotapes Come More Questions
description: When a former New England Patriots employee sent eight videotapes to the N.F.L. this week that showed the team spying on opponents, the question turned to whether the tapes contained new evidence of cheating, or if the league was already aware of everything on the tapes.

title: Paris on the Anniversary of the 1968 Protests
description: France puts great stock in anniversaries. On your Paris map, youll find streets named 8 Mai 1945 and 4 Septembre and squares called 8 Novembre 1942, 18 Juin 1940, 19 Mars 1962, and, most recently, Place du 8 Fvrier 1962  this one so christened last year on the anniversary of a protest for peace in Algeria. Flags come out, like the mammoth Tricouleur under the Arc de Triomphe for todays Victory Day; newspapers groan under weighty ruminations; officials don sashes.

title: Trade Deficit Narrows in March, but Exports Fall
description: Domestic demand for imports fell in March by the most since 2001, the latest indication that the economic slowdown has forced Americans to rein in their spending habits, the government reported Friday.

title: Imagining a Cipriani Dining Place Without Those Family-Invented Bellinis
description: A Cipriani restaurant without a liquor license: aphorisms about dogs without bones spring to mind. How could it go on? And would it even be possible?

title: Starting a Party, and Hoping to Crash Singapores Parliament Again
description: SINGAPORE

title: Violence in Beirut
description: Heavily armed Hezbollah fighters seized control of much of western Beirut on Friday, after three days of the worst sectarian clashes Lebanon has seen since its 15-year civil war.

title: The Quad Countdown: No. 111 U.N.L.V.
description: Location: Las Vegas

title: Respond to Todays Column: Mothers Day Scandal
description: Its hard to imagine that a love child or two poses any actual threat to a Congressmans constituents. The same cannot be said about having a local lawmaker who is prepared to get behind the wheel of a car when hes too drunk to remember the rule about not mentioning the daughter in Alexandria to authority figures brandishing pencil and pad.

title: Meg and Wes
description: Meg Berte and Wes Owen discuss briefly dating at Harvard and then finding years later that they belonged together.

title: Meg and Wes
description: Meg Berte and Wes Owen discuss briefly dating at Harvard and then finding years later that they belonged together.

title: Rastafari Culture at the Smithsonian
description: Images of the exhibition Discovering Rastafari! at the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History.

title: Rebranding the Hirshhorn
description: Images from the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, a contemporary art museum in Washington, D.C., which is hoping to distinguish itself through a new ad campaign.

title: Jason Taylor Dances; The Theme Is Nostalgia
description: Jason Taylor on Dancing With the Stars

title: Pleasingly Plump
description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

title: Free-Fallin Pols: The Screen Savers
According to the Most Recent Exit Polls
description: Aired Friday night on NBC: I saw something in the paper today which shows how fat were getting in this country. A company has now come out with a bathroom scale that goes to 1,000 pounds. This is probably the worst Mothers Day gift in history.

title: Tensions Rise as Polar Bear Decision Looms
description: Steven C. Amstrup, the federal biologist who led an analysis last year concluding that the worlds polar bear population could shrink two thirds by 2050 under moderate projections for retreating summer sea ice, is once again in the field along Alaskas Arctic coast, studying this years brood of cubs, yearlings and mothers.

title: Stalling exports?
description: Brad Setser tells us that the trade numbers, contrary to just about all reporting, are worrisome: strip out the effects of raw material prices, and it looks as if export growth  the only thing that has kept us from having a much worse slowdown  is stalling out.

title: Sick transit and all that
description: The Times reports that ridership on mass transit is surging thanks to high gasoline prices. Good.

title: Where Gymnasts Are Chosen, in the Middle of Nowhere
description: NEW WAVERLY, Texas  This week, a group of Olympic gymnastics hopefuls headed for Bela and Martha Karolyis womens national team training center held about 60 miles north of Houston. The last time I was at this 2,000-acre ranch was four years ago, just before the Athens Games. Since then, Id forgotten about how far away this training center was from civilization. Its in the boondocks, or maybe just south of there: about 16 miles away from the Texas State Prison in Huntsville, death row capital of the United States, and smack in the middle of Sam Houston National Forest, where the Karolyis settled in the early 80s.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Saturday, May 10:

title: Your Comments on my Kids Column
description: My Sunday column is about high school and younger students moving into philanthropy and social action. Its something that my wife and I noticed in particular in our work on a forthcoming book about women in the developing world. High school students, for example, have done great work on human trafficking, perhaps because its kids their age who are being locked up in brothels in India and Cambodia. Among the high school-led groups on that issue are Loosen Change to Loosen Chains and Minga. Mingas founder was inspired by Free the Children,  a network of children helping other exploited children through education and other means. Girls Learn International is another example of high school kids fighting trafficking and helping kids abroad by keeping them in school.

title: The Early Word: Delegate Catch-Up to General Match-Up
description: Now that he has caught up with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the superdelegate count, Senator Barack Obama is clashing more directly with Senator John McCain (so is Mrs. Clinton, for that matter).

title: Blog Roll: Searching for Belmont Winner
description: Our friend Paul Moran appears to be conceding a victory to Big Brown in next Saturday in the Preakness Stakes. He is, however, looking for a Triple Crown upsetter for the Belmont Stakes. His search begins today in the Peter Pan Stakes out at Belmont.

title: Narrow Escapes for CNN Reporter in Myanmar
description: The Associated Press reports:

title: HBO Signs Writer For Hung
description: HBO has lined up another big Hollywood name for a new project, Edward Wyatt reports. Alexander Payne, the director and Oscar-winning co-writer of Sideways, will direct and serve as an executive producer of Hung, a new dark comedy series about a former basketball coach with a large penis.

title: Avocado Refrigerators Out, Mass Transit In
description: There are a couple of important stories in The Times worth highlighting today, one on determining when an old appliance should  and should not  get the heave-ho, and one on a burst of interest in mass transit driven by high gas prices.

title: Three stories behind qualifying in Turkey
description: The top three finishers in todays qualifying session each had equally interesting stories, although they are not all equally as straightforward.

title: Retiring Horses
description: While we are in the midst of the Triple Crown, the showcase of our best 3-year-olds, it is important to remain committed to all horses that perform at racetracks up and down North America, and those horses that can no longer perform. Racetracks are now starting to recognize the issue and do something positive for its retired stars.

title: Mays Poli-Book Best Sellers
description: Cokie Roberts rides in at No. 1 with Ladies of Liberty, on the heels of her earlier work, Founding Mothers.

title: McCain Plane Still Flying
description: Cindy McCain said Thursday that she would never release her personal income tax filing even if her husband, Senator John McCain, was elected president. But Federal Aviation Administration records indicate that she appears to be using her personal wealth to help his campaign, through the continued use of her corporate jet.The New York Times reported last month that during a crucial five-month period Mr. McCains campaign regularly used a corporate jet owned by the Phoenix-based beer distributor that Mrs. McCain heads, saving the campaign hundreds of thousands of dollars. His campaign pays rates well below market ones for the planes use because of an unresolved exemption in a recent campaign finance law that Mr. McCain backed.

title: Quick Hits: Catching Up With Mauer
description: In 2006, Joe Mauer of the Twins had two hits on the final day of the season that raised his average to .347. In doing so, he became the first catcher since 1930 to lead his league in batting average, and the first ever to lead the majors.

title: The Morning Skate: Mighty Pens, Mighty Mouth
description: Poor Marty Biron. Hes been the Flyers MVP this spring, and deservedly so. But, cmon without, cmon within, hes not see nothin like the mighty Pens.

title: Clouds With No Rain

title: Paperback Row
description: THE GRAVEDIGGERS DAUGHTER, by Joyce Carol Oates. (Ecco/Harper Perennial, $15.95.) The daughter of a Holocaust survivor (the gravedigger of the title) who commits an incredible murder, Oatess heroine endures enough violence to fill a slasher movie. But she is able to reinvent herself as a peppy salesclerk with a jazz-musician lover and become a living, breathing, complex presence on the page, our reviewer, Lee Siegel, wrote. Oates is sometimes compared to Theodore Dreiser, the author of Sister Carrie, Siegel continued, but in the way her novels take off at the moment when her heroines break free, Oates is sometimes more like Carrie herself.

title: Chronicle of a Death Foretold
description: One of the wonders of the genome is how it enables us to time-travel, both backward and forward. Scribbled within it are clues to our ancestry, which can give us an emboldening sense of continuity, coherence, place  how marvelous to imagine ourselves the sons of Levi, the daughters of African queens! But scrawled within it, too, are clues about our future, which can be downright terrifying. Rather than expand our sense of possibilities, they foreshorten them. There are dread mutations slumbering in our cells. From our genes, we learn how we may die.

The April 6 error was discovered when TIAA-CREF sent an e-mail message on Tuesday pointing out that a headline and an article in Business Day that day contained the error.

title: 36 Hours in Liverpool, England
description: THE word Liverpool invariably evokes two images: the Beatles and soccer. Thats a shame because this industrial city, which celebrated its 800th birthday last year (and is the 2008 European Capital of Culture), moved on a long time ago. Avant-garde architecture and glassy museums share the skyline with redbrick warehouses and foggy quays. Liverpools contemporary art scene is no longer overshadowed by Londons but possesses its own roster of Turner Prize winners. And the citys legendary music scene continues to put together new sounds. Just listen to the recent crop of breakthrough bands like the Wombats, the Zutons and the Coral. Never heard of them? Must be a different generation.

Have you shown the film to   Al Gore? He has not seen the film as far as I know.

title: Take My Brother, Please
description: Children tend to become what we expect them to be. When we envisioned them as vessels waiting to be filled with virtue, they made like vessels; nowadays we see them as consumers, and they fall into line, getting, spending and demanding designer gear. The comfy habitat of liberal Manhattan intelligentsia has been dismantled: the hedge funders have colonized the classic sixes, every other storefronts a bank and Broadway is lousy with Starbucks. But the old neighborhoods still got some magic, as evidenced by Lily Koppels new book, The Red Leather Diary: Reclaiming a Life Through the Pages of a Lost Journal. Where else can a young writer inherit a 75-year-old diary, left to rot in the storage room of a prewar building? And in a plastic bag from Zabars, yet?

But what of its more unassuming antecedent, 1958? Fifty years ago, Eisenhower was in the White House, the country was in a recession and the American intellectual scene was crackling with energy.

His .220 average can be partly attributed to a lack a patience  he is seeing fewer pitches per at-bat than in his previous three seasons. If there is an encouraging sign, it is that he is hitting fewer ground balls, which could spark his power numbers.

title: All the Difference
description: The life of Robert Frost has been autopsied and re-autopsied so many times that, 45 years since his death, the congeries of appraisals can already be measured in layers, like geologic strata. The early biographies  beginning with Gorham B. Munsons Robert Frost: A Study in Sensibility and Good Sense, published less than 15 years after Frosts first book of poems  tended toward hagiography, portraying Frost as Frost carefully portrayed himself: as a homespun Yankee sage, the L. L. Bean of verse, a swinger of birches and picker of apples whose wisdom and prickly wit were like a potbellied woodstove taking the chill (Eliot, Pound) out of Modernist poetry.

The Iraq correspondent for The Independent in London, he has been visiting Iraq since 1977 and has written two previous books on the country. Cockburn lives up to those credentials in his important new book, Muqtada, which goes a long way toward helping us understand the radical cleric Moktada al-Sadr by following his family through the modern history of Iraq.

title: Three Soldiers
description: Of all the grim theaters of conflict in World War II, none were more dismal and murderous than Italy in the winter of 1944. As American forces slogged and scrambled their way north, the Germans gave way with brutal reluctance, while Italian partisans fought Fascists, and others welcomed the liberators or just sullenly watched. The war took place in a world of ambush, treachery and uncertainty. This is the setting for Richard Bauschs 11th novel, a short, bleakly brilliant one-act drama depicting the futility and moral complexity of combat.

title: Vote Like Thy Neighbor

In reality, matters are not so simple. Far from being postpartisan, todays young adults are significantly more likely to identify as Democrats than were their predecessors. Along with colleagues at the Brookings and Hoover institutions, we recently completed a comprehensive study of the nations polarization. Our research concludes not only that the ideological differences between the political parties are growing but also that they have become embedded in American society itself.

description: MOUNT KISCO

title: The Greatests Story, Told Twice
description: Muhammad Alis epic journey  from the 12-year-old Cassius Clay who learned to box after his new bike was stolen, to the 60s icon of defiance, sacrifice and principle, to the first three-time heavyweight champion of the world, to the gallant Parkinsons patient  is a narrative so dense and complex that it has so far eluded definitive biography.

title: Pragmatic Politics, Forged on the South Side
description: In August 1999, Barack Obama strolled amid the floats and bands making their way down Martin Luther King Drive on Chicagos South Side. Billed as the largest African-American parade in the country, the summer rite was a draw over the years to boxing heroes like Muhammad Ali and jazz greats like Duke Ellington. It was also a must-stop for the citys top politicians.

title: In Dixie, Signs of a Rising Biracial Politics
description: Across the South, Barack Obamas smashing primary victory in North Carolina last week reflects a new reality  a half-century of rising Republican red tide has crested, with signs of receding.

title: Boys to Men
description: A college friend who was struggling in one of his classes went to talk things over with his professor. If he was counting on sympathy, he was in for a surprise: Get interested in Latin, the professor advised him. Latin wont get interested in you.

title: Difficult Truths
description: A young man, heir to a fortune so vast he considers it his cross of gold, comes home from Guadalcanal a decorated hero, bearing scars from a bullet that just missed his heart. God has saved him, he believes, for a purpose. The vocation he heard at Yale has grown loud enough to drown out the objections of his family. Ordained an Episcopal priest in 1949, he begins his career in a blighted New Jersey parish, eventually climbing to a position so exalted that at his death in 2003 he is remembered as a prince of the church, a saint.

title: Bridal Gown? Caterer? Mortgage?
description: AS they seek ways to offset the downturn in home sales, real estate and mortgage brokers have recently started courting first-time buyers among the newly engaged  at wedding expos and on wedding Web sites.

title: When We Last Saw Our Heroes ...
description: Unto God is the sequel of all things, says the Koran, but weve never paid much attention to that, have we? America is the land of the sequel, from the founding of the New World to the release of Spider-Man 3, and childrens literature is no exception. Perhaps this is because both children and publishers are honest enough to say out loud what the rest of us think when we finish a good book: More!

title: City Operas Man in Waiting, Thinking Ahead
description: PARIS

title: First-Class Privilege
description: Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff went to Baltimore-Washington International Airport two weeks ago to inaugurate a program called Checkpoint Evolution. It introduces 600 whole-body imagers that replicate, in schematic 3-D, everything a passenger is hiding under his or her clothing  not only hypothetical daggers, pistols, knuckle dusters and cocaine but also actual moles, scars, sores, nipples and genitalia. And all of it so vividly that the A.C.L.U. calls the imagers virtual strip-search machines. But Checkpoint Evolution is about comfort as well as security. Pleasant music, better lighting and open spaces are supposed to change the airport-security experience in a way that lowers the general stress level, Chertoff said. He failed, however, to mention a thing about checkpoints that drives stress levels to insurrectionary heights: the segregated security lines that certain airports and airlines permit. Many first- and business-class passengers, as well as frequent fliers, zip right to the metal detectors while coach passengers snake through lines for waits than can exceed half an hour. If Americans will put up with that, theyll put up with being seen naked.

title: Pastors and Politics
description: Pastors and Politics

title: Kitchen So Small, but Taste So Big
description: THE major dissonant note at Harvest Supper, a new restaurant in New Canaan, is the name. On my first visit I expected home-style cooking and a fake Amish atmosphere. What I found was a stylish American menu, sophisticated food to match, beautifully plated on Japanese ceramics of varying shapes. And while the dcor is crisply simple, it is artfully so. This is no country kitchen in the Poconos.

title: Day to Remember, Night to Forget (Except Pelfrey)
description: The opener of their day-night doubleheader Saturday reminded the Mets how simple and enjoyable baseball can be: see the ball, hit the ball. They thrashed the Cincinnati Reds, 12-6, scoring 12 runs for the second straight game, as Carlos Beltrn and Carlos Delgado were front and center in offsetting a merely good outing by their ace, Johan Santana.

title: A Peek Behind the Price at the Pump
description: FROM Capitol Hill to Wall Street to the campaign trail, the recent surge in oil prices is quickly threatening to supplant the mortgage crisis as the countrys leading economic issue. Last week, prices for crude set another record, finishing at $125.96 a barrel on Friday, while gasoline prices closed in on $4 a gallon.

title: Taking a Break From Life to Live the Fantasy
description: A LATE-NIGHT jam session in a hotel lobby is what persuaded Tom Stockfisch to take up the cello shortly before his 50th birthday. On a summer night four years ago, he and his wife stumbled upon a Quality Inn where participants were staying for the annual Strings Conference in San Diego, a summer camp of sorts for violinists, cellists, bassists and viola players created by the virtuoso violinist Mark OConnor.

title: Station Site Envisioned as Village
description: A TRANSIT village consisting of an estimated 1.2 million square feet of commercial, residential, retail and industrial development, tied together by a new Long Island Rail Road station, is being explored for the Route 110 corridor near Republic Airport.

title: Back From the 80s, Eyeing Other Peoples Money
description: Would Larry the Liquidator have been able to take over Yahoo?

title: Over the Bustle of the Everyday Commute, Her Voice Has Guided the Way
description: The voice that launched a thousand trips  on Thursday alone  was about to launch another.

title: Even Listening Is Dangerous
Humbler, After a Streak of Magic
description: FOR 15 years through 2005, Bill Miller, one of the countrys most closely watched and widely worshiped stockpickers, made investments that handily beat stock market averages. But for the last two years, the market has handily pulverized him.

title: Almighty Dolor
description: Foreign-Currency C.D.s

title: New Rules and Economy Strain Adoption Agencies
description: Faced with a tightening of federal regulations governing foreign adoptions, and suffering from a downturn in business, international adoption agencies in the United States are finding themselves in financial straits and closing their doors in unprecedented numbers, experts say.

title: Katherine Barge, Jeremy Paris
description: Katherine Wright Barge and Jeremy Austin Paris were married on Saturday evening at the Grove Park Inn in Asheville, N.C. Rabbi Harvey J. Winokur officiated, with the Rev. Timothy C. Ahrens, a United Church of Christ minister, taking part.

title: Ski Portillo in Chile Opens a Spa Hotel
description: Owners of the prestigious Chilean ski resort Ski Portillo recently opened the Tierra Atacama Adventure Spa Hotel (www.tierraatacama.com) in northern Chile, just outside the historic town of San Pedro de Atacama. The 32-room resort, which was built at an elevation of 8,000 feet in the Andes Mountains, below, is surrounded by high-altitude deserts and salt flats. Its spa incorporates local ingredients, like desert herbs and salt from the flats, into treatments like body wraps and massages.

title: Correction: Evening Hours
description: Two picture captions last Sunday in the Evening Hours column reversed the identities of the couples honored on April 27 at the New Museum anniversary gala. Susan and Leonard Feinstein were at the middle left; Mitzi and Warren Eisenberg were at the top left.

title: Katharine Carter, Bradford OGrady
description: Katharine Carter and Bradford OGrady were married on Saturday at Christ Church in Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Leslie Smith, an Episcopal priest and the churchs interim rector, performed the ceremony.

title: Quiet Jazz, Roaring Noise, Hip-Hop Wizardry
description: Jonah Jones

title: Hezbollah Begins to Withdraw Gunmen in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Hezbollah and its allies began withdrawing their gunmen from the capital here on Saturday evening, raising hopes for a political settlement after four days of street battles that left at least 29 people dead.

title: Correction: Inside the List
description: Because of a transcription error, a brief report in the Inside the List column on April 27 about Julie Andrewss memoir, Home, misquoted one word of an interview Andrews had with Terry Gross on NPR. She described being very young with a voice that was able to do cadenzas, not condensers.

title: 50 Years of Dizzy, Courtesy of Hitchcock
description: I LOOK up, I look down, says Detective John (Scottie) Ferguson of the San Francisco police, standing nervously on a stepladder in an early scene of Alfred Hitchcocks Vertigo.

title: Editors Choice
description: LIFE AND DEATH ARE WEARING ME OUT, by Mo Yan. Translated by Howard Goldblatt. (Arcade, $29.95.) This visionary novel tracks Chinas revolutionary experience through the eyes of five animal narrators, serial reincarnations of a wealthy landlord.

title: Criminal Charges Filed in Fuel Spill Aftermath
description: WHEN fuel-pumping equipment at the Croton-Harmon Metro-North rail yard ruptured in late March, about 17,000 gallons of diesel fuel spilled into the ground  a potential environmental hazard.

title: Von der Lippe Is Still Making a Splash at 42
description: Winning an Olympic medal is supposed to open doors. Isnt that how it works? Susan von der Lippe, a three-time Olympian who won a silver in 1984, ruminated on the privileges bestowed upon the sports ultra-elite from her seat high above the pool deck at the United States swimming trials four years ago.

title: The Dangers of the Deltas
description: Deltas are disaster zones in waiting. From the Mekong to the Mississippi, the rich soils and strategic positions of river mouths have long lured farmers, fishers and traders. But the same geography also guarantees they will be periodically inundated.

title: Emily Forland, Mark Abrams
description: Emily Forland and Mark Abrams were married on Saturday evening at the McNay Art Museum in San Antonio. Rabbi Samuel M. Stahl officiated.

title: Lottery Numbers
With Echoes of Their War, Veterans Greet Iraq Soldiers
description: Fort Dix

title: Bread Thats Flat and Flavorful
description: At restaurants that serve Mediterranean foods, the bread is often a semiflexible scoop for hummus or a bland envelope for a sandwich. So it comes as a surprise when the first impression  a good one  of a falafel sandwich is the pita, fluffy, pliant and even flavorful.

title: Stocks and Earnings Suffer Together
description: The stock market fell last week, beaten down by grim corporate earnings reports and the burden of record-breaking energy prices.

title: Going Once, Twice, Sold to the Guy on the Curb
description: BRIAN KEARNEY, an auctioneer wearing a black suit and red tie, stood at the front door of 593 President Street in Park Slope on Tuesday, holding a wooden gavel that proved merely decorative, since there was nothing on which to bang it.

title: A Funhouse Floating in a Korean Spa
description: THIS is the best night of my life! burbled Rory as he was swashed in an inner tube around the whirlpool section of the outdoor hot pools at Inspa World.

title: Judges Guantnamo Ruling Bodes Ill for System
description: A decision by a military judge on Friday to disqualify a top Pentagon official from any further role in a Guantnamo war crimes case was a major new challenge to the Bush administrations legal approach to the war on terrorism.

title: One County Away, a Different Care Picture
description: While Suffolk County is considering whether to dispose of its nursing home, Nassau County is making plans to build a $100 million replacement for its 47-year-old A. Holly Patterson Extended Care Facility in Uniondale.

title: As You Exit J.F.K., a Chilling Memory Below
description: The Dispatches column last Sunday, about an AirTrain station near Kennedy Airport that was struck by a police detectives bullet during the confrontation that led to the shooting death of Sean Bell in 2006, referred imprecisely to the background of Richard Criscuola, an airport cargo handler who often passes through the station. He moved to Queens about a year ago  but not to Jamaica, Queens, where he moved more recently.

title: An Indie Scene That Comes With a Texas Twang in Denton
description: WITH its Piggly Wiggly markets and dusty pawnshops, the Texas college town of Denton does not look the part of a Woodstock in waiting. A Romanesque courthouse juts out of the central square, as in that fictional town in Back to the Future. And whenever the local college football team plays at Fouts Field, the entire town seems to put on Mean Green T-shirts.

title: The Mother Hood
description: Suddenly unmoored in her 41st year, Amy Lamb is drifting in a familiar midlife sea of ambivalence and regret. Like many other Manhattan mothers, she left a career to raise her child. But now her son, Mason, is 10 and increasingly independent; Leo, her kindly, overworked husband, is more and more remote, burrowing ever deeper into the files he brings home at night. And as for her long-lost career  she was a corporate lawyer in the middling firm where shed met Leo  well, it was really never that absorbing. Amys circle includes Roberta Sokolov, an artist turned full-time mother whose own career, like Amys, never quite blossomed, and Jill Hamlin, her best friend from college, who carries around a whole satchelful of disappointments: a failed dissertation, years of infertility, an inability to connect with her placid, adopted daughter.

title: Avenues of Change
description: New wrinkles keep coming in the competition between the incumbent Fifth Avenue and the challenger Seventh Avenue as Park Slopes restaurant row. These additions have arrived in the past year.

title: Istanbul's Beat Is International
description: TO sample the youthful sounds of Istanbul, snake down a narrow street behind Tunel square until you find Badehane. For years, this one-room corner cafe (General Yazgan Sokak 1D; 90-212-249-0550) in the buzzing night life district of Beyoglu has been a favorite of the bohemian set, which comes on Wednesday nights to listen to the gypsy tunes of a local legend, Selim Sesler.

title: Information That Doesnt Come Freely
description: NINA BERNSTEIN, a Times reporter, wrote a front-page article last June about the deaths of prisoners in the fastest-growing form of incarceration in America, immigration detention.

title: Woodsman, Dont Spare That Tree
description: ON a sunny afternoon last week, a retired New York firefighter named Bruce Stuart sat on a tree stump overlooking a narrow creek that ran through Udalls Cove Park Preserve in Douglaston, Queens. A tall man with a graying mustache, Mr. Stuart listened as the birds chirped and the water murmured on its way toward Little Neck Bay to the north.

title: Balcony? Not at These Intimate Listening Spots
description: WHEN it comes to describing places to hear music, heres an adjective that is tossed around a lot: intimate.

title: That Isnt Lint on My Lapel, Im an Officier
description: AT a recent book party high above Gramercy Park, Brian Gallagher, a young journalist, approached Robert Silvers, the longtime editor of The New York Review of Books. What, Mr. Gallagher asked, was that little red thread sewn onto Mr. Silverss suit lapel? Legion of Honor, Mr. Silvers answered, with a smile at once proud and slightly bashful. It was for the paper, he said, referring to his literary journal.

title: Fearing for Many at Home, Citys Burmese Unite to Aid Cyclone Victims
description: Linda Wu said that whenever troubles in Myanmar make news in the United States, business spikes at the two Burmese restaurants she owns in Manhattan, with regular patrons coming by daily to check on her and the restaurants staff. And once the regulars check in, Ms. Wu said, most of them stay to eat.

title: Kelly Edwards, Michael Irwin
description: Kelly Elizabeth Edwards, the daughter of Sandra L. Edwards of Madison, Conn., and James R. Edwards of Dallas, was married on Saturday evening to Michael Alan Irwin, the son of LuAnn Irwin and Lee Irwin of Sodus, N.Y. The Rev. George S. Salzmann, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church of Harvard.

title: Already, Obama and McCain Map Fall Strategies
description: Senators John McCain and Barack Obama are already drawing up strategies for taking each other on in the general election, focusing on the same groups  including independent voters and Latinos  and about a dozen states where they think the contest is likely to be decided this fall, campaign aides said.

title: The Trunk Is in Their Yard, the Branches Are in Yours
description: Q I own a home that abuts property, owned by a railroad company, that has trees that are growing over my property and dropping large branches. When I contacted the company, I was told it does not clear branches from trees that grow over other owners property, but I could do so at my own risk and cost.

title: Up Front
description: No conservative writer was tougher on Richard Nixon than George F. Will, the longtime columnist for The Washington Post and Newsweek  particularly on the subject of the 784-day Watergate debacle, as he once termed it. The Nixon White House ran amok as no other has done, and its abuses were uniquely lurid and sinister, Will wrote on Aug. 8, 1974, the day Nixon announced he would resign from the presidency.

title: Progress in Promoting Black Officers, but Police Department Faces Hurdles
description: The fatal police shooting of Sean Bell, a black man killed in a hail of 50 bullets on his wedding day, spurred widespread public anger and put the Police Departments relationship with some black New Yorkers under a microscope.

title: Jenny Slayton, Justin Green
description: Jenny Anna Slayton, the daughter of Margareta Slayton and Paul Slayton of Bridgehampton, N.Y., was married on Saturday evening to Justin Hays Green, the son of Susan Zises Green of New York. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein performed the ceremony at Central Synagogue in New York.

title: Mike Tyson Film Takes a Swing at His Old Image
description: Henderson, Nev.

title: A Reprieve for State Parks, but Not a Solution
description: Hopewell Township

title: Letters: Clothing Optional
description: CLOTHING OPTIONAL

title: Sarah Myler, Nicholas Ingrassia
description: Sarah Rachel Myler, a daughter of Carol and Colin Myler of London, was married on Saturday to Nicholas Andrew Ingrassia, the son of Vicki and Lawrence Ingrassia of Brooklyn. Msgr. Robert T. Ritchie performed the ceremony at St. Patricks Cathedral in Manhattan.

title: Spiritual Retreat
description: It was 7:30 p.m., minutes before the 12 diners schmoozing on the opposite side of the kitchen wall would sit down to an elaborate eight-course tasting menu. Chef Bryan Sikora, who was running water through pig intestines for chorizo sausages hed fill the next day, was meditating absently on the undeveloped potential of hot dogs stuffed in gougres. His wife, Aimee Olexy, uncorked a bottle of Sauvignon Blanc and poured everyone in the kitchen a generous glass. So while most every other restaurant in the country edged toward meltdown getting ready for the onslaught of diners, the staff of Talulas Table in Kennett Square, Pa.  about 40 miles southwest of Philadelphia  clinked together their handblown glasses and began service.

title: Suffolk-Run Nursing Home Falls in Budget-Cutters Sights
description: YAPHANK

title: Focused Food, Center Stage
description: THEATER SQUARE GRILL, the 10-year-old restaurant in the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, is impressive on many counts. But the most impressive may be its theatrical sense of pace.

title: A Hurdle for TV: Wall Street Reality
description: The mortgage crisis hasnt merely caused millions of home foreclosures, cost big Wall Street firms tens of billions of dollars and forced layoffs. It has also made it harder to find willing participants for Wall Street Warriors, a cable television show that documents the lives of traders, brokers, bankers and other financial professionals.

title: Doubling Up for Shakespeares Twin-Laden Comedy of Errors
description: If one set of identical twins doesnt generate enough mayhem for a comedy to take flight, the presence of two doppelgnger duos should ensure total bedlam. In his Comedy of Errors, Shakespeare not only borrowed twins from Menaechmi by Plautus, the play that was his principal source, but tightened the tangle by adding another pair, from Amphitruo, by the same author.

title: Daria Natan and Robert Pahlavan
description: Daria Mia DeLancey Natan and Robert Bardia Pahlavan were married on Saturday evening at the Church of the Holy Trinity in Philadelphia. The Rev. Alan Neale, an Episcopal priest and the churchs rector, led a ceremony that included Muslim and Jewish elements.

title: Lexicographical Longing
description: When I was 19, my father gave me an Oxford English Dictionary, the 1971 compact edition with the 1987 supplement. Citations for every English word since the eighth century were crammed into three bulky volumes of minuscule print. I hallucinated before the speckled onion-skin pages until I discovered that the dictionary came with a magnifying glass.

title: San Francisco: Yoshi's Jazz Club & Restaurant
description: Jazz and sushi seem at first an unusual combination, but in the San Francisco Bay area they are inextricably linked, thanks to Yoshis.

title: Sadr City Bomb Squad: Looking for Trouble Before It Explodes
description: BAGHDAD  The bland job description is route clearance, but it is one of the most unglamorous and dangerous missions in Iraq. Creeping along the scarred streets of Sadr City, the soldiers search for roadside bombs around the clock, using bright spotlights at night that make them a big, bright target.

title: Adele Morse, William Nevins
description: Adele Forbes Morse and William McCay Nevins were married in Pasadena, Calif., on Saturday at the home of Mary Lois Nevins, the bridegrooms mother. The Rev. Valerie M. Webster, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

description: Arizona
