title: Correction: The Coming of Age of Copenhagens Nordic Cuisine
description: A map with an article on May 4 about restaurants in Copenhagen labeled incorrectly a body of water near Nyhavn. It is Copenhagen Harbor, not the Malmo River. The label on the map is by the former dock for ferries to Malmo, Sweden; there is no Malmo River.

title: Oil Prices Are Up and Politicians Are Angry. Yawn.
description: There is seemingly no more combustible mix than high oil prices and a hotly contested election. With gasoline closing in on $4 a gallon, Washington is awash in proposals to bring down prices  once more turning the energy debate into political football.

title: Miya Kang and Justin Ko
description: Mi-Hyang Kang and Justin Ko were married on Saturday evening at Viansa Winery in Sonoma, Calif. Christopher M. Jackson, a Universal Life minister and friend of the couple, officiated.

title: The Story of a Marriage
description: We think we know the ones we love.

title: In New York, Parking Is Ever So Easy
description: SHOULD Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg be feeling glum over the death of congestion pricing, his plan to divert drivers onto public transit by imposing an $8 surcharge to motor into the heart of Manhattan, he ought to be cheered by the arrival of the Smart car from Europe.

title: Sudans Army Beats Back Rebel Attack on Capital
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Darfurian rebels staged a bold attack on Saturday, advancing to within a few miles of the center of Sudans capital, Khartoum.

title: Feeling Like a Rock Star
description: IVE been driving my Smart Fortwo since the middle of last month and have been having a great time. It is, simply, a hoot to drive.

title: Mad Pride Fights a Stigma
description: IN the YouTube video, Liz Spikol is smiling and animated, the light glinting off her large hoop earrings. Deadpan, she holds up a diaper. It is not, she explains, a hygienic item for a giantess, but rather a prop to illustrate how much control people lose when they undergo electroconvulsive therapy, or ECT, as she did 12 years ago.

title: Trajectories
description: TO JUDGE from the news out of NASA these days, you might think we are witnessing the last gasps of the space age. The agency has announced that it will phase out its aging fleet of space shuttles by the year 2010, and the next iteration of the space program, known as Constellation, isnt likely to be sending people into orbit before 2015. Back in 2004, President Bush exhorted NASA to return humans to the moon (and then continue on to Mars), but precious little has been heard from the White House on the matter since. The American enthusiasm for space travel that accompanied the first footprints on the lunar surface seems less ardent with each year that separates us from that one small step.

title: Under Analysis: The Psychology of Tudors Ballets
description: WHEN the choreographer Antony Tudor, whose centenary is being celebrated this year, moved to America in 1939, the moment could not have been more right. He was known as the psychological choreographer, and he arrived when psychology entered American popular culture. In 1938 Fred Astaire played Ginger Rogerss psychoanalyst in Carefree; in 1942 Claude Rains steered Bette Davis back from a nervous breakdown in Now, Voyager. Later Martha Graham would become yet more famous for the Greek myths she turned into modern-dance psychodramas, but that phase  like Hitchcocks (notably in Spellbound, 1945)  had not yet arrived.

title: Getting Used to the Quirks
description: I dont drive my Smart much. My office is only about a mile from home, but I still have to drive because the lack of sidewalks makes it dangerous to walk. My Smart, a red Cabriolet, is well-equipped and has been a pleasure to own.

title: 24-Hour TV News
description: To the Editor:

title: The New New World
description: Every 20 years or so, the end of America is nigh  ever since the 18th century when, in France, Comte de Buffon fingered the country as a den of degeneracy while Abb Raynal slammed its cultural poverty: America had not yet produced one good poet, one able mathematician, one man of genius. In 1987, in his book The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers, the Yale historian Paul Kennedy saw the United States on the road to perdition  this, four years before the suicide of the Soviet Union, which left America all alone in the penthouse of global power. Now, two decades on, it is the much-hyped great power shift toward Asia that will turn the United States into a has-been.

title: Living a Charmed Life
description: SOME people say that whats on television is not an accurate reflection of reality. But look at Joan Collins. She had her ingnue moments in the mid-1950s, yet it was not until 1981 that she truly became the Joan Collins we know, portraying Alexis Carrington Colby, etc., on Dynasty. It was this incarnation, brimming with fur hats, Nolan Miller gowns, leg-of-mutton sleeves and shoulder pads out to there, that resonates as one of the most potent of the 80s.

title: Earth to Young People: Help!
description: Environmental consciousness-raising is a big thing now in childrens books, and thats good. But as a genre, it can be kind of a bummer, which may explain why it doesnt bring in nearly the returns of, say, fantasy novels. DK Publishings Earth Matters is a perfect example of why.

description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.

title: Breeding for Speed, Ignoring Durability
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  The Hancocks have been raising racehorses for four generations and not too long ago, Arthur III kept to a rule he learned from his father, Bull Hancock Jr.: Never breed to a stallion with fewer than 25 career starts. That rule was good enough to produce the Kentucky Derby champions Gato Del Sol in 1982 and Sunday Silence in 1989.

title: Brooklyn Churches Come and Go
description: EVIDENCE suggests that New Yorkers may be more religiously observant now than three decades ago. The number of churches, temples, mosques and other houses of worship  many of them in storefronts  jumped by 37 percent in Manhattan from 1980 to 2000, according to census data. In Brooklyn during the same period, the jump was a whopping 87 percent.

title: What Could I Get for my House? Please, Dont Ask
description: It can be so much fun to play the Whats my home worth? game, either with your friends and family or inside your own head.

description: News Corporation, the global media conglomerate controlled by Rupert Murdoch, is withdrawing its bid to purchase Newsday.

description: New Canaan

title: Dying of Cancer, but Full of Life Lessons
description: Pittsburgh wide receiver Hines Ward arrived for this months Steelers minicamp with two books tucked in his duffel bag: the teams playbook and a copy of The Last Lecture, co-written by Randy Pausch, who left his job as a computer science professor at Carnegie Mellon University last September.

title: The Second Plane
description: To the Editor:

title: Party Like Its 2008
description: ANOTHER weekly do-or-die primary battle, another round of wildly predicted game changers that collapsed in the locker room.

title: These Daredevils Dont Dust the Crops. They Plant Them.
description: OLIVEHURST, Calif.  As rice farmers in Northern California plant their flooded fields over the next couple of weeks, most will not head for a tractor or a tiller or any kind of seeder.

title: Do You Have That Portable in a Midsize?
description: THIRTY-SIX years ago, Alan Kay, a computer scientist, published a rough sketch of his Dynabook portable computer, establishing the ideal of ever more intimate personal computers.

title: Memoirs of a Girl From the East Country (O.K., Queens)
description: IT is one of the most evocative images of Greenwich Village in the 1960s. An attractive young couple are walking down the middle of a snow-covered street. His head is down and tilted toward her. Hes wearing an artfully half-buttoned brown suede jacket, but his hands are stuffed in his jeans pockets against the cold. She is smiling, huddling against him. Shot in February 1963, the photo would come to epitomize the romantic youth culture of the time  its freedom and fragility, its rootlessness and sense of purpose.

description: Preface

description: Caroline Mary Simko was married on Saturday to Hans Francis Olsen. The Rev. George M. Witt, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Kim Stays Focused, or at Least Hes Trying
description: Hours before the final round of this years Masters, Anthony Kim was sitting in a Dallas hospital room next to his girlfriend, who was seriously injured when she stepped on a beer mug at his home.

description: Film

title: When Modifying Vehicles, Upgrade the Insurance
description: NO matter what improvements youve made to your car  fancy wheels, neon glow, or a more powerful engine  one component is almost certain to lag in performance: your insurance policy.

title: Letters: Remembering Ansel Adams
description: To the Editor: I read with delight your story about Ansel Adams and Yosemite National Park (What Adams Saw Through His Lens, April 27). I was privileged to work with Mr. Adams in the summer of 1982 as a professional environmentalist to assist him in protecting Big Sur, in California, from development.

title: Ohio State Tops Cornell for Its First N.C.A.A. Victory
description: ITHACA, N.Y.  Anticipating a rematch with No. 1-ranked Duke, Cornell might have overlooked Ohio State.

title: For Griffey, the Roads Not Taken
description: Any day now, perhaps this weekend at Shea Stadium, Ken Griffey Jr. will hit his 600th major league home run. It will have been a long time in coming. Griffey, when he was traded to the Cincinnati Reds in February 2000, had hit 398 homers, to that point the largest total ever for a player yet to reach his 30th birthday. (Alex Rodriguez has since broken his record.)

title: A Buyers Guide to Inventions, in Plain English
description: INVENTORS and companies like to court each other. Inventors need companies to move their ideas forward, and companies need inventions to help their businesses grow. But suitors sometimes have trouble finding that perfect partner. Now a Web-based service under development, the USA National Innovation Marketplace, offers a new tool intended to help with the matchmaking.

title: A Welcome Into Artists Creative Spaces
description: The Studio: An Alternative Space for Contemporary Art, in Armonk, closed its gallery last November, but the 10-year-old nonprofit group is still living up to its name by providing opportunities to view contemporary art.

title: Mrs. Corbetts Request
description: Chapter 2: Roger Corbetts Last Misstep

title: Baseball Legends, and a Beloved Song
description: Anatomy of Baseball is no medical book  if it was, Im certain I wouldnt have read it, Yogi Berra writes in the foreword.

title: Bring Us Apart
description: Rick Perlsteins sprawling, rollicking book arrives hard on the heels of a contest of empathy-exhibitionism in which the two Democratic presidential candidates competed to see who could more ardently adore churchgoing, gun-owning, not-at-all-bitter working-class Pennsylvanians. Perlsteins readers will learn why this happened. He shrewdly quotes a commentators assessment of Richard Nixons 1952 Checkers speech with its maudlin reference to his wifes Republican cloth coat: Dick Nixon has suddenly placed the burden of old-style Republican aloofness on the Democrats.

title: As Foreclosures Rise, Towns Take on Storage Role
description: NEWINGTON

title: Laura Campbell and Abe Shahim
description: Laura Catherine Campbell, the daughter of Leslie Campbell of Arnold, Md., and Michael Campbell of Potomac, Md., was married on Saturday to Dr. Abe Shahim, the son of Shahla Shahim and Dr. Houshang Shahim of White Plains. Debby Altomonte, a Spiritual Science minister, officiated at the Oaks, an inn in Royal Oak, Md., and Payman Amiri led them in a Persian cultural ceremony.

title: Mermaid Actor Breaks Wrists in Fall From High Over Stage
description: An actor in the Broadway show The Little Mermaid fell through a trap door on the deck of a suspended boat and onto the stage just before the start of the Saturday matinee performance, a spokesman for the production company said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with an article last Sunday about the eroding boundary between Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway productions misidentified the actress pictured with Tobias Segal and Julie White in From Up Here. She is Aya Cash, who portrays the sister of Mr. Segals character, not Jenni Barber, who portrays his student mentor.

title: Militants Kill Israeli; Israelis Kill 5 Hamas Policemen
description: JERUSALEM  Five Hamas police officers were killed in Israeli airstrikes on two police posts in southern Gaza late Friday night, Palestinian officials said Saturday. The strikes occurred hours after an Israeli civilian was killed by a mortar round fired into Israel by militants from Gaza.

title: Youth Lacrosse Program Places Premium on Sportsmanship
description: FRENCHTOWN

title: In Mali, S.U.V.'s and Camels Deliver the Fans
description: The Festival au Desert, held each January in the remote African city of Essakane, Mali, is a time-shifting experience. This year, as it began to come to life, Tuareg men in billowing clothes and brightly colored turbans ducked in and out of leather and canvas tents. Camels strolled into camp by the hundreds and folded their ungainly legs as vendors prepared their wares for an invasion of foreign travelers.

title: A Cruise for Jazz Fans With a Soft Side
description: Smooth-jazz enthusiasts who like cruises might want to check out Bob Jamiesons Smooth Music Cruise series (www.smoothmusiccruise.com). Mr. Jamieson, a former music executive (Sony, CBS, BMG) has assembled a collection of Grammy-, Tony- and Emmy Award-winning musicians to perform night and day on a Caribbean cruise aboard the 1,778-passenger Century, a Celebrity Cruises ship.

title: Losing a Home, Then Losing All Out of Storage
description: ELK GROVE VILLAGE, Ill.  The foreclosure crisis is hitting yet another American locale: the self-storage center.

title: Because Its Good for You
description: While a book can lead us to love reading  the one that did it for me was Little Runner of the Longhouse, written by Betty Baker and illustrated by Arnold Lobel  can it do so on purpose? Tyrone Brown, professional student and class clown, likes a lot about school: math, science, recess. But reading bugs him: Its not that I despise books; I just dont prefer them. I like playing freeze tag with my friends and catch with my dad and helping my mom pull the pesky weeds from the front yard. These things are real.

title: Worth the Climb
description: LIVING in a top-floor walk-up in New York City is a mixed blessing.

title: With Ryan Church
description: The last five months have turned Ryan Churchs life upside down. Church joined the Mets in a November trade with the Washington Nationals. He sustained a concussion in spring training and, two weeks later, became a father for the first time. His wife, Tina, gave birth to their son, Mason Alexander, on March 14. Church, a 29-year-old outfielder, entered Saturday hitting a team-best .328 with 6 homers, 24 runs batted in and 4 outfield assists.

title: Styrons Choices
description: There used to be a time when writers, purely on the basis of the books they had published, were invited to eat dinner with presidents. By his own estimation, the novelist William Styron, who died in 2006, was one of the last of his kind to enjoy an honor more likely, since John F. Kennedy at least, to be bestowed upon rock stars, stand-up comedians and golf champions. Havanas in Camelot, his charming collection of essays, recounts two such dinners, one with Kennedy, whose fondness for cigars both impressed and intimidated the cigarette-addicted Styron, and the other with Franois Mitterand, after which Styron, Arthur Miller, Carlos Fuentes, Elie Wiesel and the Greek politician Andreas Papandreou had to be rescued from an exuberant crowd of Mitterands admirers by a resplendent Melina Mercouri: A heady and thrilling moment indeed, even when  as Fuentes pointed out  the crowd surely thought that the five gentlemen in their raincoats were Mercouris bodyguards.

title: Selling Isnt Poetry
description: THERE was one last full-floor condominium lingering on the market in a meticulously restored and expensive prewar Park Avenue building at East 75th Street. So Elliott P. Joseph, the projects developer, jumped on what he thought was the perfect sales sweetener: two free Lexus hybrids with the purchase.

title: 32 Gas Stations in Report Show Spillage Signs
description: An article on April 27 about the presence of methyl tertiary butyl ether, or M.T.B.E., in soil beneath some gas stations on Long Island misidentified the agency whose study reported the contamination. It was the New York State Department of Conservation, not the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority.

title: The Uneven Playing Field
description: BY THE TIME JANELLE PIERSON SPRINTED ONTO THE FIELD for the start of the Florida high-school soccer playoffs in January, she had competed in hundreds of games since joining her first team at 5. She played soccer year-round  often for two teams at a time when the seasons of her school and club teams overlapped. Like many American children deeply involved in sports, Janelle, a high-school senior, had traveled like a professional athlete since her early teens, routinely flying to out-of-state tournaments. She had given up other sports long ago, quitting basketball and tennis by age 10. There was no time for any of that, and as she put it: Even if you wanted to keep playing other sports, people would question you. Theyd be, like, Why do you want to do that?

title: Corrections
description: METRO

title: Sheila Miller, John Rivera-Dirks
description: Sheila Kathleen Miller and John Thomas Rivera-Dirks were married on Saturday at the Holy Trinity Methodist Church in Old San Juan, P.R. The Rev. Carmelo Tosado Moya, a minister of the Methodist Church of Puerto Rico, officiated, and the Rev. Jimmy Casellas, a Roman Catholic friar, participated in the ceremony.

title: Steeped in History, With a Feel of the Brand New
description: JONNY SNEMYR understands perhaps better than anyone how much Rossville, Staten Island, has changed. He is both a resident and a contractor.

title: Dance
description: California

title: Amy Flynn, Jeffrey Posternak
description: Amy Elizabeth Flynn and Jeffrey Maxwell Posternak were married on Saturday evening at Woodend Sanctuary, an estate in Chevy Chase, Md. Rabbi Arthur C. Blecher officiated.

title: That Must Be Bob. I Hear His New Hip Squeaking.
description: The first time John L. Johnsons artificial hip squeaked, he was bending down to pick up a pine cone in his yard in Thomasville, Ga. Mr. Johnson looked up, expecting to find an animal nearby.

title: Letters: Triple-A Failure
description: Congratulations to Roger Lowenstein (April 27) for writing what is perhaps the definitive explanation of the underlying mechanics of the credit-rating agencies as they relate to the causes of the mortgage meltdown. This opens the door to regular folks understanding this mess, and perhaps now we can put pressure on Congress to act forcefully to make necessary regulatory changes.

title: But the Songs Remain the Same
description: DO you play piano? My mothers question is timed with the precision of a Swiss watch  always after I have slipped out of the left sleeve of my coat, but not quite before breaking free of the right one.

title: Zoe Segal-Reichlin and Daniel Garodnick
description: Zoe L. Segal-Reichlin, a lawyer, and Daniel R. Garodnick, a New York City councilman, were married Saturday afternoon in Westhampton Beach, N.Y. Judge Colleen McMahon of the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York, officiated at the Atlantica, a catering business at the Westhampton Bath and Tennis Hotel and Marina.

title: The Dollar: Shrinkable but (So Far) Unsinkable
description: If the United States were any other country, these would surely be days of panic and austerity in Washington. With debts spiraling higher, a trade deficit exceeding $700 billion a year, and its currency plunging for years, the government would be forced to cut spending and jack up interest rates in a frantic bid to attract investment.

title: Racing Industry Is Stuck in Perpetual Post Time
description: Thoroughbred racing has been too slow to change.

title: Gut-Wrenching
description: 1. Symptoms

title: Letters: Young Gay Rites
description: It strikes me that one of the obvious reasons straight people in their 20s get married is because thats when you pretty much need to start having kids. Gay people are spared that necessity: we get to choose so very much more from the smorgasbord. The chirpy, bright tone of nearly all the 20-somethings, married or affianced, in your article (April 27) was a little scary to me: they sound supercharged  either on too much Starbucks coffee or on some notion that true love is something you can trap forever in a legislative cage of marriage. I kept wanting them to take long, long breaths and not feel they had to be couples in some institutionalized way so very, very quickly.

title: How I Met My Mother
description: For much of our life together, my mother and I hated each other. The way I saw it, I spent most of my childhood fighting with her  or trying to get away from her bitterness, her unhappiness and her endless smoking. As a teenager, I learned how to defend myself with words that were designed to hurt and could never be taken back. In return, she vowed that one day I would have a daughter who would feel the way about me that I felt about her.

title: Grueling Series Put the Stars on Their Heels
description: The Dallas Stars path toward the Stanley Cup has wound through the toughest teams in the league, and it may be taking its toll.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: FILM

title: Stephanie Cuomo, Aaron Dillon
description: Stephanie Cuomo, the daughter of Lena Cuomo and Gary P. Cuomo of Farmingdale, N.Y., was married on Saturday evening to Aaron George Dillon, the son of Kathryn Dillon and Robert G. Dillon of Hawthorne Woods, Ill. The Rev. Bojan Jancic, a pastor of Revival Ministries International, officiated in a nondenominational service at the Bourne Mansion in Oakdale, N.Y.

title: Creation of a Bygone Era, Soon to Be Demolished
description: The ramshackle wooden tower has loomed over Avenue B for more than 20 years, drawing curiosity and a range of reviews from tourists and neighbors. Some have declared the colorful structure a masterpiece, and have admired the effort that went into assembling it. Others have complained that it takes up valuable space or just looks weird.

title: Rulers Keep Grip on Aid as Burmese Cast Votes
description: This article is by a reporter for The New York Times in Myanmar and Seth Mydans in Bangkok.

title: Can the Sponsor Vote for His Ex-Wife?
description: Q The ex-wife of the sponsor of our Queens co-op recently purchased an apartment in our building and wants to serve on the board. The sponsor is no longer eligible to designate a board member.

title: As Gazprom Goes, So Goes Russia
description: Moscow

title: Matching Newcomer to College, While Both Pay
description: ATHENS, Ohio  When Xiaoxi Li, a 20-year-old from Beijing, decided she should go to college in the United States, she applied only to Ohio University  not that she knew much about it.

title: Leisures Starring Role in a Complete Life
description: LEISURE is not a topic that typically emerges as a workplace concern. But in fact it has a direct effect on how we handle and view our working life, according to Alison Link, who has done research on leisure issues and is a consultant for individuals and organizations through her firm, the Leisure Link (www.theleisurelinkconsulting.com).

title: As Bush Term Wanes, Mideast Peace Appears as Elusive as Ever
description: WASHINGTON  The 2008 race for the White House is casting a long shadow over President Bush. So long, in fact, that it may extend all the way to the Middle East.

title: Spring in a Cold Climate
description: THE only way to know when the residential real estate market has hit bottom will be with a look in the rear-view mirror, according to Jeffrey G. Otteau, the New Jersey-based real estate analyst.

title: Cracking the Comics Code
description: Tricking children into reading has a long and mostly honorable history. Key to the con are coupling pictures, which are fascinating and adorable, with letters and words, which are alphanumeric. This duplicity dates back at least to the 17th century and Comenius Orbis Sensualium Pictus, a primer with woodcuts designed to hoodwink the young into thinking Latin was going to be a treat. Advances in technology and desperation have added color to the ruse, along with pop-ups and pull-tabs, scent strips, sound chips and touch-and-feelies, none of which approach the sensual pleasures of Lego Star Wars or Guitar Hero III: Legends of Rock.

title: Special Effects From the Real World
description: IN this era of digital special effects, weve become accustomed to the idea that by manipulating pixels on a computer screen, filmmakers can show us practically anything in a more or less convincing manner.

title: George Lois: Ignoring the Photographer
description: To the Editor:

title: Stockholm Is More Than Abba's Town
description: STARING out at the azure waters of Saltsjon Bay from a hilltop in the Sodermalm district of Stockholmisland, I stopped for a moment to take in the last glints of a long, Nordic sunset. Behind me, the neighborhoods clubs and concert venues were starting to get busy. Behind the sound of crowds and shouted hellos came a line of familiar music, filling the crisp air: Dont come back to Stockholm.

title: Nuala OFaolain, 68, Irish Memoirist, Is Dead
description: Nuala OFaolain, an Irish journalist who mined a rich vein of longing and childhood suffering in two midlife memoirs and an acclaimed first novel, My Dream of You, died on Friday night in Dublin. She was 68 and lived in Barrtra, County Clare, Ireland, and Manhattan.

title: Stylish School Expansion
description: WITH its ornate moldings and mahogany paneling, and its links to New Yorks high society and old money, the brick and limestone mansion at 17 East 90th Street near Fifth Avenue seemed a perfect refuge for another wealthy family in the heart of the city.

title: Scrubs Near the D Train
description: THE first e-mail message that David Gregorius sent to friends describing his new job in New York did not sound promising.

title: This Is Your Brain on Evolution
description: To the Editor:

title: Arriving in London: Hotels Made in China
description: TRAVELODGE, one of the largest budget hotel chains in Britain, is a company in a hurry.

title: How to Tell if a Rally Is Real
description: IN fits and starts, blue-chip stocks have been climbing higher since mid-March. But many market watchers arent convinced that the worst of this market storm, which began in October, is behind us.

title: Big Rescues Can Work. Just Ask New York.
description: AS the great American credit crash continues to reverberate, we still have nothing that resembles an intelligent and comprehensive plan for dealing with mass foreclosures and the economic consequences associated with the debacle.

title: Upside of Being Knocked Around
description: WASHINGTON  So, now that it might finally be over (or maybe close to it, possibly, perhaps), does Senator Barack Obama come out a bloody mess, or a battle-tested warrior?

title: How to Deal With Midlife: Keep Dancing
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Bodies Flow Into Hard-Hit Area of Myanmar
description: THANAP PIN SATE, Myanmar  The bodies come and go with the tides. They wash up onto the riverbanks or float grotesquely downstream, almost always face down. They are all but ignored by the living.

title: Voices in Concert
description: EXCEPT for five years when I lived in Arizona, from ages 9 to 14, I grew up in Los Angeles. My family lived in a small apartment off Wilshire Boulevard and I went to Beverly Hills High School. There were a lot of children of famous people. Rob Reiner was in the class behind me. Albert Brooks played on the football team with me.

title: Official Chosen by McCain to Run Convention Resigns
description: The public relations executive whom Senator John McCains campaign had chosen to run the Republican National Convention this summer resigned his post on Saturday after a magazine reported that his firm had lobbied for the military junta that runs Myanmar.

title: Maria Bucceri, Jonathan Kirsch
description: Maria Teresa Bucceri and Jonathan Bradford Kirsch were married on Saturday evening at the Yale Club in New York. Rabbi Michael L. Ehrlich officiated.

title: Women in Film: Its Not Bias, Its Logic
description: To the Editor:

title: Gen. Vang Paos Last War
description: The wars of the 20th century destroyed many millions of people who once lived in the hillsides and valleys of remote rural worlds. Few were hit as hard as the Hmong, an ancient tribe whose members hewed out rough lives upcountry in Laos, west of Vietnam. Half a century ago, Laos became a cockpit of the cold war. The Hmong, led by a charismatic soldier named Vang Pao, sided with the United States in the fight against Communism in Southeast Asia. They lost everything  their land, their way of life, their country.

title: Their Place in the Sun, and on the Court
description: Uncasville

title: Not Exactly the Wild West
description: THE Landmarks Preservation Commission is reviewing a proposal from the local chapter of the Victorian Society in America to include the west side of West Broadway in the SoHo-Cast Iron Historic District, and it would seem that the east side of that avenue  protected by the designation since 1973  would provide an instructive architectural contrast.

title: Alexandra Snyder, Elliot Charen
description: Alexandra Elizabeth Snyder and Dr. Elliot Michael Charen were married on Saturday evening at the Cosmopolitan Club in New York. Rabbi Amy B. Ehrlich officiated.

title: A 16-Year Tour Veteran Takes an Unlikely Lead
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  The Players Championship demolition derby continued Saturday at T.P.C. Sawgrass, with the contestants in the $9.5 million tournament spinning out, hitting spectators and marshals with tee shots, running into railroad ties, and littering the landscape with bogeys, double bogeys and other unmentionables.

title: Danna Drori, Benjamin Strauss
description: Danna Drori and Benjamin Henry Strauss are to be married on Sunday afternoon at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Cantor Angela Warnick Buchdahl is to officiate.

title: Circle of Solace for Those Without Parents
description: IRVINGTON, N.Y.

title: Like Rainfall, Restored Map Trickles Home
description: Seventy years after it was booted out of the Worlds Fair and 60 years after it was last seen by the public, a gorgeously sculptural relief map of the New York City watershed has finally reached its intended destination: the New York City Building, now the Queens Museum of Art, in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

title: Ready for Its Hollywood Close-Up
description: IF Smart USA, distributor of the Smart microcar, could get every person who shouted, whooped, ran into the street, stopped traffic and corralled me for a chat to actually buy a Fortwo like the one I drove around Los Angeles, Daimlers factory in France would have to run 24/7.

title: Foreign Exchanges
description: In responding to readers questions, I often discuss why a proposed act is wrong. But it is also incumbent on me to suggest more ethical alternatives. Below, I revisit a few recent answers in which I failed to propose a better course of action when one was available  as many of you pointed out, and quite rightly.

title: Vendlers Yeats
description: The critic is the only artist who depends entirely upon another art form, which means that part of his job is to determine the nature of that relationship. Should he be an advocate? A policeman? A curator? A hanging judge? A mostly loyal but occasionally snippy personal assistant? The decision is an unconscious one, perhaps, but once its made, the critics writing will be colored by his chosen role in the same way that our voices carry the accents of our birthplaces.

title: Killing Deer in New Jersey
description: To the Editor:

title: Straightening Out the Northeast Corridor
description: FOR many train riders, the concrete ties that keep the rails in place are about as noteworthy as the electrical power lines above the train.

title: Letters: Questions for Ted Sorensen
description: Journalism at its best: Deborah Solomons interview of Ted Sorensen covers so much in one page (April 27). His 11 years with J.F.K; his forthcoming memoir; the so-called poet of Camelot asking not about ask not; the Cuban missile crisis versus World War I; Bill-Hillary and Barack; Teds unsuccessful run for the U.S. Senate; his religion and his own obit (many years in the future, one hopes).

title: Can a Bargain Rent Have Staying Power?
description: FOR landlords and some tenants in rent-stabilized buildings, few issues are more important than preferential rent  rent that is lower than the legal regulated rent registered with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.

title: Alison Franklin, Shane Milam
description: Alison Beth Franklin and Shane McGuire Milam, lawyers, were married on Saturday evening in Columbia, Mo. Michael Heath, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Firestone Baars Chapel at Stephens College.

title: A Deadly Day on the Top of the World
description: STORIES of the catastrophic ascent of Mount Everest on May 10, 1996, which claimed the lives of five climbers, including two top guides, began circulating even before some of those caught on the mountain had returned home.

title: A Career Born of Babies
description: EAST NORTHPORT

title: Partners, in Pursuit of a Marriage License
description: East Hills

title: Sadrists and Iraqi Government Reach Truce Deal
description: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi government and leaders of the movement of the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr agreed Saturday to a truce, brokered with help from Iran, that would end more than a month of bloody fighting in the vast, crowded Sadr City section of Baghdad.

title: Shakespeare in England, in Luxury
description: Heres a luxurious  and cultured  outing if you happen to be in England on July 9. Board one of two Orient-Express Trains  the British Pullman in London or the Northern Belle in Birmingham, Coventry or Milton Keynes  start the voyage off with a Bellini, and then watch the countryside roll by while having brunch.

title: Taking a Chance on a Second Child
description: HARRISON

title: Correction: What Adams Saw Through His Lens
description: An article and a map on April 27 about Ansel Adamss photographs of Yosemite National Park gave an incorrect location of Wawona Tunnel. It is on the western end of Yosemite Valley, in the southern section of the park, not on the parks southern edge.

title: If N.F.L. Doesnt Call, the Army Will
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  No matter how he performed at the Giants rookie camp this weekend, Owen Tolson will be issued a uniform. His name will be stitched on it, and he will be assigned a number.

title: To Smell the Roses, Take the Bus
description: A REGULAR visitor who drove on May 1 to Wave Hill, the pristine, 28-acre public garden in Riverdale, to spend a few hours sitting on a bench and admiring the vivid tulips and the majestic copper beech tree, would have been in for a surprise.

title: All in Favor, Say Word
description: IN 1976, a 16-year-old boy from Washington Heights heard a radio announcement from Percy Sutton, then Manhattan borough president, urging that people of all ages be represented on the citys community boards. When the boys mother, a City Council member who represented the neighborhood, heard of her sons plan to answer the call, she told him, No way, setting the stage for a simultaneous act of civic precociousness and teenage rebellion.

title: Rough Justice
description: You can usually count on three things in a Louise Erdrich novel. One: the tale will be told by many characters, each with his or her own chapter or three. Erdrich established this pass-the-talking-stick style in early novels like Love Medicine and The Beet Queen. Its served her well, and shes staying with it. Two: although these narrators differ in age, perspective, gender and disposition, they will share an uncannily similar voice, hushed and deeply observant. Erdrichs characters have rich inner lives, expressed in language thats often achingly poetic but can sometimes resemble a John Mayer lyric. (I was everything the mountain knew.) This is Erdrich, take her or leave her. Third: there will be Indians, there will be white folks, and there will be tension between the two.

title: Jill Furman and Richard Willis
description: JILL FURMAN, a producer of the Broadway musical In the Heights, believes in big dreams and bright lights. So when it came to love she refused to settle for less.

title: A Farmhouse Near the L Train
description: KERMIT WESTERGAARD grew up on the Upper East Side, far from hammers and paintbrushes. Yet early on, he was seized by the idea of renovating a historic house for himself. Last year, he got the chance when he and his wife, Azadeh, bought a 1908 row house in Ridgewood, Queens, for $592,000, and turned it into their comfortable fantasy of a simple upstate farmhouse.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: Inside the List
description: GOODBYE, HARRY: It had to happen sometime - and, lo, an era has ended. After a 10-year run, and less than a year after the seventh and final book in J. K. Rowlings series was published, the Harry Potter books have fallen off The Timess best-seller list.

title: The Fog of Love
description: We think we know the ones we love, and though we should not be surprised to find that we dont, it is heartbreak nonetheless. It is the hardest kind of knowledge, not only about another but about ourselves. To see our lives as fiction we have written and believed. So observes plain, devoted, innocent Pearlie Cook, the narrator of Andrew Sean Greers wondrously unsettling new novel and the wife of Holland Cook, a man whose physical beauty creates a force field of strong passions all around him.

title: Something Wild
description: Its funny when, as a relatively well-adjusted woman in your 40s, you read two fine novels about intelligent girls who are curious and daring and good-hearted. There is a wrench in your belly  of recognition, or nostalgia. Its appreciation for careful attention paid to a short, mostly underrated phase in the life of women. Suddenly the body armor youve built and polished feels leaden and even cowardly. What seem bold are the characters of Jacqueline Woodson and Pat Murphy, who in their new novels render the knotty friendships of girls with gravity, whimsy, intimacy and melodrama.

title: Woman Charged in Fatal Stabbing of Companion
description: A Queens woman was arrested and charged with murder on Saturday after the police said she stabbed her live-in companion to death with a steak knife at their home near Rockaway Beach.

title: In a Fantasy Realm With Joys and Disappointments
description: If, as one of Spains classic plays declares, life is a dream, lovers and emigrants must be particularly alive. Being in love is as close as we come to the dream state while awake; and who would ever leave the comfort, or even the discomfort, of home without the insistent prodding of a dream?

title: Parking Space as Living Space?
description: GENERATING both praise and criticism in a county with plenty of expensive housing but not much of the budget-friendly kind, a Department of Planning report urges towns and villages here to use land in existing office parks as sites for new housing, some of it for moderate-income families.

title: Letters: Drawing Lessons
description: Until we can agree on standard and objective criteria of what arts in education is, we will never have proof that the arts can build better learners (Ann Hulbert, April 27). Thats a pity. Art education must be described and approached as a discipline like all others.

title: Belt-Tightening Can Bring Change, or More Misery
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Turkish Traffic Stopper
description: Tava in Port Washington is a traffic-stopper. The Turkish restaurants snappy red awning stands out against its coal-black walls. Theres even a tree out front wrapped in strings of red mini-lights.

title: Downtown-Uptown Girl
description: BEFORE heading out of the four-story West Village town house she shares with her husband, the musician Billy Joel, Katie Lee Joel bade goodbye to her makeup artist and one of her two pugs. Be a good watchdog, she called to the dog, which was slumbering on a silk-covered armchair in the lavish living room.

title: A Fixed-Fee Refinancing
description: FOR many borrowers, adjustable-rate mortgages, or ARMs, are too risky, even though the interest on such loans is usually fixed for 5 or 7 years at a rate lower than that offered on 30-year fixed mortgages.

title: Rockin the Casbah
description: FROM his perch on a rooftop terrace near the crenelated western ramparts of the walled city, a visitor from England watched the sun set in spectacular display over the Atlantic Ocean. As it disappeared on the cloudless horizon, the suns rays cast a golden glow on a rising crescent moon decorated on the eve of the summer solstice by a silvery alignment of planets and stars.

title: You Cant Make This Stuff Up, or Can You?
description: FOR a long time, I spent my days as an independent producer by morning, a law professor by afternoon and a dog fancier by night. I would hatch ideas for television shows and movies, take them to studios and pitch them and, once in a while, some kindly soul would buy one and, even more rarely, one would be made.

title: Good Times at Sothebys
description: As the housing market continues to implode, financial markets go haywire and recession looms, there is nothing like an art sale in New York to reassure everyone that it is still fun to be rich.

title: Say Good Night, Ducks
description: SOUTHAMPTON

title: State Agrees on Protocol for Governor and Father
description: ALBANY  The state Ethics Commission has advised Basil A. Paterson, a labor lawyer and the father of the governor, to avoid conflicts of interest by not arranging meetings between his clients and his son or accepting business with the state.

title: After Hard Pasts, a Sanctuary by the Sea
description: BRIGHTON BEACH conjures plastic swans, women in tight pants, men in small bathing suits, and deep-fried dough with surprise morsels inside. The neighborhood is defined by contradictions: deep shadows and bright light.

title: Peace
description: They went on anyway, putting one foot in front of the other, holding their carbines barrel down to keep the water out, trying, in their misery and confusion  and their exhaustion  to remain watchful. This was the fourth straight day of rain  a windless, freezing downpour without any slight variation of itself. Rivulets of ice formed in the muck of the road and made the walking treacherous. The muscles of their legs burned and shuddered, and none of them could get enough air. Robert Marson thought about how they were all witnesses. And nobody could look anybody in the eye. They kept on, and were punished as they went. Ice glazed their helmets, stuck to the collars of their field jackets, and the rain got in everywhere, soaking them to the bone. They were somewhere near Cassino, but it was hard to believe it was even Italy anymore. They had stumbled blind into some province of drenching cold, a berg of death. Everything was in question now.

description: Doris Lessing, the 2007 Nobel prize winner in literature, told the BBC that receiving the prize was a bloody disaster that brought so much attention from the news media that writing a full-length novel was next to impossible. All I do is give interviews and spend time being photographed, Ms. Lessing, 88, complained in a radio broadcast on Sunday. Discussing her writing, she said: It has stopped; I dont have any energy anymore. This is why I keep telling anyone younger than me, dont imagine youll have it forever. Use it while youve got it, because itll go; its sliding away like water down a plug hole.

title: Theres a New Thane in Town, a New Lady, Too
description: The director Adrian Nobles bleak and boldly updated production of Verdis Macbeth made a strong impression when it was unveiled at the Metropolitan Opera in October. The production returned to the Met on Friday night with new singers in the four main roles, and as often happens, the mood and impact of the overall staging seemed to change.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the conviction of a drifter on charges of stalking the actress Uma Thurman misspelled the given name of her spokesman in some editions. He is Beau Benton, not Bo.

title: The Jewish State at 60
description: This week marks the 60th anniversary of the founding of the state of Israel. There have already been many birthday greetings, some heartfelt, some perfunctory, along with numerous reflections on the meaning of the occasion, some profound, some commonplace. For me, however, a discordant voice broke through.

title: As Rivals Rest on Mothers Day, Clinton Pushes On
description: GRAFTON, W.Va.  On Mothers Day, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was not served breakfast in bed. She did not go to a fancy lunch, or get to be queen for a day.

title: Venezuelas President Scorned by Bitter Political Foe: His Ex-Wife
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chvez is faced with problems like rising inflation, a diplomatic crisis with neighboring Colombia and defections of officials from his Socialist Party to the political opposition.

title: Ecuador Opposes Outpost in American War on Drugs
description: MANTA, Ecuador  The scene at the Manta Ray Cafe, a mess hall here at the most prominent American military outpost in South America, suggests all is normal.

title: The United States Open Changes Its Cable Home
description: ESPN and the Tennis Channel will start televising the United States Open starting next year through 2014, ending the USA Networks reign as the Opens exclusive cable TV home.

title: Pro Surfers Death Exposes Beach Towns Violent Side
description: SAN DIEGO  The affluent community of La Jolla has long produced beach cliques, most formed around the inclination of surfers and other beachgoers to guard their local break.

title: That Pundit on Fox News? An Upstart Named Rove
description: WASHINGTON  Late Thursday night, Karl Rove, the architect of the last two Republican presidential victories, was on his new television perch at Fox News, offering free advice to Senator Barack Obama as he closed in on the Democratic nomination.

title: Downsizing a Larger-Than-Life Warlord
description: This may seem counterintuitive, but a surefire way to guarantee yourself a portrayal in the modern Western operatic canon is to become a brutal Chinese despot. John Adams turned Mao Zedong into a philosopher king in Nixon in China (1987), and Mao turned up again (though seen more critically) in Bright Shengs Madame Mao (2003). More recently Tan Dun used a Metropolitan Opera commission to resurrect Qin Shi Huang, the emperor who unified China through conquest and the suppression of regional cultures and ruled in the third century B.C.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the Chicago Symphony Orchestras hiring of Riccardo Muti as its music director referred imprecisely to a role with the New York Philharmonic that Mr. Muti agreed to take last year. It is equivalent to principal guest conductor but does not carry that title.

title: After a Quixotic Attack in Sudan, a Question Lingers: Why?
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The day after the Sudanese government quickly dispensed with an attack by Darfurian rebels on the capital, Khartoum, the question that many people are asking is, What were the rebels thinking?

title: A Horse Trainers Rough Ride
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Big Brown is perfect. The colts trainer, Rick Dutrow, admittedly is not. He once was a drug-addled horseman who was ruled off New York racetracks for five years. Since returning, he has earned a rogue reputation for being suspended for everything from medication violations to making up a workout for one of his better horses.

title: Joseph Egan, Lawyer Who Fought Nuclear Waste Site, Is Dead at 53
description: WASHINGTON  Joseph R. Egan, a nuclear engineer-turned-lawyer who led Nevadas legal campaign to block a nuclear waste dump at Yucca Mountain, died Wednesday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 53.

title: A Lesson for a Price That Cannot Be Beat
description: Whether you know it or not, you probably need a golf lesson. People will go to a driving range 10 times during a season and fork over $100 for range balls.

title: Garca Clears Water and Ends a Drought
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  In world-class tournament golf, as in almost every athletic competition at the highest level, superior talent usually prevails. It did again Sunday at The Players Championship, when Sergio Garca shot a final-round one-under-par 71 to chase down Paul Goydos and win the first sudden-death playoff in 21 years at the T.P.C. Sawgrass.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a new generation of developers leaving their mark on Las Vegas misidentified the university at which Lorenzo Fertitta, a son of the founder of Station Casinos, befriended Thomas C. Breitling, part of a group that bought and later sold the Golden Nugget. It was at the University of San Diego, not the University of Southern California.

title: Idealism and Bawdiness Under Many Guises
description: Between songs at Radio City Music Hall on Friday night Erykah Badu leaned over a computer and some electronic equipment to set off burbling, swooping noises straight out of sci-fi B movies, as if she were tuning in the concert from another dimension. Maybe she was.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on May 1 about Yossi Harel, captain of the Jewish refugee ship Exodus 1947 that was turned back as it tried to cross the British blockade to deliver Jews to Palestine, included an incorrect figure from a speech in which Mr. Harel estimated the number of Jewish combatants in Israels 1948 war of independence. The number is variously estimated at 40,000 to 100,000  not the 600,000 Mr. Harel cited. (That was believed to be the total Jewish population in Palestine at the time.)

title: Serious-Minded Golfers Tackle a Whimsical Game
description: Peter Gilchrist is a favorite to win this years United States Open. He practices his golf game daily, tours the country to play in tournaments and has pocketed his share of prize money. He is the patriarch of a family that includes four national golf champions.

title: Production of a Movie Stops Over Funds to Pay Its Stars
description: LOS ANGELES  The Screen Actors Guild on Friday pulled its members, including the stars Jake Gyllenhaal and Jessica Biel, from a movie being directed by David O. Russell after producers of the film failed to keep sufficient funds to pay actors in a union-mandated account.

title: The Oil Nonbubble
description: The Oil Bubble: Set to Burst? That was the headline of an October 2004 article in National Review, which argued that oil prices, then $50 a barrel, would soon collapse.

title: Can Corzine Still Pass as a Liberal? He Thinks So
description: TRENTON  You never know which Gov. Jon S. Corzine is going to show up at the State House these days.

title: GodTube, Where Networking Is More Spiritual Than Social
description: GodTube.com, a YouTube knockoff for the evangelical set, seems to be one step closer to building a kingdom on earth.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column on Thursday about a film contest to promote Microsofts Vista operating system misstated the distance between Hollywood and Microsofts headquarters in Redmond, Wash. It is more than a thousand miles, not several hundred miles.

title: In Sadr City, a Cease-Fire Is Put to the Test, and Fails
description: BAGHDAD  A column of Iraqi armor set out on Sunday to test a new truce in the Sadr City area of Baghdad between the militias and the Iraqi government by venturing north on a major thoroughfare that borders the Shiite enclave.

title: City Ballets Itinerary: Robbins and Beyond
description: Those who assemble programs at New York City Ballet have much to learn, but will they learn? The two new ones that the company presented on Friday (Russian Roots, a quadruple bill) and Saturday afternoon (World Tour, quintuple) were built with quite different objectives, but neither satisfies as a whole.

title: Citis New Slogan Is Said to Be Second Choice
description: Perhaps the next Citigroup tagline should be Lets Get It Right.

title: One More on the Road
description: Most states do not just outlaw driving while drunk, but also drinking while driving. Not Connecticut.

title: Rainout Spoils Chance for Jeter to Bat Fourth
description: DETROIT  It has been almost nine years since Derek Jeter batted fourth in the Yankees batting order. Who knows how long it will be before he sees his name in the cleanup spot again?

title: Crandall Canyons Shame
description: The six miners and three would-be rescuers killed in last summers Crandall Canyon mine disaster might have died needlessly. New evidence suggests that the mining company concealed an earlier collapse, which could have alerted safety regulators and avoided the tragedy. There will be no peace for the dead  and no deterrence of future disasters  until there is a criminal investigation.

title: Strains of Humor in a Classical Vein
description: Music has a hard time being funny, especially music of the last 100 years. Haydn managed it in the past, and Gyorgy Kurtags piano pieces, as played by Mitsuko Uchida at Carnegie Hall on Friday night, come close today.

title: Encores! for Bernstein
description: Leonard Bernstein is coming back to New York City Center as part of a celebration of what would have been his 90th birthday. For the first time, the City Center Encores! series will begin in the fall, with On the Town, the 1944 musical that Bernstein wrote with Betty Comden and Adolph Green. On the Town is scheduled to run from Nov. 19 to 23, followed by a production of the 1932 Jerome Kern-Oscar Hammerstein musical Music in the Air from Feb. 5 to 8. The season will conclude with Finians Rainbow, the 1949 musical by Burton Lane, E. Y. Harburg and Fred Saidy about what to do with an Irish pot of gold in the state of Missitucky. That is scheduled to run March 26 to 29.

title: At the Cavendish Pairs, Six Spades, Much at Stake
description: The Cavendish Invitational Pairs, which finished Sunday afternoon in Henderson, Nev., was won by Geoff Hampson of Las Vegas and Eric Rodwell of Clearwater Beach, Fla. They led before the final session and moved further ahead of Gary Cohler of Miami and Sam Lev of New York City. Third were Bobby Levin of New York City and Steve Weinstein of Andes, N.Y., who won last year. A full report will appear in Thursday's column.

title: Sinew and Blood: Tugging Connections Between America and Africa
description: The dancer and choreographer Reggie Wilson seems to be constantly working to enlarge the meanings of the term African-American. He is the main figure behind and within Kwenda Vutuka (Come Go Return), which was presented for two performances at the Florence Gould Hall over the weekend.

title: Accepting the Costs of a Life in Football
description: Lying in his hospital bed, Reggie Williams watched a flow of blood, four or five inches high, coming from his postsurgical knee.

title: Crews Search for Storm Survivors
description: Emergency crews searched through wreckage and conducted rescue operations on Monday in areas that were hit by violent storms that killed at least 23 people in Missouri, Oklahoma and Georgia over the weekend.

title: A Better Immigration Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloomberg Asks Albany to Oppose Union-Backed Retirement Bills
description: ALBANY  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York is appealing to Gov. David A. Paterson and legislative leaders to hold firm against two bills that the city believes would cost as much as $300 million a year.

title: Once a Hostess, Now a Bars Grande Dame
description: Show up at the storied Caf des Artistes anytime after 6:30 most evenings, and you might notice an elderly woman nursing a glass of red wine at the bar, her carriage erect, her suit jacket immaculate, her gaze resting nowhere in particular. Her small smile suggests that shes not waiting for anyone, and that shes comfortable with that. Shes old enough that even among the restaurants graying clientele, she stands out. Maybe youd even avoid an empty seat next to her, for fear it might open the door to a rambling tirade about some government conspiracy involving vitamins or aluminum foil.

title: Saying No to Everything
description: Even before the House passed a new plan last week to prevent foreclosures, President Bush threatened to veto the bill, calling it overly burdensome. The bill is not burdensome enough.

description: ECONOMIC REPORTS The highlight for economic news this week will be the Consumer Price Index for April, on Wednesday.

Something similar drew me admiringly to Paul Lewiss evening of piano music at the 92nd Street Y on Saturday.

title: Deutsche Telekom May Gain Control of Greek Company
description: ATHENS  With its sales slipping and fixed-line customers defecting, Deutsche Telekom looked set this week to complete plans to buy a stake worth nearly 3 billion euros ($4.6 billion) in Greeces former phone monopoly.

title: Pro-Palestinian Rally at Turin Book Fair
description: Protesters in the thousands, including Dario Fo, the 1997 Nobel laureate in literature, massed on Saturday in Turin, Italy, to demonstrate their opposition to that citys book fair, which highlights the 60th anniversary of Israeli independence. The fairs decision to showcase Israeli writers drew a crowd of Free Palestine demonstrators  estimated at 3,000 to 4,000 by photographers, at 10,000 by the organizers and at 1,500 by the 1,000 police officers mobilized to shepherd the protesters, Agence France-Presse reported. The Paris book fair in March, also with an Israeli theme, drew similar pro-Palestinian demonstrations.

title: Little Mermaid Actor Has Surgery on Wrists
description: The actor who plummeted through a trapdoor minutes before the Saturday matinee of The Little Mermaid remained hospitalized on Sunday, said Chris Boneau, a spokesman for the show.

title: To Curb Truancy, Dallas Tries Electronic Monitoring
description: DALLAS  Jaime Pacheco rolled out of bed at dawn last week to the blaring chorus of two alarms. Then Jaime, a 15-year-old high school freshman, smoothed his striped comforter, dumped two scoops of kibble for the dogs out back and strapped a G.P.S. monitor to his belt.

title: What Social Security Isnt Meant to Do
description: To hear some in Congress tell it, the federal government urgently needs to expand its electronic employment verification system, E-Verify, to all corners of the country and force every business to use it. But a hearing in the House last week raised serious questions about the costs and collateral damage of that expansion, the latest scheme by hard-liners to slam the door shut on unauthorized immigrant workers.

title: Attack in Kashmir Leaves 7 Dead
description: NEW DELHI  A long lull in violence in the Indian-administered province of Kashmir broke on Sunday as a gun battle between militants and Indian soldiers left seven dead, according to Indian authorities.

description: This week, the television upfronts  in which the broadcast networks present their schedules to advertisers  will open with a mystery. Who stole six million viewers?

description: Location: DeKalb, Ill.

description: EnCana, Canadas biggest energy company, said on Sunday it plans to split into two separate oil and natural gas firms in an effort to wring out more value with crude prices at record highs.

title: HSBC Says 1Q Profit Up Despite $3.2 Billion Write-Down
description: HSBC Holdings said Monday that its first-quarter profit was ahead of the equivalent period a year ago as higher profits in Asia, the Middle East and Latin America helped offset rising bad-debt charges in the U.S. and a write-down at its investment banking arm.

description: Yahoo has acquired Inquisitor in a move to improve how search results appear on Apple computers.

description: Westpac Banking said Monday that it was in talks on an all-share bid for St. George Bank, which has a market value of 15 billion Australian dollars, in a deal that would create Australias largest home-lending and wealth-management provider.

description: John C. Malones Liberty Media filed an appeal to stop Barry Dillers IAC/InterActiveCorp from pursuing a plan to break up the Internet conglomerate, although Libertys chief executive said it was still exploring a variety of options.

description: D.B. Zwirn & Company is a leading contender to win the upcoming bankruptcy auction of TVT Records, the record label known for its stable of rap and hip-hop artists.

title: In Gun Cases, Police Testimony Met With Disbelief
description: Over the last six years, the police and prosecutors have cooperated in a broad effort that allows convicted felons found with a firearm to be tried in federal court, where sentences are much harsher than in state court. Officials say the initiative has taken hundreds of armed criminals off the street and turned some into informers who have helped solve more serious crimes. But a closer look at those prosecutions, Benjamin Weiser writes, reveals something that has not been trumpeted: more than 20 cases in which judges found police officers testimony to be unreliable, inconsistent, twisting the truth or just plain false. The judges language was often withering: patently incredible, riddled with exaggerations, unworthy of belief.

She was discovered at the corner of Hart Street and Lewis Avenue, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood.A passer-by made the discovery at about 7 a.m. the police said, and officers who responded found a kitchen knife close by that is believed to be the murder weapon. Inside Ms. Brisols car, a dark-colored Hyundai, the officers found the 1-year-old boy sitting in a car seat. He was immediately transported to Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center in Brooklyn.

I wasnt surprised to hear that, having grown up in a family where conversation is more of a competitive sport than a polite interaction. In our home, talking over one another and interrupting were fairly standard, and as a result our communication probably suffered. Mastering listening, Ms. Neels says, allows you to get things right the first time, build better relationships and find the nuances behind what is being said.

The bookmakers William Hill fixed the odds on Mr. Rushdies novel at 5-1. Other nominees for the award, celebrating the 40th anniversary of the prize, which was established in 1969 (it was shared in 1974 and 1992) were: Disgrace by the Nobel laureate J. M. Coetzee (10-1); The Ghost Road by Pat Barker (20-1); Oscar and Lucinda by Peter Carey (25-1); The Conservationist by Nadine Gordimer (40-1); The Siege of Krishnapur by J. G. Farrell (80-1). The short list was chosen by a panel of judges. The winner of the Best of the Booker prize will be chosen by a vote of the public and will be announced in London on July 10. The award, now called the Man Booker Prize goes annually to the best work of fiction by an author from the British Commonwealth or the Republic of Ireland.
