description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Footnotes
description: Indiana Jones  oops, make that Harrison Ford   has been elected to the board of the Archaeological Institute of America. Brian Rose, president of the nonprofit organization, said, Harrison Ford has played a significant role in stimulating the publics interest in archeological exploration. ... Dog the Bounty Hunter, featuring Duane Chapman, will return to the A&E lineup on June 25. The series, the most successful on A&E in recent years, was suspended last fall after Mr. Chapman made racially charged comments in a private telephone conversation made public by The National Enquirer, which paid Mr. Chapmans son for the tape. At the time, A&E announced it was stopping production for the foreseeable future. ... Yet another reprieve has been granted the Mount, the financially troubled Edith Wharton House in Lenox, Mass. Seeking to avert foreclosure, it has raised more than $875,000 in an emergency campaign and announced on Thursday that its major creditors had agreed to extend the foreclosure deadline for six months, until Oct. 31. Planning a full season of operations, the house opened to the public last Friday and generated $8,000 in revenue in its first three days.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Saturday about Senator John McCains criticism of Senator Barack Obamas Middle East policy incompletely described Mr. Obamas position on negotiating with the leaders of countries, including Iran, with which the United States currently has little contact. While Mr. Obama and his aides have indeed described various conditions and limitations on such negotiations, Mr. Obama himself, in a Democratic debate in July 2007, also said he would be willing "to meet separately, without precondition" with the leaders of Iran, Syria, Venezuela, Cuba and North Korea.

title: California Supreme Court Overturns Gay Marriage Ban
description: The California Supreme Court, striking down two state laws that had limited marriages to unions between a man and a woman, ruled on Thursday that same-sex couples have a constitutional right to marry.

title: Farm Bill, Facing Veto, Goes to Bush
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday approved a five-year, $307 billion farm bill with wide bipartisan support, virtually sealing President Bushs defeat in a battle over agriculture policy.

title: Those Gas Prices: Think Outside the Tank
description: To the Editor:

title: Yahoos Chairman Disputes Icahns Accusations
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Yahoos chairman, Roy Bostock, rejected late Thursday accusations from the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn that the companys board had acted irrationally in turning down a $47.5 billion takeover offer from Microsoft and repeated that Yahoo remained open to a deal at the right price.

title: Unions Bankrolled Analyst Vetting Pension Bill
description: ALBANY  A bill offering thousands of additional city workers early retirement has been gaining support in the Legislature in recent weeks. New York City officials have protested, saying it would cost the city $200 million annually.

title: Pakistan: Sharif Cleared to Run for Parliament
description: An election tribunal in Lahore accepted the nomination papers of former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, paving the way for him to run in legislative elections on June 18. Mr. Sharifs papers had been rejected during the general elections in February. His party, Pakistan Muslim League-N, pulled out of cabinet ministries this week over the failure to reinstate the Supreme Court judges dismissed by President Pervez Musharraf last year.

title: This Is Basketball, Boys; Its Not Rocket Science
description: Well now, if this isnt just the cutest thing I dont know what is. Quantum Hoops, a documentary by Rick Greenwald, tells the story of the California Institute of Technologys mens basketball team  a topic that in the context of college sports is approximately as farcical as the history of aspiring semioticians among the contestants on Americas Next Top Model.

title: Soon-to-Be Retiree Has a Share of the Lead
description: CLIFTON, N.J.  Annika Sorenstam may be retiring from the L.P.G.A. Tour at the end of the year, but she hardly seemed like a retiree Thursday while grabbing a share of the Sybase Classics first-round lead.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a skirmish between rival ice cream truck drivers outside a school building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan referred incorrectly in some copies to the school that shares the building with Public School 9. It is the Anderson School  not the Sarah Anderson School, which is an alternate name for P.S. 9.

title: 100 Feared Dead in Nigerian Pipeline Fire
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  More than 100 people were feared dead on Thursday after a construction vehicle struck an oil pipeline on the outskirts of Lagos, Nigerias biggest city, setting off an oil-fed inferno that spread to surrounding homes and a school.

title: 'Idol' Semifinals Buoy Fox
description: Foxs American Idol dominated another night of television ratings on Wednesday as the singing competition reduced its cast of would-be pop stars to two, David Archuleta and David Cook, above, who will compete in next weeks finale. Nielsens estimated that 24.3 million viewers tuned in to the results show at 9 p.m., during which Syesha Mercado was eliminated. Fox led the night overall despite drawing much more modest ratings during the 8 p.m. hour with its comedies  Til Death (5.8 million) and Back to You (6.9 million). CBS took second place with Criminal Minds at 9 (12.7 million) and CSI: NY at 10 (11.6 million). NBC and ABC ranked third and fourth, with NBC earning slightly more viewers with Deal or No Deal from 8 to 10 (7.1 million) followed by Law & Order (8.6 million).

title: Doherty Performs Again
description: Fresh out of prison after serving 29 days of a 14-week sentenced for breaking probation imposed for drug and driving offenses, the Babyshambles singer Pete Doherty, 29, returned to the stage for the first time, performing with his band in London on Tuesday, the BBC reported. He says he had overcome his drug problems while in Wormwood Scrubs prison. ... Bob Dylan will perform on June 23 at the 2008 World Expo in Zaragoza in northeastern Spain, Agence France-Presse reported on Wednesday, citing organizers of the event, scheduled to run from June 14 through Sept. 14. For the fair, expected to draw 6.5 million visitors, Mr. Dylan has recorded a new version of his classic A Hard Rains A-Gonna Fall, including his spoken comments on the importance of clean water worldwide. Other performers at the fair, with exhibits from about 100 countries, will be Alanis Morissette, Iggy Pop and Montserrat Caball.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A film review on May 7 about Battle for Haditha, which looks at the killing of 24 Iraqi civilians by United States marines in the city of Haditha in November 2005, referred incorrectly to some of the evidence in the case. According to marines testimony in legal proceedings, Iraqi men shot and killed in one house were armed. It has not been established that no weapons were found in the houses where Iraqis were killed.

title: Lottery Numbers
Italy Arrests Hundreds of Immigrants
description: ROME  Underscoring the new Italian governments determination to crack down on illegal immigration and what the government contends is associated crime, Italys police arrested hundreds of people this week in a sweep of migrant shantytowns in major urban areas across the country, the police announced Thursday.

title: What Next for the Democrats?
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Just a Dance, but a Book and a Web Site, Too
description: It is endearing to give the members of your audience a gift. It is smart to butter them up with compliments. And it is dynamite to perform a dance that makes them think. Eleanor Bauer/Good Move manages the trifecta in At Large, which opened on Wednesday at the Chocolate Factory.

title: What Wine Goes With Beetle Larvae?
description: The new vogue for survivalist entertainment has had trend watchers citing its roots in rising oil prices, the housing crunch, the credit crisis and other aspects of our economic turmoil, but Im not so sure that people who enjoy Man vs. Wild are getting into it because they are fearing a collapse at Fannie Mae.

title: Working Toward Total Seizure Control
description: Dr. Patricia Crumrine is a pediatric neurologist and the director of the Pediatric Epilepsy Center and the EEG Laboratory at the Childrens Hospital of Pittsburgh. Dr. Crumrine is as a principal investigator on several clinical studies evaluating the safety and efficacy of antiepileptic drugs for use in the treatment of childhood seizure disorders. Here are five things that she thinks everyone with epilepsy should know.

title: Selected Studies: Epilepsy
description: Government agencies, universities, and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: New Indictment in Police Corruption Inquiry
description: In late 2006, a New York City detective was suspected of being involved with illegal drugs, and an Internal Affairs Bureau sergeant was bluntly advising him on how to avoid investigators, according to new court filings in a continuing federal probe of police corruption.

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: Shaking Up the Crowd at Cannes
description: CANNES, France  The apocalypse came early to the Cannes Film Festival this year, filling screening rooms with snarling dogs, bursting bombs, shouting men and screaming women. Midway through Day 2, on Thursday, characters had gone blind, gone to prison, gone to war. One had turned into a piece of furniture, and another had crawled out of a sewer, slimed in waste that the filmmaker threw at the audience with giggles, metaphorically speaking, of course.

title: Ruling May Revive Gay Marriage as Issue
description: WASHINGTON  Gay marriage is an issue on which the three major presidential candidates  John McCain, Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton  are pretty much in agreement. All oppose it, while saying at the same time that same-sex couples should generally be entitled to the legal protections afforded married couples. All think the decision should be left to the states.

title: More Progress Asked of Smithsonian
description: The Government Accountability Office recognized the Smithsonian Institutions progress in improving governance during the past year, but said in a report released on Thursday that there is still some distance to go. Among the initiatives cited in the report were the Smithsonians new and clarified policies on senior staff compensation, standardized leave and travel policies, ethical reforms, transparency and improved communications. The Board of Regents, the Smithsonians governing body, has also established an executive committee with three voting members, begun posting the minutes of its meetings on the Smithsonian Web site (si.edu) and agreed to hold a public meeting every year. At the same time, the report said, development of policies and internal controls for broader operational issues such as travel, event expenses and contracting is still underway, and training and establishing accountability remain challenges.

title: Concerts Set to Benefit Children
description: Free concerts starring Shakira, Miguel Bose, Los Tigres del Norte and David Bisbal and others are expected to draw 300,000 people in Mexico City and Buenos Aires on Saturday and will issue a call for action to support early childhood development programs in Latin America. The concerts follow an announcement on Thursday by artists, intellectuals, business leaders and philanthropists, including Carlos Slim Hel and Howard Buffett, of the establishment of ALAS (Amrica Latina en Accin Solidaria) to address the needs of an estimated 32 million impoverished children in the area.

title: Fox Plans to Run Fewer Ads in 2 New Prime-Time Dramas
description: The Fox network announced a new approach Thursday to keep viewers hooked on shows: give them fewer commercials.

title: From Around the Globe, a Mustering of the Tribes
description: All art fairs are messy, but the New York International Tribal & Textile Arts Show is messier than most. It assembles a ridiculously broad range of tribal art from Africa, Oceania, Asia and North and South America. It is a forceful, entrancing ensemble nonetheless.

title: Opera Official Quits
description: Peter Mussbach, below, the general manger of the Deutsche Staatsoper Unter den Linden in Berlin, has quit, The Associated Press reported. A statement from the city government on Thursday said that the Staatsoper, which oversees the citys three opera houses, decided in consultation with Mr. Mussbach to release him irrevocably with immediate effect and that both sides were prompted to take this step because they were unable to reach agreement on the future direction of the overall operation and the artistic programming. Mr. Mussbach, 59, had been general manager of the Staatsoper since 2002.. Daniel Barenboim is the music director. The two reportedly were at odds over whether more money should go into opera productions or into the houses Staatskapelle orchestra. At a recent public meeting of the heads of the opera houses and the citys mayor, Klaus Wowereit, Mr. Mussbach denounced the mayor, who had said he would not renew Mr. Mussbachs contract when it expired this summer.

title: Ways to Share, and Save
description: TO own a second home, you need to be rich, right? Wrong. Various options are out there that let even regular folks have a piece of the vacation-home pie. And piece is the key word. You can buy into a second home either by time, by use or as part of a group.

title: Oakley Hall, 87, Novelist Attuned to the Old West, Is Dead
description: Oakley Hall, the author of the novels Warlock and The Downhill Racers and a literary heir to fellow California writers like Wallace Stegner, died Monday at his home in Nevada City, Calif. He was 87 and lived in Nevada City, Squaw Valley and San Francisco.

title: Blackstone Reports a $66.5 Million Quarterly Loss
description: The Blackstone Group, the big private equity firm run by Stephen A. Schwarzman, posted a $66.5 million quarterly loss on Thursday, and its executives warned that the turmoil in the financial markets may not be over.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article in the special Well section on Tuesday about foot health described incorrectly peripheral artery disease, which reduces blood circulation to the feet. The disease involves narrowing of arteries in the legs, not veins.

title: Myanmar Farmers May Miss Harvest
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Normally, at this time of year, Burmese farmers in the southern delta of Myanmar would be draining their rice paddies, plowing their fields with their water buffaloes and preparing to plant new seeds for an autumn harvest.

title: Shingles Vaccine Recommended
description: People 60 or older should be vaccinated with Zostavax against shingles, a painful disorder related to chickenpox, health officials said. Only 2 percent of the 43 million people at risk for shingles have been immunized since the drugs maker, Merck, won approval in May 2006 to sell the vaccine, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. A panel of outside advisers to the centers, based in Atlanta, gave a preliminary recommendation in October 2006 for the vaccine. More than one million people each year develop shingles, a recurrence of dormant chickenpox virus. Anyone who had chickenpox can contract shingles. The vaccine is covered by many health insurers.

title: Deal for Auto Workers
description: The Canadian Auto Workers union reached tentative agreements with General Motors of Canada and Chrysler Canada on Thursday, four months before current contracts expire.

title: The Table Brought a Whole Lot to DAntoni
description: On the day Ethel Kennedy arrived for tea, Mike DAntoni was a 9-year-old blur skittering through the family kitchen. A West Virginia boy had more pressing concerns than who would lead the free world.

title: Out of the Wardrobe, Into a War Zone
description: Here in the unenchanted world of ordinary moviegoing, it has been about two and a half years since The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe, the first installment in Walt Disney and Walden Medias mighty Chronicles of Narnia franchise. In wartime England, where the Pevensie children live when theyre not consorting with talking lions and battling witches, a year or so has gone by. But in Narnia itself, to which the four plucky Pevensies return in Prince Caspian, the second movie in the series, centuries have passed, and everything has changed. The grand hall where Peter, Susan, Edmund and Lucy were made monarchs of the realm has fallen into ruin, and the friendly woodland creatures with their homey British accents and computer-animated fur seem to have vanished from the scene.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Wednesday about Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons victory in the West Virginia primary overstated the size of her campaign debt. The total debt is approximately $20 million and includes $11 million in personal loans from Mrs. Clinton; the $20 million is not in addition to those loans.

title: Easing the Seizures, and Stigma, of Epilepsy
description: The first thing you notice about 13-year-old Nora Leitner is the dark circles under her eyes. They stand in stark contrast to the rest of her appearance. At a glance she might be any petite, pretty tween girl, with her blond ponytail, elfin frame and thousand-watt smile, but the circles tell a different story. Nora looks as if she hasnt slept in a month.

title: Spontaneity Was the Medium and the Message
description: Since Polaroid announced in February that it would stop manufacturing instant film and that supplies would run out next year, artists like Chuck Close and Lucas Samaras have been passing through stages of grief. Nothing, they say, can replace the Polaroid  awkward, dated, a little sleazy, but miraculous nonetheless.

title: Gay Couples Celebrate California Decision; Both Sides See a Fight
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Gay and lesbian couples in San Francisco rejoiced on Thursday over a State Supreme Court decision affirming their right to marry even as political leaders on both sides of the issue girded for an extended fight over the ruling in the courts and at the ballot box.

title: Oregon: Heat Killed Sea Lions
description: Six sea lions caught in traps at a major dam on the Columbia River died of heat exhaustion, not gunshots, as had earlier been suspected, federal officials said this week. The sea lions, which were found dead on May 4, feed off salmon and other fish making their way past the Bonneville Dam. They were being trapped as part of a federal and state effort to protect endangered Chinook salmon. Wildlife officials are authorized to permanently remove, and in some cases kill, California sea lions that had been previously tagged for feeding at the dam. One of the six that died was a tagged animal. Officials initially believed that the animals had been shot in the cages but later determined that they died from heat exhaustion. For reasons that remain unclear, gates on the cages, shown covered above, had closed unexpectedly, preventing the sea lions from cooling off in the water.

title: Grand Isolation
description: WHO Denise Travers, 43, her husband, Brian Mills, 52,a lender for commercial real estate, and their children Conor, 14, and Cennedi, 11 WHERE Little Gasparilla Island, Fla. WHAT 4-bedroom house

title: Eight Belles Did Not Have Heart Attack, Necropsy Report Says
description: Eight Belles, the filly who broke down after the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs on May 3, sustained compound fractures of her front legs at the fetlock joints, a necropsy report released Thursday concluded.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a string of weeklong antiwar marches in upstate New York, culminating at Fort Drum on Saturday, misstated, in some copies, the number of years since the war in Iraq began. It started five years ago, in March 2003, not six years ago.

title: France: Caesar Was Ambitious, and Perhaps Worried
description: An excavation near Arles has found what is thought to be the only surviving bust made of Julius Caesar during his lifetime, the newspaper Le Monde reported. It is the only known bust of Caesar that was made when the emperor was still alive, said Luc Long of the French Ministry of Culture, which organized the dig. The bust, which shows Caesar with little hair and a wrinkled forehead, was found in the Rhone River. The ministry said it was created around 46 B.C.

title: Text of Icahns Letter to Yahoo Board
description: Following is the text of a letter sent by the billionaire investor, Carl Icahn, to the chairman of Yahoo, Roy Bostock, on Thursday in which Mr. Icahn announced plans to start a proxy fight for Yahoo. Included with the letter were the biographies of Mr. Icahns 10 nominees for the board. (Later in the day, Yahoo issued a response.)

title: When Artworks Collide
description: Whos Afraid of Jasper Johns?, a group show at the Tony Shafrazi Gallery in Chelsea, is the latest proof that you dont have to be a museum to shake things up. It was organized by Gavin Brown, who has a downtown gallery of his own, and Urs Fischer, a Swiss artist he represents.

title: Zimbabwes Rulers Unleash Police on Anglicans
description: JOHANNESBURG  The parishioners were lined up for Holy Communion on Sunday when the riot police stormed the stately St. Francis Anglican Church in Harare, Zimbabwes capital. Helmeted, black-booted officers banged on the pews with their batons as terrified members of the congregation stampeded for the doors, witnesses said.

title: Western Experts Monitor Chinas Nuclear Sites for Signs of Earthquake Damage
description: Chinas main centers for designing, making and storing nuclear arms lie in the shattered earthquake zone, leading Western experts to look for signs of any damage that might allow radioactivity to escape.

title: A Disgraceful Farm Bill
description: Congress has approved a $307 billion farm bill that rewards rich farmers who do not need the help while doing virtually nothing to help the worlds hungry, who need all the help they can get.

title: McCain Vision Has Most G.I.s Out of Iraq by 2013
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Senator John McCain declared on Thursday that most American troops would be home from Iraq by 2013 and that the nation would be a functioning democracy with only spasmodic episodes of violence. The comments were a striking departure from his usual refusal to set a date for American withdrawal.

title: For a Change, N.L. Clubs Are Outscoring A.L. Clubs
description: Johan Santana was focused on finding the right shirt to wear under his Mets jersey. As a conversation started, Santana was more immersed in the shirt than the words. But once Santana heard statistics detailing how National League hitters have been superior to American League hitters this year, he was intrigued.

title: Safer Building Sites
description: To the Editor:

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Shaping a Work That Has Returned to Fashion
description: Monteverdis Vespro Della Beata Vergine (1610) seems to be in fashion at the moment. Years go by when performances are few and far between (although recordings are always plentiful), yet over the last five years or so they have been turning up several times a year, sometimes performed by period-instrument bands and Baroque vocal specialists but often by church choirs supported by modern forces.

title: In Manhattans Dominican Areas, a Different Political Campaign Holds the Stage
description: For the past few weeks, the talk of Washington Heights, like most other places in New York, has been of campaigns and elections and a nations future. But in Upper Manhattan, the names Hillary Clinton, John McCain and Barack Obama rarely come up.

title: Of Canadians, Tourism, and Free Parties as Ads
description: With Canadas dollar on a par with Americas  and having a cuter, Seuss-like nickname: the loonie  New Yorks upstairs neighbors need to find better reasons than the exchange rate to lure tourists.

title: Blackwaters Impunity
description: After guards from Blackwater Worldwide protecting a State Department convoy killed at least 17 Iraqis in a hail of bullets last September, we hoped the Bush administration would rethink the folly of relying on mercenaries, who have no accountability to Iraqi or American law.

title: Pakistan Defies U.S. on Halting Afghanistan Raids
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Pakistani officials are making it increasingly clear that they have no interest in stopping cross-border attacks by militants into Afghanistan, prompting a new level of frustration from Americans who see the infiltration as a crucial strategic priority in the war in Afghanistan.

title: The Serene Life of a Fighter for Civil Liberties
description: Kent Lakes, N.Y.

title: Gay Couples Rejoice at Ruling
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Gay and lesbian couples in San Francisco rejoiced Thursday over a state Supreme Court decision affirming their right to marry even as political leaders on both sides of the issue prepared for an extended fight over the ruling in the courts and at the ballot box.

title: Editor From Herald Tribune to Run A.P. News in the U.S.
description: PARIS  Michael Oreskes, the executive editor of The International Herald Tribune and a veteran journalist at The New York Times, said on Thursday that he was leaving the paper to take a newly created position as managing editor for United States news at The Associated Press.

title: Led by Germany, a Strong Quarter for Europe
description: FRANKFURT  Surprising even the most optimistic forecasters, the German economy grew 1.5 percent in the first quarter of this year, delivering its best performance in more than a decade despite the global financial crisis and recessionary fears enveloping the United States.

title: Mans Best Friend, Hoofed Department
description: Without horses, where would we be? Trousers might never have become fashionable. The violin might never have come into existence. The Aztecs might have thrived another few centuries. The Industrial Revolution might have sputtered out before its time. No one would have to get off his high horse, and no political race would have a dark horse candidate. And the American Museum of Natural History would have had to find another subject for its sprawling, charming and illuminating exhibition that is opening on Saturday: The Horse.

title: Rescuers Aim for Chinese Villages Yet Unreached
description: WANDENG, China  The Peoples Liberation Army marched into this tiny village only to find that Mondays earthquake had destroyed the road leading deeper into the mountains. Beyond, 20 men were trapped in a distant coal mine. Even farther away, a mining town of 5,000 people was cut off and partly buried beneath fallen rocks and dirt.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bob the Builder
description: I APPROACHED Bob Rauschenberg in the mid-80s to design a cover for the Talking Heads record Speaking in Tongues. I had recently seen some of his black-and-white photo collages at Leo Castellis gallery on West Broadway and thought they were amazing, and I wondered what he would do with an LP cover.

title: Hunger and Food Prices Push Afghanistan to Brink
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  Thieves raided the city flour market in broad daylight a few weeks ago, shooting and wounding two people before escaping with their loot.

description: To the Editor:

description: People on Wall Street seem to be vanishing overnight.

description: TENDING TO THE LEGACY

title: Bush Assails Appeasement, Touching Off Storm
description: JERUSALEM  President Bush used a speech to the Israeli Parliament on Thursday to liken those who would negotiate with terrorists and radicals to appeasers of the Nazis  a remark widely interpreted as a rebuke to Senator Barack Obama, who has advocated greater engagement with countries like Iran and Syria.

title: Former Videographer Details Patriots Spying
description: Matt Walsh, a former New England Patriots videographer who helped the team spy on opposing teams, met with N.F.L. officials and Senator Arlen Specter on Tuesday for separate interviews about how the Patriots conducted an illicit videotaping program under Coach Bill Belichick.

title: The Quad Countdown: No. 105 Temple
description: Location: Philadelphia

title: LIVE Friday on This Blog: Russia-Finland and Canada-Sweden
description: Stuck in the office, jonesing for hockey? No problem. Join the Times hockey blog on Friday afternoon at 1:00 Eastern Time for our description of the IIHF World Championship semifinal between Russia and Finland, LIVE, as it happens at Le Colise in Quebec City. Then return to the Slap Shot blog at 5:00 Eastern for our LIVE play-by-play of the Canada-Sweden semifinal, described as it unfolds in Quebec City. Jeff Z. Klein will narrate the Russia-Finland match, Jeff Hale the Canada-Sweden contest.

title: Herald Reporter Walks Through How He Botched Article
description: In a  lengthy column posted shortly after midnight on The Boston Herald Web site, John Tomase, The Heralds Patriots beat writer, explained how he blundered in his infamous Super Bowl walk-through article. How much damage did Tomase do? In a radio interview Thursday, the Patriots president, Jonathan Kraft, said the article was a significant distraction for the team the day before its Super Bowl loss to the Giants (more on that below).

title: The New Jersey State Museum
description: The New Jersey State Museums main building reopened in Trenton after four years of renovation.

title: The King and the Pygmy
description: With thoroughbred racing praying for an accident-free Preakness and hoping a Triple Crown winner will take the publics mind off the industrys troubles, the time has come to tell the story of The King and the Pygmy.

title: Major art fair this weekend in Hong Kong
description: By Caroline Mok and Joyce Hor-Chung Lau

title: Now Online / T's New Travel Issue
description: The new issue of T Travel charts the seasons most intriguing spots both near and far, from the Ontario lakes and the beating heart of Provence to a Himalayan wonderland in the north of India and the otherworldly desert of Namibia. (Be sure to check out Norbert Schoerners film Soar, shot near the Namib-Naukluft National Park, the site of our cover shoot.) We also take a look at how the creative class is shaking up Copenhagen; a new hotel thats drawing attention to Australias Kangaroo Island; and even an unlikely artistic revival in Paducah, Ky. Plus: a guide to Beijing, the laid-back Italian island of Ischia, shopping in Barcelona and more. So come hit the road with us, no passport necessary.

description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

title: A Hot Dog Play, Then a Throw With Mustard on It
description: At the end of a running catch on Wednesday, Manny Ramirez of the Red Sox high-fives a fan in the bleachers before doubling-up the runner on first:

title: Kohlberg Kravis Digs Into Infrastructure Plays
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is strapping on its hard hat.

title: Morgan Stanley Cuts Staff in London
description: Morgan Stanley has begun a series of job cuts in London that could see at least 350 people let go. The Telegraph reported that the bank began cutting jobs on Wednesday, with the process expected to take some weeks as Morgan Stanley continues to restructure.

title: Prudential Eyeing Equitable Fund
description: Prudential is among the parties eyeing Equitable Lifes 7 billion pound with-profit fund, which is up for sale in what is expected to be the final restructuring of the troubled mutual, The Financial Times reported.

title: Berkshire Hathaway Leaves R.B.S. Auction
description: Warren Buffetts Berkshire Hathaway has pulled out of the bidding in Royal Bank of Scotlands $13.6 billion auction for its British insurance business.

title: Australias GrainCorp Offers to Buy Ridley
description: GrainCorp has offered to buy livestock feed maker Ridley for $390.5 million. The deal would allow eastern Australias largest grain handler to gain 23 domestic grain mills and sales in North America.

title: Report Finds Big Health V.C. Industry in Pennsylvania
description: In a study, Pennsylvania ranked sixth in the nation in health care-focused venture-capital firms.

title: BHP Stock Mines Gold On Report of Partial Stake Buy
description: Shares of BHP Billiton set a record high in Sydney, Australia on Friday, after a local newspaper reported that China has approached an Australian superannuation and investment fund to partner in a multibillion-dollar attempt to buy a 9 percent stake in the mining giant.

title: Bernanke Says Banks Need More Capital
description: Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, pushed banks on Thursday to keep raising capital in the aftermath of losses from the credit crisis to avert deeper damage to the economy.

title: Yue Yuen Aims for Retail Spinoff
description: Athletic shoe manufacturer Yue Yuen Industrial will spin-off its retail distribution business in China, assuming that its minority shareholders give it a nod of approval at a special general meeting next Tuesday.

title: BlackRocks UBS Portfolio Move: A Good Sign?
description: BlackRocks assignment to manage a massive subprime portfolio from UBS is a sign that first buyers are returning to assets long considered too toxic to touch, and more similar deals may follow, Reuters reported.

title: Evercore Toasts Bollinger
description: Evercore Capital Partners has bought a majority stake in insurance broker Bollinger in a deal valued at $250 million, The Daily Deal reported citing unnamed sources.

title: As Private Equity Snaps Up Debt, Others Stay Away
description: While Citigroup, Deutsche Bank and other investment banks purge themselves of billions in buyout loans, investors remain skittish about investing in the high-yield debt market, The New York Post reported.

title: Severstal to Sell $1.5 Billion in Bonds
description: Severstal is planning to sell $1.5 billion of bonds, according to media reports.

title: An Expensive Stroll Down Old Lane
description: It is far too early to say whether Vikram Pandit will be a success as Citigroups chief executive. But it is already clear that his performance as a hedge-fund manager is nothing to crow about.

title: CBS-CNet Deal is Good News for Jana
description: Activist hedge fund Jana Partners generated big gains on Thursday after CBS agreed to buy Internet news provider CNet Networks for $1.8 billion.

title: In Yahoo Fight, Its Goldman Against Icahn Again
description: Goldman Sachs and Carl C. Icahn, it seems, will square off once more.

title: Seattle Venture Firm Stays Active
description: OVP Venture Partners is celebrating its 25th anniversary this year, but the Seattle venture firm apparently isnt slowing down as it gets on in years.

title: For Wall Street Workers, Ax Falls Quietly
description: People on Wall Street seem to be vanishing overnight. Thousands are losing their jobs as hard-pressed banks cut deep. But while layoffs are nothing new in the financial industry, this round seems different: it is eerily quiet.

title: Yahoo Chairman Fires Back at Icahn
description: Yahoos chairman, Roy Bostock, rejected late Thursday accusations from the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn that the companys board had acted irrationally in turning down a $47.5 billion takeover offer from Microsoft and repeated that Yahoo remained open to a deal at the right price.

title: Attention CNET Shoppers
description: CNET Networks surprised the market, and no doubt Jana Partners, with its announcement Thursday that it would be acquired by CBS. But the merger agreement filed by CNET on Thursday contains its own surprise. CNET has negotiated a rather unique provision that gives it more leeway than usual to find another, higher bidder. If it can.

title: Verso Shares Fall in Market Debut
description: Shares of Verso Paper, a company backed by private equity firm Apollo Management, fell 17 percent in their market debut Thursday. The company had already cut the number and expected price of shares to be sold.

title: G.E. Confirms Potential Sale of Appliances Unit
description: General Electric on Friday confirmed that it is exploring a potential sale or spinoff of its appliances business, one of the oldest at the 120-year-old conglomerate.

title: The Early Word: Conflict Issues for McCain
description: John McCain, the presumptive G.O.P. nominee, is cleaning up some ethical entanglements after news outlets questioned his campaigns association to some questionable supporters.

title: Senate Rejects Looser Media Ownership Rules
description: The Senate voted on Thursday to overturn new, looser media ownership restrictions in the 20 biggest U.S. cities, defying a White House threat to veto the measure.

title: VH1 Acquires Bachelor Library
description: The Hollywood Reporter: The Bachelor will be looking for love all over again on VH1. The lifestyle cable network said Thursday it acquired the full library of ABCs reality competition series. VH1 has set network records with its own dating reality shows.

title: Citys Employment Rate Holding Steady, for Now
description: The latest labor report indicates that the citys economy has remained relatively vibrant even as the rest of the state has continued to lose jobs, Patrick McGeehan reports.

title: Thursday Ratings: Idol Nears End
description: Foxs American Idol dominated another night of television ratings on Wednesday as the singing competition reduced its cast of would-be pop stars to two, David Archuleta and David Cook, who will compete in next weeks finale.

title: In Search of McCains Mideast Doctrine
description: James P. Rubin, a former State Department official in the Clinton administration, says John McCain is guilty of hypocrisy when he criticizes Barack Obama for being willing to talk with Hamas. title: Protest Stops Traffic in Crown Heights

The protesters marched from the scene of the crime, at Empire Boulevard and Albany Avenue, to the 71st Precinct, and then up New York Avenue to Eastern Parkway, one of the neighborhoods main corridors, where protesters blocked traffic. They were briefly stopped at Kingston Avenue from going forward by a line of police officers who stood arm-to-arm. After the protesters shouted for a while longer, traffic was reopened on the parkway at 6:10 p.m. and the crowd gradually dispersed around 6:45 p.m.

Because of the limited ticket availability, the Yankees are encouraging fans to use their tickets on the rescheduled date. The Yankees and the Mets are scheduled to play at Shea Stadium on June 27, 28 and 29. Sounds as if another day-nighter between the Queens and the Bronx is possible.

Mr. Trovati was the first witness at a trial where Parmalats chief executive, Enrico Bondi, is seeking to prove that the dairys former banker, Citigroup, abetted corrupt employees who looted the company. Citigroup has countersued, claiming it was a victim of the fraud that led to the companys collapse.

He also drew comparisons to Earnhardts father, whose aggressive driving style helped him win seven Cup titles and a following that still exists seven years after he died in a crash at the Daytona 500.

Nina Winthrops Minority, which opened at the Flea Theater on Thursday night, accomplishes this feat in its first moments with ambient sounds of chattering, a half-lighted stage and one woman who walks on slowly, only to slump forward, gradually straighten and tip her head backward.

title: A Classroom Where the Teacher Really Wants That Apple
description: THE gelding we nicknamed Big Brown, in honor of the Kentucky Derby winner, loped off to the far corner of the arena as if he were looking for a place to hide. I exchanged frustrated frowns with my teammate, Shanda Steenburn, a tall, curly-haired nurse and hospital pharmacy manager.

title: Medical Companys Investors Sue Over Acquisition
description: Shareholders of CryoCor, the maker of a device that freezes heart muscle to correct abnormal rhythms, sued the company to block its acquisition by Boston Scientific. The complaint, filed in California state court in San Diego, requests a court order blocking an April 18 merger agreement. Boston Scientific and CryoCor announced last year that they would work together to develop new treatments for atrial fibrillation using extreme cold.

title: Sunni Insurgents in Mosul Offered Amnesty and Cash
description: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki offered amnesty and cash payments to Sunni insurgents in the northern city of Mosul on Friday.

title: Mr. Bloombergs Small Pot of Gold
description: Each day, it seems, there is more news about how New Yorks politicians  in the City Council and the State Legislature  hand out taxpayer funds as political sweets to friends and allies. The only one who seemed exempt from the game was Mayor Michael Bloomberg.

title: Mayoral Hopeful, an Earmark Critic, Has His Own
description: There is no doubt that Anthony D. Weiner wants to be mayor of New York. And there is no doubt, to that end, that he has seen an opening to wound a rival: criticizing Christine C. Quinn and the City Council he once was a member of for doling out money to favored groups in their districts.

title: In Effort to Avoid Conflicts, McCain Issues New Rules for Staff
description: WASHINGTON  After expelling four advisers in the last week over concerns about their outside entanglements, Senator John McCain said Friday that his presidential campaign was beginning a new vetting process intended to end the embarrassments over staff ties to private interests, foreign governments or independent political groups.

title: Women of Rock, Heres Your Musical Grandma
description: All those interested in improving their chances of snagging the vice-presidential slot on one of the 2008 tickets should tune in The Sweet Lady With the Nasty Voice, on Sunday on the Smithsonian Channel. It has nothing to do with politics, but its a virtual clinic in the art of self-promotion.

title: The Harm That Drug Laws Do: 4 Perspectives
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A chart on Friday sizing up the field for the Preakness Stakes misstated the distance of the race. It is 1 3/16 miles, not 1 3/4.

title: Rhode Islands Budget Crisis Deepens
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  Darrell West, a political science professor at Brown University, sums up Rhode Islands budget crisis this way: Its a bad situation that keeps getting worse as the economy weakens.

title: A Problem of Perception for the Mets
description: Such is the state of the Mets that they make the last-place Yankees, with a blustering owner and a general manager probably dangling again on the big employment hook, appear as placid as Carlos Beltrn on a cloudless day at Coney Island.

title: Hard Roads Ahead
description: Walt Disney would have been proud of John McCains presentation on Thursday of what the world might look like at the end of a first McCain term as president.

title: Places to Go, but Dreading the Fill-Up
description: SOMETIME in the last couple of months, the price of gasoline crossed a line. Its not just that gas is now hovering around the dreaded $4 a gallon. Its that an unconscious expense has become a painfully conscious one.

title: Stiller Eyes Sequel
description: Ben Stiller has found another hallowed institution to flee. The sequel to Night at the Museum, the 2006 hit in which he played a security guard trapped in the American Museum of Natural History when its exhibits come alive, will be shot at the Smithsonians National Air and Space Museum, below. Night at the Museum II: Escape From the Smithsonian, scheduled for release in May 2009, is the first commercial film for which the museum has allowed itself to be used. The popularity of the first movie convinced us that this is an innovative way to capture the imagination and curiosity of a young audience, Richard Kurin, the museums acting under secretary for history, art and culture, wrote in a memo that was posted on the blog Modern Art Notes at ArtsJournal.com. The cast includes Owen Wilson and Amy Adams. On-location shooting was scheduled to be completed next week.

title: In New York, Debating a Flat Tax on Gasoline
description: With gasoline prices hitting new records daily, oil companies are not the only ones raking it in. New York City is profiting, too.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article in some editions on Friday about the comedian Mort Sahl was accompanied by an incorrect picture in some copies. The photograph was of the comedian Shelley Berman, not Mr. Sahl.

title: Paulson Says Economy Is Starting to Rebound
description: The Treasury secretary, Henry M. Paulson Jr., delivered a guardedly optimistic message to business leaders on Friday, saying that the economy was moving toward a rebound after months of malaise.

title: Soldiers Ploy Backfires in Bid to Quit War
description: The door to the doughnut shop swung open. For a moment, the tall young man, every bit a soldier in his bearing, stood with the windy rain of Friday afternoon at his back. A wave of coffee and doughnut humidity slapped him in the face.

title: A Traveling Festival Comes Back to Town, This Time With a New Slate of Works
description: On its home turf, the Jerusalem International Chamber Music Festival takes place at the end of the summer. But during the rest of the year, the pianist Elena Bashkirova, who founded the festival in 1998, tours with some of its players, and on Thursday evening, a representative ensemble performed at the Metropolitan Museum. Ms. Bashkirovas celebrated husband, the pianist Daniel Barenboim, was not among them, but their son, Michael Barenboim, was the groups violinist. They were joined by Kyril Zlotnikov, a cellist, and Matthias Glander, a clarinetist, in works by Schumann, Hindemith, Berg and Beethoven.

title: Obama Says Bush and McCain Are Fear Mongering in Attacks
description: WATERTOWN, S.D.  Senator Barack Obama responded sharply on Friday to attacks on his foreign policy, linking President Bush and Senator John McCain as partners in the failed policies of the past seven years and criticizing them for hypocrisy, fear peddling, fear mongering.

title: Frustrating the Pirates
description: DISPENSING with the bluster that normally surrounds the issue of pirated movies and music, Anders Bylund of Ars Technica tries to appeal to business sense in arguing that media companies should stop suing their potential customers and instead try to serve them (arstechnica.com).

title: Saving Horses, One Thoroughbred at a Time
description: COOKSTOWN, N.J.  A thoroughbred named Tchaikovsky, a grandson of Secretariat, was having a tooth pulled in one stall. A horse in another was given a sponge bath. Out the stable door, about a dozen horses shared a sun-lit field.

title: No Hope for the Defense? Create a Distraction
description: When you are defending and believe that declarer is slated to make his contract, try to find a diversionary tactic.

title: Smithsonian Director Resigns
description: Sharon F. Patton has resigned after five years as the director of the Smithsonian Institutions National Museum of African Art, effective in December. In a statement, Ms. Patton said she had achieved much of what she set out to accomplish, but she also nodded to the appointment of a new leadership at the Smithsonian. (G. Wayne Clough, the president of Georgia Tech, is to assume the post of Smithsonian secretary, or chief executive, on July 1.) It seems to be the right time to leave, Ms. Patton, 64, said. Under her leadership the museums collection of more than 9,000 African art objects grew to include the Walt Disney-Tishman collection of 500 pieces from nearly every country in Africa. She also increased programming for children and promoted contemporary artists. The Smithsonian has been through considerable turmoil over the last year and a half. Its previous secretary, Lawrence M. Small, resigned over revelations that he spent the institutions money on luxuries like private jets. In a report on Thursday, the Government Accountability Office cited recent progress at the institution but said it still needed better internal controls.

title: Galaxies Twice as Bright as They Seem, Study Finds
description: The universe, it seems, has been operating with a dimmer switch.

title: Looming Dangers for Orphaned Burmese
description: BANGKOK  While the death toll in Myanmar continues to climb, international aid agencies are warning of a new kind of threat to the most vulnerable survivors, children.

title: House G.O.P. to Re-evaluate Course
description: WASHINGTON  Still smarting from Tuesdays special-election loss in Mississippi, House Republicans have set a special meeting for next Tuesday to try to find a way to turn around their political slide.

title: Airlines Told to Report Tarmac Delays Fully
description: WASHINGTON  The Department of Transportation said on Friday that it would require airlines to give fuller accountings about what has become a bane of modern air travel  delays on the tarmac  and is taking several steps to reduce delays around New York City.

title: F. A. O. Schwarz Will Sell Toys in Macys Stores
description: Two of New Yorks most venerable retail brands, Macys and F. A. O. Schwarz, are teaming up for a risky experiment: bringing toys back to the department store.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,072 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday:

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A pop music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about Laura Veirs and Liam Finn, at the Bowery Ballroom next Thursday, misidentified Mr. Finns nationality. He is from New Zealand, not Australia. The entry also referred imprecisely to the record label of his solo debut album, Ill Be Lightning. While Independent Records is the label in Ireland, in the United States the album is on Yep Roc Records.

title: Report Assesses Blame in Hepatitis Cases
description: Health care workers at a Las Vegas endoscopy clinic linked to more than 80 cases of hepatitis C routinely mishandled injection equipment and medication vials and often failed to perform basic hand hygiene, according to a report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released Friday.

title: This July 4, Fewer Bombs May Burst in Air
description: An explosion that destroyed 20 fireworks warehouses in China three months ago will probably dim night skies in the United States this Fourth of July.

title: R. Kelly Jury Selected
description: A panel of eight men and four women will decide the fate of R. Kelly, the R&B star whose much-delayed trial on child pornography charges is to begin Tuesday in Chicago. During jury selection, which ended Thursday, the defense accused the prosecution of eliminating some African-Americans from the pool of candidates, while the prosecution countered that it had also eliminated some white males, The Chicago Sun-Times reported. The final group of jurors includes an African-American woman married to a Baptist preacher, a young white woman who is an aspiring police officer, a 68-year-old Romanian immigrant and a recent college graduate who was once arrested for marijuana possession. Mr. Kelly was indicted on June 5, 2002, after the appearance of a videotape that prosecutors say shows him having sex with a girl as young as 13. He has pleaded not guilty. On Friday, the judge, Vincent Gaughan, rejected a motion that news organizations have access to sealed court transcripts and records of the case.

title: 3 Nordic Banks Help Iceland Prop Up Currency
description: FRANKFURT  In a show of Nordic solidarity, three central banks in the region have ridden to the rescue of Iceland, lending the island emergency credit of up to 1.5 billion euros ($2.3 billion) to shore up its swooning currency and forestall a broader economic collapse.

title: Skirting Appalachia
description: As Hillary Clinton's rout in West Virginia underscores, Appalachia is not Obama country. Of 410 counties in the region, which stretches from New York to Mississippi, Barack Obama has won only 48 (12 percent) so far. Of the counties he has lost, nearly 80 percent have been by a margin of more than 2 to 1. The region is whiter, poorer, older, more rural and less educated than the rest of the country, and seems to be voting like a bloc.

title: Smoothing the Rides on Greyhound
description: AS the summer travel season approaches, oil and gasoline prices continue to rise. Gas cost an average of about $3.75 a gallon nationwide earlier this week. Oil prices are setting records almost daily, passing $125 a barrel.

title: Chasing Utopia, Family Imagines No Possessions
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Like many other young couples, Aimee and Jeff Harris spent the first years of their marriage eagerly accumulating stuff: cars, furniture, clothes, appliances and, after a son and a daughter came along, toys, toys, toys.

title: Ex-Speaker Hires Lawyer in Inquiry
description: Gifford Miller, the former City Council speaker, has hired a criminal defense lawyer to represent him in a federal investigation into the Councils longstanding practice of allocating millions of dollars to phantom nonprofit groups, people involved in the case said on Friday.

title: Released From Rigors of a Trial, a Nobel Laureates Ink Flows Freely
description: TOKYO

title: Learning Not to Rely on Bryant, Lakers Close Out Utah
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Outside of Hollywood, the perception persists that the Lakers are the N.B.A.s answer to H.B.O.s Entourage, with the guard Kobe Bryant filling the role played by Adrian Grenier and his teammates playing his cool crew of acolytes.

title: McCains Superfuture
description: John McCain gave a speech this week describing what the world would look like after his first term in office.

title: Upshaw Expects N.F.L. Owners to Opt Out of Labor Deal
description: Gene Upshaw, the executive director of the N.F.L. players union, said Friday that he expected the owners to opt out of the collective bargaining agreement after they meet Tuesday in Atlanta.

title: A Victory for Equality and Justice
description: The California Supreme Court brought the United States a step closer to fulfilling its ideals of equality and justice with its momentous 4-to-3 ruling upholding the right of same-sex couples to marry.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on Thursday about Hollywoods summer movies, including Sex and the City, using information provided by New Line Cinema, which made the movie, misstated its release date. It is May 30, not May 28. (On the Hollywood calendar, summer movies include those released in May.)

title: Water Rates Are to Rise 14.5 Percent on July 1
description: The New York City Water Board voted on Friday morning to approve a 14.5 percent increase for water and sewer rates, the largest increase since 1992.

title: Congressional Pressure Prevails as U.S. Halts Filling of Oil Reserve
description: Bowing to pressure from Congress, the Energy Department said Friday that it would temporarily suspend a program to fill the nations strategic oil stocks.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the surprising early success of the Florida Marlins misstated, in some editions, the scheduled length of their series this week with the Cincinnati Reds. It was four games, not three. (They played only three games because the finale on Thursday was postponed because of rain.)

title: Famine Looms as Wars Rend Horn of Africa
description: DAGAARI, Somalia  The global food crisis has arrived at Safia Alis hut.

title: Painting Damaged
description: During the removal of an installation at the National Gallery in London, Marcia, a 500-year-old painting by the 16th-century master Domenico Beccafumi, slipped out of its frame, causing one of its three large panels to break away from the other two. The Art Newspaper, which reported the incident, called it one of the most serious handling accidents known to have occurred in a U.K. museum in living memory. The painting, one of three by Beccafumi depicting classical heroines, was part of the Renaissance Siena exhibition, which closed early this year. The damage was not made public until recently, when minutes of a National Gallery trustee meeting on Feb. 8 were posted online. Museum authorities ordered an investigation which is still going on, the publication reported, but the panels were restored immediately and the painting is now on public view. Under present lighting in the gallery, the vertical strip of damage can hardly be seen when looked at straight on although it is just visible when the painting is viewed from the left side, Martin Bailey wrote in The Art Newspaper.

title: Rethinking Locally: New Jersey Opens Big Museum Doors Again
description: TRENTON  The New Jersey State Museums main building reopens here on Saturday after four years of renovation, but appeals for celebration are premature. Closed since 2004 for work that expanded in scope, ran two years late and cost $15 million  with at least $12 million more still being sought from private donations  the museums main building seems to embody anticipation more than realization.

title: Same-Sex Marriage and Racial Justice Find Common Ground
description: Not long into the oral argument before the California Supreme Court in March over whether gay and lesbian couples have a constitutional right to marry, Chief Justice Ronald M. George showed his hand.

title: The President Goes Negative
description: President Bushs penchant for slash-and-burn politics, learned at the feet of Karl Rove and the late Lee Atwater, is unseemly when practiced at home. It is shameful for the president and damaging for the country when put on display abroad.

title: Shop Owner Is Charged With Assault
description: A Brooklyn store owner who struck a 15-year-old boy in the head with a hammer was indicted on felony assault charges on Friday, although his lawyer said he acted in self-defense.

title: Pen in One Hand, Cricket Bat in the Other
description: There are no longer any Staten Islanders in the Staten Island Cricket Club, one of the countrys oldest. The members are from places like Sri Lanka, India, Pakistan, Jamaica, Guyana, Trinidad, St. Vincent and Grenada. There are just two Europeans; one of them, Joseph ONeill, a 44-year-old Irishman who grew up in the Netherlands, was educated at Cambridge but has lived in New York since 1998.

title: Robert Mondavi, Napa Wine Champion, Dies at 94
description: Robert Mondavi, the California vintner who set in motion the rebirth of the Napa Valley wine industry and, to a generation of Americans, championed the idea that fine wine was an integral part of the good life, died Friday at his home in Yountville, Calif. He was 94.

title: Lottery Numbers
New Tack on Straying Parolees Offers a Hand Instead of Cuffs
description: WICHITA, Kan.  Since his release in January after serving time for a 2006 theft conviction, Lonnie Kemp has violated his parole conditions several times, getting drunk and kicked out of a halfway house and showing traces of marijuana in urine tests. If this were a few years ago, he almost certainly would be back in prison.

title: Talk of Larry Kings Successor Wont Stop, but Neither Does Larry King
description: Larry King, who said last year that he hoped Ryan Seacrest would succeed him on CNN should he ever give up his prime-time show, invited Mr. Seacrest on as a guest on Thursday night and then sought to tamp down speculation that any succession was imminent.

title: Passions Run High on Indexing
description: Did you see the latest issue of The Financial Analysts Journal?

title: France: Warming Imperils Truffles
description: The black truffle is under threat from climate change, with years of bad harvests becoming the norm, according to Jean-Charles Savignac, president of the Fdration Franaise des Trufficulteurs. The European black truffle, highly aromatic and expensive, is suffering from prolonged drought in traditional growing areas, Reuters reported. Prices have soared, with a kilogram of truffles, about 2.2 pounds, costing roughly $1,550, three times the price eight years ago.

title: For Officers Survivors, a Long Wait for Benefits
description: WASHINGTON  In October 2004, Gary Tilton, the fire chief in Katy, a suburb of Houston, came home and jumped into the shower after directing traffic around an accident in the Texas humidity. Within minutes, he lay dying of a heart attack.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: The San Isidro Tilantongo Journal article on Tuesday, about the successful use of old pre-Hispanic farming techniques in the barren Mixteca highlands of Mexicos Oaxaca State, misstated, in some copies, the three-to-four-fold rise in crop yields in eight villages where the techniques have been applied. The yields have grown to between one and one and a half metric tons per hectare, or 16 to 24 bushels per acre  not 100 to 150 bushels per acre.

title: Poverty in Connecticut
description: To the Editor:

title: Finales Boost CBS
description: Finales of CSI and Without a Trace lifted CBS into first place in the ratings on Thursday. According to Nielsens estimates, CSI attracted 17.7 million viewers to CBS at 9 p.m., the nights largest audience, while Without a Trace won the 10 p.m. hour with 14.5 million viewers. Despite CBSs edge in total viewers, the network ranked third for the night among adults 18 to 49, just behind NBC, which got a boost from the season finales of My Name Is Earl at 8 (7.1 million), The Office at 9 (8.1 million) and ER at 10 (8.4 million). ABC, trailed by both networks in that demographic, broadcast the nights top two shows among the 18-to-49 set, Greys Anatomy at 9 and Lost at 10, which delivered 15.2 million and 11.4 million total viewers respectively. Fox finished fourth overall.

title: Missouri Legislature Ends Session With Voter ID Amendment Still on Agenda
description: Missouri lawmakers ended their legislative session on Friday without completing action on a proposed constitutional amendment that would have enabled election officials to require proof of citizenship from people registering to vote.

title: Do the Superfriends Have Library Cards?
description: One of the worlds largest collections of comic art has found a home in Columbus, Ohio. According to The Associated Press, the Cartoon Research Library at Ohio State University will soon exhibit about 200,000 works from the International Museum of Cartoon Art, founded by the cartoonist Mort Walker (Beetle Bailey) in Greenwich, Conn., in 1974. The museum, most recently located in a villa in Boca Raton, Fla., was $2 million in debt and closed in 2002. Plans to have its memorabilia  including a Walt Disney storyboard for an early Mickey Mouse cartoon and original drawings for Dick Tracy, above  moved to Yale University or be displayed at the Empire State Building fizzled. But Ohio State has plans for the sketches, films, figurines, toys and collectibles, which will double its existing collection, the librarys curator, Lucy Shelton Caswell, told The Associated Press. Ms. Caswell, a former board member of the International Museum of Cartoon Art, said new space was being sought for the collection, expected to go on display in the summer.

title: Myanmar Raises Cyclone Toll to 78,000
description: BANGKOK  Myanmars government almost doubled the official death toll on Friday to 78,000, two weeks after a huge cyclone ravaged much of the Irrawaddy Delta and the main city, Yangon. It also nearly doubled the number of missing to 55,917, and raised the number of injured steeply to 19,359, up from 1,403.

title: Brooklyn Dry Cleaner Is Found Dead in Her Windsor Terrace Store
description: When her husband became too sick five years ago to tend to the family dry-cleaning business, Kyung-Sook Woo did not hesitate to take over the job, sometimes rising so early to open the shop that customers would find her with a curling iron in her hand and her short hair half-curled.

title: Networks Anticipate the Fall Cautiously
description: At the party after the Fox networks presentation of its fall schedule on Thursday, an executive from one of Hollywoods biggest talent agencies looked around and said, Finally, we had a real upfront.

title: The World Cant Stand By. Help the Burmese Now.
description: To the Editor:

title: With Chvez in Check, Talks in Peru Stay Calm
description: LIMA, Peru  To the relief of organizers of a summit meeting here of leaders from Latin America and Europe on Friday, the encounter was notable for being relatively free of insults being flung publicly.

title: Reducing College Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: In Siberia, Shopping Malls Are Sprouting All Over
description: NOVOSIBIRSK, Russia  In this region of Siberia, long synonymous with gulags and hardship, shoppers mobbed an Ikea store last winter with the vigor of a miners riot. They loaded their outsize yellow shopping carts with clothes, housewares, appliances and small furniture.

title: Tending to a Flock in Hard Hats
description: The Rev. Brian Jordan had just loped to the end of a long run on a Saturday afternoon, savoring one of those rare times a priest could be considered off duty, when he checked the message on his cellphone. The voice belonged to an old contact in Local 14 of the operating engineers union. His words were succinct and specific: Theres been an accident at 51st and Second. Can you help us?

title: Detainees Trial Delayed Until Justices Rule
description: A military judge delayed the first war crimes trial of a Guantnamo detainee Friday, saying he wanted the opportunity to examine a much-awaited Supreme Court decision on the rights of the detainees.

title: U.S. Plans Steps to Ease Congestion at Airports
description: WASHINGTON  To hold down ticket prices and ease airplane congestion over the New York region, the Bush administration proposed Friday to auction landing slots at two major airports, Kennedy and Newark, and to impose a limit on airline traffic at Newark.

title: U.S. Frustrated by Myanmar Juntas Aid Limits
description: WASHINGTON  Two weeks after a devastating cyclone smashed ashore in Myanmar, the United States is facing the limits of its clout, at least in dealing with a junta that human rights advocates say is putting its own survival before that of a storm-ravaged population.

title: Zimbabwe Election Runoff Set for June 27
description: JOHANNESBURG  Zimbabwes delayed runoff election between President Robert Mugabe, who has led the nation for nearly three decades, and the opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai has been set for June 27, the countrys election commission said Friday.

title: Robbins, Served Up in French Style
description: The latest evening in New York City Ballets Jerome Robbins Celebration draws on the music of two refined composers: Ravel and Debussy. Despite its painfully cute title, French Cuisine, the choreographic treats are of a quiet, understated variety.

title: Suit Accuses Ex-Principal of Defamation
description: Clarification appended.

title: Failing to Close Door on Road, Celtics Will Return Home
description: CLEVELAND  LeBron James had to halt his shot in midair, tuck his legs under him and hold the ball an extra count before heaving it. A foul, he said. No call, the referees said. It did not matter. Even when his shot was off kilter, James was the most dominant player in the building Friday night.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: International

title: Einstein Letter on God Sells for $404,000
description: From the grave, Albert Einstein poured gasoline on the culture wars between science and religion this week.

title: Citigroup May Sell Its German Banking Business
description: Citigroup may sell Citibank Privatkunden, its consumer-banking unit in Germany, as part of a plan to replenish capital, the unit, based in Dsseldorf, said. The German retail unit could fetch 5 billion euros ($7.8 billion) to 6 billion euros, according to Dirk Becker, an analyst at Landsbanki Kepler in Frankfurt. Citigroups chief executive, Vikram S. Pandit, has said he plans to get rid of about $400 billion in assets over the next three years. Citigroups German unit has about 6,800 employees and 3.2 million customers and is one of the countrys largest credit card issuers.

title: Sri Lanka: Attack on Police Bus Kills 10
description: A suicide bomber rammed a motorcycle into a police bus in Colombo, and military jets continued airstrikes on suspected rebel bases in the islands north for a second day. The military said 10 people were killed and 86 were wounded in the bombing, for which the military blamed Tamil rebels.

title: Senator Kennedy Is Hospitalized After a Seizure
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, 76, leader of the nations most storied political dynasty, was hospitalized in Boston on Saturday after apparently suffering a seizure.

title: Lou Reed to Play D.J.
description: Lou Reed will take a break from promoting his forthcoming concert film, Berlin, to host a two-hour radio show on the Sirius Satellite Network. Starting Saturday on Channel 70, Lou Reeds New York Shuffle will broadcast a mix of rock, country and jazz, the kind of programming that Mr. Reed said he has enjoyed for years. He will share host duties with the producer Hal Willner, who was the music director of Berlin. The staged concert, based on Mr. Reeds 1973 album of the same name, was taped at St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn in December 2006. The film version, directed by Julian Schnabel, is to open in New York and Los Angeles on July 18. Requests for Mr. Reeds radio show will soon be taken at loureed.com.

title: Given Second Chance Against Mets, Rasner  Misses Out Again
description: In his start against the Mets last May, Darrell Rasner broke his finger when he was struck by a batted ball. He will never know what would have happened in an encore this May, because his start was wiped out by rain Friday.

title: Dick Netzer, 79, Municipal Finance Expert, Dies
description: Dick Netzer, an economist who advised mayors of New York City and governors of New York State and served on the first board of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which pried New York City out of bankruptcy in the 1970s, died on May 7 in Manhattan. He was 79 and lived in Brooklyn and in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: A Fast-Fading Sway: The Nations Leader, but Not His Partys
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush is not irrelevant. Presidents never are. But with eight months left in office, his ability to shape the countrys legislative and political agenda has diminished more quickly than his aides and allies expected  or at least hoped  only weeks ago.

title: In China, Skittish Pandas, Then Exploding Cliffs
description: CHENGDU, China  The birds suddenly disappeared from the sky. Something also was wrong with the pandas. They were strangely skittish. And then, within minutes, the isolated, verdant mountains above Chinas most famous panda reserve exploded as if hit by a megaton bomb.

title: F.B.I. Gets Mixed Review in Interrogation Report
description: WASHINGTON  A new Justice Department report praises the refusal of F.B.I. agents to take part in the militarys abusive questioning of prisoners in Guantnamo Bay, Iraq and Afghanistan, but it also finds fault with the bureaus slow response to complaints about the tactics from its own agents, people with knowledge of the still-secret report said.

title: U.S. Planning Big New Prison in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon is moving forward with plans to build a new, 40-acre detention complex on the main American military base in Afghanistan, officials said, in a stark acknowledgment that the United States is likely to continue to hold prisoners overseas for years to come.

title: The Doctor With a Dark Side Samples Boston
description: Evil is always more compelling than virtue. This axiom of drama gets a workout in Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, which will be shown on the Ion network on Saturday night. It sets Robert Louis Stevensons story of dual personality in contemporary Boston; makes Dr. Henry Jekyll a dedicated, hardworking neurologist (or urologist; the sound quality is not perfect); and opens with another staple: the murder of a prostitute.

title: Another Star Pairing in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  Kareem and Magic. Shaq and Kobe. Are Lisa and Candace next?

title: Courting N.R.A., McCain Criticizes Obama and Clinton on Gun Control
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Senator John McCain reached out to the National Rifle Association on Friday and warned 6,000 people at the groups annual convention that a President Barack Obama or Hillary Rodham Clinton would put the rights of law-abiding gun owners at risk.

title: Afghanistan: Soldier Killed in South
description: A suicide bomber attacked Afghan and Canadian soldiers patrolling a village in the Panjwai district of southern Afghanistan, killing one Afghan soldier and wounding four Canadians, the Afghan military said.

title: That Fake Gucci: Does It Have Links to Terrorists?
description: New York City is starting an advertising campaign on Monday to educate tourists and residents about the social costs of counterfeit and pirated goods.

title: A Meeting, an Apology and Support for Randolph
description: Soon after Carlos Delgado strolled into the Mets clubhouse on Friday, he said Billy Wagner intercepted him. Wagner, who a day earlier complained about some teammates accountability, began his damage control by talking to Delgado, then to reporters. It was the beginning of the Mets attempt to mitigate a potentially explosive situation.

title: Booz Allen to Sell Part of Its Government Unit to Carlyle
description: Booz Allen Hamilton, the consulting firm, said on Friday that it would sell a majority stake in its government practice to the private equity firm Carlyle Group for $2.54 billion.

title: Heavens Gate
description: I found myself, on the longest day of last year, in what was billed as the highest motorable pass in the world, though motorable seemed as open to question as pass. Icicles were hanging from the mountainside, and plaques around every hairpin turn recalled those fellow travelers, most of them soldiers, who had left for their heavenly abode after plunging over the precipice inches from the loose stones that made up the road. My driver, red-cheeked and indomitable, clambered out of our rickety Toyota to fiddle with a loose starter  not quite what I had ordered at 18,350 feet  and fluid the color of Pepto-Bismol began to leak out of the back of the truck in front of us.

title: Locomotive in Petticoats
description: In 1878, Queen Victoria used a telephone for the first time, after Alexander Graham Bell arranged a demonstration. A phone was placed on a piano and a series of songs played and sung for the curious monarch, who listened intently. In retrospect, this little incident seems charged with symbolism, a marker of the old age touching the new. But who had the honor of performing for the queen, albeit telephonically? Not a famous musician, nor even a Briton, but rather an American journalist named Kate Field whod been moonlighting for Bell as what we would now call a P.R. flack. With her knack for job-juggling, eye for the main chance and limitless energy, Field (1838-96) was herself a pure product of modernity, a self-invented dynamo chugging across the later 19th century like a locomotive in petticoats.

title: Beauty and the Beat
description: With her boyish platinum mop and her penchant for wearing leopard-print pants with silver oxford shoes, the model Agyness Deyn is used to stopping people dead in their tracks. But recently its her G4530 Wild West Sweethearts guitar, from the Gretsch Americana limited-edition series, thats been getting all the attention. I carry it on my back everywhere I go, she explains. When Im wearing it, people just come up to me and start chatting about it. I get to meet some cool people that way. For Deyn, who is a new face for Shiseido and a Burberry favorite, crisscrossing the globe is all in a days work. In fact, she got her acoustic shredder last year in Japan, a surprise gift picked up by her boyfriend Josh Hubbard (of the band the Paddingtons). The guitars compact size makes it easy for lugging on the road, and the campy aesthetic perfectly riffs on Deyns own Paris-meets-Lower East Side style. I love the whole Wild West thing. It reminds me of a Sailor Jerry tattoo, she says. But Deyns love for her little red six-string is no passing fancy. I think Ill have it forever.

title: Correction: Trying to Lighten That Carbon Footprint
