title: Does the Real Ireland Still Exist?
description: AN August night in the sea-scented village of Kinvara finds us at Connollys, a pub so permanent that if some codger were to tell you it was here before Galway Bay, lapping now just outside the door, youd nod and buy him a pint. My wife and I are hunched at a small table with friends when a smiling woman in a peasant skirt sits beside us, carrying a perfectly appropriate accessory in this corner of Ireland  a button accordion.

title: Passing the Doorbell Test
description: WESTCHESTER was a good place for Amanda Allensworth and Sean Cleary to start out. They married two years ago, after meeting while waiting on tables together at a restaurant in Eastchester.

title: O Canada, Where Have Your Bargains Gone?
description: ONCE upon a time, not all that long ago, there existed a magical country that was a lot like the United States, only less expensive. Its enchanted currency  the other dollar  allowed Americans to indulge as they could not back home. This delightful fantasyland was called Canada, and for centuries it was synonymous with frugality.

title: The Watch List
description: When Kenji Johjima was hitting below .200 last month, the Mariners gave him a three-year, $24 million contract extension. Johjima, a soon-to-be 32-year-old catcher, is showing signs they did not make a mistake. Johjima has raised his batting average 50 points this month and had four extra-base hits, including his first homer, in three games this week.

title: O Pioneer!
description: If slavery is Americas original sin, lynching is its capital crime. The historical memory dies hard: only last year, three nooses were hung from a schoolyard tree contested by white and black students in Jena, La.

title: The Language of Loss for the Jobless
description: THE neighbor, a jovial suit-and-tie presence at the school bus stop in the mornings, disappeared for a while last fall. Nobody saw him for weeks. Finally he began to venture out  at afternoon pickup, in jeans and a T-shirt. A senior manager of a technology department, he had been laid off. Neighbors didnt know what to say to him.

title: Diesel Automobiles Clean Up for an Encore
description: AFTER years in the automotive wilderness, largely exiled to the smoky borders of truck stops, diesel is coming home. Americans may not recognize its freshly scrubbed face.

title: Call Him the Worst Director (Then Duck)
description: UWE BOLL is often referred to as the worst filmmaker in the world.

title: The Price of Street Justice: A Child Is Gone
description: TRENTON

title: A Haitian in U.S. Wins Case Over Forced Labor
description: MIAMI  Amid tears, Simone Celestin recalled the repeated beatings she endured at the hands of her adoptive family while working for them as an unpaid servant for six years.

title: Kahne Proves Fans Faith Was Well Placed
description: CONCORD, N.C.  Talk about a million-dollar smile.

title: Next Stop: A Commuter Village
description: SECAUCUS

title: Events in New Jersey
description: COMEDY

title: Correction: What Adams Saw Through His Lens
description: An article and a map on April 27 about Ansel Adamss photographs of Yosemite National Park misstated the location of a tunnel, and a correction in this space on May 11 misspelled the name of the tunnel. It is the Wawona  not Wauwona  Tunnel and it is on the western end of Yosemite Valley, not on the parks southern end.

title: Hungarian Rhapsody
description: For years, the Hungarian menu has stuck to tradition  hearty paprika-accented dishes, tokaji wine and the national brandy known as palinka. But these days theres bright, creative energy in Budapest, as chefs and bartenders give a new spin to old ideas.

title: The Birth of a Nation, 1948
description: IT was Friday, May 14, 1948. I was sitting in the press section of the United Nations General Assembly in its temporary quarters at Flushing Meadow in Queens. I felt my heart thumping. We journalists were waiting impatiently to see who would win a tug of war taking place in Washington.

title: John Cusack Goes to War
description: POLITICAL satire has its work cut out for it in the current environment. An unpopular war, the tortured rhetoric of a government defending its various pratfalls and news media that many see as complicit in the mess have created a burlesque  one that may not require annotation or exaggeration. Not that John Cusack isnt willing to give it a whirl. His War, Inc., which opens in New York and Los Angeles this weekend, is a satire that goes over the top and stays there.

title: Lee Finds Location, and Success Follows
description: Cliff Lee, a left-hander who won 18 games in 2005, reached a low point in his career last year when he was left off the Cleveland Indians postseason roster. It was an expected move after he produced a 6.29 earned run average in 20 games and was sent down to the minors for 10 starts.

title: Escape plan
description: A world apart from the seedy foot-rub joints on every Beijing block, Zenspa occupies a hushed courtyard residence in the Chaoyang district. Inside the colorfully lacquered structure, the Hong Kong interior designer David Ng has created a modern retreat where treatments like a fresh milk bath and gold-leaf scrub are administered in suites arranged around a reflecting pool. House 1, 8A Xiaowuji Lu; 011-86-10-8731-2530; www.zenspa.com.cn.

title: Provence Profound
description: Many travelers to the Vaucluse are like me: they believe that among the joys life can provide, one of the most moving is to plant oneself before the sausage stand in the Place de lglise, in lIsle-sur-la-Sorgue, during the Sunday market, and just gawk and taste. Who knew that human ingenuity could craft of simple animal flesh and fat (with some addenda) so many wonders? Lets enumerate. Theres sausage in the tradition of Arles, sausage with marc brandy, extra-lite sausage (why bother?), sausage with herbs, boar sausage, duck sausage, spicy sausage, Corsican figatelli, pure pork sausage, sausage with wild mushrooms, donkey sausage (!) and at least 40 other kinds. There are French things here that, even given todays global market, you just arent going to find in the United States. The cheese stands and the olive stands are similarly dazzling.

title: More Than Snappy Comebacks
description: Our elders, who remember American life before World War II, swear that people were nicer to one another then. My father always said that. Neil Simon makes the point convincingly in Lost in Yonkers, his Pulitzer Prize-winning 1991 play. And the Schoolhouse Theater is currently demonstrating it with a production that radiates warmth from beginning to end.

title: No Internship Yet? Theres Still Time
description: Q. You still havent found an internship for the summer. Is it too late?

title: Trenton Tea Party
description: You dont see a lot of puppets having afternoon tea. But DoDo and DaDa have a standing invitation in Cecilias Last Tea Party, a modest but ravishing new piece of theater well served by the Passage Theater Companys production in Trenton.

title: In-Store: Maine Event
description: 1. His Portland, Me.-based store and fashion label Rogues Gallery may be more stylish than salty, but Alex Carletons supercool riffs on sailor and workmans garb draw heavily from local traditions. I grew up on Cape Cod and am passionate about the sea and the history of the region, he says. I moved to Maine because it reminds me of what New England used to be. 41 Wharf Street; (207) 553-1999; dandyrogue.com.

title: In His Former Home, a Spirited Randolph
description: Willie Randolph was pacing as much as he could pace in the narrow, crowded Mets dugout. He moved 15 feet to his left, then 15 feet to his right. It was not the type of manic pacing that happens in a maternity ward, but it was a brief, tense walk.

title: For Ochoa, No Shortage of Birdies or Confidence
description: CLIFTON, N.J.  It seemed destined. Lorena Ochoa, the 26-year-old Mexican who has dominated the L.P.G.A. Tour the past three years, took the lead Saturday in the $2 million Sybase Classic.

title: Immigrants Children Find Better Lives, Study Shows
description: A decade-long study of adult children of immigrants to the New York region has concluded that they are rapidly entering the mainstream and doing better than their parents in terms of education and earnings  even outperforming native-born Americans in many cases.

title: Bitter Young Things
description: The Israeli writer Etgar Keret is a genius, although its not entirely apparent in The Girl on the Fridge, his new story collection. New in this case means newly published, not newly written. These stories date from the mid-1980s, when Keret was a young man in the army, just starting to develop the powerful and unsettling voice that would turn him into an acclaimed spokesman for his generation of Israelis  and gain him an enthusiastic foreign audience with the publication of a collection called The Nimrod Flipout.

title: Plane Crash in New Jersey Kills 2
description: A small airplane crashed in a wooded area near an airport in Ocean County, N.J., on Saturday, killing two passengers and critically injuring the planes other two occupants, officials said.

title: Putting Science to Work in the Kitchen
description: HARTFORD

title: An Alarm Is Blaring: Time to Buy
description: MARKET timing  trying to jump into or out of the stock market just before rallies and declines  is notoriously difficult. Most investors would probably be better off sticking with a buy-and-hold strategy.

title: Death in Venice
description: Official justice being arbitrary in Donna Leons gorgeously written but deeply melancholic Venetian police procedurals, the task of her detective, Commissario Guido Brunetti, isnt so much to solve a crime as to find a way of bearing the pain and horror of it. THE GIRL OF HIS DREAMS (Atlantic Monthly, $24), the 17th book in this superlative series, restates Leons theme with more intensity than usual, opening with the burial of Brunettis mother and his sad thoughts about the transitory nature of life.

title: A New Place Satisfies the Craving for Italian
description: IF I lived near Lucianos Italian Ristorante and Lounge, my weekends would be calmer. I wouldnt feel the need to make double batches of marinara, or 96 meatballs at a time, just to freeze some for the hectic weeknights ahead.

title: The Horse, Familiar and Unfamiliar
description: Perhaps the most interesting thing about The Horse  a new exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History  is how remote its subject seems, how completely the horse has faded from the everyday life of ordinary people.

title: Ho Hum, Its Just Another Senate Race
description: TRENTON

title: Readers Picks: Prague
description: Selected reader suggestions on Prague, compiled from user comments on the Travel sections Web site, nytimes.com/travel.

title: Mugabe Opponent Cancels Return to Zimbabwe
description: JOHANNESBURG  Zimbabwes opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, suddenly canceled on Saturday his planned return home, where he would have begun campaigning in the June 27 presidential runoff election, after his party received what his spokesman called credible, specific intelligence about a plot to kill him.

title: Edifice complex
description: As construction cranes continue to crawl through the city, architecture in Beijing is bound to have its highs and lows. Here, a few top projects.

title: What a Deal: Trash for Treasuries
description: SAVING the nations financial system from reckless banks and brokerage firms is an enormous job, heaven knows. But somebodys got to do it, so the Federal Reserve Board, with its taxpayer-funded balance sheet, stepped in.

title: Aiming to Coach Students to Excellence in Exams
description: NEWARK

title: Cold War? What Cold War?
description: If youre going to make a stage musical out of a television show, Happy Days is not a bad choice. All that cheerful white-bread 1950s innocence. All those instant audience associations with beloved characters and the actors who played them. The show wont ever win a Pulitzer Prize (or the musical-comedy equivalent), but the Goodspeed Opera Houses bouncy new production delivers a pleasant if not transporting evening, and  most important  the Fonz (Joey Sorge) is cool.

title: Can a Dead Brand Live Again?
description: Do you remember Brim?

title: Datebook
description: DETROIT

title: The Ashes
description: There have been good novels about living in the post-9/11 world (Ian McEwans Saturday), pretentious ones (Don DeLillos Falling Man) and sentimental ones (Jonathan Safran Foers Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close). But sorting through the pile of so-called 9/11 novels is a sad exercise, one that grows more pointless by the day. Theyre all 9/11 novels now.

title: When Shakira Calls, Even the Shy Appear
description: The Mexican telecommunications billionaire Carlos Slim Hel does not seem to like appearing in public, but he apparently could not resist an invitation from the Colombian pop star Shakira and about a dozen other Latin music stars.

title: In Westchester, Many Seem Able to Wait Out the Storm
description: THE real estate troubles that have been plaguing the rest of the nation are now hitting hard in Westchester, with markedly fewer sales, according to a report released last month by the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service.

title: Beating the Bushes for a Bargain Ticket
description: IS it still possible to find cheap airfares? With prices rising  the average cost of an airline ticket in the United States was up 10.2 percent in March, compared with a year ago, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics  and with airlines raising fees on everything from ticket changes to checked bags, its no wonder that a lot of travelers are talking about just staying home this summer.

title: In Iran, Debate Over an Article of Faith
description: TEHRAN  In his three years as president of Iran, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad has been harshly criticized in the West. But he is increasingly drawing fire from Shiite clerics here, who accuse him of using religion to distract attention from his governments failure to deliver on promises of prosperity and political freedoms.

title: Past the Sound Barrier, on a Business Jet
description: SPEED sells in the business-jet world, where Gulfstream Aerospace recently announced a hot new heavy-metal model, the G650, due for delivery in 2012.

title: Street Cred Vienna
description: Trends dont take hold easily in Vienna. This is a city charmed by its own traditions  a seventh-generation bootmaker, an Adolf Loos-designed haberdashery. Still, hats are suddenly huge in town, most obviously in the Museumsquartier, where the cool kids are all rocking headgear. But this is no passing fancy for trucker caps or a Pete Doherty trilby. Driving the craze is the 105-year-old hatmaker Mhlbauer, which has lately been revitalized by the fourth-generation owner Klaus Mhlbauers clever designs and savvy marketing (Elfie Semotan shot his current ad campain). His newsboy caps, perforated leather fedoras and unisex turbans have become hipster staples. Mhlbauer. Seilergasse 10; 011-43-53-352-6912; muehlbauer.at. MARKUS EBNER

title: Even in the Hamptons, Homes Are Slow to Sell
description: HOME sales on Long Island continued to slide in the first quarter of 2008, with even the usually resilient East End vacation market falling on sluggish times.

title: The Sophisticated Traveler: Hit The Hay
description: No longer just for beach totes and barnyards, straw has become a summer favorite of designers looking to stay cool. Witness Salvatore Ferragamos retro tote ($650; ferragamo.com), Tom Fords posh panama hat ($790; tomford.com) and Anya Hindmarchs oversize clutch adorned with amethyst ($370; anyahindmarch.com). Thinking outside the picnic basket, Lanvin has made a pair of raffia platform sandals with an ostrich heel ($1,435; lanvin.com). And the French designer Alexis Mabille has even raised a crop of

title: Yes, Its a Cooperative. But for Whom?
description: THE traditional idea of agricultural cooperatives is that farmers have more muscle to negotiate prices when they band together.

title: We Are Now Beginning Our Descent
description: At four a.m., when it was still dark and an hour before the Fajr prayer, Sarina Najafi got up, washed, dressed, ate a hasty breakfast of lavash and cheese and left her family's apartment on the tenth floor of a modern block on the southern outskirts of the Iranian city of Esfehan.

title: Phillis Levin, Jack Shanewise
description: Phillis Marna Levin and Dr. Jack Stacey Shanewise were married on Saturday evening at the Century Association in New York. Rabbi Richard A. Davis officiated at the ceremony, and the Very Rev. Dr. James A. Kowalski, an Episcopal priest, participated.

title: Blade Runner
description: In the 1980s, the distinguished but now forgotten Paris decorator Christian Badin would pose for design magazines with an old-fashioned watering can, dribbling water on the chunky Elizabethan rush matting in his apartment in an 18th-century htel particulier. While connoisseurs of the Rolls-Royce of vegetal floor coverings nodded mischievously, many more shrunk at the thought of spores, mildew and the ravishing parquet de Versailles underneath. Watering your parquet? Quelle horreur.

title: Yes, Manhattans Over There. What of It?
description: The Living In column on May 4, about Maspeth, Queens, incorrectly listed a Kiwanis flea market as an upcoming event. There will not be a flea market today.

title: Park Slope: Where Is the Love?
description: POOR Union Hall. First, there was the tempest in a sippy cup stirred up in Brooklyn last February by this bar-brunch-boccie spots ban on children in strollers. And just last week, a subcommittee of the Park Slope community board  swayed by an army of pitchfork-wielding locals  dealt the joint a harsh, if symbolic blow: no liquor license renewal until you do something about the noise. Though the full board overruled the committee within days, the blogospheres critics and conspiracy theorists had already drawn their conclusions: Its the revenge of the Stroller Moms.

title: Stock Gains Defy Reports of Weakness
description: The stock market gained ground last week, despite surging oil prices and sharp declines in consumer confidence and in the construction of single-family homes.

title: Aria! Action! Making Opera a Directors Art
description: HERE is a treasure. Opera DVDs tumble out by the dozens nowadays, too often featuring routine performances of recent productions that hardly seem worth preserving. In contrast Arthauss scholarly and imposing Walter Felsenstein Edition offers a fascinating glimpse of an important moment in operatic history now vanished.

title: Another Side of Dr. House, in Sitcom Mode
description: HUGH LAURIE has a long rsum in British television comedy, from Blackadder to a stint as P. G. Wodehouses highborn twit, Bertie Wooster. Fans of Mr. Lauries current series, the medical drama House, may have a hard time reconciling his sarcastic and saturnine diagnostician with the goggle-eyed goofballs hes made a career of playing. But there was a transition between the two, now available as a DVD: the six-episode 2003 British comedy Fortysomething.

title: A Rock, a Hard Place and an Exit Strategy
description: DO you feel that youre working harder and harder to get ahead financially, but cant even seem to stay in the same place? Do you feel trapped by larger forces that are increasing your cost of living but lowering your income? Do you worry about losing your job or having to change your career, even as news reports say the overall economy is growing and you see a privileged few enjoying unparalleled prosperity?

description: THE BASICS

title: Garlic Defanged
description: Its often been said that chefs must be a little crazy. Those who advance this theory usually cite the willful pursuit of long hours and low pay under punishing conditions, the erratic behavior and temperament that tend toward what might generously be described as artistic. This is a lie, a cruel stereotype that I, as a perfectly sane chef, flatly reject. Well, I do have one quirk that might be considered a little eccentric: I dont like garlic.

title: Q&A
description: I am taking three teenagers to Paris in June and will be doing day trips from there. I was thinking of taking a trip to Bruges, Belgium, because it sounds cool. Is there enough there to keep the kids interested for a day?  Colleen McCloskey, Catonsville, Md.

description: Londons venerable Connaught has snagged Hlne Darroze, the two-Michelin-star chef whos earned a cult following at her eponymous Paris kitchen. As part of the Mayfair hotels $138 million makeover, Darroze will open her first of three dining rooms in June with a restaurant designed by India Mahdavi.

title: Counting Classroom Seats in a Booming City
description: STEPHANIE PEDERSON, an author of books on beauty and health and the mother of a kindergartner named Leif, first became aware of the problem in September. It was Leifs first day at Public School 116, on East 33rd Street in Kips Bay, and Ms. Pederson had just arrived to drop him off.

title: Captain Kangaroo
description: People always tell me, Finally I feel like Im in Australia, even if theyve been in the country for weeks, Craig Wickham said as we barreled down a red dirt road on Kangaroo Island. Wickham is tall and graceful, with tan skin and a salt-and-pepper buzz cut. He grew up on a farm on the islands north coast and now owns the Exceptional Kangaroo Island touring company, which has been taking travelers around this island, 10 miles off the coast of southern Australia, for nearly 20 years. Beyond the dusty windshield of our Land Cruiser scrolled great arcades of silvery gum trees, tossing dappled sunlight onto the road. Every once in a while the greenery dropped away, revealing the islands famous limestone cliffs and aquamarine water, bright flashes of color amid sedate browns and greens. K. I. encapsulates everything people were hoping to find here in Australia, Wickham said. You can have a lot of people lost in the landscape and you never feel that the land is crowded.

title: Lottery Numbers
Derby Winner Cruises to Victory at Preakness
description: BALTIMORE  The first time Kent Desormeaux came to this venerable old racetrack, he was a kid from the bayou, barely removed from Louisiana bush track match races where boys like him, as part of their early lessons, rode against horses strapped with bags of rocks, or a rooster, and sometimes a monkey. He was the Cajun Kid, who won nine riding titles in Maryland and still holds a single-season record for victories here  599 of them in 1989.

title: Drilling for Defeat?
description: Nearly two decades ago, Republicans won the West by linking Democrats to environmentalists, who supposedly cared more for the spotted owl and other favored species than they did for the jobs of loggers or miners. But now, as a boom in natural-gas drilling reshapes the region, Western Democrats have found success recasting environmentalism as a defense of threatened water supplies, fishing spots and hunting grounds. As a result, the party may hold the advantage this fall in the regions key Congressional races. The simultaneous rise of Western energy production and the Western Democrat is no coincidence.

description: SEATTLE

title: Who Needs to Travel When Theres Home?
description: How much have you really explored your neighborhood? Theres the diner where youve never eaten, the store youve never bothered to enter, the statue in the park that commemorates something  youve never found out what. Who needs London or Paris, with these cultural riches so close at hand?

description: WEI WEI SHANNON and Andrew Gluckman occupy one of the more eccentric spaces in Manhattan.

description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Pakistans ambassador to Afghanistan, who was kidnapped three months ago by Taliban militants as he traveled in Pakistans tribal area, was released Friday night, the government said.

title: Brooklyn Public School Is a Big Winner at National Championships
description: At the elementary school national championships in Pittsburgh last weekend, public schools won many of the top prizes. But there was controversy when one team had to split its squad and when another won a division with players who might have had an unfair advantage.

title: The Scars of Losing a Home
description: ACROSS the United States, there were 243,353 foreclosure filings in April alone, nearly three times the total in the same month just two years ago, according to RealtyTrac, a company that follows the numbers. The trend is unmistakable, and suggests that, without government intervention, many millions of American families will be losing their homes before long.

title: Whose Rain Forest Is This, Anyway?
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  For as long as most can remember, Brazil has gazed nervously at maps of the vast, mostly uninhabited territory of the Amazon rain forest.

title: Not Much Help for the Polar Bear
description: Boxed into a corner by the courts and its own scientists, the Bush administration agreed last week to place the polar bear under the protection of the Endangered Species Act. The decision was the clearest official acknowledgment that the bear, its hunting grounds diminished by shrinking summer ice, is seriously at risk.

title: Her Goats, Her Cheese
description: Five years ago, with her children grown and her motherly instincts still strong, Lisa Schwartz bought two American Alpine goats. In short order, her herd grew from 2 to 36. Standing in her milking barn on a recent spring day, with nanny goats stuttering and butting heads and their kids bleating incessantly, Ms. Schwartz cradled a newborn in her arms and said, A psychologist could have a field day with me.

title: Thinking About California. Maybe Gonna Get Married.
description: As soon as the California Supreme Court ruled Thursday that gay men and lesbians had a constitutional right to marry, my partner and I started getting the calls: When would we head West to get hitched?

title: A Virgin Islands Invitation
description: The United States Virgin Islands Department of Tourism is directing marketing to Caribbean cruisers who would like to stay a little longer after their time at sea has ended. The USVI Six to Six promotion entices travelers who spend about six hours visiting the ports of St. John, St. Croix or St. Thomas on cruises to remain on land six days longer through freebies that include a sixth day of lodging, a bottle of Cruzan rum, a sixth day of car rental, a $60 gift certificate and a coupon book with a value of $626.

description: WHEN several major oil companies agreed earlier this month to pay nearly $424 million to settle a federal lawsuit brought by scores of water providers claiming damages from the gasoline additive M.T.B.E., one Long Island provider took the largest share by far.

description: Nightclubbing is a relatively new pastime in this otherwise conservative town. And the capital is certainly making up for lost time, with a host of new clubs catering to a range of nocturnal passions.

title: Born Supremacy
description: Style Map | Barcelona: Once a neglected tangle of narrow streets around the Picasso Museum and the church of Santa Maria del Mar, the Born district has slowly shed its gritty image to become Barcelonas version of the West Village. The cafe-lined squares and bosky lanes are filled with young local talent offering their own bold, distinctly Spanish take on fashion, design and cuisine. DALE FUCHS

description: It is true that Big Browns stallion rights were sold to Three Chimneys Farm for more than $50 million. Michael Iavarone, the president of International Equine Acquisitions Holdings and a co-owner of Big Brown, confirmed he signed a deal Saturday on his way to Pimlico after a week of negotiations.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE ASSAULT ON REASON, by Al Gore. (Penguin, $16.) The former vice president pulls out all the stops in this blistering assessment of the Bush administration and the state of public discourse in America, as Michiko Kakutani described it in The Times. Gore argues that reason, logic and truth seem to play a sharply diminished role in the way America now makes important decisions; one example is the administrations tendency to ignore expert advice (from generals and scientists) so it can promote its ideological agenda.

title: Instead of Fistfights, Fashion at a Troubled High School
description: CAMDEN, N.J.  Notable happenings at Camden High School this year included a cafeteria brawl that led to the arrest of 18 teenagers and left a police officer with a bruised face, a 14-year-old boy smuggling a gun loaded with hollow-point bullets into school in his backpack, the replacement of a principal and a hip-hop fashion show that turned the auditorium into a South Jersey version of a Bryant Park tent.

title: Elena Wechsler and John Simpson
description: IT came as no surprise to anyone who knew her that Dr. Elena Wechsler would find herself with a man who won her heart with ducks. Her childhood home in Glen Mills, Pa., was often referred to as the zoo by friends. Besides caring for the familys own menagerie, Dr. Wechslers mother, a veterinarian, was known to care for an injured flying squirrel in the bathtub or give dialysis to a dog in the kitchen.

description: RIVERHEAD

title: Times Square to Have New Tourist Center
description: Befuddled tourists in Times Square in New York will welcome the Broadway Concierge and Ticket Center (www.broadwayleague.com), scheduled to open next month. The center, in the Times Square Information Center at 1560 Broadway, will provide information on Broadway shows in six languages (English, Japanese, German, Spanish, Portuguese and French); offer ticket sales; make restaurant, hotel and car service reservations; distribute free neighborhood maps; and share parking information. The center will also customize packages, like the Regular Guys Guide to Broadway, which might be dinner at ESPN Zone, tickets to Stomp and bowling afterward).

title: Letters: Where Alaa Al Aswany Is Writing From
description: Alaa Al Aswany is grateful for the extensive coverage of his life and work in The New York Times Magazine, but he has asked the American University in Cairo Press, as his principal English-language publisher and international literary agent, to inform your readers of the following crucial clarifications (April 27).

title: A Masterful Caricaturist and His Lithographs
description: In 1830, newly installed on the throne, King Louis-Philippe boldly declared an end to censorship laws. So began a golden era in the French press, with publishers and editors seizing the opportunity to start political newspapers and journals.

title: Kimberly Wilson, Michael Portnoy
description: Kimberly Ann Wilson and Michael Steven Portnoy were married on Saturday evening at the Bushnell Center for the Performing Arts in Hartford. Stephen M. Gromko, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Road Scholar
description: The new book A Road Trip Journal (Phaidon, $250) documents a 1973 cross-country drive the photographer Stephen Shore made from New York to the West Coast and back, one of many such trips he took during the 1970s. The volume recreates the scrapbook Shore made at the time: what TV shows he watched (the Watergate hearings, All in the Family), the mileage he clocked, which locations he shot (Sha-Mar Beauty Salon, Chestnut St.). He also included every piece of paper he collected  receipts, parking and movie tickets, and, most important, postcards. I found them fascinating because they were not trying to be works of art, he says. They just show you the main street, the so-and-so motel. I was attracted to that matter-of-factness. Ultimately, it was that matter-of-factness that had a big influence on his own pictures; although made with a view camera on a tripod, they are printed to look like everyday snapshots.

title: A Musical Collaboration Thats Making Noise Beyond Bridgeport
description: BRIDGEPORT

title: Over the Long Haul, Diesels Appeal
description: THE first fuel crisis that followed the Arab oil embargo of 1973 persuaded Americans to give diesel cars a try. These proliferated at first, but quickly faded under a foul-smelling cloud.

title: Critic Earns I Told You So in Meadowlands Project
description: Lyndhurst

title: Along Cherished Lanes, the Last Strikes and Spares
description: MANY of the gray-haired patrons of Woodhaven Lanes bowling alley in Glendale, Queens, have bowled there since they could barely lift a bowling ball. Romances, friendships and competitive spirits have budded on its 60 lanes, and wedding pictures were once taken on Lanes No. 1 and 2. The bowling alley is a place where its not uncommon to hear someone earnestly declare, Bowling is my life.

title: Hedging Their Bets
description: The saying everything old is new again came true during the Milan furniture fair last month, when Meta made its debut. The company, which was created by Mallett, the venerable antiques dealer, pairs the fine materials and techniques of the past with contemporary design. Its first collection includes objects like a solid-gold box by Hani Rashid and Lise Anne Couture and a modern take on the traditional lantern by Matali Crasset. But its showstopper is the Fig Leaf wardrobe by Tord Boontje, who helped make a black-clad design world learn to love flora and fauna some years back. The wardrobes hand-forged ironwork structure is adorned with 616 individually attached leaves, each of which is hand-enameled on both the front and back and signed by its respective enameler. Inside is a cast-bronze tree, the branches of which offer a poetic alternative to the conventional hanging rod. Boontje said he could see the wardrobe in a minimalist house as well as in a palace, next to a Gainsborough.

title: Court Without a Quorum
description: Appointment to the United States Supreme Court is an extraordinary honor that conveys the power to influence the course of American law and justice. It does not seem too much to ask that sitting justices order their personal financial affairs to minimize the potential for conflicts of interest requiring them to sit out cases.

title: In Rhode Island, Deficit Keeps Growing
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  When Rhode Island officials learned that they faced a budget shortfall this year of $168 million, they began pruning services.

title: For Senate, Clinton (Bill)
description: Charleston, S.C.

title: As Prices Rise, Crime Tipsters Work Overtime
description: To gas prices, foreclosure rates and the cost of rice, add this rising economic indicator: the number of tips to the police from people hoping to collect reward money.

title: Chvez Seizes Greater Economic Power
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Faced with shortages of foods, building materials and other staples, President Hugo Chvez is intensifying state control of the Venezuelan economy through a new wave of takeovers of private companies and the creation of government-controlled ventures with allies like Cuba and Iran.

title: An E-Commerce Empire, From Porn to Puppies
description: TRIBUTES on the Web site of Richard J. Gordons company strike all of the uplifting chords one would expect of a digital maverick. He is described as a trailblazing businessman who is operating in the front ranks of those transforming the Internet into the global marketplace of the future.

title: G.O.P. Eyes Two Westchester Senate Seats
description: EAGER to preserve their majority in the State Senate, Republican leaders are beefing up efforts to capture the two Westchester seats held by Democrats, including that of the longtime Senator Suzi Oppenheimer.

title: Ink-Stained and Loving It
description: ITS hard to look authentically rebellious or menacing these days, when even well-behaved businessmen wear earrings and ponytails and college students destined for quiet suburban lives have body piercings and tattoos.

title: Costs of Living
description: The timing for Jeffrey D. Sachss new book on how to avert global economic catastrophe couldnt be better, with food riots in Haiti, oil topping $120 a barrel and a gnawing sense that theres just less of everything  rice, fossil fuels, credit  to go around. Of course, weve been here before. In the 19th century, Thomas Malthus teased out the implications of humans reproducing more rapidly than the supply of food could grow. In 1972, the Club of Rome published, to much hoopla, a book entitled Limits to Growth. The thesis: There are too many people and too few natural resources to go around. In 1978, Mr. Smith, my sixth-grade science teacher, proclaimed that there was sufficient petroleum to last 25 to 30 years. Well, as Yogi Berra once may have said, Its hard to make predictions, especially about the future.

title: Earthquake Opens Gap in Controls on Media
description: SHANGHAI  Two and a half hours after a huge earthquake struck Sichuan Province on Monday, an order went out from the powerful Central Propaganda Department to newspapers throughout China. No media is allowed to send reporters to the disaster zone, it read, according to Chinese journalists who are familiar with it.

title: Letters: The Queen of the New Age
description: For 20 years, there has been a copy of Heal Your Body, by Louise L. Hay, at my bedside, and I subscribe to her descriptions of the mind/body connections, but I was appalled to read Hays response to questions about victims of genocide and the Holocaust (April 4). Bad karma? Former lives? What enormities could they possibly have committed to deserve their horrific fates? Im sorry that Hay thinks human cruelty, or autoimmune disease, for that matter, is a result of karmic transgressions. For a woman with her influence, coyly sidestepping with Thats just my opinion doesnt fly.

title: Paying Off the Refs
description: I officiate youth hockey. In nonleague games, it is the coaches who pay the two officials. At one game, one teams coach (whom I knew) paid the other official the normal fee but tucked away extra money for me. When my co-official asked if I had gotten the same wage, I said yes so he would not feel cheated. Was it ethical for this coach to pay me extra when the other official and I are the same age, have the same experience and both did the same amount of work?  A.M., NEW JERSEY

title: A Thicket of Easy Loans That Entangled One Mortgage Holder
description: Redding

title: Pixels at an Exhibition
description: What do video artists make of YouTube? Every minute, 10 hours of video are uploaded to the video-sharing site, which now shows hundreds of millions of videos each day. The place is a mess. Maybe artists should avoid it altogether.

title: California Ruling on Same-Sex Marriage Fuels a Battle, Rather Than Ending It
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Just hours after the California Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that same-sex couples have a constitutional right to marry, Mathew D. Staver was already raising money to overturn the decision.

title: Art Just for the Arts Sake in Berlin
description: THE Fifth Berlin Biennial for Contemporary Art, which runs through June 15, may well be remembered for signaling the beginning of a new curatorial movement: Slow Art.

title: Letters
description: Mad Pride

title: Table talk
description: The citys food scene may be getting haute, but for every reimagined egg roll theres also a triedand-true original worth seeking out. Here, three approaches to high-and-low Beijing eating.

title: Dreams and Disaster
description: On long bus rides, David Samuels used to fake a Southern accent and tell strangers he was raised on Army bases rather than in the Orthodox Jewish household in Brooklyn where he grew up. There was something scary about the ease with which I became a new person, a fictional character, he has written. I felt cold inside, and detached from my own body. Eventually he started listening more carefully to the stories of his fellow travelers, spending much of the last 10 years on the road for Harpers Magazine and The New Yorker, absorbing himself in the lives of a strange cross section of America: con men and fugitives, radicals and rap stars, addicts and politicians. Now we have his first collection of long-form journalism, a tribute to the twin American traditions of self-invention and self-deceit.

title: Tori Amos | Songbird
description: For the musician Tori Amos, the best way to travel is to step onstage. Performing is like taking a magic carpet ride, she says. Her songs cover a wide range of subjects, from sexuality to religion to designer accessories. (Sample lyric: Somewhere in the hills of Ireland, theres a Prada bag.) Comic Book Tattoo, an anthology of graphic art inspired by her songs, is due out in July. The book follows last years Legs and Boots, a series of live bootlegs sold through her Web site, and her American Doll Posse World Tour; ever the provocateur, she invited Pope Benedict XVI to her show in Rome. (He never R.S.V.P.ed.) Despite his absence, Amos still managed to feel a higher power. Of giving a concert, she says: Its a legal way to get ecstasy. But there is less of a hangover if you go my way. ALEX HAWGOOD

description: CHICAGO

title: Senator Kennedy Is Hospitalized After a Seizure
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, leader of the nations most storied political dynasty, was airlifted to Boston from Cape Cod on Saturday where he was hospitalized after suffering a seizure.

description: We often expect little from politicians; our standards for athletes, whether we admit it or not, are higher.

description: DETROIT  The auto industrys longest strike in more than 40 years, a walkout at a parts supplier that disrupted production at 32 General Motors plants, will end within days if the picketing workers ratify a tentative agreement reached late Friday with their employer, American Axle and Manufacturing.

title: The Ingnue Who Roared
description: AS Nellie Forbush, the sweetheart from Little Rock in the smashing new revival of Rodgers & Hammersteins South Pacific, Kelli OHara deserves a medal for single-handedly rescuing the ingnue from extinction.

title: When the Kremlin Tried a Little Openness
description: A dash of openness can be a dangerous thing in an autocratic state.

title: Correction
description: A brief report in the Suits column on May 4 about Sheldon Adelson, chief executive of the Las Vegas Sands Corporation, referred imprecisely to his perks at the company. Although he is entitled to free use of dry-cleaning services at the companys Venetian Resort and of the gym in the resorts Canyon Ranch Spa, he says he has never used these benefits.

title: Letters: Blocking the Transmission of Violence
description: Alex Kotlowitzs insightful piece (May 4) on the cycles of violence that plague many communities makes the points that in matters of health, prevention is more effective than punishment, and that ending any addiction requires us to teach alternatives. Our own experience and a vast body of rigorous research suggest a few simple directives. Support prevention programs that start early, are rooted in community values and resources and are sustained over time. Focus on resources instead of deficits; embrace the hopes, skills and positive values of youth and communities, and build on that foundation. Teach alternatives to violence: anger management, empathy, communication, cooperation, conflict resolution and active community engagement help young people not only avoid violence; they also help inoculate them against the hopelessness that breeds these cycles.

title: Edging Closer in Cypruss Divided Capital
description: LIKE most of Nicosia, the Atolye Cadi Kazani Cafe feels nostalgic. It is awash in jazzy piano music, the scent of cardamom-spiced coffee and an Ottoman ambience that reminds the owner, Nilgun Guney, of her grandmothers house.

title: Alley Cats
description: While most of Beijings hutongs  narrow lanes snaking around historic courtyard houses  have come under the bulldozer, theres new life in the old Drum Tower district, where designers have opened hip boutiques.

title: Fielding Edlow, Larry Clarke
description: Fielding Edlow and Larry Clarke are to be married on Sunday in Santa Barbara, Calif. Rita Rivest, a friend of the couple who was appointed a deputy marriage commissioner for the occasion by Santa Barbara County, is to officiate at the Bacara Resort and Spa.

title: A Voice of Mother Russia, in English
description: JUDGING from the news lately, Russia is well on its way to restoring that old Evil Empire image. Military parades have returned to Red Square. Key businesses are choked by corruption or are under state control. Journalists who probe too deeply turn up dead. And critics of the Kremlin are jailed, pushed out of elections or, in one instance, mysteriously poisoned.

title: Penguins Hit Detour on Route to Finals
description: One victory from the Stanley Cup final, the Pittsburgh Penguins had faced little adversity through three rounds of playoffs.

title: Eastern Star
description: Beijing has been attracting plenty of attention (and controversy) lately. Love it or hate it, the Chinese capital is the boomtown of our times. As architects, chefs, designers and filmmakers  to say nothing of the Olympics  leave their mark, this once buttoned-down metropolis has become a stylish city of the future. BY AMY FABRIS-SHI

title: As Goes the Rest of the Nation, So Goes Connecticut
description: WINIFRED WILKINS did not need numbers to tell her about the state of real estate in Connecticut.

title: Subdivided We Fall
description: As catchy pop-social science coinages go, the Big Sort may not have quite the pith or resonance of, say, bobos or tipping points. But in attempting to define and argue the implications of the sweeping social and political balkanization that has swept across America over the last 30 years, Bill Bishop has set his sights ambitiously on David Brooks and Malcolm Gladwell territory: identifying a big, worldview-changing social science phenomenon, and interpreting it for a popular audience.

title: The Poetry of Barack Obama
description: Following are two poems by Barack Obama that were published in the Spring 1981 issue of Feast, a 51-page student literary journal that described itself as "a semi-annual journal of short poetry and fiction collected from the Occidental College community. The journal is no longer published, according to a college spokesman.

title: Where the Kids, Not the Stars, Are the Stars
description: ENGRAVED with the name Sopranus and looking not a little like a certain fictional New Jersey mobster, the faux-marble bust suggested a man no longer of this world. But in a Manhattan rehearsal space, Carmela Soprano was alive and kicking  literally  alongside Uncle Junior, Little Paulie and a trio of pint-sized henchmen in The Mezzo-Sopranos, a spoof of the HBO series of almost the same name.

title: Loosen Your Borscht Belt and Raise Your Highbrows
description: JEWISH arts in New York City. What, exactly, does that mean? A 19th-century Austrian menorah? D.J.s from Tel Aviv playing Prospect Park in Brooklyn? Jackie Mason cracking up an Off Broadway crowd with jokes that would not be funny  and would be offensive  from the mouth of anyone else?

title: Sealing Victory, Wagner Is Happy to Talk About It
description: Mets closer Billy Wagner, who questioned his teammates accountability on Thursday, was relieved to be talking about his pitching instead of his critical remarks on Saturday. Wagner notched the last four outs as the Mets defeated the Yankees, 7-4, at Yankee Stadium.

title: Democracy, Limited
description: When Bill Clinton was in the twilight months of his presidency, he made a compelling case that by integrating China into the world economy we would gradually undercut the viability of its authoritarian government. It was only a matter of time, he told an audience of American and Chinese students in March 2000, before a Net-savvy, rising middle class would begin to demand its rights, because when individuals have the power not just to dream, but to realize their dreams, they will demand a greater say.

title: Correction: Inside the List
description: A brief report in the Inside the List column on May 4 misstated the title of the Lawrence Durrell novel that was No. 8 on the fiction best-seller list of May 5, 1968. It is Tunc, not Tune.

title: Obama to Return to Iowa, Possibly to Claim Victory
description: Senator Barack Obama has chosen to spend Tuesday night not in Kentucky or Oregon, the two states that will be holding their primaries that day, or even at his home in Chicago. Instead, Mr. Obamas staff announced on Saturday, he will be returning to Iowa, where he won the Democratic caucuses way back in January and has at least two good reasons to revisit now.

title: Israel at 60
description: To the Editor:

title: The Story of Obama, Written by Obama
description: Barack Obama was a first-time author and rookie politician embarking upon his first run for public office. Hermene Hartman was the publisher of NDigo, a magazine in Chicago aimed at upscale black readers. As Ms. Hartman tells it, she got a call from Mr. Obama in the fall of 1995 saying he wanted to come and talk. He wanted her to read his newly published memoir.

title: Jane Austen Meets Nancy Drew
description: In Karen Joy Fowlers new novel, Wits End, set in Santa Cruz on the eve of the 2006 midterm election, a 29-year-old woman named Rima, whose entire nuclear family has died, comes to stay with her fairy godmother, the rich, outrageously successful mystery writer Addison Early. Sixty-four and unmarried, Addison lives near the beach with her housekeeper and her dachshunds in a sprawling, Hitchcockian mansion called Wits End (one, but not the only, justification for the books title). The house, which would make a fine up-coast annex to Disneyland, is littered with cutesy-macabre dollhouses  on a bedside table, in a kitchen corner, by the sink, on a shelf  each a meticulous replica of a murder scene from one of Addisons detective novels. Every diorama comes with a miniature corpse, wee props (a toy blue convertible, a cummerbund the size of a twist-tie, a lipstick slightly larger than a grain of rice), right down to its tiny clues and tiny gore. Addison likes to entertain her friends or fans (theres no difference  everyone she knows is obsessed with her genius and possesses an exhaustive mental concordance of her oeuvre) by sharing personal anecdotes; ruminating on admirers of her fictional detective, Maxwell Lane; and fulminating on Bush-era politics.

title: Trying to Sell Europeans on Connecticut Charm
description: NEW HAVEN

title: A Bid to Shield a Row of Sturdy Soldiers
description: GENERATIONS come and go on West End Avenue. White-collar types have replaced exiled Viennese Jews, and the Freudians in ground-floor suites have given way to cognitive behaviorists.

title: Doors Close, Doors Open, and the Homeless Trudge On
description: THE old brick building that sits behind a tall iron fence at East 30th Street and First Avenue has been a haven for the lost since 1931. From that year until 1984 it operated as Bellevue Psychiatric Hospital, and now its ivy-covered walls house some 600 homeless men, along with the main intake center for homeless men citywide. Soon, the building will provide more luxurious shelter: In March, the citys Economic Development Corporation announced plans to convert it into a hotel and conference center.

description: South Amityville, N.Y.

title: Andr Galerne, 81, an Entrepreneur of the Deep, Is Dead
description: Andr Galerne, who in the early 1960s brought together a band of rugged divers willing to descend hundreds of feet to repair oil rigs, lay cables or salvage something from a sunken vessel  starting what became the worlds largest privately owned deep-sea construction company  died on May 6 in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 81, and for more than 30 years had lived by the bay in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Abigail Fyten, Johan Aasbo
description: The Rev. Abigail Fagan Fyten, a Disciples of Christ minister, and Dr. Johan David Aasbo, a physician, were married on Saturday at the Quogue Chapel of the Westhampton Presbyterian Church in Quogue, N.Y. The Rev. Gretchen Steffenson, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated following a nondenominational Christian ceremony led by George Fitchett, a Quaker chaplain.

title: An Island Scorned
description: If the measure of a writers success is the ire he provokes, then V. S. Naipaul is a spectacular success in Trinidad. In this island nation of just over a million people, there is a widespread perception that he has jilted his homeland through unflattering portraits in his books and a string of cutting remarks over the years. History is built around achievement and creation; and nothing was created in the West Indies, Naipaul wrote in The Middle Passage (1962)  the first sign that he wasnt going to play the proud native son. A fresher wound came in 2001, when Naipaul omitted any mention of Trinidad from his initial press release after winning the Nobel Prize, which many here saw as a deliberate rebuff. And last year, during a visit sponsored by the University of the West Indies, Naipaul more than lived up to his reputation for cantankerousness, prompting disapproving press coverage after he snapped at a group of students at a Hindu girls high school.

title: Roach Qualifies
description: Melanie Roach, whose road to Beijing has been longer and more winding than many Olympic hopefuls, emerged from the United States weight lifting trials in Atlanta as the nations top qualifier.

title: A More Permanent Crash Pad
description: The Habitats column on May 4, about two friends who pooled their resources to buy a house in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, misstated the name of a thoroughfare in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, that one of them, Robin Scott, referred to as sort of a fashion parade. It is Bedford Avenue, not Bedford Street.

title: Profile in Courage
description: In 1956, Douglas McKay left the Eisenhower cabinet to go back to Oregon and run against Wayne Morse for the Senate. At the Portland airport, he read a ghostwritten arrival statement, took off his glasses and said, to snickers, Now Id like to add a few words of my own.

title: From Afterthought to Essential
description: BROADWAY has no shortage of unsung heroes. After actors, playwrights, directors and producers, name recognition drops off steeply. But many who work behind the scenes can take solace that they might win a prominent award or, failing that, at least find a union to represent them.

title: Letters: Young Gay Rites
description: I was surprised and saddened to note that although some of the couples mentioned (Benoit Denizet-Lewis, April 27) intend to have sex with multiple partners, there was no reference to sexually transmitted diseases, especially AIDS. It doesnt matter whether a marriage is gay or traditional: there is danger involved in such behavior. As The Times has reported, sexually transmitted diseases are increasing among just about every segment of the population.

title: Bold, Colorful and Detailed
description: Though he never achieved the fame of Grandma Moses, Ralph Fasanella, who died in 1997 at the age of 83, had a lot in common with her. He, too, was a self-taught, folk-primitive artist who created bold, colorful compositions loaded with minute detail.

title: At N.Y.U., a Reason for Students to Feel Good About All That Trash
description: By the end of their academic careers, students in the dormitories at New York University acquire a lot of knowledge. They also acquire a lot of stuff.

title: Letters: Biofuels for Jet Travel
description: To the Editor: The May 4 Green Traveler column (Trying to Lighten that Carbon Footprint) cites Friends of the Earths negative comments regarding Richard Bransons biofueled flight and the drawbacks of producing biofuels for air travel. Friends of the Earth is considering only the current state of biofuel technology. Mr. Branson showed a successful proof of concept that might have boosted the confidence of consumers, industry, policy makers and investors and catalyzed more biofuel research. Evidence that biofuels work in a high-risk and unforgiving mode of transportation is a major step forward in powering them past the novelty stage.

title: On The Q.t.: Paul Smith
description: Paul Smith calls London home, but hes a designer without borders, finding inspiration for clothes and furniture around the globe. His latest project  a travel-themed store in Heathrows new Terminal 5  reinvents the airport gift shop. Between takeoffs, Smith took the T Travel Questionnaire.

title: Lacrosse Teams Form Bonds in Durham
description: The reverberations from the false accusations against members of the Duke lacrosse team more than two years ago are still felt throughout the campus and the community of Durham, N.C. Lawsuits linger, controversy simmers over Duke players being granted an extra season of eligibility, and players say they occasionally detect tension when they wear Duke lacrosse gear around town.

title: Rumi Malott, Stephen Morales
description: Rumi Justine Malott, the daughter of Hiroko Iwami Malott and John R. Malott of Alexandria, Va., was married in New York on Saturday to Stephen A. Morales, a son of JoAnn Morales and Arturo Morales of East Brunswick, N.J. The Rev. Joseph S. Some remembered the older man fastidiously washing his car outside the white, two-story house. One believed the younger man might have owned a string of cellphone stores in Queens and New Jersey.

description: Aimee Elizabeth Torres and Alejandro Alfonso Latorre were married on Saturday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan. The Rev. George M. Witt, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: The McCain Doctrines
description: Whatever their disagreements on policy, United States senators, even in todays hyperpolitical climate, are reluctant to impugn one anothers motives or integrity.

title: Fixing the Military
description: The United States military is the worlds best. It is also in need of substantial repair. Two wars  the war of necessity in Afghanistan and President Bushs disastrous war of choice in Iraq  have worn out soldiers and equipment at an unprecedented rate. So alarming is the deterioration that many military commanders say the country is unable to sustain the current operation in Iraq let alone face down future threats.

title: Crash
description: All is suffering, say the Buddhists, but all is not tragic. Some is downright comical, as Caroline Adderson demonstrates in her second novel, Sitting Practice, in which a good man marries the love of his life and permanently disables her in a dumb automobile accident. His wry and sensible wife, now unable to walk, is game to wheel her way through lifes rich pageant, but self-blame paralyzes the husband and threatens the marriage. None of this should be amusing  except when its played out by Addersons surprising, generously realized characters.

title: Traveling Salesman, Nash Pitches Belief in Knicks
description: The Mike DAntoni Show is coming to New York this fall, with apologies to the Phoenix Suns.

title: Road Rules
description: Mao sneakers may be on every corner of Beijing, but the kitschiest bit of Maomorabilia has to be Madame Maos limousine. The bulletproof black stretch with red-velvet trim takes you on a 50-minute joy ride accompanied by a bottle of Mot & Chandon, a guide from the Red Detachment of Women and Maos voice crackling over the radio. $270; 011-86-10-8403-5308; redcapitalclub.com.cn.

title: Battlefield Notes
description: James Meeks fourth novel opens with a scene that seems stolen from a Tom Clancy thriller, albeit one with a sharply anti-American twist. While attacking an Iranian nuclear plant, American soldiers shoot hundreds of young women, one of whom catches the massacre on a video camera even as she is killed: She recorded it all, under the harsh lights. The American soldiers screaming at each other. ... The moving of the trucks into the mass of schoolgirls. The screams as their bodies went under the wheels.
