title: Mekhala Subramanian and James Attonito
description: Mekhala Subramanian, a daughter of Ananthi and Sethuraman Subramanian of Wake Forest, N.C., was married on Saturday evening to James Michael Attonito, the son of Kathleen and Joseph Attonito of East Quogue, N.Y. Pandit Umesh K. Jois, a Hindu priest, officiated at an Indian wedding ceremony at Loft Eleven in Manhattan.

title: McCain Can Run, but Bush Wont Hide
description: THE biggest gift President Bush has given his party this year was to keep his daughters wedding nearly as private as Connie Corleones. Now that his disapproval rating has reached the Nixon nadir of negativity, even a joyous familial ritual isnt enough to make the country glad to see him. The G.O.P.s best hope would be for both the president and Dick Cheney to lock themselves in a closet until the morning after Election Day.

title: Parents Sue Over Equestrians Death, Raising Safety Issues
description: The parents of a 17-year-old girl who died in a fall while competing in the Olympic equestrian sport of eventing have sued the sports governing body, her former trainer and others in a California court, claiming that the death was caused in part because the course was made more dangerous to make it more thrilling to spectators.

title: End in Sight for Bank Standoff
description: Northport

title: Katherine Patterson and Michael Gilles
description: Katherine Meghan Patterson, the daughter of the Rev. Caroline Johnson Patterson of Cranston, R.I., and Dr. Robert Bruce Patterson of Warwick, R.I., is to be married on Sunday to Michael James Gilles, the son of Jane Susan Jung and David Joseph Gilles of Madison, Wis. The Rev. Dr. Leslie S. Simonson, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at Fearrington Village in Pittsboro, N.C.

title: 36 Hours in Luang Prabang, Laos
description: THE Southeast Asia circuit  Vietnam, Cambodia and Thailand  is thick with travelers encountering familiar faces at the next required stop. (If its Tuesday, it must be Ho Chi Minhs Tomb.) The crowds are beginning to head to Laos as well  with both Vientiane and Luang Prabang emerging as the next potential hot spots for globe-trotting tourists. But the beguiling ancient capital of Luang Prabang, nestled between the Mekong and Nam Khan Rivers, is still a place that feels as if it is on the cusp of discovery. It is a town where one minute you are checking your e-mail messages at an Internet cafe next to giggling novices and the next you are walking on a bridge across the Nam Khan with views of farmers silently working in the lettuce fields with nary a tourist bus in sight.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the potential rise of biracial politics in the South referred incorrectly to a young man whom George Allen, a Republican senator seeking re-election in Virginia, called a macaca, widely considered to be a racial slur, during a campaign appearance in 2006. The young man, who was of Indian descent, was conducting opposition research for the Democrats; he was not heckling Mr. Allen.

title: Foreign Intelligence
description: When in Rome, why not eat as the Romans (really) do? One of the surest ways to get off the tourist grid is to read local guidebooks. Never mind if you dont speak their language  a handful of guides to Italy and France have symbols, numerical ratings and pictures that will steer you toward your next discovery. Osterie dItalia, from Slow Food Italy, recommends restaurants, organized geographically, with a snail icon to indicate that they follow Slow Food principles. If you like nonna-in-the-cucina places, its worth the weight. Another Italian bible, Ristoranti dItalia del Gambero Rosso, groups restaurants, trattorias and wine bars regionally. A numerical score is based on a 100-point scale, and a meter indicates value for your money. But the most important symbols are the forks (for restaurants) and shrimps (for wine bars): if you see a place with three, go. In France, Carnet de Route Omnivore is for anyone serious about 21st-century French cuisine. The annual book lists 200 experimental restaurants and highlights the best dish at each (under the heading Le Plat qui Change Tout). Accompanying recommendations of nearby hotels are a bonus. The same publisher also recently released Carnet de Vigne Omnivore, a guide to 200 small, artisanal vineyards, with handy regional maps. And for architecture, art and history lovers, theres Ouverts au Public: Le Guide du Patrimoine en France, which provides visiting information, photos and maps for more than 2,500 state-protected monuments. CHRISTINE MUHLKE

title: One Countrys Table Scraps, Another Countrys Meal
description: Grocery bills are rising through the roof. Food banks are running short of donations. And food shortages are causing sporadic riots in poor countries through the world.

title: In Courtroom 102, Focus Is on Sex Offenses
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: President Bush Calls for More Oil Exploration at Home
description: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt  President Bush said Saturday that Saudi Arabias decision to boost oil production by 300,000 barrels a day is something, but it doesnt solve our problem, and he called again on Congress to approve legislation allowing more oil exploration at home.

title: Correction: Where Many Ended Their Search for Paradise
description: A correction on May 4 of an April 13 article about the Marquesas in the South Pacific described two of the points of the so-called Polynesian Triangle incorrectly. Neither Hawaii, a state, nor Easter Island, a Chilean territory, is a country. In addition, Tahiti is included in the triangle, though it is not one of its points.

title: Correction: Cover Story: The King of Visceral Design
description: An article on April 27 about George Lois misidentified the creators of two advertising campaigns that his firm handled. Julian Koenig and Helmut Krone of Doyle Dane Bernbach created the Think small ads for Volkswagen, and John and Faith Hubley worked with Fletcher Richards, Calkins & Holden to produce the I want my Maypo ads; Mr. Lois did not create them.

title: That Stegner Fellow
description: If you were choosing an all-star team of 20th-century American writers to represent the liberal mind  construed expansively, not in narrowly political terms  you might have Lionel Trilling batting cleanup, Arthur Schlesinger Jr. hitting eighth and so on. But youd have to reserve a spot in the lineup for a non-Mormon graduate of the University of Utah (class of 1930) who spent some of his formative years in a tiny, windblown town in Saskatchewan, just across the border, a dry prairie region that couldnt support the farmers who had been encouraged by the Canadian government to settle there.

title: Journalism From the Bottom of the Boat
description: THE front-page articles out of Myanmar last Saturday and Sunday, a week after a cyclone hit the Irrawaddy Delta, told of horrible devastation and suffering  countless bodies floating face down in the river and canals, a landscape of toppled trees, flattened houses and bloated farm animals, and survivors without food, clean water or aid.

title: The Buck Starts Here
description: With the dollar as anemic as last years Brazilian models, even the most fortified travelers are looking for new, less pocket-emptying summer playgrounds. So where to go next? CHARLES RUNNETTE

title: The Hakawati
description: Listen. Allow me to be your god. Let me take you on a journey beyond imagining. Let me tell you a story.

title: Correction: Classical Music
description: A classical listing in the Summer Festivals section last Sunday omitted one of the cities where the Oregon Bach Festival takes place. In addition to Portland, where the festival opens, it takes place in Eugene. Another classical listing misidentified the director of the new chamber version of William Bolcoms opera A Wedding, to be performed at the Music Academy of the West. The director is Chas Rader-Shieber  not Marilyn Horne, director of the voice program at the academy, which is presenting the production.

title: 30 Seconds With Penny Marshall
description: Jack Nicholson gets most of the attention, but the Bronx-born actress and director Penny Marshall is a regular at Los Angeles Lakers home games, too. Marshall, 64, who played Laverne DeFazio opposite Cindy Williamss Shirley Feeney in the sitcom Laverne & Shirley from 1976 to 1983, has season tickets to the Lakers and the Clippers. Her seat at Staples Center is along the baseline, cater-corner to the visitors bench. During halftime of a playoff game against the Jazz, Marshall stood to stretch her legs and, while surveying the Utah bench, answered a few questions. KAREN CROUSE

title: Despite H.I.V., Fighting to Maintain Health and a Positive Attitude
description: Patricia Clouden dresses in a whirl of color, from her bright African dress to her shiny green toenail polish. She is a grandmother of eight who gets noticed in her Harlem neighborhood and is not afraid to speak her mind.

title: Removing, Little by Little, a History in Stone
description: SHARON

title: What Are Friends For? Power and Pain
description: FOR adults, romances are variable, and friendship is the constant. Privileged Youth reverses the equation: Love affairs are constant, and its the friendships that vary.

title: A Honda on a Diesel Diet
description: HONDA has spent decades establishing a reputation for fuel efficiency. But nothing in the companys current lineup, including its Civic Hybrid, can match the mileage of the diesel Accord that I recently tested in and around New York City.

title: Gaining Seats, Democrats Find Their House Ideologically Divided
description: While much of the Congressional political focus has been on the declining fortunes and numbers of House Republicans, House Democrats have their own problem: They are winning too many elections.

title: Bag Man
description: The end of the world just inched a little nearer: an eBay seller has written a memoir. About handbags.

title: Liquid Assets
description: India. The House of Herms had declared it its theme of 2008, and silk scarves are vivid with raw pinks and fleshy mangoes, elephants harnessed to carriages and tigers rampant. The companys resident nose, the man hired in 2003 to juice perfume sales, Monsieur Jean-Claude Ellena, is back in the south, in the state of Kerala  cut with canals, the Venice of the subcontinent, the worlds supermarket for spice  where he has been wrestling for some time with how to bottle the fantasy.

title: Mommys Dearest
description: Let us begin by eradicating all suspicion: Julie Klams memoir of growing up a coddled daughter of Westchester County bears no sign of narrative inauthenticity. In Please Excuse My Daughter, there are no discernable lies masking dark hopes of literary recognition.

title: A New Stamp on a Vast Space
description: THE historic American Bank Note building in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx is the kind of structure that inspires a second look.

title: White Terrorists
description: In the middle of the Colfax, La., cemetery stands a 12-foot-high obelisk. Its weathered now. But in its day it must have been a grand sight, towering over the rows of gravestones, its marble glinting in the Southern sun. The monument was built as a tribute to three local white men, the heroes, according to its inscription, who fell in the Colfax riot fighting for white supremacy on April 13, 1873  Easter Sunday. There is no mention of the estimated 81 black people who were murdered that day.

title: Correction: Summer Movies
description: A listing in the Summer Movies section on May 4 misidentified the nationality of the Baekelands, whose family is chronicled in the film Savage Grace. They are American, not British. The listing also misstated the relationship between Tony Baekeland and the inventor of the plastic Bakelite. Mr. Baekeland is the great-grandson of the inventor, not his grandson.

title: Diesel Is Showing Its Racy Side
description: Last week, Jacques Villeneuve, the 1997 Formula One champion, took his first major win in 11 years for the 1,000-kilometer race at Spa-Francorchamps in Belgium, but his mind was already on the next race in June.

title: Houses Even Bigger, Scores Way Above Average
description: FOR the most part, the imposing Tudors and colonials look as if they had always been here. The only clue that some are no longer originals, dating back to the towns first building boom in the 1920s, is the presence of large bins in their driveways, overflowing with plasterboard and worn plumbing fixtures.

title: Katherine Lavin, Scott Phillips
description: Katherine Elizabeth Lavin, a daughter of Elizabeth H. Lavin and Thomas J. A. Lavin of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married on Saturday to Scott Young Phillips, a son of Gwendolen M. Phillips and John D. Phillips Jr. of New York. The Rev. Carleton P. Jones, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: As Deaths Outpace Births, Cities Adjust
description: PITTSBURGH  This city has passed a grim demographic milestone: More people are dying here than are being born.

title: Marisa Fort, Brandon Adams
description: Marisa Rose Fort, the daughter of Laurinda Spear and Bernardo Fort-Brescia of Miami, was married there on Saturday evening to Brandon George Adams, a son of Holly Bryan Adams of New Orleans and Wayne L. Adams of Pensacola, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Thomas R. Niblock performed the ceremony at Plymouth Congregational Church, where he is the senior pastor.

title: The Almost Naked City
description: Burlesque, that fabled if slightly soiled fantasy realm whose heraldic totem was the twirling pasty and whose undisputed queen was Gypsy Rose Lee, has returned to New York, dripping with rhinestones and trailing clouds of glitter. Under the rubric neo-burlesque, a Depression-era genre whose hallmarks were smut with attitude, bargain-barn glamour, rock-bottom ticket prices and a proudly stuck-out tongue is reasserting itself, flourishing in unexpected corners around the city.

title: The Computer Industry Comes With Built-In Term Limits
description: MATHEMATICIANS have long tried, and failed, to solve the Riemann Hypothesis, a stubbornly unyielding math problem. Good luck to whoever tries to figure it out. For the first correct proof, a $1 million prize will be awarded by the Clay Mathematics Institute.

title: G.M.s Dreadful Engines Gave Diesels a Bad Name
description: WHAT WERE THEY? 1978-85 General Motors full-size diesel sedans.

title: Just Before Budget Vote, Fingers Are Crossed at School
description: BAND practice at the A. B. Davis Middle School in Mount Vernon takes place in a windowless fourth-floor classroom where students spread out to play their instruments, except on days when it rains. On those occasions, the seventh and eighth graders maneuver into the back of the room, avoiding the half-foot gaping hole in the ceiling.

title: An Experiment in Endowments at Wesleyan
description: THE good news for students and their parents facing high tuition bills is that the student government at Wesleyan University voted last month to establish an endowment to reduce costs at the liberal arts university in Middletown.

title: The Talk
description: last great / (last& gra\t&) / commonly used phrase signifying a place that has retained a rare quality, e.g., I just had the most amazing journey in Namibia, one of Africas last great wildernesses. An erstwhile clich, it has taken on new significance as travelers become ever more aware of environmental and cultural fragility, as in, Ladakh is the last great stronghold of Himalayan Buddhism  like an unfallen Tibet.

title: Prescription Med
description: Ah, Ischia, a Neapolitan friend said wistfully when I told him I was headed to the green island, as it is known. I spent every summer there as a kid. You know, those summers where three months last for years and years? As soon as I made landfall on Capris earthier neighbor, 15 miles off the coast of Naples, I knew exactly what he meant. A hard-driving New Yorker, Id wanted a vacation from a vacation  a simple summer weekend at the beach, without all the glitz and glamour found in most Italian seaside playgrounds.

title: Theyre All Connected
description: WHEN James Keating moved into the Beacon, a 10-tower residential conversion in Jersey City, in August, he found a cascade of e-mail messages circulating among the new residents. Some had questions about amenities, some wondered when construction projects would be completed and others just wanted to get to know their neighbors.

title: Lauren Gold, Adam Block
description: Lauren Dara Gold, the daughter of Jill Vogel of Long Beach, N.Y., and Fredric Gold of Port Washington, N.Y., was married on Saturday to Adam Eric Block, a son of Rochelle Block and Michael Block, also of Port Washington. Cantor David Katz officiated in Southampton, N.Y.

title: Chinese Flee Flood Threat From Quake
description: CHENGDU, China  Thousands of earthquake survivors fled tent camps and villages across the ravaged landscape of southwestern China on Saturday after the government warned that several lakes and rivers were getting dangerously close to overflowing because landslides have blocked water flow.

title: Once Upon Many Times
description: If any work of fiction might be powerful enough to transcend the mountain of polemic, historical inquiry, policy analysis and reportage that stands between the Western reader and the Arab soul, its this wonder of a book  a book not about a jihadi but a hakawati (Arabic for storyteller). Listen, Rabih Alameddine invites. Allow me to be your god. Let me take you on a journey beyond imagining. Let me tell you a story.

title: Foot Soldiers Can Use the Parkway Now, Too
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: Chic by Accident
description: On most Sunday mornings, Emmanuel Picault, a tall, chain-smoking 39-year-old Frenchman, spends a few hours at the weekly Lagunilla flea market in Mexico City, sifting through piles of painted masks and brass candlesticks. Other days, he may call on a private collector in Lomas de Chapultepec, the leafy enclave of the citys bourgeoisie.

title: Chinese Soldiers Work to Restore a Winding Lifeline
description: BAIHUATAN, China  It is not a voyage for the faint of heart.

title: Provence Profound
description: In 1860, two Canadians named James Bain (age 18) and John Campbell (20) made the quite peculiar decision to holiday in the northern wilderness. From Toronto they took the train to the end of the line, caught a steamer up to a town called Orillia, then started rowing. When they finally hit their destination, a giant freshwater lake named after an Ojibwa chief, the only signs of humanity were two wigwams on the beach. Bain and Campbell enjoyed sojourning in the wild and returned the following year, stopping at a tavern along the way. Shocked to find city folk in her establishment, the proprietor asked, Yezll be preachers, then?

title: Truce Holds in Sadr City Amid Patrols by Iraqi Army
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi Army troops have encountered little resistance during operations near the fortified front line in Baghdads Sadr City district, the American military reported Saturday, signaling that a shaky truce with the cleric Moktada al-Sadrs Shiite militia was holding.

title: Events on Long Island
description: COMEDY

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Sports

title: Ask for a Taco, Not for Lucinda
description: Lucinda Burritos + Tacos in downtown Jersey City is not your typical lunch truck; its logo features a retro pinup girl in short-shorts playing a ukulele.

title: Correction: Memoirs of a Girl From the East Country (O.K., Queens)
description: A picture caption with an article last Sunday about Suze Rotolos memoir of her relationship with Bob Dylan carried an incorrect credit. The picture of Mr. Dylan in glasses being embraced by Ms. Rotolo was taken by Ted Russell, not by Don Hunstein.

title: A Poisonous Love Affair
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Lost in the Big City
description: IT takes all kinds of people to turn a cold building of marble and brick, even a famous one, into a community.

title: Alexis Bryan and Spencer Morgan
description: Alexis Bryan and Spencer Morgan were married on Saturday in at the Church of St. John the Divine in Houston. The Rev. Laurens A. Hall, an Episcopal priest and the churchs rector, performed the ceremony.

title: Philharmonic and the Man Who Got Away
description: TALK about stepping all over your own message.

title: No Incidents: Race Is a Success
description: Baltimore

title: When Your Child Has a Genetic Disorder
description: To the Editor:

title: International Pressure on Myanmar Junta Is Building
description: YANGON, Myanmar  International pressure on the ruling military junta in Myanmar continued to grow over the weekend as a senior United Nations envoy was due to arrive in Yangon on Sunday to talk with government officials about what the United Nations has called a slow response to international aid offers after Cyclone Nargis.

title: A Rock Star, Finally
description: I WAS born in the city of Sasebo in southern Japan right near a United States naval base. My father, who had been a soldier during World War II, had his own construction company there and some of my mothers friends married Americans. So we had a lot of connections with American families.

title: Inside the List
description: OH, DSIRE: Fifty-five years ago this week, the No. 1 book on the hardcover fiction list was one that is all but forgotten today: Annemarie Selinkos lusty novel Dsire. Based on the life of Dsire Clary (1777-1860), a onetime fiance of Napoleon Bonaparte, it was later turned into a film starring Marlon Brando as Napoleon. Here are all of the Times best sellers for May 17, 1953  a group that includes (hard to believe) a best-of collection of Adlai Stevensons speeches:

title: Notes From the Underground
description: Off a cobblestone street in Montparnasse, behind a small courtyard, down a poky alleyway, hides something called the Territory. Two juniper trees cling to the alley wall; a tin roof hangs over an entryway; and the only outward clue of habitation is a Beware of Dog sign that, oddly enough, is written in English. The Territory had been described to me variously as a youth hostel, an art studio, a submarine, a dreamscape and a favela  to which one could add, on first impression, a firetrap, a serial-killer lair and Willy Wonkas chocolate factory.

title: Parallel Misfortunes
description: Early on in The Third Angel, Alice Hoffmans three-part tale of women falling for impossible men, a kindly doctor tells a woman whose fianc is dying that love has nothing to do with the here and now. A London hotel clerk later expands on this maxim, reassuring a young girl that she did no wrong in abetting an ill-starred lovers reunion: Love is ancient and mysterious and you cant mess with it. If you do it just backfires and you meet with disaster. Thats a fact.

title: Vertigo: A Brilliant Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: State Development Agency Buffeted by Slowing Economy and Internal Rifts
description: For more than a year, the states main economic development agency, the Empire State Development Corporation, has been in disarray, plagued by turf battles, poor management and the political collapse of Gov. Eliot Spitzer, business leaders and state officials say.

title: A Theatrical Jigsaw Puzzle for All Ages
description: LAST August Mary Rose Lloyd was scouting for the New Victory Theaters 2008-9 season at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, where she had previously uncovered shows like Tapeire and Life Is Rhythm. As director of programming, Ms. Lloyd spends half her life on the road and sees more than 250 shows a year, but she says she never knows where the next treasure might be waiting.

title: India Landrigan, Ryan Bayley
description: Dr. India Fox Landrigan, the daughter of Judith Landrigan and Ward Landrigan of New York, was married on Saturday evening to Dr. Ryan Patrick Bayley, the son of Robin Bayley of Las Vegas and the late Patrick Bayley. Evelyn M. Daly, a probate judge in Farmington, Conn., officiated at a farm owned by the brides parents in South Kent, Conn.

title: Industrial Conversions, Stuck in Gear
description: STONINGTON

title: Seeking a Few Good Shepherds
description: Children everywhere love prizes and fuzzy animals, right? The North Dakota shepherding industry is counting on it.

title: When the Hokey-Pokey Isnt Enough
description: SHOULD you be in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park on June 28, you may witness a once-in-a-lifetime site-specific performance. People dressed in strange costumes, wielding various props and accompanied by musicians, will enter Queens Theater in the Park, forming a vibrant, carnival-like parade.

title: High School Ranks Have Been Infiltrated by Agents
description: A report last week that O. J. Mayo received thousands of dollars in extra benefits while in high school and during his one season at Southern California raised eyebrows but ultimately was not a shock to those in college basketball circles.

title: Only Connect
description: Many affluent travelers used to consider a private villa and an after-hours museum tour the ultimate vacation  a way to seal oneself off from the world in a bubble of luxury. But as a cult of authenticity has taken hold among global nomads, the impulse to engage has replaced the desire to escape. And they want more than just superficial encounters with the natives; they want their culture unfiltered. What the locavore movement did for food  giving the heirloom tomato from down the road more cachet than an ounce of beluga  this new humanism has done for travel.

title: One or Two Murderers in Any Crowd
description: To open one of Charles Simics collections of poetry  this is, incredibly, his 19th  is to enter with renewed delight an instantly familiar neighborhood. Delight may not be the first word youd associate with his shabby rooming houses, seedy movie theaters, empty restaurants on lonely side streets, dusty stores about to go out of business, bare trees. But if the scenery comes out of Edward Hopper, complete with the aura of loneliness and of ordinary things made strange by odd slants of light, the people who live there are nothing like Hoppers doughy American depressives. Theyre characters from Eastern European folk tales or Kafka, boiling with energy, nicely poised between the comic and the sinister and prone to metamorphosis: an opera singer keeps a monkey dressed in baby clothes, a woman turned into a black cat / and I ran after you on all fours. Even Grandmother  and Simics poems are full of grandmothers  knitted / With a ball of black yarn. The fun  and Simics poetry is nothing if not amusing  comes from the way he puts together the whimsical, the earthy, the banal and the transcendent. There are a lot of chickens in his poems and a lot of angels, too.

title: First W Hotel Opens in Europe
description: The first W Hotel in Europe (www.whotels.com) opened this month in Istanbul. The hotel, among the recently renovated Akaretler Row Houses, a group of historic structures built in the 1870s to house employees of the Dolmabahce Palace, blends the traditional Ottoman design of the row houses with the contemporary feel of the luxury hotel chain. The hotel, which opened May 6, has 134 guest rooms and suites, many with private gardens, terraces and cabanas. Amenities include WiFi and MP3 docking stations; a spa; and a Jean-Georges Vongerichten restaurant, Spice Market, specializing in Southeast Asian street food.

title: Myanmars Children Face New Risks, Aid Groups Say
description: BANGKOK  While the death toll in Myanmar continues to climb, international aid agencies are warning of new threats to the most vulnerable survivors, children.

title: Mets Gain Is Yet Another Yankees Loss
description: The Steinbrennerian overtones at Yankee Stadium pervaded the clubhouse, seeped through an adjacent interview room and trickled into the third-base dugout, where the Mets, not the Yankees, reside. It is the visiting team, for a change, reeling from internal friction and poor play, and whose manager has begun facing a daily barrage of questions about his job security. That man does not wear pinstripes, either, at least not anymore.

title: As Menus Turn Green
description: Tender and fresh, early spring produce is starting to appear in the citys Greenmarkets and on the menus of these restaurants near Union Square, home of its own famous Greenmarket.

title: Sliding Down Memorys Fire Pole
description: OF all the places where Ive done my writing, none was more unusual than the office that had a fire pole. The year was 1987, and I had just left an editors job in New York to get back to my own writing and teaching.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article last Sunday about changes to the N.F.L.s game operations manual referred incorrectly in some editions to the way operators of clocks and coach-to-quarterback radio systems were hired before the 2007 season. It was done then, as it is now, by the league  not by individual teams.

title: Chick Crit
description: Sex and the City, the former HBO hit about four single women devoted to designer shoes and other forms of self-gratification, is about to be released as a feature film. But isnt the film out of sync with the spirit of New York at a time when people are scaling back? But the top are not scaling back. Thats what we keep hearing, right? These girls are doing pretty well. My money and Charlottes money  thats big law-firm money.

title: Hope Amid the Plantains
description: DURING its heyday in the 1950s and 60s, La Marqueta was a steaming, fragrant, noisy, tropical bazaar, sheltering 500 mostly Puerto Rican vendors in five buildings under the elevated Metro-North tracks on Park Avenue between East 111th and 116th Streets.

title: Rough Spots Remain in Nascars Safety Road
description: CONCORD, N.C.  After slamming into the wall at about 185 miles an hour at Texas Motor Speedway in April, in a trajectory eerily similar to the wreck that killed Dale Earnhardt in 2001, the rookie Michael McDowells No. 00 Toyota barrel-rolled over and over down the track.

title: After 24 Open Houses ...
description: ON a Wednesday evening nearly three weeks ago, Dawn and Barry Goldstein were surprisingly calm as they sat on their plush brown sofa chatting with a guest, while their son, Jordan, almost 3, fidgeted between them.

title: The Hillary Lesson
description: Berkeley s Fourth Street is my towns version of a strip mall: there is little you might need there, but much to want: hand-crafted Japanese paper; diaphanous Stevie Nicks-inspired frocks; wooden toys imported from Europe. One recent morning, as my 4-year-old daughter and I strolled to our favorite diner, she pointed to a bumper sticker plastered on a mailbox. A yellow, viraginous caricature of Hillary Clinton leered out from a black background. Big block letters proclaimed, The wicked witch of the East is alive and living in New York.

title: Neighbors Puzzled by New Jersey Deaths
description: Neighbors knew little about the older couple and the younger man who moved into the quiet neighborhood in Tenafly, N.J., last year. One neighbor remembered the younger man tending to the garden outside the white two-story home. Another believed that the young man might have owned a string of cellphone stores in Queens and New Jersey.

title: Salvation Army
description: Stroll into Cynthias Ristorante in downtown Paducah, Ky., on any given Friday night and youll likely find a gaggle of artists holding court at the end of the bar, their animated conversations fueled by Finlandia cosmopolitans and Chambord martinis. In the dimly lit dining room toward the back, locals tuck into twice-baked Montrachet goat-cheese souffls or oak-grilled pork tenderloin wrapped in apple-wood-smoked bacon. The vibe is faintly reminiscent of Elaines on a Thursday night, which is a bit of a shock since this Southern town on the western tip of Kentucky is a long way from the Upper East Side.

title: Under My Skin
description: Not very long ago I was in New York for a few weeks and decided to get a tattoo while I was there. It was a partly impulsive decision. Id thought of doing it for years, but I think of doing all sorts of relatively exciting and ostensibly transgressive things and never do them, either because I am too lazy or too cowardly or because I come to my senses in time to stop myself.

title: Lucius Battle, Diplomat and Official, Dies at 89
description: WASHINGTON  Lucius D. Battle, a career diplomat who was special assistant to Secretary of State Dean Acheson in the administration of President Harry S. Truman, led a reorganization of the State Department under President John F. Kennedy and later served as ambassador to Cairo, died on Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 89.

title: Obama and the Jews
description: Pssst. Have you heard? I have. I heard that Barack Obama once said there has to be an end to the Israeli occupation of the West Bank that began in 1967. Yikes!

title: Correction: Evening Hours
description: The Evening Hours column last Sunday misidentified the guest shown with Senator John McCain at the Time magazine party on May 8. He is Jeff Bewkes, chief executive of Time Warner  not Richard Stengel, the magazines managing editor. The column also misstated the given name of the guest shown with Eva Mendes at the Metropolitan Museum party on May 5. He is Francisco Costa, not Francesco.

title: Soccer as N.B.A. Building Block
description: LOS ANGELES  The Phoenix Suns had just finished a practice earlier this season when Steve Nash, Boris Diaw, Leandro Barbosa and Grant Hill joined a man in jeans and a T-shirt who had arrived carrying a soccer ball. They formed a small circle and with their feet, thighs, chests and foreheads took turns juggling the ball. Each took more than a few touches, some to control the ball, others to show off tricks learned long ago. Then the ball was flicked to someone else in the circle. Rarely did it touch the court.

title: The Long Shadow
description: Strange to think that Sean Wilentz, a professor of history at Princeton University, would embrace Ronald Reagan as the historic alpha dog of postmodern American politics. For starters, Wilentz was trained as a Jacksonian-era scholar; the 20th and 21st centuries arent his bailiwicks. Then, back in 1998, Wilentz testified before the House Judiciary Committee that the impeachment of Bill Clinton was an abomination. He also endorsed Al Gore in 2000 and Hillary Rodham Clinton in 2008. Considered by some the heir apparent to Arthur Schlesinger Jr., Wilentz is perceived more as an erudite spokesman for the Democratic Party than as a judicious analyst of the Republican agenda. Yet in The Age of Reagan  a smart and accessible overview of the long shadow cast by our 40th president  Wilentz largely abandons partisanship in favor of professionalism. Thus, the supposedly inflexible Reagan emerges here as the pragmatic statesman who greatly reduced the worlds nuclear stockpiles.

title: The Return of the One-Man Band
description: On a rainy afternoon this past December, in his cramped rehearsal studio on Torontos southwest side, Owen Pallett  known to his fans as the singer, songwriter, violinist, pianist, bassist, harpsichordist, engineer and everything else that makes up the indie-rock one-man band Final Fantasy  was trying to play his violin through five amplifiers at once. Effects pedals, instrument cables, patch cords and microphone stands took up most of the space, radiating out from the laptop and sound card that Pallett was fussing over, and an ominous hum filled the room. The amps were arranged in a loose semicircle, vaguely reminiscent of Stonehenge: Pallett spent the day before writing a computer program to coordinate the various outputs, and the impression he made now was less that of an up-and-coming rock star than of a crackpot inventor,  la Nikola Tesla, sequestered in his workshop. Oh! This is exciting, he whispered at one point, giggling to himself nerdishly. Ive never made it this far before.

She let me be a Brownie, but then she found out that the Girl Scouts were segregated, and she couldnt tolerate that, Ms. Burrows Grad, a glass of wine in her hand, explained to a roomful of women last week. But she didnt think Id understand that idea at that age. So she just told me that green wasnt my color.

title: Democracy and the Web

A new net neutrality bill has been introduced in the House, which would prohibit this sort of content discrimination. Congress has delayed on this important issue too long and should pass net neutrality legislation now.

title: An Orchestras Woes
description: The financially stricken Columbus Symphony Orchestra has suffered another blow. The grants committee of the Greater Columbus Arts Council, which gave the ensemble $261,417 last year, recommended last week that no more money be given to the orchestra, The Columbus Dispatch reported. The full board of the council will decide the matter on May 27, said a spokeswoman, Emily Swartzlander. Bryan W. Knicely, president of the council, said, We shouldnt be giving operational support to an organization thats not going to be here after June 1. The orchestra, which had a budget of $13.5 million this season, canceled its outdoor summer concerts, and its board chairman, Buzz Trafford, said it would be out of money at the end of the month, adding, It is likely the C.S.O. will suspend operations effective June 1, 2008.

title: Corrections

title: A Gust of Wind, and a Check of the Rulebook

Next, Jerry replaces his ball and leaves his ball marker behind his ball as he walks to the other side of the hole to read his putt. While he is there, a gust of wind blows the ball into the hole.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Senator Barack Obamas plans to spend primary night on Tuesday in Iowa referred incorrectly to the state of the delegate race for the Democratic nomination. But that alone would not be enough to allow him to proclaim, without fear of contradiction, that he is now the Democratic nominee. (To become the presumptive nominee, Mr. Obama would have to win additional support from elected officials and party leaders known as superdelegates. title: Profit Honors Poet in His Own Country
description: William McGonagall (1825-1902) may have gone to his unmarked grave a mocked man, ridiculed as the worlds worst poet, but when a collection of 35 of his poems went up for auction on Friday in his native Edinburgh, they fetched more than $13,000, better than the price (about $12,000) paid for a set of Harry Potter first editions signed by J. K. Rowling, the BBC reported. Known as the Tayside Tragedian, McGonagall, above, who spent much of his life in Dundee as a weaver in the jute mills, did not take up poetry until he was 47. He specialized in subjects like Scottish battles and Queen Victorias golden jubilee, as well as death and catastrophe. At his readings in Dundee, he was often scorned, and audiences were fond of throwing eggs and vegetables at him. Perhaps his best-known poem dealt with the Tay Bridge disaster of 1879 and included the lines So the train movd slowly along the Bridge of Tay/Until it was about midway,/Then the central girders with a crash gave way/And down went the train and passengers into the Tay. Alex Dove, of the auctioneers Lyon & Turnbull, said: He was a confident gentleman who thought that his poetry was some of the best. He once walked all the way to Balmoral to try to become poet laureate. Unfortunately, the queen wasnt in.

title: Drama Desks Awards
description: With five citations, including the accolade for outstanding musical revival, Rodgers & Hammersteins South Pacific led the field when the 53rd annual Drama Desk Awards were announced on Sunday at the LaGuardia Concert Hall at Lincoln Center. Three awards each went to the drama August: Osage County and the musicals Gypsy and Passing Strange. South Pacific won for actor in a musical (Paulo Szot), director of a musical (Bartlett Sher), set design of a musical (Michael Yeargan) and sound design (Scott Lehrer). August: Osage County by Tracy Letts won in the categories of outstanding play, actress in a play (Deanna Dunagan) and director of a play (Anna D. Shapiro). Jule Styne, Stephen Sondheim and Arthur Laurentss Gypsy was cited for actress in a musical (Patti LuPone) and featured actor and actress in a musical (Boyd Gaines and Laura Benanti). Passing Strange by Stew and Heidi Rodewald, took honors for outstanding musical, music (Stew and Ms. Rodewald) and lyrics (Stew). Mark Rylance of Boeing-Boeing, which was named outstanding revival of a play, won for lead actor in a drama; and Laurence Fishburne was honored for solo performance for his portrayal of Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall in Thurgood. The unique theatrical experience accolade went to The 39 Steps, and Forbidden Broadway: Rude Awakening was cited as outstanding revue.

title: Paying Attention to Food We Dont Eat
description: (Photo: The food we waste. (Jonathan Bloom))   The health community has long focused on how much Americans eat, but now the world is starting to pay attention to how much we don't.  For a detailed look at how much food the typical family wastes each month, check out this great graphic that appeared in The Times this weekend, along with this story on food waste by my colleague Andrew Martin.   I've also started reading WastedFood.com, a great blog by  journalist Jonathan Bloom, who chronicles food waste and efforts to salvage food. Recent blog postings highlight the fact that 60,000 pounds of shrimp are consumed in Las Vegas each day, and how immigration policies can lead to food waste in the field because there aren't enough workers to pick it.  To see a slide show illustrating how much edible food gets wasted every day, click here.

title: Britain: Hybrid Embryo Ban Is Defeated
description: The House of Commons has defeated a bill that would have banned the creation of so-called hybrid embryos  part human and part animal  for medical research. That means scientists who obtain proper licenses will be allowed to create hybrid embryos by transferring DNA from human cells into animal eggs that have had most of their genetic information removed. The embryos would then be grown in a laboratory and their stem cells would be harvested for up to 14 days, after which they would be destroyed. Opponents call the process unethical and unnatural; supporters say the embryos could aid the understanding of genetic defects and diseases like Parkinsons.

Each seat has a 15.4-inch L.C.D. screen and an audio system with noise-canceling headphones. The system has a dedicated cable that supports iPods and iPhones. The all-business-class flights on A340-500 aircraft began May 15, and a route connecting Los Angeles and Singapore will be added in August.

title: Beverly Rae Kimes, Automotive Journalist and Historian, Is Dead at 68
description: Beverly Rae Kimes, who, after failing to find work as a theater writer, parlayed a job as a secretary at a fledgling car magazine into a career as one of the nations pre-eminent historians of automobiles, died on May 12 at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 68.

title: Not All Earmarks Are Paid in Full, and a Senator Wants to Know Why
description: In early 2005, the office of Senator Ben Nelson received a curious phone call.

title: Grisham Football Novel to Become a Movie
description: The John Grisham novel Playing for Pizza will have its shot at the big screen. Executives at Phoenix Pictures said Monday that they had acquired rights to develop a feature film based on the book, about a washed-up National Football League quarterback who joins a semiprofessional team playing American football in Italy. Mr. Grisham is best known for legal thrillers, several of which became the basis for hit movies, among them The Pelican Brief and The Firm. Mike Medavoy and Arnie Messer of Phoenix Pictures expect to join the companys co-president of production, David Thwaites, in producing the film. Among Phoenixs credits are Zodiac and All the Kings Men.

title: A Living-Room Crusade via Blogging
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Jane Novak, a 46-year-old stay-at-home mother of two in New Jersey, has never been to Yemen. She speaks no Arabic, and freely admits that until a few years ago, she knew nothing about that strife-torn south Arabian country.

title: The Spurs Get Past a Game 7 Roadblock
description: NEW ORLEANS  The San Antonio Spurs had won four N.B.A. titles, but had never captured a Game 7 on the road, losing all four attempts. In this Western Conference semifinal series against the New Orleans Hornets, they had lost three games here by more than an average of 20 points. Monday night was a reversal of fortune.

title: Little Orphan Artworks
description: CONGRESS is considering a major reform of copyright law intended to solve the problem of orphan works  those works whose owner cannot be found. This reform would be an amazingly onerous and inefficient change, which would unfairly and unnecessarily burden copyright holders with little return to the public.

title: As Time Runs Short, Clinton Claims Lead in Popular Vote
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is entering the Kentucky and Oregon primaries on Tuesday with one of the most pugnacious political messages of her campaign: That she is ahead in the national popular vote when all votes are counted, including from the unsanctioned primaries in Michigan and Florida, and that party leaders who have a vote as super-delegates should reflect this level of appeal.

title: Supreme Court Upholds Child Pornography Law
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday upheld the latest Congressional effort to curb the spread of child pornography on the Internet, a 2003 law that makes it a crime to offer or solicit sexually explicit images of children.

title: Birds Rely on Surface Tension to Eat Dinner
description: Surface tension can be a wonderful thing. It helps some insects walk on water. It allows the dappling of raindrops on the hood of a car. And, a new study in Science shows, it enables certain birds to eat.

title: Patterns: Craving Sweets? It May Be in Your Genes
description: Could there be a genetic explanation for the sweet tooth?

title: Lets Be Serious
description: The general election is about to unfold and well soon see how smart or how foolish Americans really are. The U.S. may be the richest country on earth, but the economy is tanking, its working families are in trouble, it is bogged down in a multitrillion-dollar war of its own making and the price of gasoline has nitwits siphoning supplies from the cars and trucks of strangers.

title: Son of a Gun, Hollywood Has Big Fun on the Bayou
description: SHREVEPORT, La.  There is a backlot feel to Shreveport, tucked in Ark-La-Tex, the nexus of three states where the piney woods encircle sloughs and bayous. Its post-boom downtown  the oil and gas petered out in the mid-1980s  has plenty of fine old buildings, not many people and, along with a bit of dissipation, an air of expectation, as if the circus might suddenly crest a hill and bring all manner of hoopla.

title: Ruling on U.S. Currency and the Blind
description: WASHINGTON  In a decision that could drastically change the appearance of American money, a federal appeals court panel ruled on Tuesday that the United States discriminates against the blind because the countrys paper currency is the same size regardless of a bills value.

title: Sailing the Waters of New York Harbor
description: Just above the desk in my office hangs a U.S. Geological Survey map of New York and Vicinity made in 1901. When I sit at my desk, the top of my head is about level with the Narrows between Staten Island and Brooklyn, where the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge later went. I used to admire this map mainly for the vast expanses of swamp and salt meadow it shows and for the still incomplete hatch work of streets. But now I find myself looking at the waterline  especially the waterline of what the map calls the Upper Bay of New York Harbor, north of the Narrows and south of the Hudson River proper.

title: A Second Chance
description: With prison costs soaring, many states are understandably desperate for ways to cut recidivism and increase the chances that newly released prisoners build viable lives. The Second Chance Act, signed into law by President Bush last month, would galvanize the re-entry effort, providing the states with money and guidance. Now Congress must appropriate the promised dollars.

title: Housewives Future: Not as Good as Its Past
description: ABCs Desperate Housewives delivered Sundays top ratings, as the closing minutes of the shows fourth season gave viewers a brief flash-forward five years into the future. According to Nielsens estimates, the two-hour finale attracted 16.8 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., in line with its performance earlier this spring but down two million from its third-season finale a year ago. ABC led the nights ratings over all. The finale of Extreme Makeover: Home Edition, from 7 to 9 p.m., attracted a modest 9.4 million viewers, although the shows second hour averaged 3.5 million more viewers than its first. CBS was runner-up for the night thanks to 60 Minutes at 7 (10.7 million), followed by the Academy of Country Music Awards, which drew 11.7 million viewers from 8 to 11 p.m., an increase of 2.4 million from a year ago. Fox finished third over all, with season finales of The Simpsons at 8 (6.1 million), King of the Hill at 8:30 (5.4 million) and American Dad at 9:30 (5.6 million). NBC was fourth.

title: Katie Holmes Is Broadway Bound
description: Katie Holmes is about to make her Broadway debut.

title: Far-Flung Placement of Children in Texas Raid Is Criticized
description: SAN ANGELO, Tex.  Texas policy holds that when children are taken from their parents for investigation of possible abuse, geographic distances should be kept to a minimum to allow supervised visitation.

title: With Primaries in Two States, Obama Looks to End Race
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama would like to begin shutting down the nominating contest with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Tuesday night as two more states  Kentucky and Oregon  hold their primaries. But he wants to do it subtly.

title: Department Charges in Bell Shooting
description: Facing a legal deadline, the Police Department on Tuesday filed administrative charges against a group of officers involved in the fatal police shooting of Sean Bell, a black man killed in a hail of 50 bullets on his wedding day.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Monday about the sale of Francis Bacons Triptych (for $86.3 million) and Lucian Freuds Benefits Supervisor Sleeping ($33.6 million) at auctions in New York last week misidentified the auction house that sold the Freud painting. It was Christies  not Sothebys, which sold the Bacon work.

title: Arc-Shaped Troughs on Europa May Be Sign of Wandering Poles
description: Europa, that icy moon of Jupiter, is famous for its odd surface features  long lines, pits, domes, spots and the occasional crater.

title: Huntington Hartford II, A. & P. Heir, Dies at 97
description: Huntington Hartford II, who inherited a fortune from the A. & P. grocery business and lost most of it chasing his dreams as an entrepreneur and arts patron, died Monday at his home in Lyford Cay, Nassau, in the Bahamas, where he had lived since 2004. He was 97.

title: A Musician Who Performs With a Scalpel
description: For Claudius Conrad, a 30-year-old surgeon who has played the piano seriously since he was 5, music and medicine are entwined  from the academic realm down to the level of the fine-fingered dexterity required at the piano bench and the operating table.

title: Report Urges Tennis Match Fixing Investigation
description: An independent review of possible match fixing in professional tennis recommended that 45 matches played in the last five years be investigated because betting patterns gave a strong indication that gamblers were profiting from inside information. While finding that professional tennis is neither systematically nor institutionally corrupt, the report cautioned that the scale of the suspicious matches left no room for complacency.

description: To the Editor:

title: Obama and McCain Spar Over Iran
description: Senators Barack Obama and John McCain traded blows over foreign policy in separate speeches on Monday in which the two presidential hopefuls clashed over the proper approach to dealing with Iran.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bruce Lee, Singing and Dancing
description: Enter the director. Bartlett Sher, currently being feted for his work on South Pacific, has agreed to direct the previously announced new musical by David Henry Hwang and David Yazbeck, Bruce Lee: Journey to the West. The show, which follows Lees path to martial arts superstardom (and involves Chinese mythological figures like the Monkey King along the way), is aiming for a place in the 2010-11 Broadway season.

title: Upset by Fumes and a Visit by the Biohazard Team
description: IM one of those guys who are comfortable when flying. But even folks like me have their limits.

title: Tumors Location and Size Determine Treatment
description: The malignant tumor that Senator Edward M. Kennedys doctors said he has is known as a glioma, a cancer that arises in the brain.

description: About five minutes into Lord of the Ants, on Tuesday on the PBS Nova series, certain preconceptions you may have about ivory-tower types are likely to be exploded. Thats when Edward O. Wilson, the eminent Harvard biologist and the Lord of the title, demonstrates a point by plunging his hand into a nest of stinging fire ants. So much for aloof theorizing.

title: Rising Food Prices Sharpen a European Debate
description: BRUSSELS  The recent sharp rise in global food prices added an element Monday to the long-running debate over farm subsidies in the European Union, with some government ministers seeing a new reason to dismantle the multibillion-euro payouts and defenders countering that the system was needed more than ever.

title: Supreme Court Upholds Child Pornography Law
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday upheld a 2003 federal law aimed at child pornography, concluding in a 7-to-2 opinion that a federal appeals court was wrong to find the law unconstitutionally vague.

title: As Primaries End, Clinton Appeals Directly to Blogs
description: As Hillary Rodham Clinton decries the mainstream media for diminishing her chances of capturing the Democratic nomination, she is turning more to the Internet to make her increasingly urgent case.

title: Senate Leaders Agree on Housing Aid
description: WASHINGTON  Senate negotiators on Monday said they had reached a deal on legislation aimed at helping hundreds of thousands of homeowners in danger of foreclosure by expanding the availability of government-insured mortgages.

description: A 6-year-old girl in foster care in Harlem died Sunday after her foster mother placed a powerful medicinal patch on her neck and sent her to bed to treat the childs complaints of pain, the authorities said.

title: Who Are These Guys? Mets Identity Is in Flux
description: Before a frenzied capacity crowd at Yankee Stadium on Sunday, the Mets throttled the home team for their second consecutive victory. They toppled two elite pitchers, Andy Pettitte and Chien-Ming Wang, over the weekend with equal parts patience and power. They played crisp, fundamentally sound baseball and, when Sundays game ended, declared themselves fit to begin a winning streak.

title: McCain Finds a Thorny Path in Ethics Effort
description: Sorting out the lobbying entanglements of his campaign advisers is proving to be a messy business for Senator John McCain.

title: One for the Ladies  and Their Friends
description: LOS ANGELES  Fan boys, move over. The girls are back in town.

description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi troops uncovered a large cache of arms in a raid on a Baghdad mosque on Monday amid signs that Shiite militants had stepped up their attacks outside Sadr City.

title: Screening for Abuse May Be Key to Ending It
description: The silver-haired woman greeted me at the clinic door, one arm suspended in a bright blue sling.

title: A Series of Unfortunate Events
description: WASHINGTON  When it comes time to recount the story of Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons descent from inevitable nominee to defeat at the hands of Senator Barack Obama  assuming that is how this ends up  there is no shortage of mistakes by the Clinton campaign to put on the what-went-wrong list.

title: Reaching Well Beyond the Farm
description: WASHINGTON  Few pieces of legislation generate the level of public scorn consistently heaped upon the farm bill.

title: Many Hands, Not Held by China, Aid in Quake
description: LUCHI, China  Hao Lin had already lied to his wife about his destination, hopped a plane to Chengdu, borrowed a bike and pedaled through the countryside in shorts and leather loafers by the time he reached this ravaged farming village. A psychologist, Mr. Hao had come to offer free counseling to earthquake survivors.

title: Willis Lamb Jr., 94, Dies; Won Nobel for Work on Atom
description: Willis E. Lamb Jr., who shared the 1955 Nobel Prize in Physics for the discovery of a slight and subtle discrepancy in the quantum theory describing how electrons behave in the hydrogen atom, died on Thursday in Tucson. He was 94.

title: Senator Kennedy Has Malignant Brain Tumor
description: BOSTON  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the longtime Massachusetts Democrat and patriarch of the Kennedy family, has a malignant brain tumor, his doctors said on Tuesday.

title: Project Digitizes Works From the Golden Age of Timbuktu
description: From Timbuktu to here, to reverse the expression, the written words of the legendary African oasis are being delivered by electronic caravan. A lode of books and manuscripts, some only recently rescued from decay, is being digitized for the Internet and distributed to scholars worldwide.

title: Court Upholds Tax Exemptions for Municipal Bonds
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday upheld the preferential tax break that nearly all states give their residents who invest in bonds issued by the state and its municipalities.

description: To the Editor:

title: Hazards: Despite Dangers, Hookahs Gain Favor
description: First the casbah, now the campus.

title: Girls Gains Have Not Cost Boys, Report Says
description: The American Association of University Women, whose 1992 report on how girls are shortchanged in the classroom caused a national debate over gender equity, has turned its attention to debunking the idea of a boys crisis.

title: A Dark and Stormy Night, Played for All Its Drama
description: James Levine has made the Met Orchestra into a powerful precision instrument that plays Romantic and contemporary works with an uncommon beauty and suppleness. But if you want to hear these players in music that howls, roars and drags you through one or two dark nights of the soul, Valery Gergiev is your man.

title: Lingerie Stores Enjoyed Heyday, but Now Simply Try to Survive
description: Hidden amid the hip shoe stores, stylish coffee shops and Asian markets on Orchard and Grand Streets are tiny remnants of the Lower East Side of long ago.

title: Sex, School and Videotape (Hold the Tea and Sympathy, Please)
description: Good Boys and True, about a scandal at a prep school, is a standard-issue issue play written by Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa and acted competently by a likable cast. The brouhaha in question, unfortunately, is likely to inspire more stifled yawns than furrowed brows or raised consciousnesses.

title: France Admits Contacts With Hamas
description: PARIS  France confirmed Monday that it had been engaged in contacts with the leaders of Hamas, the radical Islamic group that is running Gaza, for several months to try to better understand its positions.

title: Talking Versus Doing
description: In 1965, Mancur Olson wrote a classic book called The Logic of Collective Action, which pointed out that large, amorphous groups are often less powerful politically than small, organized ones. He followed it up with The Rise and Decline of Nations. In that book, Olson observed that as the number of small, organized factions in a society grows, the political culture becomes more divisive, the economy becomes more rigid and the nation loses vitality.

title: New Developer Signs $1 Billion Deal to Transform West Side Railyards
description: Less than two weeks after the collapse of a billion-dollar deal to develop the railyards on Manhattans Far West Side, a new developer has agreed to salvage the plan and help keep alive the Bloomberg administrations campaign to transform the area into a major business district.

title: Odoms Wait Began Long Before Playoffs Did
description: Forward Lamar Odom could not hide his hunger after the Los Angeles Lakers closed out the Utah Jazz in Game 6 of the Western Conference semifinals. Scooping popcorn out of a bucket the size of a bowler hat, he consumed a couple of mouthfuls and spit out a kernel of truth. From now on, he said, every game is the biggest game of my life.

title: Girardi Preaches Amnesia for Woeful Yanks
description: When Manager Joe Girardi discussed the Yankees 20-24 record on Sunday night, he seemingly spit out those two numbers, which define his underachievers. Girardi said he was embarrassed, and he acted disgusted. He preached the need for amnesia regarding the previous seven weeks.

title: Netflix to Sell a Device for Instantly Watching Movies on TV Sets
description: Netflix, which pioneered the business of offering DVD movie rentals by mail, is now offering its 8.2 million subscribers an option to watch movies easily on their televisions without involving the post office.

title: When He Tried to Vanish, His Sister Wouldnt Let Him
description: Dying of cancer, terrified of becoming an invalid and reluctant to give up his strenuous life, Carl Brenner  a former trial lawyer turned apple grower  prepared to take his own life in early 2003. He returned home to Texas, took his computer hard drive to a garbage dump on the other side of San Antonio, and filled his car with every piece of paper that might tell anyone anything about his life. He invited friends and cousins over to cart away his possessions  his guns, his fishing tackle, his books and prints. And for good measure, he spent several hours erasing all of his last appointments from his calendar.

title: Argentine Farms to End Strike
description: BUENOS AIRES  Farm leaders announced on Monday night that they planned to suspend a national strike and resume negotiations with the Argentine government to resolve a dispute over a tax increase on exports. They said they would begin selling grain on Tuesday at midnight.

title: Water Main Break Brings a Busy Midtown Street to a Gushing Standstill
description: New Yorks aging network of subterranean pipes, valves and connectors poked through the surface again on Monday morning when an 85-year-old water main burst beneath West 57th Street, sending torrents of water  some laced with small amounts of asbestos  into one of Manhattans busiest commercial districts.

description: To the Editor:

title: Huntington Hartford, A. & P. Heir, Dies at 97
description: Huntington Hartford, who inherited a fortune from the A. & P. grocery business and lost most of it chasing his dreams as an entrepreneur, arts patron and man of leisure, died Monday at his home in Lyford Cay in the Bahamas. He was 97.

title: Google Offers Personal Health Records on the Web
description: After a year and half of development, Google began offering online personal health records to the public on Monday.

title: Aspirin More Beneficial if Taken at Night
description: People who are at risk of developing hypertension may be able to lower their blood pressure by taking a small amount of aspirin daily  but only if they take it at bedtime, a new study suggests.

title: Where Industry Once Hummed, Urban Garden Finds Success
description: PHILADELPHIA  Amid the tightly packed row houses of North Philadelphia, a pioneering urban farm is providing fresh local food for a community that often lacks it, and making money in the process.

title: Obama Is Expected to Hit a Milestone in Todays Votes
description: Senator Barack Obama is poised to reach a milestone in the presidential race on Tuesday by capturing a majority of pledged delegates, but he said he would not declare victory against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton or suggest the Democratic primary should end until the final three contests are finished on June 3.

title: In Todays Air Travel, Stress and Comfort Mix
description: THE summer of 2008 looms, and the airlines have shrunk the domestic system to the point where the term cattle car is no longer useful, because there are laws about how many cattle can be crammed into a railway car.

title: Aloft and Close to Nature, Fine-Feathered Birds in Constant Flux
description: BEACON, N.Y.  The glorious expanses of Robert Rymans paintings always seduce on a first tour through his galleries at Dia:Beacon. As you get closer, you are taken in anew by the details. Rich edgings of vibrant color appear where there seemed to be only white. Thick ridges of paint complicate not-so-pristine surfaces.

title: Support for Girardi, a Bit Less for Cashman
description: Not long ago, a humbling weekend for a stumbling Yankees team could have provoked the principal owner, George Steinbrenner, into criticizing the manager. Times have changed, but only to a point.

title: Newspapers on Upswing in Developing Markets
description: NEW DELHI  While gloom haunts the newspaper industry in the United States and Europe, the business is flourishing in much of the developing world.

title: Met Director Will Become Professor at N.Y.U. Institute
description: The mellifluous voice of Philippe de Montebello will next be heard in classrooms at New York Universitys Institute of Fine Arts, where he will become the first professor to teach the history and culture of museums.

title: War Takes Toll on Baghdad Psychiatric Hospital
description: BAGHDAD  In a different time, in another country, where violence and terror did not stalk the streets, Dr. Amir Hussain could practice psychiatry the way he once hoped to.

title: Arbitration Panel Gives Raise to City Police Officers
description: Ending a protracted labor dispute, an arbitration panel on Monday awarded New York Citys roughly 23,000 police officers a retroactive 9.7 percent raise over two years and significantly increased the low starting pay for recruits by $10,781.

title: Public Theaters History to Be Published
description: In 1986 Kenneth Turan, then a freelance writer and now a film critic for The Los Angeles Times, collaborated with Joseph Papp on an oral history of Papps Public Theater. But after 18 months and interviews with more than 160 people, Papp did not like the first draft and the project was dropped. After Papps death in 1991, Mr. Turan brought up the project with Papps widow, Gail Merrifield Papp, and they decided to revisit the book, addressing some of Papps objections. Stephen Rubin, the president and publisher of Doubleday (who, as editor in chief at Bantam, originally acquired the rights), has now announced that the book, Free for All, is going forward, with a 2009 publication date. Mr. Turan chose not to do any new reporting for it, so the interviews with theater stars are all from the period. Almost a quarter of those interviewed are now dead, among them Bob Fosse, Raul Julia and Madeline Kahn. Other subejcts include David Hare, Larry Kramer, David Rabe and Meryl Streep. I thought about that a lot, Mr. Turan said in a telephone interview. I finally decided were all different people 20 years down the road.

title: Red Bulls Rookies Earn Praise, but Not Much Money
description: Major League Soccer is trying to make itself more vivid in the hearts and minds of American fans, and one way is by importing big-name and big-salaried stars from abroad like David Beckham, Juan Pablo ngel, Marcelo Gallardo and Cuauhtmoc Blanco.

title: Victims Journal Leads Investigators to Slaying Suspect
description: TENAFLY, N.J.  Han Il Kims journal, written in Korean, included both commonplace entries and crucial clues, leading the police from a house here where he, his mother and an uncle were found stabbed to death to a casino near downtown Los Angeles where, the authorities said, they found a suspect with nearly $90,000.

title: From Cracks to Falling Cranes, a Big Job for Building Inspectors
description: The crack in the facade of the century-old apartment building looked ominous. Nearly an inch wide and jagged, it ran through the basement and up the front wall, causing the building to list precariously to the right.

title: Foster Mothers Pain Patch Is Believed Responsible in 6-Year-Old Girls Death
description: A foster mother in Harlem has been arrested and accused of accidentally killing a 6-year-old girl in her care by placing a powerful medicinal patch on the childs neck as treatment for pain, the authorities said on Monday.

title: Myanmar to Widen Neighbors Aid Role
description: BANGKOK  Myanmar agreed Monday to let its Southeast Asian neighbors help coordinate foreign relief assistance for cyclone victims, bending somewhat to international pressure to allow more outside aid, Singapores foreign minister, George Yeo, said.

title: Assertions by Ex-Referee Are Dismissed by N.B.A.
description: A lawyer for the former N.B.A. referee Tim Donaghy suggested in court papers Monday that games had been influenced by relationships among referees, coaches and players, and that other factors had prevented games from being played on a level playing field. The league immediately denounced the charges as unfounded.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Chart on Friday was premature in describing the accomplishments of the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope. The telescope is not expected to be completed until 2014.

title: Britain Tries to Lower the Volume on Commercials
description: NO noise please  were British.

description: JOHANNESBURG  The man certainly looked dead, lying motionless in the dust of the squatter camp. His body seemed almost like a bottle that had been turned on its side, spilling blood. His pants were red with the moisture.

title: Finding the Best Way to Cook All Those Vegetables
description: By now, most people know they should be eating more vegetables. But are there ways to get more from the vegetables you already eat?

description: A theater review on Friday about The Bully Pulpit, at the Beckett Theater, misidentified the sound designer. He is Tom Shread  not Jill Nagle, who designed the lighting.

title: Index Implies Slowdown May Prove a Short One
description: The index of leading economic indicators rose in April for a second month, the first back-to-back gain since October 2006, suggesting that the current slowdown will be short-lived.

title: Economic Tide Is Rising for Repo Man
description: HARRISON TOWNSHIP, Mich.  So many people have so many things they can no longer afford. This is an excellent time to be a repo man.

title: Telltale DNA Bits Give Away Presence of Secretive Invaders
description: In dealing with invasive species, conservationists first have to identify the scope of the problem. But that isnt always easy. Some animals are so secretive that finding them, to determine how far they have spread, is nearly impossible.

title: Makeshift Space for Inmates as Prisons Exceed Capacity
description: New Yorks federal prisons are letting inmates sleep in areas not originally designed for inmate beds  like television rooms  because of overcrowding in excess of 50 percent, according to correspondence with the Federal Bureau of Prisons released on Monday by Senator Charles E. Schumer.

title: Trying to Break Nicotines Grip
description: Michael Shaw, a 40-year-old from Brooklyn who has smoked cigarettes for 24 years, says he really wants to quit. And I do not doubt his sincerity. He has tried to give up cigarettes many times. But after several days or weeks of not smoking, something happens  an evening out with friends, an emotional upset or just plain boredom  and he relapses.

title: As Term Wanes, Bloombergs Temper Boils Up
description: For more than six years, Councilman Peter F. Vallone Jr. and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg have enjoyed a warm relationship. So when the councilor spotted the mayor outside City Hall on a recent sunny morning, he greeted him amiably, shook his hand, and turned to go on his way.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A film column on Monday about the Cannes festival misstated the surname of the author of Gomorrah, the book on which the film of that title is based. He is Roberto Saviano, not Soriano.

title: Buffetts Shopping Trip to Europe Draws a Crowd
description: FRANKFURT  Warren E. Buffett may be one of the few Americans who can still afford to come to Europe for a shopping spree.

title: Call in France to Lengthen Workweek Falls Flat
description: PARIS  The leader of Frances governing party called Monday for a definitive end to Frances 35-hour workweek, but within hours he was contradicted by other party figures and by President Nicolas Sarkozy.

title: 4 Philadelphia Police Officers in Videotaped Beatings Will Be Fired
description: PHILADELPHIA  Four police officers who were caught on video beating three suspects in a drug-related triple shooting will be fired, Police Commissioner Charles H. Ramsey said Monday.

title: Comfort Food, for Monkeys
description: The ladies who lunch do not obsess about their weight in the rhesus monkey compound at the Yerkes National Primate Research Center in Atlanta. Food is freely available, and the high-status females do not pride themselves on passing it up. They dont seem to stigmatize obesity  there is no equivalent of a Kirstie Alley joke  and they certainly dont turn themselves into Social X-Rays.

title: More Hospital Tests for Kennedy
description: BOSTON  Senator Edward M. Kennedy underwent further tests Monday that doctors hoped would reveal the cause of seizures he had Saturday morning.

Details of Microsoft Offer to Yahoo
description: Under its latest proposal to Yahoo, Microsoft would buy its search business and take a stake in the company, people briefed on the negotiations said Monday.

title: No Rescue, Yet, for Airport That Saved Berlin
description: BERLIN  Sometimes you can read a city though a cultural landmark. Tempelhof Airport is Berlins open book.

title: Who Is the Walrus?
description: I was about to meet a walrus for the first time in my life, and I felt fabulous. After all, Ronald J. Schusterman of the University of California, Santa Cruz, who has studied them for years, had assured me over the phone that to meet a walrus was to fall in love with walruses  the mammals were that smart, friendly and playful. Theyre pussycats! he said.

title: When the New Kid on the Block Is a Swaggering Cad
description: Reggie Youngblood, lead vocalist of Black Kids, saved his meta-commentary for the very end, biting his tongue until he could bite it no more. He had, somewhat sourly, made it through the bands set at the Bowery Ballroom on Sunday appearing alternately glib and wary. Mocking his bands naysayers, he declaimed, This is going to be the worst encore of all, because we only have four songs.

title: Initially Rebuffed, a Greenwich Village Hospital Scales Down Its Redesign Plans
description: St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan returned from the drawing board on Monday with a more modest redesign of its $1.6 billion development proposal that was rejected this month by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Concerns About BPA Plastic
description: Anybody worried about the potential danger from plastic bottles and cups, especially for the very young, should take note. The Canadian government has announced plans to restrict the use of bisphenol-a, or BPA, a chemical used to make hardened plastics. title: Veteran Knopf Editor Switches Jobs
description: Marty Asher, the editor in chief of the Vintage Anchor paperback imprint of Alfred A. Knopf, is stepping down from his position after 21 years to become an editor at large at the company. In a staff memo, Sonny Mehta, chairman and chief executive of Knopf, said Mr. Asher, 63, wanted to devote more time to acquiring and editing books. While he ran the paperback imprint, which largely repackages books already published in hardcover, Mr. Ashers acquisitions included Stumbling on Happiness by Dan Gilbert and Letter to a Christian Nation by Sam Harris. He will now spend his time looking for new books and editing them. During his tenure at Vintage Anchor, Mr. Asher, in partnership with Anne Messitte, the imprints publisher, helped quadruple gross sales in the last two decades. He also helped shepherd the paperback fortunes of authors including Charles Frazier, David Guterson and Nicholson Baker. Mr. Asher did not return a call seeking comment. Mr. Asher, who reported directly to Mr. Mehta, will be replaced by LuAnn Walther, who is being appointed editorial director of Vintage Anchor, and Edward Kastenmeier, who is being named executive editor of the paperback imprint. Both will report to Ms. Messitte.

title: Germany: Dalai Lama Ends 5-Day Visit

Heidemarie Wieczorek-Zeul, the development minister, met with the Dalai Lama, apparently against the wishes of Foreign Minister Frank-Walter Steinmeier and the leader of the Social Democrats, Kurt Beck. Both had said that no senior party leaders would meet with him. The Dalai Lama ended his visit with a big rally in Berlin at the Brandenburg Gate, the symbol of Germanys reunification.

title: Russia: Plans for a Car Plant
description: PSA Peugeot Citron, the European carmaker, and a Japanese rival, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation have agreed to build sport utility vehicles and midsize cars in Russia, Europes fastest-growing major auto market. Peugeot will invest as much as 350 million euros ($543 million) in a plant near Kaluga, 112 miles southwest of Moscow, Christian Streiff, the chief executive, said. The factory will initially make 160,000 vehicles a year, of which 50,000 will be S.U.V.s, and eventually increase production to 300,000. The Peugeot-Mitsubishi plant will open in 2011, employing 3,000 people, Mr. Streiff said. Peugeot will hold a 70 percent stake, he said.

The selections, both screened out of competition, find each director working through the past, with Mr. Wong revisiting one of his older features, the martial-arts fantasia Ashes of Time (originally released in 1994) and Mr. Davies returning to Liverpool, the city of his birth and the backdrop for his earlier autobiographical films, including the haunting and haunted Distant Voices, Still Lives (1988).

title: The Clarinet, Speaking in Many Voices and Accents
description: When composers look for important voices among the family of wind instruments, they come away, more often than not, with a clarinet. It has many colors. Its acoustical presence makes it a good public speaker. It can sing simply or be complicated on demand. But there is something else: an ambiguous quality, a hint of delicious sourness that says to the listener, You think Im playing flat, but Im not.
