title: Kenny Chesney Honored but Upset
description: No sooner had the Academy of Country Music handed out its awards on Sunday than Kenny Chesney, above, objected to the method that gave him his fourth straight win as entertainer of the year. For the first time in the shows 43 years, its foremost accolade, traditionally decided by academy members, was determined in an online vote by the public. Backstage on Sunday night, Mr. Chesney said that although he favored the inclusion of fans, he did not think they should determine the academys most important award, The Associated Press reported. He emphasized that his criticism was directed at the industry, not the fans, and said that this years voting method amounted to complete disrespect of the artists, turning the award into a sweepstakes to see who can push peoples buttons the hardest on the Internet. The academy did not immediately respond to messages seeking comment. At the ceremony in Las Vegas, Brad Paisley was named top male vocalist and Carrie Underwood top female vocalist, both for the second consecutive time. Honors for vocal group went to Rascal Flatts (six in a row) and for vocal duo to Brooks & Dunn (13 in a row).

title: Regina Kellerman, 84, Locator of New Yorks First City Hall, Dies

She was 84 and lived in Greenwich Village, the neighborhood in Manhattan where much of her work was focused and about whose buildings she may have known more than anyone else.

title: Colombia: Rebel Commander Surrenders
description: A woman who was a senior commander in the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, has surrendered after almost two decades of guerrilla activity. Nelly vila Moreno, who used the nom de guerre Karina, turned herself in to the army in the latest setback for the FARC, Colombia's largest rebel group. Four other senior commanders were killed in the past year. Ms. vila had been accused of taking part in the killing of President lvaro Uribe's father in the early 1980s, a claim she denied at a news conference in Bogot, the capital. "My hands are not dirty with that crime," she said.

title: Yemen: Judge Orders Suspect Held
description: A Yemeni judge has ordered the detention of Jaber Elbaneh, a Yemeni- American accused in terrorist plots who had been living free despite a $5 million American bounty on his head. American prosecutors won the indictment of Mr. Elbaneh in 2003, accusing him of being part of a group of young men from Lackawanna, N.Y., who had traveled to Afghanistan to train at a camp of Al Qaeda. Mr. Elbaneh, 41, was convicted last fall of conspiring to blow up oil installations in Yemen. He had been allowed to remain free during his appeal, which angered American authorities. While a judge ordered his detention on Sunday, it was not clear on Monday whether he had in fact been detained.

title: Nigeria: Senator Faces Graft Charge

The senator, Iyabo Obasanjo- Bello, had been sought for weeks by investigators who have accused lawmakers of having accepted cash from government officials in exchange for approving inflated budgets, which were then looted. Ms. Obasanjo-Bello is the daughter of Olusegun Obasanjo, who stepped down last year after two terms as Nigerias president.

title: Riding the Vespa S

Getting through a traffic jam on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway is a game of inches. So even though Im a fan of almost anything with a motor and two wheels, I was a bit skeptical about venturing onto the city streets aboard the Vespa S. After touring through Manhattan and Brooklyn on a group ride for journalists, though, I found myself persuaded that scooters are extremely useful for basic city transport  at least when the weather is cooperative.

title: About Tom Kuntz
description: Tom Kuntz has been a New York Times journalist for more than 20 years. He was a foreign editor during the collapse of communism and the first gulf war. At the Sunday Week in Review, his Word for Word columns of verbatim excerpts led to two books, The Titanic Disaster Hearings (Pocket Books, 1998) and The Sinatra Files (Three River Press, 2000). After 9/11, he produced Times television documentaries for Discovery about rebuilding ground zero. As a special projects editor, he helped edit Class Matters, a series about social class in America. As pop music editor, he started New York Times Popcast, a podcast. After returning to the Week in Review in 2007, he started the Laugh Lines and Idea of the Day blogs.

title: Worst-Named Horses

Brom was the designated driver, I the annoying right-side passenger, when I slipped into a familiar routine, doing what I had done any number of times when I took the subway back from the Big A or got on the pokey Long Island Railroad train from Belmont, having forgotten to pack along some reading material to kill the time on the journey back: That is, I got my kicks by gleaning the past performances of the horses at tracks we rarely if ever handicapped  Evangeline and Emerald, Fort Erie and Fairmount and Fairplex.

title: Reconsidering Orientalism

For instance, in Irwins view, Said was utterly oblivious to the humour and stylishness of Alexander Kinglakes Eothen. Hmmm. Some quick googling shows that Kinglake, an Englishman, traveled to the Levant in the 19th century. And through Project Gutenberg you can even download the entire book. Irwin is the TLSs Middle East editor, and has also written a cute book on the Alhambra.

(Conceiving a child the old-fashioned way doesnt guarantee a tissue match.) Another is a reduction of the legal time-limit on abortion, which up to now has been 24 weeks.

title: Hussein Aide Faces Accusers in Trial on Mass Execution
description: BAGHDAD  Tariq Aziz, the diplomat who served as the public face of Saddam Husseins government, appeared in court on Tuesday accused of being part of a systematic campaign to kill Iraqi merchants. The deaths, prosecutors said, amounted to crimes against humanity.

title: Jesse Edwards, Pathologist, Dies at 96
description: Dr. Jesse E. Edwards, a leading cardiac pathologist, who assembled a formidable collection of human hearts to let doctors study coronary disease, congenital defects and trauma, died on May 18 in Rochester, Minn. He was 96.

title: A California of Noir Shadows and Blood
description: CANNES, France  Clint Eastwood has wrangled a number of unruly stars in his long directing career, but somehow he hasnt been able to do the same with  or for  Angelina Jolie. Shes the lustrous centerpiece of his latest endeavor, Changeling, which was shown to a respectful if subdued press audience on Tuesday morning at the Cannes Film Festival. A view of the human beast at its worst, the film is a tricky bit of storytelling business, in part because it involves a true crime with no moral gray areas, in part because it takes place in the 1920s, an era so at odds with its modern star that its like watching Joan Crawford do Queen Victoria.

title: In Milan, a Diva Finds a Home
description: MILAN

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on Friday about the contemporary art auction at Phillips de Pury & Company in Manhattan misstated the total sales at the Christies auction of postwar and contemporary art earlier last week. Sales totaled $348.2 million, not $438.2 million.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A television column on Friday about Man vs. Wild, a show on the Discovery Channel starring Bear Grylls, misstated Mr. Gryllss original name. He was born Edward Michael Grylls, not Mitchell Winston.

title: Importing a Spanish Spring
description: RECENTLY at a lunch at the Capafons-Oss winery in the Priorat region of Spain, I sat with wine experts sipping grenache-and-carignan-based blends. Tasting descriptors dominated the conversation  clove and raspberry, vanilla and coffee, my companions suggested.

title: Rodriguez Returns; Jeter Leaves Early
description: Mike Mussina threw only 41 pitches Tuesday night before Ross Ohlendorf jogged in from the bullpen to take his place. Mussina got only two outs with those 41 pitches, and any game that Ohlendorf enters in the first inning is quickly disintegrating.

title: Benefits
description: Downtown Sampler

title: Report Details Dissent on Guantnamo Tactics
description: WASHINGTON  In 2002, as evidence of prisoner mistreatment at Guantnamo Bay began to mount, Federal Bureau of Investigation agents at the base created a war crimes file to document accusations against American military personnel, but were eventually ordered to close down the file, a Justice Department report revealed Tuesday.

title: A Video Game Star and His Less-Than-Stellar Pay
description: Michael Hollick never thought his big break would come in a video game.

title: Florida: 7-Year Sentence for Imposing Forced Labor
description: A former schoolteacher was sentenced in Fort Lauderdale to more than seven years in prison for forcing a Haitian girl to work as a virtual slave in her home. The defendant, Maude Paulin, told the court at her sentencing that she had made some mistakes while raising Simone Celestin, but she would not admit she held the girl as a forced laborer. Ms. Paulin, 52, along with her mother, Evelyn Theodore, 74, were convicted of conspiring to violate Ms. Celestins civil rights and compelling her to perform forced labor. Ms. Theodores sentencing was postponed because she suffered a stroke shortly after her sentencing in March. Ms. Celestin told jurors in March she worked 15 hours a day, was sometimes beaten by the women and was forced to eat table scraps. I love Simone with all my heart, said Ms. Paulin at the sentencing hearing. I regret it. I blame myself.

title: Iceland: Bond Rating Cut by Moodys
description: The government of Icelands bond rating was lowered to Aa1 from Aaa by Moodys Investors Service on growing concern that the countrys banks may face a credit squeeze. The rating on the foreign currency country ceiling for bank deposits was also reduced one rank to Aa1 from the top level, Moodys said. Icelands banks may encounter liquidity constraints because their assets are mostly denominated in foreign currency, according to Moodys. The move comes four days after Iceland was offered an emergency loan by the central banks of Denmark, Sweden and Norway to support the krona and avert an economic collapse. The offer is evidence that Iceland still has access to funds and that liquidity risk should not be overstated, Moodys said.

title: Nearly Deaf Professor Teaches English Literacy, One Student at a Time
description: ASHEVILLE, N.C.  After three degrees, after five universities, after 40,000 pupils, and after 84 years, 10 months and 25 days, John Kuhlman has circumnavigated his way back to the essentials of education: a teacher and a student in a room.

title: Correction
description: An article last Wednesday about sculpture carved from produce misstated the date of an exhibition of photographs of such work by Hugh McMahon. The photographs are on display at the James Beard House, 167 West 12th Street, through May 31; they will not be on view next month.

title: Corrections
description: Editors' Note

title: Slipping the Knife With Care
description: These knife guards are as practical as they are neon-bright. The guards, which protect the blades in a drawer, also prevent cooks from cutting themselves when searching for the right knife. And they are indispensable for transporting knives to a picnic.

title: Cooking School Tempest
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sudden Transfer of 40 Priests Brings Egan Unrest From Within
description: Cardinal Edward M. Egan has reassigned almost 10 percent of the active priests in the Archdiocese of New York without adequately consulting the personnel board that has traditionally advised him and his predecessors, according to members of the board and other clergy familiar with the developments.

title: U.S. Moves to Prohibit Beef From Sick or Injured Cows
description: The Agriculture Department proposed on Tuesday banning from the food supply all cows that are too sick or injured to walk, a long-sought victory for advocates of animal welfare.

title: No Sex, Please, This Is Jerusalem
description: Jerusalem, the Holy City, has effectively banned sex. No, not the act but the three-letter word that appears elsewhere in billboard advertising for the new film Sex and the City. Sex in the city became an issue when the advertising company Maximedia told the news media that it would not post billboards featuring Sarah Jessica Parker, above, one of the stars, in deference to requests from city officials concerned about offending public sensitivities by mentioning sex, Agence France-Presse reported. Then the distributor, Forum Films, said that without sex there would be no billboards in Jerusalem or Petah Tikva, a town near Tel Aviv that has a large ultra-Orthodox Jewish population. But in other Israeli cities, sex in advertising is O.K.

title: Senator Kennedy Has a Malignant Brain Tumor
description: BOSTON  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the longtime Massachusetts Democrat and patriarch of the Kennedy family, has a malignant brain tumor, his doctors said on Tuesday.

title: Red Wings and Pistons to Split Screens in Detroit
description: Detroit sports fans will face a rare predicament on Saturday and Monday nights: whether to watch Games 1 and 2 of the Stanley Cup finals between the Red Wings and the Penguins, or Games 3 and 4 of the N.B.A. Eastern Conference finals between the Pistons and the Celtics.

title: Biotech Company to Auction Chances to Clone a Dog
description: A California company is planning a string of online auctions next month to clone five dogs, with the bidding to start at $100,000.

title: More Ball Fields Allowed Despite Voiding of Deal
description: A judge in Manhattan has ruled that the Bloomberg administration can continue to build athletic fields on Randalls Island even though a deal in which private schools had agreed to help pay construction costs was voided by the court earlier this year.

title: Footnotes
description: Rupert Goold, who staged the hit production of Macbeth currently on Broadway at the Lyceum Theater, has been named an associate director of the Royal Shakespeare Company, Variety reported. He will join the company on a full-time basis 2010. ...Projected for Broadway in 2010 is a new musical based in part on a forthcoming memoir by Zindzi Mandela, a daughter of Nelson and Winnie Mandela who grew up under apartheid in South Africa. The show will deal with the struggle for freedom and its leaders. The freedom songs were so important to the morale of the people, Zindzi Mandela said in a statement, so its natural for the story to be told with music as a cornerstone. ... The two-time Tony and Emmy Award winner Bebe Neuwirth is making her nightclub debut at Feinsteins at Loews Regency with Stories With Piano, a show emphasizing the works of Kurt Weill and Kander & Ebb but also saluting Cole Porter, Stephen Sondheim and Tom Waits. Ms. Neuwirth, appearing through May 31, will be followed from June 3 to 14 by Tony Danza in a new show, I Could Have Danced All Night, and from June 17 to 28 by Liz Callaway, whose show The Beat Goes On will be devoted to music of the 1960s. ... Keely Smith, whose honorary titles include Queen of Swing and First Lady of Las Vegas, will make her Birdland debut with performances from June 3 through June 8.

title: Tying Knots That Bind Lives Despite the Divisions of Generation and Nationality
description: There are six principal characters in The Edge of Heaven: two mothers, two daughters, a father and a son, all arranged in more or less symmetrical pairs. In the course of this extraordinary film by the German writer-director Fatih Akin (which won the best screenplay award in Cannes last year) children are lost, lost parents are never found, and generational and geographical distances grow wider.

title: Poison Moonshine Kills 110 of Indias Poor
description: BANGALORE, India  Venkateshwarappa, a shepherd on the edges of the city, found plastic sachets of it tossed in the bushes. It was moonshine. It was Sunday afternoon. He felt lucky and drank it.

title: Safety at the Stove
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuba Is Topic as McCain Continues Attack on Obama
description: MIAMI  Senator John McCain took his sharp criticism of Senator Barack Obama on foreign policy to a new venue on Tuesday, using a speech on Cuba here in a critical swing state to again argue that Mr. Obama is too willing to talk to Americas enemies.

title: On the Road Again? Tricks to Logging On
description: THE Internet may be more accessible than ever, but business travelers often need more than one way to log on to get their e-mail, send and receive files and search the Web for maps, restaurants and other information.

title: Rodriguez, Unlikely Savior, Is Back to Help
description: When Alex Rodriguez reported for work Tuesday at Yankee Stadium, he did not have an S on his chest, he was not wearing a cape and he was not planning to leap any tall buildings. Rodriguez is a super player, but he is not Superman. He is one man, one very important contributor on a stagnant team.

title: Once More Unto the Breach (Its a Rambo World Out There)
description: Many a martial march is heard, but not a single flag is waved in The Great American All-Star Traveling War Machine, a revue of songs, sketches and speeches focusing on the history of human conflict at the Theater for the New City.

title: Iraqi Troops Take Charge of Sadr City in Swift Push
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi troops pushed deep into Sadr City on Tuesday as the Iraqi government sought to establish control over the district, a densely populated Shiite enclave in the Iraqi capital.

title: ABC's Dancers Draw Eyes
description: ABCs Dancing With the Stars attracted Mondays largest audience as 18.8 million viewers tuned in for the shows final performances of the season at 8 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. The reality competition led its time slot but failed to lift ABC to No. 1 for the night overall as the networks premiere of The Bachelorette struggled from 9 to 11 p.m., averaging 8.8 million viewers. CBS eked out a victory as the nights most watched network thanks to solid ratings for finales of its comedy lineup from 8 to 10 p.m. CBSs CSI: Miami also led the 10 p.m. hour with 16.1 million viewers. Fox, meanwhile, despite a third-place finish in total viewers, ranked second among adults 18 to 49 behind CBS but ahead of ABC, earning the nights top ratings in that demographic with the finale of House at 9 p.m. (16.2 million). NBC finished a distant fourth over all, drawing just 4 million viewers for American Gladiators from 8 to 9:30.

title: Problems in School May Come From Outside
description: To the Editor:

title: R. Kelly Jurors Hear Opening Statements
description: Jurors in the child pornography trial of the R&B star R. Kelly, right, were warned on Tuesday by a prosecutor that they would be required to watch a videotape of an under-age child performing sex acts that you have never seen before. In an opening statement in Cook County Criminal Court in Chicago, the prosecutor, Shauna Boliker, said, A child doesnt choose to be violated and placed on a videotape, a videotape that will live on forever  long after this child becomes an adult, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Kelly, 41, a Grammy Award winner, is accused of videotaping himself having sex with an under-age girl. Prosecutors contend that she was as young as 13 when the recording was made, between Jan. 1, 1998 and Nov. 1, 2000. Both Mr. Kelly and the woman, now 23, deny they are the people on the tape, and one of Mr. Kellys lawyers, Sam Adam Jr., told the jurors during his opening statement that the videotape is at best a copy of a copy and that Mr. Kelly was not the man on the tape. Not a single witness can tell you that is him on the tape, he said. If convicted, Mr. Kelly could face as much as 15 years in prison.

title: For Many Olympic Families, the Dream Is Proving Costly
description: Peter Fekete is about to retire from his job as a maintenance machinist at a General Motors plant in Wilmington, Del. His wife, Irene, is an administrative assistant at a pharmaceutical company.

title: The Coffee Was Lousy. The Wait Was Long.
description: THE Rooz Cafe, a restaurant and coffee shop in Oakland, Calif., signals its distaste for patrons who post reviews on Yelp.com with a small sign: No Yelpers.

title: In Quake, Apotheosis of Premier Grandpa
description: CHENGDU, China  He is widely known as the crying prime minister, although he prefers to be called Grandpa Wen. Over the past week, as Wen Jiabao toured earthquake-shattered towns and cities across northern Sichuan, he has hollered out words of encouragement to those trapped beneath fallen buildings and shared tearful moments with newly orphaned children.

title: To Thwart TiVo, a Nod to Televisions Golden Age
description: TELEVISION may be the ultimate green medium, recycling ideas that go in one era and out the other. NBC, for instance, plans to bring back Knight Rider in the fall, and CW is scheduling a new version of Beverly Hills 90210.

title: Operation in Sadr City Is an Iraqi Success, So Far
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi forces rolled unopposed through the huge Shiite enclave of Sadr City on Tuesday, a dramatic turnaround from the bitter fighting that has plagued the Baghdad neighborhood for two months, and a qualified success for Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: French Cookies, in Vivid Hues
description: Ccile Cannones macarons are not shy. She bakes them in bold, improbable tones of turquoise, chartreuse, burgundy and buttercup yellow, and puts them on bright display at Macaron Cafe, which opened several months ago in the garment district.

title: New Era Brings Buzz (and Big Budgets) to the Met
description: In his mission to reinvigorate the Metropolitan Opera, Peter Gelb, who completed his second season as general manager on Saturday night, has inaugurated outreach campaigns and digital-media ventures that are the envy of the opera world. There have been the enormously popular live high-definition transmissions of broadcasts to movie theaters worldwide, and the Mets lively 24-hour station on Sirius satellite radio. Mr. Gelb has proved a master of marketing and drawn high-profile directors from film and theater into the house.

title: Pondering a Common Word With One Dreaded Meaning
description: Some words are asked to do too much. Love is what you feel for ice cream and your life partner. God is a multipurpose interjection or the creator of the universe. In Depression: Out of the Shadows, a stark documentary on Wednesday on PBS, Andrew Solomon, who won a National Book Award for his book about depression, makes his own nomination for this grouping.

title: Genre-Bending Hangout Takes Its Final Bows
description: ALMOST 23 years ago a transplanted young Frenchman named Florent Morellet, the youngest son of the conceptual artist Franois Morellet, took over a diner named the R & L on Gansevoort Street.

title: Clinton Still Sees Plenty of Reasons to Press Her Campaign
description: Rebuffing associates who have suggested that she end her candidacy, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has made it clear to her camp in recent days that she will stay in the race until June because she believes she can still be the nominee  and, barring that, so she can depart with some final goals accomplished.

title: A Broken Pipe Is Fixed, and the Good Life Goes On
description: But for a steady drizzle, water was in short supply Tuesday on the north side of 57th Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, where a water main break the day before had forced a shutdown.

title: Actuaries Scrutinized on Pensions
description: By firing its actuarial consultant last week, the New York State Legislature shone a light on one of the public sectors deepest secrets: All across the country, states and local governments are promising benefits to public workers on the basis of numbers that make little economic sense.

title: Oven Adds Flavor When the Grill Cant
description: THIS is a story about hedging bets, about taking advantage of some old-fashioned barbecue techniques, and about the heartbreak of Memorial Day.

title: Blind Win Court Ruling on U.S. Currency
description: WASHINGTON  In a decision that could radically change the size, the color and even the feel of American money, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday that the United States discriminates against the blind and those with limited vision because its paper currency is all the same size regardless of a bills value.

title: Simply Irresistible
description: LONG before she became one half of the most knocked-off fashion label you have probably never heard of, Dana Foley was an aspiring playwright on the Lower East Side of Manhattan who used to avoid writing by shopping.

title: Celtics Remain Perfect at Home in the Postseason
description: BOSTON  The central conflict heading into the Eastern Conference finals has been as much about home court and road performance as it has been about the Detroit Pistons and the Boston Celtics.

title: Racing the Clock to Bring Back the Intrepid
description: Getting stuck in the mud on its first attempt to leave Manhattan was not the last or the least of the troubles that the aircraft carrier Intrepid has encountered in the past 18 months.

title: Troopers Honor Inspector Amid Disbelief at Suicide
description: NEWBURGH, N.Y.  There was the familiar long gray line, ranks of troopers gathered in uniform to pay their respects, as they always do for a fallen brother in service. There was ritual and recollection, as hundreds gathered inside a tidy Roman Catholic church here on Tuesday to pay tribute to a loving husband, father and friend.

title: Bush Team Criticizes New Report About Iran
description: WASHINGTON  The White House sharply criticized a news organization on Tuesday for the second time in two days over reports about administration policy toward Iran, dismissing an Israeli report that President Bush was preparing to order an attack on Iran before leaving office in eight months.

title: A Young Mans Passion for Beer Blossoms Along With His Hops
description: Squatting in the cold drizzle Tuesday morning, Dan Suarez fingered a little shoot of a plant that has managed, somehow, to rise for a second season from a tiny green patch of his parents backyard in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

title: Haunting Soundtracks: Jazz With a Polish Accent
description: The Polish trumpeter Tomasz Stankos records of the last six years, with their elegiac moods and clean, controlled lyricism, have become a primary reference point for current European jazz. So it was curious to see him taking a step back into a woollier past on Monday in a performance at the Museum of Modern Art, part of the museums Jazz Score series on jazz and film.

title: Good Wine Reading With Mellow Aftertaste
description: GASOLINE? Shooting past $4 a gallon. Airfare? Similar trajectory. The dollar? Stuck at the bottom. Summer? A shady spot in the park and a good book is sounding awfully attractive.

title: Mondavis Legacy: Reinventing Napa Valley
description: LIKE many great Americans, Robert Mondavi reinvented himself  several times, in fact  and in the process he reinvented Napa Valley and the American wine industry.

title: Telescope Takes a Long View, to London
description: Before sunrise on Tuesday morning, a strange sight began to appear on Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn: a six-foot-tall metal drill bit seemed to emerge from the wooden pier, covered in genuine East River mud and revolving slowly beneath the glow of the Manhattan skyline. On Wednesday it will grow into a 12-foot-tall industrial-looking behemoth erupting just in front of the quaint Brooklyn Ice Cream Factory. And on Thursday? Imagine an enormous brass and wood telescope, 37 feet long by 11 feet tall, connected to a mirrored dome, like a childs drawing of something that will see into the future. Voil: the Telectroscope will have materialized.

description: To the Editor:

description: Lewis S. Ranieri, a pioneer of the mortgage bond industry, spent the last few years warning anyone who would listen that the housing market was about to collapse.

description: Beijing

title: South Africa: Anti-Immigrant Mob Kills 2 at Hostel
description: Violent attacks against immigrants, a siege of mayhem that has afflicted the Johannesburg area for more than a week, began to ease, though two more foreigners were killed, bringing the death toll to at least 24 people. The latest victims were killed when a mob raided a hostel. Thousands of immigrants  most of them from Zimbabwe, Malawi and Mozambique  have been chased from their ramshackle homes. The South African Institute of Race Relations blamed the government of President Thabo Mbeki for a tinderbox of unmet expectations.

title: Prognosis Usually Bleak for Condition, a Glioma
description: The statement that Senator Edward M. Kennedys doctors issued on Tuesday made clear that his malignant tumor was a glioma, a cancer that arises in the brain and that often carries a bleak prognosis.

title: Minnesota: Students Vandalize Portraits at Capitol
description: In flesh and blood, former Gov. Jesse Ventura is stubborn and unvarnished. In oil paint, it is a different story, which is good news for the two high school freshmen who are believed to have made marks on his portrait when their United States government class toured the Capitol in St. Paul. It turns out the ink wasnt very stubborn and the paintings had enough varnish to keep the ink from seeping below the surface, Brian Szott, curator of art at the Minnesota Historical Society, said of the vandalism the students are believed to have inflicted on three portraits of governors. Marks were also drawn across the mouths of Elmer L. Andersen and Harold LeVander. Initial estimates suggested the vandalism would require restoration, costing several thousand dollars. In fact, the repairs cost $175. It took an hour and a mild solvent to remove the ink from the paintings. An investigation is focusing on students from Eastview High School in Apple Valley. Mr. Ventura, a former professional wrestler, called the act despicable. A fine and community service are the likely penalties for a misdemeanor of this type, said James Backstrom, the county attorney for Dakota County.

title: Officers Face Department Charges in Bell Killing
description: Seven New York City police officers involved in the fatal shooting of Sean Bell, including three detectives who were acquitted in a criminal trial, were formally accused on Tuesday of breaking Police Department rules in the case.

title: The Last Debate
description: What do you want? Please, Sweetie, would you just tell me what you want?

title: Homeland Security Stands by Its Fence
description: NACO, Ariz.  As the Department of Homeland Security pushes to complete 670 miles of fencing along the Mexican border by the end of this year, it is confronting the sharpest resistance yet while conceding that physical barriers alone do not stop illegal crossings.

title: Foreign Investors Pull Back, but Not Out of Deals
description: The extraordinarily strong office market in Manhattan in recent years owed its vigor in part to the presence of foreign real estate investors. Now, however, many such investors, even those with deep pockets and a strong currency on their side, are waiting on the sidelines.

title: Spains Defense Minister Becomes a Mother
description: MADRID  Spains first female defense minister, whose pregnancy became a symbol of Spains new commitment to sexual equality, began maternity leave Tuesday after giving birth to a boy.

title: While the Economy Struggles, Profits Can Be Made
description: WHILE the slow economy has left many small businesses scraping to get by, some enterprises are finding opportunity in the carnage. They include an entire industry devoted to distressed companies. When things are booming, this sector is like the lonely Maytag repairman, who doesnt have much work to do.

title: Limits Weighed for Commodities Investors
description: The chairman of a Senate oversight committee said Tuesday that he was considering legislation limiting large institutional investors in commodities markets.

title: Braised and Grilled or Broiled Pork Ribs
description: Time: About 2 hours

title: At Trial, Witnesses Tie Coach to Drugs
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Two people pointed at Trevor Graham in a courtroom Tuesday and accused him of lying. One was a federal agent who said Graham misled him about his involvement with performance-enhancing drugs, and the other was a former Mexican athlete who said Graham arranged for him to supply the drugs.

title: Charitys Leaders Suspended as Payments Are Reviewed
description: The American Bible Society, the Christian charity based in Manhattan, announced on Tuesday that its president, Paul G. Irwin, and chief financial officer, Richard B. Stewart Jr., had been placed on paid temporary leave at the request of the organizations board.

title: China Blocks Thousands of Hindus From Tibet Pilgrimage
description: NEW DELHI  The Chinese government is refusing to issue visas to Hindus trying to make the traditional summer pilgrimage to what they hold to be the home of Lord Shiva in Tibet, forcing thousands to delay or cancel the trip.

title: Buyout of Penn National May Involve Revised Terms
description: Another private equity deal is feeling pressure this week, as the firms buying Penn National Gaming for $6.1 billion begin to jostle with the banks over the terms for the leveraged buyout, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

title: Giants Face Questions About Two Key Players
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Many people in the Giants organization have had to parry questions about the futures of Jeremy Shockey and Michael Strahan. Their position coaches took turns Tuesday answering those persistent questions, and neither provided much clarity.

title: What You Get for ... $5 Million
description: Clarkesville, Ga.

title: Report Details Interrogation Debate
description: WASHINGTON  F.B.I. agents complained repeatedly, beginning in 2002, about the harsh interrogation tactics that military and C.I.A. interrogators were using in questioning terrorism suspects, like making them do dog tricks and parade in the nude in front of female soldiers, but their complaints appear to have had little effect, according to an exhaustive report released Tuesday by the Justice Departments inspector general.

title: Randolphs Comments Add Another Distraction
description: ATLANTA, May 20  Willie Randolph finds himself in the spotlight these days, with his job status in question and his demeanor in the dugout under a microscope.

title: A Warning to Europe From Gazprom
description: BERLIN  Gazprom, the Russian export monopoly, warned the European Union on Tuesday that it was endangering the security of its natural gas supplies by planning to break up the Continents energy giants.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about the winemaker Robert Mondavi misstated part of the name of an institute established in his name at the University of California, Davis. It is the Robert Mondavi Institute for Wine and Food Science (not Service).

title: Developer of Affordable Housing Faces New Challenge
description: Among the many programs established to encourage construction of affordable housing in New York in the last few decades, the states 421-a negotiable certificate program uses one of the more original approaches.

title: Estranged Father Testifies in Sect Case
description: SAN ANGELO, Tex.  In the weeks since the authorities raided a fundamentalist polygamy group here in West Texas in an investigation of possible child marriages and abuse, the sects mothers have drawn the most attention.

title: The Obies Cite Passing Strange
description: The musical Passing Strange was honored as best new theater piece, and its cast (featuring Daniel Breaker, above) was honored as an ensemble when the 53rd annual Village Voice Obie Awards were presented on Monday in a ceremony at Webster Hall in the East Village. Honors in playwriting went to Horton Foote for Dividing the Estate and David Henry Hwang for Yellow Face. For accomplishments in directing, Krzysztof Warlikowski was cited for Krum and David Cromer for Adding Machine. ... Not a bad month for Rob Ashford. In addition to winning the Fred & Adele Astaire Award for best choreography on Broadway for his work in Cry-Baby, he was cited for outstanding choreography (Cry-Baby again) when the Drama Desk Awards were handed out on Sunday. Spencer Liff of Cry-Baby also won an Astaire Award as best male dancer on Broadway for his performance in the show. Karen Olivo was honored as Broadways best female dancer for In the Heights.

title: Central Figure in State Police Inquiry Strikes Back
description: ALBANY  In his first public response to a widening investigation of the State Police, Daniel Wiese, the former lieutenant colonel at the center of the inquiry, has sought to rebut suggestions that he ran a rogue unit specializing in political favors and dirty tricks.

title: Keeping Vow on Obama, McCain Adviser Resigns
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCains chief advertising strategist, Mark McKinnon, announced Tuesday that he was resigning, following through on a vow he had made months ago not to work against the candidacy of Senator Barack Obama.

title: Plastic Finds a Second Life and Skirts the Dump
description: WALTHAM, Mass.

title: Weak Dollar Bolsters H.P. Global Sales in Quarter
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The weak dollar has its detractors, but it is working out just fine for Hewlett-Packard.

title: For $1 Billion, They Should Work
description: Officially, the elevators and escalators in New Yorks sprawling subway system are incredibly reliable. In the last quarter alone, New York City Transit reported that they were working more than 98 percent of the time. Tell that to the pregnant woman on the runaway escalator or the passenger whose escalator began to disintegrate beneath her feet as she scrambled to safety. Tell that to all those commuters who have been trapped inside steamy elevators waiting for help.

title: A Double Standard Over Candidates Flag Pins?
description: To the Editor:

title: Wider Antiterror Role for Elite Forces Rejected
description: WASHINGTON  The militarys elite Special Operations Command has quietly stepped back from a controversial plan that gave it the authority to carry out secret counterterrorism missions on its own around the world.

title: Wall Street Journal Editor Named
description: Rupert Murdoch named Robert J. Thomson as the top editor of The Wall Street Journal on Tuesday, shifting one of his most trusted advisers from the publishers chair into one of the most important editorial jobs in American media.

title: In Netherlands, Soccer Is King, but Baseball Eyes Crown
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands  Robert Eenhoorns cellphone rang to the tinny tune of Take Me Out to the Ball Game, interrupting a discussion of the vigorous state of honkbal in his native land. Honkbal is the Dutch word for baseball, and Mr. Eenhoorn, 40, the coach of the Dutch national baseball team, should know something about it.

title: Clinton Fades Even in a Victory
description: While Senator Barack Obama gingerly commended his rivals perseverance, the shrinking candidacy of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton all but vanished from the television set on Tuesday, sidelined by bigger news.

title: Study Finds High Ground Zero Stress
description: A new study by the Mount Sinai School of Medicine suggests that the percentage of ground zero workers who suffered post-traumatic stress is roughly the same as for airline crash recovery workers and returning Afghanistan war veterans.

title: Fire Under Control at Home of Berlin Philharmonic
description: BERLIN  Firefighters brought a large fire in the roof of the famed home of the Berlin Philharmonic under control on Tuesday, but the full extent of damage to the building remained unclear.

title: Senate Panel Backs Housing Compromise
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate Banking Committee on Tuesday approved compromise legislation aimed at helping hundreds of thousands of homeowners in danger of foreclosure by expanding the availability of government-insured mortgages.

title: New Trend in Biofuels Has New Risks
description: ROME  In the past year, as the diversion of food crops like corn and palm to make biofuels has helped to drive up food prices, investors and politicians have begun promoting newer, so-called second-generation biofuels as the next wave of green energy. These, made from non-food crops like reeds and wild grasses, would offer fuel without the risk of taking food off the table, they said.

title: A Little Breathing Room for a Growing Market
description: The Flatbush Food Coop started with 11 members in 1976 and now has more than 3,000. But unlike many other co-ops, it is open to the public. On Sunday, it had a ribbon-cutting ceremony for its expanded store, which has been open for about a month.

title: A Developers Unusual Plan for Bright Lights, Inspired by a Dark Film
description: LOS ANGELES  The year is 2019. The illuminated windows of the citys densely packed towers sparkle like stars in the night, and their facades are covered with bright, animated billboards. A flying car glides past the enormous eye of a smiling geisha hundreds of stories above the wet urban streets.

title: Hamilton Jordan, Carters Right Hand, Dies at 63
description: Hamilton Jordan, a self-proclaimed political animal and campaign whiz-kid who, at age 26, ran a successful campaign for governor and, at age 31, a successful presidential campaign for Jimmy Carter, eventually becoming the presidents chief of staff and top confidant, died Tuesday at his home in Atlanta. He was 63.

title: Piazza Calls It Quits After 16 Years and 427 Homers
description: Mike Piazza, who went from a 62nd-round draft pick to the best-hitting catcher in major league history and a near-certain Hall of Famer, announced his retirement from baseball on Tuesday.

title: Correction
description: In his column on Monday, Bill Kristol said he could not find a recent primary in which the candidate who would go on to win the nomination lost by as big a margin as Barack Obama lost by (41 points) in West Virginia. Mitt Romney won the essentially uncontested Utah primary on Feb. 5 with about 90 percent of the vote.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A subheading on Tuesday with an article about a developers agreement to salvage a $1 billion deal for the railyards on the Far West Side of Manhattan misidentified, in some editions, the agency that owns the railyards. It is the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, not the Port Authority.

title: Pakistan: High-Level Talks With India Resume
description: India and Pakistan held high-level talks in Islamabad, marking the first peace negotiations between the rival nuclear nations after a 15-month lapse. Foreign Secretaries Shivshankar Menon of India and Salman Bashir of Pakistan discussed Islamic terrorism, economic cooperation and the disputed region of Kashmir. Pakistan and India agreed on what they described as a road map for peace in 2004, with both sides pledging to curb terrorism and strengthen ties.

description: Time: About 2 hours

title: Seeking Raise, Firefighters Will Reopen Contract

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on Tuesday about Senate legislation to expand the availability of government-insured mortgages misstated the role played by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-sponsored financial institutions. They purchase mortgages from lenders; they are not lenders themselves.

title: Dalai Lamas Britain Visit Raises Questions of Protocol
description: LONDON  The Dalai Lama arrived in London on Tuesday as part of a protracted foreign tour, highlighting efforts by European governments to balance Chinas hostility toward him against their support for human rights in Tibet.

title: Cyprus: Court Denies Extradition of Russian
description: A court in Cyprus has denied Russias request to extradite Vladislav Kartashov, a former executive of Yukos, once Russias largest oil company. The court ruled that charges of theft and tax fraud filed against him had been politically motivated. The decision further undermined the legitimacy of a Russian legal challenge to the corporate remnants of Yukos, which had been Russias top oil company before the arrest in 2003 of its owner, Mikhail Khodorkovsky. The arrest was widely viewed as an attack by the Kremlin on a political rival.

title: Bob Schieffer Makes a Golden Years Deal
description: Bob Schieffer has reached agreement with CBS News on a new contract that will probably keep him hosting Face the Nation for several more years. The deal does not specify how long he will host the Sunday morning public affairs show, Mr. Schieffer, 71, said on Monday. But when his tenure on the program does eventually end, said Mr. Schieffer, above, the new contract ensures that he will stay on at CBS News to provide on-camera analysis, including on election nights. Thats kind of the way Tom Brokaw works at NBC, Mr. Schieffer said. Toms kind of my model for how to live out the golden years. Mr. Schieffer said in January that he planned to leave Face the Nation soon after the inauguration of the next president, but he later said he had decided to postpone his retirement at the request of CBS News executives. The network has been unable to identify a successor to Mr. Schieffer, at least one who was available. The Washington Post reported on Monday that Mr. Schieffer and CBS had reached a long-term agreement.

title: On Back-to-Back Nights, a Homer Is Not a Homer
description: On consecutive nights this week, umpires ruled incorrectly about a batted ball that should have been called a home run.

title: Bertelsmann Appoints Outsider to Head Random House
description: On the day that Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate, quelled weeks of speculation by announcing that Markus Dohle, head of the companys printing unit, would take over as chief executive of Random House, industry executives were largely reserving judgment on what it would mean to have a relative outsider in charge of the worlds largest publisher of consumer books.

title: Barbara Sears Rockefeller, Actress With a Famous Divorce Settlement, Dies at 91
description: Barbara Sears Rockefeller, a Pennsylvania coal miners daughter who married one of the richest men in America and, after their divorce six years later, won a settlement regarded as a record in its day, died on Monday at her home in Little Rock, Ark. She was 91 and had lived in Arkansas for the last few years.

title: Excerpts From the Season, and a Return of Old Friends
description: No matter the sense of occasion that a ballet gala affords  the gowns, the celebrity sightings, the air kisses  once the actual dancing gets under way, its best to consider the expression one step forward, two steps back. If youre lucky, by the end the steps might more or less equal out, as they did on Monday night, when American Ballet Theater opened its spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: More Glory: Talking Baseball, From the 50s and 60s
description: Bart Giamatti, the former commissioner of Major League Baseball, was fond of saying that the history of the game was oral. This may sound somewhat counterintuitive, considering how much great literature the national pastime has produced. But there is an essential truth to Giamattis words. For baseball lovers nothing is more delicious than the firsthand stories of those who lived the dream and made it to the big leagues.

title: Argentina: Farmers Ready to Resume Negotiations

The strike began in March, initially paralyzing Argentine highways and leading to food shortages.

title: Auteur Whos Ripe for French Discovery
description: CANNES, France  On Monday evening, as I emerged from Lisandro Alonsos Liverpool, an Argentine movie that takes place in Tierra del Fuego (as you might have guessed from the title), it occurred to me that I had not seen an English-language film in four days. Not a long time, but in those 96 hours I had watched 12 movies. Whats more, of the 20 or so I had seen since the festival started last Wednesday, only one had come from the United States. (No, it was not Indiana Jones and the Global Publicity Bonanza, which Ill see with my kids when I get home. It was James Tobacks Tyson.)

title: From Sichuan to Oregon: Schools at Risk
description: [UPDATE 5/22: A poem has risen from the wreckage in China.] Im doing a fresh article examining how to cut the chances that more schools in known earthquake zones will crumble and kill in years to come. Yumei Wang, the geohazards team leader for the state of Oregon, sent me a cautionary note saying its important to remember that such risks are not confined to poor countries or emerging powers, but also face parts of the United States and other industrialized nations. She cited a 2007 survey of the vulnerability of schools and emergency-services buildings in Oregon that provides a chilling hint of the dangers. The bottom line? More than a thousand schools in Oregon are ready to fall in a quake that could be 32 times more powerful than the one that shattered eastern Sichuan province.

title: What About the Veterinarians?

title: Recipe of the Day: Spicy Shrimp Salad With Mint
description: Heres another dish, like those in todays Minimalist column, thats usually grilled but that works just as well, if not better, in the broiler. For years I never realized that one of the greatest assets of my favorite grilled shrimp dish  the juices that the shrimp exude  was just sputtering away on those hot coals. Thats why broiled shrimp are so desirable: you get to savor the juices, the essences, produced by the shrimp itself.

title: The Morning Skate: Cup Dates and Diving Greats
description: Poor Detroit. The local economy is crumbling, there are no jobs, the mayor  who is accused of perjury, obstruction of justice and misconduct in office charges  spends all his time fighting to save his own job. You know, small stuff. But now, real problems of apocalyptic proportions: the first three games of the Stanley Cup final are going head to head with three Pistons-Celtics NBA semifinal games. On two of those dates, theyll both be playing home games. The horror. THE HORROR!

Hillary Clinton won Kentucky, Obama is expected to win Oregon, which would mean that he would clinch a majority of the pledge delegates. There are the delegates, superdelegates, pledge delegates, Lemon Pledge delegates, and the farmer in the delegates, without which you dont get to the White House.

title: How to Talk About Iraq
description: When it comes to trying to figure out what we should do in Iraq, the presidential campaign debates are close to useless. To appease their parties bases, all the candidates articulate oversimplified, emotion-laden positions  Stay in! Get out!  that have little to do with the day-to-day complexities on the ground. Television talk shows, with their ratings-driven shouting matches, are worse. (And even though youre reading a blog, lets not talk about what gets said in most of the blogosphere.)

title: The Starting Line: Dalai Lama Reverses Himself on Attending the Olympics
description: The Dalai Lama said today in London that if he is invited to the Beijing Olympics, he would be happy to attend, reversing a statement he made last week in which he said it would be very hard for him to attend the Games if invited. The Tibetan leader made the remarks after arriving yesterday for a 12-day visit to the U.K..

As Asian nations spend more on their militaries, Mr. Schieffer said, so should Japan. He even has a shopping tip: buy fighter jets compatible with U.S. forces. The more joint operational we become, the better off we will be, he said.

Still, the researchers are not suggesting that sexism and cultural pressures on women dont play a role, and they dont yet know why women choose the way they do. Read more

title: Remain Silent Remain Silent Remain Silent
description: Maybe it was a 70s thing, but my mom thought it was her duty to prepare her kids for the tricky ways of police interrogators. I dont know why she was so sure wed one day need to know how to elude the stock police plays  your buddy upstairs has confessed, and of course good cop/bad cop  but she drilled us on cop stuff as if it were multiplication tables.

title: Clinton Invokes 2000 Recount
description: In the wake of her romp in Kentucky last night, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton pivoted with a wheels-up for a trip to Florida, one of those two states shes intent on seeing included in the delegate count as she uses her own magic math of 2210 delegates needed to become the Democratic nominee. (Not the 2026 the Obama campaign relies on, but the Clinton calculus that includes the Florida-Michigan seating.)She dialed in to the radio in Cleveland, Ohio, this morning, with Florida in mind, and reminding us all of oh, the 2000 nightmare that was a 36-day recount. Remember that? Shes not going to let us forget it soon; (at least not before the May 31 meeting of the Rules and Bylaws Committee of the Democratic National Committee).

title: More Unintended Risks From Biofuels?
description: Much of the recent heat over biofuels has been focused on how much this booming business may have contributed to the international spike in food prices that has had an outsize impact on poor people. Defenders of farm-grown fuels point to studies showing the biofuels boom has had a minor impact on food prices compared to the surge in energy costs. They also say the eventual goal is to shift away from sources like corn toward plants harvested for their cellulose  ending competition with cropland or food markets.

title: Giuliani Owes $3.1 Million
description: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York not only went through $58 million of other peoples money in his failed presidential bid. Hes also facing $3 million in campaign debt. And that is after he put $500,000 of his own money into his losing effort to win the Republican nomination  a campaign that ended shortly after his Florida-focused strategy failed.

But people there and elsewhere are still buzzing about Mr. Obamas Sunday rally in Portland, which drew 75,000 people  the largest crowd not just of Mr. Obamas campaign but probably, according to local politicos, in Oregon campaign history.

This upgrade to its pedestrian walkway on the Brooklyn side includes new pedestrian signs and a permanent public-art lighting installation to welcome pedestrians exiting the bridge through the stairwell leading into Dumbo.

It was the first final played in Russia and the first final played on two surfaces: a much-maligned grass field (which like the games referee is from Slovakia) installed over the equally maligned artificial turf at Luzhniki Stadium. Chelsea came into the game without a loss in nine matches; United traveled to (wet and cool) Moscow after winning its second straight Premier League title.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An obituary on May 13 about Murray Jarvik, a psychopharmacologist who was among the first to study LSD, referred incorrectly to the chemical compound D-lysergic acid, which he studied in the 1950s. It is a precursor of LSD, not LSD itself. The obituary also referred incorrectly to the publication history of The Village Voice, quoting an account Dr. Jarvik gave in a 2001 interview. The newspaper was founded in 1955; it did not exist in 1953, when, by Dr. Jarviks account, he placed an advertisement in the paper seeking subjects for an LSD study at Mount Sinai Hospital.

title: Understanding and Outrage From Air Travelers
description: Daniel Rosenthal just finished classes at Yeshiva University, but he already expects that his expenses this fall will go up, thanks to American Airlines.

title: Courage in Elm City
description: Last year, in an act of considerable political courage, New Haven began offering a municipal ID card to all residents, including illegal immigrants. The reaction from anti-immigrant forces was predictably ugly. Protesters disrupted hearings, heckled and threatened city officials and tried to intimidate businesses that supported the program, which is believed to be the first of its kind in the nation. The city has held firm.

title: City Says Best Schools May Suffer
description: Some of New York Citys highest-performing schools could suffer painful budget cuts as high as 6 percent next year, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said on Wednesday, blaming state rules that restrict how the city can spend state education money.

title: A Surprise as Fans Pick a 7th Idol
description: LOS ANGELES  It was a winner by a knockout on Wednesday in the finale of the seventh season of American Idol, but the victor was not the contestant who appeared to have delivered the decisive blow on the final night of competition one night earlier.

title: Testimony Links Sprinter Pettigrew to Drugs
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A drug adviser and distributor testified in federal court Wednesday that the sprinter Antonio Pettigrew obtained performance-enhancing drugs during a four-year period in which he competed on a record-setting 4x400-meter relay team.

title: Two Choirs, and One Increasingly Busy Conductor
description: If the Department of Justice investigated conducting monopolies, its agents would be taking a close look at Kent Tritle. Just under two decades ago he started the Sacred Music in a Sacred Space series at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola and quickly turned its resident choir into a finely polished, stylistically nimble ensemble. In 2005 he was appointed music director of the venerable Oratorio Society of New York, and this year he added Musica Sacra to his portfolio.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A jazz review on Wednesday about the Tomasz Stanko Quartet, at the Museum of Modern Art, referred incorrectly to the selection of music played. Three of the nine pieces were by Mr. Stanko; they were not all by the Polish film composer Krzysztof Komeda.

title: Senate Panel Supports California Emissions Waiver
description: A Senate panel approved a measure to reverse a ruling by the Environmental Protection Agency and let California enforce auto emission standards that are tougher than federal law. The Committee on Environment and Public Works voted 10 to 9 to amend the Clean Air Act to grant Californias request for a waiver from E.P.A. rules that prohibit states from establishing their own pollution restrictions. Fourteen other states have adopted or are adopting the California standards and seek similar waivers from the federal rules.

title: In the Spring Garden, Some Joys Just Wont Wait
description: MY friend Rock and I have different attitudes about the garden.

title: Police Dig Up Backyard in Futile Search for Body
description: Workers dug up a Queens backyard on Wednesday in a police search for human remains after a man imprisoned for murder suggested that he had left a body there, the authorities said.

title: F.A.A. Bans Antismoking Drug, Citing Side Effects
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said Wednesday it would no longer permit pilots or air traffic controllers to use the smoking cessation drug Chantix, citing potential side effects that could pose a threat to the safe operation of aircraft.

title: Moscow Takes British Soccer Invasion in Stride
description: MOSCOW  Red Square felt more like Piccadilly Circus as thousands of English soccer fans swarmed the Russian capital for some quick sightseeing ahead of the first all-English final of the prestigious European Champions League later on Wednesday.

title: Bell Canada Takeover Is Blocked
description: OTTAWA  An appeals court quashed approval for the $51.8 billion leveraged buyout of Bell Canada on Wednesday after siding with angry bondholders in a ruling.

description: ROME  Beginning his third term as prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi on Wednesday pledged unusually forceful measures to solve Italys deep problems. These steps include new restrictions on illegal immigrants and the use of the military to tackle the longstanding garbage crisis in Naples.

title: A Sly Brand of Relaxation That Doesnt Involve Leisure
description: Al Foster pulls off a neat trick as a jazz drummer, and its hard to say exactly how he does it. Like a number of his peers, Mr. Foster, 64, places his beat on the forward lip of any tempo, creating an irresistible pull. And yet his playing exudes a laid-back feel, with plenty of room built in. To watch him in action, perched low to the ground behind several sharply angled cymbals, is to witness something like an expert golf swing.

title: Oklahoma: University Gets $100 Million Donation
description: In the largest gift to a university from a living donor this year, Oklahoma State University is being given $100 million by the energy tycoon Boone Pickens, the university announced. Mr. Pickens, an alumnus of Oklahoma State and the founder and chairman of BP Capital Management, has already donated about $400 million to the university. Oklahoma law dictates that gifts like Mr. Pickenss, given for endowed chairs, are to be matched by the state, bringing the amount the university will receive to $200 million.
