title: Americans Can Send Phones to Cuba
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush announced Wednesday that Americans would soon be allowed to give their relatives in Cuba cell phones to use. The move is intended to challenge Cubas new leader, Raul Castro, to make good on his promises of reform, by giving ordinary Cubans more freedom to communicate with one another and the outside world.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on Wednesday about personnel issues confronting the Giants described incorrectly, in some editions, a big Super Bowl catch by Kevin Boss, the teams promising young tight end. It was a 45-yard play, not a touchdown.

title: At Table No. 3, Lunch With a Side of Schmooze
description: Joe Armstrong, who is otherwise known as the Mayor of Michaels, took his usual perch at Table No. 3 on Tuesday as the suits began filling the room.

title: Israel Holds Peace Talks With Syria
description: JERUSALEM  Israel and Syria announced on Wednesday that they were engaged in negotiations for a comprehensive peace treaty through Turkish mediators, a sign that Israel is hoping to halt the growing influence of Iran, Syrias most important ally, which sponsors the anti-Israel groups Hezbollah and Hamas.

title: Former Band Manager Is Sentenced
description: Lou Pearlman, right, the former manager of pop acts like the Backstreet Boys and N Sync, was sentenced to 25 years in prison on Wednesday for running a decades-long investment scheme that defrauded investors of $300 million. In a sentencing hearing at Federal District Court in Orlando, Fla., Judge G. Kendall Sharp gave Mr. Pearlman an unusual incentive to pay back his investors, offering to reduce the sentence by one month for every $1 million he repays. Mr. Pearlman, 53, pleaded guilty in March to charges of conspiracy and money laundering in connection with a Ponzi scheme in which he used fake accounting documents to lure people to invest in two companies that existed only on paper. Mr. Pearlman fled the country early last year, once federal authorities began investigating him, and in June he was found at a hotel in Bali, registered under the name A. Incognito Johnson. Larry Rifken, a lawyer representing victims of the schemes, said in a statement: The Creditors Committee is delighted with Judge Sharps ruling today on Mr. Pearlmans sentence and believes that Judge Sharp did an excellent job in maximizing Mr. Pearlmans incentive to cooperate with the Trustee and the Committee in identifying, locating and monetizing any remaining undisclosed assets.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article in some editions on March 13 about the struggle among parents in the New York region over how to answer their childrens questions about the sex scandal that brought down Gov. Eliot Spitzer misstated the name of the 6-year-old daughter of Joy and Jeff Yagid of Maplewood, N.J.. She is Bella, not Della. Ms. Yagid left a note on an online bulletin board on March 14 alerting the reporter to the error, but the reporter did not see the note until Friday.

title: A New Turn on Old Pots
description: Teco art pottery vases produced by William D. Gates in Illinois in the early 20th century, in dark blue, pale yellow and a popular subtle green, have been highly collectible since the 1980s. Now Prairie Arts, a company outside Chicago that makes and sells American Arts and Crafts accessories, is reproducing the vases in two new colors that appeal to that younger demographic, said Bryan Kelly, one of the owners.

title: U.N. Leader Aims to Get More Aid in Myanmar
description: BANGKOK  The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, flew on Thursday to Myanmar, where he hoped to pry open the door to more international aid at what he called a critical moment in the countrys slow recovery from the cyclone that left at least 100,000 people dead or missing.

title: Britain: A New Look for Judges
description: Civil court judges in England are scheduled to ditch their traditional wigs and robes in October. The old, stuffy outfits  curly gray wigs made from horsehair, severe black robes with winged collars and stiff neckbands  are to be replaced by modern navy robes created by the fashion designer Betty Jackson. Ms. Jackson, who donated her services, is friends with the wife of a judge, a spokesman for the judiciary said. The changes will not apply to criminal court judges, nor to barristers, as lawyers who argue cases in court are known in Britain. Critics of the traditional wigs and robes have long complained that they alienate people in court and look hopelessly out of date.

title: A Keyboard Invites Preschoolers to Play With the Computer. Mom and Dad Wont Mind.
description: While custom keyboards for children are not new, Computer Cool School from Fisher-Price takes the genre up a notch, with light-up activity keys, a surprisingly sensitive touch pad and stylus and a software package that can manage settings for up to five children.

title: When Two Davids Became Goliaths
description: As David Archuleta and David Cook competed for the title of American Idol, the second-to-last installment of the Fox shows seventh season attracted 26.1 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. That tally was up slightly from the same night a year ago (25.3 million). Fox dominated the nights ratings over all, attracting 12.6 million with Hells Kitchen during the 9 oclock hour after the final performances. ABC was runner up, as 19.9 million viewers tuned in for the finale of Dancing With the Stars from 9 to 11. CBS ranked third, earning a large audience for the two-hour finale of NCIS (16.4 million). At 10, CBSs Shark delivered more modest ratings (10.5 million). NBC finished fourth over all, with mostly repeats.

title: Pakistan and Taliban Agree to Armys Gradual Pullback
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  The government signed a deal with Taliban militants on Wednesday that calls for the Pakistani Army to withdraw gradually from Swat, a once popular resort area in North-West Frontier Province that has become a battleground.

title: Sony Pictures to Release Rent
description: The Broadway production of Rent is headed to movie theaters. The final performance of the rock musical, which exits Broadway on Sept. 7 after 12 years, will be exhibited nationwide as part of a new business from Sony Pictures. The movie studio said on Wednesday that it would bring music concerts, stage shows and sporting events to multiplexes. Another early offering will be Delirium, a Cirque du Soleil show touring Europe. Exact dates for the limited engagements are still undecided. Programming theaters with nonmovie content has been gaining steam as multiplex owners seek ways to attract new ticket buyers. Sony is the first big studio to dip its toe into the arena, which until now has been left to niche players like Colorado-based Fathom Events, which simulcasts from the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Kennedy: A Little Like Everyone, a Lot Like No One Else
description: WASHINGTON  Congress is rife with types: the Serious Legislator, the Bomb Thrower, the Show Horse, the Workhorse, the Blowhard, the Orator, the Partisan, the Statesman, the Prima Donna, the Mentor, the Old-fashioned Pol and the Visionary.

title: Clinton Signals She May Carry Fight to Convention
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla.  A day after Senator Barack Obama gathered a majority of pledged delegates in the Democratic presidential nominating contest, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton defiantly sent out new signals Wednesday that she might take her fight for the nomination all the way to the partys convention in August.

title: Gun Dealer and Mayor Face Showdown
description: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg stood at City Hall two years ago to announce that he had just filed suit against several gun shop owners, mainly in the South, it was in a certain fashion the capstone of a signature campaign. Mr. Bloomberg had already bashed the industry in several angry speeches, gone to Washington to pressure congressmen and lobbyists, and made his war against illegal guns a personal crusade.

title: With Mild Concussion, A Met Hopes to Return
description: ATLANTA  Ryan Church sauntered down the tunnel leading from the Mets clubhouse to the field, his bright blue hat on backward, concealing the tomato-size red welt on the right side of his forehead. The night before, he collided with Braves shortstop Yunel Escobar on the last play of the game and laid motionless, his head in the dirt next to second base.

title: Swimsuits Make the Man
description: THERE is a sad deficiency of well-made mens swimwear. Apart from classic surfer shorts from reliable suppliers like Birdwell, we are drowning in a sea of bunchy nylon, bad graphics and unfortunate cuts.

title: U.S. Troops Kill 11 Shiite Militants
description: BAGHDAD  American troops killed 11 suspected Shiite militants in a series of clashes near Sadr City on Wednesday, one day after thousands of Iraqi troops moved onto the streets of the east Baghdad district.

title: Diplomatic Effort Seeks to Ease Tensions and Lead to Talks in Georgian Enclave
description: SUKHUMI, Georgia  The long military standoff in Abkhazia, where a separatist dispute has threatened to escalate this year into a renewed war, has entered a phase of quiet diplomacy aimed at easing tensions and urging negotiations, officials on each side of the conflict said.

title: Lion Who Made Players Roar Faces the Quiet
description: Marvin Miller transformed major league baseball players from sheep into lions.

title: McCain Set to Release Health Data on Friday
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain is set to release 400 pages of medical records, including documents related to his melanoma surgery in August 2000, to a tightly controlled group of reporters on the Friday before Memorial Day weekend.

title: Where Ralph Buys Blouses
description: AT 7 most mornings, including a lot of Saturdays and Sundays, Pat Capolupo is in his garment factory, Pat & Rose Dresses, on West 37th Street. Rose is Rose Panebianco, his sister, and for the last 40 years they have made the drive together from Cliffside Park, N.J., where they live two blocks apart.

title: Return of the Scream
description: Bearing scars from a brazen theft, the Edvard Munch Expressionist masterwork The Scream went back on view on Wednesday in Oslo at the Munch Museum, where it was stolen in 2004, Agence France-Presse reported. The Scream and Madonna, another Munch painting seized at the same time, were presented to the news media and will go on public display from Friday through Sept. 26 under the title Scream and Madonna  Revisited. Then Madonna will undergo further restoration. The museum said its Scream, long thought to have been painted in 1893, as was another version, probably dates from 1910, although some doubts remain. Both paintings were scratched and torn and showed signs of humidity damage when they were recovered by the police in August 2006 under mysterious circumstances.

title: Ways for Collectors and Dealers to Keep It Real
description: David H. Wilson, an antiques restorer in New Jersey who consults for Christies, offered these tips for spotting fakes.

title: The Meaning of Mushrooms
Florida Pension Fund Is Suing A.I.G.
description: In another blow to the embattled American International Group, a Florida pension fund accused the insurance giant and a number of its top executives on Wednesday of understating the companys exposure to the subprime mortgage crisis in order to inflate its stock price artificially.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on May 14 about a request to Congress for an infusion of $275 million for the Food and Drug Administration misstated the time frame for spending the money. Legislation is being written to allow the agency to spend the money through fiscal year 2009. A letter from the Food and Drug commissioner, Andrew C. von Eschenbach, to Senator Arlen Specter did not say that the agency could absorb the money in the next few months, nor did it give a specific time period.

title: Quick Reminder to Speed Up Games
description: Baseball games are taking an extra minute out of the lives of fans, and team owners are concerned. On Tuesday, officials from the office of Commissioner Bud Selig held conference calls with club officials and umpires to remind them of rules designed to quicken games.

title: Fewer Conflicts Involve Child Soldiers, Report Finds
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The number of conflicts in which children are used as soldiers has dropped sharply in the past four years, to 17 from 27, according to a research report released this week by the Coalition to Stop the Use of Child Soldiers.

title: Where Children Fight the Wars, Innocence Dies First
description: CANNES, France  The brutal French-Belgian-Liberian movie Johnny Mad Dog, an assaultive fiction about Liberian child soldiers made with boys and girls who actually fought in that countrys recent war, left me wrung out  furious, confused, deep in thought. Shown Tuesday in Un Certain Regard, a section of the Cannes Film Festival reserved for younger and experimental filmmakers, the movie is the first fiction feature by Jean-Stphane Sauvaire, a former assistant director who was born in 1968. Mr. Sauvaire previously made the documentary Carlitos Medellin (2004), about children who are surviving and dying from the violence that plagues Medellin, Colombia.

title: Taliban Make Afghan Stability a Distant Goal
description: KHAKREZ, Afghanistan  Last fall, groups of Taliban fighters swarmed into every village in this district in southern Afghanistan. American forces arrived to sweep them out in January, people here say. By April, the Taliban were back, surrounding the district center in a show of force that froze villagers in their tracks. Then the insurgents melted away again.

title: A Sketch From Spain and More Classic Fare
description: Countries with powerful popular cultures dont produce many fugues. Abstraction and formal design have a hard time competing with musical impulses that seem to grow out of the ground, especially when the country is Spain and the melding of European and North African music remains so strong.

title: Pirates, Pashas and Slaves in a Duel of Airborne Acrobatics
description: As war horses go, Le Corsaire is decidedly pretty and can still kick, a nice choice for the first week of American Ballet Theaters season at the Metropolitan Opera House. What is rather lovable about this ballet, which opened on Tuesday night, is its utter lack of interest in Great Art. The story, originally inspired by Lord Byrons 1814 poem The Corsair, now bears only the faintest of resemblances to that work, which blends ideas about slavery and liberation into the tale of the pirate Conrad, that man of loneliness and mystery, scarce seen to smile.

title: Lottery Numbers
Why a Fish Didnt Show at a Festival in Its Honor
description: NYACK, N.Y.

title: Deal for Lebanese Factions Leaves Hezbollah Stronger
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The agreement reached by Lebanese political factions early Wednesday amounted to a significant shift of power in favor of the militant Shiite group Hezbollah and its allies in the opposition, who won the power to veto any cabinet decision.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A capsule summary on Wednesday for an article about F.B.I. agents creating a war crimes file to document accusations against American military personnel misstated the year that the agents were told to close the file. It was 2003, not 2002.

title: Web Site Sells Designers Discounted Samples
description: A Web site where decorators and designers can buy from hundreds of manufacturers and showrooms now has a sample-sale area open to the public. Discounted items change constantly, but those now on sale at decorati.com include a colored crystal chandelier in black, left, from NiBa Home in Miami for $8,438 (reduced from $9,375), a Hans Wegner Airport Chair from Dennis Miller in New York for $1,100 (it was $2,500) and a pair of Karl Springer chairs from Todd Hase Furniture for $1,900 (marked down from $2,879). Information: (415) 227-4558 or decorati.com.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Plants for a Japanese Garden

title: Puerto Ricos Moment in the Sun
description: PUERTO RICO, an afterthought trophy for the United States 110 years ago at the end of the Spanish-American War and an island in limbo since, has become an improbable player in the contest between Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama. Its primary on June 1 could bolster Mrs. Clintons claim to a majority of the popular vote  the combined tally for all the Democratic primaries and caucuses held across the country over the past six months.

title: Frank Rich to Be Consultant for HBO
description: Frank Rich, an Op-Ed columnist for The New York Times, has signed on with HBO as a creative consultant to help develop new programming, while still writing his weekly column, HBO and Times executives said Wednesday.

title: Senators Sharply Question Oil Officials
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee vented their fury over high gasoline prices at executives of the nations five largest oil companies on Wednesday, grilling the oilmen over their multimillion-dollar pay packages and warning them that Congress was intent on taking action that could include a new tax on so-called windfall profits.

title: A Quick Leap to Five Hearts, All in the Interest of Charity
description: The worlds most successful single-session charity bridge event had its 45th running on May 14 at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan, with most of the top New York-area players competing. Organized by Marci Miron and Marion Madoff, the event raised more than $125,000 for the UJA-Federation of New York.

title: The Senate Race in New Jersey: Watching the Debates
description: To the Editor:

title: In Bronx, Dancer Does Right Thing
description: For 10 years the choreographer Arthur Aviles has been doing yeomans work in the Hunts Point neighborhood of the Bronx, where he and his partner, the writer Charles Rice-Gonzalez, founded the Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance (BAAD!) in 1998. This work  maintaining a safe, welcoming space for performers and people of all stripes  is as much about activism as it is about art.

title: Education Agencys Plan Shores Up Market for Loans to College Students
description: Secretary of Education Margaret Spellings on Wednesday announced a plan committing the federal government to buy college loans for the coming school year from student lending companies and to take other measures to ensure that despite troubled credit markets, students will have access to college financing.

title: Rock and Blue Eyes Top Billboards Chart
description: Two unlikely acts top this weeks Billboard album chart. Death Cab for Cutie, a bookish indie-rock quartet from Seattle, has reached No. 1 for the first time, and a Frank Sinatra compilation is No. 2. Narrow Stairs (Atlantic), Death Cab for Cuties seventh album, sold 144,000 copies in its first week, Nielsen SoundScan reported. Nothing but the Best (Reprise), released to coincide with the 10th anniversary of Sinatras death, moved 99,000 copies and is the highest-charting Sinatra album since his Duets reached No. 2 a dozen years ago. We Sing. We Dance. We Steal Things. (Atlantic) by the singer Jason Mraz bowed at No. 3 with 73,000 sales, and another new album, Rockferry (A&M/Polydor) by the Welsh singer Duffy, is No. 4, moving 71,000.

title: Rescue Ends One Ordeal for Young Chinese Pupils
description: CHENGDU, China  When the earth finally stopped bucking, only one building was left standing in the vicinity of the Yinxing Township Central Primary School, and that was the school itself.

title: Three Dubliners Plain Poetry of Everyday Loss
description: Words are sharp, shiny hooks in the monologues of the Irish playwright Conor McPherson. They attract and snag the attention, snaring it at least until the language stops, and usually well after that. Give those words to actors who know how to cast a line, and youll find an audience helplessly captive.

title: Nokia and France Tlcom Form Partnership
description: Nokia and France Tlcom said they had agreed to a partnership to provide Internet services over mobile telephones in nine European countries.

title: A Laptop Straight From the Mothership
description: Alienware, a Dell subsidiary that makes amped-up desktops and laptops for gamers, just released the Area-51 m17x. True to its name, this futuristic-looking laptop, which starts at $2,199, looks as if it just floated out of an invading spacecraft.

title: Theme Persists: Obama Outraises Clinton
description: Though Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton raised an impressive $21 million in April, her campaign ended the month $20 million in debt and with Senator Barack Obama more than $30 million ahead of her in cash on hand for the primary season, according to their latest campaign finance reports.

title: Ex-Network Reporter Leaves Journalism to Join Obamas Campaign
description: Linda Douglass, a longtime network news correspondent in Washington now working as a contributing editor to The National Journal, said Wednesday that she would leave the magazine to work for Senator Barack Obamas campaign.

title: Questions on Claim That Senator Was Target of Attacks
description: YONKERS  The staff of State Senator Andrea Stewart-Cousins says that her district office here has been the target of attacks and a break-in recently, but the police have raised questions about some parts of the staffs account.

title: Bush to Let Americans Send Cellphones to Cuban Relatives
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush announced Wednesday that Americans would soon be allowed to send cellphones to relatives in Cuba, a policy shift he said was intended to force the countrys new leader, Ral Castro, to make good on promised reforms by giving his people the freedom to communicate.

title: Making Opponents See Double
description: The Final Four on Saturday in Foxborough, Mass., will showcase a Duke team that is considered one of the best ever, a revitalized Syracuse club that did not qualify for the postseason last year and a Johns Hopkins team that overcame a five-game losing streak.

title: Church Has Mild Concussion, but He Plans Quick Return
description: ATLANTA  Ryan Church sauntered down the tunnel leading from the Mets clubhouse to the field, his bright blue hat on backward, concealing the tomato-size red welt on the right side of his forehead. The night before, he collided with Braves shortstop Yunel Escobar on the last play of the game and laid motionless, his head in the dirt next to second base.

title: House Votes to Override Bushs Veto of Farm Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The House voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday afternoon to override President Bushs veto of the $307 billion farm bill, setting the stage for the second veto defeat of Mr. Bushs presidency.

title: More Questions Are Raised About Moodys Ratings
description: The Moodys Corporation is investigating whether it assigned top-flight credit ratings to certain securities because of computer errors, the company said Wednesday, raising new questions about the credibility of its assessments.

title: Its Still a Big City, Just Not Quite So Big
description: Somehow, Michael S. Miller resisted the temptation when he got home not long ago.

title: In These Places, Old Age Becomes a Team Sport
description: For their new books, Dudley Clendinen and Andrew D. Blechman had different versions of the same idea: infiltrate the world of the not-young and study the native customs. But they took on similar projects for very different reasons. Mr. Clendinen cared deeply about his mother and wanted to understand the last years of her life. Mr. Blechman apparently liked the prospect of shooting geriatric fish in a barrel.

title: Concerns From Fed Reverberate on Wall Street
description: The Federal Reserves aggressive rate-cutting campaign may be at an end.

title: American, Cutting Back, Plans $15 Bag Fee
description: Theres an old saying about the best way to travel: bring half the clothes and twice the money.

title: Top ETA Leader Is Seized in France
description: MADRID  Spanish and French authorities said on Wednesday they had arrested one of the highest-ranking members of ETA, dealing a blow to the Basque separatist group after a series of attacks in northern Spain.

title: Minnesota Agency Faulted on Bridge Upkeep
description: Before the Interstate 35W bridge in downtown Minneapolis collapsed last year, state transportation officials had put off recommendations from experts to make it safer, failed to follow their own inspection policies and at times allowed financing concerns to affect how it was maintained, a team of investigators told Minnesota lawmakers in a report Wednesday.

title: Donor Gives $20 Million to Revive a Historic Church
description: An anonymous donor has come to the rescue of St. Brigids Roman Catholic Church in the East Village, saving the building  which has presided over Tompkins Square Park since 1848  from demolition and making it possible for the structure to be reopened as a parish church.

title: Zelma Henderson, Who Aided Desegregation, Dies at 88
description: Zelma Henderson, a Kansas beautician who was the sole surviving plaintiff in Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka, the landmark federal desegregation case of 1954, died on Tuesday in Topeka. She was 88 and had lived in Topeka all her adult life.

title: Texas Seeks Stay of Polygamy Sect Custody Ruling
description: HOUSTON  The custody battle over 468 children seized from the ranch of a polygamist sect moved to the Texas Supreme Court on Friday, with the state insisting that the children were too endangered by sexual and emotional abuse to be returned to their families.

title: Appeals Court Rules Against Texas in Polygamy Case
description: HOUSTON  A Texas appeals court ruled Thursday that state authorities and a lower court judge abused their authority by illegally seizing up to 468 children from their homes at a polygamist ranch in West Texas last month.

title: Fashions Harlem Address
description: IN the self-aggrandizing nature of fashion speak, the term emerging designer market is often employed to mask what to the average mind would be called a crafts fair, where the only key to entry is a hot glue gun and a sack of beads.

title: Zimbabwe: More Trouble for Anglicans
description: Despite a Supreme Court order requiring that the renegade Anglican bishop Nolbert Kunonga, a supporter of President Robert Mugabe, share dozens of churches in Harare, the capital, with followers of Bishop Sebastian Bakare, church officials and parishioners said the police had continued to harass and lock out the bulk of the citys Anglicans. The police have continued to brutalize our people, which is sad, said Bishop Albert Chama, the dean of the Anglican Province of Central Africa. This is political interference. Im sure the police are getting orders from above. Theyre protecting Kunonga.

title: Fund Manager Is to Refinance Stalled Auction-Rate Notes
description: Nuveen Investments, the largest American manager of closed-end funds, said on Wednesday that it had a commitment for up to $1.75 billion in liquidity support to help refinance the troubled auction-rate preferred shares its funds once issued.

title: More Space, Delivered to You
description: NEARLY everyone needs more space for storage, but theres an alternative to renting a truck and carting the excess to a rented unit: the storage space can come to you.

title: Scientists See Supernova in Action
description: A star trembled on the brink of eternity. Outwardly all was serene, but its inside was falling into chaos.

title: I Love What You Didnt Do to Your Chipped Nails
description: PITY the mothers and grandmothers. Visible bra straps, glaringly obvious roots  these are but a few of the grooming no-nos that have become yes-yeses in recent years.

title: Unnecessary Distraction Brings Randolph Apology
description: ATLANTA  Willie Randolphs pregame meeting with members of the news media in the managers office at Turner Field on Wednesday started with a question about the health of Ryan Church, who was injured the night before in a collision at second base.

title: At One University, Tobacco Money Is a Secret
description: On campuses nationwide, professors and administrators have passionately debated whether their universities should accept money for research from tobacco companies. But not at Virginia Commonwealth University, a public institution in Richmond, Va.

title: Costly in Alaska
description: To the Editor:

title: From a World-Class Rower, Tips to Sharpen Technique
description: UNLIKE the teammates who power a quad or an eight-boat and rely on one another for rhythm and timing, a single sculler has no other rower to look to. He or she is a solitary person in a narrow shell of a boat no more than 12 inches across at its widest point.

title: A Digital Picture Frame, Packaged With Your Images
description: If you wish you could skip the technical hurdle of loading your photos from a computer or memory card onto a digital picture frame, Kodak will happily do it for you.

title: Voters Choose David Cook as Idol Winner
description: LOS ANGELES  It was a winner by a knockout Wednesday in the finale of the seventh season of American Idol, but the victor was not the contestant who appeared to have delivered the decisive blow during the final night of competition one night earlier.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A picture caption with an article on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about foreign investors purchases of Manhattan office buildings reversed the identifications of the two buildings shown. The building at 31 West 52nd Street was shown in the top photograph and the Altria Building, at 120 Park Avenue, was below.

title: Microsoft Offers Rebates to Shoppers Using Its Search
description: With its share of the Internet search market in steady decline and its pursuit of an alliance with Yahoo in doubt, Microsoft is taking a new approach to jump-starting its search engine: offering rebates to people who use it to find and buy some products.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on April 4 about Rafael Azcona, the Spanish novelist and scriptwriter, misstated his date of death, relying on information from the Spanish Writers and Editors Society, and misstated his widows given name. He died on March 24, not March 23, and his widow is Susan Youdelman, not Susi. The Associated Press issued a correction on Wednesday.

title: Charles Brenner, Psychoanalyst, Dies at 94
description: Dr. Charles Brenner, who reigned for nearly a half-century as the dean of American psychoanalysis, working to clarify, refine and fiercely defend its core principles, died Monday in Manhattan. He was 94.

title: Physical Culture | At Trails End, Theres Nothing Like Happy Feet
description: DESPITE improvements in socks and shoes, blisters remain a sports injury that wont go away. Its one of the most common minor injuries among outdoor enthusiasts, said Dr. Christopher Van Tilburg, the author of Mountain Rescue Doctor and the editor of the magazine Wilderness Medicine. Its not often reported so we dont have a lot of statistics, but its very, very common and can be extremely debilitating on a long hike.

title: Manchester United Wins Champions League Final
description: MOSCOW  A domestic rivalry splashed over international borders on Wednesday when Englands two best soccer clubs took their tenacious battle to the banks of the Moscow River to play for Europes most coveted athletic prize.

title: House Override of Farm Bill Veto Is Only the 2nd in Bushs Presidency
description: WASHINGTON  The House voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday to override President Bushs veto of the $307 billion farm bill, just the second override in his presidency.

title: Was Camerawork Negative? Sure, but Not in a Victory
description: I took the Willie Randolph Television Challenge.

title: When Lightning Strikes a Modem
description: Q. The first time I used my Dell laptop after a heavy storm, the computer would not hold a dial tone when I tried to dial up to the Internet, and I still cannot get online with that computer. If this modem is fried, can I get an external modem for my laptop, or are there other options?

title: Artisanal Offerings Are the Trend at Furniture Fair
description: MANY of the pieces at this years International Contemporary Furniture Fair at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center this month felt more artisanal than manufactured, with less of the emphasis on new materials and technology that dominated the show in the last decade.

title: Doctors Who Say Theyre Sorry
description: The willingness of doctors at several major medical centers to apologize to patients for harmful errors is a promising step toward improving the quality of a medical system that kills tens of thousands of patients a year inadvertently.

title: Make It Proud and Loud, With Strings
description: The New York Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Marvin Hamlisch demonstrated what might be called the First Law of Orchestration on Tuesday at Avery Fisher Hall in a 90-minute entertainment, Broadways Greatest Showstoppers.

title: Police Officers Gather to Mourn and Wonder
description: ALBANY  Between the solemn invocations and bagpipe tributes on Wednesday afternoon, it was hard to overlook the fact that this years annual tribute to fallen New York police officers took place under unusually fraught circumstances.

title: Headbangers From Iraq, Thrashing and Waiting
description: It was already an unlikely story: Around 2000, a group of Iraqi school friends weaned on bootleg Metallica and Slayer tapes formed their own metal band with an imposing name, Acrassicauda (derived from the name of a species of black scorpion), and an appropriately do-or-die attitude.

title: A New Manhattan Park Teaches Children About Plants
description: Michael Van Valkenburgh, a landscape architect making his mark in New York with ambitious projects like Brooklyn Bridge Park, has created a more modest bit of greenery: the Toyota Childrens Learning Garden, a pocket park at 603 East 11th Street, on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

title: At West Bank Conference, Dreams of Investment
description: BETHLEHEM, West Bank  Hundreds of potential investors and dignitaries from the Middle East and beyond gathered here on Wednesday for the start of a vaunted conference under the slogan, Palestine is open for business.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on Friday about CBSs $1.8 billion deal to buy CNet Networks misstated, in some copies, the color of the sneakers worn by Quincy Smith, president of CBS Interactive, in an appearance last week at the networks upfront presentation for advertisers. As an accompanying picture showed, they were dark-colored  not his trademark white ones. And the caption for that photograph misstated, in some copies, the day of Mr. Smiths appearance. It was Wednesday, May 14  not last Thursday.

title: As Oil Prices Rise, Nations Revive Coal Mining
description: BIBAI, Japan  These rugged green mountains, once home to one of Asias most productive coal regions, are littered with abandoned mines and decaying towns  backwaters of an economy of bullet trains and hybrid cars.

title: New Florida Law Allows Low-Cost Health Policies

title: Author Examines the State of the Avant Garden Movement
description: What has happened to the avant garden since 1979, when Martha Schwartz burned a hole in the landscape world with her Bagel Garden? In Avant Gardeners: 50 Visionaries of the Contemporary Landscape (Thames & Hudson, $60), Tim Richardson, a British critic, examines gardens driven more by concept than plants or place, from Ms. Schwartzs double row of varnished bagels in Cambridge, Mass. (he calls it half Pop Art, half 17th-century parterre), to more recent projects like Claude Cormiers Lipstick Forest, 52 pink concrete tree trunks at a Montreal convention center, and Ron Lutskos minimalist landscapes in California. Mr. Richardson, who is as well-versed in 18th-century landscapes as he is in the primary colors of a Topher Delaney garden, matter-of-factly acknowledges that art must shed some blood to stay alive, which makes him a good Virgil for the journey into what he calls conceptualist landscape design.

Like the 1981 blockbuster Raiders of the Lost Ark, the first in a monster franchise that has spawned two previous movie sequels, a television series, comics, novels, video games and Disney theme-park attractions, this new one was directed by Steven Spielberg, cooked up and executive produced by George Lucas (with Kathleen Kennedy) and stars Harrison Ford as the archaeologist-adventurer-sexpot with the sardonic grin, rakish fedora and suggestive bullwhip.

title: Records Broken at Christies Auction

The price set a record for a 19th-century American painting, surpassing that of John Singer Sargents Robert Louis Stevenson and His Wife, which fetched $8.8 million when it was sold at Sothebys in 2004 to the Las Vegas casino owner Stephen A. Wynn and his wife, Elaine. The buyer of the Moran was the Avery Galleries of Bryn Mawr, Pa. Another oil on canvas, Marsden Hartleys Lighthouse, created in Berlin in 1915 and recently brought to light after its discovery in a museum in eastern Germany, sold for $6.31 million to an anonymous telephone bidder. Christies said the painting, with a estimate of $5 million to $7 million, set an auction record for an American Modernist painting, surpassing the $6.16 million for Georgia OKeeffes Calla Lilies With Red Anemone, sold at Christies in 2001.

title: Spike Lee Plays Critic
description: Spike Lee is at the Cannes Film Festival to promote a new film, but he couldnt resist taking a few swipes at his fellow directors Joel and Ethan Coen and Clint Eastwood. Speaking about his World War II drama, Miracle at St. Anna, Mr. Lee said that, unlike the Coens, he was respectful in the way he portrayed death.I always treat life and death with respect, but most people dont, he said at a news conference on Tuesday, according to The Hollywood Reporter. Look, I love the Coen brothers; we all studied at N.Y.U. But they treat life like a joke. Ha ha ha. A joke. Its like: Look how they killed that guy! Look how blood squirts out the side of his head! I see things different than that.Speaking about the casting for his tale of four black American soldiers in Tuscany, Mr. Lee said that black actors appeared in war films too infrequently.Clint Eastwood made two films about Iwo Jima that ran for more than four hours total, and there was not one Negro actor on the screen, he said, adding, Theres no way I know why he did that  that was his vision, not mine. Mr. Lee also said that he was starting work on a documentary about Michael Jordan.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD

She served for more than 17 years; she was not an 18-year incumbent. And while she led the group for the longest period of time under the title of president  changed from chairman during the tenure of her immediate predecessor  she is not in fact the A.C.L.U.s longest-serving leader. (That would be Harry Ward, who served as chairman for 20 years.) The article also misspelled the surname of one of Ms. Strossens debating partners over the years. She is Phyllis Schlafly, not Schlafley.

title: Bach

But the universality of Bachs music is distinct in that many of his works can be effectively performed on different instruments, in a way that Beethovens Moonlight Sonata cant. Bach cannot die, the pianist and harpsichordist Rosalyn Tureck said in 1961. An instrument can die, but Bach can never die.

title: Small Steps in Talks on Kashmir

title: New York Fair Highlights Decorative Art Objects

Starting May 29, more than 60 galleries from 11 countries will fill the Park Avenue Armory with modern and contemporary pieces like the hand-hammered metal Bis sculpture by Herv Wahlen ($17,500 from Barry Friedman Ltd.), above; Michael Geertsens glazed earthenware Yellow Wall Object ($4,000 from Koppe Gallery); and Malene Mllertzs ceramic White Burrs Basket ($3,200 from Lacoste Gallery), left. Mark Lyman, SOFAs founding director, said he prefers to think of it not as craft, but as unique work that celebrates quality of material and process while maintaining a connection to the intellect. Through June 1 at the Park Avenue Armory at 67th Street, (800) 563-7632 or sofaexpo.com; admission is $25.
