title: Place Your Bets: Buyout Team or Big Red?
description: The battle between financial and strategic buyers has broken out on a new front: Expro, a relatively small oil-service firm based in the United Kingdom. On one side is a consortium of financial investors that includes Goldman Sachs and the British private equity firm Candover. On the other side sits the oil-service giant Halliburton, or Big Red as it is known in the trenches.

title: Obama Takes 3 More Superdelegates
description: Senator Barack Obama added three superdelegates to his total today, a boost that comes after he saw just a trickle of delegates go to his side in recent days. Despite Mr. Obamas triumphant speech in Iowa and the buzz about the vice presidential search, the Senator had not initially capitalized on his performance in Tuesdays primaries, which gave him a majority of pledged delegates. (He received only two superdelegates on Wednesday and none on Thursday).

title: Human Guinea Pig Seeking Cure for Jet Lag
description: This weekend, were running an article called Coffee and naps not helping your jet lag? Try starving instead. The snappy headline (thanks to yours truly, ahem), is not totally straightforward. If you read into the text from Reuters, it quotes a study showing that food deprivation, or a drastic change in meal times, can override a mouses internal clock and its natural mechanism for coordinating waking and sleeping with periods of light and dark. A period of fasting with no food at all for about 16 hours is enough to engage this new clock, said Dr. Clifford Saper of Harvard Medical School, whose study appears in Science.

title: Wanted: Better Data on Bad Subway Elevators
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority needs to do a better job informing the public about mechanical problems with elevators and escalators in the subway, an authority board member says.

description: Gymnast Paul Hamm, who won a gold medal at the 2004 Athens Games and is the only American to win an all-around gold at an Olympics or world championship, has a broken bone in his hand that will probably force him to miss next months U.S. team trials. If he does miss the qualifiers, hell have to petition USA Gymnastics for a spot on the team.

Everyone who has ever watched the Masters on television, for instance, knows that the greens at Augusta are treacherous, but since no one has ever pulled a fan out of the gallery and asked him to knock in a putt to win the tournament, who knows how hard that really is?

title: Ratings: Grey Leads, Dance Follows
description: The two-hour season finale of Greys Anatomy vaulted ABC to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday, attracting 17.8 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. Although the number of viewers for the shows fourth season conclusion declined nearly 5 million compared to a year ago (22.6 million), it still led the night by a wide margin over its nearest competitor, NBCs Deal or No Deal, which garnered 10.3 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m.

title: In This Weeks Magazine: Narrow Minded
description: You dont have to search very hard to find the excruciating online videos known as thinspiration, or thinspo. Photomontages of skeletal women, including some celebrities and models, play all over the Internet, uploaded from the United States, Germany, Holland and elsewhere. These videos are designed to inspire viewers  to fortify their ambitions. But exactly which ambitions? To lose weight, presumably. To stop losing weight, possibly. Thinspo videos profess a range of ideologies, often pressing morbid images into double service, as both goads and deterrents to anorexia.

title: Minaya to Join the Mets in Denver, Not for the Food

The Mets have a front-office representative  either Minaya, Tony Bernazard, the vice president of development, or the assistant general manager John Ricco  traveling with the team to every city, but I cant recall Minaya making a trip out here since I took over the beat, in August 2005. description: We have no idea what, exactly, Hillary Clinton was thinking when she referred to the assassination of Bobby Kennedy in explaining her decision to keep on campaigning when it looks like there is virtually no hope of her winning the Democratic nomination.

title: Things We Learned This Season: The Big Issues and What They Meant
description: No matter what happens in the series, the Detroit-Pittsburgh Stanley Cup final stands as perhaps the biggest success for the National Hockey League in a season with many positive developments. Below, the writers and editors of the Slap Shot blog look back at the key issues, both good and bad, that defined the 2007-08 hockey season:

title: Tidbits for the Long Weekend
description: With the Memorial Day holiday bearing down hard on a blog that thinks the season of taking your laptop out to a rocking chair on the porch with a cold lemonade handy, a ballgame on the transistor radio and the scent of barbecue wafting through the neighborhood to your eager nostrils cant start soon enough, here are a few items we wish wed gotten to today before the stampede out of Dodge took hold in earnest:

title: Clinton, Discussing Nomination Battle, Invokes R.F.K. Assassination
description: Updated BRANDON, S.D. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton defended staying in the Democratic nominating contests Friday by saying that her husband did not wrap up the nomination until June 1992 and that, We all remember Bobby Kennedy was assassinated in June in California.

title: Eating Spring: Seasonal Vegetables in Italy
description: May is prime time for some of Italys most delicious and unusual vegetables. Hang on, I wont name names just yet.

title: UrbanEye: El Museo Del Barrio
description: El Museo Del Barrio holds its 15th anniversary "Quinceanero" gala. Melena Ryzik reports (con tiara).

title: Bloggingheads: Hillary and Sexism
description:
Daniel Drezner of Tufts University and Megan McArdle of The Atlantic debate how sexism and gender have affected Hillary Clinton's presidential run.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: If Girls Are Girly, What Are Boys?
description: This isnt a tech post, just a linguistic musing.

title: Paul Hamm Is Ailing but Not Quitting
description: The Olympic gold medalist Paul Hamm broke a bone in his right hand Thursday during the United States gymnastics nationals, but his goal of defending his all-around title at the Summer Olympics is far from doomed.

title: Behind the Circuits
description: As high schoolers compete in a national robotics competition, the pressure brings team members together.

title: Cheryl and Robert
description: Cheryl Bennett and Robert Davidowitz tell of being set up by Mr. Davidowitz's mother.

title: Cheryl and Robert
description: Cheryl Bennett and Robert Davidowitz tell of being set up by Mr. Davidowitz's mother.

title: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: Music in Another Chamber
description: CHARLESTON, S.C  While the Dock Street Theater is undergoing renovations, the Spoleto Festival has moved its chamber music concerts  about 30 of them this year  to the newly renovated Memminger Auditorium. The first was on Friday afternoon. A sliding wall cut across the middle of the space, leaving roughly 350 seats facing the stage, which was angled into a corner.

title: N.C.A.A. Lacrosse: Linked In
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Were winding down toward the first face-off of the lacrosse Final Four on Saturday. And in the interest of giving you the best coverage around, here are a few links from around the country to get you ready for Saturdays games.

title: U.S. seniors unite to build their own retirement villages
description: Retirees in the United States are banding together to create a novel solution to senior housing issues. And it seems like the type of concept that can translate to, say, a beach in Mexico as easily as a suburb in Texas

title: Russia and Ukraine Lock Horns Over Naval Base
description: MOSCOW  They have bickered over NATO expansion, energy prices and how to commemorate a 1930s mass famine. Now, Russia and Ukraine are locked in a new dispute over a naval base in the Ukrainian city of Sevastopol.

title: At Spoleto Festival, Revisiting a Fateful Chapter in Slavery
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Not so often do new American operas find life after birth. But Anthony Daviss Amistad, a historically inspired exploration of slavery and freedom, has come back to the stage 11 years after its debut at the Lyric Opera of Chicago, and in a deeply resonant setting.

title: A Flawed but Enduring Leader Returns to Zimbabwe
description: JOHANNESBURG

title: The Killings in South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about efforts by the Swiss bank UBS to raise additional capital misstated several figures. The bank will issue 760 million new shares at 21 francs or $20.43 each, not $5.03. That price is 31 percent below the Wednesday closing price of 30.64 francs or $29.81, not $7.34. UBSs shareholder equity fell to 16.4 billion francs or $15.96 billion, not $3.92 billion, at the end of March, from 51.3 billion francs or $49.9 billion, not $12.2 billion, a year earlier.

title: Teeth Gritted, Drivers Adjust to $4 Gasoline
description: Hating every minute of it, Americans are slowly learning to live with high gasoline prices. For a nation accustomed to cheap fuel, big vehicles and sprawling suburbs, the adjustments are wrenching.

title: Northwestern Keeps Hope Alive for 4th Title in a Row
description: TOWSON, Md.  Northwestern, trying for its fourth straight womens lacrosse title, is still on course, but it got a scare before beating Syracuse, 16-8, on Friday night in the national semifinals.

title: For Police, a Vacation Day Is Soon a Training Day, Too
description: For New York police officers, a day at the firing range has traditionally been a day away from the rigors of patrol. Officers shoot their guns, learn new techniques, meet colleagues and often get to go home a little early, a perquisite known in police jargon as an early blow.

title: Survival Guide for New Hires
description: NO matter how prepared you may be for the opportunity, entering a new job can be overwhelming, Angeli R. Rasbury writes in Black Enterprise.

title: Beyond Red State, Blue State: The Big Task Ahead
description: To the Editor:

title: Franken-Coleman Race Is Going to the Blogs
description: EAGAN, Minn.  On a laptop at a kitchen table in this cheery Twin Cities suburb, headlines ripping into Al Franken, the satirist whose campaign for the United States Senate is seen as one of the most competitive in the nation, are written up day after day for Minnesota Democrats Exposed, a political blog created by a former Republican Party researcher.

title: Composers of a Certain Age Receive a Makeover
description: Composers have long filtered their own ideas through a prism of older styles, adding contemporary flourishes to established forms. This theme of reinvention was the focus of an evening at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday by the pianists Stephen Gosling and Anthony Coleman that featured works reinventing older styles or techniques, in some cases the composers own.

title: Cable Prices Keep Rising, and Customers Keep Paying
description: Americans discouraged by higher gas prices and airline fares may decide to spend more vacation time at home, perhaps watching television.

title: Idol Tries to Keep Viewers Guessing
description: LOS ANGELES  Even after seven seasons, with ratings down about 10 percent from last year and some of the teenage fans who helped build the franchise in its early years shunning the show for its un-hip ubiquity, American Idol demonstrated on Wednesday that it still has the capacity to surprise.

title: Russia and China Attack U.S. Missile Shield Plan
description: BEIJING  President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia and President Hu Jintao of China met on Friday to conclude a deal on nuclear cooperation and together condemn American proposals for a missile shield in Europe. Both countries called the plan a setback to international trust that was likely to upset the balance of power.

title: Doctors Say McCain Is in Robust Health and Free of Cancer
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Senator John McCain, 71, is in excellent health and shows no evidence of a recurrence of the melanoma skin cancer that led to extensive head and neck surgery in 2000, Mr. McCains doctors said on Friday.

title: 270 Illegal Immigrants Sent to Prison in Federal Push
description: WATERLOO, Iowa  In temporary courtrooms at a fairgrounds here, 260 illegal immigrants were sentenced this week to five months in prison for working at a meatpacking plant with false documents.

title: Using Movement to Thank a Champion of the Arts
description: In opening remarks on Thursday night for Dancing for Micki, a homage to the longtime arts supporter Micki Wesson, the theater director Ping Chong counted her among those who help us transcend, however briefly, the mundane, and approach the divine.

title: Top Queens Democrats Shun Incumbent
description: Democratic Party officials in Queens voted on Friday not to endorse State Senator John D. Sabini, a Queens Democrat who has been in office six years, for re-election. Instead, they voted to back his challenger, City Councilman Hiram Monserrate.

title: Cornell Capa, Photographer, Is Dead at 90
description: Cornell Capa, who founded the International Center of Photography in New York after a long and distinguished career as a photojournalist, first on the staff of Life magazine and then as a member of Magnum Photos, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

title: Georgia: Governing Party Wins
description: The governing party triumphed in parliamentary elections, official results showed, securing President Mikheil Saakashvili and his supporters as the nations pre-eminent political force. Citing the preliminary official results, the Central Elections Commission said Mr. Saakashvilis United National Movement Party won 60 percent of the vote in Wednesdays ballot. A leader of the opposition coalition, the United Opposition bloc, which had 18 percent of the vote, said it planned to boycott Parliament and stage demonstrations to protest what it called a rigged election, Reuters reported.

title: Far From Always Being Right, the Customer Is on Hold
description: REMEMBER the days when, if something went wrong with a product you ordered, you picked up the phone and there was a live person on the other end? Wait, there is more. You asked for customer service and were transferred  to another human! And that person perhaps even solved your problem.

title: Yankees Keep Stottlemyre Busy in Rout of Mariners
description: Mel Stottlemyre spent parts of four decades in the home dugout at Yankee Stadium, playing in the World Series and winning championships as a coach. This is his last weekend at the old ballpark, as the pitching coach for the Seattle Mariners.

title: Georgias Ruling Party Victory Is Confirmed
description: The ruling party in Georgia triumphed in parliamentary elections, official results showed Friday, cementing President Mikheil Saakashvili and his followers as the nations pre-eminent political force.

title: The Failures of Thabo Mbeki
description: Crackpot and dangerous theories on AIDS. Extreme and widening levels of income inequality. Enabling Zimbabwes Robert Mugabe and only belatedly trying to halt mob atrocities against desperate Zimbabwean and other African immigrants. This is the legacy of South Africas president, Thabo Mbeki, who has one more year in his second term.

title: Shoe Sellers Secret of Success
description: HARVARD BUSINESS ONLINE posted a blog item on Monday morning praising the online shoe retailer Zappos. In short order, it spread around the Internet like kudzu.

title: Prayers for the Invisible: Immigrants Who Die in Legal Limbo
description: Among the many rituals of the Roman Catholic Church, none specifically mention a Mass for the Invisible. Still, on Thursday, 12 people gathered at a church in Lower Manhattan to remember Boubacar Bah, a 52-year-old tailor from Guinea who overstayed a tourist visa and died in an immigration detention center.

title: From a New Autobiography, a 1970 Breakthrough Revisited
description: Bobby Wolff has written his autobiography, The Lone Wolff (Master Point Press). Wolff has won 22 world championship medals: 11 gold, 7 silver and 4 bronze. He also has 44 national titles. What do you think the book is about?

title: Wright Wants Mets to Take Losses Personally
description: DENVER  Back in the sanctuary of his Atlanta hotel room early Wednesday morning, about an hour after the Braves demolished the Mets while sweeping a doubleheader, David Wright dialed a familiar phone number. If anyone could understand his frustration, Wright thought, it was Paul Lo Duca, a former Met who is now a catcher with the Washington Nationals.

title: R. Kelly Trial Continues
description: The trial of the R& B star R. Kelly, who is charged with 14 counts of child pornography stemming from a video in which, prosecutors say, he has sex with an under-age girl, wrapped up its first week on Friday in Chicago. In testimony this week Stephanie Edwards, a singer, identified the girl in the tape as her niece and said the girl was 13 or 14 when it was made. Mr. Kellys defense team filed a motion to call to the stand Jim DeRogatis, the pop music critic for The Chicago Sun-Times, who anonymously received the tape in 2002. Judge Vincent Gaughan said lawyers for The Sun-Times had until next Friday to respond. The trial is to resume on Tuesday. Mr. Kelly has pleaded not guilty, and the woman, now 23, said to be the girl on the tape, has denied that she is.

title: Marines Wont Charge 2 Officers Whose Men Killed Afghans After Car Bombing
description: WASHINGTON  The Marine Corps will not bring criminal charges against two officers in command of a unit involved in the shooting deaths of as many as 19 civilians in northeastern Afghanistan last year after a car bomb struck the marines convoy, it was announced Friday.

title: Tight Control on McCain Files and Shortened Question Period
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain released his medical records on Friday under tightly controlled circumstances, allowing them to be reviewed by a small group of reporters from news organizations that his campaign chose.

title: Forecast Sends Pacific Sunwear Stock Price Tumbling
description: Pacific Sunwear of California fell the most in six years in Nasdaq trading on Friday after the clothing chain said annual earnings would be less than it previously forecast because of sluggish sales in states hit by the housing slump. Pacific Sunwear predicted profit of 59 to 64 cents a share, excluding some items, for the year through early 2009. In March, the retailer of surf-themed T-shirts, shorts and sweatshirts projected earnings of at least 73 cents. Analysts had expected 67 cents. About a quarter of the companys 942 PacSun stores are in California, Florida and the Southwest, areas reeling from the housing decline.

title: A Bidding War for Well Equipment Maker
description: LONDON  A group of private equity firms increased its offer for the Expro International Group, which makes deepwater well equipment, to more than 1.71 billion, or $3.4 billion, on Friday, entering into a bidding war with Halliburton amid record oil prices and rising exploration costs.

title: Lottery Numbers
Cindy McCain Releases Summary of Taxes
description: Senator John McCains wife, Cindy, abruptly reversed course on Friday and released a summary of her 2006 income tax return after weeks of vowing not to do so. The form revealed that she took in more than $6 million in taxable income that year.

title: Controversial Contractors Iraq Work Is Split Up
description: WASHINGTON  Sometime soon, a group of American corporate executives and military leaders will quietly sit down and divide Iraq into three parts.

title: Microsoft Will Shut Down Book Search Program
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Microsoft said Friday that it was ending a project to scan millions of books and scholarly articles and make them available on the Web, a sign that it is retrenching in some areas of Internet search in the face of competition from Google, the industry leader.

title: Hip-Hopper Is Pardoned by Governor
description: During a federal immigration hearing in 1995, Gov. David A. Paterson, then a New York State senator, testified on behalf of the hip-hop pioneer Ricky Walters, who was facing deportation to his native Britain for convictions on attempted murder and weapons charges.

title: Neutra House Sale Wont Take Place
description: The $16.8 million sale of a landmark Modernist house by Richard Neutra has been derailed, Christies said on Friday. An unidentified bidder bought the 1946 residence, the Kauffmann House in Palm Springs, Calif., above, at Christies auction of postwar and contemporary art in New York on May 13. But Marc Porter, president of Christies, said in a brief telephone interview on Friday that the deal had fallen apart. The contract has been terminated by the seller by reason of a breach of its terms by the buyer, he said. He declined to identify the buyer or to say whether that person had failed to deliver a payment. The sellers, Brent Harris and Beth Edwards Harris, who have divorced, could not immediately be reached for comment. The midcentury landmark of glass, steel and stone sold at the low end of its estimate of $15 million to $25 million at the auction. It was commissioned by the department store owner Edgar J. Kaufmann Sr., the same client who commissioned Frank Lloyd Wright to build Fallingwater in Pennsylvania in the 1930s.

title: Suicide Is the Second for the State Police in 9 Days
description: ALBANY  A State Police scientist hanged himself in his garage Friday, law enforcement officials said, the second time in a little over a week that someone with ties to the agency has killed himself.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: The Talking Business column last Saturday, about a sharp debate over the advantages and faults of investment instruments called fundamentally weighted index funds, misstated the name of the organization that publishes The Financial Analysts Journal, which prompted the feud by publishing an article on the funds. It is the CFA Institute, not the Chartered Financial Analysts Institute.

title: Saudis Give $500 Million for Food
description: Saudia Arabia gave $500 million to the World Food Program, which Secretary General Ban Ki-moon described as of unprecedented size and generosity. The United Nations, in announcing the gift, said it would complete the programs emergency appeal for $755 million to offset the rise in fuel and food prices around the world.

title: From Thebes to Suburbia, in Dire Need of Therapy
description: The members of the doomed house of Oedipus have thrown together their own garage band. Its part of a family therapy project, which they sorely need, and nobodys quite in control. But, you know, they sound pretty good, especially considering that the lead vocalist has just gouged out his eyes, and the chief backup singer, who wears a noose around her neck, is dead.

title: Merrill Trader Is Suspended After Derivatives Review
description: Merrill Lynch is investigating one of its trading desks in London and has suspended a trader after discovering that he may have overstated the value of some of the banks equity derivatives. The firm routinely reviews the marks our traders set, a Merrill spokesman, Jezz Farr, said Friday, referring to the values given to securities. Our preliminary review determined that one desk used marks that appear to be outside of our accepted policy. Merrill declined to identify the trader.

title: Switch to Nascar Brings Struggles but No Regrets
description: CONCORD, N.C.  The last two winners of the Indianapolis 500 will be miles from the starting grid Sunday when the green flag waves and the most prestigious open-wheel race in the country begins.

title: Have We Got a Deal for You
description: Just when it appears that the New York State Legislature has hit bottom, we find a false floor. The Timess Danny Hakim recently uncovered another appalling example of how a politically powerful group can order up laws in Albany, even skewing the estimates of how much it will cost taxpayers.

title: Spotlight Recasts Church Leaders and Their Support
description: When George W. Bush ran for president in 2000, an influential megachurch pastor from Texas made an early endorsement that helped him win over skeptical evangelical conservatives.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary and a headline on Friday about the architect and preservationist Jan Hird Pokorny misstated his age. As the obituary noted, he was born on May 25, 1914, and therefore was 93, not 83.

title: When One-Man Bands Bend the Metal Clichs
description: Hi, Joe Preston announced. Were Thrones, from Salem, Oregon.

title: Frances Bright Shining Lie
description: Paris

title: New Yorks Past Beckons the Future
description: Here they come, chugging down Fifth Avenue with their cargo of gleeful passengers: public double-decker buses in New York City!

title: Big Plans for Parks
description: The Leon Levy Foundation, run by Shelby White, a philanthropist, and named for her husband, a hedge fund pioneer who died in 2003, is giving $25 million to New York City parks in what the city has described as the biggest private green gift. The New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx will get $15 million to create a new native plant garden for the study and display of Northeast flora. In Brooklyn, Prospect Park will receive $10 million to finance the Lakeside Center, a new 36,000-square-foot building that will replace Wollman Rink and its surroundings. The 26-acre area will be restored to the original design of Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, with a natural-habitat sanctuary and pedestrian pathways along the lake, and will be open year round.

title: A Final Four That Is Filled With Talent and Tradition
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The teams participating in lacrosses Final Four weekend at Gillette Stadium took a walk through the stadium Thursday afternoon and craned their necks at the nearly 80,000 seats surrounding them.

title: Lakers Take Two-Game Lead Without a Sweat
description: LOS ANGELES  Clutching, grabbing and just playing good defense, Bruce Bowen has had as much success as anyone defending Kobe Bryant. That is to say there are some nights he does not feel completely helpless.

title: A Cantankerous Crowd in No Mood for Love
description: CANNES, France  The predictably cranky and impatient press audience offered little love to Philippe Garrels Frontier of Dawn at the Cannes Film Festival on Thursday, just a weak round of applause amid a chorus of jeers. One of the most significant and, in the United States, unknown of the post-New Wave French directors, Mr. Garrel employs poetic melancholia and unhurried rhythms that were, particularly at 8:30 in the morning, either too much or not nearly enough for a crowd that had stayed up late the previous night to take in and debate Che, Steven Soderberghs ambitious epic about the revolutions won and lost by Che Guevara. (The arguments continued hotly on Friday.)

title: Chinas Rush to Dispose of Dead Compounds Agony
description: BEICHUAN, China  The 30 bodies in plastic bags lay strewn outside the tea factory at the foot of the forensic scientist, flies buzzing all around. From some he had collected molars, and from others cartilage. He had worked quickly, 20 minutes per body.

title: A Poll Finds Californians Still Oppose Gay Marriage
description: SAN FRANCISCO  More than half of Californians support a proposed ballot measure that would overturn a recent ruling that legalized same-sex marriage in the state, a poll has found.

title: Cornell Capa, Photojournalist and Museum Founder, Dies at 90
description: Cornell Capa, who founded the International Center of Photography in New York after a long and distinguished career as a photojournalist, first on the staff of Life magazine and then as a member of Magnum Photos, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

title: U.N. Chief Says Myanmar Yields on Aid Workers
description: BANGKOK  Myanmars military junta promised on Friday to allow into the country all aid workers of any nationality, after three weeks of blocking most assistance to cyclone victims, the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, announced.

title: Israeli Police Question Olmert Again
description: JERUSALEM  The prime minister of Israel, Ehud Olmert, was interrogated on Friday morning by the police for the second time this month in connection with a new and potentially serious corruption scandal. Meanwhile, his lawyers failed to delay by two weeks the early court deposition of an important witness in the case, the American fund-raiser and businessman Morris Talansky.

title: Where to Catch the Sights, Sound and Smell of a Campaign
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich.  The man was persistent in demanding Senator Barack Obamas tie.

title: 20-Year Journey for 15-Minute Fall
description: He has spent two decades and nearly $20 million in a quest to fly to the upper reaches of the atmosphere with a helium balloon, just so he can jump back to earth again. Now, Michel Fournier says, he is ready at last.

title: Corrections
description: Obituaries

title: Boom Times for Brazils Consumers
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Consumers in the United States are tightening their belts; Brazilians are spending like theres no word in Portuguese for recession.

title: Surfing on a Big Wave of Enthusiasm
description: David Robertson has done great work with the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra in his three seasons there, both as an experienced and persuasive new-music conductor and as an insightful interpreter of the standard canon. He has an enthusiastic following among New York concertgoers as well, and his performance with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening  the first concert in a two-week visit  offered ample reason for it.

title: British Tory Leader Warns Against Triumphalism
description: CREWE, England  In the 30 months since he became the Conservative Party leader at the age of 39, and the fourth man to hold the job in eight years, David Cameron has had his fair share of showy, seemingly callow moments and policy pronouncements that raised doubts, in his own party and elsewhere, about his fitness to be the pretender to the keys of 10 Downing Street.

title: Darfur Peacekeepers Robbed in Ambush
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Militiamen in Sudanese Army uniforms ambushed a convoy of Nigerian peacekeepers in Darfur, robbing them of cash and weapons, United Nations officials said Friday.

title: Ortiz as Ruth? Yankees Say Not in Their House
description: The Yankees voiced their dismay to Major League Baseball on Friday about a promotion in which David Ortiz, the Red Sox slugger, will try to hit a home run to a designated spot at Yankee Stadium during the home run derby on July 14, the eve of the All-Star Game. It will be the fourth and last All-Star Game at the 85-year-old stadium.

title: Djokovics Ascent Adds Intrigue to the French Open Draw
description: PARIS  Tennis draws are not nearly as suspenseful as tennis tournaments, but there was a buzz of anticipation as officials sifted through the seedings Friday at Roland Garros Stadium.

title: A Passion for (and Against) Sarkozy
description: PARIS  Serge Hefez, a practicing psychiatrist, has identified a new mental illness among the French: obsessive Sarkosis, an unhealthy fascination with the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy.

title: Existing Home Sales Fell in April to Another Low
description: Stocks took a dive on Friday after a report confirmed fears that the housing slump, which has weighed on nearly every corner of the nations economy, was nowhere near its end.

title: Gymnast Breaks Hand, but Still Has Olympic Chances
description: The Olympic gold medalist Paul Hamm broke a bone in his right hand Thursday during the United States gymnastics nationals, but his goal of successfully defending his all-around title at the Beijing Olympics is far from doomed.

title: 'Anatomy' Is Down but Still on Top
description: The two-hour season finale of Greys Anatomy vaulted ABC to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday, attracting 17.8 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. Although the number of viewers for the shows fourth-season conclusion declined by nearly 5 million from a year ago (22.6 million), it still led the night by a wide margin over its nearest competitor, NBCs Deal or No Deal, which garnered 10.3 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m. NBC finished third for the night, earning mediocre results from 9:30 to 11 with the start of the sixth edition of Last Comic Standing (5.9 million). Fox ranked second over all, thanks to the fourth-season premiere of So You Think You Can Dance, which averaged 8.6 million viewers from 8 to 10. Despite its modest number of total viewers, the Fox dancing contest fared particularly well among adults 18 to 49, winning the 8 oclock hour in that demographic, ahead of ABCs finale of Ugly Betty, which drew 8.8 million total viewers. CBS finished fourth with a lineup of all repeats.

title: Tears for Teddy
description: My father was stricken with throat cancer back in the early 1990s, and I remember talking to his doctor (as clearly as if it was yesterday) about his prognosis.

title: McCains Health Is Called Robust by His Doctors
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Senator John McCain, 71, is in excellent health and shows no evidence of the recurrence of the melanoma skin cancer that led to extensive head and neck surgery in 2000, Mr. McCains doctors said Friday.

title: After Minaya Supports Randolph, Mets Lose in 13
description: DENVER  Omar Minaya, the Mets' general manager, can choose wherever and whenever to accompany his team. Coming here was not on Minaya's agenda until Thursday morning, after the third of four straight losses in Atlanta, when he decided to show support for his fading team and embattled manager.

title: Parole Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Changing the Game With Innovations
description: CERTAINLY A. G. Lafley had his work cut out for him when he became Procter & Gambles chief executive eight years ago. Profits were lackluster and the stock was way down. New product introductions had slowed to a trickle, and no more than 15 percent of those wound up making money.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: The Crown Heights Journal article on Thursday, about racial tension between Jews and blacks in the Brooklyn neighborhood, omitted the name of the publication that first reported a comment by District Attorney Charles J. Hynes on accusations that Shmira, a Hasidic civilian patrol group, has been uncooperative with investigators. His comment, You cant have a group, whether its the Bloods, Crips or Shmira, acting like vigilantes, was made to The Jewish Week of New York on April 29.

title: 40 Million Acres of Rain Forest for the Greenest Bidder
description: The other day I went to a meeting to hear Harrison Ford talk about saving the rain forests and ended up listening to a man who has a rain forest to save: Guyanas president, Bharrat Jagdeo.

title: Snipes Is Granted Bail
description: Wesley Snipes can spend his Memorial Day weekend a free man. Last month in Ocala, Fla., he was sentenced to three years in prison for willfully failing to file his tax returns, one year for each misdemeanor conviction. He plans to appeal the conviction, handed down in February, and on Thursday Judge William Terrell Hodges granted his motion for bail, saying Mr. Snipes did not pose a flight risk, according to The Associated Press. At his sentencing, Mr. Snipes read a statement apologizing for some unspecified mistakes and failures; he did not mention taxes.

title: Money for Museums
description: These have been good days for art lovers. In Colorado the Aspen Art Museum, home to contemporary art exhibitions, film and video series, has announced that starting on Thursday its admission will be free for the next 10 years, thanks to an undisclosed contribution by John and Amy Phelan. (The admission was previously $5 and under.) The Phelans are members of the museums council and part-time residents of Aspen. In New York, El Museo del Barrio, which showcases the art and cultured of Latin America, Puerto Rico and the rest of the Caribbean region, has received a $3 million gift from Carmen Ana Unanue, its chairwoman, and her family. The museum, at 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, East Harlem, is closed for a major renovation and is expected to re-open in September 2009.

title: Ex-Worker in Child Care Is Sought in Smut Case
description: A former employee of a Manhattan company that provides emergency child care for workers at high-profile corporations is being sought by the authorities for possessing child pornography on his home computer, the police said on Friday.

title: With Summer on the Way, Con Ed Girds Its Grid
description: Ah, spring. Season of baseball, budding trees and final exams. Or, for the engineers, planners and cable splicers at Con Edison, time to build new substations, overhaul thousands of breakers, feeders, switches and transformers and replace 1,900 miles of underground cables.

title: Girardi Serves Penalty for Dirt-Kicking Tirade
description: It was three hours before game time on Friday when Joe Girardi read a distressing e-mail message from Major League Baseball. Girardi had been suspended for the game against Seattle for kicking dirt on the plate umpire, Chris Guccione, in a hat-kicking tirade in the ninth inning on Thursday.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article last Saturday about a report on lapses at a Las Vegas endoscopy clinic linked to cases of hepatitis C misidentified the jobs of some of the health care workers who, according to the report, did not wear gloves when they administered intravenous medications. They were nurse anesthetists, not anesthesiologists.

title: Heading Off New Account Fraud
description: One of the scariest types of identity crimes is something called new account fraud. This happens when a criminal steals your personal information, opens credit or other accounts in your name and goes on a spending spree. Here are a few things you can do on your own to prevent the crime.

title: Ready to Charge Head-On Into Pain
description: Watching Bebe Neuwirth extract the scar tissue from the emotional viscera of Brecht-Weill songs at Feinsteins at Loews Regency on Wednesday evening, I thought, Here is the new Julie Wilson! title: President and the Play
description: What can a popular ex-president do as a second act? Collaborate with his wife, of course  or try to. And in the former Czech leader Vaclav Havels case, return to his roots on the stage. Mr. Havels first new play in 20 years opened in the Archa Theater in Prague on Thursday. The play, Odchazeni (Leaving), is about a chancellor who must re-adjust to civilian life and the loss of power after being forced out by his former deputy. (Mr. Havel, now 71, whose last presidential term ended in 2003, has said he wrote most of the play before taking office.) It alludes to King Lear and The Cherry Orchard but has some postmodern touches: the playwright himself appears in a recorded voice-over. The play received mostly positive reviews in the Czech press. But this highly anticipated absurdist comedy was marred by some personal drama when Mr. Havels wife, Dagmar Havlova, who he said helped inspire the work, was barred from performing in it. The National Theater of Prague, which was originally scheduled to stage it, cited a policy against guest actors in rejecting Ms. Havlova for a role written for her. Mr. Havel responded by shopping the show to other theaters; citing health problems, Ms. Havlova eventually dropped out of the production altogether shortly before it opened at the Archa. In September the play is scheduled to run at the Orange Tree Theater in London.

title: California: Search for Remains in Manson Case Ends

title: LETTERS: The Readers Speak
description: Re Information That Doesnt Come Freely (May 11):You write that bad things can happen when a government tries to hide the records of its actions. It is clear that this administration has no intention to serve the publics best interest, but in fact is subjugating at all costs all that would counter its sole objective, namely the profits of its in-crowd.I have never had so many alarms going off in my head. America is in trouble! The only insights into the administrations wrongdoings are the investigative and analytical reporting of the media.Thank you to the reporters Nina Bernstein and David Barstow, to David McCraw, a vice president and assistant general counsel for The Times, and to you. Robert PalmerCastro Valley, Calif., May 11, 2008  Re The Preachers New Pulpit (May 4):I strongly disagree with you on the question of the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr. and The Timess coverage of his recent public and television appearances.I felt that the issue was covered ad nauseam everywhere and ran 24/7 on cable news channels. Yes, it was news, but it became the dominant news of the week at the expense of other more important stories.I appreciate that The Times showed some restraint while still covering the story well.Elizabeth KilroyNew York, May 5, 2008 Your column about the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr. scandal should have also noted the failure of The Times to discuss the anti-American and outrageous statements of many men of the cloth, such as, but not limited to, the Rev. Jerry Falwell, the Rev. Pat Robertson, Rev. John C. Hagee and even the Rev. Billy Graham.While The Times has provided article after article about Mr. Wright (and Senator Barack Obama), theres been far less coverage of the other reverends who have made similar statements. In the Week in Review of May 4, we read about the fiery theology of black preachers, with no mention of the many other (white) preachers who have said far worse.Where is the balance?Vicki G. CheikesBoca Raton, Fla., May 6, 2008 I was interested in the difference between the coverage of the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr. in the paper and on The Caucus blog on the Web site.Perhaps you are right, and The Times should have reported more on the content of Mr. Wrights recent speeches in the paper. But nothing substantial in the speeches had not been reported before, and nothing in them was not being reported endlessly on cable news. It seems that the story really was that Mr. Wright was saying these things again, which to me came through in the reporting in the paper.The Caucus blog, however, was all Wright all the time for at least three days that week. It was infuriating.The content of Mr. Wrights speeches is available on television and on the Internet. How much of this do you want to put on the front page? The Wright story represents a great distraction from real issues, and it is entirely media-generated. Now, the media are a story, but they are becoming the main story. And thats not good.Christopher WilsonMadison, Wis., May 4, 2008 While I very much appreciate your column about the papers coverage of the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., The Times was hardly the first or only media outlet not to cover Mr. Wright in a proper sense. I dont see why what Mr. Wright says in his crazy rants should be given the news attention that it has been given.What kind of impact will that have on the issues of the day? Does his hateful comments help a family with their bills, or help get us out of Iraq?I am a realist and know the news media will cover him because of his ties to Senator Barack Obama, though for the reasons I just stated, I wish it werent so.Steven M. ClaytonOcean, New Jersey May 4 2008

title: Gangsters Without Borders
description: Around the time the Soviet Union ceased to exist, I was waiting in the entry queue at Fiumicino Airport in Rome when I noticed a party of several dozen young Russian girls being fast-tracked past a freshly opened control window. By young I mean perhaps 15, and by Russian girls I mean beautiful adolescents with pale gold hair, perfect skin and the figures of child ballerinas. These wide-eyed coltish kids werent dancers or on a school trip. They were hustled along by a stocky middle-aged man with a short mustache and a stash of passports in his hairy hand. It was an unforgettable image of lambs to the slaughter  or, more precisely, of children to the brothel. You sometimes glimpse them, older now, dispersed around the world, and how they were engulfed by the criminal universe is one of the things Misha Glenny describes in McMafia, his dizzy tour of the forms of global crime born in the late 80s, when finance capital shook off restraints and the Soviet Union collapsed.

The guide is available in bookstores for $15.95 (addresses and phone numbers are available free at Zagat.com and on mobile devices at Zagat.mobi). title: Correction: Trying to Lighten That Carbon Footprint
description: The Green Traveler column on May 4, about the use of biofuels in air travel, summarized incorrectly a statement by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change on the effect of jet exhaust. The panel said exhaust contributed to global warming by emitting carbon dioxide and nitrogen oxides at high altitude and by forming condensation trails; it did not say jet engine exhaust depletes the ozone layer.

title: A Chic Double-Wide
description: YOU can do a lot with a narrow town house, especially one on a private cobblestone street facing the East River and the Queensboro Bridge.

title: Noraan Sadik and Stephen Haskins
description: Noraan Sadik and Stephen Caleb Haskins were married on Saturday at the Mosque of the Jerrahi Order in Chestnut Ridge, N.Y. Imam Yurdaer Doganata performed an Islamic ceremony. On Sunday evening, the Rev. K. Jeddah Vailakis, an interfaith minister, is to officiate at Studio 450, an event space in New York.

title: The Tower That Has No Friends
description: PICTURE, if you will, the Brooklyn Bridge: the solid stone towers and the gentle arc of the roadbed over the river. Picture it from the Brooklyn side, where thousands gathered Thursday to celebrate the spans 125th anniversary as one of the citys most loved structures. If your picture is clear enough, you will also see, looming directly behind it in Manhattan, what may be the least loved: the 32-story, beige limestone monolith that is 375 Pearl Street.

title: Lottery Numbers
Where Europe, Africa and the Mideast Meet in Tunisia
description: THE night air was cold and damp on the narrow, walled streets of Tuniss medina, and the markets and stores all dark and locked up tight for the night. But all it took was a single rap of the iron knocker on the wooden door at 5, rue Dar El Jeld and in that instant a mystical world opened up.

title: Alyssa Saunders, Eric Trager
description: Alyssa Tami Saunders, a daughter of Rhonda E. Saunders and Jeffrey H. Saunders of Andover, Mass., is to be married on Sunday to Eric Robert Trager, the son of Cara S. Trager and Michael I. Trager of Hollis Hills, Queens. Rabbi David Wise is to officiate at Temple Judea of Manhasset, N.Y., and Cantor Sol Zim is to participate in the ceremony.

title: Mickelson and Woods Take Two Paths to the U.S. Open
description: FORT WORTH  With the 108th United States Open approaching, the two best golfers in the game are plotting very different courses toward their showdown at Torrey Pines on the cliffs above the Pacific in San Diego in three weeks.

title: Chinese Are Left to Ask Why Schools Crumbled
description: This story was reported by Jim Yardley, Jake Hooker and Andrew C. Revkin, and was written by Mr. Yardley.

title: Poor, Obscure, Plain and Little
description: Early in Queen Victorias reign, 30 percent of adult Englishwomen were single  and considered, as one social commentator put it, redundant. If of gentle birth and no means, without a family to care for, an extra woman naturally sought work as a governess. Living in another familys home made romance unlikely and isolation inevitable, with poverty and unemployment always on the horizon. It was a grim life, grimmer still because it was the only choice open to many. As Charlotte Bronts Jane Eyre decides, I want this because it is of no use wanting anything better.

title: Leanne Jochim, Aahren DePalma
description: Dr. Leanne Michelle Jochim, a daughter of Marilyn S. and Timothy Jochim of Evansville, Ind., was married on Saturday afternoon to Aahren Rodriguez DePalma, a son of Miriam R. DePalma and Anthony DePalma of Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Nancy Waters, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Third Lutheran Church in Louisville, Ky.

title: A Carrot? A Stick? No, a Cobra
description: IN 2001, our son, Tim, was a smart middle-schooler who, like many of his peers, wasnt meeting his parents expectations. We thought he should be getting better grades, but distractions always seemed to get in the way: video games, roller hockey, Magic cards, girls, video games, TV and cars. Did I mention video games?

title: The Prosecutor
description: Q: In 2001, you were tapped by President Bush for your dream job  U.S. attorney for New Mexico  only to end up as one of the eight federal prosecutors whose firing five years later set off an outcry. With your book In Justice about to come out, have you heard anything from President Bush? No, not even a little note of thanks. If somebody served honorably, you at least have your staff member send a form letter or something: thanks for your service.

title: Divining a Lesson in Basra
description: BASRA, Iraq  On Basras Corniche, the boulevard past which the mingled waters of the Tigris and Euphrates flow into the Persian Gulf, there is a collective sense of relief these days.

title: Letter: A Malian Festival
description: To the Editor: We were pleased to see The New York Times take note of the Festival au Desert in Mali (In Mali, S.U.V.s and Camels Deliver the Fans, May 11). Unfortunately, the article flattened the richness and complexity of the festival, which combines entertainment with the functions of a county fair, town-hall meeting and community clinic. We heard great music, but also saw workshops on AIDS prevention, witnessed Doctors Without Borders at work and heard a discussion of the duties of a good citizen presented in French and Tamashek.

title: Al Green Pays Tribute to the Old Al Green
description: ASK the Rev. Al Green about his gallant, groove-laden new album, Lay It Down (Blue Note), and youre likely to hear a familiar phrase. Love and Happiness, Mr. Green said recently by phone from Memphis, where he has been the pastor of the Full Gospel Tabernacle for more than 30 years. Thats the story that we are carrying. This whole theme is in the love zone, and in the happiness zone.

title: Jackson Reaches Out to Former Teammate Randolph
description: Reggie Jackson, a special consultant for the Yankees, has made three telephone calls recently to his former teammate Willie Randolph, the manager of the Mets.

title: Boo! Boo! Boo! for the Home Team
description: At least one fan at Shea Stadium had to sadly pause over his $7.50 cup of beer as boos rained down from the supposed faithful on one of their own star hitters  merely for an unsuccessful at-bat. This in a city where the home-team breed from Brooklyn once prayed for divine intervention to deliver a long-ago Dodger slugger from an abysmal slump at the plate.

title: Law Is the Law, but Producing Is His Life
description: JOHN BREGLIOS shift from veteran theatrical lawyer to fledgling Broadway producer either took place gradually, over three decades, or in a split second, depending on how you look at it. And like the seasoned negotiator he is, Mr. Breglio maintains that both scenarios are arguable.

title: Toughest Summer Job This Year Is Finding One
description: TULSA, Okla.  School is out, and Aaron Stallings, his junior year of high school behind him, wanders the air-conditioned cocoon of the Woodland Hills Mall in search of a job.

title: Correction
description: An article on April 27 about commercial applications for hybrid vehicles described a bucket truck used by Florida Power and Light incorrectly. While the trucks hybrid system can indeed power the bucket, it can also power the drive wheels.

description: FOR nearly a decade, it seemed to Barbara Krajkowski that the second sentence of every conversation she had was: Do you know of a space?

description: CONCORD, N.C.  A glass-encased wall of trophies greets visitors to the museum at Hendrick Motorsports, from the old Winston Cup and Nextel Cup championships to the many prizes for individual race wins over the 24-year history of the team. Jimmie Johnsons No. 48 Chevrolet that clinched the 2007 Cup championship is prominently displayed on the floor nearby.

title: Finding Potential for Debt in Distress
description: THE credit crisis and economic slowdown have sunk billions of dollars of debt into distressed status  deep in the junk-bond pile. Money managers have traditionally profited in such markets by buying debt on the cheap.

title: Coffee Mated to Chocolate
description: Some food combinations are so natural, like strawberries and cream or beer and barbecue, you hardly give them a second thought. Coffee and chocolate may not coalesce on the tongue as readily, yet in the care of the Kent Coffee & Chocolate Company, its a marriage that is likely to grow on you.

title: With Steve Cauthen
description: Steve Cauthen, 48, is the last jockey to win the Triple Crown, which he did aboard Affirmed in 1978. In 1979, he moved to England, where jockeys can ride at slightly higher weights, and became one of Europes most successful ones. Cauthen retired after the 1992 racing season. Today, he operates Dreamfields, a breeding farm and training center in Verona, Ky.

title: Sarah Frank-Meltzer, William Callahan
description: Sarah Mira Frank-Meltzer, a daughter of Carol Frank and Ronald I. Meltzer of Washington, was married on Saturday to William ONeill Callahan, a son of Sarah A. Callahan of Wellesley, Mass., and the late Thomas W. Callahan. Rabbi Michael R. Namath officiated at the Evermay Society, an event space in Washington.

title: Gay, Punk and Ever the Provocateur
description: WITH each passing year the British artist and iconoclast Derek Jarman seems at once more important and more marginal. His place in history as a pioneering gay filmmaker is secure, but his work remains little seen, and the spirit in which it was made seems further away than ever.

title: The Snare of Privilege
description: WASHINGTON  Hillary Rodham Clinton, Wellesley 69, Yale Law 73 and the first lady of the land for eight years, is suddenly a working-class heroine of guns and whiskey shots. Barack Obama, Columbia 83 and Harvard Law 91, visits bowling alleys and beer halls and talks about his single mother who lived on food stamps.

description: MOZART was wasted on Vienna, and he knew it. From 1786 to 1791, audiences there witnessed the premieres of Le Nozze di Figaro, Cos Fan Tutte and Die Zauberflte, but they made a bigger fuss over other operas.

title: Sheraton Expanding Lobby Computer Services
description: Sheraton Hotels and Resorts and Microsoft announced this month a partnership that will expand the communications hubs in many Sheraton lobbies. Called the Link @ Sheraton experienced with Microsoft, hubs will offer free Wi-Fi and Internet-enabled computer stations, where guests will be able to access their e-mail accounts, search the Web and print out materials like boarding passes.

title: How Are Humans Unique?
description: Human beings do not like to think of themselves as animals. It is thus with decidedly mixed feelings that we regard the frequent reports that activities once thought to be uniquely human are also performed by other species: chimpanzees who make and use tools, parrots who use language, ants who teach. Is there anything left?

title: Williams, Former Goat for Phillies, Is Now Fan Favorite
description: PHILADELPHIA  On his radio show The Wild Pitch, before Phillies games, Mitch Williams regularly reads a commercial for a plastic surgery clinic that promises to replace hair on mens heads and remove their love handles.

title: Partial Recall
description: Behind all the good-natured joking about senior moments lies real frustration and fear. How empowering, then, that we can do something to ward off normal, age-related memory loss: exercise. No, its not as easy as popping a pill. But as Sue Halpern reports in Cant Remember What I Forgot, even a few brisk walks per week can have a measurable effect. Exercise promotes the birth of new neurons in the very part of the hippocampus (a brain structure crucial to forming new memories) that begins to malfunction with age. Exercise also counters age-related shrinking of the prefrontal cortex, an area involved in concentration and working memory (as in remembering a phone number long enough to dial).

title: Russian Revolutionary
description: History has been spinning heads in Moscow for centuries, but there was a particularly dizzy moment just three weeks ago, during the May Day rally around the gray granite statue of Karl Marx. Marx gazes out at the Bolshoi Theater, where the hammer-and-sickle insignia that used to dominate the frieze over the front portico  back in the days when Stalin attended performances in his bulletproof box  has been swapped for the double-headed-eagle emblem of the Russian Federation. And lest there be any doubt about the economic principles prevailing in postrevolutionary Russia, a giant Samsung flat-screen-TV ad featuring two Bolshoi dancers is plastered on the Christo-like construction shroud that will wrap the theater throughout its four-year, $730 million renovation.

title: The Ferry: Past, Present and Future
description: BRIDGES spelled the end of New Yorks ferries a century ago; when you could zip over the Queensboro by trolley or car, why bother with poky boats?

title: At the Top of His Game
description: IM in eighth grade. I got the idea for the card game Im marketing, Elementeo, at the end of fourth grade. I started working on it last year. I named my company Alchemist Empire because alchemists are always creating new things. For example, they try to make gold out of lead. I wanted to show that you can mix fun, education and action.

description: ENTERGY NUCLEARs operating policies since radioactive groundwater contamination from two of its reactors at Indian Point was discovered in 2005 have been reasonable and technically sound, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said on Tuesday.

Fortunately, history proves that once identified and studied, sports-specific athletic conditions are almost always treatable and preventable.

title: Spray of Gunfire Wounds 5 in Queens
description: Five people were wounded, one of them seriously, on Saturday when a gunman opened fire on a street in Jackson Heights, Queens, in what the police said they believed was a gang-related shooting. No arrests had been made by last night.

title: Boutonnieres in the Citys Lapel
description: THERES something about stumbling upon a manicured garden hidden somewhere in Manhattan. With the city raging just beyond the hedges, you claim a piece of bench or spot of grass and relax, let the perfume of flowers and a bumblebee or two drift over you with the breeze. Its a stillness visitors rarely expect to find in the city (and one that New Yorkers with small apartments and roommates otherwise find only by locking themselves in the bathroom).

title: Web Site Puts Focus on the Fix in Sports Bets
description: LONDON  With Internet gambling predicted to surpass $20 billion in 2008, and with illegal wagering accounting for $150 billion in the United States, by some estimates, the temptation for those seeking to influence the outcome of games has never been greater. Now, a raft of gambling scandals in sports, from cricket to soccer and most recently tennis, has raised an uncomfortable question: Are the games we watch fixed?

description: FAIRFIELD

title: Its Not a Campaign, Its a Mission
description: A YEAR ago, Leon Lim, a 35-year-old doctoral student in Sanskrit from Dayton, Ohio, decided with his wife, Ranjani Powers, a yoga instructor, to head off to Bali, or India, or anywhere, really, just somewhere very far away  from the Iraq war, the Patriot Act and the tanking dollar, Mr. Lim said.

title: High-Tech Devices Keep Elderly Safe From Afar
description: First thing every morning, Lynn Pitet, of Cody, Wyo., checks her computer to see whether her mother, Helen Trost, has gotten out of bed, taken her medication and whether she is moving around inside her house hundreds of miles away in Minnesota.

title: Touring 10 Wineries, Sip by Sip
description: Westchester residents need not travel to Napa Valley or even the far reaches of Long Island to spend the day visiting wineries. Just north of the county lies the Shawangunk Wine Trail, an association of 10 Hudson Valley wineries covering 80 miles in Gardiner, Marlboro, New Paltz, Pine Bush, Washingtonville and Warwick.

title: The Brickyard Is Patricks Backyard
description: INDIANAPOLIS  At one point Friday afternoon, 28 people stood at Danica Patricks infield souvenir truck, eyeing the merchandise. There were no shoppers at the next truck  until someone bought a disposable camera and briskly walked away.

title: Raising the Dead
description: Some writers turn despair into humor as a way of making the world bearable, of discovering some glimmer of beauty or pleasure or, most important, humanity. In contrast, the gifted Bosnian writer Aleksandar Hemon has taken the formal structure of humor, the grammar of comedy, the rhythms and beats of a joke, and used them to reveal despair. His new novel, The Lazarus Project, is a remarkable, and remarkably entertaining, chronicle of loss and hopelessness and cruelty propelled by an eloquent, irritable existential unease. It is, against all odds, full of humor and full of jokes. It is, at the same time, inexpressibly sad.

title: 36 Hours in Cartagena, Colombia
description: WITH its cocaine days in the past, the Colombian seaport of Cartagena has emerged as the belle of the ball. This tropical city on the Caribbean is pulsating like a salsa party, drawing well-heeled Latin Americans and European socialites to its restored colonial mansions, fancy fusion restaurants and Old World-style plazas. Other rhythms can be heard, too. Guitar players stroll through the cobblestone alleyways. Beauty pageants and dance festivals keep the city swinging after dark. And techno dance clubs keep Cartagenas revelers up till dawn. But this stunningly beautiful city also has its quiet side. White sand beaches and crystal-clear water are just a short hop away.

title: Correction
description: An essay on May 11 about the American intellectual scene in 1958 referred incorrectly to Jack Kerouacs Dharma Bums, published that year. It was his fourth novel, not the second. It followed The Town and the City (1950), On the Road (1957) and The Subterraneans (also 1958)

title: The Kindness of Cronies
description: When Christopher J. Christie, New Jerseys top federal prosecutor, gave a multimillion-dollar no-bid corporate monitoring contract to John Ashcroft, the former attorney general, it looked like an isolated case of favoritism. Now the Justice Department has revealed that at least 30 former government officials have been riding the same patronage train.

title: The Sergeant Lost Within
description: You want to wear this or this for therapy tomorrow? Sgt. Shurvon Phillips mother asked, holding two shirts in front of him. On one wall of his bedroom hung a poster of a marine staring fiercely, assault rifle in hand and black paint beneath his narrow eyes. Shurvons eyes, meanwhile, are wide and soft brown. He sat upright, supported by the tilt of a hospital bed. He cannot speak and can barely emit sound or move any part of his body, and sometimes its as if the striking size of his eyes is a desperate attempt to let others understand who he is, to let them see inside his mind, because his brain can carry out so little in the way of communication.

title: Name From London, People From Everywhere

The couple, who have two young children, lived there for eight years and loved being near Prospect Park and surrounded by friends. But when the time came to buy, they wanted more space and found the prices too high, and they decided they could also live without the ritual of driving around in search of a parking spot, sometimes for 40 minutes.

title: Pot Luck
description: Around 1979, when I was a child living in Russia, my teacher once assigned our class an essay: if a Magi promised to grant you a single wish, what would you ask for? I knew what I wanted, and I wrote about it with passion and sincerity. I thought it was a beautiful wish until my teacher read my essay and said she was appalled  she couldnt believe anyone would waste a wish like that. She leaned close and whispered, Wouldnt you rather wish for world peace?

title: Hope in the Unseen
description: Every once in a while as a journalist you see a scene that grips you and will not let go, a scene that is at once so uplifting and so cruel its difficult to even convey in words. I saw such a scene last weekend at the College of Notre Dame of Maryland in Baltimore. It was actually a lottery, but no ordinary lottery. The winners didnt win cash, but a ticket to a better life. The losers left with their hopes and lottery tickets crumpled.
