An anticipated 2,000 to 3,000 elementary, middle and high schoolers from more than 30 school districts, Scout troops and summer camps will be participating in the Public Tile Project, the creation of a mile-long walkway in Peekskill lined with more than 500 Dutch-style ceramic tiles.

title: Dick Sutcliffe, 90, Dies; Began Davey and Goliath
description: Dick Sutcliffe, whose idea to use animated characters to teach religious principles resulted in the cartoon show Davey and Goliath, died on May 11 in Dallas, where he lived. He was 90.

title: Labor Pains
description: Eight years ago, Deborah Shank was seriously injured when a semitrailer rig struck the drivers side of her minivan. Because Shank, then a shelf stocker at a Wal-Mart store in Cape Girardeau, Mo., had recently qualified for the companys health plan, most of her immediate hospital expenses were covered. But because the accident left her in a wheelchair, with permanent brain damage, she continues to require full-time nursing care. To help pay for it, a court set up a $417,000 trust, using the proceeds of a lawsuit against the company whose driver caused the accident.

title: Brazil Rainforest Analysis Sets Off Political Debate
description: SO JOS DOS CAMPOS, Brazil  Gilberto Cmara, a scientist who leads Brazils national space agency, is more at ease poring over satellite data of the Amazon than being thrust into the spotlight.

title: Monaco Grand Prix Is Glamorous and Grueling
description: Since its debut in 1929 as one of the earliest Grand Prix races, Monaco has captured the attention of even the least enthusiastic of motor-racing imaginations. There is no setting in the world quite like the cliffs, luxurious homes and buildings that form the races backdrop, the harbor filled with multimillion-dollar yachts, and the rich and glamorous crowd the race attracts every year, as it no doubt will again Sunday.

title: For Shipbound Sailors, a Smiling Personal Shopper
description: EARLY one recent morning, Herb Reiss drove a blue minivan through a maze of idling 18-wheelers and shipping containers stacked high like giant Lego bricks, and pulled up to the dock of the New York Container Terminal at Howland Hook, Staten Island.

title: Enjoy the Reunion. Skip the Check.
description: College students are headed home for the summer, leaving campuses to the alumni for a few days of remember-when revelry. Welcome to the annual ritual that has university development officers across the country sharpening their utensils. May I pour you another cocktail, sir?

title: Puerto Rico Gets Its Moment in the Sun (the Political One) as Primary Nears
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  Puerto Rico traditionally complains of being ignored by the rest of the United States, but that has just changed, if only for the moment. With a Democratic presidential primary to be held here on June 1, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton began their Memorial Day weekend on Saturday campaigning in the Spanish-speaking Caribbean.

title: Inside a Museum, Its Cool
description: Yonkers

title: Twain Piece That Amuses in Antics, if Not Substance
description: Mark Twain, wherever he is, can rest easy.

title: In W.N.B.A., a Little Traveling Music
description: Some W.N.B.A. fans go to great lengths to root for their favorite teams.

title: When a Loan Is a Gift
description: My parents graciously offered to lend my wife and me the down payment for a home. While we can easily afford the mortgage payments, the bank wants all of us to sign a statement saying the money from my parents is a gift, not a loan, although the bank representative literally winked as he handed me the statement. I am reluctant to ask my parents to be dishonest, but isnt everyone better off if this deal goes through?  M.S., BOSTON

title: In Search of Buckley
description: In the late 1960s an assistant prosecutor friend of mine invited me to be his guest at a Jets game. He was a member of something called the Jets Club, which was located in an upper tier of Shea Stadium just behind the press box, with a lively bar scene and a perfect view of the field.

title: Black Flies
description: "This is Camellia. Camellia, say hello. How old are you, Camellia? She says seven. When Camellia was two she stopped breathing. She has asthma. Her airway closed. Her heart stopped. She was lucky. We got to her on time. Did what we're trained to do. She's a success story. I want you all to look at her. Wave to them, Camellia. I bring her in on the last day at the academy. Once you're on the streets it's easy to forget Camellia."

title: Comments Cast Shadow on Last Laps in Primaries
description: BAYAMN, P.R.  By this point in the Democratic presidential race  after endless hours of debates, 17 election nights and so many miles of campaigning  when both candidates arrived on Saturday in Puerto Rico, it seemed that surely everything had been said between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama.

title: Mets Win and Change the Subject for a Day
description: DENVER  About 12 hours after the Mets lost their fifth consecutive game, Willie Randolph wrote the names of Fernando Tatis, Nick Evans and Claudio Vargas on a lineup card. With his team playing poorly and his general manager, Omar Minaya, refusing to guarantee that he will not be fired this season, Randolph was, to an extent, putting his fate in a veteran with five career games of outfield experience, a 22-year-old recalled from Class AA Binghamton and a starting pitcher who was in the minor leagues 10 days ago.

title: The Watch List
description: The Marlins rise to the top of the N.L. East coincides with Andrew Millers trading walks for strikeouts. Miller, below, struck out 18 and walked 13 in compiling a 9.12 E.R.A. over his first six starts. In four starts since, he is 3-1 with a 1.44 E.R.A., striking out 26 and walking 7. The Mets, who ripped Miller for five runs in his first start, will face the new Miller this week.

title: War Zone Revisited
description: The title of John Gimlettes Panther Soup refers to the mud that an American Army veteran of World War II, Putnam Flint, vividly remembers churning through in 1944 and 45 with the 824th Tank Destroyer Battalion. Its members wore a panther patch on their uniforms as their towed antitank guns, later replaced by self-propelled tracked vehicles, moved from Marseille up the Rhone Valley to fight Hitlers forces through the Vosges and Alsace into southern Germany and the Austrian Alps.

title: Misreading the Arab Media
description: ARABIC TV does not do our country justice, President Bush complained in early 2006, calling it a purveyor of propaganda that just isnt right, it isnt fair, and it doesnt give people the impression of what were about.

title: $50 Billion Telecom Deal Falls Apart
description: NEW DELHI  The world's largest corporate deal in an emerging market, a tie-up worth nearly $50 billion between two telecommunication companies, Bharti Airtel in India and MTN Group in South Africa, came to a screeching halt Saturday.

title: Dow Falls 507 Points as Oil Prices Soar
description: Rising energy costs and further declines in the troubled housing market led to steep losses in stocks last week.

title: U.N. Leader Praises Chinas Quake Response
description: CHENGDU, China  The secretary general of the United Nations, Ban Ki-Moon, flew to the heart of Chinas earthquake zone in Sichuan Province on Saturday to praise the nations response to the disaster and pledge his organizations support.

title: Editors Choice
description: NETHERLAND, by Joseph ONeill. (Pantheon, $23.95.) In the wittiest, angriest, most exacting and most desolate work of fiction yet about post-9/11 New York and London, the game of cricket provides solace to a man whose family disintegrates after the attacks.

title: Step by Step, the Showgirl Must Go On
description: West Hollywood, Calif.

title: Summer Arts in Connecticut and Westchester County
description: MAY 29 - JUNE 1

title: Events in Westchester
description: FILM

title: Worries in G.O.P. About McCain Camp Disarray
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCains presidential campaign is in a troubled stretch, hindered by resignations of staff members, a lagging effort to build a national campaign organization and questions over whether he has taken full advantage of Democratic turmoil to present a case for his candidacy, Republicans say.

title: Murder, She Once Wrote
description: AROUND 8 oclock on a breezy evening in 1992, two private investigators stepped out of their car at the Christopher Street pier in Greenwich Village and approached a group of drunks and addicts huddled over a small fire. The investigators were soon joined by three Chinatown gang members who had information that the investigators needed. But the conversation was brief; the gang leader had a temper, and guns were drawn fast.

title: Dont Bother With the Hotel Pool
description: WHAT I remember most about a nighttime tour I took of Alcatraz a couple of years ago was the fact that  given the nearness of the island prison to downtown San Francisco, just a mile and a half offshore  inmates were often haunted by the sounds of life across the water. When city residents held New Years Eve parties and their reveling carried across the cold, current-roiled bay, the two shores seemed maddeningly close to the prisoners.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE RELUCTANT FUNDAMENTALIST, by Mohsin Hamid. (Harvest/Harcourt, $14.) Hamid was born in Pakistan and educated at Princeton and Harvard Law. The protagonist of his second novel is a lot like him  a cultivated young Pakistani, working in New York in 2001 after graduating from Princeton, who finds himself sympathizing with the attackers. His resentment is at least in part self-loathing, directed at the American hed been on his way to becoming, our reviewer, Karen Olsson, said, calling the book elegant and chilling. Hamid told an interviewer that this is a story of someone who is in love with America ... who finds he has to leave.

title: Emilys Posts
description: OFFICE TATTOO FAQS

title: McMafia
description: Introduction

title: Colombian Guerrilla Leader Reported Dead
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Colombias defense minister revealed Saturday that officials were trying to corroborate an intelligence report claiming that Manuel Marulanda, the supreme leader of Colombias largest rebel group, died of natural causes in March.

title: Asparagus-Tarragon Cocotte
description: Salt

title: Amanda Viola, Peter Beuttenmuller
description: Amanda Emma Viola, a daughter of Mary Jayne Viola and Joseph Viola of New Fairfield, Conn., was married there on Friday to Lt. Peter Thomas Beuttenmuller, a son of Gail Darling and David Beuttenmuller, both of Palm Beach, Fla. Msgr. Martin P. Ryan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Edward the Confessor Church, where he is the pastor.

title: An Honor Beyond Words for New Hepburn Center Chief
description: OLD SAYBROOK

title: Childhood Is the Mother of the Play
description: AH, sweet, blessed memories of childhood. Steaming herbal tea. Hippie language police. Friends who had same-sex parents. Feminism, politics and books debated around the kitchen table every night. Also, Annie Baker said she used to wonder, precisely why were the typewritten fliers, push-pinned up in the local health food shop, always Xeroxed on purple paper with those little tear-off tabs at the bottom?

title: Narrow Minded
description: You dont have to search very hard to find the excruciating online videos known as thinspiration, or thinspo. Photomontages of skeletal women, including some celebrities and models, play all over the Internet, uploaded from the United States, Germany, Holland and elsewhere. These videos are designed to inspire viewers  to fortify their ambitions. But exactly which ambitions? To lose weight, presumably. To stop losing weight, possibly. Thinspo videos profess a range of ideologies, often pressing morbid images into double service, as both goads and deterrents to anorexia.

title: Where the Bargains Keep Rolling Along
description: LOOKING for a bargain in Europe this summer? Forget hotels, restaurants and most forms of entertainment  the costs of which are rising into the stratosphere with the dollar near its lows against the euro and still weak versus the pound.

title: Flipped Out
description: The Flip

title: Son of Speak-Easy
description: AFTER 400 years, the tides were due to turn. Here on New Yorks harbor, roughnecked stevedores once toiled on grimy docks; then came piers-turned-parks, piers-turned-galleries and piers-turned-bowling alleys. Now, anchoring a trinity of luxury waterfront condo towers near West 11th Street designed by Richard Meier, is a seemingly out-of-place dive bar, the Rusty Knot.

title: Lone Stumbling Block Stands in Front of Northwesterns 4th Title
description: TOWSON, Md.  The measuring stick for excellence in womens lacrosse is the Maryland team that won seven straight N.C.A.A. titles from 1995 to 2001. On Sunday night, when Northwestern plays Pennsylvania in this years championship game, those Maryland teams may find company.

title: The Freedom Nonagenda
description: When John McCain talks about the world, he returns again and again to the subject that so preoccupies George Bush  democracy. McCain says that democracies share not only values but also interests that differ fundamentally from those of authoritarian states. In a major foreign-policy speech this past March, he spoke of the great nations of India and Japan, Australia and Brazil, South Korea and South Africa, Turkey and Israel, and proposed that the U.S. and Europe join with them in a global coalition for peace and freedom that he calls the League of Democracies.

title: The Dogs of War
description: After the abuse of the prisoners at Abu Ghraib was exposed in April 2004 by The New Yorker and 60 Minutes, the Bush administration sought to portray the reprehensible misconduct as the work of a few bad apples. Seeming to underscore that verdict was the fact that soldiers took pictures of themselves, smiling, holding thumbs up, with the naked, dead, abused and humiliated prisoners.

title: The Kettle Boils, the Plot Thickens
description: AS any visitor from England will tell you, no one in the United States can make a proper cup of tea. But 234 years after the Boston Tea Party set a salty precedent for tea preparations here, some Americans can finally claim to make it up the steeping slope.

title: From Italian and Latin Heritage: Artful Plates
description: BASSO CAFE in Norwalk took me by surprise. It looks like a modest little cafe on Route 23  trim, tidy and plain  but its Mediterranean fusion cuisine, salted with a few South American dishes, like empanadas and tres leches, belies its looks.

title: U.S. Goalkeeper Faces Difficult Save
description: CARSON, Calif.  Eight months after the benching of goalkeeper Hope Solo and the corrosive fallout at the Womens World Cup, no one is pretending that all wounds have healed as the Olympics approach. Close friendships have frayed. The telephone calls that used to come on days off  lets go shopping, lets go to the beach  no longer come.

title: Entrees to Match the Course
description: IN 1947, Bing Crosby summoned his pals to Pebble Beach, Calif., for a boozy golf tournament by the bay. The event, officially the revival of the National Pro-Amateur Golf Championship, was called the Clambake. But no one came for the cuisine.

title: Help for Struggling Homeowners
description: LENDERS are increasingly willing to change their loan terms for struggling borrowers, mortgage industry executives say, but the increased flexibility has not been enough to help many homeowners who wait too long before seeking help.

title: Exposed
description: Back in 2006, when I was 24, my life was cozy and safe. I had just been promoted to associate editor at the publishing house where Id been working since I graduated from college, and I was living with my boyfriend, Henry, and two cats in a grubby but spacious two-bedroom apartment in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. I spent most of my free time sitting with Henry in our cheery yellow living room on our stained Ikea couch, watching TV. And almost every day I updated my year-old blog, Emily Magazine, to let a few hundred people know what I was reading and watching and thinking about.

title: Charming Italian, and Thats the Truth
description: LIARS take their chances when they put their hands in the Bocca della Verit (mouth of truth) in the portico of the church of Santa Maria in Cosmedin in Rome. The open mouth on a giant face  the design thought to grace an ancient manhole cover  supposedly will clamp down on the hand of the dissembler.

title: A Superhighway to Bliss
description: JILL BOLTE TAYLOR was a neuroscientist working at Harvards brain research center when she experienced nirvana.

title: San Diego, Doing Fine
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Chief, a Little Skepticism Can Go a Long Way
description: A NEIGHBOR of mine has eyes in the back of her head. Sometimes she can tell without looking that her children are doing something off limits  eating cookies just before dinner, shedding backpacks on the kitchen floor  and she tells them to stop without even turning around.

title: Diversity at the Office: Policy vs. Reality
description: MINORITY employees may flee workplaces even when employers have so-called diversity programs in place, says Natalie Holder-Winfield, an employment lawyer turned diversity consultant.

title: In the Military, Finding Peace From a War at Home
description: I SPENT many a Memorial Day on the airfield at McGuire Air Force Base, N.J., watching the fighter jets do somersaults above us and leave a stream of red, white and blue smoke in their wakes. The show inspired both delight and terror. The jets shone like silver birds piercing the sky, but I worried that they would crash into the crowd, or one another.

title: A Big Loss for Rutgers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tale of the Long-Suffering Wife, by Way of Queens
description: You can almost hear the thought processes behind this revival of The Vows of Penelope Corelli as you listen to the exaggerated Noo Yawk accents of the actors: its the Odyssey set in ethnic Queens and performed by the Sopranos. Richard Veteres goofy play, revised from his 1990s original, gives an Italian-American spin to the Homeric story of Penelope, who waited and waited and waited for Odysseus to return from his far-flung travels.

title: A Spike in Screams Before Graduation
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn.

title: Seeing and Counting Salamanders Close-Up
description: Mystic

title: Cloud Computing: So You Dont Have to Stand Still
description: CLOUD computing is the jargon of the moment in the technology industry. Google, I.B.M., Microsoft and Yahoo are just some of the big companies talking up the cloud, and a bunch of smaller ones are, too.

title: London: The Narrow
description: If cutting edge has never been a primary draw for me in choosing a restaurant, waters edge is something else again. Perhaps its a throwback to a childhood spent in Brooklyn-by-the-Sea, but eating places with views of rivers, lakes and oceans hold an immediate attraction, at least until the often disappointing food appears.

title: A Tiny Masterpiece, Unloved, Faces Threat
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn.

title: In Houston, Expectations Defied
description: After the Astros lost 90 games in 2007, expectations were not particularly high before this season.

title: A New Freedom, Without All That Stuff
description: To the Editor:

title: Italian Mainstay Thats True to Its Roots
description: AS some of us know all too well, when we get older we tend to get quirkier. Radicchio, in downtown Ridgewood, is almost 16  a couple of lifetimes in restaurant years  and it has enough quirks for a Preston Sturges movie.

title: Circumstantial Evidence
description: Letters

title: Lovers, Not Fighters
description: Once I had eluded the 90-mile-an-hour fastball sizzling toward my head, I knew it was time for me to keep my promise.

title: Making the Call on a Home Run Promotion
description: David Ortiz of the Boston Red Sox is scheduled to play the role of Babe Ruth in a Call Your Shot promotion that is part of the home run derby scheduled for the All-Star Game festivities on July 14 at Yankee Stadium. The Yankees were upset when they heard about the plan and said they would ask Major League Baseball for an explanation. Readers of Bats, The Timess baseball blog, weighed in.

title: Tears and Memories as Business Resumes at Dry Cleaners Where Woman Was Killed
description: Eden Dry Cleaners and Tailoring opened about 8:30 a.m. on Saturday. Kenneth Oh and a friend assisted the first customers. His younger brother, Daniel Oh, and some helpers arrived a few hours later.

title: One-Slam Wonder Still Loved in France
description: PARIS  It is a nostalgic time in France, and the tennis world is in the same mood. Paris intellectuals have spent much of the year filling air and space with ruminations on the deeper meaning of the student demonstrations that peaked 40 years ago, in May 1968. But tennis has its own anniversary to analyze this spring with the French Open beginning Sunday.

title: Mussina and Offense Among Signs of Hope
description: The Yankees are on a four-game winning streak, their best of the season, but there was more than just that for the home team to smile about after Saturdays 12-6 victory over Seattle on a partly sunny day before 53,512 fans at Yankee Stadium.

title: Minimal, but Not Radical, Carousel
description: There are many adjectives one can apply to the great musicals by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein II. But a half-century or so after their creation, fresh is not typically the first, or even the last, word that springs to mind.

title: Great Views, Priceless.
description: WHAT price glory? It could be more than $100 million.

title: Indie Films, Coming to a Small Screen Near You
description: MORE than 3,600 independent features were submitted to the Sundance Film Festival this year, a record driven by inexpensive digital equipment and an abundance of film financing. But only a couple hundred of those movies will ever be distributed in theaters. Does that mean that almost 90 percent of indies have zero value?

title: Jessica Lerer, Daniel Yunger
description: Jessica Nicole Lerer, a daughter of Esther D. and Dr. Paul K. Lerer of Englewood, N.J., is to be married this evening to Daniel Yunger, a son of Alisa and Herman Yunger of Lido Beach, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel H. Mehlman is to officiate at the Hilton Rye Town in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: A Promise Paid, or Not, for Housing
description: ON a recent Tuesday, thick ropes of rain slashed at the concrete and dripped off car tires in the parking lot of Harborview Terrace, a two-building public housing project on West 55th Street, between 10th and 11th Avenues. There was little indication that the forlorn lot, and the basketball court next to it, might be the site of a real estate battle.

title: Trying to Right a Wrong Committed 20 Years Ago
description: Whatever happened to the boy and girl voted cutest couple in your senior class? In the case of the sweethearts in Craig Wrights fuzzy but often touching class-reunion drama The Pavilion, now onstage at the Westport Country Playhouse, things havent gone well.

title: Witness for the Transit
description: Raised in Fort Lee, N.J., long based in San Francisco and drawn by wanderlust or employment to Montreal, Lisbon, Auckland, Austin, Dubai and Berlin, August Kleinzahler is as much a travel writer as he is a poet: his sometimes bitter, sometimes astonished poems (several even entitled Travelers Tales) seek the distinctive qualities of each place, repellent or beautiful or (in places he loves best) both at once. In Vancouver, the neon mermaid over the fish place / looks best that way, in the rain. At Coney Island, a cluster of hip-hop Lubavitch punks watch Neil Diamond (yes, its really him) amble past on the sand; in the American South, the poet imagines pecans suffering /their convoluted slumber in the heat. The poets interest in places spans the globe now, but it began with his native New Jersey, where (an early poem called Poetics says) I have loved the air outside Shop-Rite Liquor / on summer evenings/ better than the Marin hills at dusk. Few poets since William Carlos Williams have done more for the Garden State, or rendered with such mixed feelings what they saw there.

title: Balancing Art and Business
description: PETER C. SUTTON looked a little weary as he presided over a senior staff meeting at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Conn. Dr. Sutton had just returned the night before from a business trip to Japan, where he had given a lecture on Vermeer and the Delft School, his specialty, and discussed loans of artworks for future shows at the Bruce. Now he was listening as Nancy Hall-Duncan, senior curator of art, reported on plans for a 2009 show devoted to the French Impressionist painter Alfred Sisley.

title: Mexico Ties Rise in Killings to Its Crackdown on Drugs
description: MEXICO CITY  Killings related to an underworld war between drug cartels have increased sharply, up almost 50 percent from the same period last year, the attorney general said Friday.

title: Voters Pass All but Two School Budgets
description: MOUNT VERNON

title: Correction: Cartoon Captions
description: Credits last Sunday for two cartoons were reversed. The cartoon depicting a FEMA executive commenting on Myanmar, on the bottom left, was by Signe Wilkinson of The Philadelphia Daily News, Washington Post Writers Group, and the cartoon about gas prices, on the bottom right, was by Rob Rogers of The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, United Features Syndicate.

title: A C.E.O. Hits Reply, and Now Its Regret
description: His multimillion-dollar compensation package and appearances at Congressional hearings have made Angelo R. Mozilo, Countrywide Financials chief executive, the public face of the subprime mortgage crisis. That face may have turned crimson after he mishandled an e-mail message from a Countrywide customer asking for an adjustment to the terms of his mortgage.

title: The Big Squeeze
description: Worked Over and Overworked

title: Lynne Salkin, Andrew Morris
description: Lynne Jessica Salkin, the daughter of Wilma Salkin and Gerald Salkin of Bondville, Vt., is to be married on Sunday evening to Andrew Gary Morris, the son of Sandra Morris and Dr. Kenneth Morris of Melville, N.Y. Rabbi Michael Friedman is to officiate at the Equinox, a resort in Manchester, Vt.

title: Blood and Guts
description: In the early 1990s, lacking direction after a breakup with a girlfriend, Shannon Burke left New Orleans (where hed been working in a bookstore), moved to New York and took a job on an ambulance crew. He was drawn to emergency medicine partly out of guilt, he later explained to a paramedic friend. Back in the French Quarter, he had come upon a tourist, shot in the head, and had been unable to help her. I thought I should have known first aid, he recalled. Like I could have saved her. Burke went to Manhattan as a kind of personal test because I figured it would be the most extreme place to do it. In the five years he served on city ambulances, first as an E.M.T., later as a paramedic at Station 18, on 136th Street across from Harlem Hospital, he saw unspeakable horrors. Unspeakable, but not inexpressible.

title: On Shore, a Week to Release Stress but Also a Chance to Address It
description: For many service members, Fleet Week is a fun time to get some shore leave, explore New York and have a few  maybe free  drinks.

title: Rendering Justice, With One Eye on Re-election
description: Last month, Wisconsin voters did something that is routine in the United States but virtually unknown in the rest of the world: They elected a judge.

title: Citizen Pruners, on Deadwood Patrol
description: A CITY street tree has a rough life. Plumes of vehicular exhaust cloud trees spring blossoms, teenagers carve their trunks with the musings of adolescent love, and trucks barrel into their branches. And so at 8:30 on a recent morning, two citizen pruners, Peter Arndtsen and Bruce James, set out to care for some of the afflicted street trees in their Upper West Side neighborhood.

title: Reviving a Dark Horse and His Revelation
description: IT doesnt help your legacy as a composer to give the Nazi salute in 1938 at the premiere of your greatest work. Nor is it good for your cause to tell a young Herbert von Karajan that he has no future in conducting. So it may not be a total surprise that the Austrian composer Franz Schmidt is little known to the wider world, given his difficult character and distasteful political associations.

title: Starting Salaries but New York Tastes
description: Laura Werkheiser knew she would have to make many sacrifices to live in Manhattan. Foremost among them was shopping for clothes.

title: Now Hes Only Hunted by Cameras
description: The written record cannot be trusted in Salman Rushdies newest novel, The Enchantress of Florence, a story that roams from the red sandstone palace of the great Mughal emperor Akbar to the towered Palazzo in Machiavellis Florence. One character is erased from official history, a second is imagined into existence, a third is hopelessly mischaracterized.

title: When They Were Around, the Ayes Had It
description: WASHINGTON  In the annals of Congressional history, Representative Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas is remembered for the ignominious end to his long legislative career: a public display of inebriation during a dalliance with a stripper named Fanne Fox.

title: Wall Street Exodus: Fear, Panic and Anger
description: THE mind wraps itself around losing a job, one of lifes great traumas, in jagged and swerving fits. When the call comes in, when rumor turns to reality, when its not the broker in the next cubicle but you who is presented with a stack of severance papers, the psyche takes over.

title: The Abstinence Pledge
description: To the Editor:

title: Dancing in Space, Banjos in China, Jazz From All Over
description: Midnight Juggernauts

title: A Champions Troubles
description: Harry Carson, the Giants Hall of Fame linebacker, inducted Vince Lombardi into the New Jersey Hall of Fame recently, and according to Carson, the Super Bowl champions had better be prepared for every game.

title: Amanda Slater, Matthew Salganik
description: Amanda Post Slater and Matthew Jeffrey Salganik are to be married by Rabbi Mark Lipson on Sunday evening at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the effect of budget cutbacks on international agricultural development misstated the relationship between the Asian Development Bank and the World Bank. While the membership and goals of the organizations overlap, they are not legally affiliated.

title: Two Budget Airlines
description: While one budget airline tightens its belt, another one flexes its muscles. JetBlue (www.jetblue.com) recently announced that it would postpone its planned service between Los Angeles International Airport and Boston Logan and Kennedy Airport. The airline, which serves 53 destinations, was planning to offer three daily nonstop flights between Kennedy and Los Angeles International, and one between Los Angeles and Boston. The service was to have started last Wednesday.

title: Israelis and Arabs Walk Into a Film ...
description: ADAM SANDLERS comedies can usually be distinguished  if thats the right word  by setups so improbable that they border on the ridiculous, from the re-education of a man forced to complete grades 1 through 12 (Billy Madison) to the sham gay marriage of two heterosexual firefighters (I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry). Yet his latest movie places him in what may be his most improbable scenario to date.

title: Jessica Atkins and Jos Hernndez
description: Jessica Leigh Atkins, a daughter of Sherri M. Atkins and Jay R. Atkins of Wyckoff, N.J., is to be married on Sunday evening to Lt. Cmdr. Jos Graciano Hernndez, a son of Myriam Retamar of Dorado, P.R., and the late Alberto I. Hernndez. Rabbi Jordi Gendra-Molina is to officiate at the Garrison, a resort in Garrison, N.Y.

title: Maha Ahmad and Mehdi Rizvi
description: Dr. Maha Ahmad and Mehdi Rizvi are to be married on Sunday at Battery Gardens, a restaurant in New York. Imam Ghazi Y. Khankan, a Muslim cleric, is to officiate.

title: Time and Cost Rise for Yankee Stadium Parks
description: The cost of replacing two popular parks where the new Yankee Stadium is being built has nearly doubled. At the same time, several of the eight new parks, which were supposed to be completed before the new stadium opens next spring, have been delayed by as much as two years, according to city documents.

title: Eve Biddle, Joshua Frankel
description: Eve Georgina Biddle, a daughter of Geoffrey Biddle of Berkeley, Calif., and the late Mary Ann Unger, is to be married on Sunday evening to Joshua Nicholas Frankel, a son of Nina Frankel of Manhattan and Richard Frankel of Leonia, N.J.

title: Matchmaking, the Ultimate Government Service

title: The Other Half
description: Today one of the last Bowery flophouses leans up against the futuristic steel facade of the New Museum, and a bed at the Bowery Hotel can run $750 a night. After such gentrification, it can be difficult to conjure up the squalid New York that Jacob Riis documented in his groundbreaking 1889 work of photojournalism, How the Other Half Lives. Riis was well aware that the other half in New York City had become the other three-quarters, with 1.2 million impoverished New Yorkers living in slums, 19th-century tenements that were a public health catastrophe, rife with typhus, diarrhea, cholera and tuberculosis. Employing unsentimental storytelling, reportage, social statistics and the latest advances in flash photography, Riis shed a stark light on the horrific living conditions of New Yorks vast population of poor immigrants.

title: From Break Dancing to Ballet

But here was the rub: The 9-year-old wanted to be Pel, not a prince. And although this is a Cinderella story  ragamuffin running wild in the streets metamorphoses into ballet god  it is one in which the hero spends a dizzying amount of time pining for his position amid the squalor of the hearth.

title: The Enchantress of Florence
description: In the day's last light the glowing lake below the palace-city looked like a sea of molten gold. A traveler coming this way at sunset  this traveler, coming this way, now, along the lakeshore road  might believe himself to be approaching the throne of a monarch so fabulously wealthy that he could allow a portion of his treasure to be poured into a giant hollow in the earth to dazzle and awe his guests. And as big as the lake of gold was, it must be only a drop drawn from the sea of the larger fortune  the traveler's imagination could not begin to grasp the size of that mother-ocean! Nor were there guards at the golden water's edge; was the king so generous, then, that he allowed all his subjects, and perhaps even strangers and visitors like the traveler himself, without hindrance to draw up liquid bounty from the lake? That would indeed be a prince among men, a veritable Prester John, whose lost kingdom of song and fable contained impossible wonders. Perhaps (the traveler surmised) the fountain of eternal youth lay within the city walls  perhaps even the legendary doorway to Paradise on Earth was somewhere close at hand? But then the sun fell below the horizon, the gold sank beneath the water's surface, and was lost. Mermaids and serpents would guard it until the return of daylight. Until then, water itself would be the only treasure on offer, a gift the thirsty traveler gratefully accepted.

The new Indiana Jones films gross was sufficient to wrest the No. 1 ranking from last weeks champion, The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (Disney), which slipped to second place with $23 million. description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  While flying over Cayuga Lake in upstate New York a week ago, the Johns Hopkins mens lacrosse coach, Dave Pietramala, and his offensive coordinator, Bobby Benson, heard a thud in their six-seat plane.

title: Amid Calm in Sadr City, Officials and Clerics Backers Swap Charges of Weakness
description: BAGHDAD  As some semblance of normal life began to return to the Sadr City area on Sunday, the Iraqi government and followers of the radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr accused each other of being weak. The verbal sniping occurred despite a cease-fire that had finally brought calm to one of Baghdads most volatile areas.

title: A New Twist on Balloon Sculpture
description: Most people associate balloon twisting with clowns, birthday parties, poodles and fanciful hats for children. But as it turns out, there are strong subcultures of balloon-twisters, and they do not always get along.

title: Mets Lose Again; Wilpon Is Up Next
description: DENVER  Passing a trunk containing his No. 12 jersey, Willie Randolph wheeled a suitcase through the middle of a near-empty clubhouse Sunday afternoon. He knew he was flying to New York as the Mets manager, this much was certain. How much longer he retains his job may be in question after the Mets lost for the sixth time in seven games, 4-1 to the Colorado Rockies.

title: Teenage Newshounds, Its a Dog-Eat-Dog World
description: Before the television cameras rolled, Amanda Lorber was just one of 5,500 students at Cypress Bay High School in Weston, Fla. She was passionate about writing and musical theater, and possessed an intense desire to become the editor in chief of her school newspaper, The Circuit.

title: Long March to an Apology
description: Washington

title: Kuerten, a Three-Time French Open Champion, Bids Adieu
description: PARIS  Those searching for a last glimpse of vintage Gustavo Kuerten did not leave entirely unsatisfied on the first day of the French Open.

title: Remember to Remember
description: Last Thursday, the soldiers of the Third United States Infantry Regiment (the Old Guard) placed a small American flag in front of each of the 260,000 or so grave markers in Arlington National Cemetery. The soldiers remained on duty throughout the weekend, replacing flags that had fallen or been removed, to ensure that each grave was appropriately decorated and honored on Memorial Day.

title: Season Finale With a Florentine Touch
description: New Yorks vibrant music scene is packed with ensembles of every type, but many worthy young musicians still struggle to find work. So the composer and conductor Salvatore Di Vittorio saw a niche for a professional orchestra for young players, offering regular performance opportunities to some of the many graduates who pour out of the countrys conservatories each year.

title: More Monaco?
description: The names of the renowned architects Norman Foster and I. M. Pei have been associated with a secret plan by Prince Albert II of Monaco to enlarge his principality, which covers less than one square mile, by extending it out to sea on stilts, according to The Guardian of London. The new territory, with an estimated construction time of 10 years, would include apartments, shops, mooring for yachts and an architectural showpiece likely to be a museum. Some environmentalists along the Cte dAzur are concerned about the projects impact on marine life, but Robert Calcagno, Monacos councilor for the environment and a close associate of the prince, who regards himself as a champion of ecology, said, Not only will we protect the ecosystem, but we will actually better the environment by putting in man-made reefs to allow species to thrive.

title: Donors Press Myanmar to Let Aid Workers In
description: BANGKOK  Delegates from 52 donor nations meeting on Sunday in Myanmar pressed its government to make good on a promise to give foreign aid workers free access to millions of isolated cyclone survivors.

title: States Chafing at U.S. Focus on Terrorism
description: Juliette N. Kayyem, the Massachusetts homeland security adviser, was in her office in early February when an aide brought her startling news. To qualify for its full allotment of federal money, Massachusetts had to come up with a plan to protect the state from an almost unheard-of threat: improvised explosive devices, known as I.E.D.s.

title: Sydney Pollack, Film Director, Dies at 73
description: LOS ANGELES  Sydney Pollack, a Hollywood mainstay as director, producer and sometime actor whose star-laden movies like The Way We Were, Tootsie and Out of Africa were among the most successful of the 1970s and 80s, died on Monday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 73.

title: Military Chief Warns Troops About Politics
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff has written an unusual open letter to all those in uniform, warning them to stay out of politics as the nation approaches a presidential election in which the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan will be a central, and certainly divisive, issue.

title: Mbeki Calls Harm to Migrants a Disgrace
description: JOHANNESBURG  After two weeks of only faint and infrequent condemnations of the anti-immigrant violence that has troubled South Africa, President Thabo Mbeki on Sunday described the wave of xenophobic attacks as an absolute disgrace that has blemished the countrys reputation.

Mr. Kaurismaki, 51, received the title of Academician from Tarja Halonen, president of Finland, on Friday at a ceremony in Helsinki. ... Eartha Kitt, the eternal femme fatale who opened the 2007-8 season at the renovated Caf Carlyle in September, will close the season when she returns, June 4 to July 5, with an evening of standards and songs associated with her long career, including Cest Si Bon, Monotonous and La Vie en Rose. ... description: The dozen or so people in the folding chairs did not quite know what to do when 10 a.m. finally rolled around and the sound system stopped playing soft, up-tempo jazz and started playing The Star-Spangled Banner. Get up? Stay seated?

description: If you ask me, theres nothing like having a caddie by your side on the course. It can be one of golfs great cosmic connections. Unfortunately, I havent yet persuaded a caddie to live in my guest room, which would be a real bonus for those situations when I want to dash out for a quick nine holes and need a caddie ready and waiting.

description: Its Memorial Day. Some of us can remember doubleheaders on this holiday, with radio broadcasters saying, If youre in the neighborhood, plenty of seats. Instead, the Mets, currently by the twin furies of ineptitude and controversy, come home to a night game on Memorial Day. Bring the kiddies, bring the wife, indeed.

At the time of its publication it spoke not only to cold war fears but also to more up-to-the-minute notions that lunar missions might result in the importation of perilous contaminants from the Moon.

He is also one of the people credited with coming up with the holiday that we celebrate today. A statue in Logan Circle in Washington shows the general on horseback flanked by two female figures said to represent America at war and America at peace.

The front door had been kicked in so many times that the dead bolt was exposed and bent. Trash littered the front and back yards. A copper pipe was gone.

description: OBERLIN, Ohio  Lucas Brown, a junior at Oberlin College here, was still wet from the shower the other morning as he entered his score on the neon green message board next to the bathroom sink: Three minutes, according to the plastic hourglass timer inside the shower. Two minutes faster than the morning before. One minute faster than two of his housemates.

Given to up-and-coming classical musicians who seek an international career, the Belgian prize, established in 1937 for violinists by the Bavarian wife of the late King Albert I, now also honors pianists, composers and singers on a rotating basis.

title: Radios Fair Game to Be Canceled
description: Fair Game, the 17-month-old weeknight public-radio show hosted by Faith Salie, has been canceled for financial reasons, and its last broadcast will be on May 30, Public Radio International, the shows producer, said on Friday. We took a gamble on a show that was a departure for public radio, a little bit edgier, Melinda Ward, P.R.I.s senior vice president for content, said in an interview. Unfortunately, the program didnt catch fire fast enough, broadly enough to attract underwriting. The program, which mixed newsmaker interviews and pop culture, was heard on about 25 stations, including WNYC-AM in New York, and had about 140,000 weekly listeners on average, P.R.I. said. Ms. Salie, 37, a former Rhodes Scholar and actress with a relaxed, often irreverent approach, called the show experience wildly fulfilling. Noting that P.R.I. hired me to get a hipper, younger audience for public radio, she said, I think public radio is smart to recognize it needs to innovate in order to survive, and I hope that it will continue to actually allow for innovation rather than just recognize the need for it. P.R.I. is exploring continuing Fair Game online; the shows listeners downloaded about 100,000 podcasts each month, Ms. Ward said. Ms. Salie said that she was interested but was also exploring television hosting offers. WNYC-AM said it would expand On Point to fill the Fair Game time slot of 8 to 9 p.m.

title: Corrections: For the Record

It is Iguaz Falls  not Iguau, as it is called on the other side of the waterfall in Brazil.

title: Corrections: For the Record

In the poem, Sunset, it is The sun, not The man that just went behind the ridge, and turned it mauve, marked green by firs, not by fire.

title: Conflicts Hang Over Argentine Leader
description: BUENOS AIRES  These could be giddy times for Argentina and its first elected female president, Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner. Prices for agricultural commodities are soaring, consumer spending has been rising and foreign investment is flowing in.

title: A Pause Before Summer
description: There is something wonderfully calming about standing on the edge of summer, here on Memorial Day, as though summer lay before us as undisturbed as a spring-fed mountain lake. We all know its not going to be like that. The heat and humidity will build, streets will melt, the presidential campaign will intensify, and the weeks will be no less crowded and worrying in June and July than they are any other time of year. But this morning, many Americans are quietly visiting cemeteries, thankful that Memorial Day comes just when spring blossoms are at their peak. Many more are simply savoring the pleasure of a day off in good weather.

description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Colombias largest rebel group on Sunday confirmed the death of its senior leader, the legendary guerrilla Manuel Marulanda.

description: Anguish over the recent earthquake in China helped set off a small ideological disturbance in Chinatown on Sunday when a Falun Gong parade was jeered by supporters of the Chinese government who hurled water bottles and pieces of pastry at the marchers, as well as insults.

title: Affordable Housing, at a Price
description: For years, officials in New Jersey have talked about the need for more affordable housing and then done almost nothing. The need is pressing, and the state may finally be ready to move. Unfortunately, this newfound resolve carries serious risks. Unless the state changes its current plan, some of the new housing will be built on the few parcels of undeveloped land that still remain. That must not be allowed to happen.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Thursday about Joe Armstrong, the New York bon vivant known as the Mayor of Michaels, the West 55th Street restaurant popular with television and publishing executives, referred imprecisely to Paul Newmans Hole in the Wall Gang camp in Connecticut, where Mr. Armstrong has volunteered as a cabin counselor. It is for children with cancer and other serious  but not necessarily terminal  illnesses.

title: Potter Actor Killed
description: An 18-year-old actor with a small role in the forthcoming film Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince was fatally stabbed in a brawl outside a London bar on Saturday, The Associated Press reported. The actor, Rob Knox, who plays Marcus Belby, a student from Ravenclaw House at the Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry in the seriess sixth installment, to be released in November, was one of five young men taken to hospitals, the police said. Among them was a 21-year-old arrested on suspicion of murder. The killing brought to 14 the number of violent teenage deaths in London this year.

description: If theres one country where nuclear power would seem superfluous, its oil-rich Saudi Arabia. Yet a highlight of President Bushs recent trip there was the signing of an agreement to cooperate on developing civilian nuclear energy. Saudi Arabia is only one of many nations in the Middle East suddenly eager for nuclear power.

description: Fifteen years after the movie Sleepless in Seattle gave his workplace even more fame, Robert Gross finally has a uniform that is camera worthy.

title: Despite Much Adversity, Keeping the Music Alive
description: The Brazilian pianist and conductor Joo Carlos Martins has lived a life of renown, challenge, tenacity and triumph sufficient to fill a lively memoir. An acclaimed recitalist in the 1960s, he specialized in playing Bach with a Romantic subjectivity and intensity. When his concert career was derailed by injuries in the 1970s, Mr. Martins retreated to the studio for an extensive series of Bach recordings while reinventing himself as a successful entrepreneur and, briefly, a politician. A brutal 1995 mugging robbed him of his ability to play professionally.

She also flirted with samba, adopting a translucently airy cadence. Her concert was a study in small gestures and subtle touches, and she made it feel both natural and special.

title: Modernism, Rapid-Fire or Dreamy
description: The word has been out for decades now: The bug-eyed monster of musical modernism is vanquished. Try telling that to the young, accomplished members of the Xanthos Ensemble of Boston, which came to Roulette in SoHo on Saturday night with a program featuring works by three uncompromising modernists: Pierre Boulez, Mario Davidovsky and Charles Wuorinen. And in the hands of musicians so copiously skilled and confident, this undeniably challenging music had genuine appeal.

He was believed to be 76 years old.

title: Behind a Start-Up: One Familys Choices
description: Many of the questions I get from readers have to do with money  specifically how people fund a career shift. I try to get these financial details as often as possible, and I recently heard from a reader, Nina Murphy, whose story of how her husband, Bart Ferris, left the corporate world to start a gourmet foods company with a partner touched on just this issue. It turns out that Ms. Murphy was a big part of the story herself since she is bringing her own skills to her husbands venture by working as the companys publicist. (Career reinvention is always a little easier with a supportive spouse in the wings. But thats a subject for another post.) I asked Ms. Murphy to tell their story here in the blog, with a focus on how they managed the financial side of things. And now, Ill leave it to Ms. Murphy:

title: Readers Respond to Earthquake and Hope

Some questioned the value of democracy for China, while others rallied to the defense of Prime Minister Wen Jiabao (). The support shown here for Mr. Wen is consistent with the outpouring of approval that can be found elsewhere on the Web, including Facebook and sites on the Chinese blogosphere. Readers response to the Communist Party was generally tempered, with neither heavy criticism nor praise for the governments management of the earthquake and its handling of the news media.

title: With Migrant Workers in Short Supply, a Farmer Looks to Machines
description: APPLETON, N.Y.  Scores of Jim Bittners cherry trees are now just heaps of roots and sticks, piled in his fields here along Route 18. Some of the branches lying on the ground are dotted with small blossoms, the seasons earliest evidence that sweet cherries were on their way. But for Mr. Bittner, having sweet cherries would have meant hiring someone to prune the trees and harvest the fruit, and he was not sure that he could do it this year. So he cut his trees down.

title: Memo Pad
description: FARE INCREASES The six network airlines put in place another round of fare increases over the holiday, ranging up to $60 for a round-trip ticket, said Rick Seaney, the chief executive officer of Farecompare.com. It was the 11th fare increase of the year that all six major carriers had joined in. Despite the wide-ranging fare increases, airlines have been very cautious about increasing fares on routes where there is competition from Southwest, JetBlue and other low-cost carriers, Mr. Seaney said. Additionally, he said, airlines are now frequently firing out short-duration sales on fares for certain routes, mostly to fill seats on off-peak business travel days.

title: Glass and Rachmaninoff, With Percussion to Spare
description: The New York Youth Symphony closed its 45th season with what looked like a monster of a program at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon. Ryan McAdams, completing his first season as music director, devoted the first half of the program to a pair of contemporary percussion concertos by Lembit Beecher and Philip Glass, though only Mr. Glass called his piece a concerto explicitly. After intermission Mr. McAdams led his large ensemble of young instrumentalists (ages 12 to 22) in Rachmaninoffs Second Symphony, a huge, broad-boned work full of structural pitfalls that must be overcome if the music is to sound coherent.

title: Spanish Company Buys Stake in Mexico Bank
description: Criteria CaixaCorp, the investment company owned by Spains biggest savings bank, agreed to buy 20 percent of Grupo Financiero Inbursa, a Mexico City bank owned by the billionaire investor Carlos Slim, for 1.5 billion euros ($2.4 billion) to tap economic growth in Mexico. Criteria will pay 38.5 pesos ($3.71) a share for the holding, a premium of 8.6 percent above the Inbursas May 23 closing price, the Spanish company said Monday in a filing. Criteria, a unit of Barcelona-based La Caixa, which holds stakes in businesses worth about 24 billion euros, is buying the stock in Inbursa to diversify in a major Spanish-speaking country as the bank faces the increasing chance of a recession at home. The Mexican bank was set up in 1984 by Mr. Slim, the worlds second-richest man after Warren E. Buffett, according to Forbes magazine.

title: Asian Contemporary Art Sets a Record
description: Mask Series 1996 No. 6, above, a large oil-on-canvas diptych by the Chinese artist Zeng Fanzhi, sold for $9.7 million on Saturday at a Christies auction in Hong Kong, setting a record for Asian contemporary artwork, Reuters reported. The final price was more than triple the presale estimate of $1.9 million to $3.2 million. The piece depicts eight masked young people, arms linked, in what appears to be a friendly grouping. All of them are wearing red scarves reminiscent of Mao Zedongs Communist guards, and the masks, each frozen in a grin, hide the emotion and identity of the characters beneath.

title: Hendrix on Display
description: An exhibition of the work of more than a dozen photographers who captured the rock star Jimi Hendrix between 1967 and 1970 will open on Thursday at the Celebrity Vault gallery in Beverly Hills. The show, Hendrix Revealed: A Life through the Lens, was presented in London earlier this year and has been organized in association with Raj Prem Fine Art Photography in London. A portion of proceeds from the opening-day sales will benefit the nonprofit arts organization Experience Music Project, in Seattle, where Hendrix was born. Among the images on display will be Ed Caraeffs shot from the 1967 Monterey International Pop Music Festival of Hendrix setting fire to his Fender guitar.

title: High Court Sets Date on Bell Canada Appeal
description: The Supreme Court of Canada said on Monday that it would accelerate its process to consider Bell Canadas appeal of a court decision that withdrew approval for a $51.8 billion leveraged buyout of the company last week. While the high court has yet to decide if it will hear Bells appeal, it issued a notice to both the company and its disgruntled bondholders indicating that June 17 is available for a hearing and setting a rapid timetable for filings. A Quebec appeals court sided with bondholders last week because Bell had not considered the impact of the buyout on their holdings. The buyout will add about 30 billion Canadian dollars (about the same in United States funds) in debt to the company, depressing the value of current bonds. Bell asked the court to rule by June 30, the closing date for the deal. The bondholders, in a separate court filing on Monday, rejected that idea and suggested that Bell and the buyout group, led by the Ontario Teachers Pension Plan, should simply make the closing date later rather than expect the court to rush its decision.

title: Its the Genes, Stupid
description: Social scientists are stumped. Why do we bother to go to the polls when we know our individual vote has no chance of determining the result of a national election? Variations in turnout  by age, race, income or whatever  are hard to fit into a theory of human conduct that assumes that people are rational. But with time to spare before the November election, molecular biology is coming to the rescue. In the same way that researchers have teased out a role for genes in determining sexual orientation or the propensity to smoke, they are deploying genetics to understand our political choices.

title: Mixed Outcomes in Laparoscopy for Prostates
description: Laparoscopic operations for prostate cancer, a minimally invasive surgery that is in rising demand, result in fewer immediate complications and quicker recovery than the more common open procedure, a new study reports. But the surgery increases the chance for longer term problems that require further therapy, the research says.

title: Virginia Commonwealths Secret Deal
description: While most universities are struggling to ensure that any research supported by industry remains free of corporate control, it is shocking to find Virginia Commonwealth University going in the opposite direction. It has signed a contract to do research for Philip Morris that gives the company the final say over what results, if any, can be published.

title: Soaring Fuel Prices Take a Withering Toll on Truckers
description: As his logging business expanded in the pine and hardwood forests of eastern Georgia, Jesse Hendley got into trucking. He scraped together the cash gradually to acquire seven tractor-trailers so that he could not only sell timber to mills in the south, but also charge the mills for delivery.

description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Struggles to Replace a Favorite Son
description: Finding a candidate to replace Representative Vito J. Fossella, who will step down at the end of the year, is proving much harder than Republican Party leaders ever imagined.

title: Turning Schools From Death Traps Into Havens
description: The potential for a modest school to survive a powerful earthquake is perhaps nowhere better illustrated than in Balakot, Pakistan, one of hundreds of communities near the border with India shattered by a devastating tectonic jolt on Oct. 8, 2005.

title: Shuttle to Take Big Science Lab to Space Station
description: The space shuttle Discovery is set to deliver the International Space Stations biggest room, in what its commander calls a complicated, busy mission that is scheduled to begin on Saturday.

title: Cause of Fire at Berlin Philharmonic Is Found
description: German officials confirmed Monday that welding work was the cause of the recent fire at the Berlin Philharmonics landmark concert hall, The Associated Press reported. The fire broke out last Tuesday afternoon, just before a rehearsal was scheduled to begin, but there were neither injuries nor any serious damage to the structure or interior of the building, which is scheduled to reopen on June 2.

title: U.S. National Soccer Team Enters a Busy Season
description: The two-month hiatus for the United States mens national team ends Wednesday, when Coach Bob Bradley takes the team to the sports rebuilt cathedral, Wembley Stadium in London, for a friendly match against England.

title: Minnelli in London
description: Liza Minnelli performed at the London Coliseum on Sunday, marking the start of her first British concert tour in more than two decades. The audience thanked her with six standing ovations, The Times of London reported, which was all the more remarkable considering that the concert was nearly canceled. Ms. Minnelli, right, 62, was detained at Heathrow Airport in London on Saturday, when she and her entourage arrived following an appearance in Moscow last week. She did not have the proper work permit, The Daily Mail reported, and the British authorities told Ms. Minnelli she would have to cancel her Sunday concert. The British Home Office eventually smoothed things over, and she appeared on schedule. After her performance in London on Tuesday, Ms. Minnelli will sing in Nottingham, Manchester, Birmingham and Glasgow before heading on June 20 to Los Angeles, where she will be inducted into the Hollywood Bowl Hall of Fame.

title: The Frenzy for Campaign Money
description: The power of money in politics has never been more pronounced or problematical as it is in this years presidential campaign  the costliest in the nations history.

title: Syracuse Captures Lacrosse Title
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The Syracuse mens lacrosse program hit a generational low a year ago. The Orange, a perennial juggernaut, failed to make the N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time since 1982, and the teams direction was uncertain.

title: In Myanmar, Loss, Grief and, for Some, Resignation
description: THAT KYAR, Myanmar  One of Daw Then Khins grandsons has gone insane. He wanders day and night through the fields looking for his wife and son, both swept away by the furious floodwaters that came with the cyclone.

title: Fast-Food Chain Advises Consumers to Get Culverized
description: Editors Note: This issue of In Advertising is coming to you today because of the Memorial Day holiday yesterday. Look for the newsletter next week on its regular day, Monday.

description: To the Editor:

title: MTVs Unscripted Show May Get a Dose of Gritty Brooklyn Reality
description: There is reality, like the reality-check, wake-up-call kind, the sorry-but-thems-the-breaks kind, and there is reality, the kind in reality shows. The two may be sharing screen time this summer in The Real World, the great-grandfather of reality shows, filming in Brooklyn.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article in some editions on May 17 about the killing of Kyung-Sook Woo, the owner of a dry-cleaning shop in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, referrred incorrectly to the length of her hair, which friends said she often did not curl until she was at work because she had risen so early to open the shop. Her hair was short, not long.

title: Summer Entertainment in Bryant Park
description: Once again Bryant Park will provide a summer setting not only for lunchtime getaways or a chess game, but also for film and theater events. The HBO Bryant Park Summer Film Festival is to begin on June 16 with a screening of Dr. No (1962), the first James Bond film, starring Sean Connery, below. Subsequent Mondays will bring screenings of Bride of Frankenstein, The Man Who Came to Dinner and Superman, among others. Each week the lawn will open at 5 p.m. for blanket placement and picnics, and the film will start at dusk. For theater lovers, the annual Broadway in Bryant Park series, presented by the radio station 106.7 Lite FM, will be back for the seventh year, offering lunchtime concerts by cast members from Broadway and Off Broadway shows. The first show this year, on July 10, will include performances from Chicago, Monty Pythons Spamalot, Cry-Baby and Stomp. The series runs consecutive Thursdays through Aug. 14, from 12:30 to 1:30 p.m. The full schedules for both series are at bryantpark.org.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Julie Bertrand and Barbara Gillespie joined Concentric Pharma Advertising, New York, as group art supervisors. Both had worked at Draft FCB Healthcare, New York, part of the Draft FCB unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, where Ms. Bertrand had been a senior art director and Ms. Gillespie an art supervisor.

description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Blames Russia for Downed Drone
description: MOSCOW  A United Nations investigation has concluded that a remotely piloted Georgian reconnaissance aircraft that was destroyed last month was struck by an air-to-air missile fired from a Russian fighter jet.

description: Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: When Hostility Melted for the Funny Accent
description: It was 1:06 in the morning when I got the call from the emergency room. An 82-year-old required admission. Severe anemia. Stool test positive for blood.

title: Atomic Monitor Signals Concern Over Irans Work
description: PARIS  The International Atomic Energy Agency, in an unusually blunt and detailed report, said Monday that Irans suspected research into the development of nuclear weapons remained a matter of serious concern and that Iran continued to owe the agency substantial explanations.

title: Memorial Day Draws Two Messages on Iraq
description: LAS CRUCES, N.M.  Senator John McCain stood before hundreds of flag-waving veterans and their families on Monday and vowed not to waver in his support of the Iraq war. Even, he said, if I must stand athwart popular opinion.

title: Vancouver Museum Reopens After Theft
description: The University of British Columbias Museum of Anthropology, in Vancouver, reopened Monday following an incident on Saturday, when a dozen works by the Canadian artist Bill Reid were stolen, The Globe and Mail and The Calgary Herald reported. Since most of the works are sculptures made from gold, museum authorities and the artists widow, Martine  Reid died in 1998  expressed concern that the thieves would melt the figures in order to cash in on the precious metal. These pieces are Canadian treasures and belong to the Canadian people, Jim Storie, the chairman of the Bill Reid Trust, said in a statement. Theyre all priceless. Reid, who produced around 1,500 works, helped to popularize Canadian native art, and his work appears on the Canadian $20 bill.

title: De-emphasis on Race in Adoption Is Criticized
description: WASHINGTON  Minority children in foster care are being ill-served by a federal law that plays down race and culture in adoptions, a report released on Tuesday said.

title: At Yale, Another Honorific for Sir Paul
description: The former Beatle Paul McCartney, 65, was awarded an honorary doctor of music degree from Yale University at its commencement festivities Monday, The Associated Press reported. On Sunday the former British prime minister Tony Blair spoke at the universitys Class Day, advising students to be prepared to fail as well as to succeed, and realize it is failure, not success, that defines character, The Yale Daily News reported. Sir Paul McCartney reminded me that the first record company the Beatles approached rejected them as a band no one would want to listen to, Mr. Blair added, foreshadowing Mr. McCartneys honor. Other recipients of honorary degrees on Monday included the former United States trade representative Carla Hills, the astronomer Martin Rees, the architect Cesar Pelli and the poet John Ashbery.

title: Lottery Numbers
Treasures of a Nation, Not Fodder for an Ad
description: MEXICO CITY  Eager to bolster tourism, Hidalgo State came up with a novel idea: an advertising campaign featuring a well-known actress wearing Hidalgos most eye-popping sites on her flesh.

title: Big Brown Could Return to Training Regimen Today
description: Big Browns trainer, Rick Dutrow, and the hoof specialist Ian McKinlay are encouraged by the colts recovery from a slight quarter crack (or stress fracture) on the inside of his left front hoof, and they say they are not concerned that Big Brown could miss the Belmont Stakes on June 7.

title: Convicted Gambler Whose Lawyer Is His Son
description: Father and son shared little in common. There were no Little League games, no backpacking trips, no going to the movies together. The father, Raymond Marquez, was just too busy.

title: China Mobiles Shares Fall 8% in Hong Kong Trading
description: China Mobile, which counts more than two-thirds of the nations mobile phone users as customers, lost more than $26 billion in market value in Hong Kong trading on Monday after the government said it would merge smaller operators to increase competition. The shares fell 8.2 percent to close at 114.90 Hong Kong dollars ($14.93), the biggest drop in more than six years. Chinas two biggest fixed-line companies will also provide wireless services under the government plan announced Saturday, threatening China Mobiles dominance of a market with 583.5 million customers. The government wants to balance the telecom industry instead of having just one dominant player, said Teresa Chow, who helps manage $1.1 billion at RBC Investment Management Asia in Hong Kong, including China Mobile shares.

title: Justices Favor Workers in Cases of Bias Retaliation
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday adopted a broad reading of two federal civil rights laws to protect employees from retaliation when they complain about discrimination in the workplace.

title: Footnotes
description: Musical theater fans should take note: The original cast recordings of the Broadway production of A Catered Affair (PS Classics) and the current Lincoln Center revival of Rodgers & Hammersteins South Pacific (Sony Classics) are to be released Tuesday. ... Tuesday nights guests at Comic Book Club, the weekly talk show that takes place onstage at the Peoples Improv Theater in Chelsea at 8 p.m., will include the comedian Selena Coppock and the comic artist Joe Infurnari, creator of The Process (theprocesscomic.com). Tickets for the event are $5 each (popcultureshock.com/cbclub).

title: Lauder Steps Down as Whitney Museum Chairman
description: After 14 years in the post, Leonard A. Lauder stepped down on Tuesday as chairman of the board of trustees at the Whitney Museum of American Art. He remains a trustee and the chairman emeritus, with full voting rights.

title: The Trouble With June 1992 as a Case for Pressing On
description: WASHINGTON  When Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton told The Argus Leader of Sioux Falls, S.D., last week that efforts to push her out of the race before all the nominating contests were over was unprecedented, she offered a few historical references to support her argument.

title: Verizon and the City: Digital Package (and Delays) Appear to Be Near
description: Michael and Susan Slutsky, who live with their two daughters in Tarrytown, N.Y., canceled Cablevision about two years ago when Verizon, which already provided their phone line, entered the television market in town. Last year, when their contract with AT&T for four cellphones expired, the Slutskys switched to Verizon Wireless, too, getting 10 percent off the monthly bill.

title: Trying Again on a Coast That Defies Big Dreams
description: PACIFIC BEACH, Wash.  Big Bold Dream No. 1 arrived on the cloudy coast of Washington State in 1905. It was called the Moclips Beach Hotel, 270 grand rooms at its peak, with a railroad depot and waves crashing beyond the veranda. Then the ocean washed it all away.

title: Prevention: Breast-Feeding Protects Against Arthritis
description: A Swedish study suggests yet another health advantage of breast-feeding, this time for the mother: it reduces the risk of rheumatoid arthritis.

title: A Mind Geared to Physics, a Profile Set for Prime Time
description: Its tempting to applaud Joo Magueijos Big Bang, a special on the Science Channel on Tuesday night, simply for existing. How often is an hour of prime-time television devoted to making the case for a radical but legitimate theory of cosmology?

title: Roads, High and Low
description: On Friday morning, Joe Biden gave us an example of a leading national politician exhibiting decency and class. Later in the day, Hillary Clinton gave us an example of something else.

title: At Worlds End, Honing a Father-Son Dynamic
description: ERIE, Pa.  Cormac McCarthys Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, The Road, takes place in a world that, because of some unexplained catastrophe, has just about ended. The sky is gray, the rivers are black, and color is just a memory. The landscape is covered in ash, with soot falling perpetually from the air. The cities are blasted and abandoned. The roads are littered with corpses either charred or melted, their dreams, Mr. McCarthy writes, ensepulchred within their crozzled hearts.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on Wednesday about cutbacks in airline service to American cities erroneously included a city among those where scheduled service disappeared in the last year. New Haven, Conn., does indeed have regularly scheduled service. (US Airways has flights at Tweed New Haven Regional Airport.) The article also described incorrectly Myrtle Beach DirectAirs thrice-weekly service at Plattsburgh, N.Y. The airline offers service to South Carolina, not North Carolina.

title: The Bullpens Ineffectiveness Costs the Yankees and Rasner
description: BALTIMORE  In Darrell Rasners 21 major league games, few players have rattled him as thoroughly as the Baltimore Orioles Nick Markakis. Rasner had faced him only eight times before Mondays game, but on seven of those occasions, Markakis wound up with a base hit.

title: Scientists Document Bustling Community Far Below Ocean Floor
description: The lost civilization of Atlantis may just be legend, but way down below the ocean (to quote the folksinger Donovan) there are some things that are very real  namely, bacteria and archaea. By some estimates, sub-seafloor prokaryotes may account for two-thirds of the biomass of these types of organisms on Earth.

description: Front Page

title: Mars Lander Transmits Photos of Arctic Terrain
description: PASADENA, Calif.  The first pictures sent back by NASAs Phoenix Mars lander from the northern arctic plains of Mars show a flat terrain marked by a polygonal pattern of shallow troughs and a few pebbles scattered about.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on Saturday about Cindy McCains release of a summary of her 2006 income taxes misstated the greatest amount of income Senator Barack Obama and his wife, Michelle, reported in the seven years of tax returns they have released. It was $4.2 million in 2007, not $1.7 million in 2005.

description: In the last year, Barack Obama has learned a thing or two about running for president, and Reggie Love has learned a thing or two about Barack Obama.

title: Sydney Pollack, Director of High-Profile Hollywood Movies, Is Dead at 73
description: LOS ANGELES  Sydney Pollack, a Hollywood mainstay as director, producer and sometime actor whose star-laden movies like The Way We Were, Tootsie and Out of Africa were among the most successful of the 1970s and 80s, died Monday at home here. He was 73.

title: Mating Midges
description: Q. In May, near the Jerome Park Reservoir in the Bronx, my sister and I observed individual flies that sometimes clumped together in large swarms, which seemed to be attracted to people and animals passing by. The swarms then dissipated briefly, only to re-form. What kind of fly acts this way? Why are they swarming?
