description: THE FACTS

title: UBS Foresees More Subprime-Related Losses
description: UBS, the European bank hardest hit by the collapse of the subprime housing market in the United States, fell the most in more than two months in Swiss trading on Monday after it said it may face more losses from mortgage securities. UBS declined 5.8 percent to 28.20 francs in Zurich, and has dropped 43 percent this year, cutting its market value to 61.4 billion francs ($59.9 billion). UBS, in a prospectus for a 16 billion-franc rights offer to shareholders, said the banks losses on residential and commercial real-estate securities outside the United States could increase in the future. UBS is seeking to replenish capital after about $38 billion in write-downs related to the subprime crisis.

title: Thirty-Five Years of Rockefeller Justice
description: Enacted in 1973, New Yorks Rockefeller drug laws penalized some first-time drug offenders more severely than murderers. Named for Nelson Rockefeller, who was governor at the time, the laws tied the hands of judges and mandated lengthy sentences for young offenders who often deserved a second chance. The laws, which were supposed to ensnare kingpins, have filled the prisons with drug addicts who would have been better dealt with through treatment programs. They also undermined faith in the fairness of the justice system by singling out poor and minority offenders while exempting wealthy ones.

title: Taiwan: More Talks With Beijing
description: Wu Poh-Hsiung, the chairman of Taiwans Nationalist Party, began a six-day visit to the Chinese mainland intended to lay the groundwork for detailed talks on more charter flights across the Taiwan Strait and more mainland tourists on Taiwan.

title: Amid Tremors, a City Trembles With Dread
description: CHENGDU, China  The teahouses are nearly empty, travel agents sit beside silent telephones and shopkeepers pass the day watching the continuing agony of their countrymen on television. The buildings in this usually teeming city of 10 million, about 50 miles east of the epicenter of the May 12 earthquake, may be unscathed, but its residents are living on edge.

title: Rules for Reservoirs Pose Threat to Trout Population
description: HANCOCK, N.Y.  The West Branch of the Delaware River, when in good shape, is one of the great trout streams of North America. Like the more renowned Missouri and Henrys Fork of Montana and Idaho, it is a tailwater fishery; that is, it owes its remarkable fecundity and its population of big wild trout to the cold-water outflow of reservoir impoundment.

title: More Travelers, Costlier Oil and More Commotion
description: THE airlines are running out of ways to squeeze money out of passengers, now that they have jacked up fares all year and slapped extra charges on checked bags.

title: Hezbollah Leader Plays Down Groups Political Aims in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Hezbollahs leader sought to reassure the Lebanese about the Shiite militant groups intentions in a speech on Monday, saying that its newly expanded political clout will not translate into greater control over the state, and that its top priority remains the fight against Israel.

title: Myanmar Detention Overshadowed
description: BANGKOK  Almost lost in the clamor over Myanmars devastating cyclone, the house arrest of the charismatic pro-democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, reaches a deadline for its annual renewal on Tuesday.

title: 2 Colleges End Entrance Exam Requirement
description: Smith College, a womens college in Northampton, Mass., and Wake Forest University in Winston-Salem, N.C., will no longer require prospective students to submit SAT or ACT scores as part of their applications.

title: Zimbabwe: Mugabe Threatens to Expel U.S. Envoy
description: President Robert Mugabe threatened to expel the American ambassador, William McGee, who has been outspoken about state-sponsored violence against the opposition party. Mr. Mugabe accused Mr. McGee of meddling in the countrys internal affairs and said, Tall as he is, if he continues doing that, I will kick him out, according to the state-run newspaper, The Herald. On Sunday, eight men carrying AK-47s intercepted a delivery of 60,000 copies of The Zimbabwean, a newspaper that opposes the president, and burned the newspapers, The Zimbabwean reported on its Web site.

title: Emily Gould Responds to Readers
description: The author responds to readers' questions and comments on blogging about your private life. (Go to Original Article)

title: At Center, BMXers Are Part of Team
description: CHULA VISTA, Calif.  Mike King started racing BMX bikes in 1975, 30 years before anyone envisioned the sports becoming part of the Olympics.

title: Patterns: Vomiting Raises Risk of Irregular Periods
description: Teenage girls who vomit one to three times a month to control weight increase their risk of having irregular menstrual periods by 60 percent, a new study reports; those who vomit once a week or more triple their risk. When researchers restricted the analysis only to girls of normal weight, the association was even stronger.

title: Contractors Are Kept Busy Maintaining Abandoned Homes
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  The house on East 24th Street was the worst of the six that David Law and Trey McCallister worked on the other day here. The front door had been kicked in so many times that the dead bolt was exposed and bent. Trash littered the front and back yards. A copper pipe was gone.

title: Lure of Olympics Prompts Return of a BMX Star
description: CHULA VISTA, Calif.  When Jill Kintner left BMX racing six years ago, she never planned to come back. She finished the 2002 season with typical dominance, adding a national pro title and a world championship to a racing rsum filled with more than 70 career wins.

title: Red Flags for Hereditary Cancers
description: All cancers are genetic in origin. When genes are working properly, cell growth is tightly regulated, as if a stoplight told cells to divide only so many times and no more. A cancer occurs when something causes a mutation in the genes that limit cell growth or that repair DNA damage.

title: Republican Senate Candidates in New Jersey Want You to Know Their Names
description: TRENTON  Depending on whom you ask, this is a story about Maverick Murray, Jersey Joe and the Liberal Loser Lobbyist. Others regard it simply as the Republican primary to choose a candidate for the United States Senate in New Jersey.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on Saturday about Michel Fournier, the retired French army officer with plans to sky dive from a balloon gondola 25 miles above the earths surface, misstated the point during his journey at which he expects to experience weightlessness, and it misstated the altitude at which his parachute was designed to open. He would experience weightlessness during descent, not while in the balloons gondola. And his parachute is designed to open at around 5,000 feet, not 20,000 feet.

title: His Life With the Deaths That the State Carried Out

title: Some Pitfalls of Genetic Testing
description: The deciphering of the human genome has prompted a number of entrepreneurs to cash in on peoples genetic concerns. They offer DNA testing to look for aberrant genes associated with the risk of developing various diseases, especially cancer.

title: One-Child Policy Lifted for Quake Victims Parents
description: CHENGDU, China  In response to inquiries from grieving relatives, local officials announced Monday that parents whose only child was killed or grievously injured in the May 12 earthquake would be exempt from the countrys one-child policy.

description: Eight people were shot and wounded late Monday night in Harlem, the police said. Most of the victims were found along a stretch of Lenox Avenue north of 125th Street.

title: More Surgery Is Planned for Paterson, Official Says
description: After a painful eye ailment sent him to the hospital last week and led to two operations, Gov. David A. Paterson plans to have additional surgery this summer to remove a cataract from his left eye, his office said on Monday.

title: S.E.C. Backs Health Care Balloting
description: WASHINGTON  The Securities and Exchange Commission, shifting its position, has told companies they must allow shareholders to vote on a proposal for universal health insurance coverage.

title: U. Utah Phillips, Folk Troubadour, Dies at 73
description: Bruce Duncan Phillips, the itinerant folk singer, songwriter, storyteller and social activist who jokingly called himself U. Utah Phillips, the Golden Voice of the Great Southwest, died on Friday at his home in Nevada City, Calif. He was 73.

title: Time Ebbs for the Heroes Who Saved the Harbor
description: His best day? For Seymour Wittek, it was the day he met the girl he would marry. There have been other significant days over his 87 years  when children were born and new jobs were begun, when grandchildren came along. One October day last year, death claimed Anne Wittek, his wife of 64 years. That was a most important day.

title: Choreographers Intensely Personal and Absolutely Not
description: As titles of dance programs go, Male Bonding is pretty catchy. But this two-part event presented by the La MaMa Moves! festival had little to do with any affinities between the impressive lineup of choreographers taking part. Instead it showed a rich variety of intention and approach, from technically sophisticated to almost dance-free, intensely personal to determinedly neutral.

description: Grupo Financiero Inbursa, the bank controlled by billionaire Carlos Slim, rose to a record in Mexico City trading after Spains largest savings bank said it would buy a stake to jointly move into other Latin American countries.

description: Nigeria signed a $3.1 billion deal with the local arm of Royal Dutch Shell on Monday to plug a funding gap in their joint venture projects, the countrys state oil firm NNPC said.

title: S.E.C. Backs Health Care Balloting
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, shifting its position, has told companies they must allow shareholders to vote on a proposal for universal health insurance coverage.

title: Infineon Chief Resigns Over Disagreement With Board
description: Infineon Technologies, one of the largest semiconductor makers in Europe, said Monday that its chief executive, Wolfgang Ziebart, had resigned after almost four years in the role because of a disagreement with the board.

title: Web Sites Before the Internet
description: Cracked.com asked its readers to imagine what the Web might look like if it were around in pre-Internet times. Here are a few of the pages they came up with (more here, but discretion advised):

title: MTNs Iran Ties Could Complicate Financing
description: Having broken off talks with one suitor and quickly found another, the South African mobile phone operator MTN Group could still face obstacles to any deal from an unlikely corner: U.S. regulators, who prevent American companies from facilitating business in Iran, one of MTNs fastest growing markets.

title: Kleiner Said Dole Out iFund Cash to Pelago
description: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is reportedly leading a $15 million round for Pelago, the first company to tap iFund, the $100 million cash pool Apple launched in partnership with the V.C. firm to fund iPhone applications.

title: Linens n Things May Shutter More Stores, Report Says
description: Apollo Managements bankrupt retailer Linens n Things may close additional stores beyond the 20 percent of its chain that it has already pledged to shutter, The New York Post reported.

title: I.P.O. Market Sputters Along
description: After a modest uptick following Visas stock debut in March, the market for initial public offerings is back in the doldrums.

title: Kerkorian Borrows Another $100 Million for Ford Investment
description: Billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian has added $100 million in financing as part of his bid to increase his stake in the Ford Motor Company.

title: Quickoffice Scores $3 Million
description: Quickoffice, a company that makes mobile office document software for smart phones, has raised $3 million to help it expands at a time when users are expected to start using their phones for more tasks.

title: Wall Street Exodus: Fear, Panic and Anger
description: Since August, banks worldwide have announced plans to eliminate as many as 65,000 jobs. Many losing their jobs now have lived through other crises on Wall Street  the 1987 market crash, the widespread layoffs of the early 1990s and the financial upheaval of 1998.

title: MTN in New Deal Talks, Again in India
description: The MTN Group, a small mobile operator in South Africa, attracted an investment in 1995 from SBC, an American telecommunications company. Now MTN is a sprawling company that spans 21 countries with 70 million customers, and it is attracting outside investors again.

title: Rags to Riches, One Year Later
description: As Casino Drive prepares for this years Belmont Stakes, it seems like a good time for an update on his half sister, Rags to Riches, the 2007 Belmont winner.

title: Deutsche Bahn Said to Tap 4 Banks for I.P.O.
description: Four investment banks were reportedly given the mandate for one of the years biggest flotation: the 8 billion euro initial public offering of Deutsche Bahn, Europes biggest rail and logistics group.

title: Blackstone and Apollo Said to Weigh Chemical Buyout
description: The Blackstone Group and Apollo Management, the private equity groups, are reportedly in talks to buy Chemtura, a manufacturer and marketer of specialty chemicals, in what would be one of the bigger U.S. buyouts this year.

title: Borders Book Chain Turns a Page on the Web
description: The Web site for the preservation of the Borders Group, the countrys second-largest book chain, goes live today at www.borders.com.

title: The Early Word: A Week to Go
description: Let the countdown begin. With just a week between now and the final primaries in South Dakota and Montana on June 3 and a few days until Puerto Rico holds its contest, the Democratic nominating fight may be coming to an end.

title: Battle Between TCI and J-Power Heats Up
description: The acrimonious battle between J-Power, one of Japans biggest energy producers, and The Childrens Investment Fund has escalated after J-Power published an open letter to shareholders.

title: Court to Fast-Track BCE Buyout Appeal
description: BCE won its request for an expedited process as the Supreme Court of Canada considers whether or not it will hear an appeal of a lower court ruling that threatened the phone companys buyout deal. The court suggested on Monday it may hear an appeal in three weeks.

title: CSXs Hedge-Fund Struggle Puts Swaps in Focus
description: A looming decision in a heated lawsuit brought by railroad giant CSX could shut down a loophole used by activist hedge funds to hide their stake from the market, The New York Post reported.

title: Designing for Resilience in Seismic Hot Zones
description: An important theme of Dot Earth is limiting losses from inevitable disasters  what I call hard knocks. As the human population heads toward 9 billion, more or less, with most of the growth coming in struggling places, unless more is done to boost resilience to known hazards  earthquakes included  there will be ever more wrenching imagery like that out of China (and Myanmar, as well).

title: Rockefellers Seek Change at ExxonMobil
description: The Rockefeller family built one of the great American fortunes by supplying the nation with oil. Now history has come full circle: some family members say it is time to start moving beyond the oil age.

title: Renters Forced Out of Stuyvesant Town
description: More than a year after buying Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village in Manhattan for a record-breaking $5.4 billion, Tishman Speyer Properties has accused hundreds of rent-stabilized tenants of living somewhere other than their apartments, The Times reports. Residents and their lawyers say that tactic is part of an aggressive attempt to drive out tenants paying lower rents to turn their units into market rate rentals.

title: Volvo, Biofuels, and Sewage in Sweden
description: The race is on to commercialize eco-friendly transport fuels that avoid deforestation and higher food prices. The Swedes have been working with one such solution for years: Sludge from city sewage systems.

title: The Deals Bear Stearns Didnt Do
description: Bear Stearns tried at least six times to raise billions of dollars in the months before its dramatic collapse  and considered selling a stake to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts  but the efforts fizzled each time, according to an article in The Wall Street Journal that recounts the firms missed opportunities in that fateful period. Those opportunities, the article said, might have been able to save the 85-year-old brokerage.

title: Ask About Fighting Poverty in New York
description: This week, David R. Jones, the president of the Community Service Society of New York, will be answering questions about how New York City and its residents can fight poverty, and how to help low-wage, working Americans who are increasingly marginalized by the global economy.

title: Recipe of the Day: Roast Salmon With Spicy Soy Oil
description: If you can get wild salmon  and it is the season  its flavor is almost always better than that of farmed.

title: Axcelis and the Future of Majority Voting
description: The Friday before Memorial Day is a good day for a company to disclose information that it would otherwise prefer to keep quiet. Most of the press and the investment community is already physically  if not mentally  out of town. So, by the time the markets re-open Tuesday, the news is already stale and apt to be lost in the mix.

title: Readers Respond: Help With a 50th Wedding Anniversary
description: The following is a very detailed question from Linda Plaut of Golden, Colo. Shes looking for a great location for a wedding anniversary that fulfills a long list of criteria. Based on your own trips and travel experiences, do you have any advice that helps meet this tall order? We put this question to you, readers.

title: Cannes, Monaco, Yeah-yeah
description: After finishing the piece about Pat Capolupo of Pat & Rose last week, I went to Monaco to see the Grand Prixhence my recent silence. Pats last word to me as I left the factory was Ferrari. I laughed. Pat likes to keep things simple: pick a great name. On the plane to Nice I saw Tory Burch, who was going to visit some friends near Monaco, though probably wasnt going to stay for the Grand Prix. Later, the next day, the sun shining as its meant to, we got together for lunch on the beach at Cap dAil. She introduced me to her friends, who invited me to a cocktail party at their home that night, where I met some more people who I would see throughout the weekend at various places. Monaco, I guess, is like that during the GP.

title: Big Brown Returns to the Track
description: The hoof specialist Ian McKinlay was giddy Monday night about how quickly Big Brown was healing from a quarter crack, or stress fracture, in his left front hoof. He basically declared him cured, and predicted he would be on the track this morning.

title: New Teen Health Worry: Energy in a Can
description: With names like Rock Star, Full Throttle and Monster, its no wonder new super-caffeinated energy drinks appeal to teens.

title: Fire Willie Chants at Shea Stadium
description: The first boisterous fan tried to start a Fire Willie chant in the eighth inning on Monday night. It did not last long; 20 seconds, at the most. The fan couldnt find any vocal allies in his call for Willie Randolph, the Mets manager, to lose his job.

title: NBC Prepares Horror Anthology Series
description: NBC is premiering a new horror anthology series, Fear Itself, on June 5 at 10 p.m. The Associated Press reports:

title: Braves Hope the Road Leads to the Playoffs
description: Between the surprise start by the Florida Marlins and the stunning struggles of the Mets, the Atlanta Braves carved out a spot for themselves in second place in the National League East, tied with the Philadelphia Phillies at two and a half games back. But this is all about to change, according to the Atlanta Journal-Constitutions Mark Bradley.

title: Not Digging It
description: Indiana Jones and the Ivory Tower: The newest Indiana Jones movie has raked in more than $150 million already, but not all archaeologists like to dream about themselves in a whip-and-fedora ensemble. Neil Asher Silberman, the former director of the Ename Center for Public Archaeology and Heritage Presentation in Belgium, explains in The Washington Post why he dislikes the worlds most famous fictional archaeologist. He writes:

title: Inquiry Finds Port Security Lacking
description: The attacks of Sept. 11 transformed ports of entry into points of anxiety, but the job itself didnt get any easier  just as illegal drugs slipped through loopholes, so did potential security threats. While no attacks have originated at the ports, reminders that they are vulnerable are frequent  from the Sept. 11 Commissions final report to the uproar over a proposal to allow a Dubai company manage some operations at U.S. ports.

title: Renewable Energy Appeal Is Newest Twist on Old E-Mail Scheme
description: It was only a matter of time before those e-mail scammers purporting to be Nigerian oil ministers who need your financial help to embezzle cash switched to a more green appeal: renewable energy.

title: End to Soccer Apartheid
description: A day after FIFA decided to boot last years darlings of international soccer, the world soccer governing body announced a more welcome decision, lifting a confrontational ban on international matches played at high altitude.

description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: McCain Calls for a Harder Line on North Korea
description: DENVERSenator John McCain kept up his attacks on Senator Barack Obama on Tuesday as nave in foreign policy and appeared critical of the Bush administrations diplomatic engagement in North Korea. Both positions were precursors of a speech on nuclear security policy that Mr. McCain gave today at the University of Denver.

title: A Freemason Returns to the Albany Helm
description: Here is a little-known fact about New Yorks accidental governor, David A. Paterson: He is the first Freemason to hold that office in more than 60 years. He joined the fraternal order in 2002, his office confirmed. In fact, he is actually the 20th New York governor to be a member, according to the Grand Lodge of New York (which is still on a public-relations binge to demystify itself).Having governors on the membership rolls hasnt necessarily helped the Freemasons fend off the conspiracy theories swirling around them, ranging from possession of the Holy Grail, the founding of Atlantis and the hiding of secret symbols in Washington architecture and United States currency.

title: Super Sunday: Monaco Grand Prix and the Indianapolis 500
description: Once again, there was considerable heartbreak for some very well known names (and some not so well known) at the Monaco Grand Prix and the Indy 500 (both held on Sunday). Lets go in chronological order:

title: Previews of a Potential Cable Deal
description: Now that Time Warner Cable is to be spun off from parent company Time Warner, questions have emerged about what it will do with its newfound freedom. Richard Greenfield, an analyst at Pali Research, said in a report Tuesday that he thinks it may move to swallow a smaller rival.

title: Mexican Navy vs. Sharks
description: BRIEFS Weve seen navies take on pirates and green pirates take on whale hunters. But a navy hunting sharks? Thats a new one. After a series of rare attacks that left two swimmers dead, the Mexican Navy is searching for the feared beast by helicopter, boat and binoculars.

title: Memorial Day in Mosul
description: Updated MOSUL  The closest thing to a Memorial Day barbecue for soldiers at Combat Outpost Rabiy came when one of their Bradley fighting vehicles, rumbling along a rubble-strewn street in Mosul, hit a sheep.

title: Retired Thoroughbreds: Athletes for All Occasions
description: As people are becoming more aware of the fate of racehorses after they finish running, it is important to highlight those horses that have successfuly transitioned from the racetrack to a second career. To show that our stars have other options. And as more people become aware of the qualities thoroughbreds can bring to other equestrian disciplines, we can expand the adopter pool for Off Track Thoroughbreds (OTTBs) and increase the numbers that can then avoid the miserable fate of horse slaughter.

title: Rockefellers Take on ExxonMobil
description: CNBC's Larry Kudlow discusses the Rockefellers' call for ExxonMobil to move into alternative energy with a panel of analysts and reporters.

title: Another World
description: Peter Cooper is building a 16,000-square-foot family house on four acres in New Zealand.

title: Inside the Candy Factory
description: Late Friday, Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company filed the preliminary proxy statement for its shareholders to approve Wrigleys acquisition by Mars. The heart of this document is the background to the transaction section  the companys disclosure, mandated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, of the events leading up to Wrigleys agreement to be bought for about $23 billion.

description: ABC, CBS and NBC have agreed to set aside the same hour of prime-time television on the first Friday night in September for a live, joint telethon benefiting cancer research, Jacques Steinberg reports.

title: A Busy Period for Chess
description: As the weather has warmed, tournament and match activity has picked up. Last week, began with Vladimir Kramnik of Russia, ranked No. 2 in the world, winning the CEZ Chess Trophy, a rapid-play match in the Czech Republic against David Navarra, that countrys top-ranked player (No. 50 over all). Kramnik got off to a blistering start with 3.5 out of 4 points; the final score was 5.5-2.5.

title: All Summer Long
description: I have a problem. These days Im in school most of the year, which means my own reading list takes a back seat to whatevers on the syllabus. As the fall, winter and spring wear on, I collect books the way a chipmunk does seeds and nuts for the winter. This has made for a daunting pile  and kept me feeling woefully behind.

title: Culinary Tourism in Iowa?
description: Thats what the Iowa Arts Council is pushing and, while I am not jumping into the jalopy or logging on to book a ticket, I do find this little presentation  a convincing bundle of evidence that wonderful eating is possible wherever there is good land and decent weather. (Hat tip to Mike at www.notionscapital.com.)

description: Is this what the Stanley Cup final has come to, these words from Pittsburgh Post-Gazette columnist Gene Collier?

title: Whats Next for Securitization?
description: The word securitization has taken on a sinister tone since the subprime mortgage debacle poked holes in the balance sheets of some of the worlds biggest banks. But this kind of Wall Street alchemy isnt going away, an article from the Investment Dealers Digest suggests.

title: Fillies in France
description: Sometimes taking on the guys is easier than tangling with one tough broad. Thats the reasoning behind the trainer Pascal Barys decision to run his top filly, Natagora, in the French Derby at Chantilly on Sunday rather than in the Oaks a week later.

title: Ask the Locals, Yes, but Which Ones?
description: You know youre onto something when even Brooklynites extend a compassionate hand to their mainland rivals in the Bronx. Yet that is what happened after my City Room post in mid-May about hotels, tourism and the Bronx. Boosters of both boroughs know they are often seen as provincial outposts that could never rival the imperial majesty of Manhattan Island.

title: Obama and the White Working Class
description: John Harwood of The Times and CNBC analyzes Barack Obama's standing with a constituency that is the core issue in the Democratic endgame.

title: Free 41-day Visit to the North Pole in 44 Seconds
description: You can experience 41 days of conditions around the North Pole in 44 seconds, thanks to the web cams left behind by an international research team (funded by the National Science Foundation) that annually ventures northward to install and retrieve instruments on and under the drifting sea ice at the top of the world. The view is not as extreme, perhaps, as that provided by the Phoenix lander on Mars, but its pretty neat, nonetheless.

title: Gas Prices Rise, Buses Crowd
description: BRIEFS Last month, our sibling blog Freakonomics asked Will Drivers Learn to Stop Worrying and Love the Bus? The answer just arrived from North Carolina: The surge in gas prices this spring  a 65-cent rise in two months to a record average of $3.92 per gallon for regular on Monday  has driven Triangle commuters in unprecedented numbers to park their cars and board the buses. [The News & Observer]

title: That Beijing Air; those Olympic Women
description: After my Sunday column about Chinas pollution problem, a belated peg: Beijing declared an air emergency today in part because of dust storms rolling in from Mongolia. The authorities told people with respiratory problems to stay inside. Thats from a new Olympics blog, Rings, that the Times has started.

title: The Headwinds of War
description: This isnt the blogging equivalent of Walter Cronkite saying that Vietnam was an unwinnable war, but its close. Byron York, the White House correspondent for National Review, calls the Iraq war a mistake in a post at The Corner, National Reviews staff blog.

title: M.B.As Still Love Google and Goldman
description: Business school graduates are getting ready to hit the work force  if they are lucky  and it seems that nearly a quarter of them want to work for Google.

title: A Bearish Outlook for Lehman
description: CNBC's David Faber reviews a negative report by Bank of America about Lehman Brothers, whose stock has been battered by pessimists.

title: Questioning the Wisdom of Crowds
description: Sometimes Crowds Arent That Wise, wrote a smart blogger on the shortcomings of Digg, the news hub run by the masses. Inevitably, Digg linked to the story, packaging it with a warning that this story contains information that may not be accurate. The particular inaccuracies were not immediately apparent, but another Digg user was hardly surprised by the overall point: Was this article written by Captain Obvious?

title: Liberty Pulls Back from Vongo Internet Movie Service
description: UPDATED | 5/27 4:45 PM Mr. Southwick writes to say he speaks for Starz, not Liberty Media, its owner.

title: An Officer and a Beekeeper
description: When they join the Police Department, new officers tell their employer about their other life skills and interests. Anthony Planakis, who joined in 1994, listed masonry and cement work. And beekeeping. So it was that about 4:30 p.m. on Monday, Officer Planakis, the son of a beekeeper who now works in the polices Building Maintenance Department, got a call asking whether he could help contain a swarm of bees that had attached itself to the side of an apartment building in the Bronx. He grabbed his gear, and hopped into his car.

title: Another Bearish Call on Lehman
description: Lehman Brothers stock has taken it on the nose over the past week, falling more than 14 percent after a new wave of criticism struck the securities firm.

title: Cheevers the M.V.P. on Indy TV
description: The currently popular definition of a Most Valuable Player is someone who makes the teammates around him better. If true, give Eddie Cheever Jr. the M.V.P. trophy for Sundays Indianapolis 500 telecast on ABC.

title: O.K., Ban Racing  But Then What?
description: Depending on which recent poll you believe, anywhere from 10 to 38 percent of Americans support a ban on horse racing. Debate lingers over how much the emotionally charged aftermath of the death of Eight Belles in the Kentucky Derby swayed public opinion on this matter. But for the sake of argument, lets grant the extremists their wish, in theory. What would happen if thoroughbred racing  as of this instant  suddenly became illegal in the United States?

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Tuesday, May 27:

title: Investors Criticize Socit Gnrale Chief for Losses
description: They had been saving their anger ever since the trading scandal at the French bank Socit Gnrale broke in January. On Tuesday, shareholders were given their first chance to challenge management on a loss of 4.9 billion euros or $7.1 billion  and there was no more holding back.

title: Protests Planned for Rules Committee Meeting
description: The Democratic National Committee is bracing itself for protests outside its Rules and Bylaws Committee meeting on Saturday in Washington, where the fates of the Florida and Michigan primaries could finally be decided.

title: Cool Avocado Soup With Shrimp
description: Mark Bittman makes a summertime soup so easy it required no talking at all.

title: Pignapped
description: What does a comic novelist do when hes shortlisted for an award (the Bollinger Everyman Wodehouse Prize), only to conclude that the contest was rigged and the winner predetermined? Why, steal the prize and hold it ransom, of course.

title: Stories The Times Missed
description: Totally dropped the ball on these. Sorry. From a compilation of favorite Weekly World News covers found here:

description: School budgets have not made for an easy time for Chancellor Joel I. Klein these days.

description: Mark Bittman makes a recipe he picked up at La Zucca Magica, a vegetarian restaurant in Nice, France.

title: Artichokes Provencal
description: Mark Bittman demonstrates a recipe he invented to show off miniature artichokes.

title: Obama Eyes Western States
description: LAS VEGAS  Senator Barack Obama arrived at a small home here today on Isabelle Avenue  with the skyline of the Las Vegas Strip far in the distance  as he continued a three-day swing of Western states that he believes could be pivotal battlegrounds in the fall.

title: Jeter Envy
description: The synonym, presumably, would be to favrerate: Joe Posnanski is a sports columnist for The Kansas City Star who, in his spare time, produces one of the finest blogs on The Series of Tubes. In a post over the weekend, Posnanski coined the word Jeterate, a verb meaning to praise someone for something of which he or she is entirely unworthy of praise in the course of a post explaining why fans of Derek Jeter, the Yankees shortstop, drive him batty.

title: How to Celebrate a Championship
description: Its far too soon to anoint the Red Wings presumptive Stanley Cup champions, although if the Penguins continue to score goals at the rate theyve been scoring them lately, well have no choice. Actually, though, this post applies to Detroit and Pittsburgh equally, because it involves  Zurich.

title: Willie Randolph, Blowing in the Wind
description: Maybe thats not exactly how the Bob Dylan tune goes, but it is appropriate for the Mets manager. Randolph is still the manager today. Tomorrow, too. But if the Mets keep losing, how much longer will he be commuting to Shea?

title: Feeling For  Malcolm McLaren
description: Malcolm McLaren, 1980 (Stuart Nicol/Evening Standard/Getty Images).

title: The Finer Points of Catching, at Age 6
description: I have a feeling Dante Girardi, even at 6 years old, knows hes getting a special kind of baseball instruction. On the field at Camden Yards, while his dad chatted with Orioles Manager Dave Trembley, Dante was getting pointers from Tony Pena.

title: Wireless Broadband Bolsters Economy
description: Wireless technology will continue to have a huge impact on the economy as it becomes easier for businesses and their employees to access the Internet on their cell phones and other wireless devices, according to a study to be released Wednesday by the CTIA, a trade group for the wireless industry.

title: Spray-Painting Brighter (and More Lawful) Swashes of Graffiti
description: A love of graffiti has gained Steve Powers notoriety as an outlaw artist, plus a Fulbright scholarship.

title: A Tailor Who Caters to a Certain Taste
description: Memorial Day has come and gone and summer stretches out languidly before him; now is the time that a certain kind of Northeastern dandy, when in polite company, may safely revel in a certain kind of highly coded casual wear.So I stopped by the fifth-floor atelier of Paul Winston, the proprietor of Winston Tailors (a k a Chipp 2). Chipp, which is what most people still call it, is a family-owned business at 11 East 44th Street. It has occupied various locations near this same spot in Midtown, between Fifth Avenue and Madison Avenue, since it was started by Mr. Winstons father, Sidney, in 1945.

title: Nascar Wins Ratings
description: Ratings were low all around for prime-time television over the Memorial Day holiday as repeats on CBS ranked first on Monday and Nascar coverage lifted Fox to No.1 on Sunday.

title: Pens Find Turnabout Is Fair Play
description: How odd near the end of a playoff run where nearly all their previous opponents were reduced to whining about the officiating and accusing the Penguins of diving that the Penguins have resorted to just that after falling behind 2-0 to Detroit in the Stanley Cup final.

title: Working Toward Safer Bombs: 2 Tracks
description: It rained in Dublin today, and at least one person was happy about that. Marc Garlasco, a senior military analyst at Human Rights Watch, has been trying to move nations closer to an international ban on cluster munitions  arms that critics blame for preventable civilian casualties.

title: McCain on Nuclear Disarmament
description: In a speech at the University of Denver in which he was interrupted by hecklers, Senator John McCain vowed to work with Russia on arms.

title: Pasta With Soft-Shell Crabs
description: Mark Bittman demonstrates how to cook pasta with soft-shell crabs.

title: Edamame Salad
description: Mark Bittman turns a familiar Japanese appetizer into something new.

title: Smoke Clears. Dust Does Not.
description: These pre-Olympic mornings, when the air is thick with the scent of jasmine and roses, I gaze out the window of my high-rise apartment in northwest Beijing and see, alas, not much. Thats because the air is also thick with oxides of many colors and complex carbon chains yet unclassified.

title: Live From New York . . . Its the World Science Festival!
description: The World Science Festival opens this week in New York. When I first heard about this new event, I was a bit surprised, because Id never thought of New York as even the national science center, let alone the world hub. In 1994, when the Times Magazine put out a special issue asking, Whats New York the Capital of Now? I wrote the introductory essay and came up with about two dozen answers ranging alphabetically from advertising and art to restaurants and theater. It never occurred to me to put science on the list.

title: Will Lieberman Skip Hagee Event?
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut is scheduled to appear as the featured speaker at a July conference in Washington for a group run by the Rev. John C. Hagee, the televangelist whose controversial statements led Senator John McCain to disavow Mr. Hagees endorsement of his presidential campaign.

title: Gravel Exits, Stage Left
description: As Bob Barr, a former Republican, reignited his political career by taking the Libertarian presidential nomination at the partys convention in Denver on Sunday, the political career of Mike Gravel came to a close. It was the former Democrats second loss of a partys presidential nomination in a single year.

title: Campaign Mementos
description: In 1952, Adlai Stevenson ran for president on the Democratic ticket against Republican Dwight D. Eisenhower and was labeled egg-head for being an intellectual. But worse, he was saddled with the ignominious distinction of being too frugal. During a campaign stop, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photograph by William M. Gallagher of The Flint Journal revealed a hole in the sole of Governor Stevensons right shoe, and this quickly became a trademark. The shoe was made into metallic lapel pins, proudly worn by supporters in both the 52 and 56 elections.

title: Obamas Staff Corrects WWII Story
description: LAS VEGAS  The family tree of Senator Barack Obama has been the subject of much discussion  and inspection  since he arrived on the national political stage four years ago.

title: Home Prices Rise (Somewhere)
description: The economic numbers today were dreadful. Consumer confidence is down, again. New home sales are still horrid. And the S.&P./Case-Shiller indexes show home prices falling further.

title: Blog Roll: Superfecta
description: On the day we launched The Rail, I said it was part of our mission to reflect the eclectic mix of folks who are passionate about horse racing. We have also tried to be as democratic as the game itself by offering a platform to a wide variety of voices.

title: Why Walter Bender Left One Laptop Per Child
description: When Microsoft joined the One Laptop Per Child project earlier this month, I wrote an article noting the change in heart by both sides. The O.L.P.C. project, intended to bring cheap computers to children in poorer nations, had been committed to using the freely distributed Linux operating system, an open-source alternative to Microsofts Windows. And Microsoft had resisted joining anything that promoted open-source software.

title: Clintons Grand Design
description: The campaigns have become fond of those teaser e-mail messages. They make you think theyre making some big announcement (like, say, suspending their campaigns), but then its just some silly pitch.

title: Riding a Flavor Trip
description: At "flavor tripping" parties, guests eat a berry known as miracle fruit that temporarily rewires taste buds, turning sour flavors sweet.

title: Donnie Baseball Visits Baseball Shrine
description: Don Mattingly has played in or coached in more than 2,000 major league games, but he had never visited Wrigley Field. That finally changed on Monday after Mattingly, a special assignment coach with the Los Angeles Dodgers, saw the famous ivy on the outfield walls and heard the Bleacher Bums.My mom always wanted me to play here, Mattingly said. It was day baseball. It was five hours from my home. You were close enough so that you could get home, but not so close that you would have people bothering you all the time.When Mattingly, who played his entire career with the Yankees, was asked if he ever came close to playing for the Chicago Cubs, he said that he had not. Then Mattingly laughed and added, Well, not that I know of.As Mattingly and Manager Joe Torre drove to Wrigley on Monday, he told Torre that he had never seen the Friendly Confines. The Yankees played here in 2003, but Mattingly, who lives in Evansville, Ind., did not became a Yankees coach until 2004.Mattingly was supposed to be the Dodgers batting coach, but he assumed a lesser role so he could be home with Jordon, his youngest son. Mattingly and his wife, Kim, filed for divorce last November. Jordon is in high school.Although Joe Girardi beat out Mattingly for the Yankees manager position, Mattingly said he still wanted to manage. Mattingly said he would renew his quest once his family situation was stabilized. He will not travel to Shea Stadium with the Dodgers for the series starting Thursday because he is taking Jordon to compete in a horse jumping show.

title: Cleaning Up Those Soft-Shell Crabs
description: Video

title: No Midges, but the Rain and the Umps are Bugging Girardi
description: Flash back to Game 2 of the playoffs in Cleveland last October. The field is infested with midges off Lake Erie, and Joe Torre makes no move to confront the umpires or pull his team off the field. Later, after losing his job as Yankees manager, Torre would cite that as a regret.

title: Frugal Traveler: Paris, France
description: The Frugal Traveler falls in love with a bourgeois bohemian neighborhood and throws a frugal housewarming party.

title: Frugal Traveler: The Grand Tour
description: The Frugal Traveler falls in love with a bourgeois bohemian neighborhood and throws a frugal housewarming party.

title: Famed architect Richard Meier on his new project in Tel Aviv and the state of tower design
description: There should be a purpose to building a tower other than making sure its taller than the last one, says Richard Meier, the designer of some of the worlds most recognizable buildings.

title: Compared to Other Liquids, Gasoline is Cheap
description: In five years of writing this blog, Ive generally resisted passing along some of those great little tidbits that get passed around by e-mailjokes, quotes, factoids, and stuff like that. Most of the sob stories are bogus, most of the jokes arent funny, and so on.

title: Musings Inspired By a Quagga
description: The hall is hushed, like a church. No one else is here. The only sound is the clicking of the heels of my shoes. I walk up and down, looking at the animals. They make no noise, for they are dead.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on May 17 about the killing of Kyung-Sook Woo, the owner of a dry-cleaning shop in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, included an erroneous age from the police for the victim. She was 62, not 52. The error was repeated on May 19 in an article in some editions about an arrest in the case.

title: When Doctors Go to Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Hint of Hope as Child Obesity Rate Hits Plateau
description: Childhood obesity, rising for more than two decades, appears to have hit a plateau, a potentially significant milestone in the battle against excessive weight gain among children.

title: J. R. Simplot, Farmer Who Developed First Frozen French Fries, Dies at 99
description: J. R. Simplot, a billionaire who grew up in a sod-roofed log cabin and dropped out of school at 14, then marshaled luck, spunk and inventiveness to fashion an entrepreneurial career that included developing the first commercial frozen French fry, died on Sunday at his home in Boise, Idaho. He was 99.

title: With Bold Steps, Fed Chief Quiets Some Criticism
description: WASHINGTON  Over a frantic weekend in mid-March, Ben S. Bernanke rewrote the rule book as chairman of the Federal Reserve. Like a military commander applying overwhelming force, he took steps then and over the next two months that some at the central bank are now calling the Bernanke Doctrine.

title: Al Qaeda Warrior Uses Internet to Rally Women
description: BRUSSELS  On the street, Malika El Aroud is anonymous in an Islamic black veil covering all but her eyes.

title: Drawn by Nature to New Zealand
description: Another world at the edge of the world is how Peter Cooper likes to refer to his isolated beachhead on the remote northern coast of New Zealand.

title: After Seven Years Away, His Return Is Filled With Rage
description: Free advice for playwrights: If youre going to leave the antagonist of your story unseen, you should make doubly sure that his loathsome qualities are clear. Its a test that Blink, an intense drama in the Brits Off Broadway Festival at the 59E59 Theaters, doesnt quite pass. The result is that a lot of well-acted rage by the three-member cast feels as if its bouncing off the walls rather than striking a target.

title: Three Remain in Running for Newark Schools Post
description: NEWARK  After nearly four dozen job applications over the past six months, the search for a new superintendent in Newark, New Jerseys largest school system, has been narrowed to three candidates.

title: For Coors Light, a Night Out That Begins on MySpace
description: BEER has long been marketed as a sociable beverage, from a campaign for Budweiser that carried the theme When gentlemen agree to the Lwenbru jingle that began, Heres to good friends. Now, another beer brand, Coors Light, is extending its presence in the new media with efforts on the social networking Web sites Facebook and MySpace.

title: A Staten Island Slice Stirs Up Manhattan
description: IT was only a matter of days once Artichoke Basilles Pizza & Brewery opened on 14th Street until a gaggle of food bloggers and critics descended on it.

title: Parents Grief Turns to Rage at Chinese Officials
description: DUJIANGYAN, China  Bereaved parents whose children were crushed to death in their classrooms during the earthquake in Sichuan Province have turned mourning ceremonies into protests in recent days, forcing officials to address growing political repercussions over shoddy construction of public schools.

title: Study Links Caesareans With Births Before Term
description: Premature single births have been increasing in the United States, mostly among infants delivered by Caesarean section, researchers are reporting. And they say some of the increase may be due to Caesareans that are not medically necessary.

title: Are We Willing to Pay So All Kids Can Learn?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pistons Top Red Wings in Ratings
description: The Pistons have defeated the Red Wings for the viewing hearts of Detroit fans  at least in two playoff games played head-to-head in the same market.

title: Investors Criticize French Bank Chairman for Loss
description: PARIS  They had been saving their anger ever since the trading scandal at the French bank Socit Gnrale broke in January. On Tuesday, shareholders were given their first chance to challenge management on a loss of 4.9 billion euros or $7.1 billion  and there was no more holding back.

title: Where They Are on Land
description: Following are some places to try New York oysters:

title: Cloning Pets
description: To the Editor:

title: Fearing Floods, Chinese Order Evacuations in Quake Area
description: SHANGHAI  The Chinese authorities are evacuating 150,000 people threatened by possible flooding from a lake in southwestern China formed by landslides following this months earthquake, and military engineers struggled Tuesday to dig sluiceways to drain the water safely.

title: Realtors Agree to Stop Blocking Web Listings
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department and the National Association of Realtors reached a major antitrust settlement Tuesday that government officials said should spur competition among brokers and ultimately bring down hefty sales commissions.

title: China Leader Makes Debut in Great Wall of Facebook
description: BEIJING  Chinese leaders are not known for making themselves available to the public, even since the Internet opened the door to governments around the world. But Prime Minister Wen Jiabao has jumped into the online social networking world with a page on Facebook, one of the most popular sites of its kind.

title: The Rich Get Hungrier
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Mishap Foils Latest Attempt at a 25-Mile Skydive
description: Michel Fournier, the retired French Army officer who hoped to fly a giant helium balloon about 25 miles above Earth and parachute down, has failed again.

title: Earle Hagen, Who Composed Noted TV Tunes, Dies at 88
description: Earle H. Hagen, a onetime big-band trombonist who wrote some of the most famous theme songs in television history, died Monday in Rancho Mirage, Calif., near Palm Springs. He was 88 and lived in Rancho Mirage.

title: The Guessing Game Has Begun on the Next iPhone
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Can Steven P. Jobs top the iPhone ... with another iPhone?

title: Move From Bullpen Gives Chamberlain a New View
description: BALTIMORE  His first four months of major league service have been a whirlwind for Joba Chamberlain, so the process of converting him to a starting role does not exactly feel weird.

title: Designers Teach Glass (and Themselves) New Tricks
description: Summer hadnt quite arrived in the city over the Memorial Day weekend, but in the garden of the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, on upper Fifth Avenue, it was several hundred degrees in the shade. Onstage in the Corning Museum GlassLab, four sweat-beaded men in black T-shirts rotated elongated rods  tipped with molten glass hot enough to ignite anything it touched, whether metal, wood or flesh  with the nonchalance of baton twirlers.

title: Penguins Look for Way to Relocate Their Offense
description: PITTSBURGH  The Penguins spent the regular season and the first three rounds of the playoffs as a puck-possession team, with enough offensive firepower to score seemingly whenever necessary.

title: A Specialists Sole Focus Is Trying to Repair Hooves
description: OCEANPORT, N.J.  There was more good news from the Big Brown camp Tuesday morning. His foot problem on the mend, Big Brown returned to training, jogging a mile and a half at Belmont Park. All signs indicate that he is on track to make the Belmont Stakes, which can only mean that Ian McKinlay has done his job well.

title: Yankees Lose Kennedy, Then Things Get Worse
description: BALTIMORE, May 27  For Ian Kennedy, Tuesday's game was his major league career in microcosm. It started flawlessly and spiraled quickly into shambles in the Yankees' wild 10-9 loss to the Baltimore Orioles in 11 innings.

title: Ex-Governor, Now in Prison, Sees Case End
description: CHICAGO  The United States Supreme Court announced Tuesday that it would not hear an appeal by former Gov. George Ryan of Illinois of his 2006 racketeering and fraud conviction.

title: Canada: Hollinger Control of Sun-Times Ends
description: The Sun-Times Media Group, the newspaper publisher once led by Conrad M. Black, won Canadian court approval of the settlement of a four-year dispute that will end control over the company by Hollinger Inc. Hollinger, Mr. Blacks former Toronto-based holding company, will convert its supervoting shares in Sun-Times to common stock under an agreement approved by Ontario Superior Court Judge Colin L. Campbell. Mr. Black, convicted of fraud last year and sent to prison, helped build Sun-Times, formerly called Hollinger International, into the worlds third-largest publisher of English-language newspapers, before selling most of its properties in a $3 billion strip-down of assets from 1998 to 2001.

title: In Ex-Spokesmans Book, Harsh Words for Bush
description: PHOENIX  President Bush convinces himself to believe what suits his needs at the moment, and has engaged in self-deception to justify his political ends, Scott McClellan, the former White House press secretary, writes in a critical new memoir about his years in the West Wing.

title: The Tension in the Democrats Camp
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about the Public Tile Project in Peekskill, N.Y., misstated the telephone number for information about an event that is being held on Friday to benefit the project. It is (914) 461-3275.

title: Mayor of Orange Resigns and Pleads Guilty to Extortion
description: NEWARK  A prominent New Jersey Democrat who had served simultaneously as the mayor of Orange and a state assemblyman pleaded guilty in federal district court Tuesday to one count of attempted extortion.

title: The First Step for Woods Is Negotiating 18 Stairs
description: BETHESDA, Md.  Walking down the 18 stairs from a hallway above the ballroom at the Congressional Country Club was like a tap-in putt for Tiger Woods on Tuesday. He moved fluidly, almost gliding into the room and onto the elevated platform before a room full of reporters, photographers, TV cameras, talking heads, club members and tournament officials.

description: Adapted from A Voce

description: Time: At least 45 minutes plus at least 30 minutes resting

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about a warning from the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to all troops that they should not become involved in partisan politics referred incorrectly to the length of the Iraq war. It has not lasted longer than World War II. ( The Second World War began in September 1939 with the invasion of Poland and ended in August 1945 with Japans surrender. The Iraq war began in March 2003. The United States five-year involvement in Iraq, however, has indeed been longer than its four-year involvement in World War II.)

title: Making Age an Issue
description: PRODUCER Campaign Group

title: Mexico: 7 Federal Police Officers Killed in Shootout With Drug Cartel
description: Seven federal police officers were killed in Culiacn during a gun battle with three men working for a drug cartel, the police said. The officers were the latest victims in a conflict between the cartels and the police that has claimed the lives of more than 30 federal agents and 170 local police officers in the last 18 months. The officers were trying to enter a house where they believed that drug dealers were hiding and were met with a hand grenade and machine-gun fire, the police said. One of the gunmen died in the exchange of fire, and a second man and a teenage boy were arrested.

title: End Runs on Medicaid
description: A federal district judge has slapped down a sneaky attempt by the Bush administration to impose an onerous Medicaid regulation despite the clear intent of Congress that it be deferred. Once again, the administration has been caught in a flagrant attempt to ignore the will of Congress and unilaterally chart its own path.

title: 2 Voter Rights Cases, One Gripping a College Town, Stir Texas
description: PRAIRIE VIEW, Tex.  Vote or Die, exhorts the faded slogan on a roadway at Prairie View A&M University, where black students once marched for the right to vote here in the town where they attend school, on a former cotton plantation about 50 miles northwest of Houston.

title: A Sunni Bloc Pulls Back on Rejoining Iraqi Cabinet
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs largest Sunni political bloc suspended its return to the Shiite-dominated government on Tuesday, saying Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki had refused to give it the cabinet ministries it wanted.

title: A Court Full of Chaos, a Trial Crammed With Questions
description: The 1916 trial of Sir Roger Casement had everything a dramatist could want: salacious revelations, media manipulation, star cameos (George Bernard Shaw and Arthur Conan Doyle were among those appealing for clemency), political intrigue and a central character wrapped in mystery.

title: Trinity Loses, but Wins Title
description: Trinity College started Tuesday hoping to become the first undefeated team in modern N.C.A.A. baseball history. It had to settle for a national championship.

title: A Not-So-Old Standby
description: I havent had anything I didnt like, said one of my tablemates as she reflected on the meal we were just finishing at the Harrison, and her tone communicated surprise and significant regard. What sounded in one sense like faint praise was actually a major compliment.

title: Germany and Poland Find That Trying to Get Along Has Its Benefits
description: BERLIN  Its springtime in Europe and something like love is in the air again for an unlikely pair. Germany and Poland have finally patched things up again.

title: Soft-Shell Crabs Take a Turn With Pasta
description: IM forever looking for new ways to cook soft-shell crabs. So when the splendid Los Angeles chef (Angeli Caffe) and radio host (KCRWs Good Food show) Evan Kleiman mentioned to me that she served soft-shells on top of pasta, I thought, Yes, well, thats obvious enough  once a good cook mentions it to you! Then I got to work.

title: U.S. Businessman Testifies He Gave Olmert $150,000 Over 13 Years
description: JERUSALEM  A Long Island businessman at the heart of a corruption case involving Prime Minister Ehud Olmert told an Israeli court on Tuesday that he gave about $150,000, mostly in cash stuffed into envelopes, to Mr. Olmert over the course of 13 years.

title: In an Uncertain Market, Hotels May Be Ripe Buys
description: A $200 million resort hotel does not exactly resemble a suburban home. But scratch the surface of the sales market for each property category, and they look remarkably similar today.

title: Truth or Consequences
description: Imagine for a minute, just a minute, that someone running for president was able to actually tell the truth, the real truth, to the American people about what would be the best  I mean really the best  energy policy for the long-term economic health and security of our country. I realize this is a fantasy, but play along with me for a minute. What would this mythical, totally imaginary, truth-telling candidate say?

title: Pennsylvania: Scouts Group Sues City
description: The Philadelphia city government said it would fight a lawsuit by the local Boy Scouts organization that seeks to block the citys efforts to evict it from rent-free premises because of alleged anti-gay policies. City officials say the policies violate a city ordinance and have told the Cradle of Liberty group to renounce its ban on gay Scouts, start paying $200,000 a year in rent or vacate its headquarters by May 31. We are not going to subsidize the violation of our ordinance, said Shelley Smith, the city solicitor. Its still our intention to take the legal action necessary to evict them.

title: Lottery Numbers
Celtics Look for Shots, and a Sense of Urgency
description: WALTHAM, Mass.  A mere 12 hours after touching down in the wee hours Tuesday morning, the Boston Celtics were back at work. Late afternoon practice/film sessions at home after playoff losses on the road have become a staple of the Celtics postseason. They have won only once in eight road games.

title: A Return Home May Place Torre in a Tough Spot
description: CHICAGO  Joe Torre was talking recently to his wife, Ali, about Willie Randolphs perilous status as manager of the Mets. They lamented how difficult it must be for Randolph to endure the percolating speculation that he may lose his job.

title: Connecting Philosophy, Sondheim and Seurat
description: The topic of the days seminar was Kripke on Philosophy of Mind and Wittgenstein, and the first couple of philosophers on the docket began speaking of the seeming possibility of the falsity of necessity and how it can be epistemologically possible to conceive of a metaphysical impossibility. As this was being discussed, a reporter discovered that it is very possible to contract a throbbing headache, and quickly.

title: If a Terrace Is Unusable, Is the Rent Reduced?
description: Q. I rent a penthouse studio with a large terrace. There is major construction on the exterior of the building, making the terrace impossible to use. This was not a problem in January, when construction began and I wasn't using the terrace. But now that the weather is warming, they are telling me that they don't anticipate completion until July.

title: Moose Gain Ground but Keep a Low Profile
description: McKENZIE MOUNTAIN WILDERNESS, N.Y.  Here in the boreal forests of the Adirondack Mountains, moose are seemingly everywhere and nowhere.

title: Devil May Care
description: THE WATCHER WATCHED

title: Justices Say Law Bars Retaliation Over Bias Claims
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday ruled that employees are protected from retaliation when they complain about discrimination in the workplace, adopting a broad interpretation of workers rights under two federal civil rights laws.

title: A City Tailor Who Revels in the Boldest Sportswear
description: Memorial Day has come and gone, and summer stretches out languidly before him; now is the time that a certain kind of Northeastern dandy, when in polite company, may safely revel in a certain kind of highly coded casual wear.

title: Brazil: Oil Company Planning to Sell Shares
description: The Brazilian billionaire Eike Batista, below, is planning a 5.59 billion real ($3.37 billion) initial public offering of OGX Petroleo e Gas Participacoes, betting the countrys recent oil finds will lure investors who snubbed other offerings this year. Mr. Batista founded Rio de Janeiro-based OGX less than a year ago. He paid $800 million in November to buy his first oil-exploration licenses off Brazils coast. Francisco Gros, vice president of the OGX board and former chief executive, said in an interview April 4 that OGX might have oil reserves of 4.8 billion barrels, according to a study by DeGolyer and MacNaughton, an oil-reserve appraisal firm based in Dallas.

title: A Few Aid Workers Reach Into Myanmar
description: BANGKOK  Myanmar is allowing some foreign aid workers to enter remote areas hard hit by the May 3 cyclone in what relief agencies said Tuesday appeared to be the beginning of a new policy that fulfills a pledge made last week to the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon.

title: A Tour of Bitters for the Summer
description: YOU have to hand it to the British for their engaging skill at understatement. How else to explain their predilection for taking something refreshing and delicious and saddling it with a name like ordinary?

title: Home Village Exerts Pull, Even Amid the Rubble
description: SHENXI VILLAGE, China  Since returning to this mountain village a few days after fleeing from the earthquake that devastated this region of Sichuan Province, Xiong Fuquan has made two or three daily round trips to the nearest town for supplies.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,075 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Tuesday:

title: Nothing Says Summer Like Icing
description: I WAS recently at a lunch where the birthday girl ordered flourless chocolate cake. Someone else ordered chocolate mousse. The mousse looked like mousse. The cake did, too, only darker and wetter, like a floor tile gone horribly wrong.

title: Pairings: Red Snapper Tacos With Tomatillo Salsa
description: Alex Hall, an English guest at our tasting of English and American bitter ales, told us that the typical partner for a pint of bitters was a pub lunch: a sandwich of Cheddar or Stilton with pickles on whole-grain bread.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the convictions of illegal immigrants who worked in an Iowa meat-packing plant misstated the sentence or crime for some of them. Of the 270 immigrants who were sent to prison, 260 were sentenced to five months for using false work documents; 2 were sentenced to 12 months and 1 day for that crime; and 8 received five-month sentences for re-entering the United States illegally after deportation. All 270 immigrants were not sentenced to five months for using false documents.

title: Charity Finds Child Sexual Abuse by Peacekeepers and Aid Workers
description: A British charity, Save the Children UK, said it had uncovered evidence of sexual abuse of children, some as young as 6, by United Nations peacekeepers and by workers from other international aid groups. The finding was based on field research in southern Sudan, Ivory Coast and Haiti. United Nations officials said the report reflected a continuing problem, despite efforts in recent years to establish conduct and discipline units in all the missions.

title: Nascar Wins Ratings
description: Ratings were low all around for prime-time television over the Memorial Day holiday, as repeats on CBS ranked first on Monday, and Nascar coverage lifted Fox to No. 1 on Sunday. Opposite mostly low-rated repeats, Foxs live broadcast of the Coca-Cola 600 drew an average of more than seven million viewers from 7 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. One day later, on Monday, only reruns of CBSs regular Monday lineup managed to earn more viewers. Led by Two and a Half Men at 9, the nights most watched show with 10.7 million viewers, CBS easily outdrew its Monday competitors, ABC, NBC and Fox, which finished in a virtual tie for runner-up. ABC was closest, attracting 5.5 million viewers for The Bachelorette from 9 to 11. Meanwhile, NBCs American Gladiators delivered 5.2 million viewers from 8 to 9:30, followed by a 90-minute edition of Dateline, which also earned 5.2 million viewers. Fox broadcast an encore of its two-hour So You Think You Can Dance premiere from 8 to 10 (4.9 million).

title: Glitch Hinders a Second Day on Mars
description: A communications glitch kept the Phoenix lander from getting instructions for its second day on Mars, mission officials said. But the problem was fixed later in the day, The Associated Press quoted NASA officials as saying. The spacecraft is equipped to send and receive data via radio from two satellites, the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter and the Mars Odyssey. But the Reconnaissance Orbiter spontaneously turned off its UHF radio, preventing transmission of the days instructions. Phoenix is healthy; everything is fine, Fuk Li, the manager of the Mars exploration program for the NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., said at a news conference.

title: Tilting at the Bocuse dOr
description: WITH all the chef competitions, you wouldnt think there was a cooking contest in which Americans were underrepresented.

title: A Tiny Fruit That Tricks the Tongue
description: CARRIE DASHOW dropped a large dollop of lemon sorbet into a glass of Guinness, stirred, drank and proclaimed that it tasted like a chocolate shake.

title: Santana Provides Relief for Mets
description: Johan Santana was entrusted with more than just rescuing the Mets from their tailspin Tuesday night. At stake, in no particular order, was their peace of mind, their managers job security and the support of a fan base that has grown increasingly vociferous with its discontent.

title: Sydney Pollack, Filmmaker New and Old
description: Sydney Pollacks career as a director blossomed in the 1960s and 70s, but in many ways he was a throwback to an earlier era in American movies.

title: Resources Scarce, Homelessness Persists in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS  Mayor C. Ray Nagin recently suggested a way to reduce this citys post-Katrina homeless population: give them one-way bus tickets out of town.

title: Defamation Case: Clemens Responds
description: Lawyers for Roger Clemens responded Tuesday to a two-month-old motion by his former trainer Brian McNamee that asked for the dismissal of a defamation lawsuit brought by Clemens.

title: Please, Is This $1 or $100?
description: In most countries, it is fairly easy for people to tell how many euros or pounds or yen they are holding in their hands. Different denominations can come in different sizes and colors. Some have filaments or other characteristics that make it easy to recognize their value by touch. The all-American greenback is an exception, but it should not be.

title: Major San Francisco Development Faces a Ballot Test
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It is difficult to imagine a tougher place to undertake a major redevelopment than the Hunters Point Naval Shipyard here.

title: Giving the Corkscrew a New Twist
description: Inspiration for the Wine Ratchet Magnum came from the toolbox. This sleek new wine opener operates like a ratchet wrench, which is what the people at Built, a New York company, were thinking of when they designed it.

title: South Africa: Notorious White Dorm Converted Into Diversity Center
description: The University of the Free State in Bloemfontein announced that it will close down the Reitz Residence, which became a symbol of white racist resistance to integration of campus housing, and convert it to an institute for the study of diversity. Four students who lived there made an infamous video that humiliated black cleaning women through mock initiation rites into the residence. The university called the closing an important gesture of reconciliation towards all South Africans who had been offended.

title: A Tomboy in Malaysia Is Introduced to Hormones
description: The Malaysian filmmaker Yasmin Ahmad tells deeply personal and intensely humanistic stories based largely on her own experiences. For her fourth film, Mukhsin, she revisits the loving and liberal family of her previous features, continuing her portrait of one womans journey from childhood through adolescence and marriage.

title: Delgado Benched as Slump Deepens
description: The Mets were losing by three runs in the fifth inning Monday night but showed signs of life: no outs, runners on first and second, and Carlos Delgado striding to the plate. On the fourth pitch of the at-bat, though, Delgado fouled out.

title: In Vermont, a Debate Swirls Around an Aging Nuclear Plant
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt.  After part of a cooling tower collapsed last August at Vermonts only nuclear power plant, the company that runs it blamed rotting wooden timbers that it had failed to inspect properly. The uproar that followed rekindled environmental groups hopes of shutting down the aging plant.

title: Some Foes of a Floundering German Far-Right Party Want to Try Again to Ban It
description: BERLIN  Germanys leading extreme right-wing party is on the ropes because of financial mismanagement, criminal investigations and fierce competition from the left for the populist protest vote. The debate among the authorities here is whether to try to ban it or to allow it to quietly self-destruct.

title: Can He Take a Frisk?
description: After Rahmbo Emanuel, the Illinois congressman dubbed the hostage negotiator by the Obama forces, fails to talk Hillary down, Barack Obama knows that he is left with one final roll of the dice. He sets up a secret meeting with Bill Clinton in neutral territory at Rahms hideaway office in the Capitol.

title: Grotesquerie and Ecstasy, on Both Street and Stage
description: Sometimes Butoh, the outr, avant-garde dance movement that developed in mid-20th-century Japan, seems tailor made for New York.

title: An Annual Holiday Celebration Still Resonates Inside a Cathedral
description: Over the years the annual free concert on Memorial Day by the New York Philharmonic at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine has become a very meaningful holiday event for music-loving New Yorkers. Before the cathedral began its extensive renovations several years ago, it used to be possible for more than 2,500 people to attend these concerts.

title: Harlems Bloody Past Is Reluctantly Revisited
description: When the gunfire started, Donald Banks crouched behind a parked car on Lenox Avenue, not sure where the bullets were coming from and not caring, as long as they did not get too close.

title: Calendar
description: Party From 1988

title: New Climate Report Foresees Big Changes
description: The rise in concentrations of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere from human activities is influencing climate patterns and vegetation across the United States and will significantly disrupt water supplies, agriculture, forestry and ecosystems for decades, a new federal report says.

title: Big Bangs Dont Always Require Long Fuses
description: Some people think Neil LaBute should write only one-acts  and its easy to see why. His lean, economical dialogue is usually built around a savvy concept that can stretch thin by the second hour of a full-length play. But Mr. LaBute, who polarizes critics like few other playwrights, excels at shorthand, as demonstrated by The Great War, a bruising, comically nasty portrait of a broken marriage directed by Andrew McCarthy. Call it Virginia Woolf Lite.

title: Stark Contrasts Between McCain and Obama in Judicial Wars

title: Footnotes

title: Paris Chooses Tower by Jean Nouvel for La Dfense
description: The French architect Jean Nouvel has been selected to design a high-rise building that will strikingly alter the skyline in La Dfense business district on the outskirts of Paris, officials announced on Tuesday. His project was chosen from among those of five finalists, among them Norman Foster and Daniel Libeskind. The building, dubbed the Signal Tower, is part of an ambitious plan to revitalize La Dfense that was conceived in 2006 when Nicolas Sarkozy, who is now Frances president, led a public body dedicated to that goal. Patrick Devedjian, who succeeded him, said the tower would be the most important architectural act since the Eiffel Tower. Comprising four segments that resemble stacked cubes, the tower will have apartments on the upper floors, as well as a hotel, offices and a business plaza. (Above, an artists rendering of an interior view, and, right, of the tower, shown with the Grande Arche.) It is to be completed by 2015. Mr. Nouvel, who captured the Pritzker Prize, architectures top honor, this year, also designed the Quai Branly Museum in Paris, which opened in 2006, and is at work on a satellite of the Louvre Museum in Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates.

title: Nude Photos Ignite Australian Debate
description: Cate Blanchett joined forces on Tuesday with prominent people in the arts to protest plans by the police to initiate an obscenity prosecution over images by Bill Henson, an eminent photographer, that feature nude 12- and 13-year-olds, Agence France-Presse reported. An open letter signed by Ms. Blanchett, who, with her husband, the playwright Andrew Upton, is a joint artistic director of the Sydney Theater Company, declared that the potential prosecution does untold damage to our cultural reputation. The signers included Elizabeth Ann Macgregor, director of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Sydney, and the writer Larissa Behrendt.  Last week, responding to a complaint from a member of the public, the police raided and closed the Henson exhibition at the Roslyn Oxley9 Gallery in Sydney and seized 20 works. They said they were likely to bring charges in connection with the images, described by Prime Minister Kevin Rudd as absolutely revolting. All the signers of the protest letter took part last month in Canberra in Mr. Rudds national summit on future directions. The letter said that Mr. Hensons work itself is not pornographic, even though it includes depictions of naked human beings. It is more justly seen in a tradition of the nude in art that stretches back to the ancient Greeks, and which includes painters such as Caravaggio and Michelangelo.
