title: 007 Runs Full-Throttle Through a New Book
description: Its the big day: the 100th anniversary of the birth of Ian Fleming. Without Fleming, who died in 1964 at 56, we would never have had the debonair company of James Bond, the creative sadism of Goldfinger and Dr. No or the pet octopus named Octopussy. Without the benefit of Fleming, however, weve had Octopussy as a cinematic Bond Girl in 1983, part of a movie franchise that is miraculously resuscitated (most recently by Daniel Craig as Bond in Casino Royale) each time it falters, and a string of ersatz Bond books by fill-in writers. To this shaky bibliography we can now add Devil May Care.

title: Germany Remembers Persecuted Gays
description: A monument featuring two men kissing was unveiled by Germany in Berlin on Tuesday in memory of thousands of homosexuals who were persecuted, tortured and killed by the Nazis, Agence France-Presse reported. Designed by the Danish-born Michael Elmgreen and the Norwegian-born Ingar Draset, both based in Berlin, the memorial, situated in the Tiergarten park, near the Brandenburg Gate and the Holocaust memorial, consists of a gray concrete slab about 13 feet high. Inside, at eye level, is a gap filled by a television screen that shows the kissing men, above. Bernd Neumann, Germanys minister of culture,  evoked the present when he said the monument was also first and foremost an expression of our conviction that in our country there is no place for the discrimination of homosexuals, of people who think and live differently. On hand for the unveiling was Berlins openly gay mayor, Klaus Wowereit, but no survivors. The last known survivor, Pierre Seel, died in November 2005. Homosexuality was illegal in Germany until 1969 and not formally decriminalized until 1994.

title: Restoration Row
description: (Photo: A bison in Theodore Roosevelt National Park, in North Dakota. (Credit: Dan Koeck for The New York Times)) PAWHUSKA, Okla.  It is hard to love a land you don't understand, and for most of my life I had no idea why anyone would ever live in the Great Plains  let alone love the place.   Flat, featureless, boring. Those were the words I heard growing up whenever someone would mention the plains. My view was informed by Dorothy's Kansas, which looked scary and Gothic even before the twister took her house and Toto, too.  But then I spent some time here, mostly listening to people in the twilight of their lives tell about the land when it turned on them, during the Dust Bowl of the 1930s. At the end of a long day of hearing stories, I would go for a run in the wind, and sometimes get a glimpse of the magic of the place  a pronghorn antelope in a sprint, a sky blushing pink, the quiet when the air finally settles.   There are people with us still who remember the Great Plains in its birthday suit, grass as far as the eye could see, what Walt Whitman called, "that delicate miracle, the ever-recurring grass."   That land is gone to us, now. Once, the grassland in our midsection spanned at least 14 states, from Minnesota to Texas, the second biggest ecosystem in North America. It's gone because the grass was overturned and the bison were chased off the land and the riot of biodiversity that evolved over 10,000 years was replaced by a few commodity crops to feed us.   It's not worth arguing over whether this was a good or a bad thing, because most of the intentions were good, even if the excesses were bad. But it's always worthwhile to wonder whether humans can fix what they screwed up.   And here, just north of this little town in Osage Indian country, I saw some evidence that the land can be healed. I saw shaggy-headed bison and their calves, several thousand of them, in a setting that was neither park nor zoo. I saw grass stretching almost to the horizon, flowering in parts, combed by the wind. I saw the sun dip behind the lilt of the Flint Hills, closing out a day with a burst of color.   This miracle of restoration is the Tallgrass Prairie Preserve, nearly 40,000 acres run by the Nature Conservancy. It is the largest protected remnant of tallgrass prairie left on earth, according the stewards of this land  cowboys with advanced botany degrees.   The conservancy bought this land in 1989 and then set out to bring it back. The two biggest missing elements  fire and bison  were returned. Both renew the grass, distribute seeds, and keep the carpet of big bluestem, wild rye and other species healthy.   The result is somewhat astonishing. Over 300 species of forbs, grasses and flowers are here. And while this preserve is just a patch, an anchored Noah's Ark of what used to cover much of the continent, it says something about restoration. Bit by bit, maybe some of what we lost can be brought back.   I say this at a time when nearly all commercial salmon fishing has been halted on the West Coast. What used to be a rite of the season  a taste of the wild, spring Chinook returning to the Columbia River, the richest salmon on earth  is almost a memory this year.   But look also at bald eagles that fly in all 50 states, a byproduct of strong laws and far-sighted bird lovers. From my house in a metro area of nearly 3 million people, I can see a pair of nesting bald eagles.   We restore things to the wild, and in time, they return the favor. Think of Nick Adams, the psychically wounded veteran coming home to the nurturing water in Hemingway's "Big Two-Hearted River."   So even with the sky here in Oklahoma rumbling and clacking, menaced by twisters rolling down Tornado Alley, there is just enough of the original plains at the Tallgrass Preserve to make flatland believers out of skeptics.   You can see in the remains of a day the reason why people who came here a hundred years ago were so lonely  and, also, why they fell in love with the place.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on Tuesday about the breaching of a dam on the Clark Fork River in Montana as part of a toxic waste cleanup misstated the reason that arsenic-laden waste is found in the river. The waste comes from naturally occurring arsenic in the ore minerals that have been mined in the area over the years; arsenic was not used by miners to separate metal from rock.

title: Old Meters Mean Double the Price at the Pump
description: For a brief moment on Wednesday morning, the gas pump at Gary Staianos Texstar service station in Bellerose, Queens, turned into a time machine. After 11.3 gallons was pumped into a Pontiac Grand Am, the meter read $23, or $2.03 a gallon, a price not seen in more than three years.

title: Sony Taps Into Photo Archive as a Resource During Hard Times
description: Some of Sonys music executives believe there is a gold mine under the companys New York headquarters on Madison Avenue. It doesnt look like much: just a small room, three floors below ground level, with a wall full of the sliding shelves youd find in a law firm or university library.

title: Democrats Are Advised to Seat Half of 2 States Delegations
description: Democratic Party lawyers have determined that no more than half the delegates from Florida and Michigan can be seated at the partys August convention, dealing a blow to Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons efforts to seat the full delegations from those states.

title: In Her Own World
description: BEACH Lake, Pa.

title: Staten Island Democrats Choose a Councilman as Their Candidate for Fossellas Seat
description: The Staten Island Democratic Party voted on Wednesday night to endorse City Councilman Michael E. McMahon as its choice for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Vito J. Fossella, a Republican.

title: In Dispute on Free Transit Passes, Its New York Agency vs. States Top Lawyer
description: It is a contrast that has often galled some commuters: While they have to pay their way on trains, buses and bridges, members of the Metropolitan Transportation Authoritys board, many of them quite wealthy, travel free.

title: New Life for an Old PC
description: Q. Im planning on reformatting and erasing the hard drive in my old computer before I give it to a friend, but I cant find the original Windows discs that came with it. I dont want to pass along a machine with no operating system on it, so what can I do?

title: Leather-Bound Hard Drive Transports Data in Style
description: Although autumn usually signals the arrival of leather weather, Iomega is bucking the trend this summer. The companys eGo Leather Portable Hard Drive wraps a swath of sturdy brown leather around 250 gigabytes of storage so your files can travel in style.

title: Munch Moves
description: The Munch Museum, which has the worlds largest collection of works by Edvard Munch, is moving across Oslo to a new building, near the futuristic new opera building, city officials said on Wednesday. Agence France-Presse reported the move in an article about plans for a cultural center that includes the museum. The center, which will include two museums and a library, is to be built on the banks of the Oslo Fjord behind the opera house. It is to be inaugurated in 2014 when Norway celebrates the 200th anniversary of the signing of its constitution. The Munch Museum was in the headlines in 2004 when The Scream and Madonna were stolen from it; they were retrieved two years later and went back on display last week.

title: Extreme Makeover: Shakespearean Edition
description: Shakespeares crumbling grave marker at Holy Trinity Church in Stratford-upon-Avon, left, needs a makeover, The Associated Press reported. But the superstitious can exhale: Shakespeares remains would not be moved, so workers could avoid the curse on anyone who moves my bones, as the stone tablets inscription warns. Friends of Shakespeares Church hope to raise 4 million ($7.9 million) to restore the marker and other elements of the church, Josephine Walker, a spokeswoman for the group, said. The church, still used for worship, attracts 100,000 tourists a year, Ms. Walker said. Shakespeare was baptized at Holy Trinity on April 26, 1564, and buried there on April 25, 1616.

title: Mayor Loses a Film Role, but Gains a Punch Line
description: At least four times, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has used a public appearance to lob some gentle criticism at Sex and the City, the film revival of the HBO television series.

title: Britain Joins a Draft Treaty on Cluster Munitions
description: LONDON  The draft of a treaty to ban cluster munitions was adopted by a group of 111 nations on Wednesday in Dublin after Britain dropped its longstanding opposition to any limitations on the weapons.

title: STOCKS & BONDS; Increase in Oil Prices Lifts Energy Sector
description: Stocks rose for a second day as a rebound in oil prices set off a late-day rally in energy shares, and a better-than-forecast report on durable goods orders lifted industrial companies.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the adjustment by Americans to higher gasoline prices misstated, in some editions, the year of a car owned by Florian Bialas, who lives near Chicago and plans to begin walking to save money. It was a 1997 Pontiac Sunfire, not a 1987. (The Sunfire was not introduced until the 1995 model year.)

title: In Defense of Workers
description: The Supreme Court handed down a pair of well-reasoned, fair-minded rulings this week upholding the rights of employees who charge age and race discrimination. The decisions, which forbid employers from retaliating against such workers, are a welcome break from some of the recent rulings by this court that have ignored precedent and common sense to throw out legitimate claims of unfair treatment.

title: 3 Doors Down at No. 1
description: Three new albums take the top spots on the Billboard album chart this week. The rock band 3 Doors Down is at No. 1 with 154,000 sales of its self-titled new album on Universal, Nielsen SoundScan reported. Bun B of the long-running Texas rap duo UGK is No. 2 with his second solo record, II Trill (Rap-A-Lot/Asylum), with 98,000. (Bun Bs partner in UGK, Pimp C, died in December.) Third place goes to Julianne Hough, a 19-year-old country singer and Dancing With the Stars alumna; her self-titled debut on Mercury Nashville sold 67,000 copies. Last weeks No. 1, Death Cab for Cuties Narrow Stairs (Atlantic), slipped to No. 5 with 53,000 sales. Down the chart, Donna Summers first CD of new material in 17 years, Crayons (Burgundy), opened at No. 17 with 23,000.

title: A J.F.K. Footnote
description: To the Editor:

title: A Wrap Dress Unwinds
description: THE artist E. V. Day makes fireworks from fashion. She has torn apart wedding gowns, a Chanel suit and a replica of Marilyn Monroes white halter dress  symbols of feminine entrapment or empowerment, depending on your perspective  to create installations rigged on fishing line that make them seem to be exploding. She has made bomber jets out of G-strings.

title: Obama Seeks to Clarify His Disputed Comments on Diplomacy
description: WASHINGTON  With his experience and leadership credentials under sharp criticism, Senator Barack Obama and his advisers are trying to clarify what has emerged as a central tenet of his proposed foreign policy: a willingness to meet leaders of enemy nations.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: Schedule information on Wednesday with a theater review of the plays in Series B of Marathon 2008, at the Ensemble Studio Theater on West 52nd Street, using information from the program, misstated the closing date. Series B runs through June 20, not this Saturday. (Series C will run from June 6 through June 28.)

title: Just a Twist (and Tilt) of the Wrist
description: WHEN Scott Forstall, a senior vice president at Apple, demonstrated a new space game for the iPhone, he let the spacecraft cruise through a field of stars for a bit. As the audience finished absorbing the look of the shooter set in a distant galaxy, he asked them, I dont have a joystick on here, or any four-button toggle, so how do I steer?

title: In Stock Plan, Employees See Stacked Deck
description: CLEWISTON, Fla.  Thousands of workers at U.S. Sugar thought they were getting a good deal when the company shelved their pension plan and gave them stock for their retirement instead. They had a heady sense of controlling their own destiny as they became the companys biggest shareholders, Vic McCorvey, a former farm manager there, said.

title: Truly Thanking Those Who Serve
description: To the Editor:

title: Talks Are on With ABC, Gibson Says
description: Charles Gibson, whose contract as anchor of World News on ABC is due to expire soon after the presidential election, said in an interview this week that the network had asked him to remain on the job for the foreseeable future, and that he was considering doing so.

title: In Economic Terms, Recycling Almost Pays
description: It still costs more to recycle paper, plastic, metal and glass in New York City than to simply chuck everything into the trash. But the cost difference has narrowed, and if the trend continues, recycling could end up being cheaper than trash disposal within five years, according to an analysis released on Wednesday by the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group.

title: Martnez Goes Six Innings and Calls Himself Ready
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Pedro Martnezs fastball reached 91 miles per hour twice in the first inning Wednesday night in a Class A game, and 90 on several other occasions. That reinforced to Martnez that he was a much different pitcher than last year at this time, when he was recovering from rotator cuff surgery.

title: Terrorism and the Olympics
description: KASHGAR, China

title: Massachusetts Law to Manage and Protect Ocean Waters
description: BOSTON  Gov. Deval Patrick signed into law Wednesday a measure that will establish the nations first management and protection plan for a states ocean waters.

title: Dress for Less and Less
description: SINCE 1998, the price of a Speedy handbag  the entry-level style at Louis Vuitton  has more than doubled, to $685, indicative of a precipitous price increase throughout the luxury goods market. The price of Joe Boxers licky face underwear, meanwhile, has dropped by nearly half, to $8.99, representing just as seismic a shift at the other end of the fashion continuum, where the majority of American consumers do their shopping.

title: Studios in a Tentative Deal With TV Actors in One Union, but Uncertainty Remains
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywood took another step toward labor peace on Wednesday morning, as a union representing television actors reached a tentative three-year deal with production companies after talks had stalled over the re-use of performers images on the Internet.

title: River Threatens China Quake Survivors
description: CHENGDU, China  Faced with the prospect of massive flooding from a blocked river in the highlands of Sichuan Province, the authorities have announced plans to evacuate more than a million people should the rock-and-mud embankment give way, a threat that grew more urgent on Wednesday.

title: Tony Sopranos Duds
description: Twenty-four outfits that defined the sartorial character of Tony Soprano, the mobster played by James Gandolfini on HBO, are on sale for charity, The Associated Press reported. Proceeds from the June 25 auction at Christies will go to the Wounded Warrior Project, a nonprofit group that assists soldiers severely wounded in Iraq or Afghanistan. The outfits, above, include the button-down blue shirt that Tony wore in the opening credits of The Sopranos, the bathrobe in which he collected the morning newspaper and the blood-splattered black-and-beige polo shirt, white tank top and black pants he wore when he was shot by Uncle Junior. Mr. Gandolfinis wardrobe, which includes many items with the original production tags attached, is expected to fetch up to $36,000. His contract allowed him to keep the clothes after The Sopranos ended last year.

title: Israelis and Palestinians Launch Web Start-Up
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Nibbling doughnuts and wrestling with computer code, the workers at G.ho.st, an Internet start-up here, are holding their weekly staff meeting  with colleagues on the other side of the Israeli-Palestinian divide.

title: Gala Auction Feels a Chill From Wall Streets Slump
description: Giving away $56.5 million in a night would strike most people as extravagant. But to the tycoons of modern finance, it seems a bit low key.

title: Wire to Wire With Affirmed and Alydar
description: Seen through the current prism of fragile, transient champions, Affirmed and Alydar seem from another planet, another age, another breed. Yet it was only 30 years ago that Affirmed and Alydar not only completed the Triple Crown but actually finished 1-2 on those three different Saturdays.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on Tuesday about the growing use of machines on upstate New York farms to replace lost migrant workers omitted a passage in some editions at the start of the continuation. The complete article is at nytimes.com/nyregion. The article also misspelled the given name of the United States senator from California who tried to attach a guest worker program to an Iraq spending bill. She is Dianne Feinstein, not Diane.

title: Nepal Reborn as a Republic
description: NEW DELHI  The worlds last Hindu king, Gyanendra of Nepal, was told to step down from his throne in 15 days, as a newly elected assembly led by former Maoist guerrillas voted late Wednesday to transform the country into a republic.

title: Gliding Through Outer Space, Bathed in Trippy Colors
description: In February, Moses Pendleton created a dance in black light for the Russian ballerina Diana Vishneva in which her arms curled and spiraled, forming, among other shapes, an elegant swan. It seemed as if it could have been performed by anyone; why waste Ms. Vishnevas talent on such a gimmick? Still, the longer you stared at those arms swimming through space, the more luscious, expressive and individual they became.

title: Bloomberg, Potential Running Mate for 2 Presidential Hopefuls, Has a Bit of Criticism for 3
description: Since announcing in February that he would not pursue an independent bid for the presidency, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been rumored to be a serious contender as a running mate, either to Senator Barack Obama on the Democratic ticket or to Senator John McCain on the Republican side.

title: CNN Reporters Interview Raises Ethical Questions
description: When Howard Kurtz invited Kimberly Dozier, the CBS journalist wounded in Iraq, onto his program, Reliable Sources, on CNN on Sunday, he was not a disinterested interviewer. Mr. Kurtzs wife, Sheri Annis, had been paid to serve as a publicist for Ms. Doziers memoir, Breathing the Fire, which Ms. Dozier had come on the program to discuss.

title: A Video Camera for Anyone Exhibiting on YouTube
description: Someday all movies will be on the Internet and, if current trends persist, will last only 10 minutes. Budding auteurs can prepare for this future with the JVC Everio GZ-MS100.

title: After 05 Uzbek Uprising, Issues Linger for West
description: ANDIJON, Uzbekistan  The theater that burned has a fresh coat of paint. Bullet holes have been plastered over. Newspapers talk of cattle farming, tennis courts and World War II victories.

title: Strike Settled, American Axle Details Layoff Plans
description: DETROIT  Fewer than half of the hourly employees at American Axle and Manufacturing who are returning to work this week for the first time since going on strike in February will still have jobs in a year, company executives said Wednesday.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A summary capsule on Wednesday for an article in The Arts about Daniel Evans, an actor who is the star of a Broadway revival of Sunday in the Park With George and is also studying philosophy, misidentified the university in New York where he recently attended a philosophy seminar. It was at the City University of New York Graduate Center, not New York University.

title: Yogi, Take Me to a Higher Place
description: WHEN Raquel Prieto moved from Northampton, Mass., to Boston in January, there was one thing she sought as urgently as an affordable living situation and a job: an advanced yoga class.

title: Dimmer Lights on Broadway?
description: The Broadway League has released statistics for the 2007-8 season, which ended on Sunday. Paid attendance at Broadway shows, at 12.2 million, was down slightly from last seasons record of 12.3 million. Broadway grosses were off by about $1 million, at $937.5 million. These numbers are not watertight; The New Mel Brooks Musical: Young Frankenstein declined to provide that shows grosses, so the league has used Varietys estimates. The league attributed the slight declines to the 19-day strike by the stagehands union last fall that left most Broadway theaters dark.

title: Rare Signs of Life Uncovered at Shea
description: Among the criticisms of the Mets in this inconsistent season is that they lack a reliable bullpen and that their hitters do not compete with tenacity when trailing in late innings.

title: A Feisty String Orchestra With Shades of Pop Music
description: The String Orchestra of New York City, which also goes by its more colorful acronym, Sonyc, performs standing and without a conductor. Comparisons with Orpheus, the citys more famous conductorless orchestra, are inevitable, and in some ways Sonyc, now in its ninth season, still plays with the kind of feistiness Orpheus had when it was founded in the 1970s. But these groups have fundamental differences.

title: Seven Scientists Win First Kavli Prizes
description: Seven men  including two from Columbia University  whose work focuses on the large, the far away, the small and the horribly complex will share $3 million as the first winners of a new set of science prizes.

title: Window-Shop the Whole Place
description: Muji, the Japanese chain that sells simple, well-designed items for the home, will open its second United States store, in the base of The New York Times building, on Friday. The merchandise will be much the same as that in other Muji stores, like the one in SoHo, which opened in November (the wall-mounted CD player, left, is $178).

title: Monkeys Think, Moving Artificial Arm as Own
description: Two monkeys with tiny sensors in their brains have learned to control a mechanical arm with just their thoughts, using it to reach for and grab food and even to adjust for the size and stickiness of morsels when necessary, scientists reported on Wednesday.

title: Wars Stresses Take Toll on Militarys Chaplains
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  On a recent morning, an Army chaplain, Lt. Col. Richard E. Brunk Jr., met with a suicidal soldier who had served in Iraq, drove across Fort Hood to greet 70 activated reservists, attended meetings on future deployments and then retreated to his computer to counsel members of his military flock around the world.

title: Get Ready Now for Summer Heat
description: WHEN the heat and humidity of summer take hold and its time to hit the cool button, youll want your air-conditioner to respond with a blast of chilly air and a satisfying hum.

title: At Lost City, Saving a Craft
description: When Afshan Durrani and her husband, Nusrat, left India in 1990, they set their sights on a modern future: he would pursue a career in music at MTV in New York, where they settled in 1995, while she attended the Fashion Institute of Technology, designing dresses with a dash of punk. But Ms. Durrani, above, who grew up in Kashmir, found that Indias traditions held sway over her imagination. During a trip home for a wedding, she was astounded anew by the embroidery on the wedding regalia and aghast at the working conditions of the craftsmen who made it. So in 2002, she founded Lost City Products, a company that now employs 125 artisans making fabrics using centuries-old techniques in Lucknow, the center of the Indian crafts industry. The process remains exacting, and the product is costly: it takes 20 people working on one loom five weeks to make 10 yards of a silk like Camille ($960 a yard), top left, an adaptation of a Wiener Werksttte pattern from 1900, followed by 10 days of hand-washing and trimming. The latest collection includes other silks and duck cottons (starting at $173 a yard), right, in patterns adapted from sources like 17th-century Dutch botanicals and ninth-century Persian script. Information is at www.lostcityproducts.com.

title: Prado to Ride Casino Drive; Big Brown Works Out
description: It was an eventful morning at Belmont Park on Wednesday as Edgar Prado was selected to ride Casino Drive, the wonder horse from Japan, in the Belmont Stakes, and Big Brown turned in his first strong gallop since sustaining a quarter crack (stress fracture) over the weekend.

title: Hot Ticket in B-School: Bringing Life Values to Corporate Ethics
description: STUDENTS talk about Stewart D. Friedman, a management professor at the Wharton School, with a mixture of earnest admiration, gratitude and rock star adoration.

title: Entering Virtual Worlds for Real-Life Pitches
description: IN 2002, when Electronic Arts signed a multimillion-dollar agreement with McDonalds to place virtual burgers in an online version of its popular Sims video game, the move drew protests from players who resented the commercial intrusion.

title: Court Rules Sect Children Should Go Home
description: The Texas State Supreme Court on Thursday ruled that the removal of children from a polygamist religious groups ranch by child welfare authorities was unwarranted and that the children should be returned.

title: Seeking Profits Beyond CD Sales
description: As CD sales figures continue to erode in the United States, one of the biggest players in the classical recording industry is adding a new line of business. Universal Classics and Jazz, the worldwide market leader in classical CD sales, announced on Wednesday the formation of Universal Music Classical Artists Management and Productions.

title: Class Dismissed
description: Washington

title: I Knew It All Along
description: There are several kinds of Washington memoirs: I Reveal the Honest Truth, a kiss-up-and-tell designed to settle scores (nod to honesty optional). I Was There at the Start, designed to make the author appear to be the linchpin of history. And, most tedious: I Knew It Was a Terrible Mistake, but I Didnt Mention It Until I Got a Book Contract.

title: Italian Investigator Says U.S. Agents Left Obvious Clues in Abduction Case
description: MILAN  A top Italian terrorism investigator on Wednesday described the governments ease in unraveling an alleged C.I.A. operation to kidnap a radical imam: all that was necessary, the investigator said, was to trace the cellphones in use near the spot in Milan where the imam disappeared while going to a mosque in February 2003.

title: Amazing, the Stuff a County Can Collect
description: Thomas R. Suozzi, the Nassau County executive, billed it as the largest online yard sale in New York State history, imagining that in addition to raising perhaps $1 million, the auction could herald a new era of efficiency in government spending.

title: If Its a Challenge You Want
description: Seeking a deeper yoga practice? Here are a range of advanced classes that are favorites among high-level students.

title: White House Reacts Negatively to Ex-Aides Book
description: The White House reacted negatively today to scathing criticisms of President Bush and members of his inner circle that appear in a new memoir written by Scott McClellan, the former White House press secretary who was forced out in 2006 after three tumultuous years.

title: Real People, Really Small Spaces
description: Its hard not to have a regional bias toward the New Yorkers in Apartment Therapy Presents: Real Homes, Real People, Hundreds of Real Design Solutions, by Maxwell Gillingham-Ryan (Chronicle Books; $27.50). Since 2004, when Mr. Gillingham-Ryan started apartmenttherapy.com, the do-it-yourselfers decorating Web site, it has grown to include Chicago, San Francisco and Los Angeles. But it began in New York, and to a New Yorker theres no cleverer nester than another New Yorker, living in 250 square feet and shopping mongo on the street or on Craigslist. The sites best features have long been the house tour  uploaded pictures of a readers apartment  and the smallest, coolest apartment contest. Forty of these apartments are collected in the book, with plans, sources and snapshots of the inhabitants. I especially liked the 442-square-foot studio of Clove and Jenny, with its Murphy bed, barn-wood table and snoozing Jack Russell.

title: Florida and Michigan May See Delegates Halved
description: An analysis by lawyers for the Democratic Party says party rules call for Florida and Michigan to lose at least half their delegate strength at the partys convention in August, an outcome that could close off Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons last opportunity to cut significantly into Senator Barack Obamas lead in delegates.

title: Former EADS Chief Detained in Inquiry
description: PARIS  Nol Forgeard, the former co-chief executive of European Aeronautic Defense and Space, was detained by the French police on Wednesday for questioning about insider trading accusations linked to delays in the A380 program.

title: Taste of Senate Set Capt. McCain on a New Path
description: WASHINGTON  At a meeting in his Pentagon office in early 1981, Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman told Capt. John S. McCain III that he was about to attain his life ambition: becoming an admiral.

title: Alou Expects to Return to Mets Lineup Next Week
description: If all goes well, Moises Alou will return from his calf injury in San Diego next Thursday, when he is eligible to return from the disabled list.

title: A Booming Stereo Sound From the Little Phone in Your Pocket
description: Many mobile phones serve as pocket jukeboxes for people who want to have music with them at all times, but phone speakers are not known for their high fidelity. Logitechs new Pure-Fi Mobile speaker system, however, lets you wirelessly blast your tunes from the phone in your pocket to everyone within earshot.

title: A Good Day in the Badlands
description: MOUNT RUSHMORE

title: The Face of Chinas Olympic Hopes Is Smiling
description: In baggy jeans, sneakers and a Nike windbreaker, Liu Xiang stood on the observation deck of the Empire State Building on Wednesday morning. Perhaps surprisingly, he did not have a sports psychologist at his side.

title: Crosby Scores Twice, and the Penguins Can Exhale
description: PITTSBURGH  His Penguins teammates said forward Sidney Crosby showed no signs in the locker room of the pressure of trying to lift Pittsburgh back into the Stanley Cup finals after two disastrous games in Detroit. His response came during Game 3, for everyone to see.

title: Ostensibly Independent, a Charity Is U.S. Sugars Swing-Vote Shareholder
description: For the Mott Childrens Health Center, a corporate takeover offer to buy U.S. Sugar for $293 a share could have meant a payday of $125 million  enough to care for 12,000 children a year for more than 14 years.

title: The Year That Changed the World
description: There are many strands to the annus mirabilis of 1968  the Prague Spring, the Paris barricades, Flower Power  but all involved an uprising against a stifling postwar order. In what the author Paul Berman has called an incoherent fraternity, idealism provided what coherence there was.

title: A Wilderness, Lost in the City
description: MANY people are astounded to learn that there is a teeming wildlife preserve in New York City. Ridgewood Reservoir on the Brooklyn-Queens border is an oasis where an amazing range of plant and animal species thrive in a verdant landscape of steep hills and narrow valleys amid the citys paved sidewalks.

title: Big Brown Owner Is Trying to Put Troubles Behind
description: Michael Iavarone, a co-owner of Big Brown, the Kentucky Derby and Preakness champion, rang the opening bell Wednesday at the New York Stock Exchange. He said it was the first time he had set foot in those hallowed halls of commerce, which might surprise some of his investors at International Equine Acquisitions Holdings, as well as the public at large.

title: Puerto Ricos Status
description: To the Editor:

title: Now, Add Pimples to the List
description: AS if packing on dozens of pounds isnt bad enough, many pregnant women revert to their high school years, dermatologically speaking. Its no surprise why they get pimples, really: During pregnancy, the body manufactures high levels of estrogen and progesterone. In turn, oil glands produce large quantities of sebum, which clogs oil glands, trapping bacteria and causing blackheads.

title: U.N. Report Seeks Action to Address Food Crisis
description: In anticipation of a global summit on the food crisis, the United Nations called on world leaders Wednesday to agree to urgent measures to ease demand for grains and alleviate high food prices.

title: Back to the Garden: A Woodstock Museum
description: BETHEL, N.Y.

title: Prison for 4 in Attack on Officer Before Killing
description: Four men whose brutal beating of an off-duty police officer at a fast food restaurant in the Bronx set in motion a series of events that led to his death were sentenced on Wednesday to prison terms of 5 to 10 years.

title: In the 800, She Could Be a Contender
description: Before she graduates from Easton (Pa.) Area High School on June 12, Chanelle Price has to finish writing two papers, take two final exams and run in one internationally renowned track meet.

title: Philosophy, Mystery, Anarchy: All Is Lost
description: Among avid consumers of serial television, there is no more hubristic claim than to say that you know Lost know it in every convolution of its intentionally anarchic plot, know it in understanding the real meanings of all of its allusions to Philip K. Dick or game theory, or the Gospel of John, or Nietzsches theory of eternal recurrence.

title: 2 Senators for McCain Leave Group After Ads
description: Senators Joseph I. Lieberman and Lindsey Graham, prominent surrogates for Senator John McCains presidential campaign, stepped down Wednesday from their positions with an independent group that released a pair of Internet advertisements attacking Senator Barack Obama on Iraq.

title: Fox Is King in the Kitchen
description: Hells Kitchen lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Tuesday as 9.4 million viewers tuned in to that reality series cooking competition at 9 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. Although CBSs NCIS repeat earned slightly more total viewers at 8 p.m. (9.7 million), Hells Kitchen remained far and away the nights leader among adults 18 to 49. Meanwhile, Foxs Moment of Truth delivered the second-highest results in that demographic, despite garnering a modest audience of 7.3 million viewers at 8 p.m. Ratings for that game show, in which contestants are questioned after being strapped to a polygraph machine, were down three million viewers, compared with the last time it appeared on Foxs schedule eight weeks ago (although the show had preceded American Idol then). CBS ranked second for the night in total viewers with a rerun of The Unit at 9 (6 million) and a 48 Hours special at 10 (8.3 million). Among adults 18 to 49, CBS finished third behind Fox and NBC, which got a boost from repeats of Law & Order: Special Victims Unit at 9 (7.1 million) and at 10 (7.3 million). ABC was fourth over all.

title: Israeli Defense Chief Asks Olmert to Quit
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Ehud Olmerts troubles increased Wednesday when Israels defense minister, Ehud Barak, called on him to step down from his post pending the outcome of a high-profile corruption investigation.

title: Grunting in East Side Gym Class Leads to Hospital, and to Court
description: Stuart Sugarman was exercising the way he had hundreds of times before.

title: Bush Likens Iraq to World War II
description: COLORADO SPRINGS  President Bush on Wednesday called the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan a great struggle akin to World War II and warned anew against those who would waver in it.

title: Keeping Chlorine Out of the Pool
description: WHEN Pam Glazer, a 53-year-old architect and self-described granola-head from way back, began planning a pool for her home in Southampton, N.Y., she searched for a way to keep it sanitary without using chlorine.

title: California Sets June Date for Same-Sex Marriage Licenses
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Barring unexpected legal action, same-sex couples throughout California will be able to obtain marriage licenses from county clerks beginning June 17, state officials said Wednesday.

title: Digital Life for Analog Keepsakes
description: Millions of baby boomers today live in fear of a diagnosis of AFLS.

title: Burmese Economy Is an Obstacle to Aid
description: YANGON, Myanmar  A sport utility vehicle for $250,000 and a cellphone for $3,000. Such are the prices of bringing aid to Myanmar.

title: Sect Mothers Say Separation Endangers Children
description: Ruth Edna Fischer was first allowed to see her 2-year-old daughter, from whom she had been separated after the raid on their polygamist ranch in Texas, at the childs hospital room. The child had been taken there because of severe dehydration and malnutrition, Ms. Fischer said.

title: Espionage and Dread, With War Offstage
description: On a train bound from Warsaw to Belgrade, Col. Jean-Franois Mercier, the immensely attractive hero of Alan Fursts sinuous new novel, cannot decide what to read. Should it be Stendhals Red and the Black, which a teacher once told him was a political novel, very nearly a spy novel, one of the first ever written? Or should it be The Bar on the Seine, an early Georges Simenon detective story featuring Commissaire Jules Maigret?

title: Minimizing the Chemicals and the Spending
description: FOR pool owners who dont want to spend thousands to go chemical-free, there are more affordable ways to at least reduce chlorine use. Sean Trotter, who owns an air-conditioning business in Plano, Tex., spent $900 for an ozone generator from DEL Ozone after his wife and daughter said that the chlorine in their pool irritated their skin. The system works this way: ozone kills microorganisms and keeps chlorine in its free state rather than turning into chloramine, the odorous compound chlorine becomes after it attaches to organics in the water. Beth Hamil, vice president for corporate compliance and market development at DEL, said the system allows chlorine use to be cut by 60 to 90 percent.

title: Still Painting Messages on Buildings, but No Longer a Vandal
description: A love of graffiti has gained Steve Powers notoriety on the streets, fame in the art world and a long arrest sheet. It has also earned him a Fulbright scholarship.

title: Exxon Rejects Proposals Backed by Rockefellers
description: DALLAS  Exxon Mobils chairman and chief executive, Rex W. Tillerson, defeated a shareholder effort on Wednesday to take away one of his jobs at an annual meeting punctuated by a debate of the companys policy toward renewable energy and global warming.

title: Coaxing Images From a Browser
description: Q. My Web browser is not showing the images on certain Web sites. How can I fix this?

title: How Green Is Diesel?
description: To the Editor:

title: Highlights From Nassau Countys Online Auction
description: Here is a sampling of the hundreds of items Nassau County began offering for sale Wednesday morning on the Web site auctionsinternational.com. Minimum bid for most items was $5, and many had little action as of 5 p.m. on Wednesday, though items seized by the district attorneys office had brisker bidding.

title: By Avoiding a Late Collapse, the Celtics Maintain Control
description: BOSTON  Celtics Coach Doc Rivers said he foresaw nothing unusual or surprising that might happen in the biggest game of the Eastern Conference finals.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Wednesday about television ratings over the Memorial Day weekend misidentified the Nascar race that Fox showed Sunday night. It was the Coca-Cola 600, not the All-Star race. (That race was held May 17.)

title: Urban Areas on West Coast Produce Least Emissions Per Capita, Researchers Find
description: The West Coasts metropolitan areas had among the lowest carbon emissions per capita in the country in 2005, according to a new ranking of 100 urban areas.

title: Deals Fade, and Airlines Look to Cut
description: As the likelihood of additional mergers in the airline industry dims, big United States carriers face a bleak future of making further cuts on their own to survive in an era of soaring jet fuel prices.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: The Personal Health column on Tuesday, about inherited cancers, misstated a viral cause of certain cancers. It is human papillomavirus, not herpes papilloma virus.

title: South Africa Weighs Plan to Shelter Refugees
description: JOHANNESBURG  In the wake of a convulsion of violence against foreigners, international relief officials said Wednesday that South African authorities were planning to establish refugee camps to house tens of thousands of displaced people who had fled their homes in impoverished squatter areas, but the government contended that no decision had been made yet.

title: Leaving Terra Firma on Wings of His Own
description: After a brief nondance narrative prelude about swans and sorcerers that gives us more doppelgngers than we need, the curtain rises on American Ballet Theaters Swan Lake to reveal an immensely appealing image that for some time grows only richer and lovelier. The scene, designed by Zack Brown, is a courtyard or park beside a medieval castle. Trees rise on either side; at the center of the background is the lake of the title.

title: Minaya Defends Handling of Church
description: Omar Minaya maintained on Wednesday that he had no regrets about how the Mets had handled Ryan Churchs second concussion in 11 weeks, saying they based their decisions on regular consultations with Church and the teams medical staff.

title: At Memorial, Nostalgia Is Alive and Almost Well
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  Since its inception 32 years ago, the Memorial has had something no other tournament has had  Jack Nicklaus  then and now the man with the greatest major championship record in history.

title: Frank Lautenberg, Democrat
description: Voters in Tuesdays Democratic Senate primary in New Jersey have an opportunity to choose between a four-term incumbent, Frank Lautenberg, and a nine-term member of the House, Rob Andrews.

title: Agency Sued by 14 States
description: Fourteen states have sued the Environmental Protection Agency, saying smog regulations issued in March watered-down standards for ground-level ozone and air pollution. The states  New York, California, Connecticut, Delaware, Illinois, Massachusetts, Maryland, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, Oregon, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island  were joined by New York City and the District of Columbia.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Front Page

title: When Is a Chair Not Just Seating?
description: The Acuity (starting at $1,250; allsteeloffice.com), right, is a new competitor to the Aeron desk chair. Made of aluminum with an optional leather seat, it has a plastic mesh back and a mechanism that Allsteel, its manufacturer, says adjusts automatically to body weight. Bruce Fifield, the creative director of Design Continuum Italia and the chairs designer, talked about it.

title: A Come-From-Behind Effort Wins the 80th Goldman Pairs
description: The premier event at the Eastern States New York Regional is the Goldman Pairs, which finished Sunday. It is the oldest regional pair championship in the country, and the winners of this years title, the 80th, were R. Jay Becker of New York and Michael Rosenberg of New Rochelle, N.Y. This followed their victories in the open pair events on May 21 and last Thursday.

title: Genome Chief to Step Down
description: Francis S. Collins, who has led the National Human Genome Research Institute since 1993, will step down on Aug. 1 to pursue other professional opportunities, the institute, part of the National Institutes of Health, announced. Dr. Collins, a leader in American efforts to decipher the human genome, said in an interview that after 15 years he was ready for new work but had found it impossible to discuss possible job opportunities without running afoul of conflict of interest regulations. While he considers his next post, he said, he will work on a book about the use of genetic information to develop personalized strategies for preventing and treating illness. The institute said Dr. Collins would be replaced on an interim basis by his deputy, Alan E. Guttmacher, a pediatric geneticist.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on Tuesday about Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons references to her husbands 1992 race for the Democratic presidential nomination referred incorrectly to Paul E. Tsongas, one of his opponents that year. At the time Mr. Tsongas was running, he was a former senator from Massachusetts, not a sitting senator.

title: A Feast of Fancies in Three Robbins Works
description: The titles that the New York City Ballet chooses for its programs can seem gimmicky and irrelevant, but All American Fare is exactly right for the evening of ballets by Jerome Robbins that opened on Tuesday at the New York State Theater.

title: Garden Q&A
Amy Winehouse: Compare and Contrast
description: Lyrics for the Amy Winehouse song Love Is a Losing Game, written with Mark Ronson, appeared on a final exam taken by English students at Cambridge University, the BBC reported. Students were told to compare Ms. Winehouses words with Billie Holidays song Fine and Mellow, Bob Dylans song Boots of Spanish Leather and the Walter Raleigh poem beginning, As You Came From the Holy Land. A university spokesman said that English students had always been asked to compare writers of different eras, according to the BBC.

title: Big Chains Benefit From City Tax Incentives but Dont Create Jobs, a Report Says
description: In 1976, when New York was fighting to stem an exodus of high-paying jobs to the suburbs and beyond, the city created a program of property tax breaks aimed at retaining industrial companies and other employers.

title: Half Off Wholesale (Enough Said)
description: Golden Oldies, a company that has sold antique furniture and accessories to dealers, set designers and decorators for over 30 years, is cutting its inventory in half. Starting Friday, everything in one huge warehouse will be on sale at 50 percent off regular wholesale prices. Merchandise includes copper pots ($10 to $150), chandeliers ($600 to $4,000) and painted cupboards from the late 19th and early 20th centuries ($500 to $2,500). Cash and checks only. Golden Oldies, 132-29 33rd Avenue (College Point Boulevard), Flushing, Queens, (718) 445-4400.

title: German Milk Goes From Cow to Drain in Dairy Strike
description: TEETZ, Germany  As hunger deepens in much of the developing world, here at Jens Gerloffs small family dairy farm, milk splatters onto the tile floor and gurgles through a drain into his sewage system. It is not just a little runoff, but his entire 580-gallon daily production.

title: David Gahr, Photographer of Musicians, Dies at 85
description: David Gahr, who turned his back on a promising career as a scholar to take pictures and listen to music and who as a result landed among the pre-eminent photographers of American folk, blues, jazz and rock musicians of the 1960s and beyond, died on Sunday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 85.

title: DHL Talks With U.P.S. About Carrying U.S. Cargo
description: PARIS  Seeking to end years of losses at its struggling express delivery business in the United States, Deutsche Post, the German mail and logistics group, said Wednesday that it would cut at least 1,500 jobs in North America and hire its rival, United Parcel Service, for air-cargo services.

title: Penny Pinching Looks Great
description: EARLIER this month, people promenading along the super-fashionable Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village were surprised to come upon a decidedly low-rent window display announcing an army-navy surplus store within. Wasnt that a Marc Jacobs store just last week? Could Bleecker be going downscale as fast as it had gone up?

title: An Egg That Dances to a Multicolored Light Show, and 242 of Your Favorite Songs
description: After almost a year spent flailing wildly about and capturing the hearts and minds of Tokyo technophiles, the Sony Rolly music robot is finally available in the United States.

title: When Police Put Their Own on Trial
description: The wood-paneled room on the fourth floor of One Police Plaza looks in many ways like a typical court of law. There are witness stands, a judges bench, a desk for the court reporter and rows of seating for spectators.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article on Monday about challenges to the tax-exempt status of nonprofit institutions referred incorrectly to an effort by local assessors to tax Smith College, arguing that as a womens college it engaged in sex discrimination and thus was not charitable. That effort took place in the early 1980s, not recently, and the assessment involved an observatory owned by Smith in Whatley, Mass.; the assessors were not trying to tax the entire college, which is in Northampton.

title: New York to Back Same-Sex Unions From Elsewhere
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson has directed all state agencies to begin to revise their policies and regulations to recognize same-sex marriages performed in other jurisdictions, like Massachusetts, California and Canada.

title: Lebanon: Prime Minister Is Reappointed
description: Prime Minister Fouad Siniora, left, was reappointed for another year despite his deep unpopularity with the Hezbollah-led opposition. The new president, Michel Suleiman, had no choice but to appoint him after a majority of the members of Parliament gave Mr. Siniora their support. Opposition leaders have often accused Mr. Siniora of serving American interests and governing autocratically. Mr. Siniora was widely expected to lose his position after the recent signing of a political agreement among the countrys political factions. That deal gave the militant Shiite group Hezbollah decisive new powers but left the Western-allied government majority in place. Some analysts said the opposition did not care much who held the post in the current caretaker government, which will last only until parliamentary elections in spring 2009.

title: Amnesty International Seeks Guantnamo Bay Closing
description: In an annual report on human rights worldwide, Amnesty International again urged the United States to close the Guantnamo Bay detention camp. It also said flash points in the Darfur region of Sudan and in Zimbabwe, Gaza, Iraq and Myanmar demand immediate action from world leaders. Amnesty, a human rights watchdog group, accused the European Union of complicity in the practice of rendition, the transporting of terrorism suspects secretly to other countries for interrogation; urged China to live up to the human rights promises it made around the Olympic Games; and said Russia should show greater tolerance for political dissent, and none for impunity on human rights abuses in Chechnya.

title: Czech Republic: Court Approves Fees for Patients
description: The Czech Constitutional Court ruled that the government had the right to demand fees from patients using the health care system. In January, the government began charging about $1.85 for a visit to the doctor or a prescription and twice that for each day spent in the hospital. The courts decision was a victory for Prime Minister Mirek Topolaneks government, which instituted the payments as part of a broader overhaul of public finances.

title: Stop Smoking, With a Little Help From Your Friends
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Approves Adoption by Madonna
description: Madonnas adoption of David Banda, below, a Malawian boy she met in an orphanage in 2006, was approved by a judge in Malawi on Wednesday, The Associated Press reported. Madonna did not appear in court for the ruling, which took Justice Andrew Nyirenda an hour to read. Justice Nyirenda said that he was satisfied that Madonna and her husband, Guy Ritchie, a British filmmaker, are perfect parents. Critics had accused Madonna of getting around Malawian adoption laws because she is a celebrity. Davids father said on Wednesday that he was glad the adoption was successful. The childs mother died when he was a month old; he is now 2.

title: Does the Global Village Come in Petite?
description: AT a recent dinner, friends from Germany and Georgia heckled my reluctance to attend a party in Berlin. They took this as evidence of my tragically American mind-set regarding international travel.

title: Rock on, Retirees
description: Young@Heart, the chorus group of about two dozen elderly performers who cover the songs of an array of artists  James Brown, Coldplay, the Clash, the Bee Gees  are scheduled to play at the Beacon Theater in New York next month. Currently featured in the documentary Young@Heart, the group, which began in 1982 in a center for the elderly in Northampton, Mass., specializes in reinterpretations of rhythm and blues, rock and punk classics. Tickets to the concert, on June 22, are available through Ticketmaster and can also be purchased at the Beacon Theater, Broadway at 74th Street.

title: Czech Health Fees Upheld
description: BERLIN  The Czech Constitutional Court ruled Wednesday that the government had the right to charge fees for patients using the health-care system.

title: Teenager Charged in Upper West Side Shooting
description: A Manhattan teenager has been charged with murder in the fatal shooting of a youth on Saturday outside an Upper West Side apartment building, according to the police.

title: Officer Kills Man After Condo Lobby Attack
description: The lobby of a condominium building in Lower Manhattan erupted in violence late Wednesday, with an off-duty detective fatally shooting one of two men who had attacked the desk clerk and slashed her repeatedly with what the police believe were razor blades, the authorities said.

title: Its No Act, I Need a Job
description: THE posting jumped out from the thousands of others in the rsum section of Craigslist/New York City.

title: Argentina: Farmers Revive Strike Over Export Tax
description: Farmers resumed their national strike after the government broke off talks over a controversial export tax. The tax led to a crippling strike in March that caused domestic food shortages. This time, the farmers are gathering along roadways and stopping trucks carrying grains for export. They also planned to suspend sending cattle to slaughterhouses starting on Thursday. Both measures are to continue until early next week.

title: Excuse Me, but I Think Im Glowing
description: RASHES, pimples, dark spots, stretch marks, weight gain. Is there any good news, besides, of course, the baby?

title: Body Is Found in a Pickup in Queens
description: A body was found wrapped in a comforter in a truck in Queens shortly before noon on Wednesday, the police said.

title: Signal From Mars Is Restored
description: A satellite radio that carries signals and commands to the Mars Phoenix lander restarted last night, ending a one-day delay in the robotic explorers deployment on the Martian surface.

title: Obama Weighs a Visit to the Troops in Iraq
description: THORNTON, Colo.  Senator Barack Obama said Wednesday that he was considering visiting American troops and commanders in Iraq this summer.

title: Richard Zimmer and Leonard Lance, Republicans
description: For years, New Jersey Republicans had a welcome tendency to nominate moderate candidates like Clifford Case, who went on to win successive terms in the Senate. They can revive that practice in Tuesdays primary by nominating former Representative Richard Zimmer for the Senate.

title: Dent Is Still on Randolphs Side
description: A former Yankee infielder on the championship teams in the 1970s who went on to become a manager had some advice for his old double-play partner.

title: Stretch Marks, an Unblessed Event
description: COME down with some kind of aesthetic malaise  a dark patch or a receding hairline  and invariably someone will profess to have the magic cure.

title: Sophie B. Altman, Who Started Quiz Show in 1961, Dies at 95
description: Sophie B. Altman, who in 1961 started a television quiz show for precocious high school students, later added pep bands and cheerleaders and was as surprised as anybody when Its Academic became the worlds longest-running quiz show, died on Saturday in Washington.

title: Coffee Mated to Chocolate
description: The Quick Bite article on Sunday, about the Kent Coffee & Chocolate Company in Kent, Conn., gave an incorrect telephone number for the shop. It is (860) 927-1445.

title: 5 Countries Agree to Talk Over the Arctic
description: Diplomats from the five countries bordering the Arctic Ocean adopted a declaration on Wednesday aimed at defusing tensions over the likelihood that global warming will open northern waters to shipping, energy extraction and other activities.

title: For Lakers, Surprise Comes With Success
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  Phil Jackson walks with a cane now, a byproduct of hip operations and other accumulated aches from a long and storied N.B.A. journey. His gait is awkward, his beard a bright white, but his enthusiasm has a very 1990s vibe.

title: As Star Power Leaves, Residents Start Recovery
description: CANNES, France  On the last day of the Cannes Film Festival, the streets were awash with pale, red-eyed critics and journalists in wrinkled clothes, their credentials slung around their necks, crawling to the end of the two-week marathon of movie-watching.

title: Game 3 Aftermath: The Pens and Crosby Bite Back
description: It was no coincidence that a goal by Sidney Crosby broke the Penguins Stanley Cup final drought  in fact the first two goals in Wednesday nights 3-2 victory at Mellon Arena to pull the Penguins to within 2-1 in the series.

title: The Quad Countdown: No. 92 Wyoming
description: Location: Laramie, Wyo.

title: Chinas Muslim West
description: Nicholas D. Kristof visits the Xinjiang region of western China and finds that local Uighurs dont feel very Chinese despite being part of China.

title: Respond to Todays Column: A Good Day in the Badlands
description: South Dakota, along with Montana, is going to have the Last Primary on Tuesday. When you live in a reliably red state with only 23 electoral votes and no real fund-raising potential, it takes being overlooked in the presidential races to a whole new level. The people here, like Hillary, can use a good moment.

title: Your Comments on my Olympics Column
description: My Thursday column is about the threat of terrorism at the Beijing Olympics. Usually, Chinese officials downplay security threats, but these days theres an odd reversal. The Public Security Ministry keeps hyping the threat from Uighur terrorists, while foreigners keep saying its over-stated. I must say that on the whole Uighurs didnt strike me as discontent as I had expected, certainly more content than Tibetans are and no more unhappy than when I first visited southern Xinjiang in 1993.

title: Left Out in the Dark
description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

title: eGad
Inverness in Talks for Buyout-Backed Joint Venture
description: Inverness Medical Innovations said on Wednesday it was in talks with private equity groups about a proposed joint venture of its health management business for which it would receive about $1.2 billion, sending its stock up nearly 10 percent.

title: Countrywide Officer Wont Join Bank
description: The Bank of America Corporation, the banking giant, said Wednesday that the chief operating officer of Countrywide Financial, David E. Sambol, would retire rather than take over the banks mortgage operations.

title: Exxon Rejects Proposals Backed by Rockefellers
description: Exxon Mobils chairman and chief executive, Rex W. Tillerson, defeated a shareholder effort on Wednesday to take away one of his jobs at an annual meeting punctuated by a debate of the companys policy toward renewable energy and global warming.

title: Lichtensteins Steel Partners Ousts Board of Japans Aderans
description: Steel Partners, the hedge fund run by activist investor Warren G. Lichtenstein, helped oust most of the board of Japanese wig maker Aderans Holdings on Thursday, the first time management of a Japanese firm has been ejected under pressure from an activist fund.

title: Diller Pours Cold Water on Expedia Buyout Chatter
description: Expedias chairman, Barry Diller, on Wednesday dismissed newly resurfaced rumors that the online travel site would be taken private and blamed speculators for trying to make a quick buck.

title: Sonus Phrmaceuticals to Merge With OncoGenex
description: Sonus Pharmaceuticals has found good use for its stash of cash  and perhaps a better shot at survival  by merging with British Columbia biotech firm OncoGenex Technologies.

title: Laud Collier Leads Tread Buyout
description: Private equity firm Laud Collier & Company said Wednesday that it had led a buyout of mining equipment manufacturer Tread. The consortium also included Gladstone Investment and Argosy Investment Partners.

title: ComScore Swallows M:Metrics
description: M:Metrics, a Seattle company that measures activity in the mobile industry, has been acquired by comScore, one of the top trackers of Internet and digital-market share.

title: Judge Approves Linens n Things DIP Loan
description: A Delaware judge on Wednesday gave Linens n Things final approval to tap its $700 million debtor-in-possession loan and cash collateral.

title: Web Start-Up a Joint Israeli-Palestinian Venture
description: Workers at G.ho.st, an Internet start-up in Ramallah, hold a weekly staff meeting  with colleagues on the other side of the Israeli-Palestinian divide. They trade ideas through a video hookup that connects the West Bank office with one in Israel in the first joint technology venture of its kind between Israelis and Palestinians.

title: Russias Alrosa Not Planning I.P.O.
description: Sergey Vybornov, the president of Russian diamond miner Alrosa, has poured cold water on the prospect of the state-owned company floating this year.

title: Are KeyCorps Woes a Harbinger of More To Come?
description: Nobody was expecting an easy year for U.S. banks, but, says BusinessWeek, many observers thought the bulk of the industrys credit troubles would come in the first quarter.

title: Bear Stearns Funds Lose Appeal for Cayman Liquidation
description: Hedge funds with onshore and offshore business may want to think twice about filing for Chapter 15: Two bankrupt Bear Stearns hedge funds lost their appeal of a ruling that denied them protection under the Bankruptcy Code.

title: TPG Said to Seek $7 Billion for New Fund
description: TPG is apparently betting big on financial services deals.

title: Citadel Nabs Another Wall Street Banker
description: Citadel Investment Group has made another key hire from JPMorgan Chase, taking global co-head of securitized products Bill King to lead its own securitized product business.

title: A Battle Over U.S. Sugars Swing-Vote Shareholder
description: For the Mott Childrens Health Center, a corporate takeover offer to buy U.S. Sugar for $293 a share could have meant a payday of $125 million  enough to care for 12,000 children a year for more than 14 years.

title: Greek Shipper Prices I.P.O.
description: An initial public offering of 10 million shares of Safe Bulkers, a Greek shipping company, was priced at $19 per share, a dollar below the low end of its target range, the underwriter said on Wednesday.

title: Hot Ticket in B-School: Bringing Life Values to Corporate Ethics
description: Students talk about Stewart D. Friedman, a management professor at the Wharton School, with a mixture of earnest admiration, gratitude and rock star adoration.

title: A Busch Says Deal Would Be a Matter of Value, Not Legacy
description: A member of the founding family of Anheuser-Busch said any talks with Belgian brewer InBev should be based on shareholder value rather than the Busch familys legacy, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: In Facebook I.P.O. Q&A, the Story Remains the Same
description: Poor Mark Zuckerberg.

title: Gala Feels Chill From Wall Streets Slump
description: Giving away $56.5 million in a night would strike most people as extravagant. But to the tycoons of modern finance, it seems a bit low key.

title: Deals Fade, and Airlines Look to Cut
description: As the likelihood of additional mergers in the airline industry dims, big United States carriers face a bleak future of making further cuts on their own to survive in an era of soaring jet fuel prices.

title: Ontela Raises $10 Million
description: Ontela, a Seattle-based startup that helps consumers move photos from their mobile phone to their computers for a monthly fee, has raised $10 million in a second round of funding.

title: Bears Last Day on Earth
description: You need to have a deal by Sunday night.

title: Iraq Back in the Game
description: Days after FIFA decided to suspend the Iraqi soccer federation for the governments serious political interference in sport, soccers ruling authority reconsidered Thursday, lifting the ban and clearing the way for a crucial World Cup qualifier against Australia on Sunday.

title: Burying Bear Stearns
description: This is Bear Stearnss last day on Earth. The shareholder meeting to approve the acquisition by JPMorgan Chase is at 10 a.m. I assume that immediately after the acquisition is approved, Bear will be merged out of existence as a public company.

title: Yahoos Yang: Full Microsoft Bid Now Seems Unlikely
description: Yahoos chief executive, Jerry Yang, said on Wednesday a potential deal with Microsoft has tremendous power, but the software giant appears no longer interested in a full merger.

title: Clear Channel Says Deal on Track to Close
description: Clear Channel Communications said on Wednesday that its $17.9 billion takeover by private equity funds THL Partners and Bain Capital is now fully funded in escrow with the Bank of New York.

title: The Real Fight Over Fake News
description: The Daily Show is a bellwether for the evolution of Internet video. It is also one of those programs that signify for people why they pay so much money for cable.

title: Buyout-Financing Bankers Said to Depart
description: Bankers who arranged financing for last years largest leveraged buyouts  TXU and First Data  are leaving their firms as the pace of takeovers slows, creating an opportunity for less established lenders to fund acquisitions, Bloomberg News reported.

title: The Early Word: Pelosis Crystal Ball
description: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who has declined to get in the middle of the nominating fight between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama, made both a prediction and a promise about the race on Wednesday.

title: Talks Are on With ABC, Gibson Says
description: Jacques Steinberg reports:

title: Oh, No, Its Him Again
description: Questioning Question Time: George Will doesnt like John McCains promise to answer questions as president in front of Congress in a British Parliament-style Question Time. (I will ask Congress to grant me the privilege of coming before both houses to take questions, and address criticism, much the same as the prime minister of Great Britain appears regularly before the House of Commons, McCain pledged.)

title: A Step to Recognizing Same-Sex Marriages Celebrated Elsewhere
description: Gov. David A. Paterson has directed all state agencies to begin to revise their policies and regulations to recognize same-sex marriages performed in other jurisdictions, like Massachusetts, California and Canada, Jeremy W. Peters reports in a front-page story.

title: In Spain, property experts find it hard to believe official statistics
Farewell to Springtime in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Spring has come.

title: Nashobas Key Dies in Stall Accident
description: In the wake of Eight Belless death after the Kentucky Derby, the Rail had lively and useful discussion about where thoroughbred racing needed to go to insure safety for its athletes.

title: Azteca Producing U.S. Newscasts In Mexico
description: Los Angeles Times: Spanish-language television network Azteca America is now producing its U.S. national and local Los Angeles newscasts from Mexico City.

title: Back to Rome, but Poorer this Time
description: The euro-dollar exchange rate is a killer. No way around it. And no way not to have it affect your experience of every meal abroad, because unless youre made of money, youre gauging the quality of what you eat against what you paid for it. Youre wondering if the enjoyment redeems the expenditure.

title: Soriano Has Answers for Critics
description: Despite putting up big numbers year after year since his breakthrough with the Yankees, Alfonso Soriano has had a tough time earning true superstar status. Maybe being traded for Alex Rodriguez had something to do with the high expectations over the years.

title: Confusion at the Closing of Donnell Library
description: After 52 years as one of the most heavily used branches of the New York Public Library system, the Donnell Library Center on West 53rd Street will mostly close at the end of this week. A small circulating collection will remain open, in the basement, through the end of August. Then the building will be razed to make way for an 11-story hotel. When the $220 million hotel opens, sometime around 2011, a new Donnell will occupy part of the first floor and an underground area, coexisting with hotel guests paying $750 to $2,000 per night for a room.

title: Bear Stearns: 1923  2008
description: Its official: A majority of Bear Stearns shareholders on Thursday voted in favor of the securities firms sale to JPMorgan Chase. The approval  which was essentially a forgone conclusion, if only because JPMorgan already owned nearly half of Bears stock  clears the way for Bear to be subsumed into JPMorgan, ending its 85-year history as an independent entity. More than half of Bears employees are expected to lose their jobs in the sale, which was hastily arranged in March to avoid a complete collapse of the firm.

title: Are You Sure Ridley Scott Got Started This Way?
description: The expression New York minute is taking on literal meaning with a contest that invites would-be directors to unleash their inner Joe Pyktas or Ridley Scotts and make commercials.

title: Thoughts on Tweaking the War on Terror Message
description: During his commencement address to Air Force Academy graduates on Wednesday, President Bush made a fairly uncontroversial declaration. The war on terror, he said, will dominate your military careers. But will it always have the same name?

title: The Scoop on Fattening Ice Cream Flavors
description: Just in time for summer, Newsweek has weighed in with a list of the most-fattening ice cream flavors. In the past several years, ice creams have gotten more fattening than ever as premium brands like Hagen-Dazs and Ben & Jerrys load up their ice creams with chocolate-coated nuts, fudge-laden pretzels, decadent cake and brownie batters and even candy bars.

title: Recipe of the Day: Raita
description: This cooling yogurt concoction from India is salad, relish, dip and side dish in one. The basic recipe here is usually not eaten as is but as the foundation for other raitas; there are infinite variations, and you can take them in almost any direction you like. And you dont need to employ raita in exclusively Indian ways. It is terrific as a dip for flatbread, or, when made extra thick, an alternative to potato salad or coleslaw.

title: New on ABC: To Catch an Illegal Alien
description: First there were Cops on Fox. Soon there may be border patrol agents on ABC.

title: Nobel Winner: CO2 Going to 1,000 Parts Per Million
description: I spent a few minutes Wednesday with F. Sherwood Rowland, the atmospheric chemist from the University of California, Irvine, who shared a Nobel Prize for his work revealing the threat to the ozone layer from CFCs and similar synthetic chemicals. He has a very sobering forecast for levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.

title: Space Quiz Winner
description: After going through more than 200 entries from readers, the Lab judges have picked a winner in the Space Exploration Quiz. You can read about the quiz and see all the entries by clicking here. (You can also still take the 10-question online quiz yourself, or read full explanations of the 10 answers.)

title: Pay Consultants and Conflicts: Not a Problem?
description: There have been plenty of attacks in the last year or so on corporate boards use of compensation consultants to help determine how much to pay C-suite executives. title: Obama Disappointed by Pastors Remarks
description: Senator Barack Obama said Thursday that he was deeply disappointed for new controversial statements that a friend of his delivered from the pulpit of his Chicago church.   This time, the words were not from his former pastor, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., but rather from a Catholic priest who was mocking Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.  During a guest appearance last Sunday at Trinity United Church of Christ, the Rev. Michael Pfleger delivered a blistering critique of Mrs. Clintons candidacy. Mr. Pfleger, a wellknown activist Chicago priest and a friend of Mr. Obama, said Mrs. Clinton felt entitled to the presidency and was stunned by a black man stealing my show.  The remarks from Mr. Pfleger first appeared on several blogs in Chicago on Thursday, accompanied by a You Tube video of his words to the congregation.    When Hillary was crying, and people said that was put on  I really dont believe it was put on, Mr. Pfleger said. I really believe that she just always thought this is mine. Im Bills wife, Im white and this is mine. I just gotta get up and step into the plate. And then, out of nowhere, came Hey, Im Barack Obama. And she said, Oh, damn. Where did you come from? Im white. Im entitled. Theres a black man stealing my show.  In his next breath, Mr. Pfleger wipes his face and mocks Mrs. Clintons tears, saying: She wasnt the only one crying. There was a whole lot of white people crying.  Before he stepped away from the pulpit of Mr. Obamas church that has been under intense scrutiny, he added: Im sorry. I dont want to get you in any more trouble.  Mr. Obama, through a statement released to reporters, said he was deeply disappointed.  As I have traveled this country, Ive been impressed by not what divides us, but by all that that unites us, Mr. Obama said. That is why I am deeply disappointed in Father Pflegers divisive, backward-looking rhetoric, which doesnt reflect the country I see or the desire of people across America to come together in common cause.  Mr. Pfleger, who is the pastor of Saint Sabina Catholic Church in Chicago, a largely black congregation, said he regretted the words he preached last Sunday.  These words are inconsistent with Senator Obama's life and message, and I am deeply sorry if they offended Senator Clinton or anyone else who saw them, he said in a statement released to reporters by his church.  Mr. Obama was not present during the remarks on Sunday. Since he began distancing himself from his longtime pastor about two months ago, he has not attended services at Trinity United Church of Christ on Chicagos South Side.  Howard Wolfson, a chief spokesman for Mrs. Clinton, said the remarks were unacceptable and called on Mr. Obama to more forcefully reject the comments.  Divisive and hateful language like that is totally counterproductive in our efforts to bring our party together and have no place at the pulpit or in our politics, Mr. Wolfson said Thursday evening. We are disappointed that Senator Obama didn't specifically reject Fathers Pfleglers despicable comments about Senator Clinton, and assume he will do so.

title: Bullfighting is Dead! Long Live Bullfighting!
description: "As Spain goes, so goes toreo, or bullfighting, Michael Kimmelman writes in PLAY. In today's Spain, though, a curious divide exists between indifference to and fascination with bullfighting. While the country apparently cares less than ever about what bullfighters do, it is loathe to have people from the outside demand that it's time to do away with this centuries-old tradition. Even as it is ignored by a new generation of Spaniards and attacked by animal rights activists, it persists as a complex part of the national consciousness. There are more bullfights now than ever, and as Kimmelman writes, "Spaniards tell their children to be nice to the dog, but they talk bullfighting with their friends."
