description: By his own admission, Usain Bolt has some bad running habits.

title: A Serial Killers Evolution as Seen From a Marriage
description: Although television has provided a broad outlet for documentaries in recent years, there is still obviously enough competition for scheduling on the most prestigious networks that even someone like the producer and director Barbara Kopple  of Harlan County U.S.A., Wild Man Blues and Shut Up & Sing isnt necessarily guaranteed to show up on HBO or PBS.

title: Politics and Judges: A Matter of Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: New Yorks Shift on Gay Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Shuttle on Schedule for Saturday Launch
description: Both weather and technology seem to be cooperating for launching the space shuttle Discovery on Saturday to begin a mission to the International Space Station. The shuttle, with its crew of seven astronauts, is scheduled to blast off at 5:02 Saturday afternoon to bring a tour-bus-sized science laboratory to the station, the $1 billion Kibo module.

title: Commodity Policies Set for Revision
description: The chief regulator of the nations commodity markets will unveil early next week a set of policy changes to address public and political concerns that market malfunctions may be contributing to rising food and energy prices, according to people who have been briefed about the agencys plans.

title: Court Upholds Key Provision of the Voting Rights Act
description: WASHINGTON  A special three-judge court ruled Friday that Congress acted constitutionally when it extended the law requiring sections of the country with a history of racial discrimination to get federal approval for any changes in voting procedures.

title: Portraying Spirituality of Messiaen as Organist
description: The works of Olivier Messiaen that have traveled best are chamber, vocal and orchestral scores. But Messiaen was an organist, and he composed an imposing body of works for his instrument. This year several organists have taken the occasion of Messiaens centenary to make that point. Gail Archer began a six-concert tour of the major Messiaen works in January, and undertook a tour of Manhattans organs while she was at it, playing each concert in a different church. For her finale, on Thursday evening, she performed the huge Livre du Saint Sacrement (1984) at St. Patricks Cathedral.

title: 2 Campaigns Flare Up Over Iraq Troop Levels
description: MILWAUKEE  A fierce debate erupted on Friday between Senators John McCain and Barack Obama over whether Mr. McCain misspoke at a town-hall-style meeting the previous day when he said that American troops in Iraq had been reduced to pre-surge levels.

title: Jesters of Different Faiths Use Laughs to Bridge the Divide
description: MADISON, N.J.  The Jewish comedian began with a routine about raising adolescents. There was a reason Abraham was asked to sacrifice Isaac at 12 and not 13, he said. At 13, it wouldnt have been a sacrifice.

title: Monks Succeed in Cyclone Relief as Junta Falters
description: KUN WAN, Myanmar  They paddle for hours on the stormy river, or carry their sick parents on their backs through the mud and rain, traveling for miles to reach the one source of help they can rely on: Buddhist monks.

title: Looking Skyward in Lower Manhattan
description: New York has never been very nice to the Los Angeles architect Frank Gehry.

title: Springtime in Paris Is Cruel to the Williamses
description: PARIS  A day that started badly for the Williams family in morning sunlight ended badly for the Williams family in near darkness with flashbulbs going off in the stands.

title: British Banker Group to Strengthen Libor Oversight
description: LONDON  The British Bankers Association said on Friday that it planned to strengthen the oversight of the London interbank offered rate after questions arose about the veracity of the 22-year-old benchmark used to set borrowing costs around the world.

title: A Spiders High Price
description: A four-foot-high metal and fabric sculpture of a spider by Louise Bourgeois sold for $4.5 million, a record price for the artist, at Christies International in Paris, Bloomberg News reported. The sculpture by Ms. Bourgeois, 96, was bought by a European collector on the telephone, competing against three other bidders on Tuesday, the auction house said. Works by Ms. Bourgeois, known for her spider sculptures, already commanded the highest prices for a living female artist. Her most expensive sculpture, an eight-foot-high arachnid, fetched $4 million with fees at Christies New York in November 2006, according to Artnet.

title: The Old Family Tea Business Gets a New-Media Spin
description: TEA is the second most popular beverage among consumers around the world after water, according to the Tea Association of the United States of America, and is found in almost 80 percent of American homes. Sales of tea have increased every year for more than 15 years and show no signs of slowing. R. C. Bigelow, a family-owned company in Fairfield, Conn., is one of the countrys biggest tea producers. Cindi Bigelow is the third generation of the family to take the reins.

title: Berios Love Letter to Schubert, Inspired by Sketches for an Unwritten Symphony
description: The dynamic conductor David Robertson was almost certainly on the short list during the New York Philharmonics search for a music director to succeed Lorin Maazel. Though Alan Gilbert wound up with the job, on Thursday night Mr. Robertson conducted the orchestra in a concert that suggested what qualities he might have brought to the position.

title: Martnez Is Back in Mets Dugout, Bringing His Upbeat Attitude With Him
description: Pedro Martnez was back with the Mets at Shea Stadium on Friday, which meant he was throwing, smiling, joking and trying to bring some stability to a team that has been wobbly without him. Martnez says he believes he can still make a difference, and believes the Mets have to make a difference.

title: Errors Lead Serena Williams to Exit in Paris
description: PARIS  On a gorgeous spring day in the French capital, one where it was easy to forget all the storm clouds of the past week, Serena Williams ended up in a dark and disappointed mood after one of the most surprising defeats of her career.

title: South Africa: Attacks on Immigrants Decline
description: After more than two weeks of attacks on Zimbabweans, Malawians, Mozambicans and other immigrants living in poor townships, the government said that calm was returning and that there had been no additional incidents in the past three days. More than 1,300 people have been arrested for crimes related to the violence in Johannesburg, Pretoria, Cape Town and elsewhere. Thousands of displaced victims will be sheltered in small tents and provided with clean water and toilets.

title: Loss of a Backer Grounds a Business-Class Airline
description: LONDON  Silverjet, the business-class-only airline, on Friday became the third such carrier to cease operations in the last six months, unable to cope with rising fuel costs or to attract new financing.

title: Crane Collapse, 2nd Since March, Kills 2 Workers
description: This time, it was the top of the crane that fell. The huge pieces smashed into the penthouse of a nearby building, then tore off a row of balconies and plummeted to the street in a shower of bricks, dust and debris. Two men, both workers, were killed.

title: City Opera Plans Different Programs for a Shrinking Season
description: While its home is closed for renovations, New York City Opera will shrink its main dramatic offerings next season to one lonely opera: Samuel Barbers Antony and Cleopatra. For two performances. Unstaged.

title: Army Judge Is Replaced for Trial of Detainee
description: The chief judge at Guantnamo replaced the military judge in one of the most closely watched war crimes cases on Thursday, creating a new controversy in the military commission system and the potential for new delays.

title: Job Climate for the Class of 2008 Is a Bit Warmer Than Expected
description: Given that the economy is flagging, this would seem an inauspicious time to be graduating from college and looking for full-time employment.

title: McEwan Opera Delayed
description: The world premiere of the first opera by the novelist Ian McEwan (Atonement), a collaboration with the composer Michael Berkeley, has been postponed because the leading man has voice problems, Media Wales reported. The opera, For You, was to be staged in a partnership with the Hay Festival at Theatr Brycheiniog in Brecon on Saturday and Sunday, before embarking on a tour. But Eric Roberts, a Welsh baritone who sings the role of a womanizing composer, has been told by doctors that he must rest. Music Theater Wales, which is staging the opera, has also been forced to cancel a performance at Clwyd Theatr Cymru in Mold on Thursday.

title: Group Is Said to Bid $3.5 Billion for Weather Channel
description: An investor group led by NBC Universal and two private equity firms appeared to be leading the bidding for the Weather Channel, as final offers were due Friday night, people briefed on the matter said. NBC, the Blackstone Group and Bain Capital were offering about $3.5 billion including debt, these people said. About $1.8 billion of that was in cash, which would be split equally among the three investors. Other bidders for the channel include Time Warner, these people said. A winner may be announced as soon as next week. Landmark Communications, the privately held owner of the Weather Channel, is putting the weather-news heavyweight up for sale as part of a break-up of itself. Landmark originally sought to fetch $5 billion for the Weather Channel.

title: Text of Message Sent to United Employees
description: Following is the text of a message from the chief executive of United Airlines, Glenn F. Tilton, that was sent Friday to airline employees.

title: Mets Give Their Fans Reasons to Boo
description: The Mets left Shea Stadium in a hurry Friday night.

title: The Nucleus Remains, but Changes Await the Spurs
description: LOS ANGELES  Late Thursday night, in a cramped Staples Center locker room, Manu Ginbili talked about pain, Bruce Bowen mused on missed opportunities and R. C. Buford rifled through boxes of stale pepperoni pizza.

title: Chinas Push to Avert Quake Flood Nears End
description: CHENGDU, China  After five days of nonstop digging, engineers said Friday night that they were nearly finished carving a channel they hoped would relieve pressure on a swelling lake that threatens more than a million people already coping with the aftermath of the May 12 earthquake.

title: Coming Late to the Table
description: I guess its official now since we have a Bush administration insider, Scott McClellan, telling us that the war in Iraq was a monumental strategic blunder, and that it was sold cynically and deceitfully to a craven Congress and to a public still traumatized by the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Its Easier to Be Green if It Also Saves Money
description: PRICE matters, and suddenly Americans are seeking to conserve energy in ways forgotten since the early 1980s.

title: Push for New Direction Leads to Sudden Dead End for a 40-Year Naval Career
description: FLORENCE, Italy

title: A Premonition Fulfilled, in a City That Lives With Cranes
description: They knew what it was as soon as they heard the noise.

title: Isolated in Amazon, Visible From the Air
description: Aerial photographs of an isolated community of indigenous people in the Amazon basin, near the border shared by Brazil and Peru, were released this week to show that they exist but may be endangered by illegal logging.

title: Vengeance Revisited, With Singing
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  The macabre and the misty-eyed vie uneasily for supremacy in The Visit, a musical adaptation of Friedrich Drrenmatts 1956 tragicomedy about vengeance and venality, at the Signature Theater here.

title: Billboards That Look Back
description: In advertising these days, the brass ring goes to those who can measure everything  how many people see a particular advertisement, when they see it, who they are. All of that is easy on the Internet, and getting easier in television and print.

title: Baltimore Bids to Ban Selling Small Cigars Individually
description: Hoping to curb the increase in the number of young people who smoke small, inexpensive cigars, Baltimore plans to bar shops from the common practice of breaking open packages to sell them individually.

title: Musharraf Denies He Is Stepping Down
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pressed by a swirl of rumors that he was about to be ousted, President Pervez Musharraf insisted this week that he was staying, and President Bush on Friday confirmed his continued support with a reassuring phone call to Mr. Musharraf, the White House said.

title: Police Told to Give Street-Stop Data
description: A state judge in Manhattan has ordered the Police Department to release its database on hundreds of thousands of civilians stopped by officers.

title: Charles Ober for City Council
description: There will be a special election on Tuesday in the 30th City Council District in Queens, which includes Ridgewood, Middle Village and Glendale. The seat became vacant after the resignation of City Councilman Dennis Gallagher, who admitted to sexually abusing a woman in his district office. Voters in this election, to fill the seat for the rest of the year, should seize the chance to force some much-needed change.

title: A Vote to Ease Executive Changes at Alcatel-Lucent
description: Alcatel-Lucent shareholders, meeting in Paris, voted to make it easier for board members to dismiss and appoint the chief executive and chairman. The new rules allow board members to make such changes by a simple majority instead of the two-thirds majority previously required. Good governance is clearly moving to majority voting, rather than super-majority voting, said Patricia F. Russo, left, who has been chief executive since the company was created by a merger in 2006. Ms. Russo repeated a forecast that sales for telecommunications equipment will fall this year because of the dollars decline against the euro and possible spending delays at some clients.

title: TV Spotlight Shines on Celebrated Street Brawler
description: Kevin Ferguson, who goes by the name Kimbo Slice, has fought in only two professional mixed martial arts matches, and he has a long way to go before he is considered a polished, well-rounded fighter.

title: Climbing Down Off the Screen, Getting Up Onstage
description: Sean (Diddy) Combs has held many jobs over the course of his career: record-label owner, rapper, restaurateur, actor, fashion mogul. On Wednesday night at the Hammerstein Ballroom, he took on another: epistemologist.

title: The Huge Hybrid: a New Twist on S.U.V.s Finds Few Takers
description: DETROIT  Theyve been criticized as gas hogs, dinosaurs and land yachts.

title: Strong Backing for Ex-Governors Appeal
description: Fifty-four former state attorneys general filed a brief Friday supporting the appeal of former Gov. Don Siegelman of Alabama, convicted two years ago on bribery and corruption charges in a prosecution depicted by his supporters as politically motivated.

title: Corrections
description: Front Page

title: States Seek Delay in California Marriage Ruling
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Concerned about the national ramifications of same-sex marriages in California, attorneys general from 10 states have asked the California Supreme Court to stay its decision legalizing the marriages, which are set to begin on June 17.

title: Alvin M. Marks, Inventor With 122 Patents, Dies at 97
description: Alvin M. Marks, a prolific inventor who held patents on polarized film for sunglasses, a 3-D moviemaking process, a generator the size of a grapefruit that could produce enough electricity for a house, a windmill with no moving parts and a trillion-dollar space train, died Sunday in Gardner, Mass. He was 97 and lived in Athol, Mass.

title: In Disclosure, North Korea Contradicts U.S. Intelligence on Its Plutonium Program
description: WASHINGTON  An 18,000-page declaration submitted by North Korea to the United States is stirring debate about whether American intelligence agencies previously overstated how much plutonium the Pyongyang government might have produced for its nuclear weapons program.

title: Michelangelo for Readers With Deep Pockets
description: BOLOGNA, Italy  The gala presentation of Michelangelo: La Dotta Mano (Michelangelo: The Wise Hand), a volume of photographs of this Renaissance masters sculptures, may well have been the most lavish book debut in history.

title: Double-Decker Memories
description: To the Editor:

title: Most Popular Business News Articles on NYTimes.com
description: Following are the most popular business news articles on nytimes.com from May 23 through May 30:

title: Nine Restless Dancers and One Slippery Creature
description: Like many New York choreographers, Susan Rethorst was forced to give up her studio space for financial reasons, but unlike many, she did  or rather, made  something about it. A resulting dance, 208 East Broadway, Part 2: Suitcase Dreams, is a continuation of a work she created in her living room; in its latest incarnation it moves far beyond those four walls.

title: Gaza Strip: Rice Surprised Student Grants Withheld
description: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said she was surprised the State Department had withdrawn Fulbright fellowships to study in the United States from seven Palestinians living in Gaza, and department officials were working to press Israel to reverse its decision not to give the students exit visas. Once students have been selected for the prestigious fellowships, said Tom Casey, a State Department spokesman, It ought to be falling off a log for them to be able to do this.

title: Career Bureaucrat Rises to Prominence in Housing Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  The phone calls have been streaming into the Federal Housing Administration for months now  from White House budget officials, Democratic lawmakers and the occasional cable television news producer  all asking for a few minutes with the man in charge.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press in some copies on Friday about the comic actor Harvey Korman, who appeared for 10 seasons on The Carol Burnett Show, misstated the history of the ending of the show. Ms. Burnett chose to end it after the 11th season; it was not canceled because it was failing. The obituary also misstated the title of the skit in which Mr. Korman and Ms. Burnett played a combative married couple raising the wifes teenage sister. It was called Carol and Sis, not Old Folks at Home.

title: Chamberlain Will Make His First Start on Tuesday
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Joba Chamberlain will make his highly anticipated first major league start Tuesday night at Yankee Stadium against the Toronto Blue Jays. Manager Joe Girardi said he made the decision after weighing a ton of factors, among them keeping Andy Pettitte on normal rest.

title: Ford to Build More Fiestas to Offset Falling Truck Sales
description: DETROIT  The Ford Motor Company, struggling with tumbling sales of its bigger vehicles, revealed plans on Friday to build its new subcompact car, the Fiesta, at a Mexican factory that assembles full-size pickup trucks.

title: Drug Massacre Leaves a Mexican Town Terrorized
description: VILLA AHUMADA, Mexico  A massacre here two weeks ago has turned this once sleepy town into a ghostly emblem of the drug violence that has swept Mexico over the last year and a half, gutting local police forces, terrifying citizens and making it almost impossible for the authorities to assert themselves.

title: Extra Powerful Role Model Will Return to Weight Liftings Biggest Stage
description: ATLANTA  At first, all Cheryl Haworth sought through weight lifting was an extra layer of muscle to help smack a softball farther. Then, before she could legally drive, she awakened as the nations mightiest woman, an overnight sensation bearing the burden of XX-sized role model.

title: Shake-Up at French Bank After Trading Scandal
description: PARIS Socit Gnrale, the French banking giant, announced Friday that it would replace its head of investment banking, Jean-Pierre Mustier, in its latest effort to restore a reputation bruised by a trading scandal.

title: Text of Message to US Airways Employees
description: Following is the text of a message from W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive at US Airways, that was sent Friday to airline employees.

title: Troubled Oceans
description: Five years have elapsed since the Pew Oceans Commissions seminal report urging prompt action to arrest the alarming decline of this countrys ocean resources. Four years have elapsed since a blue-ribbon presidential commission said much the same thing, urging special attention to problems like overfishing and the deterioration of coastal wetlands and estuaries. Despite an occasional burst of energy, however, the Bush administration and Congress have left much to be done. And time is running out.

title: The Worst Way of Farming
description: In the past month, two new reports have examined how farm animals are raised in this country. The report funded by the Pew Charitable Trusts calls the prevailing system industrial farm animal production. The report from the Union of Concerned Scientists prefers the term confined animal feeding operations.

title: Q. & A. on Democrats and Disputed Delegates
description: A potentially fierce political showdown is in the offing on Saturday as Democratic Party officials meet to try to resolve one of the most contentious issues of their presidential primary process: whether to seat the delegations from Florida and Michigan at the partys August convention, and if so, how.

title: Frank Shattuck II, Who Helped Guide Schraffts, Dies at 89
description: Frank G. Shattuck II, the last president of the company that owned Schraffts restaurants, a New York City-based chain that for decades offered home-style food in genteel surroundings to secretaries, errand boys, court clerks and others watchful of their wallets, died Saturday near his home in Bennington, Vt. He was 89.

title: Hudson River Water
description: To the Editor:

title: An International Dispute Over a Humble Tuber
description: LIMA, Peru  They have quarreled over the 1880s pillaging of Perus national library by Chilean troops. They have squabbled over who has the naming rights to pisco, the fiery grape brandy. Now, Peru and Chile are arguing over another hot-button issue: the origins of the potato.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday with an appraisal of the career of the film director Sydney Pollack, who died on Monday, misspelled the surname of the actor shown with Jane Fonda in a film that Mr. Pollack directed, They Shoot Horses, Dont They? He is Michael Sarrazin, not Serrazin.

title: Seattle Asian Museum Moves Around the Corner and Into Its Identity
description: SEATTLE  As the Wing Luke Asian Museum reopens on Saturday, the celebrations here are about more than mere institutional accomplishments. The move of this 42-year-old museum around the corner (after raising $23.2 million for its new home), the size of that new home (60,000 square feet or eight times the size of the old), its expanded ambitions (projecting 60,000 annual visitors instead of 15,000)  all this is a considerable achievement for an institution that used to be housed in an old garage and that now hopes to be an anchor for revitalizing Seattles Chinatown (now part of the citys International District).

title: Colombias Chance
description: Colombias president, lvaro Uribe, may be sorely tempted to begin a final, killing offensive against rebels of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC. The rebels are weakened, and Mr. Uribe is eager to capitalize politically on their defeat.

title: Former EADS Chief Faces Insider Trading Charges
description: PARIS  French judges have filed preliminary charges of insider trading against Nol Forgeard, the former co-chief executive of European Aeronautic Defense and Space, Europes largest aerospace group, his lawyer said Friday. The charges relate to delays in the program to build the A380 superjumbo.

title: Dancing for Dollars (10,000, to Be Exact)
description: Critics may not be able to vote during the four nights of The A.W.A.R.D. Show! choreography competition, but its nice to think that we have a voice in what the events artist director, Neta Pulvermacher, described as an exercise in democracy and in seeing. Think of us as dance superdelegates, surveying the bigger picture from afar.

title: As Iowa Job Surplus Grows, Workers Call the Shots
description: DES MOINES  On a recent evening here, Greg Tew, 28, considered the question: What is it like to work in a state that is creating more jobs than workers? He was sitting in the lobby of a new hotel in downtown Des Moines, part of an extensive redevelopment investment to attract workers to Iowa.

title: Gates Warns China Not to Bully Region on Energy
description: SINGAPORE  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates issued a set of thinly veiled warnings to China on Saturday, cautioning that it could risk its share of further gains in Asias economic prosperity if it bullied its neighbors over natural resources in contested areas like the South China Sea.

title: Alexander Courage, Star Trek Composer, Dies at 88
description: Alexander Courage, an Emmy-winning Hollywood composer whose most famous work was the strange, soaring and instantly recognizable theme from Star Trek, died on May 15 in Pacific Palisades, Calif. He was 88 and until recently lived in Malibu.

title: Fuel Costs Incite Protests by Fishermen in Europe
description: PARIS  Commercial fishermen across Europe carried out new protests on Friday against soaring fuel bills, blockading ports and refineries in France and handing out fresh fish in Madrid.

title: Paterson Faces Suit Over Order on Marriage
description: ALBANY  An Arizona-based conservative Christian group said on Friday that it planned to sue Gov. David A. Paterson to block his directive to state agencies to recognize same-sex marriages performed outside New York.

title: Fox News Employee Sues Over Infestation
description: Two months after Fox News said it had wiped out a bedbug infestation in its Midtown Manhattan newsroom, a network employee who says she was bitten on three occasions has filed a negligence suit against the buildings owners and managing agent and two cleaning companies. In a suit filed Thursday, the employee, Jane Clark, a coordinator in the department that transmits the channels satellite feeds around the world, seeks unspecified damages for pain, shock, mental anguish, which she says resulted from bites on her arms, leg and neck. Ms. Clark is on medical leave. Fox News is not named in the suit. A statement by one of the building owners and Cushman & Wakefield, its managing agent, said tenants were responsible for providing extermination services. Still, the statement added, As a prudent step, we are bringing in outside, independent experts to review the situation. On March 17 a Fox executive said that the infestation appeared to have originated in the home of another employee.

title: Bureaucrats and the Cloven-Hoofed
description: As if theres not enough on its smorgasbord of potential threats, the Department of Homeland Security is studying whether the governments contagious animal disease lab can be moved to mainland farm country from its longtime island outpost off the coast of New York. Members of Congress are properly alarmed at the news that the agency is already considering five possible sites onshore, even though there have been no risk assessments yet on potential relocation dangers to the livestock industry from foot-and-mouth disease and other contagious threats.

title: Crane Collapse Kills Two and Unsettles New Yorkers
description: The collapse of a crane at an Upper East Side construction site on Friday morning killed two workers and severely damaged several high-rise apartments. And it left many New Yorkers pondering an unsettling question: This again?

title: At Exxons Cant-Miss Meeting
description: There were storms around New York on Tuesday evening, and we sat on the runway for hours. I was heading to Dallas for Exxon Mobils annual meeting, which had become this years cant-miss meeting, especially if you are a reporter.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on May 22 about the questioning of three Brooklyn high school students after notes describing a murder plot were discovered included erroneous information from the police about the McDonalds restaurant where one of the named targets worked. It is in Brooklyn but not across the street from the school, James Madison High. The article also misidentified the schools neighborhood. It is in Midwood, not Marine Park.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 22 about the impressions of Jewish voters in Florida of Senator Barack Obama paraphrased incorrectly from a statement by Rabbi David Saperstein of the Religious Action Center of Reform Judaism in Washington, who commented on those views. He said that among the concerns Jews have about Mr. Obama are his past associations and his support for Israel. Rabbi Saperstein did not say Jews are concerned about the senators patriotism.

title: Barcelona Will Play at Chicago and New York
description: F.C. Barcelona will make its third trip to the United States in the last five years and play two exhibition games in August, including one against the Red Bulls, Major League Soccer announced Friday.

title: Pakistani Nuclear Scientist Denies Selling Secrets
description: PARIS  Abdul Qadeer Khan, the founder of Pakistans nuclear weapons program, was reported on Friday to have withdrawn an admission that he sold nuclear technology to Iran, North Korea and Libya, saying that he had made it under pressure from President Pervez Musharraf.

title: Strong Winds Cant Knock the Memorial Leaders Down
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  The second round of the Memorial turned into an all-day survival test Friday, with 25-mile-per-hour wind gusts buffeting the late starters and sending the fields stroke average soaring to almost 76.

title: Farewell, Fair Weather
description: We are now firmly ensconced in the Age of Extreme Weather.

title: Phoenix to Earthlings: Ive Landed! Awesome!
description: @infoholic Yup, I can dig into frozen ground as hard as concrete. The scoop has special blades and a powered rasp to scrape ice. Cool!

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Wednesday about climate change cited the wrong year for the most recent Senate vote on the McCain-Lieberman bill. The Senate last voted on the proposal in 2005, not 2003.

title: Footnote
description: Natasha, a story written by Vladimir Nabokov around 1924 as his career began, will be published for the first time in English in the summer fiction issue of The New Yorker, on sale Monday. The story, which was part of Nabokovs archives at the Library of Congress, was translated by his son, Dmitri Nabokov. It tells of a young woman who cares for her father in Berlin as he mourns their exile from Russia.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about the difficulties of importing natural gas misstated the name of a company that builds import facilities. It is Sempra LNG, a division of Sempra Energy  not Sempra LNGE.

title: Earl Eaton, a Founder of the Vail Skiing Resort, Is Dead at 85
description: Earl Eaton, a dreamer who grew up glorying in the Rocky Mountains of Colorado as a hunter, a hiker, a prospector and a skier, then looked anew at a nameless 11,570-foot-high mountain and envisioned what became Vail, one of Americas most popular ski resorts, died on May 25 at his home in Eagle, Colo. He was 85.

title: Former EADS Chief Faces Insider Trading Charges
description: PARIS  French judges have filed preliminary charges of insider trading against Nol Forgeard, a former chief executive of EADS, as they investigate stock sales executed ahead of the announcement of major delays in building the Airbus A380 superjumbo.

title: Go Ahead, Go Barefoot. The Grass Is Fine.
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan to Send China Aid on Civilian, Not Military, Planes
description: BEIJING  Japan on Thursday decided against using military aircraft to deliver aid to earthquake victims in China after Chinese officials reportedly expressed concerns about what would have been the first Japanese military deployment to China since the two countries were enemies during World War II.

title: Blair Charity to Enlist Religion as a Positive Force
description: Tony Blair, the former prime minister of Britain, formally unveiled plans in New York City on Friday for an ambitious new charity that he hopes will enlist religion as a force for economic development and conflict resolution, rather than violence and strife.

title: Mocking of Clinton at Obamas Church Reverberates
description: CHICAGO  Reverberations from the Sunday sermon of a Roman Catholic priest who mocked Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton at Senator Barack Obamas home church here continued to spread Friday, after the priest offered an apology and the archbishop of Chicago gave him a public reprimand for partisan campaigning.

title: Columbia Takes an Early Lead, but Loses Its N.C.A.A. Opener
description: CONWAY, S.C.  Mike Malfettone hit his first home run of the season Friday in the third inning of a scoreless game in N.C.A.A. Division I regional play here. Columbia, which had not played in the tournament since 1976, was leading Coastal Carolina, the top seed in this double-elimination regional.

title: Vatican Asserts Rule That Bars Female Priests
description: ROME  The Vatican on Friday reaffirmed a ban on ordaining women as priests, warning that the consequences of any such ordination would be the automatic excommunication of anyone involved.

title: Negotiating for a House? Start With Dear Seller
description: A few years ago, when multiple bidders would show up at a real estate open house, the truly desperate resorted to writing love letters to the sellers.

title: Berlioz by the Tarmac
description: A week and a half after a fire damaged its concert hall, the Berlin Philharmonic moved on to playing an airport. The orchestra performed Berliozs Symphonie Fantastique and Mort de Cleopatre in a hangar at the Tempelhof Airport on Thursday night as planes landed nearby, including one during the quietest moment of the symphony, The Associated Press reported. It was the second temporary facility for the orchestra; after a fire caused by welding work tore through the roof of the Philharmonic on May 20, it also performed in an open-air stadium used for rock concerts. The Philharmonic hopes to return to its home, whose interior was not severely damaged, by Monday.

title: Lottery Numbers
Music Critic Must Testify About R. Kelly Sex Tape
description: A music critic for The Chicago Sun-Times who gave the police the tape that prosecutors say shows R. Kelly, having sex with an under-age female must testify at Mr. Kellys child pornography trial, a judge ruled Friday. Judge Vincent Gaughan of Cook County Criminal Court ruled that the defense can question the critic, Jim DeRogatis, about what he did with the VHS cassette between the time he received it and the time he gave it to the authorities, The Chicago Tribune reported. Lawyers for Mr. Kelly, the R&B singer who won a Grammy in 1997 and is known for his raunchy ballads, contend that their client is not on the tape and that Mr. DeRogatis has a personal bias against him. Mr. Kelly, 41, has pleaded not guilty to 14 counts of child pornography. The trial continues Monday.

title: The Generic Washington Memoir
description: To the Editor:

title: The Advice of Youth
description: BABY boomers are facing a new generation gap. But this time, they are the ones on the older side of the divide, at least when it comes to planning their financial futures.

title: Five Diamonds, and Headed to World Mind Sports Games
description: The trial to select the womens team to represent the United States in the first World Mind Sports Games ended on Tuesday in Raleigh, N.C.

title: Legitimizing Marijuana
description: JANE WELLS of CNBC keeps a blog called Funny Business, but her recent reports on Californias medical marijuana industry are about a business that is increasingly being taken seriously. They amount to a short primer on how the business works and how the operators of the states estimated 500 dispensaries deal with the high risks and high costs of working in a legal gray area (cnbc.com).

title: Before the Hunt, a Lesson With a High Flier
description: I WADED into the pitiless mid-May sun with a falconer and one of her favorite birds of prey. The grassy meadow in front of the British School of Falconry at the Equinox resort in Manchester Village, Vt., bloomed with yellow dandelions.

title: Rift Develops Among Investors in Russian Gas Venture
description: MOSCOW  BP, the huge British oil company, on Friday rejected demands from a group of Russian billionaires to fire the head of the lucrative TNK-BP natural gas venture, deepening a confrontation between shareholders as the countrys biggest state-controlled oil companies seek a stake in the venture.

title: From Britain, a Trove of Glittering Prizes
description: Not every exhibition has to be more than the sum of its parts, especially when the parts are as gratifying as those making up Medieval and Renaissance Treasures From the Victoria and Albert Museum at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a ruling by the Texas Supreme Court against the seizure of 468 children from a polygamist ranch misspelled the name of an elder and spokesman of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. He is Willie Jessop, not Jessup.

title: Kicking Back With Kiss
description: It is unclear whether they discussed makeup, but on Thursday in Stockholm, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice had a late-night meeting with the rock group Kiss. Ms. Rice was in Sweden for an international conference concerning Iraq; the band was there to play a sold-out concert and asked to meet her. After a dinner with Carl Bildt, the Swedish foreign minister, Ms. Rice joined Gene Simmons, Paul Stanley, Eric Singer and Tommy Thayer in the executive lounge of the Sheraton Hotel, where they signed autographs and gave T-shirts to her staff. It was really fun to meet them, Ms. Rice said, according to The Associated Press, adding that they seemed well informed about politics. Though she said she had never seen the band perform, she named Rock and Roll All Nite as her favorite Kiss song.

title: Democrats Debate Seating Delegates From Two States
description: WASHINGTON  A Democratic Party committee tried Saturday to resolve the disputes over primary votes in Florida and Michigan, with Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign calling for the delegations to be seated essentially as if there had been no questions about the validity of the contests and Senator Barack Obamas campaign for the first time laying out its proposal for a portion of the delegates to be seated.

title: Norway: Teachers and Health Workers Strike
description: Nearly 5,000 Norwegian teachers and health workers walked off the job, joining 3,300 others who had been on strike since Monday in a dispute over pay. What began as a narrowly focused action is likely to escalate further next week, according to Anders Folkestad, head of the Confederation of Unions for Professionals, about half of whose 270,000 members are teachers. The teachers strike has already affected nearly 30,000 students.

title: Paying Off the Debts That Seem Unshakeable
A Lifetime Amid the Lox and Rugelach
description: Nowadays, most tales of longstanding and beloved family businesses in New York seem to end with a sniff and a final mop of the floor. But as Zabars, the venerable West Side purveyor of New York noshes, approaches its 75th anniversary next year, it is flourishing and still very much in the family. Overseeing aisles of smoked fish, a United Nations worth of cheeses, and the iconic coffee and rugelach is the firms president, Saul Zabar, who will celebrate the 75th anniversary of his 5th birthday next week.

title: Profiles of Speed and Power
description: In Saturdays Times, Joshua Robinson profiles Jamaican sprinter Usain Bolt, who has come out of nowhere this year and established himself as perhaps the fastest man in the world. Also, Mike Tierney looks at how Cheryl Haworth, no longer a media novelty, remains a brute force on the lifting stage.

title: The Quad Countdown: No. 90 Stanford
description: Location: Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Football Is War! (George Carlins Routine)
description: A couple of days ago, we posted a well-written and sharply argued comment from a reader: Football Is Not War

title: Getting to Know  Graham Motion
description: Inspired by the clever American Express print ads featuring celebrities such as Tina Fey and Larry David, I thought wed try a low-budget version for The Rail. First up is Graham Motion, trainer of the Belmont contender and third-place Preakness finisher Icabad Crane. Motion, 44, was born into a racing family (his father a bloodstock agent; his mother an amateur jockey) in Cambridge, England, and now resides in Fair Hill, Md., with his wife, Anita, and his two children, Jane and Marcus. He is ranked 13th on the 2008 earnings list ($2,542,037), with 50 wins in 237 starts.

title: How I Spent My Stimulus Check
description: Some of the odder postings at howispentmystimulus.com (names withheld here; site includes accompanying photos):

title: Bark Lark
description: Fun with trees found here.

title: The Early Word: All Eyes on the D.N.C.
description: The Rules and Bylaws Committee of the Democratic Party meets today in Washington to consider a question that has loomed large over the primary season  what to do about the Democratic delegates from the states of Florida and Michigan.

title: Democrats Meet Over Fla., Mich. in Late-Night Session
description: WASHINGTON  Democratic Party officials met privately for five and a half hours late Friday night to discuss the Michigan and Florida delegations to the partys convention but did not resolve their differences.

title: A Local Immigration Crackdown
description: Sheriff Wendell Hall of Santa Rosa County, Fla., uses false-documentation laws to round up illegal immigrants.

title: Outside the D.N.C. Meeting
description: WASHINGTON  A raucous crowd of several hundred gathered outside a Washington hotel where the rules committee of the Democratic Party is poised to make a decision about the seating of delegates from Florida and Michigan.

title: Frowning on Big Brown
description: Not everybody in thoroughbred racing is giddy over the prospect of a Big Brown Triple Crown.

title: Where have I seen that dress before?
description: This week for the New York premiere of Sex and the City, Sarah Jessica Parker wore a strapless Nina Ricci gown designed by Olivier Theyskens. It was one of 40 outfits that Parker planned for the movies premieres in London and Berlin, and the press junkets. She looked glamorous and happy in the dress and was asked several times by reporters on the red carpet if it was the sort of dress that Carrie Bradshaw would have worn. New Yorkers have no trouble seeing SJP as Carrie, and given the TV shows name-dropping familiarity with the fashion world, what she wore to the opening was bound to get attention. It had to be stand-out.

title: The Morning Skate: Sour Grapes, Melrose Place and Oilers=Man U?
description: Tonight one of the largest Canadian TV audiences of the year will scurry back from their refrigerators and bathroom breaks during the first intermission of Stanley Cup final Game 4 to absorb the words of Don Cherry. His Coachs Corner segment on Hockey Night in Canada remains hugely popular and has made Cherry probably the most recognizable person in the country.

title: Blog Roll: Things We Should Know
description: Our friends in the Thoroughbred Bloggers Alliance have first-rate posts up about the past, the present and the future.

title: Embedded vs. non-embedded inflation
description: The big economic debate of the moment is whether the Fed and its peers have made a terrible mistake by focusing on staving off financial crisis while more or less ignoring the rise of inflation. Inflation is rising and it seems the worlds central banks have critically misjudged the situation, says Wolfgang Munchau in the FT. Ive heard even more apocalyptic views from some serious people in the last couple of weeks.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Saturday, May 31:

title: The World Science Festival: Behind Disneys Magic
description: Disney teamed up with the World Science Festival on Saturday with a show about the science that goes into that old Disney magic. Like most Disney productions, it was very professional and very kid-friendly. Of course the show also doubled as a giant advertisement for Disney theme parks, but I guess that comes with the territory.

title: One Big Puerto Rican Day Parade
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  Campaigning in Puerto Rico is like one big Puerto Rican Day parade, Hillary Rodham Clinton told an audience at a San Juan clinic Saturday. (And as the senator from New York, Mrs. Clinton knows her Puerto Rican Day parades  a festive mega-party up Fifth Avenue every year that attracts New York Citys population of Puerto Ricans by the thousands.)

title: Some Missions Are Just Funnier Than Others
description: Much has been made of the need to fix a malfunctioning toilet aboard the International Space Station. Toilets are, of course, comedy gold. And space toilets? More golden still. So news organizations have had a great deal of fun at NASAs expense lately.

title: On the Road: Obama at Rushmore, Too
description: Late Friday evening, Barack Obama had a perhaps strategic change of tourist heart. A bus full of campaign reporters had decided to pay an end of the day visit to Mount Rushmore and the candidate was rumored to be a no-show.

title: Art and Glitz in Moscow
description: Moscows glitterati, dripping in oil wealth, were at it again this week, celebrating art with a big party, this time at the Manezh exhibition hall at the foot of the Kremlin wall.

title: Obama Quits His Church
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama is ending his membership at Trinity United Church of Christ in Chicago, a congregation he has belonged to for about two decades and one that had become a lightning rod in his Democratic presidential bid.

title: Casino Drive Has Big Brown in His Sights
description: In an article for Sundays Times, Joe Drape writes that many expect Casino Drive, a chestnut colt whose stamina has been leisurely built, to be a formidable obstacle on Big Browns path to become the 12th Triple Crown champion.

title: Belmont News: Saturday
description: Big Browns left front foot continues to progress. It is now equipped with a new set of stainless steel wires that are holding together the quarter crack. Big Brown galloped this morning at Belmont Park.

title: D.N.C. Cuts Fla., Mich. Votes in Half
description: 7:45 p.m. | Rules Wrap Up: After a nearly 10-hour marathon meeting of the Democratic partys rules committee, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton came away with a total of 24 more pledged delegates, but todays decisions on the seating of Florida and Michigan delegates fell far short of what her campaign had hoped.
